DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Monday are as follows:
The China Times:
U.S., British forces may strike Afghanistan Monday, say British media.
The United Daily News:
U.K., U.S. may hit terror camps in Afghanistan within 48 hours.
The Liberty Times:
U.S., U.K. forces plan to attack bases controlled by Osama bib Laden, prime suspect of terrorist assaults on New York and Washington.
The Taiwan Daily:
Former President Lee Teng-hui slams the Kuomintang for alleged echoes of Beijing's intimidation of the current DPP-led Taiwan government.
The Central Daily News:
White House rejects Taliban's conditional offer to negotiate bin Laden's fate.
The China Post:
Ex-President Lee accuses KMT of colluding with Beijing.
The Taiwan News:
U.S. unwilling to bargain fate of bin Laden.
The Taipei Times:
Lee brands his successor as 'pathetic.'

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 1, or the 15th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1868: Mongkut, king of Siam, dies at the age of 64. In only 17 years he implemented sweeping political, economic and social changes with help from the West.
1916: National Peking University Professor Hu Shih's proposal that literature be written in the vernacular language rather than in the classical style wins quick acceptance.
1918: T.E. Lawrence, the British officer known as "Lawrence of Arabia," and the Arab forces of Emir Faisal capture Damascus from the Turks.
1920: The Peking government cracks down on Russian settlements in China.
1921: The Chinese Communist Party sets up a branch in Hunan Province with Mao Tse-tung as its secretary.
1924: Jimmy Carter, an American peanut farmer who became the 39th president of the United States, is born. He was instrumental in getting Israel and Egypt to sign the Camp David agreement ending hostilities between the two countries.
1936: Gen. Francisco Franco Bahamonde, 44, is proclaimed "Chief of the Spanish State" by the nationalist military junta trying to seize power in Spain.
1946: The International War Crimes Tribunal in Nuremberg sentences 12 Nazi leaders to death.
1947: The Japanese Ministry of Education abrogates the name of Kyoto Imperial University.
1949: The Chinese communists set up a regime in Beijing with Mao Tse-tung as party chairman. The regime was recognized by the Soviet Union the next day.
1956: The ROC government implements regulations governing distribution of land to retired servicemen.
1958: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, a U.S. government agency that conducts and coordinates research on flight within and beyond the earth's atmosphere, is formally set up as an independent agency headquartered in Washington, D.C.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes Nigeria.
1964: Japan's "bullet train" makes its first journey from Tokyo to Osaka.
1965: A coup attempt by Indonesian communists is crushed by Suharto, an army officer who becomes president of Indonesia two years later.
1969: The sound barrier is broken by the Concorde 001 during a test flight in France.
1972: Louis Leakey, British archaeologist and anthropologist, dies in London at the age of 69. He discovered the 1,750,000-year-old Zinjanthropus fossil at Olduvai Gorge and the contemporaneous "Homo habilis" at Lake Natron in Tanzania between 1959 and 1964.
1974: The annual three-day meeting of the Sino-U.S. Cooperation Science Program is held in Taipei.
1975: Muhammad Ali beats Joe Frazier in a rematch in Manila. Ali had recaptured the world heavyweight title after defeating the fearsome George Foreman in a sensational upset in 1974. Frazier had beaten Ali in 1971.
1976: Vice Premier Hsu Ching-chung leaves for Lesotho to attend a ceremony marking the kingdom's independence.
1982: Helmut Kohl is sworn in as West Germany's sixth chancellor, succeeding Helmut Schmidt.
1990: The National Unification Council is established under the Office of the President to help plan the policy framework for national unification and to integrate various opinions on the issue at all levels of society.
1997: Gul Mohammed, the world's shortest man at 56 centimeters tall, dies.
1999: Taiwan announces the termination of flights to and from the Philippines after negotiators from the two sides failed in last-ditch efforts to address a stormy dispute over passenger quotas.
2000: Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew says he is "less pessimistic" about cross-strait ties than he had been before his recent visit to Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Every system of moral law must be based upon man's own consciousness. It must be verified by the common experience of men."

DOC.HEADLINE: ONLY HALF OF MAINLAND-BASED TAIWAN BUSINESSES SAID MAKING MONEY

TEXT.P: Only about half of the existing businesses in mainland China that are invested in and operated by Taiwan businesspeople are making any profits, sources from mainland-based Taiwan business and trade circles said Monday.

The number of mainland China-based Taiwan businesses which are making money has gradually declined to an average of about 50 percent of the total, mainly as the result of mainland China's unstable investment climate which has become increasingly volatile in recent years, a Taiwan businessman who preferred to remain anonymous said.

The business leader singled out the prevalence of corruption and overdue payments from buyers as two major factors that have affected all the mainland China-based Taiwan businesses and have prevented many from making any profits.

Widespread graft and corruption have contributed to increasing the operating costs of the Taiwan businesses in mainland China, he said, adding that those businesses making large profits have particularly been singled out as justification for the general existence of the irregularities.
Prominent money-makers have been easily targeted by the local authorities and media, who have "picked holes" in them for no justifiable reason, he said.

He said that things usually turn out okay for the businesses making large profits after they contribute "grease money" to relevant mainland Chinese authorities. He added that otherwise, such companies are subjected to perpetual attacks and fault-finding to the point where they are so battered that they decide to close down operations.

For example, he noted, the well-known Kentucky Fried Chicken franchise, which is currently the most profitable company among the restaurant businesses run and owned by Taiwan businesspeople in mainland China, has received the largest number of threats and extortion demands.
According to another mainland-based Taiwan businessman, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, overdue payments is the major factor that severely depletes a company's funds.

Citing a Taiwan company as an example, he said that after eight years of operating on the mainland, which he said is an ordeal full of twists and turns, the company now finds that it is not making any money at all.

The company's balance sheets have been in the black and its average gross profits have been maintained at over 30 percent, but the company has not been making any profits because it has had difficulties collecting payments from its mainland Chinese buyers after receiving the initial 30-percent down payments.
The credit issue is an unbeatable nightmare for most of the Taiwan businesspeople who maintain operations on the mainland, he said.

Taking an electronics company as an example, he said the Taiwan owner of the company was so indignant with overdue payments that he declared that he would give a Mercedes Benz as an award to anyone among his staff who was able to collect the overdue funds from buyers.

He lamented that the heyday for Taiwan companies operating on the mainland had already passed. He pointed out that Taiwan companies have at most only three to five years left to flourish in mainland China, adding that he himself plans to "pull back" to Taiwan after five years when the "game is over."

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATOR URGES ESTABLISHMENT OF NATIONAL FINGERPRINT DATA BANK

TEXT.P: A legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Monday urged that a national fingerprint data bank be established.

DPP Legislator Wang Li-ping made the appeal during a press conference held at the Legislative Yuan. Central Police University Professor Yeh Yu-lan and Criminal Investigation Bureau official Liu Hui-fu also took part in the conference.

Wang urged the Executive Yuan to keep one of the provisions of the household registration regulations on the establishment of a national fingerprint data bank, which the Executive Yuan is planning to abolish.
She suggested that newborns have their fingerprints taken when they are vaccinated at the age of six months so as to provide a record of identification when they receive their ID cards later.

She noted that a national task force on promoting human rights has questioned the establishment of such a data bank as it believes that this will infringe upon human rights. She added that the Executive Yuan has been forced to cancel the budget for a national fingerprint data bank despite the necessity for such a bank.
Professor Yeh said that the task force should realize that the establishment of a fingerprint data bank will not infringe upon human rights but will instead protect them.

Yeh cited the murder of former Taoyuan magistrate Liu Pang-you as an example, adding that the lack of basic data has made the case hard to crack. Liu and seven others were murdered execution-style in Liu's official residence in November 1996. The case has remained unsolved because evidence at the crime scene was deemed incomplete.

Detective Liu said that a fingerprint data bank has nothing to do with personal privacy, adding that the establishment of such a bank will help in the identification of bodies and of people who have suffered memory loss.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOON CAKE SALES DROP 20% AMID ECONOMIC GLOOM

TEXT.P: The Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States and the trail of devastation brought about by Typhoon Nari have spoiled local business people's hopes of a sales bonanza ahead of the Mid-Autumn Festival, market sources said Monday.

In the past, people began more than a week before the Mid-Autumn Festival to form long lines in front of several well-known bakeries around the island to buy moon cakes, a traditional Chinese snack eaten on the festive occasion.
This phenomenon didn't appear until two days ago, and the average time each prospective buyer spent waiting in line was apparently shorter than in past years, market sources said.

According to market analysts, the anticipated economic gloom following the terrorist attacks on New York City and Washington, D.C., and the extensive Nari-triggered flooding in northern Taiwan have made both business executives and individual consumers more cost-conscious and frugal.

Foodstuff makers had originally hoped that the arrival of the Mid-Autumn Festival, which falls on Monday this year, could help stimulate sales. Much to their disappointment, they saw steeper-than-expected drops in their business turnover from festival-related products.

Based on sales of major ingredients for making moon cakes, such as egg yolks, and relevant packaging materials, market sources said, moon cake sales declined by an estimated 20 percent this year as compared with previous years. Records for previous years show that annual moon cake sales average a total of about NT$3 billion (US$28.99 million).

Although many moon cake makers have lowered their retail prices in an effort to stimulate business, market sources said, the strategy does not seem to have been of great help. Retail prices for specially prepared high-quality moon cakes marketed by major tourist hotels generally fell to below NT$1,000 (US$29) per case, but sales still failed to match levels recorded in previous years.

Some bakers complained that moon cake business this year was even worse than that recorded in 1999 when the Mid-Autumn Festival followed on the heels of the Sept. 21 7.3-magnitude earthquake, the worst natural disaster to hit Taiwan in a century.
Market analysts said the island's protracted economic slowdown has also been a major factor affecting sales of moon cake and other gift ware this year.

A bakery clerk said the best-selling moon cake gift boxes this year were those priced between NT$200 and NT$400 apiece. In the past, the best-selling items were those priced between NT$500 and NT$800.

The Mid-Autumn Festival, also known as the Moon Festival, falls on the 15th day of the eighth month on the lunar calendar. It is one of the most important festivals in Chinese society. Families gather in the evening of the day of the festival to eat moon cakes and gaze at the full moon. Government offices and schools are closed on the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN WELCOMES FUJIAN'S PROHIBITION OF HARMFUL FISHING METHODS

TEXT.P: Kinmen authorities expressed welcome Monday for Fujian Province's decision to prohibit certain types of fishing methods at sea, particularly the harmful practice of using dynamite to catch fish.

Yen Tah-jen, deputy magistrate of Kinmen County, said he is glad that both Kinmen and Fujian, which are separated by a narrow two-kilometer channel, now finally have a common perception that both sides should jointly endeavor to protect fishery resources.
He said the latest Fujian policy serves as a good start in terms of cross-strait crime fighting cooperation, an area in which he believes that both sides will have ample room to do more.

According to Zheng Chuanmao, deputy secretary-general of the city government of Xiamen, Fujian, who landed in Kinmen Monday for a business trip, the Fujian provincial government has recently created regulations which state that fishing by means of using dynamite, poison or electrocution is illegal and that violators will be dealt with severely.

The regulations, publicized at the end of August, stipulate that all individuals or groups shall be prohibited from using such methods, that associations of people who use such fishing methods and who manufacture and sell all equipment and articles for the purpose of such fishing methods shall be disbanded, and that all relevant fishermen shall register themselves and their equipment with their local governments before the deadline of Sept. 15, according to Zheng.

Zheng relayed the latest policy to the Kinmen authorities Monday when he arrived from Xiaman to pick up eight mainland Chinese fishermen who had been rescued Sept. 24 in waters near Kinmen after their vessel ran aground in stormy weather and rough seas.
The owner of the "Zhe-Cang-Ji No. 20" freighter, identified as Huang Dingsang, went missing in the tragedy and remains unaccounted for.
Illegal forays by mainland fishing boats into the waters around Kinmen and Matsu, another Republic of China frontline island, have become increasingly rampant in recent years.

Residents from Kinmen and Matsu have complained that mainland fishing boats have repeatedly sailed across the demarcation line in defiance of ROC marine police forces' warnings and have used dynamite to catch fish.

Matsu fishermen attributed the mainland fishermen's defiance to the "mildness" of the ROC coastal forces, who have been instructed to practice restraint in order to avoid confrontations with the mainland fishermen.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO TAIPEI MRT LINES RESUME SERVICE

TEXT.P: Two Taipei mass rapid transit lines which were partially paralyzed by floodwaters brought on by Typhoon Nari two weeks ago resumed full service Monday afternoon.

The Tamsui Line and the Hsintien Line resumed full service at 1 p.m., and it is expected that about half million commuters will return to using these two lines when offices and schools reopen Tuesday after the national Moon Festival holiday Monday.

Trains on the two lines will be operated manually instead of by the automated system that was used prior to the typhoon. It is estimated that the trip from Tamshui Station to Hsintien Station will take 63 minutes using manual operations, or about 10 minutes longer than the time it takes using the automated system.

The full resumption of service on the two lines will be good news for Taipei, which experienced the brunt of the devastation brought by Typhoon Nari. Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou has said that his most urgent task is relieving the traffic jams that have been a common sight on Taipei streets since the typhoon hit, stressing that "Taipei residents will not be defeated by Nari."

Although service on the two lines has been fully resumed, the trains will not initially stop at Taipei Railway Station or Shuanglien Station, which were badly damaged by the typhoon. Also, the time interval between each train will be between 12-15 minutes, much longer than the average of 2.5 minutes to five minutes when the trains are run using the automated system.

Typhoon Nari, which brought record amounts of rainfall to Taipei, triggered unprecedented floodwaters in many places around the city, including at Taipei Railway Station, through which four of Taipei's five MRT lines pass underground.
Only the Mucha line remained fully operational after Typhoon Nari hit Taiwan Sept. 16-18. The other lines were badly crippled, with the Pangnan Line still remaining closed.
Taipei residents, who have become accustomed to the convenience of the MRT system, have complained about the traffic jams seen across the city over the past two weeks.
Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. executives said that service on the Pangnan Line will be partially resumed within two weeks.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPORTS SAID DOOMED TO BE AFFECTED BY U.S. SLUGGISHNESS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports to the United States, the island's major export market, will be impacted by the sluggishness of the U.S. economy in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on America, Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) sources reported Monday.

The bottoming-out of Taiwan's economic downturn, which was previously expected to occur during the fourth quarter of this year, is now doomed to be delayed as a result of the devastating terrorist attacks in New York City and Washington, D.C., MOEA Statistics Director-General Chang Yao-tsung said.

Taiwan's U.S.-bound exports, which usually experience their high point during the fourth quarter because of the Christmas shopping season, will encounter difficulties this year as the U.S. unemployment rate continues to rise and consumers practice greater restraint in the United States, Chang noted.
He forecast that Taiwan's annual growth rate in the total value of export orders for 2001 will be a negative figure.

After the recent terrorist attacks, Chang noted, the United States' aviation passenger carriage rate plummeted, leading to sudden and prominent layoffs of employees by a number of American airlines, adding that insurance, tourism and related businesses in America have also been noticeable affected.

A spate of typhoons that battered Taiwan in August and September with torrential rains caused tremendous damage to the island's agriculture and industrial manufacturing. Consequently, Taiwan's manufacturing sector is expected after September to decline by an even larger margin than it has in recent months, further driving down the export business, Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MJIB VOWS TO CRACK DOWN ON BANKNOTE FORGERY RINGS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) will investigate whether there is any criminal ring involved in banknote forgery, a senior official said Monday.
MJIB Director Yeh Mao-sheng said he will order MJIB affiliate offices around the island to intensify probes into the sources of bogus New Taiwan dollar banknotes circulating in local markets.
Yeh made the remarks after Central Bank of China (CBC) Governor Perng Fai-nan took to the streets Sunday to demonstrate how to tell fake money from the real thing.

Quoting statistics compiled by major financial institutions, Yeh said the average number of seized bogus banknotes totals about 1,000 per month, with the new versions of the NT$1,000 and NT$500 bills being the most common.

"Compared with previous records, the figure does not represent a marked increase," Yeh said, adding that MJIB agents estimate that the number of bogus banknotes yet to enter circulation might be far larger than that of those seized.

As circulation of fake notes would not only cause trouble for local people but would also affect the stability of the local financial market in the long run, Yeh said the MJIB will step up intelligence gathering to determine who is behind the counterfeiting.
New versions of the NT dollar banknotes were issued late last year as part of the government's efforts to prevent forgery.
MJIB agents said it's no easy task to counterfeit the new versions of the NT dollar bills which have more than 10 anti-counterfeiting devices, marks or materials.
Judging from the seized bogus banknotes, MJIB agents said, individuals are most likely behind the majority of the phony bills.
"Most of the confiscated fake bills were made by either printers or copy machines and can be easily discerned by professional investigators," said an MJIB agent.

CBC Governor Perng visited a traditional food market Sunday to publicized ways of identifying genuine banknotes. Perng's unusual move followed a complaint by Taipei City Councilor Pang Chien-kuo who said food vendors in the city's Huannan market alone are passed an average of NT$1.35 million in fake notes a month.

MJIB agents said, however, that the number of seized fake money has not shown a significant increase. They said that the impression that the use of bogus banknotes has become more rampant since the circulation of new versions of NT dollar bills might result from the fact that fake notes were mostly used in dimly-lit traditional food markets and betel nut vending booths.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANY AIR PASSENGERS SUBJECT TO WAR-RISK INSURANCE FEES FROM OCT. 1

TEXT.P: Beginning Oct. 1, nearly all air passengers in Taiwan will be subject to extra "war-risk insurance" fees which will be assessed at check-in or will be added to the price of the ticket.
The increased fees come as a result of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States and are expected to negatively impact the already depressed local tourism industry.
Starting on Oct. 1, domestic airlines will charge each passenger an extra NT$60 (US$1.73) for each section of a domestic flight, and an additional US$2.50 for each leg of an international flight.
Northwest Airlines will charge each passenger an extra fee of 5 percent of the ticket price for each leg of a flight, the highest among foreign airlines.
In response to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, some foreign airlines have raised their ticket prices between NT$90 and NT$2,000.

In order to retain customers in times of uncertainty and a fall in consumer confidence, some travel agents are trying to absorb the increase in ticket prices and are still selling tickets at pre-war risk insurance rates.
Meanwhile, domestic airlines are promoting their businesses through various measures, including drawings for free airline mileage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN ABORIGINAL CONFERENCE ENDS IN TAITUNG, TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A conference of Asian Aborigines sponsored jointly by the Asian Indigenous People's Pact (AIPP) and Taiwan Aborigines concluded in Taitung, southern Taiwan Monday with a statement supporting Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations Indigenous People's Workshop.

The six-day conference brought together 40-odd delegates from 28 groups of indigenous peoples in Asia to discuss the common problems facing indigenous peoples of difference countries. High on the agenda was the preservation of aboriginal cultures and the autonomy of indigenous peoples.
Taiwan has sent representatives to the meetings of U.N. Indigenous People's Workshops in Geneva for the last seven years but is not a member of the organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD READJUST CROSS-STRAIT POLICY, SAYS AMCHAM CHIEF

TEXT.P: Taiwan should readjust its policy toward mainland China while engaging in domestic reform to restore the confidence of foreign businessmen, said American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei (AmCham) President Richard Henson Monday.
Henson said that a recent AmCham survey showed that its members' confidence in Taiwan has slipped to a five-year low.
He expressed the hope that the ROC government acknowledge the decline in confidence of foreign businessmen and address the situation.
Compared with the steady economic development in mainland China, Henson said that Taiwan is losing its competitive advantage.
What Taiwan should do now, he said, is to develop the island into a global center for the service industry with completely free flows of personnel, commodities and capital.
The AmCham chief pointed out that Taiwan must recognize the fact that mainland China has entered a better stage and is gradually opening its markets and its regulations are becoming more transparent.
He said that many international enterprises have skipped Taiwan to establish their branch offices in mainland China, a situation posing a threat to the prospects of Taiwan's economic development.

Henson said that Taiwan's policy of permitting only indirect trade relations with mainland China has become outdated, and added that Taiwan should employ a new strategy and direction for its economic development.
He suggested that Taiwan use its advantages in language, culture and physical location to play the role of an "economic window" to help enterprises set foot in mainland China.

Henson said that implementation of the "three links" -- direct trade, post and transportation links -- between Taiwan and mainland China will no doubt bring Taiwan's economic development to a new stage.
He said that the "three links" are also required if Taiwan wants to become a window for the world's enterprises to enter mainland China.
Henson went on to say that domestic reform to revise laws is also necessary for Taiwan's internationalization.
In this regard, he said that Taiwan should formulate regulations for allowing professional personnel from all countries to work in Taiwan and revise improper relevant labor and financial laws.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CHANG ORDERS REVIEW OF MUDSLIDE PREVENTION NEAR SCHOOLS

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Monday he will direct relevant government agencies to conduct a comprehensive review of measures to prevent mudslides near schools in mountainous regions.

Chang made the remarks during an inspection tour of the National Taipei Institute of the Arts (NTIA), whose sports facilities were destroyed Sept. 29 by mudslides triggered by protracted rains over the past week.

The arts institute is located on the side of a hill in the Peitou district in northern Taipei. A junior high school adjacent to the institute was also partially damaged by rocks and mud at roughly the same time.

Chang said the government already has measures in place to address the issues of mudslides and flooding near schools on hillsides, but since Taiwan was rattled by a 7.3-magnitude earthquake on Sept. 21, 1999 and after several devastating typhoons hit in the following years, government research data is now out of date.

"In the past couple of years, some places where rockslides and mudslides occurred were not included on the existing list of mudslides-prone areas," Chang explained, adding that the NTIA, for instance, was not on the list.

"We need to conduct an overall review to ensure the safety of all of our schools," Chang said, adding that the Taipei City Government must take precautionary measures to protect private homes near the two schools from being hit by rocks or mud.

Chang said the Ministry of Education, the Council of Agriculture, the Public Construction Commission and other relevant government agencies should join forces to examine ways to protect against mudslides and to recommend other safety measures for schools on hillsides and in mountainous areas around the island.

Meanwhile, Chang said, the government is on high alert for a possible military retaliation by the United States for the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks that brought down New York City's World Trade Center and partially damaged the Pentagon.
"Relevant government agencies are closely monitoring developments of the general world situation and we will take the necessary measures to tackle the changing situation," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC URGED TO KEEP ALERT ON BEIJING'S POSSIBLE SABOTAGE OF U.S. TIES

TEXT.P: Two opposition Kuomintang lawmakers urged the Republic of China government Monday to keep alert on the possibility that Beijing takes advantage of the U.S.-led anti-terrorism campaign to sabotage substantive ROC-U.S. relations.

Fan Yang-shang, a convener of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign Affairs Committee, said the United States and Britain reportedly will soon launch attacks on terror camps in Afghanistan in retaliation for terrorist assaults on U.S. soil Sept. 11.
"The government should pay heed to mainland China's reaction as it may take advantage of the incident to sabotage Taiwan's relations with the United States," Fan warned.

Kwan Yuk-noan, another convener of the legislature's Foreign Affairs Committee, echoed Fan's views, saying that as mainland China has traditionally maintained good relations with Afghanistan and neighboring Pakistan, it has clout in the current U.S.-led anti-terrorism campaign.
Against this backdrop, Kwan said, the ROC government should exercise prudence in handling relations across the Taiwan Strait and ties with the United States at this critical moment.

Meanwhile, officials with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said they generally do not think that the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks would have any significant impact on cross-strait relations.

But both Tien Hsin, director of the DPP's international affairs department, and Yen Chien-fa, director of the DPP's mainland China affairs department, agreed that Taiwan should keep a close watch on the possible impact of post-terrorist attacks developments on the U.S. global strategy.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF APPROVES OPENING OF E-COMMERCE INSURANCE FOR DOMESTIC INSURERS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) approved the opening Monday of electronic commerce insurance services for domestic insurance companies, ministry sources said.
The ministry sources said those enterprises that engage in electronic commerce through the Internet or Internet Service Providers can take out electronic commerce insurance policies.

Provisions of the insurance policies say that insured parties who engage in electronic commerce activities through the Internet can be compensated if they fail to complete trades because of an intrusion by a third party that results in the breakdown of the trading system.
Because the Internet has no boundaries, protection of the new insurance services will cover not only Taiwan, but the rest of the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL STEP UP ALERT, BUT WILL NOT HEIGHTEN WAR PREPAREDNESS

TEXT.P: An official with the Republic of China Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Monday that if the United States strikes Afghanistan in its war against terrorism, Taiwan will step up its alert, but will not heighten war preparedness.

Some foreign news media reported that the United States and Britain are likely to bomb Afghan bases in the near future to arrest or kill the terrorists responsible for the Sept. 11 attacks in New York and Washington.

ROC Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Monday morning that the Executive Yuan (Cabinet) has been on alert over the expected American and British military actions and has a 24-hour hotline open should hostilities break out.
Government agencies have also formulated relevant counter measures, he noted.
The MND official further stated that the armed forces have completed measures in responding to the possible U.S. and British military actions.
In case Taiwan is not endangered by an international war, the official said that the armed forces will only step up their alert and will not heighten war preparedness.
He said that the National Security Council has also instructed subordinate units to step up surveillance over the activities of suspected foreigners in Taiwan.
Police have also increased measures to protect the safety of American citizens as well those from the Middle Eastern countries, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: JANUARY-JULY WORKFORCE DOWN 2.95 PERCENT FROM 2000

TEXT.P: The number of employed workers during the first seven months of this year in Taiwan was down 2.95 percent from the same period a year ago, the largest decline in 20 years for the January-July period, according to government statistics.

The figure also represents an 11-consecutive month fall, or a reduction of 280,000 people in the nation's entire workforce as compared to June and a fifth such shrinkage over the past 20 years, the tallies released recently by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show.

Affected by the Asian financial crisis which occurred in the second half of 1997, the number of the country's workforce fell by 1.05 percent in 1998 during the seven-month period, while it also dropped by 0.5 percent in 1996 due to a sluggish local economy and the war games by mainland China in the Taiwan Strait, the DGBAS detailed, adding that a 1.12 percent fall was posted in 1990 owning to a global recession.

At the same time, the average regular monthly working hours of local employed workers during the same seven-month period was down 9.5 hours from a year ago to 170.2 hours, resulting in an actual monthly income of NT$32,983 per capita, a slight increase of 1.04 percent year-on-year and the second-lowest growth since 1981, according to the DGBAS.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOLUTION IN SIGHT OVER DISPUTE ABOUT NAME OF SINA BASKETBALL TEAM

TEXT.P: A basketball team financed by Chinese-language Internet service provider, Sina.com, might compete in mainland China's National Basketball League using a name without the words "Taiwan" or "Taipei," a move which could placate Taiwan authorities, according to a top sports official in Taiwan.

Wang Jen-cheng, president of the Chinese Taipei Basketball Association, said Sunday that the China Basketball Management Center, which runs the league, has agreed with his proposal to drop "Taipei" or "Taiwan" before it competes in the Chinese National League.
The concession will spare the team, consisting of mainly Taiwanese players, the dilemma of choosing to play either in Taiwan or in mainland China.

The team, founded on Dec. 7, 2000 in Taiwan, has sought to play in the top-ranking A league of the Chinese league, but was required by the China Basketball Management Center to chose a name that showed where the team called home.

However, names including the word "Taiwan" or "Taipei," as proposed by the team, were rejected by Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council and the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports on the grounds that it might boost Beijing's claims that Taiwan is a part of its territory.
Furthermore, the two government agencies said Taiwan professional basketball players are not allowed to play games in mainland China under the existing rules.

Annoyed by the decision by Taipei authorities, Daniel Chiang, president of the E-Ternational Sports Ventures Co., which owns the team, threatened Sept. 28 to stop playing in Taiwan and shift the team's base to Suzhou, Jiangsu province.

In the latest twist in the dispute, Wang said Sunday that at his urging, the China Basketball Management Center has agreed to give up its requirement for Sina to name its team after Taiwan or Taipei. In this way, Wang said, the friendly exchanges between the two sides in the sport of basketball would be maintained.

This deal, however, is still subject to the approval of Beijing's State Administration of Physical Culture and Sports, and the Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council, or the counterparts of Taipei's National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports and Mainland Affairs Council, Wang said.
Beijing's government offices were closed for the Middle Autumn Festival Monday and the situation will remain unclear until Tuesday, Wang said.

Chiang was in the United States Monday and could not be reached for comment. However, Tu Teh-yen, executive director of E-Ternational, said in Taipei that the Sina team would be glad to stay in Taiwan if it can compete in mainland China without using Taiwan or Taipei in its name.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT COOPERATION PRODUCES 500-KG 'MOON CAKE'

TEXT.P: A huge "moon cake," measuring 5 meters in diameter, 20 centimeters in height, and weighing 500 kilograms, was produced Monday in Suzhou, mainland China, with help from both sides of the Taiwan Strait, according to the Beijing-based China News Service (CNS).
The completion of the cake, dubbed the "Zhonghua Reunion Moon," made the Mid-Autumn Festival even more festive for both sides of the Taiwan Strait, the CNS said.
The Mid-Autumn Festival is one of the major holidays for Chinese around the world. It falls on the 15th day of the eighth month of the lunar calendar. This year's festival" fell on Oct. 1.
The materials for producing the gigantic cake were from mainland China and Taiwan, the CNS said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDEPENDENCE EVENING POST FACES CLOSURE FATE

TEXT.P: The financially-troubled Independence Evening Post, which was founded 54 years ago, is likely to fade into history after printing its last copies Tuesday.

As the paper has no money to pay for overdue charges for electrical power, Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) will pull the plug to the paper's printing plant in Wuku, Taipei County, on the morning of Oct. 3.
Facing this new crisis, the paper's management may be forced to terminate printing after Tuesday's issue.

The Bureau of Labor Affairs under the Taipei City Government will invite the managers and labor union representatives of the paper to negotiate for a solution to the financial problems Wednesday, although no positive result is expected.

The paper's labor union has accused former chairman Wang Shih-chien for "viciously embezzling" money paid by the employees for labor and health insurance amounting to NT$8 million, as well as other money.
Wang denied the accusation and stated that he has already handed the post of chairman to Chang Fu-tai.

At the same time, Chang said that he is not in a position to touch on the company's operations at present, and added that he himself is a "victim," having lost NT$10 million since assuming the chairmanship.

The Independence Evening Post ran an editorial Monday to complain that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party was not only reluctant to save the paper from its difficulty, but also insulted the paper's staff over their recent appeal for help.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL ATTEND APEC SUMMIT WITH DIGNITY: GIO CHIEF

TEXT.P: Government Information Office Director-General Su Tzen-ping said Monday that Taipei hopes to attend the Oct. 20-21 Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Shanghai with dignity.

He stressed that as Taiwan is a member economy of APEC, it is unlikely that Taiwan would be absent from the annual meeting, although some officials have suggested that the possibility could not be excluded that Taiwan might be absent.
The customary practice for APEC is that the host country sends a special envoy to present the invitation to the president of a member economy to attend the informal leadership conference.
However, this year mainland China, the host country, failed to follow this practice, and instead it sent the invitation to Taipei via fax in May.
To address this situation, the Presidential Office, the National Security Council, the Executive Yuan and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs have held several rounds of meetings.

As the date for the meeting is just around the corner, the GIO chief said that Taiwan was still engaging in positive negotiations with Beijing with a hope that President Chen Shui-bian will be able to attend the informal leadership conference.
"Our goal is very clear -- to attend the forum with dignity," Su stressed.
He expressed the hope that Beijing will make a decision on the issue as soon as possible so that Taiwan's interest will not be hurt.
Because Taiwan is a formal APEC member, Su said that it seems unlikely that Taiwan will boycott the meeting.

When asked who will represent Chen at the leadership conference if Beijing refuses to allow Chen to attend the meeting, Su said: "It is too early to talk about the appointment of a representative as we are making positive negotiations for Chen's participation."
Last year, Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan represented Chen at the APEC summit in Brunei.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO BE NO LONGER TOLERANT OF FORMER CHAIRMAN LEE'S CRITICISM

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang (KMT) will not be embroiled in a war of words against its former chief, Lee Teng-hui, but will no longer be as respectful of Lee as it used to be, said a KMT senior officials Monday.

That means the KMT might respond to Lee's criticism of the party by contradicting his current statements with those he made in the past, although KMT Chairman Lien Chan, who was the target of Lee's salvoes on Sunday, will not himself fire back against Lee's lambasting.

On a whistle stop for candidates of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) in Chiayi, southern Taiwan, Lee, without mentioning Lien's name, said a presidential candidate who has earned a Ph. D. degree in political science has exposed his total ignorance of politics by trying to oust an elected president though a recall simply because of his unwillingness to resign himself to his defeat in an election.

Lien is the only candidate with a Ph.D. in political science -- obtained from Chicago University -- who was in the 2000 race for presidency, and his candidacy was endorsed by Lee, who was KMT chairman then.
In Sunday's speech, Lee said he rued the day he entered the KMT, not the least his 12-year tenure as KMT chairman, saying it was a period of time when he rubbed shoulders with "a group of rascals."

The KMT has tried to give Lee his due respect, although the party revoked his membership on Sept. 21 after Lee intensified his rhetoric against the party while stumping for TSU candidates. The KMT's new stance toward Lee is mindful of the upcoming year-end elections for lawmakers and county magistrates.

The KMT's departure from its previous tolerance toward Lee was marked Monday by an editorial in the party's mouthpiece, the Central Daily News, which cited Lee's conflicting statements about Lien before and after Lee's falling out with the party, saying it proved that Lee was either "without insight" then or "without judgment" now.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA SETS UP MONITORING STATIONS TO SECURE QUALITY OF CROPS

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) said Monday that it has established 13 monitoring stations around the island to detect agricultural contamination to prevent tainted crops from entering markets.

The COA, Taiwan's highest government body in charge of agricultural policies, took the action in response to two cases of crop contamination found recently at a papaya-growing field and a vegetable farm in Taiwan.

The COA's office in central Taiwan said that the 13 monitoring stations will assist local governments in detecting air pollution by growing specific crops that are sensitive to air conditions. These special crops will be used as indicators of the quality of the surrounding air and may serve as an early warning system.
The COA said that it will also assist local governments in detecting heavy metal contamination and in controlling situations where contamination has taken place.
The COA said that once crops are found to be seriously contaminated, it will buy, store and burn the crops to ensure the safety of consumers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 2, or the 16th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
322 B.C.: Aristotle, Greek Philosopher, dies of a stomach illness at the age of 62. A pupil of Plato, the tutor of Alexander the Great, and the author of works on logic, metaphysics, ethics, natural science, politics and poetics, he profoundly influenced western thought.
1803: Samuel Adams, American statesman, dies at the age of 81. He was one of the signatories of the Declaration of Independence.
1835: Texan-Americans strike the first blow for an independent Texas by staging an armed uprising against the central government of Antonio de Santa Anna in the town of Gonzales, located 108 km east of San Antonio.
1869: Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, Indian leader, is born. He used non-violent civil disobedience in his campaign for Indian independence.
1870: Rome becomes the capital of Italy.
1871: Cordell Hull, American statesman, diplomat, and the secretary of state under President Franklin D. Roosevelt, is born. He was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1945.
1909: A 220-km railway from Peking to Changchiakow (Kalgan) in Inner Mongolia, the first railroad built and owned by China, is opened to traffic.
1918: The world's first public health college is established at John Hopkins University in Baltimore.
1920: U.S. marines, sent by President Woodrow Wilson to Haiti to restore order, clash with rebel forces and kill their leaders.
1924: The League of Nations in Geneva adopts a protocol for the peaceful settlement of international disputes.
1935: Chiang Kai-shek is appointed commander-in-chief of the Northwestern Communist-Suppression Army, and Chang Hsueh-ling is appointed the deputy commander-in-chief, with their headquarters located in Sian.
1942: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt's special envoy, Wendel Willkie, arrives in Chungking to confer with Chinese leaders.
1945: George Smith Patten Jr., American general who led the Third Army's sweep across France and into Germany, is demoted by U.S. Army Chief-of-Staff Dwight D. Eisenhower.
1973: Siri Siriyodhin, Thai speaker of the House of Representatives and head of an 11-member parliamentary mission, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1975: A total of 319 model soldiers are cited to mark the ROC's 21st Armed Forces Day.
1985: The ROC government announces the liberalization of gold imports and transactions.
1985: Rock Hudson, Hollywood star, dies of AIDS at the age of 59.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves the revision of tariffs, lowering the highest tariff rate to 58 percent.
1989: The ROC and Liberia re-establish diplomatic relations. Peking severs formal ties with Liberia in protest.
1990: A hijacked Chinese jet crashes into two parked planes at the Guangzhou airport, killing 127 people.
1996: A Peruvian plane crashes into the Pacific Ocean, killing all 20 people on board.
1998: Sanjaasuregiin Zorig, a popular government minister and the leading figure in Mongolia's peaceful democratic revolution, is murdered.
1999: Overseas Chinese communities around the world donate a total of NT$540 million (US$16.9 million) for victims of the Sept. 21 earthquake in Taiwan.
2000: Premier Tang Fei points out during a meeting on Taiwan's energy needs that he does not think nuclear power is "absolutely safe" or the "only option," but says he is choosing the "lesser evil."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "During the examination of every system of moral laws with the teaching of acknowledged great and wise men of the past, there must be no divergence. Applying the examination to the operations and porches of nature in the physical universe, there must be no contradiction."

Market turnover amounted to NT$23.62 billion (US$0.68 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: MANDARIN TO KICK OFF FLIGHT SERVICES ON TWO INTERNATIONAL ROUTES

TEXT.P: Mandarin Airlines announced Tuesday that it will kick off flight services on two additional international routes despite the sluggish economy.

Mandarin Airlines will this Thursday begin flight services between Taipei and Katmandu, the capital of Nepal. Initially, the airline will offer one flight every Thursday, but it said it hopes to increase services on this route to two to three flights per week.

Mandarin Airlines officials noted that Nepal is an ancient kingdom rich in religious and cultural color, adding that the months between October and March are the dry season in that country, which they said should attract a lot of Taiwan tourists.

In addition, the airline will on Oct. 9 kick off direct flight services between the eastern Taiwan city of Hualien and Miyazaki, Japan. The officials noted that residents of Hualien have always wanted to have direct flight services between their city and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 144.82 points to close at 3,492.12.

Affected by a decline in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 3,623.67 and continued to go down due to heavy selling pressure caused by a lack of confidence on the part of investors. The index fluctuated between 3,623.67 and 3,484.08 during trading.

A total of 1.21 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$23.62 billion (US$0.68 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.32 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$49.91 billion (US$1.44 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 5 percent, followed by electrical shares at 4.8 percent, textile issues at 4.7 percent, foodstuff shares at 4.5 percent, pulp and paper issues at 3.6 percent, construction stocks at 3.1 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 3 percent, and bank and insurance stocks at 1.7 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 538 to 41, with 43 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT UNLIKELY ABLE TO ATTEND APEC SUMMIT: U.S. SCHOLARS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 1 (CNA) (By Eric C.Y. Tseng and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: U.S. scholars said Monday at a seminar at Columbia University that Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian is unlikely to be able to attend the Oct. 20-21 Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum informal leadership summit in Shanghai.

Thomas Bernstein, a political science professor who served as moderator for the seminar, said that because the United States currently needs the support of a big country like mainland China in its campaign against terrorism, he believes that Washington will yield to Beijing's wishes in the end and withhold support for Chen's participation in the annual APEC summit.
Most of the approximately 30 professors and graduate students at the university's East Asian Institute who attended the seminar said that they agreed with Bernstein's viewpoint.

Political science professor Andrew J. Nathan said that he does not believe U.S. President George W. Bush will mention Taipei-Beijing relations during his upcoming visit to Shanghai to attend the APEC meeting because he is busy putting together a global anti-terrorism alliance.
However, Nathan added that he believes Bush will unlikely sacrifice Taiwan's interests just to accomplish his goal of consolidating the anti-terrorism alliance.

ROC presidential national policy adviser Byron S.J. Weng, who was invited to the seminar, said that Beijing failed to follow traditional APEC protocol in the delivery of an invitation to the ROC president to attend the summit, but that subsequent negotiations have progressed to the stage where Beijing has agreed to send a formal invitation after Taipei decides on a proxy to attend in Chen's place.

Chen has been adamant about participating in the APEC summit in person this year. In previous years, the president has always been represented by an appointed proxy because of Beijing's insistence. This is the first time that an APEC summit is being held in mainland China.

In the past, the host country had consistently sent a special envoy to Taipei to present a formal invitation to the ROC president to attend the summit, but this year, Beijing only faxed a brief notice of the summit meeting to Taiwan in May.
The notice did not include the name of the intended recipient and only asked Taipei's senior APEC official to forward the message to concerned bodies.

APEC is one of the few international organizations that simultaneously admits Taiwan and mainland China. A regional forum dedicated to promoting free trade and investment, its members include Australia, Brunei, Canada, mainland China, Chile, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, the Philippines, Russia, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand, the United States and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND APPROVES KIDD-CLASS DESTROYERS PROCUREMENT PLAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) has approved a Navy plan to purchase four Kidd-class destroyers from the United States to help beef up the Republic of China's naval defense capability, military spokesman Huang Suey-sheng said Tuesday.
According to Huang, the MND has given the green light only after a careful evaluation found that the destroyers could meet the ROC Navy's combat needs.
Also approved was the purchase of an unspecified number of Standard II air defense missiles to equip the four Kidd-class destroyers, Huang said.

With a view to winning legislative and popular support for the warship procurement plan, Huang said, the MND will brief legislators and watchdog Control Yuan members on its assessment results in the near future.
The United States agreed to sell Taiwan four of its Kidd-class destroyers in an annual bilateral meeting held in Washington in April on Taiwan's defense needs and its arms procurement plan.
Huang said the office of Chief of the General Staff (CGS) Gen. Tang Yao-ming approved the ROC Navy request last week to purchase the U.S.-built destroyers.

The CGS office then presented the procurement project to Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen for final approval, Huang said, adding that Wu gave the nod in consideration of mainland China's mounting military threat and the ROC Navy's overall combat strategy.

Nevertheless, Huang said, Wu demanded that the CGS office and the Navy General Headquarters continue lobbying the United States to sell the even more advanced Aegis radar-equipped destroyers to Taiwan following the island's purchase of the four Kidd-class destroyers built almost 20 years ago. In addition, Wu was quoted as having ordered relevant military authorities to pay heed to the four warships' future maintenance costs.

The ROC Navy now must complete two more procedures before the sale can go through. The first is a comprehensive analysis of the Kidd-class destroyer and its weaponry systems. The second is the preparation of a budget to allow for the procurement plan worth an estimated NT$25 billion (US$724.64 million). Both steps are expected to take several months to finalize.

MND sources said funds for the purchase are expected to be included in the 2003 budget bill. The MND's spending plans for fiscal 2002 have already been set and no extra funds are available, the sources said.
ROC Navy officials were initially divided over whether to purchase the Kidd-class destroyers.

Navy Commander-in-Chief Li Chieh apparently supported the plan to buy the 9,000-ton destroyers on the grounds that the warships could largely upgrade the Navy's ability to project force on the open seas. However, opponents said the Kidd-class destroyers are simply too big to suit Taiwan's needs, preferring instead to see the Navy buy smaller warships. After a lengthy tug of war, the Li camp won. A formal procurement request was presented to the CGS office in August.

MND sources said Li was able to win partly because of his efforts in seeking the support of members of the Legislative Yuan's Defense Committee. Li reportedly had sent a subordinate to brief each member of the legislative defense committee on the navy's plan to buy the Kidd-class destroyers.

The sources said the legislators were told that the navy mostly plans to deploy the destroyers east of Taiwan, rather than in the Taiwan Strait. According to the sources, the strategy is aimed at expanding the navy's range of operations on the open seas, which the navy said would be good for Taiwan from a long-term perspective.

Li himself also once told local reporters that the Kidd-class destroyers would be deployed as flagships for flexible missions on the open seas to help check mainland China's maritime combat operations.
The Kidd-class destroyers are equipped with radar systems that have an effective range of 350 kilometers and can fire four anti-aircraft missiles simultaneously within a range of 70 kilometers.

Although Kidd-class destroyers are almost 20 years old, military sources said, they still have "plenty of useful life yet." More important, they carry a price tag of only about one sixth of that of a new vessel.

The Kidd-class destroyers were originally built for use by Iran during the reign of the Shah, but the U.S. Navy took control of the ships in 1981 and 1982 after Iran's revolutionary Islamic regime took power. The destroyers, currently mothballed, will be ready for delivery by 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR ANNOUNCES ESTABLISHMENT OF RECONSTRUCTION COMMITTEE

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou on Tuesday announced the establishment of a post-Typhoon Nari reconstruction committee.

Mayor Ma said that the committee will conduct an overall review of the causes behind the heavy casualties and property losses in the typhoon, as well as study disaster prevention, rescue and relief, and post-disaster reconstruction systems, with the results and conclusions to be provided for reference.
The committee will be headed by former vice premier Liu Chao-shiuan, while Taipei Deputy Mayor Ou Chin-der will serve as the vice chairman.

Ma lauded Liu, who held an important post during the reconstruction work in the wake of the killer magnitude 7.3 quake that struck the island Sept. 21, 1999, and who presided over several major projects in the National Science Council, for having rich experience in disaster relief work.

The committee will spend a month studying substantial measures to improve the disaster prevention and rescue and relief systems in Taipei. The conclusions reached by the committee will be put into practice within three months at the latest to speed up reconstruction in the wake of the devastation brought by Nari two weeks ago.

The reconstruction committee will be divided into four groups, with one group studying disaster prevention and relief systems, another studying floodwater prevention and water drainage systems, a third looking into traffic and mass rapid transit systems, and another studying disaster prevention on hilly terrain in Taipei City.
The group studying traffic and mass rapid transit systems will have Taipei Deputy Mayor Ou serve as its head, while the other three groups will have scholars and experts to serve as conveners.
Ma said that he is hoping that the scholars and experts can conduct an objective study and discover some of the problems Taipei City Government has overlooked in the past.

Typhoon Nari, which hit Taiwan Sept. 16-18, brought record levels of rainfall to the island, triggering serious flooding in many places in Taipei. The floodwaters caused the city's mass rapid transit system to become partially paralyzed, with service on most lines only being resumed this week.
In addition, residents in many parts of Taipei had to endure long periods of power outages and suspension of water supply as result of the typhoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LAWMAKERS THREATEN TO REJECT 2002 FISCAL BUDGET DRAFT

TEXT.P: Opposition party lawmakers on Tuesday threatened to send the draft of the 2002 fiscal budget back to the Executive Yuan, saying that the budget's estimated total tax revenue is based on an unrealistic 4.2 percent annual economic growth rate.

After Premier Chang Chun-hsiung submitted his fiscal budget report to the Legislative Yuan in the morning, New Party lawmaker Lai Shyh-bao called a news conference to say that government revenues for fiscal 2002 are overestimated by nearly NT$100 billion (US$2.9 billion) because the Executive Yuan based its calculations on a figure that was far higher than the World Bank's estimate of one percent annual economic growth for industrialized nations.

Lai charged that revenues were overestimated by NT$5 billion (US$145 million) in income taxes, NT$5 billion in tariffs, NT$10 billion (US$289 million) in commodity taxes, NT$30 billion (US$868 million) in securities transaction taxes, NT$30 billion in business taxes and NT$5 billion in profits from public properties.

In the expenditure portion, Lai accused the Executive Yuan of illegally including a new budget item earmarking NT$15 billion (US$434 million) for senior citizen subsidies, saying the move lacks a legal basis.
He added that the Executive Yuan might as well take the draft budget back and put together a corrected version instead of submitting an "untruthful" one.
Opposition Kuomintang Legislator Tina W.K. Pan also demanded that the draft budget be revised to correct the alleged overestimates.

In response, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislative Whip Tsai Huang-liang said that it would be irresponsible to demand that the draft budget be sent back to the Executive Yuan before the Legislative Yuan has even allowed the premier to respond to the charges of the opposition lawmakers in an interpellation session.

Meanwhile, DPP lawmaker Hong Chi-chang admitted that the draft budget "indeed failed to reflect reality" by not accounting for the economic after-effects of the terrorist attacks on America and the devastation caused to Taiwan by two recent typhoons.
However, Hong said that "the economy is dynamic" and that legislators have the duty to evaluate the draft budget instead of demanding that a new budget be prepared.

Premier Chang's budget report to the Legislative Yuan estimates that Taiwan's annual economic growth rate could reach 4.2 percent in 2002 in part due to several factors, including a gradual recovery in global economic prospects, Taiwan's impending accession to the World Trade Organization and an expected resumption of growth in the export sector.

Chang's report also listed private investment in the Taiwan High-Speed Railway, the auctioning of third-generation (3G) cellular phone licenses, the construction of private-sector power plants, and the development of large industrial and commercial zones as likely stimulants for the domestic economy.

The draft budget lists approximately NT$1.3 trillion (US$37.6 billion) in total government revenues and about NT$1.5 trillion (US$43.4 billion) in expenditures. After taking government debt obligations into account, the fiscal deficit stands at approximately NT$350 billion (US$10.1 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: III TO SPONSOR SEMINAR ON PATENTS AND RELATED LEGAL ISSUES
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 2 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung) (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Taipei, Oct. 2 (CNA): The Science and Technology Law Center of the Institute for Information Industry (III) will sponsor a seminar on patents and related legal issues Thursday in Taipei to advise local manufacturers of international practices in patent rights.

A spokesman of the law center said Tuesday that the patent infringement lawsuits between Taiwan's semiconductor manufacturer Via Technologies and Intel Corporation have alerted local manufacturers to the potential problems with patent rights.

He said that Samsung Corp. of South Korea has set up an office in Taiwan to take up legal action against suspected patent infringements by Taiwan manufacturers. As a matter of fact, since early this year, patent related legal issues involving Taiwan manufacturers have increased considerably, he added.

In the past decade, international corporations in the United States and Europe have been paying more attention to legal and intellectual property rights. The computer giant IBM, for instance, has applied for 27,000 patent rights in the United States and its revenues from royalties and penalties amount to NT$1 billion annually, according to the law center.

To promote the awareness of patent rights and related issues, business executives from the software, communications, information appliance, and e-business sectors formed the "e-Patent Technological Alliance" on Dec. 4, 2000.
The law center will invite specialists of the Industrial Delopment Bureau and consultants from law firms to speak on international practices in patent rights applications at the seminar.

The spokesman said that facing patent infringement lawsuits in a foreign land could be very troublesome because there are many incalculable factors involved. He suggested that local manufacturers acquaint themselves with patent-related issues before starting a research and development project, in advance of the production of a new design, and prior to the signing of technical cooperation agreements with a counterpart.

In the event that a company becomes embroiled in a patent infringement lawsuit, the spokesman said that even the choice of where the case will be tried can be key to the success or failure of the suit.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN URGES PREDECESSOR TO SHOW `RESTRAINT'

TEXT.P: Lien Chan, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, on Tuesday urged his predecessor Lee Teng-hui to show "restraint" in his words and not let everyone "lose face."
Lien made the remarks in Chiayi, southern Taiwan, when he called on Chiayi County Magistrate Lee Yah-ching and invited him to represent the KMT in running in the year-end legislative elections.

On Lee's remarks over the past few days while stumping for candidates of the recently-formed Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) for the year-end elections, Lien said that one should "let bygones be bygones."

He also said that Lee, who served as Republic of China president for 12 years and who is a self-proclaimed devout Christian, has gone on tirades and made several personal attacks recently, which Lien said does set a bad example for others, especially children.
Lien expressed the hope that Lee will restrain himself more and not fire salvoes everywhere and avoid making everyone "lose face."

Lee, without mentioning the name of Lien, recently said that a presidential candidate who had earned a doctorate in political science has demonstrated a total ignorance of politics by trying to kick out an elected president through a recall simply because he could not accept his defeat in an election.

Lee also lashed out at Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou for his performance in the wake of Typhoon Nari Sept. 16-18, which resulted in heavy casualties and property losses, by criticizing Ma for being "good at shows, but not good at doing things."
The KMT, after a long period of deliberation, stripped Lee, who had served as KMT chairman for 12 years, of his membership in the party and began to draw a line between itself and its former chief.

Lee, responding to having his KMT membership revoked, said that he rued the day he entered the KMT and that his 12-year stint as KMT head was a period of time when he rubbed shoulders with "a group of rascals."
