DOC.HEADLINE: GARMENT MAKERS TO FACE FIERCER COMPETITION AFTER ENTERING WTO: CETRA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 2 (CNA) (By David Hsu) (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Taipei, Oct. 2 (CNA): An evaluation report of the China External Trade Development Council (Cetra) released Tuesday said that Taiwan's garment manufacturers will face fiercer competition from their counterparts in mainland China and other low-wage regions when Taiwan is admitted into the World Trade Organization (WTO).

The report indicated that the WTO quota restrictions on garment imports are expected to be canceled among WTO member states by the year of 2005. As a labor-intensive industry, Taiwan's garment manufacturing sector will inevitably lose its international competitiveness.
On the other hand, the report said, the capital and technology-intensive man-made fiber sector can expect better market prospects with no quota restrictions.
Taiwan is the world's third-largest supplier of man-made fibers, next only to the United States and mainland China.

Taiwan's textile exports amounted to US$15.2 billion last year. Exports of sweaters and T-shirts dropped considerably from the level of the previous year, according to statistics compiled by the Taiwan Textile Federation.

The Cetra report said that Taiwan has continued to lower import tariffs and to reduce non-tariff barriers, while import restrictions remain rigid in many aspects in mainland China. WTO memberships for both sides of the Taiwan Straits may stimulate the growth of cross-strait trade, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC IN RUSSIA-SPONSORED INVESTMENT FORUM
DOC.DATELINE: Moscow, Sept. 30 (CNA) (By H. K. Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China was present for the first time at a Russia-sponsored international investment forum aimed at forging economic integration between Russia's Far East and the Asia-Pacific region.

S. Y. Tso, chief of the trade session with the ROC representative office in Russia, took part in the gathering held in Khabarovsk in Russia's Far East Sept. 19-20. The forum on Northeast Asian investment was initiated by the Russian authorities and organized by the Russian committee under the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC).
According to Tsao, the forum was meant to clear the way to push for international cooperation between Russia's Far East and Asia-Pacific countries on the transportation and energy sectors.

Forum organizers put forth two major blueprints on building and renewing transportation networks linking European and Asian continents and on constructing pipelines to transport natural gas from Russia's Far East to Northeast Asian countries, Tsao said.

As it was the first time that ROC officials have participated in such an international gathering hosted by Russia and Tsao said the prime purpose of his mission at the forum was to collect related information to serve as reference for relevant ROC government agencies.

But he noted that the Russian side had failed to respond to a request by the ROC representative office to open a trade mission in Vladivostok to serve fishermen and business people from Taiwan in that city.
In addition to Russian officials, mainland China and Japan also dispatched officials and experts to the forum.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTRY OF JUSTICE CONSIDERING USE OF UNDERCOVER AGENTS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) is studying the feasibility of using undercover agents in its battle against organized crime, a ministry source said Tuesday.
Currently, it is unlawful for police to pose as people that they are not and must work overtly.

Tsai Pi-yu, director of the ministry's department of prosecutorial affairs, said the ministry intended to include the ability for police to go undercover in the statute governing the prevention of organized crime which was promulgated many years ago, however, this was never done because of controversy surrounding undercover work.
Following the passage of the statute, the Legislative Yuan approved the law governing the protection of witnesses in 1999, making a step forward for the establishment of the undercover agent system.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE ENDEAVORING TO UPGRADE NIGHTTIME COMBAT ABILITY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Air Force has intensified its nighttime combat training, weaponry systems integration and tactical training, a senior officer in the air force said Tuesday.
Maj. Gen. Yen Ming, head of the operations division of the Air Force General Headquarters, made the remarks while briefing media on the air force's working agenda for the second half of this year.
Yen said the priority of the air force's current training program is to upgrade its F-16 fleet's overall nighttime combat capabilities in the shortest possible time.
In the first half of this year, Yen said, the air force has seen progress in upgrading its weapons, manpower training and risk management.

By the end of June, Yen said, the air force had completed training of seed instructors for airborne and ground service personnel who will be tasked with learning how to operate newly purchased air-to-surface missiles.

In addition to manpower training, Yen said, the air force has also intensified its study and development of combat tactics as part of its efforts to cope with mainland China's mounting military threat.
Yen said the air force has also developed an upgraded version of its air combat maneuvering instrumentation, which has been used by various units to improve coordination and operational efficiency.
In the second half of the year, Yen said, the air force will focus combat-oriented training programs on integration of forces and combat maneuvering.

Noting that defending Taiwan and its outlying islands requires combined services combat operations, Yen said the air force has strengthened air-to-surface combat training and study of combined services combat tactics.

DOC.HEADLINE: NICARAGUA PUSHES FOR TAIWAN'S MEMBERSHIP AT U.N. DEBATE ON TERRORISM
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 1 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng, Jay Chen, and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The government of Nicaragua made a plea Monday for Taiwan's membership during a United Nations General Assembly debate on terrorism, but a U.S. Department of State spokesman said he hoped the debate would concentrate on the issue of terrorism.

Nicaraguan Foreign Relations Minister Francisco Aguirre, who was the first speaker in the week-long debate, told the General Assembly that the "universal calling of our organization" to defeat terrorism cannot be complete "as long as there is a state with profound democratic roots that cannot participate in the full work of the United Nations' system."
He said: "I am referring to the Republic of China, Taiwan."

The General Assembly was called to unite U.N. members into a coalition against terrorism after terrorists crashed two hijacked commercial planes into the Twin Towers of the World Trade Center in New York and crashed a third plane into the Pentagon in Arlington, Virginia on Sept. 11.

Meanwhile, Richard Boucher, a spokesman for the U.S. Department of State said in Washington that he thought the General Assembly's meeting should concentrate on the issue of terrorism and the steps that people can take against terrorism, and that other issues should not be introduced.
But he said at a news briefing that he expected various statements to emerge from the debate because people have different views on the situation.

After being pressed by a reporter for the U.S. government's opinion on Taiwan's participation in the coalition, the spokesman referred him to "everything we have said before," adding that the Department of State has addressed the issue numerous times. "We have a standard policy and it hasn't changed," the spokesman said.
The U.N. voted in 1971 to give the ROC's seat to mainland China.

The ROC has tried since 1993 to have its membership reinstated through its diplomatic allies. They have regularly asked the Assembly to debate the issue but have failed thus far to put the issue on the agenda because of opposition from Beijing, which claims sovereignty over Taiwan.
Nicaragua was one of 10 countries which raised the issue of Taiwan's bid to join the U.N. before the start of the General Assembly earlier this year, but mainland China nixed the idea Aug. 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULING DPP ANNOUNCES DRAFT RESOLUTION ON SUPPORTING TAIWAN ECONOMY

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) vowed Tuesday in a party resolution to build a knowledge-based economy and an efficient and clean government for the people of Taiwan.

The DPP's Central Standing Committee approved the draft of the five-point resolution which aims to "create a knowledge-based economy, develop an open and liberal economy, build a prosperous and equitable society, set up a clean government and become a greater player in the global economy."

Thanks to the sacrifice and contribution by the Taiwan people and many steadfast supporters of democracy, the DPP was finally able to accomplish Taiwan's first-ever power transfer between different political parties in 2000, ending the one-party rule of more than 50 years by the Kuomintang on the island, the draft resolution states.

Although the universal principles of democracy have taken root in Taiwan, it says, the country must step up its efforts to reform its economic structure and build a solid legal system in the face of the challenges after the nation's entry in the World Trade Organization. Taiwan will also have to adapt to the global trend toward trade alliances.

At this historic juncture for Taiwan society and its economy, the DPP hopes to clarify its stance and viewpoints about Taiwan's current situation and wishes to further cement the country's democratic achievements and create a new economic miracle for the Taiwan people, party members said.
The draft resolution, containing 20 policies, will be submitted to a national congress of DPP delegates for final approval on Oct. 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S OLDEST EVENING NEWSPAPER ENDS OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's oldest evening newspaper -- the Independence Evening Post -- will pass into history Wednesday because of long-term financial problems, ending 54 years in business.

The labor union of the newspaper said that they will suspend all operations after publishing a five-page final memorial issue on Tuesday afternoon becuase they have "run out of bullets." Labor union representatives apologized to the people of Taiwan for the decision to close and vowed to continue fighting for the "Independence spirit."

The labor union took over the printing of the newspaper Sept. 14 after both former chairman Wang Shih-chien and the new boss, Chang Fu-tai, declined to continue running the paper. As the newspaper has no money to pay its overdue electricity bill and no other group stepped forward to take over the paper, the labor union was forced to make the closure announcement.

A labor union official said they will continue with their protest to get back the salaries and the labor and insurance payments owning to them by the newspaper authorities. The labor union has decided to hold a farewell "funeral" for the Independence Post on Oct. 10 -- its founding day -- to highlight their demands.
Wang lamented the closing, saying that he is willing to re-start the newspaper should its staff seek his help.

But Wang clarified that he is willing to take over the management of the Independence Evening Post again only because of his passion and personal feelings about the newspaper. "This has nothing to do with the debts of the paper or the state of operations now," he stressed.

Wang had transferred the newspaper's management in a symbolic gesture to a new team led by Chang in late July following a serious labor-management row in which the working staff accused Wang of embezzling as much as NT$8 million worth of their labor and insurance payments and other money.
Chang was not available for comment Tuesday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTRY MUM ON REPORT OF U.S. MILITARY ASSESSMENT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) declined to make any comment Tuesday on a newspaper report that the U.S. military has completed a "net assessment" of the Republic of China Army's logistics and combat capabilities.

MND spokesman Huang Suey-sheng said at a routine news conference that it is the ministry's established policy to refrain from explaining or commenting on military exchanges and cooperation with other countries as well as any arms procurement issues.
A local newspaper reported Tuesday that a U.S. military delegation has finalized a so-called "Vanguard Project" report which evaluates the ROC Army's strengths and weaknesses.
Huang would not confirm whether there was such a project or not. He instead said Taiwan and the United States have a long history of military exchanges and cooperation.

ROC military sources said the U.S. military sent delegations to conduct a two-phase net assessment of the ROC Army's air-defense skills in the field as well as its ability to repulse attack and the combat abilities of the combined services over the past year.

Net assessment is an evaluation method adopted by the U.S. military to assess the strengths and weaknesses of a country's military. It evaluates military capability using both qualitative and quantitative factors.

The net assessment report to be written on Taiwan is expected to weigh heavily on the U.S. Pentagon's decisions concerning arm sales to Taiwan's army in the years to come and Taiwan's possible role in any Asia-Pacific security mechanisms, army sources said.
According to the sources, the U.S. military also sent similar delegations to Taiwan last year to evaluate the ROC Air Force and the ROC Navy's weaponry needs.

Meanwhile, MND spokesman Huang said the ROC military has stepped up its alert amid reports that the United States and Britain are ready to launch attacks on terror camps in Afghanistan believed to be controlled by Osama bin Laden, the prime suspect of the Sept. 11 terrorist assaults in New York and Washington.
Nevertheless, Huang said, the ROC military will not heighten its combat preparedness nor will it change its normal training or working schedules.
"We'll keep a close watch on the latest developments in the U.S.-led anti-terrorism campaign and step up intelligence gathering to prevent any contingencies," Huang said.
He said the ROC Air Force has tightened security measures at its air bases and major installations.

Moreover, Huang said, the ROC military has formulated a comprehensive package of measures to cope with possible biological terrorist attacks. "We are capable of detecting and countering any possible biological strikes," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE CANDIDATES PROMISE POLLUTION-FREE CAMPAIGN ACTIVITIES

TEXT.P: More than 30 candidates for the upcoming legislative elections signed up a self-discipline accord Tuesday promising to make every possible effort to prevent their campaign activities from polluting the domestic environment.

The pollution-free campaign was initiated by 15 local environmental groups, including the Homemakers' Union and Foundation (HUF), the Taiwan Environmental Protection Alliance and the Green Front Association.

Five candidates for the legislative elections slated for Dec. 1, including incumbent Legislators Lai Shyh-bao and Lai Ching-lin, signed the pollution-free campaign accord at a news conference held in the Legislative Yuan.
Thirty-one other candidates already signed the self-discipline accord last week, organizers said.
HUF Chairwoman Chen Man-li said Taiwan's "election culture" should be changed and reformed in order to upgrade the quality of living here.
"We hope that legislative candidates will take the lead in promoting environmental protection by committing themselves to pollution-free campaign activities," Chen said.

Under the self-discipline accord, the signatories must publicize their campaign budget, use recycled paper for their campaign literature, keep the number of their campaign banners under 5,000, refrain from using disposable cups and bowls at their campaign offices, clean up all garbage after every campaign rally, minimize noise and do every effort to conserve resources.

The signatories also promised that if they are elected, they would push for legislation of an environmental protection law, establishment of an environmental and resources conservation ministry and creation of a nuclear-free living environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUDDHIST GROUP DONATES US$200,000 TO ASSIST SEPT. 11 VICTIMS
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Oct. 1 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: An overseas Chinese Buddhist foundation in the San Francisco Bay area donated US$200,000 Monday to assist victims and their families of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States.
This is the largest amount of money that overseas Chinese in the Bay area have donated since the attacks.

Representatives of the Buddhist foundation, whose name they wished to remain anonymous, presented the donation to the Silicon Valley-based Chinese American Alliance for the Relief of Victims of Disasters. The alliance will transfer the donation to victims and their families.

As of Monday, the alliance has received more than US$300,000 in donations, alliance sources said, adding that US$65,000 donated by the Trident Inc., a famous Chinese American-funded semiconductor manufacturing company, will be sent to the alliance in the next few days.
Besides the alliance, many overseas Chinese-funded high-technology companies have also donated money through different channels for victims' relief.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN POISED TO IMPLEMENT NEW FOREIGN LABOR POLICY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government is to implement a new foreign labor policy within two weeks and has informed several countries whose laborers could be affected, Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Chairwoman Chen Chu said Tuesday.

Chen said that during the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum labor ministers' meeting in Tokyo last week, she told labor affairs ministers and vice ministers of Indonesia, the Philippines and Thailand that the ROC government will soon revise its current foreign labor policy to carry out a decision reached by consensus during the Economic Development Advisory Conference in August.

Stressing that "Taiwan's foreign labor policy cannot be stationary in these changing times," Chen said it must be adjusted in compliance with the country's overall labor market condition and economic situation and in line with basic human rights.
"Taiwan has the authority to make its own policy," she noted.

The CLA chief vowed that foreign laborers will be fully protected in Taiwan, as long as their mother countries accept Taiwan's new measures. "If a country has difficulty accepting Taiwan's revised rules, we will no longer import laborers from that country," she added.

Chen said she had made it clear to the Philippine vice labor affairs minister that "Taiwan is opposed to de-linking wages of Taiwan workers and foreign workers. We feel that both are subject to the ROC law which stipulates that housing and food are covered in their wages."

According to Chen, the new measures are to be made public in two weeks. Among the changes will be a raise in housing and food charges for foreign workers and a decrease in the total number of workers imported.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOWER THAN EXPECTED GROWTH WILL NOT RENDER BUDGET INFEASIBLE

TEXT.P: The government's budget as planned for next year will still be feasible even if economic growth fails to live up to expectations, Premier Chang Chung-hsiung said Tuesday.

In a defense of the government's 2002 budget, which was prepared based on a projected economic growth rate of 4.2 percent next year, the premier told the Legislative Yuan that this projection was made in July and might be a little bit too optimistic since it failed to foresee the economic fallout from the terrorists attacks in New York and Washington on Sept. 11.

However, economic growth is only one of many factors taken into account by government planners in shaping the budget, he said. Even if the actual growth is less than expected, the proposed budget should be possible, Chang said.

The 4.2 percent projection was listed in the government's written report on its budget but was omitted in the premier's verbal report to the legislature because the basis on which it was forecast changed after the Sept. 11 attacks.

The terrorists attacks in the United States and their subsequent after effects have driven down almost every stock index in the world and have clouded the already gloomy prospect for global economic recovery.

In an attempt to gauge the economic impacts of the attacks, U.S.-based Wharton Econometric Forecasting Associates predicted on Sept. 21 that Taiwan's economy will post a moderate growth of 1.6 percent next year -- far short of the projection by Taipei officials.

Several opposition lawmakers have asked the Legislative Yuan to return the budget to the Executive Yuan to review because it failed to take into account the government's need to carry out recommendations made by the Economic Development Advisory Conference, and the relief necessary after the destruction caused by typhoons Toraji, Nari and Lekima. The lawmakers also pointed to the uncertainty arising from the Sept. 11 attacks in the United States.

In his response, Chang assured the lawmakers that the government's budget is sufficient to cover the needs for all the tasks despite the fact that the budget plan was made well before the economic conference and the typhoons.

DOC.HEADLINE: RISK VERY LOW FOR MAD COW DISEASE TO ENTER TAIWAN: COA

TEXT.P: The risk of mad cow disease making its way to Taiwan is very low, a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Tuesday.
Chiang Yi-nan, a COA official in charge of the quarantine of animals and plants, made the remark in response to the outbreak of the disease recently in Japan.
Chiang said that because Taiwan has prohibited the use of animal bone meal to feed ruminant animals since 1990, the risk of mad cow disease entering the island is very small.
He said Japan was originally a high-risk area for mad cow disease because it had not banned the use of bone meal in animal feed until after the disease appeared in the country, Chiang said.
The COA official said that the mad cow disease virus can exist within animal bone meal and that if ruminant animals such as cattle and sheep eat contaminated feed, the disease will spread rapidly.
Although the risk of mad cow disease entering Taiwan is very low, the COA and other governmental departments have formed an emergency task force to prevent Taiwan from being affected by the disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: DENYING TAIWAN U.N. MEMBERSHIP AN INJUSTICE: CANADIAN EDITORIAL

TEXT.P: The time has come to consider Taiwan's bid for membership of the United Nations, said a letter to the editor which appeared in the Tuesday edition of the Ottawa Citizen newspaper.
The title of the short letter is "Taiwan deserves a seat at the United Nations."
The letter said it has taken a steady hand and a strong voice to bring Taiwan where it is today in the international community.
"All Taiwan asks for now is the opportunity to be treated as an equal among the nations of the world," said Kuo Chun-yan, president of the Taiwanese-Canadian Association of Ottawa.
Kuo said Taiwan's geographic location makes it strategically important for lasting peace in East Asia and the Pacific region.

To deny UN membership to what, by all account, is an independent nation, fully capable of meeting and even exceeding the requirements of membership, is an "injustice unlike any other in the world today," he stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: 100,000 BOOKS IN MEDICAL UNIVERSITY LIBRARY DESTROYED IN FLOODING

TEXT.P: Flooding from Typhoon Nari has destroyed the entire collection of 100,000 books in the library of the Taipei Medical University, university sources said Tuesday.

The university estimates that the losses in books alone could reach NT$75 million (US$2.17 million) and if the time spent gathering the books together over the last 40 years is figured in, the loss could top NT$100 million.

The university's preliminary plan is to spend NT$30 million over two years to restock basic books for all its departments. It also plans to urge alumni and the public to donate books to rebuild the library.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 3, or the 17th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1863: U.S. President Abraham Lincoln officially designates the last Thursday of November a national holiday, to be called Thanksgiving Day.
1867: Elias Howe, the U.S. inventor and manufacturer who designed early sewing machines, dies at the age of 48. He patented the sewing machine and made about US$2 million from the patent, subsequently winning patent-infringement suits against a number of manufacturers, including Isaac M. Singer.
1888: Carl von Ossietzky, the German journalist and pacifist who won the 1935 Nobel Peace Prize, is born. He was imprisoned for exposing Germany's military buildup.
1929: Yugoslavia becomes the official name of the Kingdom of the Serbs, Croats and Slovenes.
1932: Iraq becomes independent after the British mandate ends.
1952: The first British atomic weapon is exploded off the Monte Bello Islands, west of Australia.
1963: President Ramon Villeda Morales of Honduras is overthrown in a military coup.
1966: Lesotho, which was formerly governed by Britain as the Protectorate of Basutoland, becomes independent.
1970: "Yu Chao," the first 100,000-ton oil tanker built in Taiwan, is launched. "Yu Chao" is the name of a legendary Chinese ruler who taught the people to build tree houses for protection against wild beasts.
1972: Armando Yoshida Vaca, new Bolivian ambassador to the Republic of China, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1972: U.S. President Richard M. Nixon and Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko sign a pact limiting the number of defensive missiles of their respective countries to 200.
1973: Gen. Robert E. Cushman, commandant of the U.S. Marine Corps, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: The sixth World Chinese Pharmacists Amity Conference opens in Taipei.
1975: The 10th World Chinese Traders Conference opens in Taipei with more than 900 overseas Chinese from 57 countries and areas attending.
1976: ROC Finance Minister Walter H. Fei leaves for Manila for the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
1976: Jack Davis, president of Rotary International from 1977 to 1978, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1977: Former Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi is arrested on corruption charges.
1989: Troops loyal to Panamanian strongman Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega crush a coup attempt by junior officers.
1990: Singapore and mainland China establish diplomatic relations.
1990: East and West Germany formally unite to become the single nation of Germany, with Berlin as its capital and Helmut Kohl as provisional chancellor.
1995: Manuel Saturnino da Costa, prime minister of Guinea-Bissau, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1997: A powerful earthquake rocks central Italy, causing more damage to the frescoed interior of the 13th-century Basilica of St. Francis of Assisi.
1997: Japan's magnetically levitated train breaks the world speed record for a manned train when it is clocked at 451 kilometers per hour on an experimental track west of Tokyo.
1999: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs extends its appreciation for the efforts of the 25 countries that support membership in the United Nations for the ROC.
2000: Premier Tang Fei announces his resignation after a four-month period in office, the shortest premiership in ROC history.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Confronted with the spiritual powers of the universe, a man must be able to maintain moral law without any doubts. He must be prepared to wait a hundred generations without any misgivings for the coming of a man of perfect divine nature to confirm moral law."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SPACE SCIENTIST ELECTED IAA MEMBER
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 2 (CNA) (By M. J. Tsou and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Dr. Chern Jeng-shing, an official with the Republic of China's Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC), was was recently elected a member of the prestigious International Academy of Astronautics (IAA).

Chern, currently a project manager with the NSC's National Space Program Office (NSPO), was conferred with a membership certificate from the IAA in a ceremony held at the IAA's Paris headquarters Sept. 30, with IAA Chairman Michael Yarymovych presiding.
Chern was the second scientist from Taiwan to be elected as an IAA member, following Prof. Yeh Yung-heng from National Central University being selected several years ago.

The IAA elected Chern and Yeh as members of the prestigious institute in recognition of their outstanding performance in and contributions to their respective fields within the astronautics sciences. Their being elected as IAA members also automatically made Taiwan a member country of the academy, IAA sources said.

Chern, who graduated from Taiwan's National Cheng Kung University and later obtained his doctorate in space science from a university in Michigan in the United States, was elected an IAA member to-be in 1997 and became a full member two days ago.

He joined the military-run Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology as a researcher soon after he received his doctorate in 1979. In a two-decade endeavor, he climbed the ladder of success from being a researcher to becoming a project manager with the NSPO, which oversees and executes Taiwan's 15-year space technology development program launched in 1991.

According to Chern, who is currently in the city of Toulouse in southern France attending an international space science league meeting, the building of an observation satellite, which is a part of the ROCSAT-2 Project, in a space industrial center in Toulouse has almost been completed.

The observation satellite, designed and manufactured by Astrium, a European consortium, is currently being tested and assembled, Chern said, adding that if everything goes smoothly, the satellite for scientific observation is expected to be shipped to Taiwan at the beginning of 2002 and then launched into orbit by a U.S. spacecraft company.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 45.86 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Wednesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 45.86 points to close at 3,446.26.
Market turnover amounted to NT$29.32 billion (US$0.85 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PLEDGES SUPPORT FOR U.N. ANTI-TERRORISM RESOLUTION

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung declared at a weekly Cabinet meeting Wednesday that the Republic of China government supports a U.N. anti-global terrorism resolution passed on Sept. 28.

Chang also reiterated the ROC's condemnation of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States that toppled the twin towers of New York City's World Trade Center and partially damaged the Pentagon -- the seat of the U.S. military nerve center.

Chang said the ROC government will adopt a series of judicial and administrative measures in tandem with its domestic law and the spirit of various U.N.-sponsored anti-terrorism conventions and resolutions to deny money, support and sanctuary to terrorists.

The ROC will also step up exchanges of "operational information," especially regarding the actions and movements of terrorists, with other countries as well as provide all necessary assistance in relevant investigation and criminal suit procedures.
Chang said although the ROC has been shut out of the United Nations since 1971 simply because of political reasons, it will never waver its support for the global anti-terrorism campaign.

In a significant international response to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the U.N. Security Council (UNSC) unanimously approved last Friday a resolution requiring all 189 U.N.-member nations to deny money, support and sanctuary to terrorists.

The legally binding resolution was introduced and approved by the frequently plodding Security Council in just over 24 hours, a pace that reflects the United States' wide support as it leads a global campaign to pursue those responsible for the attacks, and any nation that harbors them.

Under the resolution, all countries must make the "willful" financing of terrorism a criminal offense, immediately freeze terrorist-related funds and prevent movement of individuals and groups suspected of having terrorist connections. All member nations must deny terrorists any "safe haven."
Additionally, nations must speed the exchange of "operational information," especially regarding the actions and movements of terrorists.

While the resolution stops short of threatening sanctions against countries that fail to abide by the anti-terrorism measures, it does express the UNSC's determination "to take all necessary steps to ensure the full implementation."
To ensure that all member countries adopt the strongly worded measure, the UNSC even has created a committee to monitor their efforts.
