DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SAYS ROC WILL NOT BE ABSENT FROM APEC INFORMAL SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday that the Republic of China will not be absent from the informal leaders' summit of the Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation forum slated for Oct. 20-21 in Shanghai.
Premier Chang stressed that President Chen Shui-bian still hopes to attend the summit, but added that if he is unable to, the government will in the near future decide who will represent him.

The premier stressed that Taiwan "will by no means" be absent from the APEC informal leader's summit and that the government is still making efforts to have President Chen represent the ROC at the summit, adding that even if its efforts at having the president fail this year, it will try again next year.

President Chen has been adamant about participating in the APEC summit in person this year. In previous years, the president has always been represented by an appointed proxy because of Beijing's insistence. This is the first time that an APEC summit is being held in mainland China.

In the past, the host country had always sent a special envoy to Taipei to present a formal invitation to the ROC president to attend the summit, but this year, Beijing only faxed a brief notice of the summit meeting to Taiwan in May.
The notice did not include the name of the intended recipient and only asked Taipei's senior APEC official to forward the message to concerned bodies.

APEC is one of the few international organizations that simultaneously admits Taiwan and mainland China. A regional forum dedicated to promoting free trade and investment, its members include Australia, Brunei, Canada, mainland China, Chile, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, the Philippine, Russia, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand, the United States and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 45.86 points to close at 3,446.26.

Despite a drop of a key interest rate by the Federal Reserve, the bourse opened at 3,480.19 and continued to go down due to a plunge in semiconductor stocks. The index fluctuated between 3,511.38 and 3,436.25 during trading.

A total of 1.48 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$29.32 billion (US$0.85 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.21 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$23.62 billion (US$0.68 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with bank and insurance shares moving up 1.3 percent. Textile issues remained unchanged.

The other major categories posted losses, with foodstuff stocks moving down the most at 3.2 percent, followed by electrical shares at 2.4 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.6 percent, construction stocks at 1.3 percent, cement stocks at 1.1 percent, and plastics and chemical shares at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 348 to 171, with 102 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MIXED ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported mixed results on Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for October moved up 3 points to close at 3,430, with 16,320 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for November rose 2 points to finish at 3,422, with 90 contract transactions, while December futures decreased 3 points to close at 3,449, with 6 contracts traded.
Next March futures gained 1 point to close at 3,457, with only one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 3,427 for October, 3,420 for November, 3,452 for December, 3,456 for next March, and 3,512 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, also reported mixed results.
October TE futures moved down 3.35 points to close at 154.6, with 4,979 contract transactions, while November TE futures decreased 3.35 points to finish at 154.8, with 24 contracts traded.
December TE futures fell 1 point to close at 154, with two contract transactions, while next June TE futures lost 1.6 points to finish at 156.5, with eight contracts changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
October TF futures rose 12 points to finish at 565, with 2,218 contract transactions, while November TF futures gained 12 points to close at 563.2, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DECIDES TO PURCHASE KIDD-CLASS WARSHIPS: DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Ministry of National Defense (MND) has approved the navy's plan to purchase the four Kidd-class destroyers that the United States offered to sell to Taiwan in April, Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen confirmed Wednesday.

Wu said that after a thorough assessment by the ROC navy, which found that the destroyers could meet its combat needs, the MND decided to endorse the purchase of the four Kidd-class destroyers from the United States.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Wu said the budget for the procurement was not listed in the 2002 Annual Budget Bill, but the funds needed, roughly between NT$25-27 billion (US$725-783 million), are expected to be allocated on a yearly basis beginning in 2003.
ROC ports, including those in Keelung, Kaohsiung and Makung, could all be considered appropriate ports to accommodate the Kidd-class destroyers, which are known for their large size.
However, Wu pointed out, the ports' designation as locations to house the 9,000-ton warships does not necessarily mean that the Kidd-class destroyers will in the end be stationed at these ports.

It was learned that ROC navy authorities vigorously debated the procurement issue before a decision to purchase the destroyers was arrived at as there were evident differences of opinion among the officers on the issue.

The four Kidd-class destroyers were part of a robust arms sales package to Taiwan worth more than US$4 billion that U.S. President George W. Bush approved in April. The package was the largest approved since 1992 when the U.S. government agreed to sell the island 150 F-16 jet fighters.

The United States deferred a decision on the sale of four Arleigh Burke-class destroyers equipped with the state-of-the-art Aegis radar system, instead deciding to offer Taiwan four Kidd-class destroyers, a dozen anti-submarine P-3 "Orion" aircraft, and eight diesel submarines.

Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Tsai Ming-hsien in late April called for the government agencies concerned to reconsider the offer before making a decision. He said the Kidd-class destroyers were built 20 years ago and have a displacement of 9,000 metric tons, making them easy targets in the event of a mainland Chinese military attack.

According to ROC navy sources, the Kidd-class destroyers, which are currently mothballed, will be ready for delivery by 2003. The destroyers are equipped with radar systems that have an effective range of 350 kilometers and can simultaneously fire four anti-aircraft missiles with a range of 70 kilometers.

DOC.HEADLINE: BANKS MUST REIMBURSE BOGUS BANK NOTES: PREMIER CHANG

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday that local banks must reimburse recipients for counterfeit New Taiwan dollar bank notes distributed either by their clerks or automatic teller machines.
Speaking at a weekly Cabinet meeting, Chang said he has made the decision with a view to enhancing banks' obligation to help prevent the circulation of fake bills.
In his view, Chang said, domestic financial institutions should assume the greatest share of responsibility for curbing the circulation of bogus bank notes.

"So long as individual holders can prove that their fake bank notes have been received from banks or affiliated automatic teller machines, the distributing banks must reimburse them for their losses," Chang said.

Noting that the circulating of bogus bank notes would affect local people's confidence in holding cash and would even perhaps disrupt the domestic financial order, Chang said law enforcement authorities should step up intelligence gathering to determine who is making counterfeit bank notes.
Chang ordered the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) to form a special task force to investigate whether there is any criminal ring involved in the counterfeiting.

The premier said the MOJ should invite officials from the Judicial Yuan, the National Police Administration, the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) and other relevant agencies to form the special investigative team.
Chang also directed the Central Bank of China (CBC) to launch a publicity campaign to help local residents be able to tell fake notes from the real thing.

"As new versions of the various denominations of bank notes contain 12 visible anti-counterfeiting marks and designs and two machine-readable anti-counterfeiting devices, it would not be difficult to detect bogus bills," the premier said.
Meanwhile, the CBC invited senior executives of 56 local financial institutions to a meeting Wednesday to discuss feasible measures to stamp out the circulation of fake bills.

CBC Deputy Governor Chen Shih-meng said domestic banks must assume full responsibility for sorting out bogus bank notes. "Each bank's performance in this field will become one of the major items to be subject to the CBC's regular financial inspections," Chen added.

A local firm displayed two specially designed sorting machines at the conference site to lobby bankers to purchase the machines to help detect all counterfeit bills. CBC officials said local banks are free to decide whether to install such machines.

Statistics compiled by major financial institutions show that the average number of seized bogus bank notes totals about 1,000 per month, with the new versions of the NT$1,000 and NT$500 denominations being the most common.

Compared with previous recorded levels of fake notes in circulation, the figure does not represent a marked increase. Law enforcement officers said the impression that the use of bogus bank notes has become more rampant since the circulation of new versions Taiwan bank notes began late last year might result from the fact that fake notes have mostly been used in dimly-lit traditional food markets and betel nut vending booths.

CBC Governor Perng Fai-nan visited a traditional food market in Taipei Sunday to publicize the ways of identifying genuine bank notes. Perng's unusual move followed a complaint by Taipei City Councilor Pang Chien-kuo who said food vendors in the city's Huannan market alone are passed an average of NT$1.35 million worth of fake bills per month.

Under current Taiwan laws, there is a maximum sentence of life imprisonment for people found illegally printing bank notes, while those who knowingly use counterfeit money can receive a prison sentence of up to three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSPORTATION MINISTER SAYS SHE FAVORS ON BOARD SECURITY PERSONNEL

TEXT.P: Transportation and Communications Minister Yeh Chu-lan said Wednesday that many international airlines have begun to staff security personnel on their planes since the recent terror attacks in the United States and that she approves of the practice.
Yeh made the remarks while fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan concerning safety on passenger flights in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York City and Washington, D.C.

Legislator Chen Ching-pao, noting that Taiwan has also been deemed a possible target for terrorists since the Sept. 11 attacks, asked whether the time has come for the reinstating of the practice of staffing security personnel on airplanes that Taiwan airlines used to carry out but have recently abandoned.
Yeh noted she is in favor of the practice, but added that Taiwan airlines will have to evaluate the situation themselves and that there are no laws on the books requiring onboard security staff.

The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) also said that China Airlines reinstated the practice Oct. 1 on its international routes after it had abandoned it a few years ago. EVA Airways, another major domestic airline, is also mulling over whether to staff security personnel on its planes.
The CAA said that onboard security personnel are allowed to carry all the necessary security equipment but are not be equipped with guns.

Meanwhile, Hu Cheng-pu, director of the General Staff for Operations under the Ministry of National Defense (MND), said in response to a legislator's question that in a situation where a civilian plane were threatening the safety of the general public on the ground, he would recommend that it be shot down.

He said that if aviation authorities alerted the MND to the fact that a passenger plane had been hijacked and had veered from its regular flight path, the MND would shoot it down out of humanitarian considerations to limit the number of casualties in such a tragedy.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA DETAILS PLANS TO DEVELOP AGRICULTURAL BIO-SCIENTIFIC TECHNOLOGY

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) will spend some NT$1.6 billion over the next three years to finance projects for improvement of Taiwan's competitiveness in agricultural bio-scientific technology.
Lee Jen-chyuan, vice chairman of the COA, made the statement at a plenary session of the Committee on Science, Technology and Information under the Legislative Yuan.

He told legislators that the COA has singled out seedling research, marine cultivation and flower-growing as important strategic sectors in the development of the fields of agriculture, fishery and livestock.

In order to improve the competitiveness of the island's agricultural bio-scientific technology, Lee said that the COA will pour about NT$520 million into relevant projects in fiscal 2002 and added that the total investment in the coming three years will total NT$1.6 billion.

Regarding the proposal of the recently-held Economic Development Advisory Conference that the COA establish agricultural cultivation centers within six months to one year, Lee said that three such centers will be set up.

He said that the academic resources from National Taiwan University will be used for the operation of the Taipei cultivation center, with the resources from National Chunghsing University being allocated for the operation of the Taichung cultivation center.
The cultivation center to be established in southern Taiwan is still in the planning phase, he said.
The Economic Development Advisory Conference, convened under the directive of President Chen Shui-bian, also proposed the establishment of high-technology agricultural bio-technology parks.
Lee said that the COA has been working out the blueprints for establishing four such parks in northern, central, southern and eastern Taiwan.

He said that the experience gained in establishing the existing industrial zones by the National Science Council and the Ministry of Economic Affairs will be borrowed for the establishment of the agricultural bio-technology parks.

Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization, expected by next January, will greatly affect the development of the island's agricultural sector. The projects being undertaken by the COA are among the steps designed to minimize the possible impact.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER SAYS NO OIL HIKE ANYTIME BEFORE END OF YEAR

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi said Wednesday that the state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) has a 110-day safety reserve of crude oil and that there will be no domestic oil price hike anytime before the end of this year.

Lin made the remarks while reporting at the Legislative Yuan, during which time several legislators expressed their concerns about the impact on Taiwan's economy if the United States were to launch a military attack on Afghanistan.

Lin said that if the United States does launch an attack on Afghanistan for harboring Osama bin Laden, the prime suspect behind the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, then the major impact would be on Taiwan's petroleum prices and on its high-tech product exports.
He said a U.S. military action would delay the recovery of the global economy and cause world oil prices to fluctuate.

Pointing out that it was generally expected that the sluggish U.S. economy would rebound in the fourth quarter this year, Lin said that because of the terrorist attacks, some believe the recovery will have to wait until the first or second quarters of next year, or even until the second half of next year.
He said that a U.S. military action would cause the consumer confidence index to dip again, directly affecting Taiwan's high-tech product exports and shipping.

On possible petroleum price increases, Lin said the CPC still has a 110-day safety reserve of crude oil, including stored crude and that which is being delivered, pointing out that this, along with the fact that Formosa Plastics also has reserves of crude oil means petroleum prices in Taiwan will not be adjusted upward anytime before the end of the year.

Lin said that if a U.S. military attack were to be carried out quickly, Taiwan's economic recovery would be delayed for one or two quarters, adding that if a U.S. military action were to turn into a prolonged war, the period for Taiwan's economic recovery would also be lengthened.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.005 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Wednesday, closing at 34.569.
The local currency opened Wednesday at 34.571 and was traded between 34.551 and 34.590.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$260 million.
The NT dollar opened high and then went bearish due to heavy buying of the greenback triggered by an comprehensive weakness in major Asian currencies.

The cut of the benchmark federal funds rate to 2.50 percent, the lowest level in 39 years, by U.S. Federal Reserve on Tuesday made investors nervous that time deposit certificate would probably be affected by the rate cut, resulting in later selling pressure on the greenback and the rallying of the local unit, dealers said.
Dealers predicted that the NT dollar will be traded between 34.50 and 34.60 in the short term. They said factors that will have an effect on the trend of the local unit include:
-- Whether the U.S. Fed will further lower interest rates;
-- Whether the United States will launch a war against Afghanistan;
-- The performance of the Taiwan stock market; and
-- The direction of foreign capital.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PRESIDENT LEE STILL HAS CLOUT IN YEAR-END ELECTIONS: POLL

TEXT.P: A majority of local people think that former President Lee Teng-hui would still enjoy a clout in the upcoming elections for local government chiefs and legislators, according to the results of an opinion poll released Wednesday.

The telephone poll of 1,068 randomly chosen adult residents, conducted by the Great Era Culture Foundation from Sept. 25-28, found that 60.4 percent of the respondents thought that even though the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has already revoked Lee's party membership, he would still be able to influence the outcome of the Dec. 1 elections for legislators, city mayors and county magistrates.
Survey results further showed that 61.63 percent threw support behind the KMT's decision to oust Lee who concurrently led the party during his 12-year stint as the Republic of China's head of state.

Asked about Lee's legacies to the KMT, 34.02 percent said they thought that Lee had done "more merits than faults" to the party during his service as KMT chairman; 28.58 percent said they thought otherwise; 20.71 percent said they thought that Lee's merits were offset by his faults; and 16.68 percent said they had no opinion about the issue.

Meanwhile, 52.53 percent said they agreed with certain ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) officials' remarks that Lee's stumping for candidates of the newly formed opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) would adversely affect their DPP counterparts' chances of victory in the legislative elections. In contrast, 32.87 percent said they don't think so.

In the wake of Lee's ouster from the KMT, 69.38 percent said they believe that the year-end elections would be a race between the "pan-blue" camp and the "pan-green" camp, while 22.38 percent said they see no signs that such a scenario would appear.

The "pan-blue" camp refers to the KMT and its two splinter groups -- the People First Party and the New Party, while the "pan-green" camp refers to the DPP and the TSU. The "pan-blue" camp is widely believed to favor eventual unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, and the "pan-green" camp prefers to keep Taiwan separate from mainland China.
The KMT-affiliated Great Era Culture Foundation also conducted an opinion survey from Sept.14-16 to explore public views on certain "pan-blue" camp-related issues.

The results of the telephone poll of 1,069 adults showed that 41.72 percent of the respondents thought that the pan-blue camp candidate for the Taipei county magistrate election, Wang Chien-shien, would be the winner, while 39.94 percent said they believe that incumbent Magistrate Su Chen-chang, a DPP stalwart, would be able to win his re-election bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA HOPING TO RESTRICT USE OF POLYETHYLENE PLASTIC BAGS

TEXT.P: The government of the Republic of China is hoping to restrict the use of the ubiquitous polyethylene (PE) bags used around the island to better protect the environment, an official with the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Wednesday.
Although recycling has gradually taken root in Taiwan, residents are still using too many plastic bags, said Lu Hung-kuang, director of the EPA's Solid Waste Control Bureau.
Taiwan consumers use excessive numbers of PE bags mainly because they are not in the habit of bringing their own shopping bags when they shop, Lu said.

Excessive use of the plastic bags is increasing the risk of health dangers, Lu said, adding that polyethylene does not decompose for many years, while burning it creates dioxin pollution, a serious toxin.
Lu said that a draft proposed by the EPA to restrict the use of PE bags has passed its first reading at the Legislative Yuan.
If the legislature passes the bill by the end of its current session at the end of October, it will pave the way for more serious restrictions on the use of the plastic bags, Lu said.

The bill stipulates restrictions on PE bag use in three stages: Public-run organizations, including government offices, schools and the military, will take the initiative to begin to stop using PE bags from May next year, to be followed by discount store chains, department stores, supermarkets, convenience stores and fast-food chains six months later, and then followed by laundries, bakeries and ordinary shops one year later, according to Lu.
Traditional markets will not be included in the three-stage implementation of the restrictions, Lu said.
Violators of the restrictions could face fines ranging from NT$60,000 to NT$300,000, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T TO APPLY ECO-ENGINEERING METHODS TO TACKLE MUDSLIDE PROBLEM

TEXT.P: The high death toll and devastation caused by mudslides triggered by recent torrential rains have awakened the public awareness of ecological preservation, and an inter-governmental Cabinet-level task force has decided to apply "ecological engineering methods" to tackle the problem from its origin.

Mudslides and floods have become the most ruthless killers in Taiwan since the island was hit by the deadly earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999. Mountainous areas jolted by the earthquake were made vulnerable to heavy rainfall, and short and steep rivers and steams very often turned into torrents carrying rocks and silt.

An official of the Public Construction Commission under the Cabinet said Wednesday that the task force would try to find remedies for the ecological damage caused by excessive exploitation of natural resources.
The task force was organized jointly by the Council of Agriculture, Ministry of the Interior, Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.

Kuo Ching-chiang, deputy director of the commission, said that integrated efforts were needed to deal with the mudslide problem. While excessive exploitation of natural resources has been proven to be a factor worsening the damage done by natural disasters, the task force planned to apply ecological engineering methods to solve the problem and to rehabilitate the environment, he added.

Kuo said that in the past, the mudslide problem was most often handled by constructing docks and banks to blockade slides. The commission in recent months has applied new methods by taking into consideration the natural environment in the mudslide prevention projects in 28 sites around the island.

For densely populated Taiwan, the new methods emphasizing stability and sustainable ecosystems and harmony between the natural environment and human society are fundamental solutions to its ecological and environmental problems, according to the official.

The concept of ecological engineering is not new in Taiwan, though the ecological environment has very often fallen victim to construction projects. The Water Resources Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs has cooperated with National Taipei University of Technology and the University of Virginia in the United States to set up the Water Environment Research Center. The center has made ecological engineering methods a major research subject.

DOC.HEADLINE: FARMERS IN C. TAIWAN LEARNING E-COMMERCE AS SALES CHANNEL

TEXT.P: Farmers in central Taiwan are getting help from the government to learn how to promote their produce on the Internet.

The Commerce Department of the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Department of Machinery Engineering of the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) are helping farmers in central Taiwan to promote sales of their farm produce via the Internet.

921.mtec.com.tw is a Web site featuring fruits, vegetables, rice and grain products, tea products, beverages and handicrafts from central Taiwan. The Web site is cooperating with employee-owned, in-house shops of big companies in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park to sell farm products. Consumers can place online orders and pick up the deliveries from these in-house shops.

The agricultural sector in central Taiwan has not fully recovered from the damage of the earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999. While helping the farmers rebuild their homes and businesses, the government has tried to develop more sales channels for farm produce from that region.
The Commerce Department will offer farmers e-commerce courses so that they can operate in the virtual marketplace by themselves in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN PITCHES FOR VOLUNTEER SERVICES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday he hopes that more local people would join volunteer services to help boost the Republic of China's relations with countries around the world.
Chen made the remarks while reviewing 19 local volunteers who will soon depart for working in countries that maintain formal diplomatic ties with the ROC.
Also present at the occasion were 37 selected conscripts who will work with the ROC's overseas technical missions for the next two years as alternative to their mandatory military services.
Quoting tallies compiled by the United Nations, Chen said more than 25 percent of citizens of advanced democratic countries have experiences of working as volunteers.
For instance, 56 percent of Americans had once worked as volunteers. The ratios in Germany and Japan were 34 percent and 26 percent, respectively.

Against this backdrop, Chen said he is convinced that there is still ample room for Taiwan's volunteer work force to grow. "I'm hopeful that our volunteer work force will expand gradually in the years to come," he added.

In addition to helping promote domestic community development, Chen said, Taiwan volunteers can also work for international cooperative programs and help boost bilateral and multilateral cultural exchanges.

The ROC began to send volunteers five years ago to work for its diplomatic allies or developing countries friendly to Taiwan. And this year, it decided to send young conscripts to work at its overseas technical missions as alternative military services. The first batch of young conscripts will work at the ROC's 25 technical missions in 21 countries in Africa, Latin America and Asia. They will depart to assume overseas missions in early November. (By Sofia Wu)]

DOC.HEADLINE: SALES OF DIGITAL CAMERAS EXPECTED TO FALL FOR ALL OF 2001

TEXT.P: Sales of digital cameras in Taiwan are expected to fall this year, hit by the domestic economic slowdown, industry sources said.

Although autumn is usually the peak season for the sales of digital cameras -- when new models hit the market -- the sources said that they are not optimistic about sales for the last half of the year.

The sources estimated that around 80,000 units will be sold for the whole of 2001, as the number of first-half sales was between 40,000 and 50,000 units. They also forecast that the growth rate in sales for this year will be around 40 percent, down from the 2000 growth level of 60 percent.

Middle-range and top-of-the-line models are the most popular among Taiwan users, given the fact that digital cameras with at least 2 million pixels account for 80 percent of total sales in the local market.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER SAYS STABLE TAIPEI-BEIJING RELATIONS IS GOV'T POLICY
DOC.DATELINE: Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan, Oct. 3 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday at a seminar with the heads of Taiwanese business associations located in mainland China that stable Taipei-Beijing relations is the government's consistent policy.

Chang told the approximately 130 participants of the two-day seminar being held in northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County that "no dispute cannot be resolved" as long as there exists domestic consensus and sincerity.
The most difficult part of formulating a mainland China policy for the government is to find a domestic consensus, he said.

However, Chang continued, the Economic Development Advisory Conference held in August managed to consolidate a certain degree of consensus among the ruling and opposition parties as well as other sectors, and the government will be able to carry out its mainland policies based on these agreements.

At the same seminar, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu, who has long served as Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, said that of the 36 consensuses reached at the advisory conference in August on the issue of cross-strait relations, the essence can be said to be the principles of "Taiwan first, global positioning, reciprocal benefits leading to win-win situations, and risk management."

Koo went on to say that the government's decision to replace its "no haste, be patient" policy on Taiwanese investments in the mainland by an "active opening, effective management" policy represents the good will of the government and its willingness to cooperate in developing normalized relations between Taipei and Beijing.

Koo said that the various problems created in increasingly frequent cross-strait exchanges -- particularly those related to protecting the investment rights of Taiwanese businesspeople in the mainland -- require the urgent resumption of dialogue and bilateral negotiations to resolve.

However, he added that a "win-win" cross-strait relationship that is reciprocal cannot be achieved overnight, and that the Taiwanese businesspeople in mainland China can do their part to help people on the mainland understand Taiwan.

The SEF is a quasi-official intermediary body empowered by the government to handle relations with mainland China in the absence of official ties. It routinely organizes seminars for Taiwanese businespeople investing in the mainland together with the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-NICARAGUA TIES WILL NOT BE AFFECTED BY ELECTIONS: MOFA

TEXT.P: Republic of China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs denied foreign wire service reports Wednesday that said the ROC may sever diplomatic relations with Nicaragua if the Sandinistas win November's presidential election.

Chang Siao-yue, spokeswoman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, stressed that the ROC and Nicaragua have maintained solid diplomatic ties and that their relations will not be affected by a change of political power.
As to the foreign wire reports saying that Taiwan may cut its official ties with Nicaragua if the leftist Sandinistas win power in November, Chang described it as "unfounded."

Some foreign wire reports dispatched from Nicaragua quoted recent observations by Sandinista vice presidential candidate Agustin Jarquin as saying that once its party wins the election in November, it will "respect" its diplomatic ties with the ROC and promote Taiwan's investments in Nicaragua, while seeking resumption of strong ties with mainland China.
Jarquin also was quoted as saying that the Sandinistas will allow Beijing to set up a trade office in Managua.
Taiwan cut diplomatic ties with Nicaragua when the Sandinistas were in power and only resumed ties in 1990 when Violeta Barrios de Chamorro came to power as president.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STEEL MAKERS FACING U.S. DUMPING CHARGE

TEXT.P: The Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said Wednesday that it, in cooperation with the Taiwan Steel & Iron Industries Association, will study how to cope with dumping allegations from the United States on Taiwan's cold-rolled carbon steel products.
The anti-dumping charge will be the second of its kind against Asian steel makers recently, and the BOFT said it will closely monitor subsequent developments.

The U.S. steel industry accused Asian makers of cold-rolled carbon steel products of selling their goods under fair market prices in the U.S. as a means to resolve their problems of overstocking and sluggish demand back at home.

Nine Taiwan-based steel makers, including state-run China Steel Corp., Ornatube Enterprise and Kao Hsing Chang Iron & Steel are named on the list of the U.S. Department of Commerce, together with other companies in Argentina, Australia, Belgium, Brazil, Sweden, Thailand, Turkey, France, Germany, India, Japan, South Korea, Holland, New Zealand, Russia, South Africa, Spain, mainland China and Venezuela.

Taiwan exported more than 40,000 metric tons of cold-rolled carbon steel products between June 2000 and June 2001, worth US$13.94 million, U.S. government tallies show. The export amount for June this year alone was 1.7 times that of the same month a year ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA UNVEILS `TAIWAN TRADE' WEB SITE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) unveiled its completely revamped "Taiwan Trade" Web site on Wednesday to help local businesses cross into a new era of electronic commerce.

CETRA Chairman Shea Jia-dong said at a ceremony marking the inauguration of the Web site (www.taiwantrade.com.tw) that Taiwan Trade is "an online B2B trading market" designed to provide convenient and instantaneous trade services for buyers from around the world as well as manufacturers in Taiwan.

Registering at the Web site -- whose predecessor was called CetraNet -- allows access to a database of 180,000 Taiwan importers and exporters and the customs statistics for 1.6 million items from Taiwan.
According to CETRA, Taiwan Trade will be a portal site for doing business in Taiwan, and CETRA will begin a series of promotions abroad to publicize the Web site.
CETRA is a semi-official organization that seeks to facilitate closer cooperation between government and industry as well as between Taiwan and its trading partners.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT ADOPTS 7-POINT PLATFORM FOR LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) adopted a seven-point platform for its candidates running in the year-end legislative elections at a routine Central Standing Committee meeting Wednesday.

The KMT's platform is based on a commitment to "reject incompetence in government and bring back prosperity to the people of Taiwan," said Hung Yu-ching, chief executive officer of the KMT's policy coordination department at a news conference after the meeting.

Hung urged the public to vote against the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and to allow the KMT to retake power. In this way, Hung said, the economy will recover and politics on the island will become more stable.
The KMT platform touches on seven points, or goals, for the party:

-- Encourage the legislature to pass bills in accordance with the suggestions reached by consensus at the Economic Development Advisory Conference and enact legislation necessary for the island's World Trade Organization (WTO) entry;

-- Establish a peaceful and stable cross-strait relationship and resume cross-strait talks on an equal footing with mainland China, as well as implementing the "three links" -- direct trade, transportation and postal service with the mainland;
-- Enact a statute that will prevent those convicted of a serious crime from entering politics and ensure that vote-buying is eliminated; and
-- Adhere to the system whereby the majority or the largest alliance in the legislature is allowed to designate a Cabinet.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO VICIOUS REMARKS WILL BE USED TOWARD EX-CHAIRMAN: KMT SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) spokesman Wang Chih-kang said Wednesday that the party will not use "vicious remarks" against former party chairman Lee Teng-hui, who was stripped of his party membership recently.
Wang said that the issue about Lee's attacks on the KMT and KMT leaders was raised at the day's Central Standing Committee meeting.

He said that the basic principle of the party is not to direct vicious remarks against Lee, but pointed out that the KMT will employ a very clear and powerful method to correct any misunderstanding or distortion regarding the party.

During his recent tour stumping for candidates of the newly established Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) in southern Taiwan, Lee attacked the KMT for taking a policy designed to "join hands with the communists against the interest of Taiwan."
He also criticized KMT Chairman Lien Chan, who replaced Lee as chairman in March last year, and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, a member of the KMT Central Standing Committee.
Wang contended that the KMT's policy toward mainland China is based on the National Unification Guidelines and therefore "will absolutely not sacrifice the interests of the people of Taiwan."

Meanwhile, KMT Vice Chairman Wu Po-hsiung said that he had already stated that there is no need to make vicious remarks against any third party, and added that everyone should have a positive attitude when joining or departing from a group.

Wu, who had served as KMT secretary-general and presidential secretary-general when Lee was KMT chairman and the ROC president, admitted that he felt a bit strange about the way Lee spoke before and the way he has spoken recently.
He said that the memory of the people will not deteriorate and they have the ability to judge for themselves.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN LABOR WAGES TO UNDERGO FURTHER CUTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top labor affairs official said Wednesday that the Council for Labor Affairs (CLA) is planning further cuts to foreign labor wages and that the workers will in effect receive the same amount of pay after brokerage fees are lowered in tandem.

CLA Chairwoman Chen Chu said while reporting to the Legislative Yuan's health, environment and social welfare committee that her council will put forward its latest foreign labor policy within two weeks to carry out the conclusions of the Economic Development Advisory Conference held in August.

As part of its new policy, she continued, the CLA plans to deduct NT$4,000 (US$116) to NT$6,000 (US$174) in "room and board fees" from the workers' monthly wages -- an increase in deduction from the previous NT$2,500 (US$72) to NT$4,000 only recently put in place.
The deductions, which Chen said would be determined by factors like the cost of living in different areas across the island, would add up to NT$48,000 (US$1,389) to NT$72,000 (US$2,083) per year.

To compensate for the lower income, brokerage fees that foreign laborers usually pay in advance for the chance to work in Taiwan will be slashed at the same time to protect the rights of the foreign workers, she added.
The minimum wage in Taiwan is NT$15,840 (US$458) per month -- higher than what foreign laborers could earn elsewhere, such as in Hong Kong or Singapore.
Foreign laborers often take out high-interest loans to pay for brokerage fees and have to work one to two years before being able to pay off the debt.
Under the new deduction scheme, businesses hiring the approximately 210,000 foreign workers nationwide will save a total of over NT$10 billion (US$289 million).
Chen said that the countries that have been exporting laborers to Taiwan have been allowing labor brokers in their countries to charge exorbitant brokerage fees for the past 10 years.
She added that the CLA will not allow such "unreasonable" practices in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CUTS DISCOUNT RATE, DEPOSIT RESERVE RATIOS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's central bank announced Wednesday that it will cut the discount rate by 0.25 percentage point to 2.50 percent starting from Thursday, following a move by the U.S. Federal Reserve Tuesday to cut its key interest rate by a half point.
It will be the 10th cut in the discount rate by the Central Bank of China (CBC) since December of last year.
The CBC will also cut the accommodations with collateral and accommodations without collateral rates by 0.25 percentage points each, to 2.875 and 4.75 percent, respectively.

At the same time, the bank will also cut the average deposit reserve requirement for banks from 6.22 percent to 5.00 percent, and the reserve requirement on foreign currency deposits from 10 percent to 5 percent.

Asked about whether the CBC's 10th rate cut can reach its goal to stimulate the economy, Chrystal Shih, director-general of the CBC's Economic Research Department, said it will take time to see the fruits of the interest rate cut.

However, Shih added, the cut in reserve requirement on deposits is aimed at lowering banks' capital and operational costs, which is expected to help increase local banks' competitiveness once Taiwan joins the World Trade Organization.
The CBC urged local banks to realistically reflect the lowered capital costs of their banks, and to cut basic loan rates in order to spur economic activities and stimulate consumption and investment.

K. C. Lee, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said that considering the relatively stable consumer prices in Taiwan, and that its real interest rate is not low, there is still room for further interest rate cuts in Taiwan.

Concerning the doubts expressed by many economists whether the frequent interest rate cuts can spur the economy, Lee said the fact that central banks around the world announced simultaneous interest rate cuts after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in United States means this policy is still necessary at a time when the world is mired in an economic downturn.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, JAPAN COULD COOPERATE IN TAPPING CHINA MARKET: OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, Oct. 3 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan could form a strategic partnership with Japan to make further inroads into the mainland Chinese market, said Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi Wednesday at a two-day seminar on cross-strait business strategies.
The meeting was held in Tahsi, Taoyuan with some 100 Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China attending.
Lin said that although Taiwan's competitiveness is keen among the world economies, the island must formulate its own discreet strategy for prospering in the globalized economy.

After both sides of the Taiwan Strait gain admission into the World Trade Organization, the cross-strait relationship will be either a competitive or a cooperative one, he said. Therefore, Lin said, if Taiwan cannot work out its own competitive strategy, it will lose its edge to mainland China.

Yang Wan-chin, deputy secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation, Taiwan's quasi-official organization for affairs relating to mainland China in the absence of official ties, said Taiwan and Japan have already made contact regarding the possibility of establishing a strategic alliance to make investments in mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: KIWANIS TAIWAN MAKES DONATION TO SALVADORAN POOR CHILDREN

TEXT.P: The Republic of China District of Kiwanis International donated NT$2.6 million (US$75,300) Wednesday to help poor children in El Salvador.

Kiwanis' Taiwan chapter head Wu Hui-wan presented the donation to the Salvadoran ambassador to the ROC, Francisco Ricardo Santana Berrios, in a ceremony held in Taichung, Central Taiwan, with ROC Vice President Annette Lu also in attendance.
Wu said the donation from the Kiwanis members in Taiwan was part of Lu's campaign to "bring love" to Latin America.

Lu said during the ceremony that Taiwan received help from many countries after it was hit by a devastating earthquake in September 1999, and Taiwan was returning the concern via the donation made by Kiwanis Taiwan to El Salvador.
After the donation to El Salvador, Lu said she will promote campaigns to help people in Tibet and New York.

As to the possible war between the United States and Afghanistan, Lu said she will write to Nobel Peace Prize winners soon, asking them to urge Osama bin Laden to make a public explanation, which she said may prevent a war and eliminate the fear of the Afghan people.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SAYS DEMOCRACY IN TAIWAN BECOMING MATURE

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday that democracy in Taiwan is maturing more than one year after the inauguration of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration.
He made the remarks while speaking at the joint opening ceremony of a study class on national development and research and a study class on the development and research of women's leadership.
Both classes are organized by the Executive Yuan.

Chang said that in the past, Taiwan lacked the history and culture of cooperation between the ruling and opposition parties, a reason why many disputes arose after the DPP's Chen Shui-bian took over the presidency in May 2000.

However, he noted that after over 300 recommendations were reached through consensus at the Economic Development Advisory Conference recently, he felt that the ruling and opposition parties have been able to work together and respect each other.
Chang said that it indicated that the pain caused by the transition of power has gone, and that democracy is maturing.
Although Taiwan has been affected by the global economic downturn, he said that the "prospects for economic development remain very optimistic" if Taiwan is able to endure the current difficulties.

Meanwhile, the president was invited to speak at the joint opening ceremony and presented his views on the development of a knowledge-based economy, leadership with far-sighted concepts, and the national development strategy for pursuit of the welfare of the people.
The president said that the success of the implementation of a national development policy depends not only on the government's efforts, but also the vitality of the private sector.
He urged those from academia, the government and industry to put their efforts together to create a better environment for development.

Chen also said that government leaders should possess a global point of view, strive for a competitive advantage in science and technology, promote partnership relationships, appreciate different cultures and cultivate outstanding personnel.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNITED WORLD CHINESE COMMERCIAL BANK BRANCH OPENS IN HONG KONG
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 3 (CNA) (By Mandy Wong and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Hong Kong branch of the Taiwan-based United World Chinese Commercial Bank (UWCCB) opened Wednesday, becoming the eighth Hong Kong branch of Taiwan-funded banks.
Several hundred dignitaries from all walks of life attended the inauguration ceremony.

Founded in 1975, the UWCCB set up a representative office in Hong Kong in 1997. In May this year, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority approved UWCCB's application to upgrade the office to be an official branch of the bank.
Presently, the bank has total assets of NT$600 billion (US$17.39 billion), capital stock of NT$37.9 billion and net assets of NT$66 billion.
It has more than 70 branches in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 4, or the 18th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1669: Rembrandt van Rijn, Dutch painter whose works are unmatched in their portrayal of subtle human emotions, dies at the age of 63.
1777: U.S. forces led by George Washington attack the British at Germantown but are repulsed.
1822: Rutherford B. Hayes, the 19th president of the United State, is born. Winning the controversial election of 1876 by one electoral vote, he pacified the South by removing federal troops in 1877, supported the welfare of minority groups, and reformed the civil service.
1824: Mexico becomes a republic.
1830: Belgium becomes an independent state after being part of the Netherlands since 1815.
1878: China opens its first embassy in the United States when Chen Lan-pin presents his credentials to President Rutherford B. Hayes.
1904: Frederic Auguste Bartholdi, French sculptor and the creator of the Statue of Liberty, dies at the age of 70.
1905: Orville Wright, American aviator, is the first person to fly an aircraft for more than 33 minutes.
1910: Portugal is proclaimed a republic as King Manuel II flees to Britain.
1924: Charlton Heston, American actor, is born. He was best known for his appearances in such film epics as "El Cid" as well as "Ben Hur" for which he won an Oscar.
1947: The Russians successfully launch Sputnik, the world's first artificial satellite.
1947: Max Planck, German physicist, dies in his home in Gottingen at the age of 89. He won a 1918 Nobel Prize for discoveries in connection with the quantum theory.
1949: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the USSR.
1949: The U.S. State Department reaffirms its recognition of the Nationalist government as the only legal government of China.
1952: The pacemaker, an external device developed by Dr. Paul Zoll of Harvard Medical School, is for the first time fitted to a human, David Schwarts, to control his heartbeat.
1969: Anthony Grey, a Reuters correspondent, is freed from house arrest after being held in Beijing by the Communist China for 20 months.
1974: The 75-member Peiping opera troupe leaves Taipei for the United States on a 72-day performance tour.
1977: The construction of the Shihkang Dam, capable of supplying 420,000 metric tons of water daily, is completed in central Taiwan.
1978: The ROC Ministry of National Defense announces the successful development of the "Hsiung Feng" missile.
1986: A 12-member political reform group of the Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang (KMT) decides to announce the lifting of the emergency decree at the appropriate time and passes legislative principles for the National Security Law during the Period of Communist Rebellion.
1992: An Israeli cargo plane crashes into a residential area in Amsterdam, killing more than 200 people.
1993: Russian troops loyal to President Boris Yeltsin capture the parliament building in Moscow after two days of fighting in which more than 300 die. Vice President Alexander Rutskoi and other parliamentary leaders are herded into Lefortovo prison.
1994: An undersea earthquake rocks Russia's Kuril Islands, killing more than 16 people.
1999: Taiwan's U-Land Airlines forges a cooperation relationship with Vietnam's Pacific Airlines to operate flights between Taipei and Ho Chi Minh City.
2000: Yu Kuo-hwa, former premier of the ROC, dies of respiratory failure at the age of 87 at Taipei Veterans' General Hospital.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian appoints Vice Premier Chang Chun-hsiung to take the place of Tang Fei as premier.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is true of the really great moral man that every act of his life becomes an example for generations, that everything he does becomes a statute for generations, and that every word he utters becomes a law for generations."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. WON'T MAKE DEALS AGAINST TAIWAN'S INTERESTS: POWELL

TEXT.P: U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell stressed Wednesday that the United States will not make any deals against the interests of Taiwan or India in order to win support for the Washington-led global campaign against terrorism.

When meeting with a few foreign news agency journalists, Powell pointed out that Washington will not make any deals to obtain Beijing's participation in the anti-terrorism coalition. And the Bush administration is seeking cooperation with Pakistan and India while striving not to inflame existing tensions between the two nuclear powers, he added.

"We are not changing any of the principled policies that we have been following," he said, adding that "I think those nations that depend on us somewhat for their sense of security should have no fear that somehow their sense of security has been weakened or will be weakened -- like Taiwan."

"There are some things that are immutable. We will always speak out strongly against human rights abuses. We will speak out about religious freedom, and we will speak out about terrorist activity," Powell said.
