DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 47.4 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Thursday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 47.4 points to close at 3,493.66.
Market turnover amounted to NT$44.23 billion (US$1.28 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC CUTS KEY RATES TO RECORD LOWS TO STIMULATE ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Central Bank of China (CBC) has cut key rates to record lows in an effort to rejuvenate the domestic economy, with the cuts being effective as of Thursday.
The CBC cut the discount rate by 0.25 percentage points to 2.50 percent, the 10th cut of its kind since December of last year.
The bank also slashed the accommodations with collateral and accommodations without collateral rates each by 0.25 percentage points to 2.875 percent and 4.75 percent, respectively.

At the same time, the CBC cut the average deposit reserve requirement for banks from 6.22 percent to 5.0 percent, and slashed the reserve requirement on foreign currency deposits from 10 percent to 5 percent.

The interest rate cuts, the largest since February 1999, promise to lead about NT$194.6 billion (US$5.64 billion) to be released onto the domestic capital market, helping to spur economic activity, CBC officials said.

By offering the prominent rates cuts, the CBC aims to lower domestic banks' capital and operational costs, which is expected to help increase the banks' competitiveness once Taiwan joins the World Trade Organization.
The CBC urged domestic banks to reflect the lowered capital costs by cutting basic loan rates in order to spur economic activity and stimulate consumption and investment.

Cheered by the quarter-point cut in local interest rates, Taiwan's stock market, particularly banking stocks, gained momentum Thursday, celebrating lowered capital costs with reduced reserve requirements for banks.
Thursday's across-the-board rate cuts were also partly made because of Tuesday's half-point interest rate cut by the U.S. Federal Reserve, its ninth cut this year.
In response to the CBC rate cuts, major domestic banks said Thursday that interest rates at their banks will be cut by an average of 0.25 percent beginning next week.
As a result, officials of the banks said, the rate of one-year time savings may be maintained at 3 percent, or lower.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 47.4 points to close at 3,493.66.

Encouraged by cuts to key rates by the Central Bank of China and by a surge in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 3,610.16 but began to go down later due to a lack of confidence on the part of investors. The index fluctuated between 3,610.16 and 3,491.32 during trading.

A total of 2.13 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$44.23 billion (US$1.28 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.48 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$29.32 billion (US$0.85 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile issues moving down the most at 1 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 0.5 percent, and plastics and chemical stocks at 0.2 percent.

The other major categories posted gains, with bank and insurance shares moving up the most at 4.6 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 1.3 percent, construction stocks at 0.9 percent, electrical shares at 0.7 percent, and cement stocks at 0.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 318 to 199, with 113 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher on Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for October moved up 43 points to close at 3,473, with 17,518 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for November rose 38 points to finish at 3,460, with 83 contract transactions, while December futures increased 36 points to close at 3,485, with three contracts traded.
Next June futures gained 135 points to close at 3,650, with only one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 3,430 for October, 3,422 for November, 3,449 for December, 3,457 for next March, and 3,515 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were generally higher.
October TE futures edged up 0.85 points to close at 155.45, with 5,054 contract transactions, while November TE futures decreased 1.3 points to finish at 153.5, with 71 contracts traded.
Next March TE futures rose 2.75 points to close at 161, with three contract transactions, while next June TE futures gained 2.3 points to finish at 158.8, with 22 contracts changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
October TF futures surged 30.8 points to finish at 595.8, with 3,188 contract transactions, while November TF futures gained 28.6 points to close at 591.8, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: POWELL STATEMENT INDICATES GREAT FRIENDSHIP TO TAIWAN: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government spokesman expressed welcome Thursday for U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell's latest remarks that the United States will not make deals against Taiwan's interests, describing it as "a very friendly statement" toward Taiwan.

Su Tzeng-ping, director-general of the Government Information Office, said Powell's remarks have given Taiwan a sense of relief at a time when Washington and Beijing are stepping up strategic cooperation in collaborative actions against terrorism, a process which some observers in Taiwan fear may consequently compromise Taiwan's interests.

Powell stressed during a meeting with several foreign news agency journalists Wednesday that the United States will not make any deals against the interests of Taiwan or India in order to win support for the Washington-led global campaign against terrorism.

Powell noted that Washington will not make any deals to obtain Beijing's participation in the anti-terrorism coalition and that the Bush administration is seeking cooperation with Pakistan and India while striving not to inflame existing tensions between the two nuclear powers.

He was quoted as saying that "we are not changing any of the principled policies we have been following, and I think those nations that depend on us somewhat for their sense of security should have no fear that somehow their sense of security has been weakened or will be weakened -- like Taiwan."

"There are some things that are immutable. We will always speak out strongly against human rights abuses. We will speak out about religious freedom, and we will speak out about terrorist activity," Powell said.

Su noted that Powell's public remarks were so clear that Taiwan could feel the great friendship from Washington, saying at the same time that he believes that such open statements carry their own important meanings and messages.

Meanwhile, the spokesman disclosed that the Bush administration has assured Taiwan, via proper channels over the past several days, that the United States will not compromise Taiwan's interests during the process of engaging in cooperation with mainland China against global terrorism.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-PIRACY GROUP AND POLICE UNCOVER CD PIRACY OPERATIONS IN S. TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Police and an anti-piracy group uncovered a massive operation in southern Taiwan that was bootlegging millions of NT dollars' worth of CDs and VCDs, a spokesman for the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry (IFPI) Members' Foundation in Taiwan said Thursday.

The IFPI anti-piracy group and police together raided an illegal music CD and VCD packaging plant in Tainan, southern Taiwan Wednesday evening and found 100,000 pirated music CDs featuring famous artists from Taiwan and VCDs of major motion pictures. Police said it was most likely the largest such operation in Taiwan.
The pirated music CDs and movie VCDs were estimated to have a market value of NT$40 million.

Elsewhere, in an early morning police raid at a warehouse in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, Thursday, more than 20,000 pirated music CDs and VCDs were discovered. The street value of the bootlegged discs was estimated to exceed NT$6 million.
IFPI Taiwan has filed lawsuits against 11 wholesale distributors of the pirated products who were arrested by police in the Tainan raid, according to the spokesman.
He said that IFPI Taiwan had been collecting information about the suspects for more than two months. The IFPI group and the police decided to take action at suspicious sites Wednesday evening.
IFPI is the organization representing the international recording industry, with a membership of 1,400 record producers and distributors in 76 countries.
Since its establishment in 1986, IFPI Taiwan has coordinated with police in numerous raids at factories and distribution points of pirated music CDs around the island and on Penghu.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD BLOCK TERRORIST MONEY LAUNDERING: FORMER U.S. STATESMAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan should make every possible effort to prevent its banks from becoming a "safe haven" for money laundering by terrorists, a retired U.S. diplomat said in Taipei Thursday.
Harvey Feldman, a former alternate U.S. representative to the United Nations, made the suggestion in a speech delivered at the Republic of China's Legislative Yuan.

Feldman, now a senior fellow in China policy at the Washington-based Heritage Foundation, said he sees no room for mainland China to take advantage of the current U.S. anti-terrorism campaign to sway U.S. policy away from Taiwan.
Quoting U.S. President George W. Bush, Feldman said every country in the world must decide on its own which side it will take in the ongoing U.S.-led campaign against global terrorism.
Feldman further dismissed as "nonsense" speculation that the United States will bargain away Taiwan's interests in seeking Beijing's cooperation in its war on terrorism.

He pointed out that Taiwan's future will neither be determined by the United States nor by Japan or mainland China. "It will all be up to the people of Taiwan to set forth the island's destiny," he stressed.
As for what Taiwan can do to assist the United States in its current campaign against terrorism, Feldman said the United States does not want Taiwan to provide either military bases or troops.
The most important thing Taiwan can do for the anti-terrorism campaign is to block terrorist money laundering through its banking system, Feldman said.

Touching on Taiwan's current issue of whether to boycott the annual summit meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to be held in Shanghai later this month in retaliation for Beijing's continuous denigration of the ROC's participation in relevant activities, Feldman said it may occasionally be useful to enter a fight you know you are not going to win in order to make a point.

"But if you do that, you also have to know when it's wise to decide that you have made the point and withdraw rather than to continue to press the issue past the point where it has any utility," Feldman said.
Noting that the fact of the matter is that it's useful for Taiwan to be represented in APEC activities, Feldman said Taiwan should know when it must make a "graceful withdrawal."
APEC, a 21-member regional forum dedicated to promoting free trade and investment, is one of the few multinational organizations which includes both Taiwan and mainland China.
Because of mainland China's opposition, the ROC president has been barred from attending the annual APEC summit in person and should appoint a proxy.

In the past, the host country of the APEC summit sent a special envoy to Taipei to forward a formal invitation to the ROC head of state. This year's host, mainland China, has so far not sent a formal invitation to President Chen Shui-bian. It only faxed a notice to Taipei in May giving the date of the APEC summit. The notice lacked the title of its targeted recipient. Taipei officials said President Chen has a legitimate right to attend the APEC summit and that Beijing's APEC protocol breach is yet another move to denigrate Taiwan.

Commenting on Beijing's failure to uphold the APEC protocol, Feldman said if mainland China behaves in an uncivilized way, it simply makes the point that Taiwan has a civilized government. "They'll make themselves look foolish. They make themselves look small," he added.

Feldman further said APEC is a meeting place where Taiwan officials can interact on the basis of equality with officials from other Asian countries. "I believe as countries become accustomed to dealing with Taiwan on an equal basis, Taiwan gains," he said.

During his stint as the China desk chief at the U.S. Department of State, Feldman helped create the American Institute in Taiwan, the quasi-official U.S. body authorized to handle relations with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties. Feldman was also a co-author of the Taiwan Relations Act, the U.S. law regulating substantive ties with the ROC.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PREPARING FIVE-YEAR TAX HOLIDAY FOR FOREIGN REGIONAL CENTERS

TEXT.P: The government is working on a bill that would give a five-year tax holiday to domestic and foreign enterprises that make Taiwan their regional headquarters, sources from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Thursday.

The bill is aimed at spurring domestic and foreign investment and increasing the profile of foreign businesses in Taiwan and is expected to be drafted in November for legislative screening, said Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi.

Lin said participants at the presidential Economic Development Advisory Conference held in mid-August suggested that Taiwan emulate Singapore and solicit foreign investment by offering serious incentives, including tax reductions and exemptions. Singapore currently offers a 10-year, tax-free holiday for multinational corporations that maintain regional business operations centers in the city-state.
Lin said corporations involving manufacturing or technological services are potential beneficiaries of Taiwan's five-year, tax-free investment incentive.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.001 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Thursday, closing at 34.568.
The local currency opened Thursday at 34.598 and was traded between 34.561 and 34.600.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$264 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER VICE PREMIER LIU STRESSES DISASTER PREVENTION

TEXT.P: The central and local governments of Taiwan have been paying too much attention to addressing natural disasters after they happen while not doing enough prevention work, former Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Thursday.
Liu was invited by the Taipei City Government to head a committee for the reconstruction and rehabilitation of areas hit by Typhoon Nari at the committee's first full meeting Thursday morning.

Liu said that government officials have seldom given priority to disaster prevention measures in their administrative planning. Adequate precautionary measures could spare the island tremendous losses and destruction caused by disasters, he added.

A trained scientist, Liu said that the National Science Council adopted a resolution 20 years ago to develop a national disaster prevention system. However, the project was approved by the legislature only a few years ago. Global atmospheric changes have made natural disasters more frequent and previously gathered data obsolete, he said.
He also said that people should keep in mind the importance of ecological sustainability when doing reconstruction work.

The Taipei City Government has entrusted the committee to develop a disaster prevention and rescue system. The committee should also locate problem areas in the city's drainage systems and the mass transportation system. It should also address water and soil preservation on hillsides.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said at the meeting that at least NT$10 billion was needed for post-Typhoon Nari reconstruction projects. The city government expects specialists of the committee to offer their expertise to help with rebuilding and to find measures to prevent future disasters.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HONORS OUTSTANDING SENIOR TEACHERS

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian gave a lunch in honor of 796 outstanding senior teachers, whose teaching careers have surpassed 40 years, at the Chungshan Building on Yangmingshan Thursday.

Before the lunch party, the senior teachers received citations from Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh and Minister of Education Ovid Tzeng. The ceremony was originally scheduled to take place on Teachers' Day Sept. 28, but was postponed till Thursday because of Typhoon Lekima.

President Chen praised the contributions of the teachers to the country's education, saying that the success of the government's educational reform relies on the support of the people and the participation of the teachers.
He said that the teachers are not only models for the students and the ones that can be instrumental in the success of students, but also the key persons in the process of educational reform.
A message by Premier Chang Chun-hsiung's was read on the occasion. He expressed thanks to the senior teachers for their long years of contributing to the cultivation of the younger generation.
The honored senior teachers are from public and private colleges and the schools affiliated with the province of Taiwan, Taipei City and Kaohsiung City.

Tsai Ying, principal of the Tungyuan Elementary School in Hsinchu, spoke on behalf of the senior teachers, saying that they are determined to follow the spirit of Confucius to continue their efforts to sow the seeds of learning.

Another representative of the teachers, Cheng Jui, said that the teachers are grateful because the government never neglected the importance of education, no matter the obstacles. "We are the witnesses of history," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, COSTA RICAN PRESIDENTS ON HOTLINE OVER TYPHOON DISASTER

TEXT.P: Costa Rican President Miguel Angel Rodriguez telephoned President Chen Shui-bian Thursday to express his concern about the devastation caused by recent typhoons in Taiwan.
Rodriguez conveyed to President Chen the sympathy and condolences of the people of Costa Rica for those who were killed in typhoons that barreled through Taiwan last month.

Rodriguez said he is convinced that under the leadership of President Chen, the people of Taiwan will be able to overcome all difficulties in the wake of the disasters and rebuild their lives with courage and perseverance.
"I believe that Taiwan will emerge even stronger from the recent typhoon devastation just as it did after a 7.3-magnitude earthquake rattled the island Sept. 21, 1999," Rodriguez said.
For his part, Chen expressed his heartfelt gratitude for the concern and support extended by the Costa Rican government and people at this time of hardship.
"Our government and people are moved by greetings from you. We truly appreciate the goodwill and friendship shown by your government and people," Chen told Rodriguez.

Because of its special geographic location and environment, Chen said, Taiwan is hit by earthquakes and typhoons from time to time. Two typhoons -- Nari and Lekima -- lashed Taiwan with gusty winds and torrential rains in September, leaving nearly 100 people dead and missing and causing huge property damage.
Chen said the people of Taiwan will never be daunted by natural disasters and would weather all challenges with wisdom, expertise and experience.

During their phone talks, Rodriguez also mentioned that the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States and the lingering economic gloom in the United States, Japan and major European countries has affected economic development in both Costa Rica and the Republic of China.
Rodriguez said his country will learn from Taiwan's experience in tackling various adversities and challenges in order to sustain its economic development.
In their conversation, Chen said he remembered that the first congratulatory phone call he received after winning the presidential election in March 2000 was from Rodriguez.
Chen further said he has fond memories of his state visit to Costa Rica last year and his meeting with Rodriguez in El Salvador in May this year when both of them attended a Central American summit.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN CALLS FOR CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE UNDER WTO FRAMEWORK
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 4 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has reaffirmed the Republic of China's desire to conduct dialogue with mainland China under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Chen made the reaffirmation in an interview with the Mainichi Shimbun, a Japanese daily. Chen gave the interview in Taipei Wednesday, and the Japanese paper published the interview in its Thursday issue.

Chen said in the interview that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait finally won official clearance in September to join the WTO. "We hope to engage in dialogue and contacts with mainland China under the WTO framework after both sides formally become members of the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body early next year," he noted.

It would be inevitable that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait conduct talks and engagements after their WTO accession, Chen said, adding that mainland China should understand that if it continues to decline dialogue with Taiwan, cross-strait differences can never be settled.

"Both of us must shelve our political disputes and sit down to talk to mend out differences," Chen said, adding that the opening of direct trade, mail and transportation links, commonly known as "big three links," could be topics for cross-strait negotiations under the WTO framework.

Chen said since he assumed office in May 2000, he has spared no efforts to maintain peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait. "I'm convinced that cross-strait relations will improve only under a stable environment. This is also the basis for upgrading cross-strait ties," he explained.

Chen said although Beijing has so far made no response to his repeated goodwill appeals, he will not be daunted and will never give up his efforts to seek a breakthrough to the lingering cross-strait limbo.
In the interview, Chen also expressed his strong desire to attend the 2001 summit meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to be held in Shanghai later this month.

Since the ROC is an APEC member, Chen said, he has a legitimate right to attend the annual APEC summit in person. Because of Beijing's opposition, the ROC president has been barred from attending the APEC summit in person and has to name a proxy to attend in his stead.

Touching on relations between Taiwan and the United States, Chen said the basic U.S. policy toward Taiwan has remained unchanged. Nevertheless, Chen said substantive ROC-U.S. ties have made remarkable progress this year. "The increased U.S. arms sales are U.S. recognition of Taiwan's democratization and would help upgrade Taiwan's defense capabilities," he added.
Chen also reaffirmed the ROC's full support for the current U.S.-led campaign against global terrorism.
Turning to Taiwan's upcoming legislative elections, Chen said no party is expected to win more than half of seats in the new legislature to be elected on Dec. 1.

"Taiwan's political landscape is expected to show significant changes after the elections," Chen said, adding that his Democratic Progressive Party is now endeavoring to become the largest party in the new legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LAUNCHES CAMPAIGN TO PROMOTE INFORMATION APPLIANCE PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's National Information Infrastructure (NII) Enterprise Promotion Association kicked off a campaign Thursday to promote information appliance (IA) flagship products made in Taiwan and to create industry standards.
The campaign is jointly headed by the association's chairman, Hsia Han-min, Acer Group Chairman Stan Shih and National Science Council Vice Chairman Wu Maw-kuen.

Shih said at a news conference to announce the launching of the campaign that following the personal computer, IAs are the next major industry opportunity for Taiwan companies competing internationally.
However, he continued, various kinds of services, key applications and compatible platforms must exist before the IA industry can truly take off.

IAs must be standardized, and the cost for required key hardware elements like central processing units, displays and flash memories must be driven lower through market proliferation in order to conform with the necessary IA characteristics of being lightweight and inexpensive, he added.
Shih said that the ubiquitous cellular phone is only a basic service, and that "smart hand-helds" bundled with content and software services are what will drive the industry forward.
The NII campaign seeks to bring together various IA-related industry alliances in Taiwan to create industry-wide standards and to facilitate the sharing of market information.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER WANTS STIFFER PENALTIES FOR FORGING CURRENCY

TEXT.P: Those convicted of forging Taiwan currency should face stiffer penalties in the future, Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan said Thursday.

Chen said that although the current law prescribes punishment for counterfeiting money to be a minimum of five years in prison, many judges have been handing down sentences of less than five years. The maximum penalty for currency forgery is death.

In other words, judges have not meted out sentences in line with the law, he said, adding that prosecutors' offices are not clear about exactly what criteria judges have been using to pass judgment on currency forgery cases.
A ministry task force on counterfeit bills will meet Friday. They are expected to invite representatives from the Judicial Yuan to help with the effort.

Chen said that in the future, prosecutors will request the maximum penalty for those who seriously disrupt financial stability and order by making or passing bogus currency. The ministry is also considering revising the law to raise the minimum penalty for counterfeiting currency.

Under current law, those who have been convicted of intentionally passing fake bills, but have not themselves forged the notes, should be sentenced to a minimum of three years and a maximum of 10 years in prison.

Addressing Chen's remarks, Yang Jen-shou, secretary-general of the Judicial Yuan, said that judges mete out sentences based on the situations surrounding each individual case, and he disagreed that sentences that have been given by judges have been lower than the minimum.

Chen, who is known for his integrity, said that fake bills will not only disrupt financial order, but will also affect people's confidence. With the current economic situation being less than ideal, he believes a stable economic environment is especially important.
Chen also urged the public to report fake bill to the police.

The Central Bank of China (CBC) has recently adopted several measures to curb the circulation of forged bills, including requesting local banks to reimburse the recipients for counterfeit bills distributed by their clerks or automatic teller machines.

The CBC has also stepped up efforts to teach the public methods to distinguish real bills from counterfeit ones. The CBC has run advertisements in newspapers, advising the public to carefully examine notes that are given them using one or more of the methods of verification, such as observing if the note bears the concealed numbers "1000" or "500" when holding the NT$1,000 and NT$500 denomination bills against the light.
CBC Governor Perng Fai-nan also went out of his way to visit a traditional food market in Taipei Sunday to publicize the ways of discerning genuine bank notes.
Statistics compiled by major financial institutions show that about 1,000 fake bills are reported each month, with the new versions of the NT$1,000 and NT$500 denominations being the most common.

Compared with previous statistics of the numbers of fake notes in circulation, the figure does not represent a marked increase. But a sluggish economy may fuel the sense of loss when fake bills are received, law enforcement officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP'S DIANE LEE RATED MOST OUTSTANDING LEGISLATOR IN POLL

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) legislator Diane Lee is the most outstanding legislator, according to the result of a public opinion poll released Thursday.
The telephone poll of 1,018 randomly chosen adult residents was conducted by Open magazine from Oct. 1-3, with a margin error of 3.1 percent.

Other legislators making the top 10 list were Lai Shyh-bao of the opposition New Party (NP), Shen Fu-hsiung of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), Hsieh Chi-ta (NP), Chu Li-lun of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), Lin Jui-tu (independent), Lin Cho-shui (DPP), Chou Hsi-wei (PFP), Ting Shou-chung (KMT), and Yu Yueh-hsia (KMT).
According to the poll, the respondents gave an average score of 56.43 points to the overall performance of all members of the current Legislative Yuan whose tenure will end early next year.
About 30 percent of those interviewed said they felt that all incumbent legislators have not performed well during their terms of office.
Poll results also showed that 82 percent support the proposal that the legislative roster be halved. The current number of legislators is 225. The new legislature will be elected Dec. 1.
In terms of party, DPP lawmakers as a whole outperformed their counterparts of other political parties, according to the poll.

As for the upcoming elections, 38 percent said they would cast their ballots in terms of individual candidates' personal qualifications, not their party affiliation. Eighty-one percent said they would go to the poll on the day of the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OFFICIAL REBUTS FORMER PRESIDENT'S ACCUSATIONS AGAINST PARTY

TEXT.P: A heavyweight of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) rebutted as groundless Thursday former Republic of China president and former KMT chairman Lee Teng-hui's accusation that the KMT "allies itself with (Chinese) communists against Taiwan."

Chin Hsiao-yi, chairman of a KMT foundation, made the remark at an international academic forum on modern China's history. Chin was former deputy secretary-general of the KMT's Central Committee and former head of the National Palace Museum.
Chin said that Lee, who led the ROC government and the KMT for 12 years, is to blame for the current political situation in the ROC and should conduct a deep self-examination.
The forum was sponsored by the KMT to celebrate next Wednesday's 90th anniversary of the 1911 revolution that led to the overthrow of the Ching dynasty and the founding of the ROC.
Lee harshly criticized the KMT many times after he was forced to step down as party chairman following the 107-year-old party's humiliating defeat in the 2000 presidential election.

He has also been stumping for candidates of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) for the year-end legislative and local government elections. The TSU is a newly founded political group which regards Lee as its spiritual leader.
Lee's behavior so angered KMT members that he was ousted from the party Sept. 21.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA'S COMPETITIVENESS `OVERRATED': ECONOMIC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: An economic official claimed Thursday that fraud and corruption in mainland China have eaten up between 13 percent and 17 percent of its gross national product and that the country's competitive edge has been overblown.

Lee Kao-chao, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said that the mainland should share only a portion of global investments by Taiwan businessmen and that such businessmen should not rely on the mainland too much.
He also said that Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China should make good use of their individual advantages and cooperate between themselves to face global competition.

Lee made the remarks at a symposium on how Taiwan industry can deal with globalization by entering the greater China market, which was sponsored by the non-profit Taiwan Institute of Economic Research and attended by businessmen as well as government officials.

Lee said that as manufacturers seek to globalize and cope with competition from their rivals, they have moved their production bases out of Taiwan in droves, citing as an example that Taiwan's information technology industry last year used mainland China as the base for overseas production.
More than 85 percent of Taiwan-produced keyboards, mice and scanners were made in the mainalnd last year, making competitiveness between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait even more fierce, Lee said.

He also quoted an article titled "Much Exaggeration of the Economic Challenge from China" carried by the Aug. 30 edition of the International Herald Tribute that said the advantage of the mainland is mainly "cheap labor, not rapidly rising skills."

In addition, the article also said that "almost all the higher-tech Chinese output depends on Taiwanese and other foreign know-how and on tax breaks," and that mainland China's export competitiveness remains concentrated in labor-intensive products of foreign-owned factories."

Lee said that although the mainland economy continues to grow rapidly, its legal system is not yet healthy and complete, local protectionism is rampant, its policy lacks transparency, corruption among its cadres is serious, and the practice of bogus products and rampant tax evasion have resulted in tax revenue losses of up to 100 billion renminbi yearly.

Official statistics by the mainland also show that up to 66 percent of state-owned enterprises fake their financial reports, up to 50 percent of individual companies evade taxes, and between 15 percent and 20 percent of the budget earmarked for infrastructure construction is siphoned off through fraud, bribery and shabby public works.

Lee said that the pursuit of mutual benefits and prosperity have been the axis of the Republic of China government's mainland policy. Taiwan, with its geographical and cultural advantages and its rich experience in international trade, should make good use of the advantages of Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China to become the key to Chinese economic circles, he went on.

He pointed out the resources, markets, development strategies and technologies of the three places are different and that all three have also developed their own respective development patterns and industrial situations, offering room for cooperation, although he warned that Taiwan's trade opportunity lies not in mainland China but in the global market.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DOCTOR ANNOUNCES RESULTS OF STUDY ON CREUTZFELDT-JAKOB DISEASE
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung County, southern Taiwan, Oct. 4 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan doctor who has been studying Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) announced the results of his research Thursday and said that the 110 outbreaks of CJD in Taiwan since 1996 are not related to diet or profession.

Chen Shun-sheng, the neurology department director at Kaohsiung Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, said that 92.7 percent of the 49 men and 61 women who contracted the brain-wasting disease were over 50 years old.
He said that the CJD and a new variant -- vCJD -- are both prion diseases like bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), more commonly known as mad cow disease.
A prion is a self-replicating protein that researchers believe is responsible for causing sponge-like holes inside the brain of affected cattle or humans.

No direct evidence has been discovered to prove that the prion that causes BSE also causes CJD, but the possible spread of the BSE prion from cattle to humans has caused alarm in Europe and the United States in recent years.

Chen said that most of the cases around the world where humans have contracted CJD after ingesting BSE-contaminated beef products were of the new variant, but that all of the 110 cases in Taiwan were of the original CJD strain.
Avoiding beef or beef products from BSE-affected regions is the first step toward protection against CJD, he added.

Chen urged the public not to be overly worried, pointing out that the government has already banned the import of relevant products from BSE-affected regions and that the 0.8-in-a-million average rate of CJD contraction in Taiwan is lower than the world average of one-in-a-million.
Chen's research was sponsored by the Center for Disease Control under the Department of Health.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CHANGES SCHEDULE FOR NATIONAL DAY CELEBRATIONS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has changed part of the schedule for National Day celebrations this year because of the effect of two typhoons in September.
In the past, the government invited some 7,000 dignitaries from home and abroad to attend the National Day celebrations. The number will be limited to around 6,000 persons this year.
As the Taipei Guest House is being renovated, the annual National Day reception to be held on the evening of Oct. 10 will be shifted to the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
This year, delegations to the National Day celebrations from diplomatic allies will include those from Tuvalu, Malawi, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, and Honduras.
Missions from the countries which maintain no formal relations with Taiwan will include those from Russia, Belarus, South Korea, Switzerland and the United States.
Meanwhile, the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission has also canceled the "four seas, one heart" welcoming rally for overseas Chinese coming to Taiwan, originally scheduled for the evening of Oct. 9.
The trips for the overseas Chinese to visit the counties and cities between Oct. 13-15 have also been canceled. Instead, they are encouraged to visit the National Palace Museum.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEAK AT NUCLEAR POWER PLANT WILL NOT AFFECT PUBLIC SAFETY: AEC

TEXT.P: Atomic Energy Council (AEC) officials said Thursday that a leak of boric acid at a nuclear power plant in Taipei County will not affect public safety, although it reveals gross negligence on the part of state-owned Taiwan Power Company (Taipower).

AEC officials said that it was investigating the cause of the incident and where the blame should be laid. AEC spokesman Ouyang Ming-sheng added that the AEC will demand that Taipower, which currently runs the island's three nuclear power plants, review and improve its plant safety upon completion of the investigation.

The officials said the incident took place Sept. 24, when six tons of boric acid leaked from a tank at the first generator of the second nuclear power plant in Chinshan, Taipei County, during maintenance work. The acid is supposed to act as the last line of defense in the event of a reactor meltdown.
The nuclear power plant has two generators with a combined capacity of 1,970 megawatts.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL BASKETBALL TEAM OFFICIALLY RELOCATES TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A local basketball team financed by Chinese-language Internet portal Sina.com announced Thursday that it is officially quitting the basketball scene in Taiwan and relocating to mainland China.

Daniel Chiang, president of the British Virgin Islands-based E-Ternational Sports Ventures Co., which owns the team, said that the decision was made because of the lack of permission by the Taipei authorities to allow the team to include "Taipei" or "Taiwan" in its team name when it competes in mainland China's National Basketball League.

Chiang, who flew back to Taiwan from mainland China earlier in the day, said that on Friday he will personally lead the team coach and the nine Taiwan-based players to their new home in Suzhou in Jiangsu Province.
The players from Taiwan will be joined by two players hired from the United States and two from mainland China.
The team, which was founded in December last year, will represent the city of Suzhou in the top-ranking A League of the Chinese league, but it wanted to identify where most of the players come from.

However, names including the word "Taiwan" or "Taipei" as proposed by the team were rejected by Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council and the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, on the grounds that it might boost Beijing's claims that Taiwan is a part of its territory.
The new season for the A League begins Dec. 8. Approximately two weeks prior to that, the China Basketball Management Center is scheduled to conduct physical testing on all the players taking part.

DOC.HEADLINE: KIDNAPPED TAICHUNG CITY COUNCIL VICE SPEAKER RELEASED

TEXT.P: Taichung City Council Vice Speaker Chang Hung-nien, who was abducted for ransom Oct. 1, was freed Thursday, police said later that day.
Chang returned home by taxi in the early evening and later gave a press conference at the request of the media, during which he said that the abduction was a "misunderstanding."
He claimed that he was not the target of the abductors and added that "they treated me well," but asked whether a ransom was paid for his release, Chang became evasive.

According to Taichung City Police Bureau Director Chang Ching-yu, the abduction was the work of Hsueh Chiu and Chen Yi-hua, who are wanted for their involvement in a shooting incident in Miaoli County and several jewelry shop robberies.
The police officer said that although the abductors demanded a ransom of NT$300 million for Chang's release, his family had not paid the ransom.

Learning of Chang's safe release, many local political leaders rushed to his home to show their concern. They included Taichung Mayor Chang Wen-ying, Taichung City Council Speaker Chang Liao Kuei-chuan, former Taichung Mayor Lin Po-jung and the Democratic Progressive Party and Kuomintang candidates for the year-end Taichung mayor election.
Police said their investigation was continuing.

DOC.HEADLINE: POST-921 QUAKE WORK TO FOCUS ON RESETTLEMENT OF AFFECTED RESIDENTS

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Thursday that the focus of post-Sept. 21 earthquake work over the next year will be on the resettlement of underprivileged groups and the reconstruction of their houses.
Chang made the declaration when he convened the latest meeting of the 921 Earthquake Post Disaster Recovery Commission in Miaoli, northern Taiwan.

The 7.3-magnitude killer temblor of Sept. 21, 1999 caused the deaths of more than 2,400 people -- the largest number of victims of a natural disaster in a century in Taiwan -- as well as heavy property losses. Many of the scenic spots in Nantou County bore the brunt of the disastrous quake.

The premier said that although public works such as reconstruction of roads, bridges, schools and public buildings have largely been completed or are bordering completion, the resettlement of affected residents and the reconstruction of their homes have yet to be completed.

He asked related government agencies to set up a one-stop service window and hold presentations in the affected areas so as to learn more about the problems of the resettlement and house reconstruction and work out solutions to these problems.
He described the task ahead as "daunting" but urged the related government agencies to complete the reconstruction work soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI URGES BEIJING TO STOP SETTING BARRIERS TO CIVILIAN EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) urged Beijing Thursday to refrain from setting up political hurdles to bilateral civilian exchanges after a group of mainland rollerskaters competing in Taiwan repeatedly lodged complaints on political issues.

The Cabinet-level MAC, which is the government's highest policy-making body in mainland China affairs, released a statement saying that all international tournaments held in Taiwan follow the "Olympic model," but the model cannot be applied outside of the sporting venue and cannot be used to govern the actions of members of the public.

A day earlier, the mainland team competing in an ongoing Asian rollerskating tournament in eastern Taiwan had complained about the presence of an ROC flag inside the venue, prompting its removal by the tournament organizers, who were bound to do so under a previous agreement.

The move, however, angered local residents, who then hoisted hundreds of the nation's flags outside the rink and cut down the mainland flag under cover of darkness, whereupon the mainland team threatened to quit the competition altogether in protest.

The MAC statement noted that the "self-initiated" actions of the residents who hoisted the flags and the waving of the ROC flag by the crowd watching the competition do not interfere with the competition, and that the tournament organizers are in no position to prevent them from such actions.
The MAC also extended its "sympathies" to the "mainland professionals who carry the burden of conducting political interventions" during bilateral exchanges.
It called for mutual respect and urged mainland China to stop "doing things that would hurt the feelings of the people from both sides of the Taiwan Strait."

DOC.HEADLINE: FIVE COUNTERFEITING SUSPECTS NABBED

TEXT.P: Five suspects in a counterfeit money ring were arrested and a total of NT$254,500 (US$7,334) fake bills in NT$1,000 and NT$500 denominations seized when police raided various locations in Taipei and Taoyuan County Thursday.
The five suspects were Ting Po-chun, 47, and 18-year-olds Lin Chia-ming and Lee Chien-yi, as well as Ho Ming-kuei, 30 and Wei Tzu-chun, 26.

Police first discovered that Ting had abetted the two teenagers in exchanging forged bills for real money at the mass rapid transit stop on Nanking West Road that morning. The police were later able to track down the other two suspects in the Wanhua district of western Taipei and in Chungli, Taoyuan County.
As one of the suspects was discovered to be in the pay of a local gang leader, police suspect that gangsters might play a role in the counterfeit ring.
The suspects told police that an undercover plant has already produced a large number of fake bills, although they did not say how many have already been circulated in the market.
Police said they are now targeting the forged bill factory, which is said to be located in central Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PALAU AMBASSADOR TO ROC PRESENTS CREDENTIALS TO PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: New Palau Ambassador to the Republic of China Johnson Toribiong presented the credentials to President Chen Shui-bian Thursday at the Presidential Office.

Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Wu Tzu-dan, Director John Feng of the Protocol Department under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Deputy Secretary-General to the President Eugene Chien witnessed the ceremony.

Chen welcomed Toribiong, who will serve as Palau's first ambassador to the ROC, and noted that Palau is a famous diving resort with abundant tourism resources, with the number of tourist arrivals from Taiwan alone last year exceeding 13,000, behind only the number of visitors from Japan.
He said that the two countries can proceed with further exchanges and cooperation in the fields of culture and tourism in the future.
Toribiong said for his part that it is his honor to act as the first Palau ambassador to the ROC.
He thanked the ROC for its various assistance to Palau and conveyed Palau President Tommy Esang Remengesau's regards to the ROC.
The ROC and Palau established diplomatic relations Dec. 29, 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TAKES STEPS TO PROMOTE BIO-TECHNOLOGY INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) Director-General Shih Yen-hsiang said Thursday that Taiwan's investment in the bio-technology industry in the coming five years will top NT$150 billion.
Shih noted that the Executive Yuan's plan for promoting the bio-technology industry has been revised three times and added that the plan will be implemented faithfully.
The immediate target of the plan, he said, is to achieve 25 percent annual growth in the revenues of the bio-technology industry over the next five years.
He added that more than 500 companies connected with the development of bio-technology will be established within the next 10 years.

According the IDB's estimate, the island's investment in the bio-technology industry this year will amount to NT$30 billion, with NT$23.1 billion invested so far this year, NT$4.7 billion of which has gone into the field of medical instruments.
Shih noted that Taiwan hopes to develop its bio-technology industry as an important part of related development in Asia and the rest of the world.
He said that the Executive Yuan will continue to push forward plans to build a Hsinchu bio-medical industrial park and related bio-technology-based parks in Taipei, Tainan and various other places.
The Council for Economic Planning and Development, the National Science Council and the Council of Agriculture have been assigned to take charge of related tasks, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 5, or the eighth day of the eighth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1830: Chester A. Arthur, the 21st president of the United States, is born. Arthur became president after the assassination of James A. Garfield.
1908: Bulgaria declares its independence from the Ottoman Empire with Ferdinand I assuming the title of czar of Bulgaria.
1922: Tsao Kun is elected president of the Peking government.
1930: The first Balkan Conference is held in Athens, with representatives from countries from the Balkan Peninsula and Turkey taking part.
1941: Chinese forces heavily defeat Japanese invaders near the Milo River in northern Hunan Province, killing or wounding nearly 80,000 Japanese troops.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek accepts General George C. Marshall's proposal for a 10-day cease-fire to pave the way for a resumption of peace talks. Marshall arrived in Chungking on Dec. 22, 1945 as U.S. President Harry Truman's special envoy.
1951: The Republic of China's Legislative Yuan passes regulations providing farmland to soldiers.
1958: The United States delivers a batch of "Hercules" ground-to-air missiles, known in Taiwan as the "Goddess of Victory" missiles, to help improve the ROC's national defense.
1970 Anwar Sadat becomes the president of Egypt following the death of Gamal Abdel Nasser.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Togo.
1973: Taiwan's first case of coronary artery surgery is performed at National Taiwan University Hospital.
1974: The third World Chinese Christian Conference opens in Taipei.
1976: The fifth World Chinese Tourism Amity Conference opens in Taipei with E. T. Chu, chairman of the Taiwan Visitors' Association, presiding.
1978: More than 20,000 boy scouts and brownies from Taiwan and 10 foreign countries launch an eight-day series of camping activities in the 5th National Jamboree held in Kaohsiung.
1980: Former Japanese Prime Minister Nobusuke Kishi arrives in Taipei to take part in the 16th Conference of the Asian Parliamentarians Union.
1983: Poland's Solidarity leader Lech Walesa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
1989: The Dalai Lama, Tibet's spiritual leader, wins the Nobel Peace Prize.
1989: Premier Lee Huan instructs the Executive Yuan to set up special task forces to study problems concerning law and order, communications, environmental pollution, public housing, and economic crimes.
1991: Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev pledges to match the United States in scraping tactical nuclear weapons.
1991: Cheng Kung, the first guided missile frigate built in Taiwan, is launched.
1993: Communist China breaks its moratorium on nuclear testing.
1996: Some 50 countries adopt a declaration calling for the earliest possible agreement on a global ban on anti-personnel land mines.
1998: The Judiciary Committee of the U.S. House of Representatives votes to recommend an impeachment inquiry into President Bill Clinton's action during the Monica Lewinsky case.
1999: The U.S. House of Representatives passes a bill in favor of Taiwan's participation in international organizations, especially the World Health Organization.
2000: Hung Chien-hsiung, a 27-year-old man, donates 60 percent of his liver to his father in a transplant operation that is the only way to save the older man's life.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The fact that a man is able to confront the spiritual powers of the universe without any doubt, shows that he understands the will of God. The fact that he is prepared to wait a hundred generations after him for the man of perfect divine nature without any misgiving, shows that he understands the nature of man."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Friday are as follows:
The China Times:
Taichung City Council Deputy Speaker Chang Hung-nien was released after kidnapping.
The United Daily News:
Taichung deputy speaker released by kidnappers.

The Central Daily News:

The China Post:

The Taiwan News:

The Taipei Times:
Flying of ROC flag irks Chinese rollerskaters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TREND MICRO TO LAUNCH NEW ANTI-VIRUS SOFTWARE ON TAIWAN MARKET

TEXT.P: Tokyo-based Trend Micro Inc. will launch its newly developed PC-cillin 2002, an anti-virus scanning program for home computers and wireless devices, on the Taiwan market at the end of October, a company spokesman said Friday.

He said that PC-cillin 2002 is a new version of the company's PC-cillin series applicable to personal digital assistants (PDAs), palms, and pocket PCs. With its "personal firewall" function, the software can defend against malicious viruses such as "CodeRed" and "Nimda" as well as unique threats hidden inside files, email or on the web.
Trend Micro earlier offered a trial run of the program to 5,500 Internet users in Taiwan. A survey regarding virus attacks was conducted among the trial copy users.

The company spokesman said that the survey report showed that 66 percent of the respondents said that their computers or systems had been infected with a virus, and 47 percent said they were able to scan the viruses within 30 minutes and rehabilitate their computer's functions.

With the expansion of Internet applications, viruses have more and more entry points into computers and wireless devices. PC-cillin 2002 can provide automatic real-time scanning to prevent viruses from entering a device during beaming, synchronizing, mailing or Internet downloading, according to the spokesman.

Trend Micro Inc. is a leader in network anti-virus and Internet content security software and services. According to a recently published report from International Data Corporation (IDC), Trend Micro dominates 33 percent of the overall anti-virus server market, 31 percent of the groupware market, and 63 percent of the Internet gateway (web server) market.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 91.8 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Friday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 91.8 points to close at 3,585.46.
Market turnover amounted to NT$41.49 billion (US$1.2 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: DENG XIAOPING'S ELDEST SON SAID TO VISIT TAIWAN NEXT MONTH

TEXT.P: Deng Pufang, the eldest son of the late mainland China patriarch Deng Xiaoping and an activist on behalf of the disabled, will arrive in Taipei early next month for his first ever visit to Taiwan, a major local daily reported Friday.

The United Daily News reported that Deng, invited by the Chinese Taipei Paralympic Committee, will attend as a distinguished guest the Far East & South Pacific Games Federation for the Disabled Table Tennis ranking tournament series scheduled for Nov. 10-11 in Taipei.

The reports said that one of Deng's big wishes had been to visit Taiwan before he died. The younger Deng had seven years ago said clearly that he had "a great desire" to visit Taiwan, but the trip never took place because of his sensitive status.
Deng Pufang will fulfill his father's dream of visiting Taiwan next month, the reports added.

It is known that federations for the disabled in Shandong, Henan, Hebei, Hunan, Guangxi, Anhui and Fujian will send their best athletes to travel to Taiwan with Deng for the tournament. Taiwan has approved Deng's visit as a show of its goodwill regarding promoting cross-strait civilian exchanges, the reports said.

The 58-year-old Deng, who graduated from the physics department at Beijing University, suffered a great deal during the 10-year Cultural Revolution on the mainland. In 1968, he and his younger sister Deng Nan were held in the laboratory at Beijing University for up to four months. It was reported that Deng tried to take his own life by jumping out of a window of the building because he could no longer bear the torture.

Deng sustained spine injuries and was paralyzed from the waist down because he did not receive treatment early enough. Deng was finally able to receive surgery in Canada in 1980, and since the operation, has been able to move around freely in a wheelchair.
Suffering from paralysis, Deng vowed to dedicate the rest of his life to the promotion of disabled people's welfare. He is also the director in chief of the China Welfare Fund for the Handicapped.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER DEFENDS NT$ 30 STANDARD FOR VOTE-BUYING VIOLATIONS

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan on Friday defended the justification for the NT$30 (US$0.87) standard for vote-buying violations, saying that the decision will not be altered despite widespread criticism.

Chen said the decision to fix at NT$30 the level above which law enforcement authorities can prosecute an individual for vote-buying violations was made by the State Public Prosecutor General's Office after a consensus was reached with prosecutor generals and leading prosecutors at all levels.

He stressed the decision, which has been ridiculed by some politicians and elected representatives as unrealistic, will not be changed as the government is determined to stamp out vote-buying in the elections for legislators, city mayors and county chiefs scheduled for Dec. 1.

Chen reiterated that the government is determined to ensure that the year-end elections are not sullied by what has become commonplace in Taiwan politics -- gifts of money or goods in exchange for votes.

He also said that if the NT$30 standard is not regulated, candidates who give out small campaign items, such as lighters, lunar calendars or packs of tissue, could easily be convicted of vote-buying by any prosecutor.
The NT$30 standard actually serves as a form of protection for candidates to-be, Chen said, adding that it also provides prosecutors with a clear-cut definition on determining vote-buying violations.

Expressing evident disapproval with Chen's endorsement of the NT$30 standard, Wu Nai-jen, secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, criticized the decision as "totally unrealistic," and described Chen as an "unworldly" justice minister.
Kuomintang Legislator Cheng Feng-shih ridiculed Chen as a "Martian" from outer space who knows nothing about matters on Earth, especially about Taiwan politics.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher on Friday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for October moved up 80 points to close at 3,553, with 19,351 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for November rose 87 points to finish at 3,547, with 79 contract transactions, while next March futures increased 100 points to close at 3,600, with 20 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 3,473 for October, 3,460 for November, 3,485 for December, 3,500 for next March, and 3,650 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were generally higher.
October TE futures moved up 7.85 points to close at 163.3, with 5,691 contract transactions, while November TE futures increased 9 points to finish at 162.5, with 60 contracts traded.
Next June TE futures gained 7.7 points to finish at 166.5, with 28 contracts changing hands. No transactions were recorded for other months.
October TF futures moved down 0.8 points to finish at 595, with 2,205 contract transactions, while November TF futures gained 3.2 points to close at 595, with six contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 91.8 points to close at 3,585.46.
The bourse opened at 3,502.37 and continued to go up later due to a rebound in electrical shares. The index fluctuated between 3,585.64 and 3,467.94 during trading.

A total of 1.95 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$41.49 billion (US$1.2 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.13 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$44.23 billion (US$1.28 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff shares moving down 1 percent.

The other major categories posted gains, with electrical shares moving up the most at 3.8 percent, followed by plastics and chemical stocks at 2 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.2 percent, construction stocks and bank and insurance shares, both at 1.1 percent, textile issues at 0.9 percent, and cement stocks at 0.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 326 to 192, with 107 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: `WAR IS NOT THE ANSWER' TO SEPT. 11 TERRORIST ATTACKS: CIVIC GROUPS

TEXT.P: Amid reports of an imminent U.S. assault on Afghanistan, more than 100 Taiwan civic groups issued a joint statement Friday, expressing opposition to any military response to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States.

Representatives of the civic groups said at a joint news conference held at the Legislative Yuan that "war is not the answer" to the terrorist attacks that brought down the twin towers of New York City's World Trade Center and partially damaged the Pentagon -- the U.S. military nerve center.

Legislator Chien Hsi-chieh of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, also the chief executive officer (CEO) of the Peacetime Foundation, said local civic groups define the Sept. 11 attacks as a crime that should be tried and judged by the International Court of Justice -- the principal judicial organ of the United Nations.

Noting that the atrocity of Sept. 11 is a global issue, not just a U.S. national affair, Chien said the United States should bring the case to the International Court of Justice and let the perpetrators be tried fairly, justly and openly under the U.N. mechanism.
"Only by so doing can the world avoid the fate of plunging into the vicious cycle of eye-for-eye, violence-for-violence retaliation," Chien noted.

Speaking on the same occasion, Chen Chun-liang, the CEO of the Eden Social Welfare Foundation, said his foundation is strongly opposed to planned U.S. military strikes on any nation suspected of being involved in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks or of sheltering the perpetrators of the attacks.

"Once the retaliatory attacks are put into action, it is evident that many innocent lives will be lost and many other people may be crippled," Chen said, adding that all countries around the world should forgo revenge in a spirit of charity.
In addition to the civic groups, many individual scholars, experts and professionals have also signed the "anti-war, love peace" joint statement.
In related news developments, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) reaffirmed Friday the Republic of China government's support for the ongoing U.S.-led anti-global terrorism campaign.

The MOFA said in a press release that the ROC government will adopt a series of judicial and administrative measures in tandem with its domestic law and the spirit of various U.N.-sponsored anti-terrorism conventions and resolutions to deny money, support and sanctuary to terrorists.

The ROC will also step up exchanges of "operational information," especially regarding the actions and movements of terrorists, with other countries as well as provide all necessary assistance in relevant investigation and criminal suit procedures, the MOFA statement said.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said in a weekly Cabinet meeting Wednesday that although the ROC has been shut out of the United Nations since 1971 simply because of political reasons, it will never waver its support for the global anti-terrorism campaign.

In a significant international response to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the U.N. Security Council (UNSC) unanimously approved last Friday a resolution requiring all 189 U.N.-member nations to deny money, support and sanctuary to terrorists.

Under the legally binding resolution, all countries must make the "willful" financing of terrorism a criminal offense, immediately freeze terrorist-related funds and prevent movement of individuals and groups suspected of having terrorist connections. All member nations must deny terrorists any "safe haven." Additionally, nations must speed the exchange of "operational information," especially regarding the actions and movements of terrorists.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER TO HELP PROMOTE TAIWAN GROCERY IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Taiwan will not be absent from the international fruits and vegetables exposition to be held in mainland China next month, Legislator Lin Feng-hsi from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said Friday.

Actually, Lin will lead a 100-strong Taiwan delegation of farmers, traders and food processors to the international fruits and vegetables expo scheduled to be held Oct. 11-14 in Xiamen, Fujian Province.

Lin said the international expo, co-sponsored by UNESCAP (the United Nations Economic and Social Council in Asian-Pacific), will serve as a bridgehead for Taiwan-produced fruits and vegetables at a time when Taiwan products will soon face fiercer competition when the island accedes to the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Under the banner of "Subtropics, Taiwan Fresh," Taiwan-produced fruits and vegetables will be displayed in 50 booths at the four-day expo, in which more than 1,000 companies from 22 countries as well as the host mainland China will take part, Lin noted.
He added that the expo provides a golden opportunity for Taiwan in its self-promotion efforts under the globally-fair trading environment provided by the WTO program.

It is hoped that Taiwan's delicious fresh fruits and vegetables will become world-brand products enjoying fame equal to that of salmon from Norway, tulips from the Netherlands and kiwi fruit from New Zealand, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FILM INDUSTRY IN NEED OF GOVERNMENT SUPPORT

TEXT.P: Representatives of the local film industry urged the government Friday to provide adequate assistance to the industry, the existence of which, they said, might be further threatened by imported films when Taiwan is admitted into the World Trade Organization (WTO).

At a public hearing at the Legislative Yuan, Wang Ying-hsiang, chairman of the Motion Picture Foundation, said that the government should learn from mainland China, Hong Kong, South Korea and Thailand and map out protective measures for the healthy development of the domestic film business.
Since the late 1980s, Taiwan's film industry has been constantly on the brink of collapse, faced by fierce competition from film studios in Hong Kong and giant international movie companies.

Officials of the fragile movie industry fear that the cancellation of an import quota on foreign films and the suspension of duty on foreign films to meet WTO requirements will pose more difficulties to the industry. Since 1992, the government has charged extra import duty on foreign films, which is funneled into a fund managed by the Government Information Office (GIO) to subsidize local film production.

Statistics released by the GIO Friday indicate that among the more-than 400 films shown in Taiwan last year, only 35 were locally produced, 128 were Hong Kong productions and 280 were imported foreign language films.
In the first eight months of this year, Taiwan's movie studios produced just eight films, all with subsidies from the government.
Even with the subsidies, local movie producers are hesitant to make new films due to marketing difficulties, according to a GIO source.

He pointed out that there are 196 theaters with 619 screens around the island. Last year, he went on, the GIO tried to coordinate these theaters to show locally produced films, but so far, only five locally produced films have been scheduled into their programs.

Movie producer Wang Ying-hsiang suggested that the government help cultivate the film industry under the umbrella of cultural affairs, instead of treating the sector as part of the entertainment business.

The Hong Kong government, he noted, has set aside NT$100 million HK dollars for a fund for good screenplays, while South Korean film production companies get tax rebate. These incentives, he said, would help stimulate investment interest in the sector.

Chiu Shun-ching, director-general of Central Motion Picture Corp., said that in Thailand and South Korea, all foreign films must be dubbed, thus providing many job opportunities for the film industry. He suggested that the authorities concerned adopt similar practices.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SAYS PERFORMANCE OVER PAST YEAR `NOT IDEAL'

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Friday that although he has spent a lot of time and energy on the nation's economy, his performance "has not been ideal" during his one year in office.

The premier was responding to questions during the general interpellation session of the Legislative Yuan when Legislator Chang Fu-hsing of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) asked him about his thoughts over the past year, as well as his best and worst moments.

Chang noted that the nation has undergone political reform, a series of natural disasters and a changed world situation, including a continued sluggish economy and the terrorist attacks in New York and Washington, over the past year.

He said he was grateful that during his year in office, the political situation remained stable and that the series of tests did not lead to the toppling of the Cabinet, as were the cases in Japan, the Philippines and Indonesia.

He also said that the Cabinet has devoted a lot of time and energy to the economy and has also begun overhauling ailing fundamental financial institutions, although he conceded that the performance in this regard has been less than ideal.

He also said the focus of the 2002 fiscal budget is on economic development, citing as an example the fact that the budget for high-tech industries such as telecommunications and agricultural biotechnology will continue to rise in the hope that these sectors will form the backbone of the development of Taiwan's economy, just as the semiconductor industry did two decades ago.
He estimated that the budget earmarked for economic development will be NT$600.8 billion (US$17.31 billion) for the fiscal year.

Responding to questions on whether he will stay on as premier after the year-end legislative elections, Chang said that he will "respect the wishes of the president" concerning whether to stay on after the Dec. 1 elections.

Legislators also questioned whether the listed revenue of more than NT$1.3 trillion listed in the 2002 fiscal budget is reasonable at a time when the economy remains sluggish and accused the government of miscalculating the economic growth rate.
The premier said that although there could be a tax revenue shortfall, other forms of revenue could increase. He added that the gap should not be too large.

Lin Chuang, director-general of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, also noted that the Cabinet had originally predicted that economic recovery would come in the fourth quarter, but since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States, there is now doubt as to whether the 4 percent economic growth rate can be reached and that everything now depends on November's performance.

The premier also said that the decision to float government bonds will have to be made after considering the cost involved and the squeeze it would put on domestic capitals, but his finance minister, Yen Ching-chang, said that the nation has ample capital and that the flotation of bonds would not squeeze domestic capital.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO OVERHAUL FINANCE REGIME TO WEATHER GLOBAL SLOWNESS

TEXT.P: Taiwan was urged Friday by a respected U.S. economics guru to overhaul its domestic financial regime to allow it to weather the global economic sluggishness that has been worsened by the recent terrorist attacks in the United States.

Lester C. Thurow, an economics professor with the prestigious Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said that Taiwan, which has been heavily reliant on the United States in its process of economic development, actually cannot do much to address the situation other than waiting for the United States to recover.

The only other realistic thing that Taiwan can do at present is to overhaul its financial sector and nurture more professionals to allow the island be ready to "rise again," Thurow said in a speech delivered Friday at the Epoch Foundation Economics Forum in Taipei.

Taiwan's economic rebound hinges on the recovery of the United States, Thurow reiterated, adding that it is hard to speculate exactly how long it will take before the American "U-shaped" economic downturn bottoms out in the wake of the Sept. 11 terror attacks in New York City and Washington.
Taiwan is not alone in this round of recession, Thurow said, adding that Japan and Singapore are also reeling.

He did not attach much expectation to expected increased U.S. military spending once retaliatory action against Afghanistan's Taleban regime is launched, saying that while the war may fuel defense demands, the specific expenditure would not be a factor of the U.S. economic growth.

Although a great number of Taiwan businesses have relocated their operations to mainland China, he said Taiwan still cannot count on the mainland's economic prosperity to help with the island's recovery. With its gross domestic product constituting only 3 percent of the global economy, mainland China is far from being able to play a "world-level" role, he added.

Commenting on Thurow's suggestions, Paul Hsu, executive director of Epoch Foundation, said that from the point of view of international economics specialists, Taiwan should have a clearer perception of its own economic situation and future.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WILL NOT BE AFFECTED BY WASHINGTON-BEIJING ANTI-TERROR COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's interests will not be compromised by mainland China's siding with the United States following the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York and Washington, a ranking government official said Friday.

Speaking at a regular news conference, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin said that according to sources in the United States, Beijing has not so far raised any request to Washington in exchange for its willingness to cooperate in the global anti-terrorist movement.

As the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks were a major disaster for the international community, Lin pointed out that any country would be condemned by international society should it try to use the tragedy to boost its own interests and added that mainland China is concerned about being a outcast in the Washington-Beijing-Moscow ties because Russia has also displayed goodwill to the United States following the tragedy.

According to Lin, U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell has also made it clear that Washington-Beijing cooperation against terrorism will not be made at the cost of Taiwan's interests and neither will it affect security in the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER VOWS TO BLOCK THUG-LAWMAKER'S RE-ELECTION BID

TEXT.P: A veteran legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Friday he will do his utmost to prevent a controversial incumbent lawmaker from winning a seat in the new Legislative Yuan to be elected Dec. 1.

Shen Fu-hsiung, a medical doctor-turned-lawmaker, said that many people think Lo Fu-chu, an independent legislator who is widely believed to be the "spiritual leader" of the Heavenly Way Alliance gang, can easily win a legislative seat in the metropolitan Taipei South constituency.
Nevertheless, Shen said at a news conference, he will join forces with four other DPP candidates for the constituency legislative elections to block Lo's re-election bid.

In the previous legislative elections, Lo consistently ran in the Taipei County constituency. This time, however, he is likely to run in the Taipei City South constituency, as he has relocated his legal abode to the district.

Lo is now serving a six-month suspension from legislative duty following his brutal assault of a female colleague in April. His latest display of thuggish behavior was nothing new, as he has an extensive history of using his fists rather than his intellect to conduct his legislative business.

On Wednesday, Lo harangued and intimidated members of the legislature's finance committee for one hour simply because the DPP legislative caucus had questioned the validity of electing his son Lo Ming-tsai as convener of the committee. The junior Lo, also a legislator, was elected to the committee's convener seat last week for a third consecutive term, breaking an internal rule of the chamber that forbids any lawmaker serving as a convener of any committee for three straight sessions. The senior Lo's invective halted the committee's plan to conduct a new run of convener elections on that day.
Shen said that Lo's invective highlights the need to revise and update the legislature's internal rules to upgrade legislative operational efficiency and improve the chamber's image.
Shen said the DPP will push for revisions to the rules regarding the number of legislators needed to form a caucus and the number of conveners of each legislative standing committee.

He said the current regulation that allow each committee to have three conveners reflects the "old" culture of pork-barrel politics. In his view, Shen said, the number of conveners should be cut to one for each committee.

On the other hand, Shen went on, the number of legislators needed to form a caucus should be largely increased to control the number of legislative caucuses. At present, five legislators can form a caucus to qualify for presenting bills for screening. The relatively lax restrictions on the number of legislative caucuses has hindered legislative operations, he pointed out.
