DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIWAN FAMILY INCOMES BELOW AVERAGE LEVEL

TEXT.P: Some 68 percent of Taiwan's 6.59 million households, or 4.47 million families, earned an annual income of less than the average level of NT$1.09 million (US$31,600) in 2000, according to government statistics released recently.

Affected by an economic downturn since the second half of 2000, per-household average annual income hit NY$1.09 million for the whole of last year, a record low increase of 0.17 percent over the 1999 level, according to the tallies released by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The 68 percent ratio is about the same level posted previously for 1999, DGBAS officials said.

In terms of householders' professions, manufacturing-related occupations, such as machine operators, fishermen and laborers posted noticeable falls in their yearly family earnings amid rising unemployment, while workers in service-related businesses, such as vendors and salesmen registered the highest growth of 2.9 percent in their annual incomes, the same statistics indicate.

Public opinion leaders, ranking government officials and private business executives are in the upper level in terms of their family incomes. Only about 7 percent of Taiwan's entire households belong to this group, enjoying an average annual income of NT$1.9 million per household last year, down 1.2 percent from the 1999 level.

Ranking second are the professional elite, with 5.6 percent of Taiwan's families being classified as led by such householders, who earned an average annual income of NT$1.8 million in 2000, up 0.1 percent from a year ago.

Families of householders who are high-level technicians and assistant specialists account for 13.8 percent of Taiwan's households, with an average yearly income of NT$1.4 million, down 2 percent year-on-year.

Families of householders who are office workers and service providers such as vendors account for 5.3 percent and 14 percent of Taiwan's overall families, earning annual incomes of NT$1.2 million and NT$1.04 million, respectively, per household.

Families supported by technicians make up 13.4 percent, with average annual earnings of NT$1.03 million. Ranking at the bottom are families whose householders work in the agricultural, forestry and fishing sectors, with an annual income of NT$690,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: DECISION TO IMPLEMENT FLEXIBLE WORK HOURS BASED ON POLL: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: An official of the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Friday that a decision of the Economic Development Advisory Conference in August to endorse flexible work hours corresponds to the results of a survey conducted in April.

In response to some labor groups' opposition to the decision, which was accepted by the Cabinet and worked into an amendment bill for the relevant labor laws, CLA Statistics Department Director Lin Lee-jen said that 39.4 percent of the survey respondents voiced support for flexible work hours, compared to 17.7 percent who were opposed.
However, 43 percent of the respondents did not express an opinion.
Lin said that the results of the survey were submitted to the advisory conference for its reference in coming up with the decision.
Of the management respondents surveyed, 49.6 percent said that they support the proposal and only 8.7 percent were opposed, while 41.7 percent had no opinion.
A total of 2,780 effective responses from the management sector and 6,746 from the labor sector were retrieved over the course of the month-long mail-in survey.

The survey results also showed that supporters of proposals to ease restrictions on labor laws governing female employees working at night or working overtime also outnumber those who oppose the plans.
The Cabinet ratified a draft amendment last month for the Labor Standard Law that aims to provide guidelines for businesses and workers that wish to accommodate more flexible working hours.
If ratified by the Legislative Yuan, the new guidelines will allow businesses to make their own scheduling adjustments provided that both labor and management agree to the new schemes.

Businesses whose average weekly working hours do not surpass 40 hours can move those hours around either within an eight-week period or within a one-year period, as long as other labor regulations on maximum daily and weekly working hours are not violated, according to the draft amendment.

The amendment also seeks to simplify the procedure for working overtime such that -- subject to labor and management agreement -- workers can work overtime as long as the total number of scheduled working hours plus overtime hours does not exceed 12 hours each day, and provided the total number of overtime hours each month does not exceed 46 hours.

In the interests of gender equality, female workers under the proposed regulations will be allowed to work at night between 10 p.m. and 6 a.m. -- also subject to labor and management agreement -- if the workplace provides the necessary health and safety facilities, transportation or dormitory facilities for female workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC STRUCTURE SOLID: NATIONAL POLICY ADVISER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 4 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A Republic of China national policy adviser expressed optimism Thursday that Taiwan's economy will recover soon in tune with the world economy, as Taiwan enjoys a solid economic structure.

Byron S.J. Weng, national policy adviser to ROC President Chen Shui-bian, made the remarks in Washington after meeting with American think tank experts to exchange views about cross-Taiwan Strait ties and Taipei-Washington relations.
Accompanying him on his U.S trip are Taiwan Institute of Economic Research President Wu Rong-i and adviser to the National Security Council Lin Chia-long.

Weng, who is also a professor at Taiwan's National Chi-Nan University, said that although Taiwan's economic performance is not very good at present, it will take a turn for the better when the world economy recovers.

Referring to the domestic political chaos, Weng attributed this to the Democratic Progressive Party's lack of experience as a ruling party and the opposition parties' equal lack of experience. He added that whether the political situation will stabilize depends largely on the results of the year-end legislative and county chief elections.

Weng went on to say that during their meeting with various think tank experts in Los Angeles, New York and Washington, they had made known Taipei's worry as to whether the United States will reach any agreement with Beijing that will sacrifice Taiwan's interests in exchange for mainland China's cooperation in its anti-terrorist campaign.

However, the worry was later assuaged when U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell stressed Wednesday during an unrelated meeting with reporters that the United States will not make any deals to the detriment of Taiwan's interests when trying to obtain Beijing's anti-terrorist cooperation.
Weng was scheduled to head for Boston later in the day to meet other American scholars.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CONSUMER PRICES POST YEAR-ON-YEAR DROP OF 0.51% IN SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) registered a year-on-year drop of 0.51 percent in September, the second fall since June, according to statistics released Friday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The island's wholesale price index (WPI) in September fell 1.43 percent from a year earlier, the seventh consecutive and largest drop in two years, DGBAS figures showed.
The fall of the September CPI was due mainly to a higher comparative base in September last year, which saw higher vegetable and fruit prices in the aftermath of Typhoon Bilis, the DGBAS said.
However, the September CPI was 0.42 percent higher from that of August, due mainly to higher vegetable and fruit prices after Typhoon Nari and Lekima, according to DGBAS statistics.
The fall of the September WPI was due mainly to the slower demand and falling prices of raw materials, the DGBAS said.
In the first nine months of this year, the island's CPI has registered a year-on-year growth of 0.2 percent, the DGBAS figures showed.
The island's 2001 CPI is expected to maintain moderate growth, a DGBAS official said, adding that the level is expected to be controlled under 0.41-percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT INSPECTS RECONSTRUCTION WORK IN NANTOU COUNTY
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, central Taiwan, Oct. 5 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian inspected the progress of Taiwan's post-earthquake reconstruction work Friday in Hsinyi Rural Township, Nantou County.

Accompanied by Nantou County Magistrate Peng Pai-hsien, Chen visited Tili Village in the township to see what progress has been made in the reconstruction work of a local river and the building of a temporary bridge, more than two years since the devastating earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999.
He said that reconstruction work of damaged river courses should be carried out not only on the middle reaches of the river, but also at its headwaters.

Later, the president went to Tannan Village to attend a ceremony marking the completion of the reconstruction of the Tannan Elementary School, which was heavily damaged in the temblor and reconstructed by the Hao Jan Foundation.
The school has six classes for its 92 students, all of whom belong to the Bunun tribe, one of Taiwan's 10 indigenous tribes.

In order to ensure that the new school's design retained the traditional styles and traits of the Bunun tribe, the foundation hired Chiang Lo-ching, an architect-researcher on aboriginal architecture, to design the new premises.
The design later won third place in the second Far Eastern Architecture Award competition.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.009 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at 34.559.
The local currency opened Friday at 34.562 and was traded between 34.547 and 34.562.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$139 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AIR FORCE F-5F JET FIGHTER MISSING DURING TRAINING MISSION

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Air Force General Headquarters announced Friday that one of its F-5F jet fighters lost radio contact in the afternoon during a routine training mission and remains missing as of Friday evening.

According to an air force news release, a wingman saw the missing aircraft fly into cloud cover at 3:08 p.m. approximately 60 nautical miles northeast of Taitung County in eastern Taiwan and then lost sight and contact of the twin-seater.
Two coast guard patrol boats were dispatched to assist in the search and rescue mission but have yet to discover any signs of the missing aircraft or its two pilots.
The missing pilots are Maj. Lee Chih-min, 36, and Capt. Kang Hung-chou, 31, according to the air force.
Over 100 F-5E/Fs remain in service in the ROC Air Force.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR VOWS TO CRACK DOWN ON SEX TRADE

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou declared war against the sex trade Friday, vowing to root out all sex businesses in the city.

Delivering a speech at a gathering of police chiefs from all precincts in Taipei, Ma asked them to crack down on all sex businesses in the city before the end of October. The major said he will "get rid of all sex shops in Taipei to cut the links between Taipei police and those illegal businesses.

"People's trust is the largest assets of the government, and police are the leading representatives of the government," Ma said, stressing that "policemen who commit crimes will not be forgiven even by heaven and must be subject to the law.
"Should any sex businesses be found operating in any district, the city government will mete out the appropriate punishment," he said.

Policemen in various Taipei districts have been discovered recently to be deeply involved in activities related to kidnapping of prostitutes to blackmail brothel owners, giving rise to grave public concern about the discipline and morality of the police.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINA BASKETBALL TEAM LEAVES FOR MAINLAND A-CLASS LEAGUE

TEXT.P: Nine members of the Taiwan-financed Sina basketball team left for the mainland Chinese city of Suzhou Friday to play in mainland China's Division A league in December.
Daniel Chiang, president of the British Virgin Islands-based E-Ternational Sports Ventures Co., which owns Sina, accompanied the group to Suzhou via Macau.
Chiang said prior to his departure that although the row over the team's name remains unresolved, Sina will not pull out of Taiwan.

"We'll keep our roots in Taiwan while venturing into the mainland basketball arena," Chiang said, adding that the team will retain its Taiwan flavor and will continue to recruit players from the island.

Chiang further said the Sina foundation will continue to sponsor youth basketball summer camps and the annual Sina Cup basketball tournament in Taiwan to help cultivate a new generation of basketball talent.

Chou Chun-san, captain of the team, said he and his teammates hope to carve out a niche in the highly competitive mainland basketball scene with the blessing of fans on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The nine players from Taiwan will be joined by two players hired from the United States and two from mainland China. The top-ranking basketball league is scheduled to begin its new season Dec. 8, with a match in Suzhou between Sina and Beijing's Capital Steel team.
It remains uncertain what Sina's official designation will be while competing in the mainland's Division A league. Chiang said he felt some regret that he couldn't decide on the team's name himself.
In consideration of the sensitive political situation across the Taiwan Strait, Chiang said he would no longer insist on the team's official title.

During a courtesy call on Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen Thursday, Chiang presented a list of five alternative names for the nation's top mainland policy planner to consider. Tsai reportedly had assured Chiang that the MAC would be flexible on the name issue.

Sina ran into trouble with local authorities in charge of sports and mainland Chinese affairs under pressure from Beijing to add either "Taiwan" or "Taipei" to its team name to be allowed to play in mainland China.

The proposed addition to the team's designation drew a sharp response from government officials in Taipei as they considered it to be yet another scheme concocted by Beijing to make Taiwan look like just another province of the People's Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPERATION FOUND MINTING BOGUS COINS

TEXT.P: On the same day that a special government task force was assembled to fight recent high-profile currency counterfeiting cases, an operation was discovered in southern Taiwan that was minting phony coins, police said Friday.
Police had been monitoring the clandestine mint in Taichung City since June, but had been unable to make any arrests as the factory was moved frequently.

Their luck changed when police caught one of the suspected operators of the bogus mint on Friday and seized around 260 fake NT$50 coins and materials -- including dies to manufacture every denomination of coin used in Taiwan.

A 59-year-old man, Lin Wu-nan, was arrested at the site. He said that the minting operation had already made and sold bogus coins amounting to a face value of NT$10 million. He also said that dies were used to mint the newly designed coins of the Central Bank of China (CBC) which are not yet in circulation.
According to preliminary investigations, the mastermind behind the operation is a retired banker who is still at large.
Police quoted Lin as saying that most of the counterfeited coins produced were sold to video game arcades in southern Taiwan.

Also on Friday, a government task force on currency counterfeiting was created and staffed by officials from the Central Bank of China (CBC), the ministries of finance and justice, the Investigation Bureau and the National Police Administration. The team will be headed by Wu Kuo-ai, the chief prosecutor of the Taiwan High Court.

Representatives of the task force said at a news conference that they had come up with three initial points in the fight against counterfeiting: First, any information about currency forgery must be relayed immediately to the task force as well as the CBC. Second, the CBC should establish a data bank on bogus bills, including how they were counterfeited and how they were put into circulation. Third, prosecutors should investigate classified advertisements that offer get rich quick schemes that have vague references to counterfeit currency.
The task force also recommended that forgers be subject to stricter penalties and advised that the government do more to educate the public in the ways to distinguish real currency from fakes.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO MINISTERS TO HEAD TAIWAN MISSION TO APEC MINISTERIAL MEETING

TEXT.P: The Taiwan delegation to the 13th ministerial meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Shanghai in mid-October will be headed by Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Chen Po-chih and Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi, a government official said Friday.

The official from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) noted that Taiwan will also attend the informal leadership meeting scheduled for Oct. 20-21, but added that the choice of the representative will be announced by the Presidential Office.

A news release by MOFA said that countries in the Asia-Pacific area have been striving to lift up their economies, but the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States have brought a new dimension to their efforts.
Although the meeting is expected to face more challenges than before, MOFA asserted that it will also provide a good opportunity for member countries to find solutions to the problems ahead.

The MOFA official said that the Taiwan delegation will discuss with the participants from other member countries how to stimulate the economies in the Asia-Pacific region in a way which will also build the basis for Taiwan's sustainable development.
Regarding the leadership conference to be attended by U.S. President George W. Bush and the leaders of other member countries, the official said that Taiwan will attend the conference.
ROC President Chen Shui-bian has reiterated his willingness to attend the Shanghai meeting, but Beijing has turned down Chen's proposal.
Last year, the Taipei-based Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan represented Chen at the APEC leadership meeting in Brunei.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE TO HOST WTO INFORMAL MINISTERIAL MEETING OCT. 13-14

TEXT.P: Singapore will host a World Trade Organization (WTO) informal ministerial meeting Oct. 13-14, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry of Singapore.
The meeting is a follow-up to an earlier informal ministerial meeting held in Mexico City last month. Discussions will relate to the fourth Ministerial Meeting in Doha this November.
Part of the agenda of the November meeting is the official approval for Taiwan and mainland China to enter the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Trade ministers of the 21 member nations to participate in this meeting will be from Australia, Brazil, Canada, Colombia, Egypt, the European Union, The Gabon, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Jamaica, Japan, the Republic of Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, Pakistan, Qatar, South Africa, Switzerland, Tanzania and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANY TAIWAN PEOPLE LACK HEALTH KNOWLEDGE: POLL

TEXT.P: A government survey released Thursday shows that the public is often misinformed about fundamental health issues.
The survey, commissioned by the Cabinet-level Department of Health, was conducted in May by telephone and received valid responses from 1,089 adults over age 20 throughout Taiwan.
The results of the survey shows that men got an average score of 50.86 out of the maximum 100, while women scored 52.2.
For example, when asked whether getting an injection or taking medicine would guarantee recovery from influenza, only about half understood that these treatments are not effective in all cases.

The study also found that 41 percent have the misguided concept that "taking Chinese traditional medicine will upset one's stomach less than Western medicines," while 45 percent know that taking antibiotics in advance cannot prevent sexual diseases.
Only 40 percent knew that hepatitis B is transmitted through blood; while 36 percent thought hepatitis B was spread through contact with food.
As to the understanding about smoking cigarettes, almost 60 percent have the wrong idea that nicotine is what causes cancer, while only 8 percent know that it is actually caused by tar.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MISSION HOPES TO EXPAND TRADE IN THREE EUROPEAN COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: Representatives of 40 Taiwan manufacturers will leave Taiwan Saturday on a trade expansion tour which will take them to Ukraine, Russia and Poland, mission organizers said Friday.
The trade mission is organized by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

Russia and Ukraine are Taiwan's largest- and second-largest trading partners, respectively, among the Commonwealth of Independent States, while Poland is Taiwan's biggest export recipient in Eastern Europe.
The MOEA and the China External Trade Development Council will mobilize all their staff stationed in the three countries to help arrange trade talks with businessmen there.
Mission members will visit Kiev in Ukraine, Moscow and St. Petersburg in Russia, and Warsaw in Poland. They are scheduled to return to Taiwan Oct. 21.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWELVE FOREIGN DELEGATIONS TO ARRIVE FOR ROC NATIONAL DAY

TEXT.P: Four delegations from diplomatic allies of the Republic of China are scheduled to attend the ROC National Day celebrations on Oct. 10, according to the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
They will be joined by eight missions totaling approximately 60 visitors from countries that maintain no formal diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

The delegations from ROC diplomatic allies will be led respectively by the parliament speaker of Tuvalu, the parliament speaker of Malawi, the house assembly speaker of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, and a high-ranking Honduran government official.
Missions from other countries include those from Russia, Belarus, South Korea, Switzerland and the United States.
The parliament delegation from Switzerland and the entourage from Honduras are scheduled to arrive Sunday, with the rest slated to arrive next week.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST OPEN LINKS FOR FOREIGN FIRMS TO MAINLAND CHINA: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan must open the "three links" with mainland China if it hopes to act as a jumping-off point for foreign businessmen in Taiwan who want to develop the Shanghai market, a government official said Friday.

Chen Chao-yi, director of the Industrial Development and Investment Center under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Taiwan can replace Hong Kong in cross-Taiwan Strait trade activities for foreign businesses. "But the key to that requires Taiwan's establishment of direct trade, transportation and postal links with the mainland," he noted.

According to Chen, Taiwan enjoys the upper hand over Hong Kong in its cultural and language links with mainland China. Foreign investors used to enter mainland China's southern markets, such as Guangzhou and Shantou, through Hong Kong, and now they can use Taiwan to expand into the flourishing Shanghai market, which lies closer to Taiwan than Hong Kong, he added.

As global capital has being flowing quickly into the mainland Chinese market ahead of its imminent entry into the World Trade Organization, Taiwan should position itself so that it is not on the sidelines of global competition, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BROAD VISION NEEDED FOR TAIWAN-MAINLAND TIES: KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Friday that the ROC government must handle its mainland China ties in line with global economic realities.

"Because of poor coordination between Taiwan's ruling party and a mishandling of the situation across the Taiwan Strait, the government here has failed to craft sound policies regarding the mainland in light of the economic situations on both sides," he said.

If the ruling party -- the Democratic Progressive Party -- cannot secure Taiwan's own interests in dealing with the mainland, Lien said, it has no right to remain in power. He also said that Taiwan and mainland China should create mutually beneficial relations through increased trade and economic exchanges.
Lien made the remarks while giving a speech to a KMT-sponsored gathering for Taiwan businessmen based in mainland China.

As mainland China has become the most important market for many Taiwan businesses, the government must have a clear idea of the country's future development, he said. "Taiwan cannot afford to lose the mainland Chinese market just because of the ruling party's ideology and fixed mindset," he stressed

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL LAUREATE OPENS PAINTING EXHIBITION IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Gao Xingjian, who won the Nobel Prize in literature in 2000 -- the first Chinese writer to win the prestigious award, showed his other talent by opening an exhibition of his paintings Thursday in Taipei.

The opening of his painting exhibition attracted many local artists and government officials including Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Minister of Education Ovid Tzeng and Council for Cultural Affairs Chairwoman Chen Yu-hsiu.
Chang said at the ceremony that Gao's paintings are like his novels, which give the audience much space to think and to taste.
The exhibition of Gao's 40 paintings will last until Nov. 11.
Invited by the Council for Cultural Affairs to Taipei, Gao, who lives in Paris, will also cast actors for an upcoming drama performance in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT RECEIVES U.S. ECONOMIST THUROW

TEXT.P: Republic of China Presdient Chen Shui-bian received visiting U.S. economist Lester Thurow Friday and exchanged views with him on the economic problems faced by Taiwan and the rest of the world.

Chen explained to Thurow the government's decision to replace the "no haste, be patient" policy with an "active opening, efficient management" stance to handle trade and investment relations with mainland China.
The president described the new policy as a "new milestone" in the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

He also stated that in order to implement the more than 300 recommendations reached through consensus at the recently-held Economic Development Advisory Conference, necessary measures are being worked out in the Legislative Yuan and relevant government institutions.
Chen said that the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States have affected not only the United States, but also Taiwan and other countries.

He added that the world's attention is also being drawn to the upcoming informal leadership conference of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum to be held later this month in Shanghai and the ministerial meeting of the World Trade Organization to be held in Qatar next month.
During the reception, Chen asked Thurow what Taiwan should do to cope with the current economic sluggishness.
The economics professor from MIT said that Taiwan's economy will be able to make an upturn only after the global economy begins to rebound.
For now, he suggested that Taiwan place more emphasis on investment in public projects and follow the formula of Sweden to strengthen skills training for unemployed workers.
Through reeducation, Thurow said that fresh labor power can be injected into the labor market once the economy begins bottoming out.
Regarding the booming mainland Chinese market, he said that he would not consider mainland China a big market at present because its economic scale accounts for only 2 percent of the world economy.
The professor noted that the consumption market in mainland China is small, although it is a good place for manufacturing.

He went on to say that it may take 100 years for mainland China to expand its economy to the present scale of the United States, and added that official statistics released by Beijing are questionable.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE LAWMAKERS TO ATTEND NATIONAL DAY CELEBRATIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo , Oct. 5 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Several Japanese parliamentarians will leave for Taipei in the coming days to attend the ROC's National Day celebrations.
Lower House member Sadanori Yamanaka, a former Defense Agency director-general who is chairman of the Japan-Republic of China Parliamentarians' Council, will depart for Taipei Saturday.

Three other Lower House members belonging to the Liberal Democratic Party -- Hisaoki Kamei, Ichiro Takahashi and Akira Sato -- will leave for Taipei Oct. 9, together with Japan Interchange Association President Toshio Goto.
Meanwhile, a 123-member delegation consisting of overseas Chinese residents from Tokyo, Osaka, Kyoto, Sendai and Kobe will also go to Taipei for the Double Ten celebrations.
In Tokyo, the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office will hold a National Day reception on the night of Oct. 9 at a Tokyo hotel.
Some 1,500 dignitaries have been invited to the reception, including over 120 Japanese parliamentarians from all major parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO FUGITIVES SUSPECTED AS ABDUCTORS OF VICE COUNCIL SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Two fugitives wanted in at least a dozen robberies were positively identified Friday as being behind the kidnapping of Taichung City Council Vice Speaker Chang Hung-nien on Monday.

Chang, who was released unhurt Thursday, has identified the two from police mug shots as Hsueh Chiu and Chen Yi-hua. The two men have terrorized Hsinchu, Miaoli and Taichung and are suspected to be involved in 12 robberies and one kidnapping since January.
Chang told police that while he was being held, the two men had showed their identification cards to him to prove that they were the notorious fugitives.

His statement confirmed the testimony given by two of Chang's aides who were present when Chang was forced to leave his Taichung office with the two men Oct. 1. The two aides also recognized the men from police mug shots and from their voices on police interrogation tape recordings.

Police said the two men had been arrested on March 21 in Miaoli City after a brief shootout and a subsequent two-hour standoff with police who had responded to calls for help from a pub where the two fugitives were brawling with workers.
However, a judge of the Miaoli District Court released the two on bail on March 22 in spite of prosecutors' demands for the men to be detained. The two then jumped bail.

The two men are suspects in at least five armed robberies since March, including the holdup of a bank run by the farmers' association in Yunlin County. The two made off with NT$20 million (US$588,235).

The high-profile abduction of Chang is their latest claim to infamy because of Chang's political status and the astronomical sum they demanded for his release -- NT$300 million (US$8.82 million). In fact, Chang reportedly actually paid between NT$30 million to NT$50 million (US$882,352 to US$1.47 million).

But Chang, who has shunned publicity after being released Thursday, downplayed the incident and said that the kidnapping was most likely a case of mistaken identity as the two men, according to Chang, were after someone else. He avoided answering any question about if he had paid any ransom to secure his release.
His father told reporters Friday that the two men released his son after finding that they had taken the wrong person and that his son had been treated well during the three days in captivity.
However, media reports stuck to their stories that ransom had been handed over before Chang was released.
A local television station, TVBS, said three of Chang's friends, two businessmen and one politician, who negotiated with the two men after the kidnapping, handed over the ransom.
TVBS said Chang's friends had kept the police in the dark about the incident out of fear for Chang's safety. The friends only notified police after Chang had been released Thursday.
Also on Thursday, a judge of the Miaoli District Court rescinded the earlier court's granting of bail.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR EXTOLS CREWS TO GIVE THEIR ALL IN TRAFFIC SIGNAL REPAIRS

TEXT.P: Realizing that numerous traffic lights went dark in the aftermath of Typhoon Nari, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou asked city maintenance crews Friday to dedicate their lives to repairing broken traffic signals in any future emergency.

In a meeting with the city's traffic officials, Ma expressed his dismay at the fact that the city's traffic signals, which were seriously damaged by Typhoon Nari on Sept. 16, were not fully back in working order until Sept. 22.

During those six days, Ma said, city residents had to suffer the inconvenience and danger of non-functioning traffic lights. He said that the disruption of the city's rapid transportation system only add to the chaos as more that half a million commuters were forced to find alternative ways to go to and from their offices.

Since the city has farmed out the maintenance of its traffic equipment to private contractors, the sudden breakdown of 700-odd traffic signals during the storm caught them off-guard and they couldn't find enough staff to attend to the signals which were either damaged by flooding or rendered useless because of power outages following the storm.
Ma asked his staff to impose heavy fines on the contractors if they failed to fix the signals after future natural disasters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WINS 14 GOLDS IN 9TH ASIAN SKATING CHAMPIONSHIPS
DOC.DATELINE: Taitung County, eastern Taiwan, Oct. 5 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan was the big winner at the Ninth Asian Skating Championships which concluded Friday.

Taiwan pocketed 31 medals -- 14 golds, 11 silvers, and six bronzes. Mainland China was the runner-up in the medal count at the five-day competition with five gold medals, but in group scores, China was behind India.
Taiwan also ranked first in group scoring.
Taiwan's Su Ping-jen won the 500-, 1,000- and 10,000-meter speed skating events and the 10,000-meter skating relay, garnering the most number of gold medals.
Japan was the champion in the ice hockey event and mainland China took second place.
All the five golds mainland China won were in the figure skating event.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 6, or the 20th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1552: Mateo Ricci, Italian Jesuit missionary in China, is born. He spent the last 30 years of his life in China.
1807: English chemist Sir Humphrey Davy discovers a new metallic element and calls it potassium.
1860: A Franco-British force captures Beijing. China's Ching court is thus compelled to make further concessions in the 1860 Treaty of Beijing.
1913: Yuan Shih-kai forces the Congress to elect him president of the Republic of China.
1925: Chiang Kai-shek becomes commander in chief of the Canton military government and begins to launch the second eastern expedition.
1927: The International Stock Exchange Center of the New York Stock Exchange is formally opened.
1937: The League of Nations condemns Japanese aggression against China.
1937: The U.S. State Department condemns Japan's invasion of China.
1939: Chinese troops win the first battle of Changsha in Hunan Province against invading Japanese forces.
1946: The Chinese communists turn down Gen. George C. Marshall's cease-fire proposal.
1958: Seawolf, a U.S. nuclear submarine, surfaces off New England's coast after setting a world record by remaining submerged for two months.
1963: President Hubert Maga of Benin and his wife arrive in Taipei for a six-day state visit.
1964: The ROC and Uruguay sign a treaty of amity in Taipei.
1973: As Israelis begin to observe Yom Kippur, one of the holiest days in the Jewish calendar, a joint Egyptian-Syrian invasion force begins an attack on Israel on two fronts, triggering the fourth Arab-Israeli war.
1975: The 11th General Assembly of the Asian Parliamentarians Union opens in Taipei with more than 80 delegates and observers from nine countries taking part.
1976: Shiroshichi Kimura, chairman of the Japanese Interchange Association, arrives in Taipei for a 16-day visit.
1980: The first World Congress of Chinese Medicine and Pharmacology sponsored by the National Union of the Chinese Medical Doctors' Association opens in Taipei.
1981: Egyptian President Anwar Sadat is assassinated by Islamic extremists while reviewing a military parade in Cairo. He was succeeded by Vice President Hosni Mubarak on Oct. 13.
1986: The ROC's Ministry of Economic Affairs decides to invest NT$1.2 billion in developing anti-pollution technology over the next three years.
1987: The National Chiang Kai-shek Cultural Center, comprising the National Theater and National Concert Hall, is inaugurated after six years of construction costing NT$7.5 billion.
1991: An Indonesian military plane crashes into a government building in Jakarta, killing 102 people and injuring more than 5,000 others.
1993: Russian President Boris Yeltsin demands the resignation of his opponents in the provinces after putting down rebellious legislators.
1999: Chen Chin-hsing, Taiwan's most notorious criminal who raped and killed the 17-year-old daughter of television celebrity Pai Ping-ping in April 1997, is executed after being sentenced to death for his crimes.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian explains that the "stone" in his earlier comment that "the stone has been removed from the path" of his four-month-old government actually referred to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party itself and not to any specific person.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of apprehension, intelligence, insight, and understanding: qualities necessary for the exercise of command."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY (Oct. 7 2001)
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 7, or the 21st day of the eighth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1571: A "holy league" of naval forces from Spain, Venice, and the Vatican explodes the myth of Turkish military invincibility by annihilating their fleet at the Battle of Lepanto in the eastern Mediterranean.
1900: Heinrich Himmler, head of the Gestapo, and from 1929, Adolf Hitler's second-in-command, is born.
1913: Henry Ford, the leading manufacturer of U.S. automobiles in the early 1900's, creates the world's first assembly line to build Model T cars.
1919: KLM, the national airline of the Netherlands and the world's first airline, is established, and flights are scheduled to begin in 1920.
1937: The Council of the League of Nations adopts a resolution pledging moral support for China in the wake of Japanese aggression.
1949: East Germany, or the German Democratic Republic, is proclaimed, with Wilhelm Pieck as president and Otto Grotewohl as prime minister.
1950: Communist Chinese troops enter Tibet.
1953: Microfilm, a kind of photographic film on which reduced images of printed and other materials are recorded, is first shown at an office machinery trade exhibition held in Paris.
1958: The Communist Chinese begin to launch a mass movement in Tientsin to make iron and steel, in which about 100 million people would eventually participate. The movement, which proved to be a waste of both human and material resources, resulted in the loss of 100 billion yuan in industrial production.
1959: Pictures of the far side of the moon are relayed back to Earth for the first time by Lunik III, the Soviet spacecraft.
1959: Mario Lanza, U.S. tenor and film actor, dies at the age of 38. His films included "The Great Caruso."
1961: Two defecting Communist Chinese pilots, Shao Hsi-yen and Kao Yu-tsung, arrive in Taipei from Seoul.
1965: The International Olympic Committee decides that starting from the 1968 Olympic Games to be held in Mexico City, East and West Germany may send separate teams to participate in the international competition.
1974: A 90-member Japanese calligraphic mission led by Akira Koyama arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1976: Wu Cho-liu, a noted writer in Taiwan, dies at the age of 77.
1976: U.S. President Gerald Ford, already under fire for pardoning the disgraced Richard Nixon, tells the public on prime-time television that "there is no Soviet domination of eastern Europe and there never will be under a Ford administration."
1977: The Soviet Union adopts a new constitution, replacing the one introduced in 1936.
1981: Dr. Hassan Hamza Hajra, mayor of Taif, Saudi Arabia, arrives in Hualien and meets with Wu Shui-yun, magistrate of Hualien County, to discuss city sisterhood ties.
1982: Jimmy Wei, the national policy advisor to President Chiang Ching-kuo and former president of the Central News Agency, dies of a heart attack at the age of 77.
1985: The Achille Lauro, an Italian cruise liner, is seized by Palestinian terrorists, endangering the lives of more than 400 passengers on board. The passengers were freed on Oct. 9 when the hijackers surrendered.
1986: President Chiang Ching-kuo tells Katherine Graham, head of the board of the Washington Post and Newsweek, in an interview that the ROC government will soon propose lifting martial law to actively promote democracy, but added that new political parties should abide by the ROC constitution and anti-Communist policy. He also emphasizes that the ROC will never negotiate with the Communist Chinese.
1990: The National Unification Council is established under the Office of the President to help plan the policy framework for national unification and to integrate various opinions on the issue at all levels of society.
1998: Thousands of Russians take to the streets to protest against unpaid wages and to call on President Boris Yeltsin to resign.
1999: Sweden donates NT$50 million (US$11.57 million) worth of relief goods to help earthquake-affected people in the Republic of China on Taiwan.
2000: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan confirms that the Ministry of Justice's Investigation Bureau will formally phase out its controversial "political surveillance" work soon.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of magnanimity, generosity, benignity, and gentleness: qualities necessary for the exercise of patience."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The China Times:
The Council of Grand Justices rules that the current Judicial Yuan organization is 'unconstitutional.'
The United Daily News:
New Schoolmate Book Store chain goes bankrupt and will be taken over by its high-tech affiliate.
The Liberty Times:
The Supreme Court, the Administrative Court and the Commission on the Disciplinary Sanctions of Public Functionaries should by phased out in two years.
The Taiwan Daily:
The Council of Grand Justices rules that the Judicial Yuan should be the highest judging organ.
The Central Daily News:
KMT Chairman Lien Chan says Taiwan should revise cross-strait trade policy with broad vision.
The China Post:
Premier Chang admits results of economic measures 'less than ideal.'
The Taiwan News:
U.S. troops set to land near Afghanistan border.
The Taipei Times:
Lawmaker squares off against DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP AIDE QUITS PEOPLE FIRST PARTY

TEXT.P: One of the closest aides of opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong announced Friday in the United States that he had quit the party that day for reasons that he said he would explain "at an appropriate time."

Shao Tsung-hai, a political science professor at National Chengchi University and a special aide to Soong, said in a faxed letter to Taipei that he decided to quit the PFP after long and careful consideration.

Shao said in the letter that his quitting the PFP has nothing to do with the party's imminent nomination of candidates for legislators-at-large, adding that he does not want people to get the impression that he quit because he has not been nominated by the party.

Currently on a three-month academic exchange program at Harvard University's Fairbank Center for East Asian Research, Shao said he will give his reasons for quitting the PFP soon after he completes his current dissertation titled "Future Political Negotiations Across the Taiwan Strait and the Role of the United States."
The following day, PFP Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung announced the list of candidates that the party has nominated for potential legislators-at-large.

Soong was not listed, while Liu Yi-ru, a former finance and monetary professor at National Taiwan University and daughter of former Finance Minister Shirley Kuo, was placed at the top of the list of 26 candidates.
The list's arrangement of order will affect the candidates' chances of becoming a PFP-appointed legislator after the election for legislators slated for Dec. 1.
Another prominent nominee is former Vice Defense Minister Ku Chung-lien, who was recently expelled from the opposition Kuomintang for switching his allegiance to the PFP.

Altogether, 41 legislators-at-large are expected to be produced after the Dec. 1 election for the new legislature, which will have 225 seats, including four seats for aboriginal people and eight for overseas Chinese representatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT AIMING TO DEVELOP HIGH-TECH AGRICULTURE

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) is working on the development of high technology agriculture to cope with the island's imminent admission into the World Trade Organization (WTO), COA sources said Saturday.
COA officials said a task force has been formed to work out measures to push for the implementation of the policy.

The council plans to form a center for livestock research and plant genetics and a special zone for high technology agriculture experimentation, with the ultimate goal of establishing a center for producing high technology agricultural products.
The COA also plans to provide domestic enterprises with technology and loans in a bid to encourage them to invest in high technology-based agriculture.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE CONTINUES SEARCH FOR MISSING F-5F FIGHTER

TEXT.P: Patrol boats and helicopters continued searching off Taiwan's eastern coast Saturday for an F-5F jet fighter which lost radio contact shortly after taking off from a Republic of China Air Force base Friday.

A spokesman for the Chih-Hang air base in the eastern county of Taitung said two 600-ton coast guard patrol boats had been dispatched to replace smaller ships in a search and rescue mission because bad weather was hampering the smaller vessels.

The twin-seater fighter jet took off from the air base Friday afternoon and lost contact with the control tower at 3:08 p.m. An AFGH press statement said the aircraft went missing 60 nautical miles northeast of Taitung.
"No trace of the jet or its two pilots has been discovered so far," said Chang Ching-yuan, director of the political warfare division at the Chih-Hang air base, some 300 km southeast of Taipei.
Chang said an air force special investigative team had been posted at the Chih-Hang air base to probe the cause of the accident.
"Initial investigations show that the fighter might have mistakenly entered an area of cloud cover while practicing a turn," Chang said.
According to Chang, an accompanying F-5E jet fighter immediately alerted the ill-fated plane upon noticing that it was veering into the cloud cover.

"The pilot aboard the F-5E heard a vague answer from the F-5F which then disappeared from the air base's radar screen and lost radio contact," Chang explained, adding that the altitude for Friday's training flight was set at a range between 22,000 feet and 14,000 feet and that the cloud cover hovered around the 14,000-foot level during the training time.

Chang said it remains unclear why the missing plane had made a wider-than-normal turn. "Mechanical failure, human error and environmental problems are all likely causes," he noted, adding that if the final response from the missing fighter can be decoded, the reasons behind the deviation and disappearance of the plane can probably be determined.
Senior flight instructors said cloud cover is widely seen as "off-limits" for fighter jets because pilots are prone to lose their sense of direction in such circumstances.

Military aircraft usually shun cloud cover except for certain difficult training missions. Friday's training courses were mainly for practicing equipment operations, including testing an airborne-ground communication facility. Flight instructors said they could not understand why the jet had strayed into the cloud.

Air Force Commander-in-Chief Gen. Chen Chao-min and several other senior officials at the Air Force General Headquarters (AFGH) flew to the Chih-Hang air base Saturday to console and boost the morale of all officers and men stationed there, as well as to probe the cause of the accident.
The missing pilots were identified as Maj. Lee Chih-min, 36, and Capt. Kang Hung-chou, 31.
Over 100 F-5E/Fs remain in service in the ROC Air Force.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SUPPORTS U.S. ANTI-TERRORISM BUT LACKS CHANNELS: DPP OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 5 (CNA) (By Eric C.Y. Tseng and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: A visiting official of Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Friday that although Taiwan is determined to support U.S. anti-terrorism work, it lacks the channels through which it can participate in the emerging global coalition of anti-terrorist nations.

DPP International Affairs Department Director Tien Hsin said that a "very special relationship" exists between Taiwan and the United States, which he said is one of the reasons that Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung voiced full support for Washington after the terrorist attacks on America, despite a lack of formal diplomatic ties between the two nations.

Tien said that although it is difficult to predict the possible repercussions that the terrorist attacks might have on Taipei-Beijing relations, a consensus exists that Washington wants that relationship to become even more stable to prevent the introduction of other variables while the U.S. administration busies itself with the establishment of an anti-terrorist coalition.

Analysts in Taiwan have warned that the U.S. administration might sacrifice Taiwan's interests to gain Beijing's support for its anti-terrorist alliance, but U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell has recently spoken out to quell such qualms.

Tien said that since his arrival Wednesday in New York, he has called on a number of prominent New York-based think tanks including the National Committee on U.S.-China Relations, the National Committee on American Foreign Policy and the Council on Foreign Relations to exchange opinions on these issues.

However, he continued, the future development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations really depends on the results of the year-end legislative elections in Taiwan, because Beijing is waiting to see whether the DPP administration can acquire a stable grip on power.
Tien said that he believes a possible opportunity for the resumption of long-stalled cross-strait dialogue might present itself after the elections.

However, he added that some of the think tank experts to whom he spoke expressed doubts that Taiwan will want to resume dialogue with a high-profile mainland China at a time when the island is facing an economic downturn, when public opinion in favor of unification with mainland China is gradually gaining support, and when mainland China's international image has been vastly improved by its successful bid to host the 2008 Olympic Games.

Tien is scheduled to leave for Washington Saturday to meet with government officials and think tank experts there. He is slated to visit Stanford University and the University of California at Berkeley Oct. 14 and to return to Taiwan Oct. 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: WIRE WALKER AIMS TO SET NEW WORLD RECORD

TEXT.P: Highwire walker Jay Cochrane is set to challenge his own world record for length of time living on the wire in Taiwan's southern port city, Kaohsiung entertainment sources said Saturday.

Cochrane, who set a world record in 1981 by staying on a highwire for 21 days in Puerto Rico, was scheduled later that day to climb onto a 150-meter wire stretched between two 20-story steel towers in downtown Kaohsiung.

At a pre-performance press conference, Cochrane, who successfully completed a daring wire walk above Kaohsiung's landmark Love River June 30 this year, said he is determined to stay on the wire for 22 days in this bid, which will be his last before retirement.
Deputy Kaohsiung Mayor Lin Yung-chien, who was present at the press conference, offered his blessing to Cochrane and wished him a great success in his daring attempt.

Cochrane, holder of five wire walking records, is expected to live on the wire, with the tiny spaces on the steel towers at the two ends of the wire offering constricted rest areas for him on a small stool and a makeshift toilet.

Without any shelter on the wire or on the tops of the steel towers, Cochrane said he expects to remain awake throughout the 22 days, adding that the first six to seven days will be the most challenging for him and that he will feel more comfortable after that period.
Cochrane will take extra clothes to keep himself warm in the much lower temperatures expected on the wire, as well as some medicine, including antibiotics, in case he falls ill.
People who are interested in watching Cochrane's show will be able to buy admission tickets priced at NT$200 and NT$100, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE ARRIVING FOR NATIONAL DAY CELEBRATION

TEXT.P: The government's decision to simplify the nation's 90th founding anniversary celebration has not resulted in a decrease in the number of overseas Chinese arriving to attend the festivities, Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) officials said Saturday.

As of Saturday, over 1,600 overseas Chinese had arrived in Taiwan to attend the celebration for the Oct. 10 Republic of China National Day, the officials said, predicting that the number will continue to increase in the next few days.

In line with the government's reconstruction work after the severe effects of typhoons Toraji and Nari, the OCAC has decided to transfer the money earmarked for the National Day celebration to a relief fund for victims of the two typhoons.
The OCAC has also canceled a large variety show to entertain the overseas Chinese visitors and a tour of southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CONSUMERS URGED TO USE `PLASTIC CURRENCY' MORE OFTEN

TEXT.P: Taiwan consumers were urged Saturday to use "plastic currency" more often amid outrage against increasingly rampant currency counterfeiting.
Chen Chi-chu, acting president of the International Commercial Bank of China, said that only in a cashless society can currency forgery be completely extinguished.

He suggested that the government help convert the entire payment market in Taiwan to a system using IC cards rather than paper and metal currency, enabling banks to issue electronic IC cards for consumers, who will in turn make their spending completely electronic.

Meanwhile, Wu Shao-chi, director of the Issue Department of the Central Bank of China (CBC), disagreed that currency forgery is so rampant that it is threatening to disrupt domestic financial stability.

Wu declined to confirm rumors that as many as 60 fake bills per day, with a total accumulated face value of NT$8 million (US$231,884), have been received by dealers at the Huan Nan Fruit and Vegetable Market in Taipei, but he admitted that it is hard to calculate the losses.
He added that the CBC will not consider changing its current minting process before better anti-counterfeiting measures are developed.

On Thursday, the same day that a special government task force was assembled to fight recent high-profile currency counterfeiting cases, an operation was discovered in southern Taiwan that was minting phony coins, police said Friday.

Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan announced recently that those convicted of forging Taiwan currency would face stiffer penalties in the future. The maximum penalty for currency forgery is death, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEOPLE FIRST PARTY ANNOUNCES LIST OF LEGISLATOR-AT-LARGE NOMINEES

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Vice Chairman Chang Chau-hsiung said Saturday that PFP Chairman James Soong is not on the list of candidates that the party has nominated for potential legislators-at-large because Soong should be leading the team from a "high vantage point."

Chang said at a news conference to announce the list of nominees that although both pros and cons exist in the debate for Soong's inclusion on the list, the party decided in the end that the popular former Taiwan provincial governor's talents lie in administration and would probably be less-suited to the Legislative Yuan.
Chang said that the first three nominees on the list of 26 candidates have strong financial backgrounds because of the party's determination to establish a "shadow Cabinet" on financial policies.
The three scholars will also be able to fill in any gaps in financial expertise left by other legislators elected from regional constituencies, he added.
The list's arrangement of order indicates the party's order of preference and will therefore affect the candidates' chances of becoming PFP-appointed legislators after the Dec. 1 elections.

In the order of their nomination, the top PFP legislator-at-large candidates are National Taiwan University finance professor Christina Y. Liu, daughter of former Finance Minister Shirley Kuo; National Chengchi University (NCCU) finance professor Norman Yin; and NCCU finance department director Lee Tung-hau.

Together with fifth-ranking Chinese Federation of Labor President Lin Hui-kuan and 10th-ranking Namchow Chemical Chairman Alfred F.L. Chen, half of the top-10 ranking PFP nominees had represented the PFP in the high-profile presidential Economic Development Advisory Conference held in August.
Lin had previously turned down a recommendation from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to be included on its legislators-at-large nomination list.
Another prominent nominee, ranked sixth on the list, is former Vice Defense Minister Ku Chung-lien, who was recently expelled from the KMT for switching his allegiance to the PFP.

Rounding out the top-10 list are former Legislative Yuan President Liu Sung-pan at No. 4, PFP Secretary-General David J.C. Chung at No. 7, aboriginal legislator Tsau Chung-han and noted neurologist Kao Ming-chien.
Altogether, a total of 41 legislators-at-large are expected to be produced after the Dec. 1 election for the new legislature, which will have 225 seats.

In addition to the 41 legislators-at-large, eight other seats are reserved for overseas Chinese representatives who will be elected according to the same formula for proportional representation among political parties.
The PFP also announced a list of six nominees for overseas Chinese legislators at the news conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DIVORCE RATE HITS NEW HIGH: LEGISLATORS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's divorce rate hit a new single-month high in August this year, with one out of every 2.9 couples ending their relationship with divorce, a lawmaker said Saturday.

In line with record-high unemployment, Taiwan's divorce rate also shot up to a new high in recent months, according to Legislator Hsieh Chang-chieh, a People First Party (PFP) representative from Changhua County, who disclosed his figures at a news conference.

In August alone, Hsieh said, 5,571 couples ended their marriages with divorce, a single-month high in Taiwan's history. One in every 2.9 married couples in Taiwan ended their relationship with divorce between January and September this year, he added.
The new record, compared with one in every 3.5 couples in 2000, illustrates the fact that marriage problems have been aggravated by the influence of the floundering economy, Hsieh noted.
PFP Legislator Ke Shu-min, who joined Hsieh at the press conference, urged the government to do more to help tackle the social problems that come as a result of a high divorce rate.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER'S RULING TEAM `PATHETIC': NEW PARTY

TEXT.P: The opposition New Party (NP) legislative caucus ridiculed Premier Chang Chun-hsiung's administrative team as a "pathetic Cabinet" Saturday, saying its overall performance over the past year is far from ideal.
Ying Chih-hung, convener of the NP caucus, made the remarks at a news conference held in connection with the first anniversary of Chang's premiership.
However, Ying went on to express sympathy for Chang because, he said, the premier has been very diligent.
"Nevertheless, his Cabinet's performance is really mediocre," Ying claimed. "All major economic indicators point to continued deterioration of our economic situation over the past year."
In his view, Ying went on, Chang did not have full authority to make decisions on major policy issues or on the Cabinet's lineup and agenda.

"Chang is only President Chen Shui-bian's chief of the general staff, not a true policy-maker," Ying said, adding that Chang's plight has been aggravated by the fact that some Cabinet members appointed by Chen have failed to cooperate fully with him.
As a result, Ying said, the Cabinet has performed dismally. "Over the past year, we have seen many policy turn-abouts, inconsistencies and operational flaws and flops," he alleged.

For instance, Ying continued, the Cabinet's measures to salvage the faltering domestic economy have so far failed to achieve ideal results as the domestic unemployment rate has surged to an all-time high and industrial production and exports have continued to register negative growth.
"My observation is that the overall performance of Chang's Cabinet deserves a score of only 30 points on a `0-100' scale," Ying added.

NP Legislator Lai Shyh-bao echoed Ying's view, saying the current Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-led Cabinet has failed to delivered on its promise to rev up the domestic economy and improve the people's livelihood.

Lai said he recognizes Premier Chang's devotion and diligence. "But the cold reality is that his Cabinet has accomplished few achievements," he said, adding that Taiwan's "misery index" has reached a record high.
Quoting official tallies, Lai said, the country's composite economic indicator has continued flashing a gloomy "blue light" since last December.

Lai said Taiwan's per capita gross national product (GNP) is expected to drop to US$13,144 this year from 2000's US$14,188, and that the island's total industrial production will decrease by an estimated NT$123.3 billion (US$3.58 billion) this year.

Worse yet, Lai said the island's private investment and foreign trade have all declined this year as compared with the 2000 levels. While the unemployment rate rose from last December's 3.16 percent to 5.17 percent in August this year, Lai said, the market capitalization of local stocks has also shrunk by more than NT$1.6 trillion over the past year.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP OVERSEAS CHAPTERS HOLD JOINT MEETING IN BANGKOK
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Oct. 6 (CNA) (By Kuo Fang-chih & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Some 40 representatives from the overseas chapters of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) participated in a three-day joint meeting in Bangkok that ended Saturday.

DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh explained to the participants the importance of the Dec. 1 elections for legislators, county magistrates and city mayors for the party, which became Taiwan's ruling party in the March 18 presidential election of 2000.

He said that only when the DPP becomes the largest party in the Legislative Yuan while continuing to hold the ruling power in most of the counties and cities, can the present political chaos be improved.

In a joint statement issued at the close of the meeting, the participants said that they affirmed the administrative accomplishments of the DPP and added that their confidence in the party's ruling ability has never swayed.
Regarding the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States, they said that any attempt to use violence against peace must be denounced.
They pledged that they will strive for the welfare, prosperity and peace of the people of Taiwan and the rest of the world.

The joint statement said that Taiwan's sovereignty should not be "invaded" by mainland China or any other country and urged the international community to support Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations and other international organizations.
The participants represented the DPP chapters in the United States, Canada, Oceania, Africa, Europe, Southeast Asia and Taiwan's Kaohsiung City and Ilan City.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE ALS PATIENTS SHARE EXPERIENCE WITH LOCAL COUNTERPARTS

TEXT.P: ALS patients need social support and "blessing" to overcome all sorts of difficulties and pain inflicted by their disease, a visiting Japanese ALS patient said Saturday.
Misao Hashimoto said that amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), more commonly known as Lou Gehrig's disease, is not completely hopeless, but "would inflicts serious disabilities on its victims."

Hashimoto, the only ALS patient in Japan who can move on her own and does not need constant care from her family, said that like other disabled people, ALS patients must overcome great obstacles and pain to forge contacts with other people and engage in various social functions.

"As we suffer the grimmest of all forms of physical disability, we must toil far harder than other handicapped people in overcoming the various inconveniences and difficulties in our daily lives," Hashimoto said, adding: "Therefore, we hope other people can recognize our efforts and render us spiritual support."
Hashimoto, one of 12 Japanese ALS patients who are currently on a four-day goodwill visit to Taiwan, made the remarks while meeting with local ALS sufferers.

"We made extensive plans and preparations for our unprecedented trip to Taiwan," Hashimoto said, adding that she hopes the trip will help boost exchanges of life experiences with their local counterparts.

Hsu Tsui-lieh, a physician who concurrently serves as president of the Taiwan ALS Patients Association, noted that there is no cure for Lou Gehrig's disease at the moment. "We can only control the development of the disease," he said, adding that ALS patients need long-term care and spiritual support.
Hsu said he has invited Japanese ALS patients to visit Taiwan with a view to allowing local patients to learn from their foreign counterparts' experiences in overcoming their difficulties.
"We also hope that the government and the private sector can make concerted efforts to create a better living environment for local ALS patients," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PRESIDENT STUMPS FOR TSU CANDIDATES FOR YEAR-END ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui stumped for two Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) candidates Saturday for the year-end legislative and local elections.
Lee stumped for Liao Pen-yen and Lee Jih-huang, the TSU-nominated candidates running for legislators, at the inauguration of their respective campaign headquarters in Taipei County.

Accompanied by TSU Chairman Huang Chu-wen and Secretary General Su Chin-chiang, Lee arrived at the campaign headquarters of Liao Pen-yen at noon and was warmly welcomed. He later proceeded to Lee Jih-huang's campaign headquarters and was also warmly received.

In the stump speech, Lee said that it was the hope that Taiwan maintains a stable political situation that made him, an 80-year-old man, stump for TSU candidates. Lee is not a TSU member but the TSU, a newly formed political party, ragards him as its spiritual leader.

Lee urged the public to support Liao Peng-yen and Lee Jih-huang, and hoped that the two would exercise interpellation rights at the legislature to promote Taiwan's economy if they are elected legislators.

As for the economic slowdown, Lee said that he has a set of solutions that will surely prop up Taiwan's stock market to reach the 8,000-point level and lower the unemployment rate to three percent through the solution of bank bad debts and the investment in government bonds.
Lee was former chairman of the opposition Kuomintang. He was forced to step down as KMT chairman after the 107-year-old party was humiliatingly defeated in the 2000 presidential election.
The KMT revoked Lee's membership Sept. 21 for his harsh criticism toward the party and stumping for rival TSU that resulted in widespread protests from KMT members.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANDIDACY REGISTRATION FOR DEC. 1 ELECTIONS TO START SUNDAY

TEXT.P: Candidacy registration for the Dec. 1 elections for local government chiefs and legislators will kick off Sunday and last through Oct. 11, the Central Election Commission (CEC) said Saturday.
During the period, all registration offices will remain open on holidays, CEC officials said, adding that the daily registration hours start from 8 a.m. to noon and from 1:30 p.m. to 5:30 p.m.

Those who intend to run for regional and aboriginal legislative seats, city mayorship and county magistrate posts should register their candidacy with election commissions of special municipalities, cities and counties around the country.
Hopefuls for at-large and overseas Chinese community legislative seats must register at the Central Election Commission.
CEC officials said all candidates will draw lots at various registration offices on Nov. 12 to determine their serial numbers to appear on the ballots.

The CEC is scheduled to unveil the rosters of candidates for various elections and the official campaign period on Nov. 20. The commission is also expected to announce the number of eligible voters for each kind of election on Nov. 27.
CEC officials said all eligible voters should go to the poll to cast their ballots in the country's first public elections in the 21st century.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIEF OF TAIWAN'S STATE-RUN OIL FIRM TO VISIT MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: W.Y. Pan, president of the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC), will leave for Beijing next Monday to study the possibility of making joint oil exploration at Daqing oil field with mainland China.
If the result is affirmative, mainland China will become another source of crude imports for Taiwan. At present, CPC's crude imports are mainly from the Middle East, Indonesia, Australia and Africa.
During the Beijing trip, Pan will first sign a letter of intent for selling diesel to China National Petroleum Corp.
Mainland China now still forbids imports of diesel, but the ban is expected to be relaxed after the mainland and Taiwan become full members of the World Trade Organization early next year.
Taiwan's Executive Yuan (Cabinet) and Ministry of Economic Affairs have agreed to CPC's plan to sell diesel to mainland China.

After his business talks in Beijing, Pan will proceed to Heilongjiang Province in northeastern China to visit Daqing oil field, the largest oil oil field in mainland China with a daily output of 1.2 million barrels.

If the mainland side agrees to sell oil to CPC, it will be another deal between mainland China and a state-run company of Taiwan. Taiwan Power Company has concluded a deal to import coal from the mainland.

Meanwhile, CPC's plan to conduct joint oil exploration at the outlet of the Zhujiang River in southern China with mainland China is still waiting for the approval from the Cabinet-level Mainland China Affairs. Therefore, it will not be taken up for discussion during Pan's China trip this time.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORKERS FROM BURMA, CAMBODIA MAY BE ALLOWED TO WORK IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) is considering to allow workers from Burma and Cambodia to work in Taiwan now that the island is going to become a member of the World Trade Organization.
The recently-held Economic Development Advisory Conference has also proposed to expand the sources of foreign labor.
An official with the CLA said Saturday that the CLA has conducted negotiations with five countries -- Burma, Cambodia, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka and Mongolia -- over this matter.
He noted that Burma's advantage is that many overseas Chinese live in that country, while interactions between Taiwan and Cambodia are frequent.
The official said that Bangladesh and Sri Lanka have high intent of exporting labor to Taiwan and their people can speak English.
As for Mongolia, he said that its government has maintained good relationship with Taiwan since President Chen Shui-bian visited there when he was Taipei mayor.

The results of the preliminary evaluation are that there are direct flights from Taipei to Rangoon and to Phnom Penh, while the air links between Taiwan and the three other countries are not so convenient.
The official said that this matter will be further discussed between the CLO and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs as well as other related government institutions.
Currently more than 300,000 foreign workers are employed in Taiwan. They are mainly from Thailand, the Philippines, Indonesia and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT STUMPS FOR DPP CANDIDATES IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian Saturday stumped for the Democratic Progressive Party's candidates for legislators, county magistrates and city mayors in the Dec. 1 elections.
He told a gathering on the ground scheduled for the Taichung "Big Egg" stadium that "Taiwan will become more stable if the voters support candidates of the Democratic Progressive Party."
Chen urged the people to cooperate with the government to strive for stability, engage in reform, stimulate economy and eradicate "black gold."
Besides Chen, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh also attended the rally to call for support for the ruling party's candidates.

The DPP candidates present at the rally included candidate for Taichung mayor Tsai Ming-hsien, candidate for Taichung County magistrate Liao Yung-lai, candidate for Nantou County magistrate Lin Tsung-nan and several candidates for legislators.
It was the first large-scale stumping rally organized for DPP candidates. Three other rallies will be held in the coming weeks in southern, eastern and northern Taiwan.
Earlier the day, Chen visited Hsinchu to attend a local festival and urged the voters to support Hsinchu Mayor Tsai Jen-chien's bid for reelection in the upcoming election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The China Times:
Ministry of Justice softened draconian criteria for vote-buying.
The United Daily News:
Afghan fires missiles at suspected U.S. planes.
The Liberty Times:

The Central Daily News:
