The China Post:
Taliban launch spy plane strike.
The Taiwan News:
Afghan anti-aircraft guns fires at intruder over Kabul
The Taipei Times:
DPP gets campaign going.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER HALF OF PEOPLE 'SATISFIED' WITH PRESIDENT'S OVERALL PERFORMANCE

TEXT.P: Nearly 53 percent of those questioned in a recent survey released Sunday are satisfied with the overall performance of President Chen Shui-bian.

The survey by Focus Survey Research Corp. was conducted Oct. 4-5 by telephone and received 1,033 valid responses from random respondents over the age of 20 around the island. The margin of error was 3.05 percent.

The survey found that 9.5 percent of those responding were "very satisfied," and 43 percent were "satisfied" with Chen's overall performance. Just over 22.7 percent said they were "not satisfied" with the president, and 9.5 percent said they were "not at all satisfied" with Chen's overall performance.
Chuang Kuo-jung, assistant professor from National Cheng Chi University, said the figures show that those who are satisfied with Chen outnumber those who are not satisfied with him.

The survey also showed that President Chen had higher approval ratings than other political figures, namely Lien Chan, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang; James Soong, chairman of the People First Party; and Lee Teng-hui, former president of the Republic of China.
About 34 percent said they like Chen, followed by 20 percent who favor Soong, 18.8 percent for Lee, and 10 percent for Lien.
On the opposite side, 19.5 percent said they dislike Chen, 54 percent dislike Lien, 39.5 dislike Soong, and 49.3 percent do not care for Lee.

Commentator Ping Lu said the high disapproval rate for Lien could be because of the KMT's recent move to revoke the party membership of Lee, who also served as KMT chairman during his 12 years as ROC president. Lee was ousted because he had recently criticized the KMT and for stumping for the recently created political party, the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY GOVERNMENT TO OFFER FREE ENGLISH AND JAPANESE COURSES

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Government is planning to open free classes in English and Japanese to promote better international relations, the director of the city's education bureau said Sunday.

Lee Hsi-chin, director of the Taipei City Government's Bureau of Education, said Sunday that since Taipei is already an internationalized city, English and Japanese are essential tools to strengthen exchanges between cultures.

The free English and Japanese programs, focusing on tourist conversations, will help Taiwan residents understand the diversification of cultures and cultivate better international courtesy, Lee added.
Lee said that as the time and teaching methods of the program are very flexible, foreign language learning can be easily promoted in this age of globilization.
Lee stressed that each class will have no more than 20 students, and the courses will be conducted in an interactive way to increase learning.
A total of 29 junior high schools will be used to offer the language program. Those interested can visit the program's Web site: www.edunet.taipei.gov.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: SWISS PARLIAMENTARIANS VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Four members of Swiss Federal Assembly arrived in Taipei Sunday for a six-day visit to the Republic of China.

During their stay, they will visit the ROC Legislative Yuan, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Council of Agriculture, and the Mainland Affairs Council, and participate in celebrations to mark ROC National Day on Oct. 10.
The four Swiss Federal Assembly members are Hans Hess, Chiara Simoneschi-Coresi, Ulrich Schluer and Marcel Sandoz.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY MAYOR RECOMMENDS SUBMARINE-STYLE PUMPING STATIONS

TEXT.P: Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday that pumping stations should be made as a water-tight as submarines to ensure they do not fail during flooding.

At a symposium on ways to prevent flooding and prevent disasters, Ma said Taipei's Yucheng pumping station -- the largest in Southeast Asia -- broke down during the height of Typhoon Nari because the facility itself was deluged by floodwaters.

Although the station can pump water equivalent to that in a standard swimming pool in just eight second, it was rendered useless during the typhoon which hit northern Taipei Sept. 16 and dumped nearly a meter of rain in 24 hours.
The computer-controlled pumping station stopped operating automatically when water flooded its cooling system.

Saying that constructing a wall around the station as a breakwater cannot guarantee that the station will remain dry during emergencies, Ma suggested wrapping the station in a water-proof shell, making the whole station resemble a submarine.
The breakdown of the Yucheng pumping station was partially blamed for the unprecedented flooding in downtown Taipei. More than 5,000 basements were deluged by floodwaters.

He also suggested that the government revise existing rules to demand that electrical fuse boxes are moved out of basements, as is currently the case in most large buildings. During Typhoon Nari, hundreds of buildings went dark after floodwaters shorted out the entire structure because of flooding in only the basement. Water was also cut because most buildings in Taipei rely on ground floor or basement pumps to deliver water to upper floors of high-rises.

Taiwan County Magistrate Su Tseng-chang agreed at the symposium with Ma's idea of submarine-style pumping stations, saying that the breakdown of the pumping station in Tucheng, Taipei County during Typhoon Nari aggravated the flooding in surrounding areas.

As a result, Su said, rainfall brought by Typhoon Nari inundated nine times more households and generated 30 times more water-damaged rubbish than did Typhoon Xangsane which struck the island on Oct. 30 last year.
In a related development, Ma announced earlier in the day that Taipei's rapid transit system will shorten the interval between trains from 15 minutes to 10 minutes on three of its five lines.
From 6 a.m. Sunday, Ma said, trains will run every 10 minutes on the Hsintien, Tamshui and Chungho lines.

The system, which transports an estimated 600,000 people each day, was partially paralyzed after Typhoon Nari flooded its underground tracks. Commuters, forced to seek alternative transportation to and from work, reduced the city's road traffic to a near standstill.

Service on the full lines of Hsintien and Tamsui was only restored last week, but the system's hub, Taipei Main Station, is still closed because of more serious water damage. Trains that usually stop at the station are now passing through without stopping.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENERGY EXPERT RECOMMENDS NUCLEAR POWER FOR TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 6 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan should seek to diversify the forms of its energy sources in case of a crisis and nuclear power is the most available for the country at present, a renowned expert based in the United States said Saturday in New York.

Hsu Yi-yun, who served as chairman of the Republic of China's Atomic Energy Commission during 1990-1996, urged authorities in Taiwan to remain on high alert should Taiwan's importation of energy be cut by an unpredictable crisis in the international community. He stressed that nuclear power is the energy form which meets Taiwan's needs the most now because of its cheap cost and security.

Hsu made the remarks while giving a keynote speech on the energy prospects in Taiwan and mainland China at an annual gathering of the New York branch of the American Association of Chinese Engineers. More than 100 academics and specialists from the telecommunications, Internet and medical sectors from Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China took part in the event.

Pointing out that Taiwan's energy reserves could last for two months if its import channels were blocked by outside factors, such as a blockade by mainland China or a major crisis in the Middle East, Hsu said the country could face blackouts soon after such a crisis.
The energy expert said that Taiwan should further diversify its sources of imported energy and that the ROC government should fully promote the use of nuclear power.

In contrast, the situation in mainland China would not be so difficult in the face of such an international crisis because the authorities there have actively built power plants in an ambitious "self-sufficiency" plan, he noted, adding that the mainland should take measures to avoid problems related to greenhouse gases, acid rain and smog.

Hsu also criticized the decision made by the current government led by the Democratic Progressive Party to suspend the building of Taiwan's Fourth Nuclear Power Plant in Oct. 2000. Although construction has been resumed, he said that Taiwan's international credibility had been seriously damaged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY MAYOR'S HANDLING OF DISASTER APPROVED BY 61%

TEXT.P: Sixty-one percent of respondents in a recent survey said they are either "very satisfied" or "satisfied" with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou's handling of the disaster caused by Typhoon Nari.

The survey, released Sunday by the Focus Survey Research Corporation, also found that the people who said their impression of the mayor was negatively affected by his performance during and after the typhoon was far higher than those who said their impression was positively affected, 12.4 percent to 7.4 percent.
Just over 68 percent said they have not changed their view of the mayor because of his performance during and after the disaster.
On the other hand, 28.5 percent said they either "strongly agreed" or "agreed to some extent" with the expression that "Ma's risk-management capabilities are insufficient."

Citing the figure as a proof of Ma's weakness, Tuan Yi-kang, a Taipei City Councilman from the Democratic Progressive Party warned in a news conference called to release the survey Sunday that the writing is on the wall for Ma.
The mayor will face an uphill battle for reelection if he fails to head off the increasing number of unsatisfied people, Tuan said.
The survey was conducted between Oct. 4-5 and received 1,033 valid responses from those over age 20 in Taipei City. The survey had a margin of error of 3.05 percent.
Typhoon Nari, which struck northern Taiwan Sept. 16 and central Taiwan Sept. 17, has claimed the lives of 83, and dumped nearly one meter of rainfall within 24 hours in mountainous areas.

The torrential rain deluged many low-lying areas. Taipei was the hardest-hit area, 51 percent of its inhabitants were affected by the storm and 26 percent in the whole of Taiwan, according to the survey.
About 5,000 buildings in Taipei had their basements inundated by floodwaters, and the city's rapid transit system was paralyzed after its underground tracks were turned into underground streams.
The city has not yet full recovered from the disaster, as its rapid transit system has only four of five lines currently operating.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT EXPLAINS 'PAINFUL DECISION' TO EXPEL FORMER CHAIRMAN IN OPEN LETTER

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang said in an open letter Sunday that Lee Teng-hui, former ROC president and former KMT chairman, has "bitten the hand that feeds him," and that it had to take the "painful decision" to expel him Sept. 21.

The letter, issued by the KMT Central Committee to all its members, noted that Lee could have used his respected status to help bridge the differences between the ruling and the opposition camps. This, the letter said, would have not only contributed to the nation, but would have left Lee's mark on history.
Instead, the letter said, Lee tried to splinter the KMT by criticizing the party that nurtured him and using a facade of wanting to help stabilize politics at the same time.
The letter noted that Lee, who taught agricultural economics at National Taiwan University before he stepped into politics, has benefited a great deal from the KMT.

It said, "Lee, as a scholar, reached the peak of his political career in the short time of little more than two decades under the tutelage of late President Chiang Ching-kuo. It is obvious that Lee could not have reached such a high position without the nurturing of the KMT.
"Furthermore, during Lee's term as the nation's president and KMT chairman, many of his ideas on reforms were able to become reality because the KMT was the ruling party at the time."

But the letter said that Lee has "bitten the hand that feed him." It noted that Lee has stepped up his tirades against the KMT, seriously damaging the KMT's reputation. Recently, Lee has openly stumped for the candidates of another political party. "The party has to seriously address his words and deeds," the letter said.

The letter also pointed out the stark difference between Lee before and after stepping down as party chairman, noting that Lee said on the 105th anniversary of the KMT that "the party is our mother, and we are brethren. If we can achieve something one day, we have to be thankful to the nurturing of the mother and support of the brethren." But in no time, Lee turned his back against the "mother," and the "brethren," the letter added.

Lee, who had earlier said that couldn't care less about being expelled from the party and that he had been rubbing shoulders with a "bunch of rascals" during his 12 years as the KMT head, said Saturday that democracy is respecting the wishes of the majority of the people.

But Lee, in stumping for the candidates of the Taiwan Solidarity Union, said that after President Chen Shui-bian took over the helm of the nation from the KMT in May 2000, the political situation has been less than stable, which he said, without mentioning the name of KMT Chairman Lien Chan, is because of "a man's lack of democratic spirit, even if he is a Ph.D. holder in political science."
Lien is the only one in such a position to have received such a degree.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE CULTURE UNIVERSITY TIES KNOTS WITH HOLLAND COUNTERPART

TEXT.P: Chinese Culture University, which has prided itself of its internalization, has recently signed a sisterhood pact with a Holland university.
Christelijke Hogeschool Noord-Nederland has become the 59th sister college of Chinese Culture University and is the first Netherlands university to team up with a Taiwan university.

Chinese Culture University President Lin Tsai-mei noted that Chang Chi-yun, founder of the university, built the school on the conviction of turning it into a internationalized college, and actively solicited sisterhood pacts with its overseas counterparts.

Lin noted that Holland has a robust business and tourism industry, and she expressed the hope that the tourism department of her school could have more exchanges with its sister counterpart in Holland in the future.
Chinese Culture University began making sisterhood pacts with overseas counterparts in 1967 and boasts the largest number of sisterhood counterparts in Taiwan.
Among its sisterhood pact counterparts, 17 are in South Korea, 12 are in Japan, and 11 in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANDIDACY REGISTRATION FOR DEC. 1 ELECTIONS STARTS

TEXT.P: Candidacy registration for the Dec. 1 elections for local government chiefs and legislators started Sunday, the formal step that raises the curtain on the races.

Although eight political movements have received application forms, only a few would-be candidates went through the process Sunday, because the date was considered "ominous" according to traditional Chinese custom.
Many would-be candidates opted to canvass votes rather than securing their candidacy Sunday.
The registration period will last through Oct. 11, during which all registration offices will remain open on holidays, according to officials from the Central Election Commission (CEC).

Those who intend to run for regional and aboriginal legislative seats, city mayorship and county magistrate posts should register their candidacy with election commissions of special municipalities, cities and counties around the country.
Hopefuls for at-large and overseas Chinese community legislative seats must register at the CEC.
All candidates will draw lots at various registration offices on Nov. 12 to determine their numbers that will appear on the ballots.

The CEC is scheduled to unveil the rosters of candidates for various elections and the official campaign period on Nov. 20. The commission is also expected to announce the number of eligible voters for each kind of election on Nov. 27.
There are 225 legislative seats and 23 magistrateships up for grabs on December 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEPTEMBER OUTPUT OF TAIWAN NOTEBOOK MAKERS UP

TEXT.P: Despite the disruptions by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States and by the typhoons which swept through Taiwan last month, major local notebook makers registered growth in their output in September.

The four leading notebook computer firms -- Quanta Computer, Arima Computer, Compal Electronic and Inventec Cooperation -- were estimated to put out a total of 760,000 units in September, up 12.6 percent from August, after international air traffic got back to normal over the past two weeks, according to initial estimates.
Quanta -- Taiwan's largest notebook manufacturer -- produced 380,000 units in September, a similar level to its August production which was near full capacity of 400,000 units per month.

Compal Electronic, which is a major contractor for the U.S.-based Dell, produced a historic single-month high of 220,000 units last month, up 33.3 percent over the August level. Compal said its third-quarter production hit 560,000 units, a 12-percent increase over the second quarter.

Arima Computer, a prime contractor for the U.S.-based Compaq, made 600,000 to 700,000 units in September, about its August level. Arima was the sole major notebook maker which failed to post an increase in output for September.

Inventec Cooperation estimated its September production at 100,000 units, up 40 percent over its August output. The company attributed the growth to rising demand from Europe following its holiday season and from the United States after the Sept. 11 disaster.

Quanta and Compal have predicted that their output will continue to grow in October, with Quanta and Compal confident of netting a monthly business revenue of over the NT$10 billion mark and the NT$8 billion mark, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC GOVERNMENT URGED TO FURTHER OPEN MARKET TO SERVICE INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: Some foreign trade associations have recently urged the Republic of China government to further open its service industry to foreign participants, since such a move would help improve the standard of living on Taiwan.

Taiwan has promised that it will open the market to some specific service sectors after it joins the World Trade Organization (WTO). These sectors, which will include telecommunications services, transportation, construction, sales, education, environment protection, finance, health, tourism, entertainment, and cultural and sports services have been either prohibited from foreign investment or have faced entry barriers.

Doubting to what extent the ROC government can open its market to the service industry, some senior officials of trade associations, including the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei (AmCham) and the European Council of Commerce and Trade (ECCT), urged the ROC government to recognize the fact that the final beneficiary of the opening of Taiwan's service industry will be its people, while over-protection of its specific industries will violate the spirit of liberalization.

AmCham President Richard Henson said that Taiwan's service industry has been protected too much and that that has made their enterprises less competitive, citing the example of frequent bridge failures throughout Taiwan and the recent heavy flooding caused by typhoons.

Henson went on to say that because local constructors have been overprotected by the government, foreign companies have no other way but to chose to leave the Taiwan market. Without outside competition, Taiwan's construction quality cannot be elevated, and the victims will be the people of Taiwan, Henson said.
He stressed that the opening of the market to the service industry is a precondition for Taiwan to become a global planning and management center.

Theo Stiftl, CEO of ECCT, said he was quite surprised that the reconstruction works of many schools ruined in the devastating earthquake in September 1999 still have not been completed, and that the complicated problems involved need the further attention of the government.
Stiftl said that refusing the participation of the foreign service sector will benefit only a few special interest groups or individuals.

He stressed that Taiwan will open its service market sooner or later after it enters the WTO, and if local entrepreneurs still do not want to dedicate time to strengthening competitiveness and reducing costs, the pressure of competition on the island will be clear in time.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION PARTIES JOIN FORCES TO REBUT GOVERNMENT ACCUSATIONS

TEXT.P: The country's two major opposition parties joined hands Sunday to side against President Chen Shui-bian and his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for blaming the opposition-controlled legislature for the nation's political deadlock.
Lin Fong-cheng, secretary-general of the leading opposition Kuomintang (KMT), said if his party is to be blamed, it is only because it is too subservient to the ruling party in the legislature.

Noting that the second and third Legislative Yuan passed 23 bills and 44 bills on average per session respectively when the DPP was the opposition party, while the fourth Legislative Yuan has seen through 63 bills per session on average when the KMT was the opposition, Lin said. He said that this betrays the president's claim that the legislature is paralyzed under the control of the KMT and has become a ball and chain around the nation.

He also pointed out that the government's overall budget for 2001 has been cut 2.03 percent by the legislature, which is smaller than the 3.8 percent cut in 1994 when President Chen served as the DPP whip at the Legislative Yuan, and the 1995 cut while Premier Chang Chun-hsiung was the DPP whip.
This bears out the fact that the KMT has been too accommodating to the government and "still does not know how to serve as an opposition party," Lin said.

Meanwhile, Chou Hsi-wei, the whip of another opposition party, the People First Party, also disputed the DPP leaders' claims, saying that members from his party were skeptical about many of the government's economic policies but have yielded their own opinions to rally behind the Cabinet in hopes of boosting the country's economy.
The DPP's blame will only force his party to review its cooperative attitude with the DPP in the next legislative session, Chou said.

Speaking at a campaign rally in Taichung Saturday, President Chen and Premier Chang took turns in lambasting the opposition for what they called its blocking of the administration's policy at every turn.
They blamed the opposition-controlled legislature as the root cause of the country's current political unrest and appealed to their supporters to return DPP candidates to the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC KEEPS CLOSE WATCH ON U.S. STRIKES AGAINST AFGHANISTAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) is keeping a close watch on the developments in the U.S. military strikes against military installations of Afghanistan's ruling Taliban, military spokesman Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng said Monday.

Huang said the Republic of China military is now maintaining normal combat preparedness, but will step up alert and keep close track of relevant intelligence and information to prevent any possible contingencies.
In fact, Huang said, the armed forces has tightened security measures at various military bases around the country since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States.

Huang said President Chen Shui-bian, Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen and Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming have all ordered chief officers of various military units to keep alert and intensify security measures at military bases and major installations since the Sept. 11 terrorist assaults that leveled New York City's World Trade Center and left the Pentagon in flames.

U.S. President George W. Bush said around midnight that the United States, with Britain's help, had begun military strikes against military installations of Afghanistan's ruling Taiban and training camps in that country of Islamic militant Osama bin Laden's al-Qaeda network.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN CONVENES EMERGENCY MEETING

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan (Cabinet) convened an emergency meeting at 1:45 a.m. Monday after the United States began taking military action to strike the Afghan capital of Kabul in its war against terrorism.
The meeting was attended by ministers from relevant ministries and agencies.
Government Information Office Director-General Su Tzen-ping said that the government has taken necessary measures to cope with the development of the situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT CLOSELY MONITORS U.S. STRIKE AGAINST AFGHANISTAN: GIO

TEXT.P: The Republic of China was closely monitoring the latest situation in Afghanistan and the national security mechanism has been activated after the United States started reprisal striking against the Afghanistan, said Su Tzen-ping, director-general of the Government Information Office (GIO), early Monday.

In anticipation of the launch of the strike, Su said, the government agencies have been keeping close contacts with one another, and heads of related agencies have been on vigil after the news of the strike broke out.
Su made the comment to CNA on telephone after Washington announced its attack against Afghanistan early Monday (Taipei time).

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT VOICES SUPPORT FOR WAR AGAINST TERRORISM

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Monday expressed its support for the U.S. and British military actions against the Taliban regime.

"As a member of the democratic world, we fully support the just military actions of the U.S. and British forces to eradicate terrorism, while striving to uphold world peace," KMT spokesman Chou Shou-hsun said.
He went on that the joint military actions were apparently made at "the most appropriate time" after careful judgment.
At the same time, Chou urged Taiwan's ruling authorities to pay attention to the possible effect on the island's economy.
He said that the war is likely to bring about adverse effect on the economy of the world, as well as that of Taiwan.
Therefore, Chou said that the government should work out efficient counter-measures at an early date so as not to worsen the domestic economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ISSUES DIRECTIVES IN WAKE OF U.S. STRIKES ON TALIBAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian ordered the Cabinet to hold an emergency meeting early Monday to discuss necessary measures to cope with the situation in the wake of U.S. strikes against military installations of Afghanistan's ruling Taliban.

Presidential Office sources said President Chen issued the directive after learning that U.S. and British forces launched around midnight (Taipei time) heavy missile strikes against a broad range of Taliban military targets and guerrilla training camps in Afghanistan.
Acting on Chen's instruction, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and relevant Cabinet ministers met at 1:45 a.m. Monday to review the latest international situation and hammer out necessary measures.

Meanwhile, President Chen is scheduled to chair a national security meeting at 8 a.m. Monday. It will be the third time that Chen has called a national security conference since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States. The first two meetings were held on Sept. 12 and Sept. 20, respectively.
After learning of the onset of U.S. military retaliation against the Sept. 11 attacks, President Chen also ordered the Republic of China armed forces to step up alert.

Premier Chang presided over the emergency Cabinet meeting, which was attended by Vice Premier Lai Ing-jaw, Cabinet Secretary-General Chiou I-yen, Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao, Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen, Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang, Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi, Transportation and Communications Minister Yeh Chu-lan, Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan and other relevant officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STRENGTHENS PROTECTION OF AMERICAN CITIZENS

TEXT.P: Taiwan police and security authorities have stepped up protection of American and Middle Eastern people living in Taiwan, said an official with the National Security Bureau Monday.

The official noted that since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York and Washington, police officers in all counties and cities have made frequent check-ups on the safety of U.S. citizens and the people from the Middle East.
He added that the security authorities have also stepped up monitoring on the activities of suspectable foreigners.

After the U.S. and British military strikes in Afghanistan, the U.S. government issued a dire warning to U.S. citizens that the military strikes could lead to terrorist attacks against Americans and American interests abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AIRLINERS DETOUR FLIGHTS AFTER U.S. START STRIKING

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based China Airlines and EVA Airways announced Monday a decision to detour their flights to Europe after Washington launched strikes against Afghanistan.

The two carriers' flight to Europe via Bangkok will reroute to southern India and Saudi Arabia to its European destinations. The new path, sidestepping the airspace of Afghanistan and Pakistan will increase the flight time by 30 minutes, executives from both corporations said respectively.
However, the China Airlines' weekly non-stop flight to Frankfurt and the EVA's weekly flight to Paris, both using a corridor over Russia, will not be affected, said sources from the two companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA ORDERS OVERSEAS OFFICES TO STEP UP PROTECTION OF EXPATRIATES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has ordered all Republic of China embassies and representative offices abroad to step up protection of ROC expatriates in their resident countries, MOFA spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue said Monday.

Chang made the remarks after U.S. and British forces launched around midnight (Taipei time) heavy missile strikes against a broad range of Taliban military targets and guerrilla training camps in Afghanistan in retaliation for the Sept. 11 terrorist assaults in New York and Washington.
Chang said the MOFA will coordinate with other relevant government agencies in reinforcing security measures at foreign embassies and representative offices in Taiwan.

Chang said Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao has attended a Cabinet emergency meeting held at 1:45 a.m. Tien is also scheduled to deliver a report on the MOFA's contingency measures to the foreign affairs committee of the Legislative Yuan at 9 a.m., Chang said.

Meanwhile, Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan said she has ordered the Civil Aeronautics Administration and harbor bureaus to tighten security at Taiwan's major international airports and sea ports.

In anticipation of possible U.S. military response against terrorist attacks, Yeh said the Ministry of Transportation and Communications has long drafted a comprehensive package of measures to cope with the situation.

Foreign wire service reports quoted U.S. defense officials as saying that U.S. and British forces have attacked Afghan targets, including Taliban air defense and command-and-control sites around the capital of Kabul and at an airbase near the Taliban stronghold city of Kandahar in southern Afghanistan.

Few details were immediately available, but the attacks by the US$1 million Tomahawk cruise missiles were apparently designed to pave the way for additional raids by smaller attack jets with laser-guided bombs, the reports said.
"It involved a number of targets," one U.S. defense official was quoted as saying, adding that the raids were still going on more than an hour after they began at 1600GMT.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TRADE TO BE NEGATIVELY AFFECTED BY WAR: CETRA

TEXT.P: The joint military actions against Afghanistan by the United States and Britain will bring about negative impact on Taiwan's foreign trade, the island's top trade promoter said Monday.

Huang Chih-peng, secretary general of the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), said that Taiwan's exports to the Middle East will first bear the brunt of the latest military conflicts, followed by its exports to the United States, the island's largest overseas market.

Nearly four weeks after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York and Washington, the U.S. and British forces launched the first wave of reprisal missile strikes against Afghanistan Monday morning (Taipei time).
However, Huang said that as the situation in the Southeast Asian region is expected to remain "relatively stable," regional trade activities will increase in the aftermath of the military actions.
The Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs also said that the outbreak of war in the Middle East is unfavorable to Taiwan's trade, the lifeline of the island.
To what extent Taiwan's trade will be impacted will depend on the scale and the duration of the war, a BOFT official said.
Meanwhile, Schive Chi, former vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planing and Development, said that war will seriously bring down global aviation, transportation and insurance industries.
Schive, now the head of a local think tank, said that the forecasts by many experts that the war will prompt a rebound in the economies of the United States and the world are "too optimistic."
He predicted that the scale and duration of the war will be "limited," otherwise global economy will worsen.

Officials with the Central Bank of China (CBC) said that CBC will not change its policy of maintaining a "flexibly stable" exchange rate of the New Taiwan dollar in the wake of the military conflicts.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REITERATES SUPPORT FOR U.S. WAR AGAINST TERRORISTS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China firmly supports the U.S. stance and operations against terrorism, not only because of its close strategic ties with the United States, but also because of the country's long-standing anti-terrorism position, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said early Monday.

During an emergent meeting of government leaders called in response to the U.S. strikes in Afghanistan, Chang also assured his fellow countrymen that his administration has anticipated the U.S. military operation and has braced up for it. He urged the public to work together with the government and face the situation calmly.
Chang said he is sure his government can contain the incident's impact on the island to the minimum.

The conference, called hours after U.S. launched strikes against Afghanistan, decided against closing local stock exchange and foreign exchange market which are supposed to open at 9 a.m. or narrowing the maximum permitted daily fall in stock prices, unless abnormality develops, said Director-General of Government Information Su Tzen-ping.
In answering questions from journalists, Su said there is nothing unusual thus far between the island and mainland China which is also keeping an eye out for the situation unfold in Afghan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CALLS FOR CALM, UNITY IN FACE OF FALLOUT FROM U.S. STRIKES

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged local people Monday to remain calm and stand united in the face of possible fallout from the U.S. strikes on military installations of Afghanistan's ruling Taliban.

DPP spokesman Cheng Yun-peng said the Cabinet has adopted measures to cope with the latest situation immediately after the onset of U.S. military response to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York and Washington.

Cheng said as the possible effects of the U.S. strikes on the Taliban military targets and training camps of Islamic militant Osama bin Laden's al-Qaeda network remain unclear, local people should remain calm in the face of all relevant developments.
Osama bin Laden, a Saudi Arabian exile, is widely believed to be the mastermind of the Sept. 11 assaults that leveled New York City's World Trade Center and partially damaged the Pentagon.
Cheng said the DPP headquarters will call a meeting of senior party officials at 10 a.m. to discuss relevant subjects and issue a statement.
Meanwhile, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Taiwan should keep track of the development and monitor whether the U.S. global strategy would change in the wake of its war on terrorism.
"We should also evaluate how the Taiwan economy would be affected if the world economy continues deteriorating after the U.S. military retaliation for the Sept. 11 terrorist assaults," Ma noted.

Commenting on the latest U.S. military response, Lin Yu-fang, a Tamkang University professor, said the Bush administration has decided to take action right now partly because the Islamic holy month of Ramadan falls in November.
If the United States attacks Afghanistan during Ramadan, Lin said, it would certainly cause strong backlash from major Islamic countries around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 8, or the 22nd day of the eighth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1836: John Hay, U.S. statesman and diplomat, is born. As secretary of state from 1898 to 1905, he promoted the "Open Door Policy" toward China.
1858: The "Arrow Incident" occurs, in which a Hong Kong-registered ship, the Arrow, is searched in Kwantung by Ching soldiers and 12 of the vessel's sailors are arrested. The incident led to an Anglo-French expedition against Peking and the burning of the Imperial Summer Palace by invading troops.
1869: Franklin Pierce, 14th president of the United States, dies at the age of 65. He was unable to reconcile the issue of slavery that divided his country.
1895: Queen Min of Korea, who had tried to stem the tide of Japanese domination, is assassinated in her palace at the instigation of the Japanese.
1897: Dow Jones & Co., Inc., a New York news agency, comes up with the novel idea of charting general trends in the trading of stocks and bonds on Wall Street. The agency computes a daily industrial average by using a list of 12 stocks and dividing their total price by 12.
1912: Montenegro declares war on Turkey, starting the first Balkan War.
1928: Chiang Kai-shek is elected chairman of the National government of the Republic of China.
1954: Communist Vietnamese forces occupy Hanoi.
1960: Lei Chen, publisher of the "Free China" monthly magazine, is sentenced to 10 years in prison for involvement in an insurrection.
1964: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Senegal.
1965: The Asian Christian Anti-Communist Conference is opened in Taipei.
1967: Clement Attlee, British politician, dies at the age of 84. As Labour prime minister from 1945 to 1951, he established the National Health Service, expanded public ownership of industry, and granted independence to India and Burma.
1970: Russian novelist Alexander Solzhenitsyn is awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature.
1973: Thai Air Force Marshal Boon Choo Chandrubekas arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1974: Economic Minister Y.S. Sun leaves for the United States to attend the China Week Celebration at Expo 74 in Spokane, Washington.
1974: Eisaku Sato, Japanese politician who served as prime minister from 1964 to 1972, is awarded the 1974 Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts toward nuclear disarmament.
1981: A team of 10 divers recovers 431 gold bars worth US$83 million from the wreckage of the "Edinburgh," a British cruiser sunk by German destroyers and a U-boat in the Barents Sea in 1942.
1981: Costa Rican President Rodrigo Carazo Odio, Madame Carazo, and their 12-member entourage arrive in Taipei for a five-day official visit.
1984: Beijing announces a plan to make primary school education compulsory by 1990 and to eradicate adult illiteracy by 1995.
1992: A chartered plane carrying tourists from Taiwan, Europe, and China crashes in northeast China, killing 13 people and injuring four others.
1995: A strong earthquake rocks Sumatra, Indonesia, killing more than 100.
1997: Tung Chee-hwa becomes the first Chinese leader to address Hong Kong's Legislature, 100 days after Britain ceded the territory to Communist China.
1998: The U.S. House of Representatives approves the launching of a formal impeachment inquiry against President Bill Clinton, only the third such investigation against a U.S. president in the country's history.
1999: Defense Minister Tang Fei says the ROC is determined to proceed with a plan to develop its own anti-missile defense even with no outside aid in the face of Beijing's growing missile threat.
2000: Direct air links between Taipei and Manila resume after a protracted dispute over air rights.
2000: Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen throws his weight behind the island's controversial fourth nuclear power plant despite the fact that the Cabinet seems determined to stop its construction.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of originality, energy, strength of character and determination: qualities necessary for the exercise of endurance."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Monday are as follows:
The China Times:
U.S. orders strikes on Afghanistan.
The United Daily News:
U.S., British forces launch air strikes in Afghanistan aimed at rooting out the mastermind in the Sept. 11 terrorist assaults in New York and Washington.
The Liberty Times:
U.S., British forces launched a much anticipated retaliatory strike on military installations and terrorist camps in Afghanistan.
The Taiwan Daily:
Afghan capital of Kabul is under attack.
The Central Daily News:
The United States launched what Bush called 'carefully targeted' counterstrikes against the Afghan Taliban regime.
The China Post:
U.S., Britain launch attacks on Afghanistan.
The Taiwan News:
War on terrorism began at 12:25 a.m. Monday, Taiwan time.
The Taipei Times:
U.S. strikes at Afghanistan.

DOC.HEADLINE: OIL PRICES WON'T INCREASE FOR TIME BEING: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi said Monday that domestic petroleum prices will not be raised for the time being and that water and electricity prices will not be increased before the end of the year.

Lin made the remarks in the wake of the U.S. and British military strikes on Afghanistan early Monday morning for harboring Osama bin Laden, the prime suspect in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States.

Taiwan's two main oil suppliers, Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) and Formosa Plastic Group (FPG), have said that they have safety reserves of 110 days and 60 days worth of oil, respectively, which should ensure an ample supply for domestic consumption.
Both the CPC and the FPG have also tried to increase oil purchase from Indonesia, Malaysia, Australia and Africa in order to diversity the sources of their oil supply.

CPC executives said the impact on Taiwan of the military conflict will depend on the scale and duration of the conflict, adding that if it does expand to the region's oil fields or to crude oil transport routes, the impact on oil prices will be limited.
In addition, Saudi Arabia recently assured the CPC that it will faithfully uphold its terms of the contract with the company and that the supply of oil will not be disrupted.
The situation in the Middle East has a great impact on the stability of Taiwan's supply of oil because the CPC imports 58 percent of its supply from oil-producing countries in the region.

The CPC also imports 25 percent of its oil from Africa and 10 percent from Indonesia and Australia. To avoid the possible negative effects of the military conflict and its aftermath on Taiwan's supply of oil, the CPC has recently consulted oil-producing countries in Asia and Africa in the hopes of increasing its short-term purchases of crude oil from the regions.

The FPG said that it imports its oil from Malaysia, Indonesia, West Africa and North Africa, adding that its oil supply is stable. As to whether FPG will raise prices, FPG officials said that they will have to closely watch the situation in the Middle East and the fluctuations in world oil prices.
Meanwhile, law enforcement authorities have stepped up security at Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan as well as at the CPC's refineries and storage facilities in Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HAS HAMMERED OUT MEASURES TO COPE WITH U.S. STRIKE FALLOUT: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday the Republic of China government has hammered out 55 measures to cope with the possible fallout from the latest U.S.-led night strikes against Afghanistan.
President Chen made the remarks in a special televised speech delivered after huddling with security chiefs in an emergency meeting at 8 a.m.
Chen called on the people of Taiwan to remain calm and keep confidence in the government's ability to handle any possible contingencies.
In his address, the president reaffirmed the ROC's full support for the U.S.-led war on terrorism, offering access to Taiwan's airspace as well as humanitarian aid to Afghan refugees.

"I would like to take this opportunity to express my country's rejection of violence and terrorism and express full support for the United States' methods and determination in striking against terrorism," Chen said.
Besides expressing concern for the aid needed for resettling Afghan refugees, Chen said, the ROC is willing to provide timely assistance.

Chen further said he has placed the ROC military on higher alert against possible "terrorist" action, and has ordered the Ministry of National Defense to monitor movements in mainland China -- the greatest security threat to Taiwan.
Chen also said if necessary, the national security fund will intervene in the local stock market to help maintain domestic capital market order and financial stability.

Meanwhile, the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) suggested that the Cabinet form a special financial task force to cope with the possible impact on the Taiwan economy of the ongoing U.S. retaliation for the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks that leveled New York City's World Trade Center and left the Pentagon in flames.
Opposition New Party Legislator Lai Shyh-bao said if the current U.S.-led war on terrorism continues, Taiwan's export-driven economy would be seriously affected.
Against this backdrop, Lai said, the National Security Council should form an economic division to craft effective measures to cope with changing world financial and economic situation.

Several opposition Kuomintang legislators also expressed worries about the possible fallout on the Taiwan economy, which is already in recession. They also reminded the government to keep track of developments in the delicate Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations in the wake of the U.S. anti-terrorism strikes.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting, Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan said the Civil Aeronautics Administration and other relevant agencies have stepped up security measures at major airports and harbors around the island since Sept. 11.

Touching on the government's 30-day guarantee for extra third-party liability insurance coverage for local airlines, Yeh said her ministry will adopt necessary measures if local carriers fail to strike new deals with their insurers before the deadline expires.

In reaction to the onset of the U.S. air strikes against military targets of Afghanistan's Taliban regime and terrorist training camps in that country, the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau ordered all MJIB offices to tighten alert to maintain domestic stability and security.

The National Police Administration also directed police officers to intensify patrols of foreign embassies and representative offices and strengthen protection of foreign expatriates in Taiwan, particularly American and Israeli citizens.

Police sources said security measures at the U.S. and Israeli representative offices have been fortified since last month. The American Institute in Taiwan, which represents U.S. interests in the ROC in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, suspended its visa services Monday.

Meanwhile, the Central Bank of China (CBC) said it will do its utmost to maintain stability of the domestic financial markets, including the exchange rate of the New Taiwan dollar against the U.S. greenback.
CBC officials said the central bank now has US$10 billion, 15 billion euro and 1 billion Japanese yen in hand to accommodate the domestic need for foreign currencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 65.11 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Monday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 65.11 points to close at 3,520.35.
Market turnover amounted to NT$26.68 billion (US$0.77 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC READY TO OFFER ANY HELP THAT U.S. MAY NEED: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is ready to offer any help that the United States may require as the U.S.-led coalition began military strikes on the Taliban regime in Afghanistan early Monday, President Chen Shui-bian said.

Addressing a national security meeting that he chaired at 8 a.m. Monday, President Chen voiced strong support for the U.S. military actions against Osama bin Laden, the prime suspect in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States, the al Qaeda, bin Laden's terrorist network, and the Taliban militia, bin Laden's host.
Chen said Taiwan is willing to offer the United States any necessary assistance and to throw its full support behind the anti-terrorism treaties and resolutions passed by the United Nations.

He added that Taiwan would like to offer help to the U.S.-led coalition operations in areas including allowing coalition aircraft to use ROC airspace and providing assistance regarding refugee resettlement.

The president, meanwhile, called for the nation to remain calm and composed in the face of the U.S. actions against Afghanistan. He added that a total of 55 contingency measures involving national security, finance and economics, and transportation issues have been mapped out by the various divisions of the government to cope with the situation.

Chen said he was notified by the National Security Council and the National Security Bureau within the first minute of the launch of the U.S.-led coalition military strikes against Afghanistan, adding that he immediately instructed the Executive Yuan to hold an emergency national security conference first thing in the morning, which set the national contingency mechanism in motion.
He stressed that it is his responsibility to take the opportunity to make known the Republic of China's firm stance against violence and global terrorism.

Noting that the just-initiated U.S.-led military action has been taken to safeguard freedom and stamp out threats of terrorism rather than to retaliate against Afghanistan, Chen said he is determined to express support for the military action on behalf of the ROC government and people.

Chen instructed the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to remain in close contact with U.S. authorities in efforts to convey Taiwan's support and intentions to assist the United States in the wake of the military strikes.
He instructed that the National Stability Fund be ready to be used at any minute to help stabilize the domestic stock market, supplies of commodity goods and the island's foreign trade.
He also instructed the Ministry of National Defense and the Mainland Affairs Council to remain on high alert against any possible changes in the situation in the Taiwan Strait.
Vice President Annette Lu and Premier Chang Chun-hsiung were present at the emergency national security meeting.

Other ranking officials who were summoned to the meeting included Presidential Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun, Vice Premier Lai In-jaw, National Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen, Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao, Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan, Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang, Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi, Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan, Council of Economic Planning and Development Chairman Chen Poh-chih, Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, National Security Council Secretary-General Ting Yu-chou and National Security Bureau Director Tsai Chao-ming.
