DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 65.11 points to close at 3,520.35.

Affected by the U.S.-led coalition military strikes on Afghanistan, the bourse opened at 3,519.35 and continued to go down later due to a prevailing wait-and-see attitude on the part of investors. The index fluctuated between 3,568.19 and 3,495.93 during trading.

A total of 1.3 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$26.68 billion (US$0.77 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.95 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$41.49 billion (US$1.2 billion).

All the eight major stock categories lost ground, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 3.4 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 2.5 percent, cement stocks at 2.1 percent, electrical shares at 2 percent, textile issues at 1.8 percent, construction stocks at 1.7 percent, bank and insurance shares at 1.6 percent, and plastics and chemical stocks at 1.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 492 to 69, with 63 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S INDUSTRIAL SECTOR MONITORING DEVELOPMENTS IN AFGHANISTAN

TEXT.P: Those in Taiwan's industrial circles, particularly in the high-technology sector, are closely observing developments regarding the U.S.-led coalition military action in Afghanistan as an extended war in the region would definitely affect international trade.

Huang Chih-peng, secretary-general of the China External Trade Development Council, said Monday that a prolonged war in the Central Asia and Middle East regions would have an adverse effect on Taiwan's export industries. He pointed out that trade activity with counterparts in the Middle East have already been affected, while exports to the United States might also be hit hard in the long run.
Taiwan's industry and trade organizations have temporarily suspended all trade promotion missions to the Middle East.

The high-technology sector has been extremely concerned about the impact of the long anticipated military conflict, worrying about mounting transportation risks and possible increases in raw material prices on the one hand, and a prolonged global economic recession on the other.
The Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park Administration convened an emergency meeting early Monday to study measures to secure raw material supplies and sales channels.
James J. Lee, director general of the administration, said that the park administration has adopted prudent security measures and has guaranteed sufficient water and electricity supplies.

An official of the Institute for Information Industry (III) said that in the event that the military conflict in the region lasts longer than 50 days, Taiwan's electronics and communications equipment manufacturing industries would be further disappointed in terms of its hopes for a gradual recovery.

Taiwan's electronics and information sectors have suffered from serious sales decreases since early this year. A long-term conflict in the region would prolong the global economic recession, according to Chan Wen-nan, director of III's Market Information Center (MIC).

Quoting an MIC report on the impacts of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States, Chan said the attacks have further weakened dwindling consumer confidence in the United States, adding that the U.S. economy is not likely to come out of the doldrums before the second quarter of next year.
This is bad news for Taiwan's electronics and information industries as the United States is the largest market for Taiwan exports.

Chan forecast that Taiwan's electronics sector can only expect a sales recovery by the second or third quarter of next year at the earliest, adding that prolonged warfare would push the world economy deeper into recession and that unpredictable factors might place the industry into deeper adversity.

In the first eight months of this year, export orders received by Taiwan's information and communications industries amounted to US$15.7 billion, down 12.9 percent from the level for the same period in the previous year. The electronics sector in the January-August period received US$17.2 billion worth of export orders, down 18.3 percent from that of the same period last year, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

While the electronics and information sectors remained Taiwan's major foreign exchange earners, sluggish sales in these sectors lead to a 9.7 percent year-to-year decrease in the total value of Taiwan's export orders received in the first eight months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower on Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for October moved down 41 points to close at 3,512, with 11,818 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for November lost 27 points to finish at 3,520, with 109 contract transactions, while December futures fell 35 points to finish at 3,500, with only one contract traded.
Next March futures decreased 50 points to close at 3,550, with three contract transactions, while next June futures plunged 180 points to finish at 3,550, with three contracts changing hands.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 3,553 for October, 3,547 for November, 3,535 for December, 3,600 for next March, and 3,730 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were generally lower.
October TE futures moved down 2.8 points to close at 160.5, with 3,058 contract transactions, while November TE futures decreased 1.55 points to finish at 160.95, with 21 contracts traded.
Next march TE futures lost 10.85 points to close at 158, with 12 contract transactions, while next June TE futures fell 7.35 points to finish at 159.15, with 10 contracts changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
October TF futures moved down 5 points to finish at 590, with 1,243 contract transactions, while November TF futures decreased 9 points to close at 586, with 31 contracts traded.
Next March TF futures rose 27.4 points to finish at 586.2, with 20 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO "ACTIVELY PARTICIPATE" IN GLOBAL ANTI-TERRORISM CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao reaffirmed Monday that the Republic of China government is opposed to any form of terrorism and that it will "actively participate" in the anti-terrorism campaign launched by the United States.
Tien made the remarks when he attended a foreign affairs committee meeting in the Legislative Yuan.

Earlier in the day, Tien took part in an emergency meeting convened by the Executive Yuan during the early morning in the wake of U.S. and British military strikes on Afghanistan for harboring Osama bin Laden, the prime suspect in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States. He also attended a national security meeting convened by President Chen Shui-bian.

Tien said that as the ROC is not on the front lines, it has not supplied any direct military assistance to the United States in the anti-terrorism campaign. He added however that the ROC has had close exchanges with the United States and has offered it any assistance it requires, but that the United States has so far not requested any.

He also said that in his judgment, the anti-terrorism campaign will be a long-term one and that it will not be limited to the military sphere, adding that the Ministry of National Defense and the National Security Council have discussed issues related to the use of ROC airspace by U.S. warplanes.

Tien said that Taiwan has received written notification of the commencement of the military strikes but that it is not expected to take part in the conflict. The ROC, however, will actively work with the United States in other areas such as intelligence sharing, cracking down on money laundering, the monitoring of suspects, and the freezing of accounts of suspected terrorists, he added.

The ROC's representative office in the United States has exchanged views on money laundering with its U.S. counterpart, Tien said, adding that financial authorities in Taiwan have also prepared to deal with the situation.

He also said that Fredrick Chien, president of the nation's top watchdog body the Control Yuan, will fly to New York City in a few days to comfort overseas Chinese and the family members of the victims that died in the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center Sept. 11.

In the aftermath of the terrorist attacks, the ROC government had scheduled to send officials to New York City and Washington, D.C., to extend its concerns, Tien said. In order not to trouble the U.S. State Department and due to the fact that ranking ROC officials still can not visit Washington, D.C., Chien will limit his visit to New York City only, he added.

Tien also said that his ministry has alerted overseas offices, especially those in the Middle East, to step up protection of ROC nationals in the wake of the outbreak of military conflict. As there are more than 3,000 ROC nationals residing in Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, the ministry will also provide financial support if necessary, he said.

He also said that the ROC government hopes to actively take part in assisting Afghan refugees, but added that it will also take Taiwan's domestic financial situation into consideration when determining the extend of its assistance.

Tien stressed that if the ROC government wants to take part in humanitarian efforts, it will have to do so through international organizations, but the premise will be not to fuel the worsening economy.

He said that the ROC did provide financial assistance to the U.S.-led coalition during the Persian Gulf War, but noted that due to the dire straits of Taiwan's present economic situation, it will first have to take domestic financial factors into account.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREX RESERVES STAND AT US$ 115.2 BILLION IN SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves hit a new high to reach US$115.2 billion at the end of September, according to statistics released Monday by the Central Bank of China (CBC).
The September figure was US$1.37 billion more than the last record high of US$113.83 billion at the end of June last year, the CBC statistics show.
It was also an increase of US$2.056 billion from a month earlier and posted a growth of US$8.458 billion from the end of last year, according to the CBC figures.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEIGHTENS ALERT AGAINST POSSIBLE BIOLOGICAL TERRORIST ATTACK

TEXT.P: Taiwan authorities said Monday that they have heightened their preparedness against possible biological attacks amid growing concerns that global terrorists may be planning to use chemical or biological agents against civilians.

Lee Ming-liang, director-general of the Cabinet-level Department of Health said at the Legislative Yuan Monday that deadly anthrax and other biological agents could be used in a terrorist attack following the Sept. 11 attacks in the United States.

He said anthrax is most worrisome because it can be deployed relatively easily and kills about 90 percent of the people it infects. So far only the United States has developed a vaccine against anthrax and there are scant supplies of it available.

Infection by anthrax is virtually incurable once symptoms develop, Lee said, adding that initial flu-like symptoms develop two to three days after the bacteria is inhaled. This is followed by high fever, vomiting, aching joints, labored breathing, internal and external bleeding, lesions and usually death.

Clostridium botulinum, a deadly bacteria usually found in contaminated canned or processed foods, could also be used if a bio-terrorist attack is launched, Lee said, adding that this lethal agent can be controlled in Taiwan as domestic medical institutions have an antidote for it.

Taiwan is also capable of containing smallpox, which could also be used in an attack, Lee said, adding that the island has enough base materials to be processed into some 1 million doses of vaccine against smallpox, despite the fact that this disease was eradicated from Taiwan years ago.
Lee said domestic medical centers and medical institutions at all levels have been urged recently to strengthen their systems of notification in preparation for possible bio-terrorist attacks.
Meanwhile, the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) called a meeting Monday afternoon to discuss drills and contingency measures against possible chemical warfare.
The meeting was attended by officials from the ministries of national defense, interior and transportation and communications in addition to the EPA.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.002 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, closing at 34.557.
The local currency opened Monday at 34.539 and was traded between 34.525 and 34.557.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$336 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNPREDICTABLE FACTORS DEEPEN WORRIES OF TAIWAN'S STOCK INVESTORS

TEXT.P: Investor concern in Taiwan over the United States' led attacks in Afghanistan were reflected in the market Monday as the weighted index of the Taiwan Stock Exchange moved down 65.11 points or 1.8 percent to close at 3,520.35 points.

Although market observers had predicted a downswing should hostilities break out in Afghanistan, analysts at local securities investment houses did not see a great immediate impact on local share prices.

Lin Sheng-chieh, an analyst of Jih Sun Securities Investment Consultants, said Monday that the military action against the Taliban was long anticipated, thus minimizing the shock. However, a prolonged military conflict in the Middle East would further depress the market.
Last month, Taiwan's stock market took a beating after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States and flooding and mudslides hit Taiwan Sept. 17.
An analyst of Yuanta Core Pacific Securities suggested that local investors observe closely the performances of telecommunications, defense-related as well as petrochemical and plastics stocks.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WILL NOT BE ABSENT AT APEC SUMMIT: FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao said Monday that Taiwan will not be absent from the informal leadership conference of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to be held in Shanghai later this month.
He made the remarks while answering questions raised by some legislators at the Foreign and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee of the Legislative Yuan.

Tien noted that President Chen Shui-bian has reiterated his intention of attending the leadership conference out of his goodwill, hoping that he can meet with Beijing's top leader at the international meeting to exchange views on cross-Taiwan Strait issues.
The foreign minister pointed out that as APEC is a very rare and important international forum in which Taiwan is a member, the ROC would not and should not be absent.
He said that his ministry would continue negotiating with Beijing through the channel of the APEC senior officials' meeting on Taiwan's participation in the Oct. 20-21 informal conference.
Beijing has turned down Chen's proposal to attend the Shanghai APEC leadership conference himself.
Last year, the Taiwan president was represented at the APEC conference in Brunei by Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan.
Tien said that the representative to the Shanghai summit is still under consideration, and added that the decision will be announced by the Presidential Office.

Meanwhile, the Taiwan delegation to the APEC ministerial meeting will be jointly headed by two Cabinet ministers -- Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi and Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Chen Po-chih.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT RECEIVES JAPANESE LOWER HOUSE MEMBER

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian Monday received Japanese Lower House member Sadanori Yamanaka, the head of a Japanese delegation for the ROC National Day celebrations.
Chen welcomed the delegation and thanked Yamanaka for his long years of contributions to the promotion of substantive relations between Japan and Taiwan.
Yamanaka, a former director-general of the Japan Defense Agency, is now chairman of the cross-party "Japan-ROC Parliamentarians' Council."

Chen affirmed the council's efforts to win the Japanese government's approval for Taiwan citizens to transit in Japan without visas for 72 hours and recognize the legality of the passports issued by the ROC government. The two countries broke off formal ties in September 1972.

During the reception, Chen told the senior Japanese lawmaker that as a member of the democratic world, the ROC, like Japan, fully supports the U.S.-led military actions against terrorism in Afghanistan.
He said the significance represented by the military actions is "respect for life" and "upholding human civilization," because everyone has the right to avoid fear and the threat of violence.

Chen said that the ROC government, along with other governments of the international community, condemned the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on New York and Washington and support the anti-terrorism military actions by the United States and its allies.
The Japanese Lower House member paid the call on Chen, accompanied by Association of East Asian Relations Chairman Chuang Ming-yao.
Several other Japanese lawmakers and Japan Interchange Association President Toshio Goto will come to Taipei from Tokyo Tuesday to join the Japanese delegation for the Double Ten celebrations.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIANE LEE SAYS SHE'S 'GRATIFIED' TO SEE SUSPENDED LAWMAKER INDICTED

TEXT.P: Legislator Diane Lee of the People First Party (PFP) said Monday she was gratified to learn that the Taipei Prosecutors' Office has publicly indicted legislator Lo Fu-chu for beating her earlier in the year.

The Taipei Prosecutors' Office has also asked the Taipei Municipal Police Bureau to list Lo, an independent lawmaker and the self-proclaimed spiritual leader of the Heavenly Path Alliance gang, as a gangster.
The Taipei police said that upon receiving the request and related information, it will start the process of evidence collection and discussions before it will list anyone as a gangster.
Lee said that she was comforted to know that "there is justice in society, and that the Republic of China is a society bound by legality, and violence will not be repeated."

Lee recalled that she was openly threatened and assaulted in the legislature by her colleague and said that the incident was "incredible." Lee was trying to expose an alledged scandal surrounding the Ching Wen Senior High School earlier this year, adding that "her injuries were small compared with the damage the incident left on the record of Taiwan's democratic development."

Lee, who was rated the most outstanding legislator in a recent magazine survey, also said that the prosecutor in the case conducted several court hearings -- to which she attended -- but that there was nothing that could be done about Lo as he failed to show up for the hearings.
Lo, who buckled under the pressure of public cencure after the incident imposed a six-month suspension from the Legislative Yuan on himself.

Lo is now back in the spotlight for another reason - his son. There is a current dispute in the Finance Committee which surrounds the rule banning any lawmaker from chairing any committee for three sessions in a row.
The rule would prevent Lo's son, Lo Ming-tsai, from chairing the committee, as it would be his third-straight session as convenor -- even though he was elected to the position.

The legislature's plenary session will now handle the matter Tuesday, but the financial committee will not meet until Oct. 15. By that time Lo's self-imposed suspension will have expired and he is presumed to then return to the legislature.

Lo, whose self-imposed suspension will expire on Oct. 12, has not ruled out the possibility of running for the position himself if his son is not allowed to preside again. (By Lilian Wu) EDNITEM ZCZC CEP030 10-08-01 TAIWAN HAS SUFFICIENT COMMODITIES SUPPLIES: AGRICULTURE HEAD

Taipei, Oct. 8 (CNA) Taiwan has sufficient stockpiles of basic commodities to allow the island to feed itself for three to six months, the head of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said Monday.
COA Chairman Chen Hsi-huang said the island will not be caught with a food shortage, at least for three months, should a war break out that affects Taiwan.

In response to growing concerns over the just-initiated U.S.-led military action against the Taliban militia in Afghanistan, which has been accused of sheltering Osama bin Laden, the prime suspect of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States, and bin Laden's al-Qaeda terrorist network, the COA called a contingency meeting Monday to review the country's preparedness.

According to Chen, the nation has a rice stockpile of about 600,000 metric tons. With another 1.44 million metric tons expecting to be incorporated into the existing stockpile by the end of this year, Taiwan will have six months of reserves.
Taiwan has three months in reserve of wheat, soybeans and corn, Chen said.

The only thing that the COA is concerned about currently is that shipping of the commodities, a great majority of them having to be imported from the United States, may be affected by the military actions, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEARCH FOR MISSING F-5F JET FIGHTER CONTINUES

TEXT.P: No trace of the wreckage or crew of a twin-seater F-5F jet fighter which went missing off Taiwan's eastern coast Friday has so far been discovered, military sources said Monday.

The Hualien Coast Guard said although the 72-hour "golden time" for rescue ended 4 p.m. Monday, the search and rescue mission will continue until high-ranking government authorities order a halt to the operation.

Over the past three days, patrol boats and helicopters have conducted an intensive search off Taiwan's east coast for the missing fighter, which lost radio contact 60 nautical miles northeast of the eastern county of Taitung Friday.

Military and coast guard authorities have conducted more than 10 three-hour helicopter search missions and dispatched dozens of warships, patrol boats as well as 200 to 300 fishing boats to search for the ill-fated fighter.

The F-5F fighter jet took off from the Chih Hang Air Base in Taitung, some 300 kilometers southeast of Taipei Friday afternoon on a routine training mission. It disappeared from the air base's radar screen and lost radio contact with the control tower at 3:08 p.m.

Initial investigations by a special Republic of China Air Force investigative team showed that the aircraft might have mistakenly entered an area of cloud cover due to making a wider-than-normal turn during the training flight. The flight was to test an airborne-ground communication facility, military sources said.
Nevertheless, air force sources said, further investigation is needed before the true cause of the accident can be determined.
The missing pilots were identified as Maj. Lee Chih-min, 36, and Capt. Kang Hung-chou, 31.
Over 100 F-5E/Fs remain in service in the ROC Air Force.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNITED STATES MILITARY ACTION TO SPUR INVESTMENT: CEPD CHIEF

TEXT.P: The United States military action in Afghanistan will help spur global investment sentiment by brushing aside many uncertain factors, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman Chen Po-chih said Monday.

Since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York and Washington, investors across the world have been mired in uncertainties, Chen said, adding that should the war against Afghanistan not spread too much, the impact on the global economy will be limited.

The CEPD head, however, pointed out that it is still too early to comment to what extent the war would affect the local economy now that it is impossible for it to regain momentum by the end of this year.

Wu Hui-lin, a researcher at Change Hua Institution for Economic Research, however, predicted that business conditions in the world market would rebound very robustly in the short term, as the new hi-tech war will not last long and "high-risks will bring about high investment returns."
Wu said optimistically that "it is unnecessary to wait until next year for the recovery to take place" on the ground that "vast damage will produce opportunities for construction."

Since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks against the United States, countries across the world have been closely monitoring subsequent developments and have taken measures to cope with possible situations, Wu said, noting that short-term pains will eventually pass and everyday life will get back to normal soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTRY REAFFIRMS SUPPORT FOR U.S. MILITARY ACTIONS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) reaffirmed Monday the ROC government's support of U.S. military actions against Afghanistan's Taliban regime for harboring the prime suspect of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on America.

The MOFA made the remark in a statement it released after receiving written notification from the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) that U.S.-led military strikes have been launched. The AIT is the de facto U.S. embassy in Taiwan that represents U.S. interests locally in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.
The MOFA statement said that the Republic of China is a democratic country that firmly believes in the people's right to be free of fear and violence.

Because of the serious threats that global terrorist activities cause to international peace, humans lives and property, and civilization, the ROC government firmly supports the United States and its campaign against terrorists, MOFA added.

The statement also said that the ROC government has on several occasions openly voiced its support for recent U.N. resolutions against terrorism, and that the government agrees that the actions of the United States and its allies in seeking to punish those responsible for the Sept. 11 tragedy fully comply with the principles of justice in the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT LU MEETS AUSTRALIAN INSPIRATIONAL SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Monday she hopes that Taiwan's handicapped people can learn from visiting Australian inspirational speaker John Coutis in overcoming disabilities and lead a happy, meaningful life.

Lu made the remarks after meeting with Coutis and his wife. "I admire Coutis' fortitude and perseverance in facing up to adversities and his passion in helping despairing persons rekindle their hope and courage to live," Lu said.

Coutis was born with no legs. With a strong will and a desire to help other disabled people, Coutis has often traveled around the world to deliver insightful speeches to cheer up handicapped people in other countries.
Lu also lauded Mrs. Coutis for her devoted, self-sacrificing services to her husband over the years.

Noting that the launch of the U.S.-led military retaliation for the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks has brought about uncertainty in the world, Lu said more love and compassion are needed at this critical moment to encourage mankind's hope for life.
For his part, Coutis said the world is still full of love and hope. "So long as people can faithfully contribute their talent, mankind certainly will have a better tomorrow," an elated Coutis noted.

Meanwhile, Lu said she hopes that Coutis can visit certain central Taiwan townships which were hit hard by a 7.3-magnitude earthquake on Sept. 21, 1999 to help console and inspire many quake victims to stand up from the rubble of their destroyed homes and rebuild new lives and careers with courage and resolve.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WAITING FOR HK RESPONSE TO AIR PACT TALKS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Monday it is waiting for a Hong Kong government response to its proposal for negotiations on renewal of an aviation pact between Taiwan and Hong Kong.

The council, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China and handles affairs concerning Hong Kong and Macau after the two former Western colonies reverted to Beijing rule, was responding to a Hong Kong newspaper report that the MAC had given up its intention to "intervene" in aviation talks.

MAC officials said the current Republic of China statute governing relations with Hong Kong and Macau clearly stipulates that the MAC is the agency in charge of aviation talks with Hong Kong and must take part in all relevant negotiations.
Against this backdrop, the officials said, it is inappropriate for the Hong Kong paper to describe the MAC's handling of the issue as "intervention."

The officials said the MAC has completed all planning work for new aviation pact negotiations. "However, we have so far not received any response from Hong Kong authorities," said an official of the council, who preferred anonymity.
The current Taiwan-Hong Kong aviation pact was signed in 1996 and the two sides originally agreed to review the accord once every five years.

According to its provisions, the accord expired June 13 this year. As Hong Kong authorities were reluctant to negotiate with the MAC, the two sides agreed through talks between their carriers to extend the existing accord to the end of this year.
Under the present pact, Taiwan and Hong Kong can both allow their carriers to operate a total of 121 weekly flights between the two places.

At present, Taiwan's China Airlines can operate 105 flights per week, while EVA Airways can only operate 16 weekly flights. Meanwhile, Hong Kong assigns 100 flights to its Cathay Pacific Airways and 21 flights to Dragon Air.

With more and more Taiwan investors and managers relocating to mainland China, the Taiwan-Hong Kong route has become one of the hottest routes. Both EVA and Dragon Air have long desired to increase their flights on the route, airline sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CENTRAL COMMANDER ISSUES OPEN MESSAGE TO U.S., COALITION FORCES

TEXT.P: The commander-in-chief of the U.S. Central Command said Sunday in a message issued to U.S. and coalition forces just prior to the initiation of strikes against Afghanistan that the goal of this campaign is "neither retaliation nor retribution but victory."

Gen. Tommy R. Franks said in the open letter to U.S. soldiers and coalition partners that on Sunday, the might of the U.S.-led coalition stood poised to "strike at the heart of those who challenged our liberties and brought terror to our shores" on Sept. 11.

Franks said that the president of the United States has ordered the execution of Operation Enduring Freedom, and that the soldiers will soon "enter into harm's way" and strike the first blow in what he said will be "a long and arduous campaign against terrorism."
He said: "Together, we will eradicate global terrorist networks and compel those who provide support to such networks to cease their activities or join the terrorist in their fate."

He added that the terrorists who struck at the symbols of America on Sept. 11 have "grossly miscalculated," and that such a miscalculation has united the American people, their allies and all others who "stand for liberty."
The U.S. Central Command is in charge of U.S. military operations in the Middle East and South Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CONSUMER CONFIDENCE INDEX SLIPS TO TWO-YEAR LOW

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer confidence index for September slipped to a two-year low of 58.09 points in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks against the United States, according to the results of a survey released Monday.

The six indicators of consumer price levels, job opportunities, business climate, the timing for buying stocks and fixed assets, and family incomes in the coming six months, which comprise the consumer confidence index, also dropped to their lowest levels in two years, according to the survey conducted by the Taiwan Research Institute.

The indicator on the timing for the purchase of stocks was most affected by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, falling to 39.2 points from the last such poll, the largest-ever fall of 13.2 points on record, the survey shows.

The indicator on the economic situation among families for the coming six months was also down 5.5 points from the last survey, while the people in Taiwan were also concerned about surges in consumer prices provoked by an outbreak of war in the Middle East, with the indicator falling by 3.6 points.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROTECTION OF FOREIGN INTERESTS IN TAIWAN STRENGTHENED

TEXT.P: The National Police Administration (NPA) instructed police Monday to strengthen protection of foreign personnel stationed in Taiwan following the attacks on Afghanistan by the U.S.-led anti-terrorism coalition.
A provisional command center to cope with emergency situations was been formed at the NPA shortly after the attacks began, according to NPA Director-General Wang Chin-wang.

Wang said that the NPA has asked foreign embassies, consulates, representative offices, residences of foreign ambassadors to the Republic of China, foreign schools, companies and chambers of commerce -- especially those of the United States -- to step up security measures.
In addition, security has been increased at the nation's ports and airports, Wang said.
At present, there are 180 people from the Middle East residing in Taiwan, all of whom hold long-term visas, Wang said, adding that "nothing unusual" has been found.
Wang said the NPA has asked the Bureau of Immigration to pay close attention to a list of terrorists provided by Interpol and the United States to prevent them from entering Taiwan.

The NPA has also instructed police to tighten security to prevent domestic power plants, oil tankers, reservoirs, the Taipei rapid transit system, roads, bridges and government organizations from possible sabotage.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SCHOLAR PREDICTS MAINLAND CHINESE ATTACK ON TAIWAN UNLIKELY

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin predicted in his capacity as a political science professor Monday that mainland China is unlikely to launch a military action against Taiwan in the short term.

Lin said that because the United States has repeatedly stressed that it will not sacrifice Taiwan's interests in exchange for Beijing's support for the U.S-led anti-terrorist coalition, any mainland Chinese military action threatening Taiwan will create "inconsistencies" between Beijing and Washington.

Lin went on to say that because Beijing is currently placing greater emphasis and attention on independence issues in its western territories, it is unlikely to mount an attack against Taiwan at this point.

He said that if the war against Afghanistan's Taliban regime drags on, the U.S. economy will be adversely affected, which would have negative repercussions on mainland China because of its export industries' reliance on the American market.
Under such circumstances, it would be interesting to see if mainland China would still have the extra strength to attack Taiwan, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRC UNLIKELY TO INVADE TAIWAN AT PRESENT: ROC MINISTER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao said Monday that he does not believe mainland China will take advantage of the ongoing U.S.-led military action in Afghanistan to invade Taiwan.
He told the Foreign and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee of the Legislative Yuan that the United States has promised the ROC government more than once that it will not sacrifice Taiwan's security.
Tien noted that the highest-priority task of the United States is the war against terrorism and added that the cross-Taiwan Strait issue is not an urgent matter for Washington at the moment.
The foreign minister pointed out that the U.S. government has guaranteed to Taipei that it will not alter its strategy toward the Asia-Pacific area.

Regarding Beijing's support of the U.S. action against terrorism, Tien said that Washington's view is that Beijing wants to use the opportunity to mend its ties with the Bush administration and to create a goodwill atmosphere for President George Bush's participation in the Oct. 20-21 leadership conference of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum in Shanghai.

In addition to the APEC factor, Tien said that mainland China will not take military action against Taiwan at present because it needs a harmonious environment to devote its full energy toward economic development and to resolving the upcoming leadership issue.
Meanwhile, Mainland Affairs Council Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen also told legislators that the possibility of mainland China using force against Taiwan at present is remote.

She said that after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on New York and Washington, the Taipei authorities had tried through foreign institutions stationed in Taiwan to give Beijing an understanding of Taiwan's hope for maintained stability across the Taiwan Strait.
Nevertheless, Tsai added, Taiwan must take precautionary measures in national defense and foreign relations, as a "misjudgment" by Beijing cannot be excluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION AT LEGISLATURE RESOLVE TO RETURN GOVERNMENT BUDGET

TEXT.P: An umbrella group of opposition parties at the Legislative Yuan demanded Monday the government withdraw what it described as a "flawed" 2002 budget and warned that it will be returned to the Executive Yuan for revamping.

The group made up of the Kuomintang (KMT), the People First Party (PFP), the New Party and the Alliance of Independents claimed at a news conference that the budget has heavily inflated the government revenue and has failed to account for the government's new financial needs.
Legislator Lai Shyh-bao of the New Party said his party will come up with a motion at the Legislative Yuan Tuesday demanding the return of the budget.

The economist-turned-legislator said the 2002 budget fails to accommodate the NT$100 billion (US$2.94 billion) needed to implement the recommendations put forward by the Economic Development Advisory Conference.
It also fails to account for the financial impact on the government's ways and means from the island's imminent entry into the World Trade Organization.

He questioned the government's promise to pump an extra NT$500 billion (US$14.7 billion) into public projects over the next five years to stimulate economic growth, since there is absolutely no trace of this extra spending in the budget.

Although the Executive Yuan may submit a complementary budget to cover the funds for the above agenda, Lai said it will strain the legislative session, which is barely long enough to go through the main budget.
Since the lawmakers will not begin to debate the budget until after the Nov. 2-Dec. 2 recess, Lai said the government still has enough time to conduct a re-draft.
Although his party will propose sending back the budget, it would be preferable for the Executive Yuan to withdraw the budget to "save face," said Lai.

Cheng Long-shui, another New Party lawmaker, said the 2002 budget was prepared on the forecast that the island's economy will expand by more than 5 percent next year, which has already turned out to be pie in the sky.
The government's latest projection, released in August, revised the economic growth to 4.2 percent, while foreign institutes put it at between just 1 percent and 2 percent.
The government's unrealistic economic projection will render its estimates of exports, imports, trade surplus and revenue inaccurate and its budget unfeasible, said Cheng.

Furthermore, he went on, the government needs more money to deal with the financial fallout from the U.S. strikes against Afghanistan and the disaster caused by Typhoon Nari which cut a swathe across the island Sept. 16.
Arguing along the same lines, PFP Legislator Chou Hsi-wei claimed that the 2002 budget has inflated its means by at least NT$100 billion and should be withdrawn and adjusted.

Besides dressing down the government for what they called a fault-infested budget plan, the opposition also excoriated President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Chang Chun-hsiung for their lambasting of the opposition at a DPP campaign rally in Taichung a day earlier.

On that occasion, Chen and Chang blamed the opposition-controlled legislature as the root cause of the island's political unrest, saying the opposition has tried to block the government's agenda at every turn, almost crippling it as a result.
They urged their supporters to return DPP candidates to the legislature in the year-end elections to help rid the country of the political scourge that is the opposition in the legislature.
KMT Legislative Whip Lee Cheng-chung dismissed the claims as a "groundless smear" that has driven the opposition parties to the limit of their tolerance.
Lee said the opposition will turn the budget back to the Executive Yuan to show the premier that his "campaign gambit" had backfired.

Meanwhile, Lin Chuan, head of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics said that although the government's budget is based on an outdated economic growth forecast, the budget is not unfeasible.

Arguing that economic growth is only one of many factors taken into consideration when drafting the budget, Lin cited this year as an example, saying the 2001 budget was made on a growth forecast of 6 percent, but the government's revenue is only NT$3 billion shy of its projection, despite the fact that there is now expected to be negative economic growth.

Lin also said the U.S.-led strikes against the Taliban regime has cast a cloud over the economic prospects for the whole world, the fallout of which has not yet fully sunk in and which the government has no way of getting to grips with in the budget.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT URGES AMERICANS IN TAIWAN TO KEEP CLOSE CONTACT

TEXT.P: The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) urged U.S. citizens in Taiwan Monday to restrict their activities and watch closely the latest developments in the attacks on Afghanistan by the U.S.-led anti-terrorism coalition.

AIT made the call through the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei and also listed the telephone numbers for information (202-647-5225) and fax on demand (202-647-3000) and the U.S. State Department website (www.travel.state.gov).

It said that the attacks on Afghanistan by the U.S.-led anti-terrorism coalition will probably result in strong anti-U.S. retaliation and that all Americans and American institutions in the world should heighten their vigilance against retaliatory attacks.
The AIT added that the U.S. government and the AIT will continue to provide information on the latest developments to Americans in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL LAUREATE CALLS FOR TAIPEI-BEIJING DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh called Monday for a resumption in Taipei-Beijing dialogue and for mankind to unconditionally renounce the use of force.

In an open message, the Nobel laureate in chemistry wrote that there is no reason for the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait to face each other with weapons raised because there is no deep hatred between them.

He said that mankind should not continue to believe in the "superstition" that brute force can resolve disputes, and that there is also no reason for the larger of any two neighbors to bully the smaller one, especially when the two peoples share common ancestry.
Lee said that the leaders in both Taiwan and mainland China should realize that an arms race cannot resolve any outstanding issues between them.

He added that the two sides should first renounce hostilities and follow the spirit of the so-called 1992 consensus of "one China, with each side free to interpret the term separately" in opening full-scale exchanges and dialogue.

Under the trend of globalization, he continued, only through cooperation and the mutual sharing of resources and interests can the two sides of the strait face the fierce competition of the global market.
On a global scale, Lee said, both economic competition and social development should be conducted on the precondition that they will ensure mankind's lasting survival.

He noted that while Western nations were able to acquire great wealth and strength through industrialization, and some countries in Asia, Africa and Latin America were able to start catching up with them, other countries remain mired in famine and poverty.
Lee said that it was only "a matter of time" before these people rose up in defiance to seek "justice" through the most basic and "most barbaric" use of force.

He added that the environment has also begun to react to mankind's over-exploitation, in the form of the greenhouse effect that has been causing changes in global weather patterns and leading to disasters.

Lee therefore called for greater sharing of knowledge and technology to help the majority of the people in the world who are living in poverty, and to help improve the environment in which people and other creatures live.
Because many of these problems cross national boundaries, he said that multinational cooperation is naturally necessary when seeking solutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROL YUAN CHIEF POSTPONES U.S. TRIP

TEXT.P: Republic of China Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien postponed a trip to the United States after the U.S.-led anti-terrorist coalition began strikes in Afghanistan, a Foreign Ministry official said Monday.

The official said that after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on New York and Washington, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) asked Chien to visit Washington and New York to extend Taipei's concern over the incident.
Chien, who formerly served as ROC representative to Washington and as ROC foreign minister, maintains close relationships with the U.S. authorities and with the Chinese communities there.

He was originally scheduled to depart for the United States one month after the Sept. 11 terror attack in New York and Washington, but he put off the trip because of the ongoing war against terrorism in Afghanistan, according to the official.

Meanwhile, Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao met with the representatives to Taiwan from the United States, Britain, Japan and Australia to exchange views on the positions of their governments over the U.S.-led military action against the Taliban regime.
MOFA has also instructed all staff to cancel their vacations for October and to keep a close watch on the development of the situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMY MAY BE HIT HARD IF WAR EXCEEDS 50 DAYS

TEXT.P: A specialist with the Institute for Information Industry (III) said Monday that Taiwan's economy may be affected seriously if the U.S.-led military action against terrorism extends to over 50 days.
However, Chan Wen-nan, director of the III Market Intelligence Center (MIC), said in an interview with CNA that if the war ends within 50 days, the impact on the island's economy may be limited.
He admitted that he could not predict the extent of the impact as it depends on the duration and the scope of the war, as well as the strategies involved.

Chan said that before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on New York and Washington, the MIC estimated that the output of Taiwan's information industry this year would go down 8 percent compared with the preceding year.
After the Sept. 11 incident, he said, the estimate put the extent of the decrease to 15 percent.
If the war continues for more than 50 days, he noted, it would deal a heavy blow to the economy, delaying the island's economic recovery until the third quarter of next year.
Chan said that the MIC will release a new forecast on the war's effect on Taiwan's information industry in the coming days.
A local research institute has recently predicted that Taiwan's real economic growth rate this year will dip to minus 1.9 percent, compared with a 6 percent growth rate one year ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO U.S. REQUESTS FOR FLIGHTS OVER TAIWAN: DEFENSE MINISTRY

TEXT.P: The United States has not requested permission to fly military airplanes through Taiwan's flight information zone, despite the government's promise to open its airspace to U.S. military aircraft, Ministry of National Defense (MND) sources said Monday.

The United States consulted the military authorities about the possibility of flying its military aircraft through the zone before it staged strikes against Afghanistan early Monday and received a positive response, military sources said.

The Taiwan flight information zone bisects the route between Afghanistan and U.S. bases in Okinawa and Guam. If U.S. transport aircraft from the bases want to provide logistical support to their combat forces in the Middle East, they have to fly through the Taiwan information zone.

Most of the U.S. aircraft involved in Monday's bombing of Afghanistan were based on aircraft carriers in the Persian Gulf and the Indian Ocean, while others came from North Atlantic Treaty Organization bases in Europe, making it unlikely that these aircraft would ever need to fly over Taiwan on their bombing missions.
President Chen Shui-bian nonetheless pledged to open the island's airspace to facilitate the U.S. strikes.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT WILLING TO HELP AIRLINES RESOLVE PROBLEMS: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan said Monday that the government is willing to help local airlines resolve problems that have been worsened by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on New York and Washington.
She made the remarks while answering a question raised by Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Chou Jung-tai (Taipei City) at the Legislative Yuan.
Yeh was asked whether she had heard rumors that the local airlines are going to make massive layoffs.

She admitted that she had heard about the rumors and added that if the airlines need government help, her ministry will give the subject serious consideration, whether in the regard of financial assistance or helping airlines reduce the number of flights or merge.
She insisted, however, that the interests of passengers and the fair trade laws should not be sacrificed.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ARMED FORCES WATCHING U.S.-LED ATTACKS CLOSELY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China armed forces are closely watching the attacks on Afghanistan by the U.S.-led anti-terrorism coalition, Ministry of National Defense (MND) spokesman Huang Sui-sheng said Monday.

Huang said that the MND has instructed the armed forces to maintain an upgraded alert, meaning that leave is cancelled for chief officers, while other officers and soldiers can take leave as usual. Under the upgraded alert, troop training is still conducted normally, he said.
Huang said that the armed forces are also keeping an eye on the cross-Taiwan Strait situation and are well prepared to cope with any sudden event.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 9, or the 23rd day of the eighth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1192: King Richard the Lion-hearted abandons the Holy Land after an unsuccessful Crusade, leaving Jerusalem in Muslim hands.
1701: Yale University is founded in New Haven, Connecticut.
1944: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill arrives in Russia to talk with Joseph Stalin in the Third Moscow Conference.
1944: The United States, the United Kingdom, the Soviet Union and the Republic of China promulgate a draft for the Charter of the United Nations.
1958: Pope Pius XII, originally Eugenio Pacelli, dies at the age of 82. He headed the Roman Catholic Church during World War II.
1960: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with the Congo Republic.
1962: Uganda gains formal independence after nearly 70 years of British rule.
1965: ROC Ambassador to the United States and Representative to the United Nations Tsiang Ting-fu dies of liver cancer in New York at the age of 71.
1967: Ernesto "Che" Guevara, the Argentine-born revolutionary who helped Fidel Castro gain power in Cuba, is shot dead after being captured by Bolivian army troops. He was 39.
1967: Indonesia severs diplomatic relations with Communist China.
1970: Dissident Soviet writer Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, winner of the 1970 Nobel Prize for literature, turns down an invitation to Stockholm to attend the award ceremony in December.
1970: Cambodia declares itself the Khmer Republic.
1972: Prime Minister Tupua Tamasese Lealofi IV of Western Samoa arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1973: Mayor Chang Feng-shu of Taipei leaves for Honolulu to attend a council meeting of the Asian and Pacific Area Conference of Mayors.
1974: A two-day post-congress symposium of the first conference of the World Nuclear Medicine Federation opens in Taipei.
1975: Soviet dissident and human rights activist Andrei Sakharov is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives Alberto Nogues Perez, foreign minister of Paraguay.
1983: South Korean President Chun Doo Hwan escapes unharmed when 17 members of his entourage, including Foreign Minister Lee Bum Suk, are killed in a bomb blast in Rangoon.
1984: A famous Cantonese opera performer from mainland China, Hung Hung, 40, announces her defection in a press conference held at the Free China Relief Association in Taipei.
1986: The Executive Yuan passes the Program for Taroko National Park, in which NT$4 billion is to be invested in developing the park over six years.
1989: The Mainland Affairs Task Force approves the first draft of the Temporary Provisions Governing Relations between the People of the Mainland Region and Taiwan Region.
1998: Italian Prime Minister Romano Prodi's government resigns after losing its 31st vote of confidence.
1999: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui urges mainland China to promote relations with Taiwan based on a "special state-to-state relationship."
2000: Haitian President Rene Preval and his wife, leading an official delegation, arrive in Taipei to attend celebration activities marking the ROC's Double-Ten National Day.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of dignity, noble seriousness, order and regularity: qualities necessary for the exercise of self-respect."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Tuesday are as follows:
The China Times:
U.S., British forces launched another wave of air strikes on Afghanistan.
The United Daily News:
U.S. planes and missiles carried out a second round of attacks on Osama bin Laden and his Taliban protectors.
The Liberty Times:
Bush said Operation 'Enduring Freedom" was designed to disrupt the use of Afghanistan as a base for terrorist action.
The Taiwan Daily:
In a stick-and-carrot strategy, U.S. planes dropped food for ordinary Afghans, already hungry for drought.
The Central Daily News:
Thirty sites hit in opening wave of U.S.-led attacks, says Bush.
The China Post:
U.S. begins second wave of attacks.
The Taiwan News:
U.S. warns U.N. of possible military strikes against other nations and groups.
The Taipei Times:
U.S. launches second round of attacks.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MILITARY READY WITH CONTINGENCY PLANS: DEFENSE MINISTRY

TEXT.P: A spokesman for the Republic of China's Ministry of National Defense said Tuesday that the ROC military has prepared various contingency plans to respond to any possible emergencies in the Taiwan Strait.

However, intelligence shows that the mainland Chinese armed forces have not conducted any unusual activities since U.S.-led forces began their attacks on Afghanistan, Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng said at a routine news conference.

He said that the ROC military will continue to closely monitor the situation in Afghanistan and in the Taiwan Strait, adding that leave has been suspended for the commanding generals and commanding officers of all echelons of the ROC armed forces.

Huang said that the defense ministry has instructed all forces to be on heightened alert and to be on guard against any possible surprise attacks from the outside or any sudden unrest from within the country.
He added that the United States has not made any requests to use ROC military bases in its war against terrorism.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTRY STEPS UP EFFORTS TO MAINTAIN SOCIAL ORDER

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice announced Tuesday that it has instructed all district prosecutor offices to step up their investigations into the recent surge in kidnapping, ransom and currency counterfeiting cases in order to maintain social order.

In support of the U.S. government's campaign against terrorism, Taiwan's district prosecutors have been charged with the task of preventing local terrorists and criminal organizations from taking advantage of the times to carry out any illegal activities.
The ministry announced that it has established a special task force to put a stop to the circulation of counterfeit bank notes.
It has also ordered its prosecutors to fully investigate any cases of organized crime interfering with the year-end elections, which it said are another form of terrorism.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 98.58 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Tuesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 98.58 points to close at 3,618.93.
Market turnover amounted to NT$36.12 billion (US$1.05 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 98.58 points to close at 3,618.93.

The bourse opened at 3,561.16 and continued to go up later due to a strong rebound in electrical shares following purchases made by government funds. The index fluctuated between 3,618.93 and 3,535.2 during trading.

A total of 1.74 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$36.12 billion (US$1.05 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.3 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$26.68 billion (US$0.77 billion).
Only one the eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff shares moving down 1.2 percent.

The other major categories posted gains, with electrical shares moving up the most at 4.4 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1.1 percent, plastics and chemical shares and pulp and paper issues, both at 0.9 percent, bank and insurance shares at 0.7 percent, and construction stocks and textile issues, both at 0.6 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 385 to 139, with 96 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher on Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for October moved up 103 points to close at 3,615, with 14,637 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for November rose 95 points to finish at 3,615, with 224 contract transactions, while December futures gained 78 points to finish at 3,609, with eight contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 3,512 for October, 3,520 for November, 3,531 for December, 3,559 for next March, and 3,550 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
October TE futures moved up 8.2 points to close at 168.7, with 4,062 contract transactions, while November TE futures increased 7.65 points to finish at 168.6, with 58 contracts traded.
December TE futures gained 5.9 points to close at 165.8, with only one contract traded, while next March TE futures rose 8.2 points to close at 166.2, with four contract transactions.
Next June TE futures moved up 8.2 points to finish at 167.35, with 11 contracts changing hands. No transactions were recorded for other months.
October TF futures gained 4.8 points to finish at 594.8, with 1,385 contract transactions, while November TF futures increased 9 points to close at 595, with 21 contracts traded.
Next March TF futures rose 4.8 points to finish at 591, with 20 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T APPROVES ADDITIONAL TYPES OF AGRICULTURAL INVESTMENT IN CHINA

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) announced Tuesday that over 200 additional types of agricultural investment in mainland China will no longer need to be approved on a case-by-case basis.

Under previous COA guidelines, only 223 types of agricultural investment in the mainland were given the automatic green light by the government. Over 1,100 other types fell under the category requiring case-by-case assessments.
Another 10 types of agricultural products remain on the COA's restricted list under the new guidelines.

The COA noted that most of the newly approved types of investment are processed product-related or fishing-related because recent COA evaluations determined that the impact of approving such kinds of investment will be minimal on Taiwan's own agricultural sector.

The COA began conducting assessments on the possible effects of Taiwan and mainland China's imminent entry into the World Trade Organization on the domestic agriculture industry after the government agreed to ease restrictions on local investment in the mainland across various industries.
The COA has also established a special task force to routinely evaluate the further easing of restrictions, approximately once every six months.

According to COA figures, a total of 4,108 agricultural investments in mainland China by Taiwan businesses have been approved since such investment in the mainland was legalized in 1992. The total value of these investments is about US$2.15 billion.
From January to August, Taiwan imported a total of US$320 million worth of agricultural products from mainland China and exported US$54 million worth of agricultural products in return.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC V.P. CALLS FOR PEOPLE TO RALLY BEHIND GOV'T IN `DIFFICULT TIMES'

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu called for the people Tuesday to rally behind the government regardless of political party affiliations to face the "difficult situations" within and outside the country together.

At a meeting of the National Women's League of the Republic of China that was held to commemorate ROC National Day, which falls on Oct. 10, Lu said that the league should be prepared to participate in international humanitarian relief missions in the "global war" against terrorism.
She said that because Taiwan could also be affected by what she called "a war beyond boundaries," the people of Taiwan should be conscious of a global crisis and be thoroughly prepared.
In the war against terrorism, she said that the people should "rally for peace" instead of "weeping for war."

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.002 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Tuesday, closing at 34.555.
The local currency opened Tuesday at 34.542 and was traded between 34.540 and 34.558.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$166 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: LATEST JIANG REMARKS SHOW NO CHANGE IN MAINLAND POLICY TOWARD TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's latest remarks on relations across the Taiwan Strait show no fundamental changes in Beijing's policy toward Taiwan, an official of the main opposition Kuomintang said Tuesday.

Chang Jung-kung, director of the KMT's mainland affairs department, said Jiang reaffirmed Beijing's insistence on the so-called "one China" policy in his speech delivered at a rally in Beijing Tuesday to mark the 90th anniversary of the Revolution of 1911, which led to the overthrow of the Ching Dynasty and the establishment of the Republic of China.

In his speech, Jiang said as the world is undergoing profound changes, the Chinese race should stand united to face up to all new challenges. He further said since the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait are all Chinese, they should sit down to talk under the "one China" principle.

Jiang stressed that the "one China" principle is the bedrock for developing cross-strait relations and realize peaceful reunification of the two sides. While reiterating Beijing's intention to promote peaceful unification, Jiang also did not hesitate to demonstrate Beijing's firm resolve to block Taiwan's movement toward independence.
Commenting on Jiang's speech, Chang said, it indicates that mainland China still hopes to forge rapprochement with the people of Taiwan and their government under the "one China" principle.

Ten years ago, then-mainland Chinese President Yang Shangkun also delivered a speech to mark the 1911 Revolution on the eve of the ROC's Double Ten National Day. In his address, Yang sternly criticized Taiwan's resistance to Beijing's call for unification talks and warned Taiwan of disastrous consequences if it declared independence.
In contrast, Chang said, Jiang didn't resort to such bellicose rhetoric. In his view, Chang said, Jiang's "soft" approach was mainly aimed at winning Taiwan people's hearts.
Touching on some Taiwan officials' forecast that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait may resume talks next spring, Chang said such prediction is meaningless.
Unless the two sides can compromise on their basic stands, Chang said, the possibility of resuming cross-strait talks in the near future is slim, if not nil.

"If mainland China would not give up its 'one China' principle and the ROC's current Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-led government would not adjust its attitude, cross-strait talks are not expected to resume any time soon," Chang observed.

The DPP government has on many occasions said Beijing's "one China" principle is unacceptable because it downgrades the ROC to a local-level government under the People's Republic of China -- mainland China's official title.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONDURAS GIVES NO-VISA TREATMENT TO ROC NATIONALS

TEXT.P: The government of Honduras agreed to allow Republic of China nationals to enter the country without a visa effective from Oct. 1, and ROC citizens can stay up to 90 days at a time, the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Tuesday.
The ministry said that except for Belize, the Dominican Republic, Paraguay, and El Salvador, all other ROC allies in central and south America have accorded visa-free treatment to ROC nationals.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEPTEMBER STOCK TRANSACTION TAX REVENUE FALLS TO SIX-YEAR LOW

TEXT.P: Stock transactions taxes reached NT$2.3 billion in September, the lowest level since April 1996, the Ministry of Finance reported.
The amount also represents a 68 percent fall compared with last year's September figure, the largest-ever percentage fall since March 1999.

Affected by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in Washington and New York and the destructive typhoons which swept through Taiwan, a bearish sentiment prevailed in the local stock market last month. The weighted index, the local bourse's major gauge, fell below the 3,500-point mark.

The daily trading volume averaged NT$3.85 billion in September, down from the previous levels of NT$7 billion to NT$8 billion, according to ministry statistics. It stressed that a three-day closure because of the terrorist attacks in the United States and the typhoons also contributed to the drop in tax revenues.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR OPPOSITION LEADERS FAIL TO SHOW AT PRESIDENT'S SECURITY MEETING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presided over the first meeting of a special task force on contingency plans for national security in the wake of the terrorist attacks in the United States and said that he regretted that leaders from the main opposition parties declined to attend.
Chen said that despite the fact that the meeting did not include major opposition figures, it was still a success and could be a model for future discussions on national security.

The president said that to solicit support from all parties, he had invited Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng and the heads of the three opposition parties -- Chairman Lien Chan of the Kuomintang, Chairman James Soong of the People First Parry, and convener Hsieh Chi-ta of the New Party -- for a briefing held at the Presidential Office by the special task force on the impact on Taiwan of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on America.

The task force, which is comprised of national security staff and government heads in military, foreign affairs, cross-strait issues, and the fields of economics and finance, reported on the government's contingency plans and national security measures.

The president said that regrettably, except for Legislative Yuan President Wang, Chairman Frank Hsieh of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, and Tsai Hao, convener of the Independent Legislators Alliance, the three leaders of the major opposition parties did not show up, although they were asked to attend.
This was the first time that national security staff in a task force have reported to any opposition leaders.

However, Chen said the meeting was still significant in that it attempted to form a mechanism for the government to work with all the major political parties to discuss contingency plans on major security issues of the nation.

Chen stressed that the main purpose of the briefing was to have the ruling and opposition parties as well as leaders from the legislature brought up to speed on developments in the policies of the government so they would understand how the government is responding to the changing world situation.
The president said he hoped that this would be the first step toward creating an atmosphere where all political party leaders can jointly discuss major challenges to the nation.

No country is isolated from the impact of the terrorist attacks in the United States and the subsequent air strikes by the United States and Britain on Afghanistan, the president said, adding that no political party or individual in Taiwan is immune from events unfolding on the world stage.
Therefore, the president said that faced with the ever-changing global situation, he has instructed government agencies to come up with short-, middle-, and long-term contingency plans.
But he said that even the best plans need to be understood and accepted by the public and their elected officials.
Legislative Yuan President Wang said that he appreciated being invited to the meeting and said that it had a positive impact on the political landscape.

Participants at the briefing also included Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Vice Premier Lai In-jaw, Minister of National Defense Wu Shih-wen, Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming, National Security Council Secretary-General Ting Yu-chou, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao, Mainland Affairs Council Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen and Secretary-General to the Executive Yuan Chiou I-jen.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN POPULATION AGING MORE RAPIDLY THAN ANTICIPATED

TEXT.P: Taiwan's elderly population is growing faster than official estimates and the government is acting to address the issue, according to a recent report from the Council for Economic Planning and Development.
As a result of a sharp drop in the country's birth rate, the council said that it will adjust its demographic policy to cope with the situation.

Taiwan's elderly population accounted for 8.6 percent of the country's total populace, about 2 million people, by the end of 2000. The number of the country's elderly population -- people aged over 65 -- had already hit 7 percent in 1993, making Taiwan an "elderly society" as defined by the United Nations.

The council estimated that the number could climb to 24 percent by 2051 and warned that an earlier-than-expected negative growth of the country's population will have a serious impact on its economic development. The council said that how to promote the development of social welfare will be high on the agenda of its future demographic policy to minimize the effects on younger generations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MISSION IN USA KEEPS CLOSE CONTACTS WITH U.S. OVER WAR
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 8 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China representative office in Washington has made intensive contacts with the White House, the Department of State and congressional leaders after the U.S.-led forces began strikes in Afghanistan Sunday.
Officials from the ROC mission transmitted the latest information about the war to the Taipei authorities and informed the U.S. side of President Chen Shui-bian's position.
The officials said that Chen's statement supporting the U.S.-led military actions against terrorism has been conveyed to the administrative branch, Congress and the media.

Chen asserted that as a member of the international community and the democratic world, the ROC supports the anti-terrorism actions taken by the United States, and pledges its support for all anti-terrorism resolutions adopted by the United Nations.
The ROC government has also announced that if the U.S.-led military actions require use of the ROC's air space, it will provide timely and necessary assistance.
It has also indicated its willingness to provide assistance regarding resettlement and relief for Afghan refugees.

The ROC mission has informed the U.S. side that the ROC government has taken necessary steps to tighten protection of the security of U.S. citizens in Taiwan and to prevent any possible reprisal by terrorists.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TRADE DELEGATION IN UKRAINE SECURES US$ 1.17 MILLION IN ORDERS

TEXT.P: A Taiwan trade promotion delegation organized by the Ministry of Economic Affairs in Ukraine cinched US$1.17 million in orders Monday, according to reports from the delegation.

The delegation, which includes 60 manufacturers in metals, hand tools, machine equipment, textiles, automobile and motorcycle parts and components, computer peripherals and stationery, arrived in Ukraine Monday.

The delegation started the two-day promotion Monday, securing orders of US$1.17 million on the first day. The delegation estimated the potential still exists for an additional US$12 million in orders.
Delegation leaders called on Victor Vanovsky, deputy chairman of the Ukrainian Chamber of Commerce Monday and both sides signed an agreement to promote trade and exchanges.

The Taiwan delegation also conveyed the wishes of Taiwan manufacturers that Ukraine lower its import tariffs on Taiwan products and give them preferential treatment, as well as increasing exchanges of trade officials between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL CANCELS SEVERAL FLIGHTS FROM TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The decrease in bookings in the wake of the U.S.-led anti-terrorist attacks has forced Taiwan's China Airlines (CAL) to cancel several flights from Taipei, CAL sources said Tuesday.

The previous national flag carrier canceled eight flights Monday from Taipei, including Taipei-Los Angeles and Taipei-San Francisco, two of its most lucrative flights, and canceled three outbound flights Tuesday from Taipei, including Taipei-Sydney, Taipei-Phuket Island and Taipei-Hakodate flights.
Because CAL had no flights from Taipei to Los Angeles and San Francisco on Mondays, there were no return flights to Taipei from the two U.S. cities on Tuesdays.

On Wednesdays, CAL will cancel its Taipei-New York, Taipei-Ho Chi Minh City and Taipei-Bali Island flights. On Thursdays, it will cancel Taipei-Manila, Taipei-Ho Chi Minh City, Taipei-Phuket Island and three Taipei-Hong Kong and three Taipei-San Francisco flights.
Another Taiwanese airlines, EVA Air, has begun from Oct. 1 to cancel 17 flights per week. Of the 17 flights, seven are Taipei-Los Angeles flights.
Singapore Airlines has begun Oct. 7 to decrease the number of its Kaohsiung-Singapore flights per week to three from five, while the number of its Taipei-Singapore flights per week remains unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT HAILS FORMOSA PLASTICS GROUP

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed admiration Tuesday for Taiwan's petrochemical giant, Formosa Plastics Corp. (FPC), and hopes that his administration can emulate the FPC's working spirit for the country's economic development.
Chen made the remarks during a visit to the construction site of Taiwan's sixth naphtha cracker plant, an investment of FPC, in Yunlin County, southern Taiwan.

It was the third time that Chen had visited the plant, which is expected to be completed in 2003. Chen said his frequent visits represents his respect for FPC Chairman Y.C. Wang and his admiration of the enterprise's efficient operations strategy.

The president said that he had adopted FPC's operations strategy in elevating the administrative efficiency of the Taipei City Government when he was mayor, but while he planned to do so in the Central Government when he was president, the related budget was canceled by the legislature.
He said he hopes the new legislature, that will be formed after the year-end elections, can support his plan.
Chen said that the FPC faced many challenges building the plant on reclaimed land and showed a spirit that the whole country should learn from.

Chen also talked about the "no haste, be patient" policy of restricting Taiwan's investment in mainland China -- a policy that the chairman of FPC is opposed to. Chen said his administration did not eliminate the policy, but rather revised it to an "active opening, effective management" strategy after gauging the international situation and cross-strait economic and trade ties.

After listening to a brief report about the plant, Chen said that the naphtha cracker plant is being built at a time when global economic prospects are not good, but with its efficient cost-control strategy, advanced equipment and production technology, the plant will be considered one of the best in the world when it goes online.

The FPC has invested NT$470 billion (US$13.60 billion) in the first and second stages of the construction of the plant, which will see 45 petrochemical material sub-plants and house an industrial port. The plant will be completed in 2003 after an additional investment of NT$110 billion (US$3 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: RECESSION SQUEEZES GOVERNMENT TAX INCOME

TEXT.P: The government's tax income has posted a noticeable fall in September amid a recession which has swept businesses in all sectors, the Ministry of Finance reported Tuesday.
The national coffers levied total revenues of NT$78.1 billion in September alone, down 25.7 percent from the level posted in the corresponding month a year ago, ministry statistics show.

Corporate taxes registered a fall of 15.1 percent year-on-year, while land value increment taxes and stock transaction taxes also dropped by 73.3 percent and 68.3 percent, to NT$2 billion and NT$2.3 billion, respectively, during the same period.

Calculating the local bourse's daily trading volume at NT$45 billion for the coming three months, the ministry forecast that stock transaction taxes might fall short of the official target by NT$34.2 billion for the whole of 2001.
