The ministry also estimated that the country's overall tax income this year will reach 93 percent of the government target, representing a NT$95 billion shortfall.
As of the end of September, the national coffers registered NT$1.02 trillion in tax revenues since the beginning of this year, a decrease of 7.9 percent from the same period of 2000.

At the same time, the central government took in NT$748.4 billion for the first nine months of 2001, a drop of 6.5 percent from the year-earlier level. Local governments registered an aggregate tax income of NT$275.6 billion, down 11.4 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN ERROR MIGHT BE REASON BEHIND MISSING F-5F FIGHTER JET

TEXT.P: Human error might be the main explanation for the a Republic of China Air Force F-5F jet fighter that went missing last week, a senior officer at Air Force General Headquarters (AFGH) said Tuesday.
Chin Ping-ho, chief of the AFGH's flight safety division, said the fighter might have crashed into the sea after its two pilots became disoriented while flying in an area of cloud cover.

Speaking at a news conference at the Ministry of National Defense, Chin said the AFGH team investigating the accident had ruled out the possibility that the incident was caused by either a mechanical failure, bird strike or a loss of consciousness of its pilots.

From a wingman's recounting of the situation at the time of the incident and an extensive study of all other available data, Chin said, the investigative team had tentatively concluded that the plane mistakenly entered the cloud cover while carrying out a difficult attitude recovery, leading to the pilots' disorientation and the crash of the plane.

As for why the aircraft strayed into the cloud cover -- an off-limits weather condition for jet fighters -- Chin said the investigative team concluded that the pilots might have made a wider-than-normal turn while conducting the maneuver.
The F-5F fighter took off Friday afternoon from the Chih Hang air base in the eastern county of Taitung, some 300 km southeast of Taipei, on a routine training mission.
A wingman saw the plane fly into the cloud cover at 3:08 p.m. about 60 nautical miles northeast of Taitung and then lost sight of and contact with the plane.
Military and coast guard authorities launched an extensive search off Taiwan's east coast for the missing twin-seater.

Over the following four days, military and coast guard authorities conducted more than 10 three-hour helicopter search missions and dispatched dozens of warships and patrol boats, as well as 200 to 300 fishing boats to search for the ill-fated fighter.
"But so far, no trace of the wreckage or crew of the plane has been discovered," Chin said.
He said that although the 72-hour "golden time" for rescue ended at 4 p.m. Monday, the search and rescue mission will continue for some time.
Under current military regulations, a serviceman who has gone missing for six months can be deemed as having died.
The missing pilots were identified as Maj. Lee Chih-min, 36, and Capt. Kang Hung-chou, 31.
Over 100 F-5E/Fs remain in service in the ROC Air Force.

Meanwhile, the Hualien Coast Guard discovered two MK25 signal flares off the eastern county of Hualien Tuesday. But military authorities said the missing aircraft was not equipped with such articles. At present, the navy's S-70c helicopters are equipped with such flares.

DOC.HEADLINE: RETAIL SALES REACH US$ 91 BILLION IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The transaction volume of Taiwan's retail industry totaled NT$3,129 billion (US$91 billion) last year, a growth of 7.2 percent over 1999, according to government statistics.

The statistics released by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show that during the last five years, Taiwan's retail industry saw an average 7.2 percent growth in transaction volume.
A DGBAS official noted that the performance of the retail industry is strongly linked to economic prospects.

The official pointed out that Taiwan's economic growth declined from 5.7 percent in the first quarter of 1998 to 3.4 percent in the fourth quarter as a result of the Asian financial crisis at that time. Consequently, the growth in transaction volume of Taiwan's retail sector dropped from 11.3 percent to 5.3 percent in the same year.
Not until the shadow of Asian financial crisis faded in 1999 did the growth of Taiwan's retail transaction volume surge to 9.4 percent.
The DGBAS official added that the retail transaction volume not only represents the market demand, but also reflects consumption.
He said that during the last five years, the retail transaction volume accounted for approximately 50 percent of private sector consumption.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER DEFENDS COLLEAGUE-FATHER

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lo Ming-tsai filed for a constitutional interpretation Tuesday on the justification for the Taipei Prosecutor's Office request to city police to have his legislator father listed as a hooligan.
Lo claimed that the prosecutor's office move to have independent Legislator Lo Fu-chu listed as a hooligan based on the Hooligan Prosecution and Wipe-out Act was unconstitutional.
The Taipei Prosecutors' Office had also prosecuted the elder Lo a day earlier for a brutal physical attack on People First Party Legislator Diane Lee.

The junior Lo lambasted the prosecutors for "violating the Republic of China Constitution." He called the move an act of "judiciary white terror" and claimed the judiciary system was illegally intervening in the legislative system.
Wearing a face mask, the junior Lo staged a rambling and choking filibuster, occupying the interpretation podium and completely paralyzing the morning session.

The Taipei Prosecutors' Office did not take any action against the senior Lo -- widely recognized as a thug because of his frequent public assaults on his colleagues at the Legislative Yuan -- until Monday, although he beat PFP Legislator Diane Lee in March.

Lo, who buckled under the pressure of public censure after the March incident and imposed a six-month suspension from the Legislative Yuan upon himself, stirred up a new storm at the Legislative Yuan a few days ago when he ranted and raved at members of the Legislative Yuan Finance Committee who were discussing the rule banning any lawmaker from chairing any committee for three sessions in a row.
The rule prevents the junior Lo from chairing the committee, as it would be his third consecutive session as convenor -- even though he was elected to the position.
Lo, whose self-imposed suspension will expire Oct. 12, has not ruled out the possibility of running for the position himself if his son is not allowed to preside again.

Nine other lawmakers, including the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)'s Chang Ching-fang and independent legislators Chao Yung-ching, Chu Hui-liang and Liao Hsieh-kuang, have also accused Lo of blackmail and intimidation.
DPP Party Whip Tsai Huang-liang later denied that the move to have the elder Lo listed as a gangster is unconstitutional and an example of "the judiciary intervening in the legislative system."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STEPS UP PREPAREDNESS AGAINST POSSIBLE BIOLOGICAL ATTACK

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Tuesday it is cooperating with the Department of Health (DOH) to craft a comprehensive plan to cope with biological terrorist attack.

The MND made the remarks in response to growing public concern about possible biological terrorist attacks after U.S. and British forces launched air strikes against the Taliban regime in Afghanistan in retaliation for its protection of Osama bin Laden, the suspected mastermind of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York and Washington.

Wu Shao-pei, director of the MND's medical and health service division, said that although the Republic of China military at present may be not capable of coping with a large-scale biological attack, it can handle small-scale assaults.
Wu said the MND is working together with the DOH to hammer out medical care and treatment plans in case Taiwan is attacked with biological weapons.
At the moment, Wu said, the MND and the DOH are focusing their efforts on dealing with attacks by the more common biological weapons such as anthrax, clostridium botulism and smallpox.

Wu said that the DOH has formed a special task force composed of officials from the department's Bureau of Medical Affairs, Bureau of Pharmaceutical Affairs and the Center for Disease Control, to counter possible biological terrorist attacks. The DOH has also appointed eight local hospitals to accommodate victims of biological attacks.

Wu said the DOH has commissioned the military-run National Defense Medical College to offer training courses on how to cope with biological attacks. "The educational program is scheduled to start in November," he said, adding that relevant DOH and military staff members at various levels will all take part in the training workshop.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPUTEX TAIPEI 2002 TO KICK OFF IN JUNE

TEXT.P: Computex Taipei 2002, the annual international computer exhibition, will take place June 3-7, 2002 at the Taipei World Trade Center and the Taipei International Conference Center, organizers said Tuesday.
Categories on display will include computer software and hardware, peripherals, components and parts, telecommunication materials, Internet products and multimedia computers.
Organizers said manufacturers who intend to take part in the exhibition must register on the Internet by logging on to www.tca.org.tw.computex from Oct. 25 through Nov. 6.
They can then fill in application forms printed from the website and mail them to organizers from Nov. 7-9 to complete the registration process.

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC LEADERSHIP CONFERENCE EXPECTED TO APPROVE `SHANGHAI ACCORD'

TEXT.P: The informal leadership conference of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to be held in Shanghai Oct. 20-21 is expected to approve a "Shanghai accord," an economic specialist said Tuesday.
Wu Rong-i, president of the Taiwan Institute for Economic Research, said that the main theme of the 2001 APEC meeting is "participation, cooperation and promotion for common prosperity."

He said that the focus of the discussions will center on the expansion of globalization and the welfare of the new economy, as well as promotion of trade and investment and ensuring sustainable growth.
Wu went on to say that leaders from APEC member economies, including U.S. President George Bush, are expected to issue a declaration approving a "Shanghai accord."
As the U.S.-led military actions against terrorism are being waged in Afghanistan, he added that the leadership conference will also discuss how to cooperate to deal with terrorism.

Meanwhile, Hsu Tsun-tzu, an official with the Chinese-Taipei APEC Research Center, said that issues connected with the regional trade agreement (RTA) will be among the important topics of the upcoming meeting.
Taiwan has not yet joined the RTA and Hsu said that Taiwan should act to become a member of the RTA, as it would provide a wider space for Taiwan to interact with other member countries.
The Taiwan delegation to the APEC ministerial meeting will be jointly headed by Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi and Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Chen Po-chih.

However, the representative to the leadership conference has not yet been decided. Last year, President Chen Shui-bian was represented by Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan at the APEC summit in Brunei.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN, MAINLAND CHINESE BRIDES FINISH `GROWTH CAMP' PROGRAMS

TEXT.P: More than 100 foreign and mainland Chinese brides attended a joint commencement ceremony Tuesday after completing separate three-month "growth camp" training programs aimed at helping them adapt to Taiwan's lifestyle.
They were the first groups of foreign and mainland Chinese brides to have taken part in the Taipei City Government-sponsored training workshops.

A total of 73 women from Indonesia, Vietnam, Thailand and other Southeast Asian countries, together with 70 mainland Chinese women, attended the colorful and fun-filled ceremony in the company of their Taiwan husbands and other family members.

During the ceremony, 12 Southeast Asian brides sang a Mandarin Chinese pop song, to great acclaim. Meanwhile, seven mainland Chinese brides also received an enthusiastic response for a Xinjiang folk dance performance.

Song Yang, a bride from mainland China's Hubei Province, said she has been married to a Taipei citizen for 10 years. "In the past, I felt I was like dust and that nobody in Taiwan was concerned about me. The `growth camp' program has helped make me feel at home here. It has enabled me to feel the concern and friendship of local society. I really appreciate the city government for its sponsorship of the program," she said.
The workshops offer Mandarin Chinese and Taiwanese language courses, along with courses in cooking, local customs, Taipei city history and sightseeing spots, as well as other practical lessons.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou presented commencement certificates to all 143 "Taiwanese daughters-in-law." He described Taiwan as an immigrant society that always welcomes new immigrants. "We hope all foreign and mainland Chinese brides can open their hearts and integrate themselves into local society as soon as possible," Ma said, adding that the city government will continue to sponsor the programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN INCLUDED IN LEGISLATORS-AT-LARGE NOMINATION LIST

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) has decided to include its chairman, James Soong, at No. 11 on its list of legislator-at-large candidates for the year-end legislative and local government chief elections, a party official said Tuesday.
PFP Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung said that Soong has promised to be a "contributing power" in the new legislature to promote political and congressional reforms.

A total of 41 legislators-at-large are expected to be elected in the Dec. 1 elections for the new legislature, which will have 225 seats, according to a system of proportional representation among the various political parties.
Soong was originally not included on the PFP's list because the party hopes that he can focus his efforts on leading the party.

However, his absence from the list aroused strong dissent among the PFP supporters, prompting the party to rethink the decision and party officials then decided to let Soong have the place of Legislator Robert Hsu, who rejected his nomination.

Chang noted that Soong, a former Taiwan provincial governor, did not reject his original inclusion on the list, but out of consideration of the scarcity of the seats offered to legislators-at-large, he decided to give way to other PFP candidates.

Chang stressed that Soong's inclusion does not mean the party is mired in crisis for the election, but rather that Taiwan is slipping backwards too much and needs a "professional team" to resolve the crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SETS UP GROUP TO FACILITATE GLOBAL REFUGEE RELIEF EFFORTS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) decided Tuesday to establish a Humanitarian Relief Committee to help facilitate Taiwan's relief efforts to refugees around the world.

The work of the committee will be aimed at consolidating resources from all aspects of Taiwan society to provide emergency relief, including medical care and supplies of commodities, to refugees around the world, said sources from the DPP Central Executive Committee (CEC).

In a statement released that day concerning Taiwan's reaction to the attacks by the U.S.-led anti-terrorism coalition on the Taliban in Afghanistan that began Monday, the CEC said the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States that toppled New York City's World Trade Center and destroyed part of the Pentagon in Washington, D.C., leaving more than 5,000 people dead or missing, allowed people around the world to witness terrorism and the adverse impact of war on mankind.

The DPP committee urged the Taiwan public to adopt an esprit de corps at this juncture of global volatility and throw their full support behind the government to carry out tasks to the greatest possible interest of the country.

Meanwhile, the statement gave President Chen Shui-bian a thumbs up for his convening of an emergency national security meeting Monday soon after the start of the reprisal military action in Afghanistan, whose Taliban regime plays host to Osama bin Laden, the prime suspect behind the Sept. 11 attacks.
The committee said the meeting explicitly made known Taiwan's anti-terrorism stance and the government's determination to protect the country's national security.

The contingency measures that were issued by Chen during the meeting concerning protection of the nation's expatriates and students living abroad, ways to maintain normal operation of financial and economic systems and measures to closely monitor the cross-Taiwan Strait situation, have helped stabilize society and secured national interests to the greatest possible extent, the statement noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMCHAM MARKS 50TH FOUNDING ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: The American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taiwan held a party Tuesday to mark the 50th anniversary of its founding.

The party, which was held in a subdued style in memory of the victims of the recent terrorist attacks on New York and Washington, was attended by several local officials, including Deputy Presidential Secretary-General Chien You-hsin, Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao, Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Chen Po-chih and Government Information Office Director-General Su Tzen-ping.

Tien delivered a speech to voice the Republic of China government's support for AmCham's performance. He also reiterated the government's firm support for the ongoing U.S.-led military actions against terrorism.

AmCham President Richard Henson told the gathering that although the United States is now in a state of war, the situation will take a turn for the better. He added that the world's economy will also make an eventual upturn.
AmCham also presented a set of proposals to the Taipei government, urging it to improve the economic environment for foreign businessmen in Taiwan.

It advised Taiwan to develop its service industry, use its advantageous position to handle cross-Taiwan Strait ties, not discriminate against foreign businessmen, create an environment for free personnel and service interflows, revise the labor standard law and company law, push forward financial reform, invest more in economic and construction projects, improve bidding procedures for public projects and develop the island into an operational center.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT `EAGER TO HELP STABILIZE' TAIWAN POLITICS

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui expressed his eagerness during a television interview Tuesday to help stabilize politics in Taiwan.
Lee said that although he is old, he is full of passion for the nation and is willing to help stabilize the nation's politics.

He said that "just like a father, it is his responsibility to discipline the children when they are not behaving well," adding that his love for Taiwan has never wavered and the only thing he is constantly concerned about is seeing Taiwan's politics stabilized.
Lee made the remarks during an exclusive interview with Taiwan Television Enterprise (TTV) in a newly initiated series of programs titled "Century Leadership."
It was the first TV interview that Lee had given since his retirement in 2000. The TTV interview team included TTV Chairman Lai Kuo-chou, Lee's son-in-law.

Defending his breakup with the opposition Kuomintang, of which he was formerly chairman, Lee said he has not changed, but the KMT has. He said statesmen and politicians should stick to their ideals and should be willing to sacrifice their own interests for the sake of the nation.

Lee answered the "sensitive" questions matter-of-factly, including why he still snoops around political groups even though he is retired, and his views on why so many of his "loyal subordinates" have turned their backs on him.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN MEETS WITH VISITING JAPANESE LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan conferred Tuesday with Japanese Lower House member Sadanori Yamanaka, who is in Taipei for the Republic of China National Day celebrations.
The topics of their discussions centered on political and economic developments in the two countries.
Lien told the pro-ROC Japanese lawmaker that the KMT has been striving to help the government stimulate the worsening economy by lending the party's experiences, policy concepts and talent.

He added that the party, which lost its 55-year grip on power on Taiwan to the Democratic Progressive Party in the March 18 presidential election of 2000, is also doing its utmost to ensure the security and stability of the Taiwan Strait.
Lien stressed that the highest priority of the KMT is Taiwan's interests and therefore the stability of the Taiwan Strait is required.
Talking about the upcoming year-end legislative elections, Lien predicted that it is almost certain that no single party will be able to control a simple majority of seats in the Legislative Yuan.
As a result, he said, "party cooperation" after the Dec. 1 elections is unavoidable.
He said that the DPP government should comply with the Constitution to implement a "dual leadership" system with a Cabinet formed by the largest party in the Legislative Yuan.
Otherwise, Lien said, the present political chaos cannot be improved.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL ELECTRONICS SHOW OPENS

TEXT.P: The five-day 2001 Taipei International Electronics Show kicked off Tuesday with the number of international buyers in the first day down significantly compared with last year's figures, according to the organizers.
The show, organized by the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), is an annual event for Taiwan's electronics industry.
According to CETRA statistics, only 1,033 foreign buyers visited the show on opening day, a decrease of 50 percent from the number who attended the first day of the exhibition last year.
The sharp decrease was attributed mainly to the launch of U.S.-led anti-terrorist attacks on the Taliban in Afghanistan, the organizers said.
Last year's show attracted a total of 6,200 international buyers, CETRA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEADS OF STATE CONGRATULATE ROC ON NATIONAL DAY

TEXT.P: Many of the heads of state and government leaders of diplomatic allies of the Republic of China offered their congratulations to President Chen Shui-bian on the nation's Double Ten National Day, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Tuesday.
Tuvalu Prime Minister Faimalaga Lurka and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Prime Minister Ralph Consalves also congratulated ROC Premier Chang Chun-hsiung on the occasion.

Other foreign leaders who sent congratulatory messages included Marshall Foreign Affairs Minister Gerald Zackios, Salvadoran Foreign Minister Maria Eugenia Avila Brizuela, Costa Rican Foreign Minister Roberto Rojas, Philippine Senate Speaker Franklin Drilon, House Speaker Jose de Venecia, and Deputy Presidential Secretary General Waldo Q. Florea.
Four state governors of the United States and 14 senators and representatives also offered their congratulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: FULL TEXT OF PRESIDENT CHEN'S NATIONAL DAY MESSAGE (I)

TEXT.P: Following is the full text of President Chen Shui-bian's National Day message which was release on Tuesday: Distinguished Guests, Ladies and Gentlemen:

Today is the 90th national day of the Republic of China. It is also the first of the new century. A year ago, we entered the new century with the first peaceful transfer of political power in our history. Twenty-three million people earned Taiwan a place in the world trend of democracy and freedom with their love and ballots. This democratic achievement created by all people in Taiwan is the solid foundation on which we stand firm and look at the world.

However, this is an era of hope filled with challenges. We confront not only the unprecedented challenge of economic transformation, but also the havoc brought by Typhoons Toraji and Nari, as well as the international adversity from the September 11 terrorist attacks in the United States.

These domestic and international developments show that the new century has not brought eternal light and peace to mankind as expected. The ever-changing international political and economic situations and unpredictable natural disasters have caused immense suffering and uncertainties at the beginning of this century. Consequently, we must solemnly and humbly face the clash of civilizations and the backlash of nature.

I believe the disasters caused by the typhoons will pass. The government has complete confidence and the courage to assist people through these difficulties and accelerate the reconstruction. On the other hand, the government and people must learn a lesson and seriously re-examine critical ecological conservation and land management issues. We need to stress that "an ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure" to prevent disasters in the future.

Regarding the international community's anti-terrorism campaign, our government has not only strongly condemned the September 11 terrorist attacks, but has also supported all necessary United States actions to fight international terrorism. The impact of the September 11 terrorist attacks has extended beyond borders. Whether economically or politically, Taiwan cannot stand on the sidelines. Our government has prepared various contingency measures in anticipation of possible changes in the international situation. I personally ask all compatriots to remain calm and united, and understand the importance of "being vigilant in peace time." Moreover, we should demonstrate a community spirit that holds us together. During the past year, the government's top priority has been maintaining a stable, peaceful, and safe society, in order to consolidate democracy in Taiwan and promote various reforms. In the area of national security, the military has strengthened its self-defense capabilities while both the military and intelligence establishment have adhered to the principle of political neutralization. The cross-strait relationship has remained peaceful and stable. In international affairs, we have strengthened our relations with friendly nations and will soon become a member of the World Trade Organization. Thus, we will be able to establish economic relations with 140 countries as part of the global economic and trade system.

Moreover, the governing and opposition parties and the private sector collaborated to hold the Economic Development Advisory Conference during late August 2001, reaching a consensus that "cultivating Taiwan with a global perspective" will be the expectation and strategic goal for economic development in the new century. The fact that all political parties were willing to advance the enduring interests of the country with an open mind marks a positive step toward the reconciliation between the governing and opposition parties.

In order to strengthen social stability, the government has made earnest efforts to crack down on organized crime, eliminate corruption, and restructure the financial system. Its resolve to improve social order has never wavered. As a result of these efforts, we have progressively achieved great success. The government's promises to the people are being realized step by step. (end of part-1)

DOC.HEADLINE: FULL TEXT OF PRESIDENT CHEN'S NATIONAL DAY MESSAGE (II)

TEXT.P: Looking into the future, I would like to propose the following four main goals of my administration and invite the entire populace to work together with me:
I. Re-building economic order

The government's recent actions to promote reform in the grass-roots financial institutions demonstrate its strong resolve to re-establish Taiwan's economic order. The enactment of the six financial laws indicates that the policy of restructuring the financial system has won support from both the governing and opposition parties. Our impending accession to the World Trade Organization will have an impact on several local industries. However, the government is well prepared and determined to rebuild the economic order and maintain a fair and independent market.

Improving government efficiency is important for economic activities. Therefore, the government will implement all recommendations of the Economic Development Advisory Conference on streamlining and reorganizing government agencies. The government has decided to invite representatives from all sectors of society to form a government reorganization committee in the near future to achieve the government's promise of a "young Taiwan and energetic government" and build a small but beautiful, capable, and efficient government.
II. Promoting clean government

The year-end elections for county magistrates, city mayors, and legislators will be the first elections held since the change of governing parties. It will also be a crucial time to test the government's determination to crack down on "black gold," eliminate vote buying and corruption, and improve electoral practices. The government pledges to "declare war on vote buying and severely crack down on black gold," and will harshly punish corruption and illicit activities to clean up elections and politics with the ultimate goal of "eradication of vote buying and elevation of democracy."
III. Nourishing Civil Society

Citizen participation is common in a democracy. However, democratic maturity is achieved on the foundation of rational debate and mutual respect. After the September 11 disaster in the United States, American citizens at all levels have united in their fight against a common foe. They have encouraged each other and extended unanimous support to the government in its handling of the crisis. This is a civil society that has been shaped by 200 years of democracy in the United States.

A reflection of our experiences over the past year or so shows that Taiwan's political stability has a direct bearing on its economic development and public confidence. Only a civil society that pursues political reconciliation and cooperation between the governing and opposition parties can constantly develop and produce the optimum benefits for its people. Therefore, regardless of the year-end election results, I have pledged to form a coalition government. The operative model of the Economic Development Advisory Conference will serve as the best example for cooperation between the governing and opposition parties and for social harmony.
IV. Pursuing cross-strait reconciliation

Although the Chinese mainland has not responded positively to our government's initiatives to normalize cross-strait relations since my inauguration on May 20 last year, we will continue to promote cross-strait reconciliation. The Economic Development Advisory Conference has reached a consensus on mainland relations that the "patience over haste" policy should be replaced by a policy of "proactive opening and effective management" under the principles of "Taiwan first, global perspectives, mutual benefit, and risk management."

In this regard, the ROC government will spare no effort to establish flexible mechanisms for cross-strait capital flow, cope with the challenges of our WTO accession and the "Three Links" across the Taiwan Strait, allow tourists from the Chinese mainland, and continue to promote cross-strait consultations. (end of part-2)

DOC.HEADLINE: FULL TEXT OF PRESIDENT CHEN'S NATIONAL DAY MESSAGE (III)

TEXT.P: I call on the leaders of the Chinese mainland to abandon obsolete and rigid thinking, raise their intellectual horizon in facing cross-Strait relations in the 21st century, considering themes such as humanitarianism to overcome the present impasse between the two sides. With the same cultural heritage, dedication to peace, and eagerness for mutually beneficial results, business, trade, and cultural exchanges will help remove political obstacles between the two sides. Only mutually supportive compassion will resolve unnecessary conflicts of opinion.

Pursuing a win-win result for the two sides and maintaining peace in the Asia-Pacific region are the unavoidable obligations of leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait; otherwise, we cannot face history or our people. We should be open and positive about developing a new era during our time.

Distinguished Guests, Ladies and Gentlemen: During the past century, the ROC has stood firm in times of adversity. We have upheld our faith in democracy and free enterprise, with full confidence in the land, people, and future development. Facing numerous challenges and difficulties, we have always progressed with great courage and perseverance.
Let us jointly fulfill our responsibilities and rebuild our confidence, so future generations in Taiwan can anticipate and attain new heights and brilliant prospects.
In closing, I wish everlasting prosperity to the Republic of China and good health and happiness to each of you. Thank you.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT PLEDGES SUPPORT FOR U.S. ACTIONS AGAINST TERRORISM

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said in his National Day message that the ROC government has not only strongly condemned the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States, but has also supported "all necessary United States actions to fight international terrorism."

He noted that the government has also prepared various contingency measures in anticipation of possible changes in the international situation now that the U.S.-led forces have begun strikes in Afghanistan.

Regarding the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Chen said that although Beijing failed to respond to Taipei's initiatives to normalize bilateral relations, "we will continue to promote cross-strait reconciliation."

He said that the policy of "no haste, be patient" is being replaced by a new policy of "proactive opening and effective management" under the principles of "Taiwan first, global perspectives, mutual benefit, and risk management."

In the message issued on the eve of the Double Ten National Day, Chen listed the four main goals of his administration as re-building economic order, promoting clean government, nourishing civil society and pursuing cross-strait reconciliation.
He called on Beijing leaders to abandon their obsolete and rigid thinking and raise their intellectual horizon in facing cross-strait ties in the new century.

With the same cultural heritage, dedication to peace, and eagerness for mutually beneficial results, he said that business, trade, and cultural exchanges will help remove political obstacles between the two sides.
"Pursuing a win-win result for the two sides and maintaining peace in the Asia-Pacific region are the unavoidable obligations of leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait," the president asserted.

Turning to domestic politics, Chen said that regardless the results of the year-end elections for legislators, county magistrates and city mayors, he will form a coalition government after the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 10, or the 24th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1911: A revolt against the Manchu (Ching) dynasty erupts in Wuchang and is followed by revolutionary activities throughout China. The government of the Republic of China formally announced on Sept. 28 that Oct. 10 is henceforth to be observed as ROC National Day in commemoration of the Wuchang Uprising, which led to the establishment of the ROC on Jan. 1, 1912.
1913: Yuan Shih-kai, who forced the Congress to elect him president of the Republic of China on Oct. 6, formally assumes the presidency.
1919: The Chunghua Kemingtang (Chinese Revolutionary Party) is reorganized by Dr. Sun Yat-sen as the Chungkuo Kuomintang (KMT), also known as the Nationalist Party.
1921: Dr. Sun Yat-sen completes the writing of "Plans for Industrial Development."
1925: The National Palace Museum is inaugurated in Peiping (now Beijing).
1928: Chiang Kai-shek assumes the chairmanship of the National Government in Nanking.
1934: The main forces of the Chinese communist troops flee northwest from their bases in Kiangsi, starting their so-called "Long March."
1942: The U.S. and U.K. governments announce their intention to relinquish extra-territoriality and related rights in China.
1943: Chiang Kai-shek is sworn in as chairman of the National Government.
1954: Ho Chi Minh returns to Hanoi as the French evacuate.
1958: The ROC air force shoots down five mainland MiG-17 fighters and damages two more off the mainland coast, losing one Saber jet in the battle.
1962: Taiwan Television Enterprise Ltd., the first commercial television station in the Republic of China, goes into operation.
1970: Fiji, a British colony in the southern Pacific sine 1874, becomes an independent member of the Commonwealth.
1973: Spiro Agnew, 54, twice chosen by U.S. President Richard Nixon to be vice president, resigns before appearing at a federal district court in Baltimore to face charges of income tax evasion.
1974: A mass rally of 250,000 celebrate the 63rd anniversary of the Republic of China.
1975: A military parade of 35,000 members of the ROC armed forces and reserves highlight the observance of the 64th National Day of the Republic of China, with more than 13,000 overseas Chinese and foreign dignitaries joining in the celebration.
1976: A quarter of a million people assemble in the Presidential Square for National Day ceremonies with more than 15,000 overseas Chinese from over 50 countries and areas taking part in events marking the 65th anniversary of the Republic of China.
1978: More than 12,000 members of the Chinese armed forces brave driving rains to stage the largest military parade in many years during National Day celebrations.
1979: President Chiang Ching-kuo accepts the people's gift of 18 F-5E jet fighters with a pledge to recover the mainland at a huge rally attended by 250,000 people to mark the Double Ten National Day.
1980: A strong earthquake rocks Algeria, killing more than 12,500 people.
1986: An estimated 250 thousand people gather before the Presidential Building to celebrate the 75th anniversary of the Republic of China. President Chiang Ching-kuo addresses the nation in person, promising that the ROC will accomplish his ultimate objective of reunifying China.
1993: An overloaded ferry capsizes off the coast of Pusan, in southern South Korea, killing 292.
1997: The International Campaign to Ban Landmines and American Campaign coordinator Jodie Williams win the Nobel Peace Prize.
1999: On behalf of the government and people of the Republic of China, Premier Vincent Siew thanks overseas Chinese community leaders from around the world for their patriotic deeds and generous donations after the Sept. 21 earthquake.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian urges his fellow citizens to strive fearlessly forward on the path of freedom, democracy and human rights.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man never upholds a man because of what he says, nor does he discard what a man says because of the speaker's character."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Wednesday are as follows:
The China Times:
Former Vice President Li Yuan-zu will represent President Chen Shui-bian at the Shanghai APEC summit.
The United Daily News:
Ex-Vice President Li Yuan-zu will attend APEC summit in Shanghai on behalf of President Chen.
The Liberty Times:
Anti-terrorist coalition can bomb Afghanistan all day long: Rumsfeld.
The Taiwan Daily:
Air strikes are not enough to rock the Taliban back on their heels, says Rumsfeld.
The Central Daily News:
U.S. unleashes daylight raids.
The China Post:
Taiwan celebrates 90th anniversary of the Republic of China today.
The Taiwan News:
U.S. air strikes continue to pummel Afghanistan.
The Taipei Times:
U.N. aid workers killed in second day of air strikes on Afghanistan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEMBERS OF ROC REP OFFICE IN U.S. DONATE BLOOD
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 9 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Members of the Republic of China's representative office in the United States donated blood Tuesday in a show of concern for those injured in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and of support for the U.S.-led campaign against terrorism.

The Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States said that following the terrorist attacks, it had arranged for its members to donate blood due to the heavy casualties, but as Americans enthusiastically came forward in large numbers to donate blood at the time, the blood supply was actually ample.
So the representative office therefore arranged for around 40 members to donate blood Tuesday.

Meanwhile, the representative office has also decided to cancel the dinner party Tuesday night marking the ROC's Double Ten National Day out of respect for the victims and family members of victims of the attacks.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC VICE CHAIRMAN TO SPEAK ON CROSS-STRAIT TIES VIA TELECONFERENCE
DOC.DATELINE: Dallas, Oct. 9 (CNA) (By Chang Hui-yen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), is scheduled to give a speech on relations between Taiwan and mainland China to the 30th annual meeting of the Southwest Conference on Asian Studies via teleconference.

Officials from the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Houston said that this is the first time the conference will have a meeting with a high-ranking official of the Republic of China via teleconference, which they said will be significant in helping the American academic world understand Taiwan's mainland China policy.

The 30th annual meeting will be held between Oct. 12-13 at Trinity University in San Antonio, Texas. Lin is scheduled to speak Friday night San Antonio time on "Goodwill and Patience: Taiwan Role in the Taiwan Strait Issue."
It is understood that Lin will later meet with members of the conference at a seminar, which will be presided over by Professor Thomas Bellows of Texas University.

The Southwest Conference on Asian Studies is a a major academic conference in the United States, with members of the conference specializing in one or more fields of Asian studies, including politics, foreign affairs, military issues, economics, culture, history, religion, philosophy and literature.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER V.P. LI YUAN-ZU TO REPRESENT ROC AT APEC SUMMIT IN SHANGHAI

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian has decided to appoint former Vice President Li Yuan-zu to represent him at the upcoming informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, a senior official said Wednesday.

Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general to the president, said Chen has directed the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to make all necessary preparations for Li to attend on his behalf the APEC summit meeting to be held in Shanghai Oct. 20-21.

Yu said Li, now a senior adviser to the president and a criminal law expert, makes a perfect envoy to the Shanghai summit as anti-global terrorism will be one of the major topics to be discussed at the gathering of the top leaders of the 21 APEC member states.

Li, 78, has a doctoral degree in law from Bonn University in Germany. He had served as minister of education, minister of justice and secretary-general to the president prior to holding the post of vice president from 1990-1996.
Yu said that although Li is no longer active in politics, he is still well respected by the public for his legal expertise, dogged integrity and dedicated working style.

Li confirmed in an interview with the domestic press at his home in the rural county of Miaoli, some 100 kilometers south of Taipei, that Chen has asked him to serve as the president's envoy at this year's APEC leadership meeting. But he added that the decision has yet to be finalized.

APEC, a regional forum dedicated to promoting free trade and investment, is one of the few international organizations that simultaneously admits the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. However, because of mainland China's opposition, the ROC president has been barred from attending the annual APEC summit in person and has had to name a proxy to attend in his stead.
Although President Chen has repeatedly expressed his desire to attend the Shanghai summit, Beijing has declined to make any exceptions regarding its position on the issue.

Yielding to international realities, President Chen finally came to a decision Tuesday to name Li as his proxy. Chen has ordered the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to inform the host country of his decision through APEC Secretariat or other proper channels. Sources said mainland China has tentatively agreed to Li's attendance at the event as Chen's envoy.

Li, born in the central mainland Chinese province of Hunan, is now a non-partisan as he didn't re-register his membership with the previous ruling and now opposition Kuomintang last year. His neutrality has helped made it easier for him to represent Chen at the APEC summit, local observers said.
Taiwan takes part in APEC meetings as an "economy" under the title "Chinese Taipei" -- an arrangement designed to overcome mainland China's objection to recognition of Taiwan as a separate state.

In the past, Beijing forced Taiwan to limit its representation at APEC summits to an economics minister or a business leader. Last year, Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan led the island's delegation to the APEC summit in Brunei.

APEC groups Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, mainland China, South Korea, United States, Philippines, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, Russia, Singapore, Thailand, Taiwan and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN CALLS FOR COURAGE AND CONSOLIDATION ON NATIONAL DAY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Wednesday called for the nation on Double Ten National Day to demonstrate courage and consolidation amid global volatility and growing challenges at home.

Addressing a national gathering on the Presidential Plaza marking the 90th anniversary of the founding of the Republic of China, Chen said that since the beginning of the new millennium, Taiwan has met with severe blows and trials in the international affairs, economics and environmental arenas.

The nation, however, has weathered the adversities and stood tall, only because the 23 million people of the island have demonstrated the "Taiwan spirit," which is the most formidable asset and treasure that the whole the nation and all the people can count on, Chen said.

Ever since the beginning of the new year, he said, volatile changes abroad and at home have greeted us with more challenges than favorable developments, with more enlightenment than pleasure. The devastating Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States, for example, have shocked the entire world and enabled the citizens around the globe to once again perceive the imperative of safeguarding freedom, democracy and peace.

He told the nation that the Republic of China government has not only strongly condemned the terrorist attacks in the United States, but has also supported "all necessary U.S.-led actions to fight international terrorism."
The ROC, meanwhile, is also willing to do its utmost to offer all kinds of humanitarian aid to the people or nations in need, he added.

As global anti-terrorism actions have entered a new era, which may consequently affect the global situation, Chen said the government has hammered out a comprehensive contingency strategy aimed at safeguarding Taiwan's national security, economic safety and social stability.

Chen called for the Taiwan public to stay calm and adopt an esprit de corps in this period of global volatility and throw their full support behind the government to beef up the nation's ability to meet international challenges.

He said that despite the twists and turns over the past year, the government has managed to maintain a stable situation across the Taiwan Strait. He urged the leadership in Beijing to perceive and acknowledge the mainstream opinion in Taiwan to resume the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue as soon as possible.

The president said that after 12 long years of waiting and negotiating, Taiwan is finally on the threshold of entering the World Trade Organization (WTO), and will hopefully become a full member of the world trade regulatory body at the beginning of 2002.

With WTO accession nearing, Chen said, Taiwan's trade and economic regimes are becoming more transparent and globalized. The new situation is expected to temporarily deal a blow to the domestic agriculture sector, and the government has been requested to map out countermeasures to cope with the changes, he added.

Chen called for concerted efforts and the greatest efficiency possible from the ruling and opposition parties and from the executive and legislative branches to implement the 322 conclusions that were reached during the presidential Economic Development Advisory Conference held in late August in order to help reinvigorate Taiwan's floundering economy.

Taiwan, which was still rebounding from the devastation brought by the deadly earthquake of Sept. 11, 1999, was again battered by a spate of typhoons this summer that caused large-scale human casualties and damage to property.

Chen said he has asked Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh to chair a group comprised of specialists to set up a long-term review mechanism to reassess Taiwan's past land development policies, and help find a new path for Taiwan that reconciles urban development and land conservation.

Looking to the future, he said, he proposes four main goals for the Chen administration to strive for -- rebuilding economic order, promoting clean government, nourishing civil society and pursuing cross-strait reconciliation -- and invites the entire populace to work together with him to achieve these goals.

At the end, Chen said, the elections for legislators, city mayors and county chiefs slated for Dec. 1 will be a crucial moment for Taiwan regarding political stability, reforms in all aspects of society, economic revitalization and eradication of "black gold" politics in the future.
He called for constituents around Taiwan to exercise their sense of justice and integrity to allow the nation to have clean elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA TO SPONSOR SYMPOSIUM ON NEW TRENDS OF WIRELESS MARKETS

TEXT.P: The China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) will sponsor a symposium at the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park Thursday on new trends in the wireless market, particularly in mainland China and North America.
CETRA officials have invited two specialists from the research and development departments of the mobile phone manufacturer Motorola and Astro Design to speak on new designs and market trends.
The specialist from Motorola will address the development of the wireless market in mainland China and Motorola's marketing strategies and deployments in Asia.

Mainland China has become the fastest-growing wireless market in recent years and a CETRA report indicates that mainland China has surpassed the United States to become the largest market for mobile phones.

At a recent conference on wireless Internet in Singapore, an Ericsson China executive said that the number of cell phone users in mainland China was estimated to exceed 100 million by the middle of this year. Mainland China also has an estimated 22 million Internet users and is expected to cross the 100-million mark in 2004, according to his report.
In Asia as a whole, the number of cell phone users is expected to increase from the current 250 million to 600 million by 2005.

A recent report from Merrill Lynch also points out the rapid development of the wireless market in Asia. The global market for wireless Internet software, content and commerce will reach US$25 billion by 2005, with more than 80 percent of the 2 billion wireless subscribers living outside the United States, according to the report.
The Astro Design specialist will deliver an address at the symposium on consumer inclinations in North America.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WELCOMES OVERSEAS CHINESE RETURNING FOR NATIONAL DAY CELEBRATION

TEXT.P: The Republic of China welcomes the return of overseas Chinese to Taiwan to join their local counterparts for ROC National Day celebrations, Chang Fu-mei, minister of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, said Wednesday.

Chang made the remarks while hosting a luncheon for 250 leaders of returning overseas Chinese groups in Taipei during which she expressed appreciation to overseas Chinese for their love of the country and also asked for their continued support.

With a series of typhoons hitting Taiwan this year, resulting in a large number of casualties and heavy property losses and dealing a huge blow to Taiwan's already faltering economy, the commission had decided to channel some funds toward disaster relief, simplify celebrations, and cancel sponsored visits for overseas groups to southern Taiwan. This has resulted in the number of overseas Chinese returning to Taiwan to celebrate the ROC national day dropping sharply compared with previous years.
The commission estimated that as of Tuesday night, some 1,761 overseas Chinese had returned to Taiwan, including 1,334 from the United States and Canada and 427 from 33 other countries.

Statistics showed that a record 12,007 overseas Chinese returned in 1996 because the government wanted to have a big celebration for the National Day following the nation's first ever popular election of its president, which was held that year.

The number of overseas Chinese who returned for National Day dropped to 6,652 in 1997 because Hong Kong reverted to mainland China rule in that year and Hong Kong people were no longer counted as overseas Chinese. The number of overseas Chinese who returned in 1998 for the celebration totaled 7,135. National Day festivities were canceled in 1999 because of the killer quake that struck the island Sept. 21, 1999.
Some 6,681 overseas Chinese returned for National Day in 2000 in the year when the nation's first peaceful political transition of power from one party to another took place.

Meanwhile, a three-hour National Day Night is scheduled to start at 7 p.m. today in front of the Presidential Office, with the theme being warmth, solidarity and creativity. Co Co Lee and Jolin are among the singers that will perform at the event.

Because of the recent typhoons, a sluggish economy, and the U.S.-led war against terrorism, the scale of National Day festivities has been reduced this year and the traditional fireworks display has been canceled.
In related developments, the number of "National Day babies" that came into the world Wednesday was far lower than that of previous years.

Taipei Municipal Hospital for Women & Children welcomed the arrival of three newborns Wednesday morning. The hospital will not charge the mothers for the delivery fees. In addition, the hospital presented a big cake and gifts for each of the three mothers.

In the past, almost all hospitals in Taipei reported the arrival of a score of babies on Double Ten day, but the total number has decreased this year, reflecting the overall trend of the continued decline in Taiwan's birth rates.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUARTERLY REPORTS OF LEADING U.S. FIRMS TO AFFECT STOCK MARKETS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's stock market analysts are watching the developments in the U.S. stock market, as the business giants in the electronics and telecommunications sectors are about to announce their performances for the third quarter, according to an analysis of the investment consultant Jardine Fleming Taiwan.
The analysis released Wednesday indicates that the developments of the U.S. stock market will have a greater effect on Taiwan's share prices than the fundamental elements of the domestic economy.

While the developments of the U.S.-led military actions against the Taliban regime in Afghanistan are expected to trigger ups and downs in stock markets around the world, the third quarter reports of such big firms as Motorola, Intel, IBM, Microsoft and Yahoo will determine the index fluctuations.
The analysis suggests that investors observe the economic forecasts of leading enterprises in the wake of the outbreak of the warfare in Afghanistan.

Referring to the price shrinkage of electronics shares in Taiwan's stock market, the analysis says that electronics share prices were expected to bottom out in the short run. However, as the recovery of the sector might be delayed, a rebound of the share prices will be unlikely.

Meanwhile, statistics released by the Jih Sun securities house's research department indicate that in the past three months, the weighted price index of the local stock market dropped by 1,246.49 points or 25.52 percent, from 4,883.43 points June 29 to 3,636.94 points Sept. 28.

Jih Sun analysts said that the fundamental elements for Taiwan's economy were not positive and that the weighted price index in the fourth quarter might fluctuate between 3,400 points and 4,200 points.

They pointed out that the conflict between the United States and the Taliban will cause a delay in the world economic recovery. Clear signs of a U.S. economic recovery might not be seen before the second half of next year, they added.

Since 23 percent of Taiwan's exports are shipped to the U.S. market and since the electronics sector, moreover, exported nearly 40 percent of its output to the United States, Taiwan's manufacturing industries might gain momentum in the second half of next year, said the analysts.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MARKS DOUBLE TEN NATIONAL DAY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian promulgated Wednesday the rebuilding of the economy, promoting clean government, nourishing civil society and pursuing cross-Taiwan Strait reconciliation as goals for the administration in the coming year.

Chen appealed to the Beijing authorities to cast away their rigid ideology to allow them to break the cross-strait political deadlock, stressing that it is the duty of the leaders of both sides to pursue a win-win resolution to the stalemate across the strait and maintain stability in the Asia-Pacific region.
He made the appeal in an address delivered at a rally in front of the Presidential Office in downtown Taipei to mark the Republic of China's 90th Double Ten National Day.

Meanwhile, the president told the nation that he has requested Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh to pool the island's wisdom to build up a research and review mechanism to reassess Taiwan's past land development policies and help find a new "third path" for Taiwan that reconciles urban development with land conservation.
Chen was accompanied by First Lady Wu Shu-chen and Vice President Annette Lu during the celebration activities.

The national day rally brought together thousands of local people from all walks of life as well as many foreign dignitaries and overseas Chinese and Taiwanese community leaders to celebrate the ROC's birthday, although the celebration scale was much constricted compared with previous years, as the government decided to practice economy in the face of global and domestic volatility.
The annual rally was reduced to a concise 30-minute celebration, while the folklore gala and fireworks extravaganza that are usually staged were all canceled.

The rally was presided over by Legislative Yuan President Wang jin-pyng, who exhorted his countrymen to adopt a mentality of gratitude while meeting various challenges. He urged all Taiwan's voters to stand united and work hand-in-hand to create a "new miracle" for the country.
The rally kicked off with the passing of a military police motorbike company while a tri-service band played marching tunes.
The military band performance was followed by the playing of brass-and-flag band from the prestigious Taipei First Girl's High School, drawing large crowds of spectators.
Students from selected senior high schools and universities in Taipei then gave colorful dancing and folk performances, adding much fanfare and creating a youthful, exuberant and joyful festive mood.

Similar celebration activities were also staged in major cities around the island, including a high-profile flag-raising ceremony in Taichung City, with Taichung Mayor Chang Wen-ying and People First Party Chairman James Soong jointly presiding.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH URGES HEIGHTENED VIGILANCE AGAINST ANTHRAX

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) has posted information on anthrax on its Website and has asked local doctors to heighten vigilance following cases of the rare disease reported in the United States.

Twu Shing-jer, director-general of the DOH Center for Disease Control (CDC), noted that the cases in the United States appeared at a sensitive time -- with the United States beginning military attacks on the Taliban in Afghanistan to retaliate against its harboring of Osama bin Laden, the major suspect in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York and Washington.

One Florida man died Friday of anthrax and a co-worker also tested positive for the disease. The Palm Beach County health Department has tested more than 800 people for traces of the bacterium that causes anthrax. Investigators in Florida have ruled out any link of the disease to terrorists. A third possible case was also reported in suburban Virginia.

Chen Kuo-tung, section chief of Taiwan's CDC, said that a suspected case of anthrax was reported in 1969, but with the medical standard at the time, health authorities could not verify if it was indeed the fatal disease.
In December 1999, a racehorse at a stable in the Taipei suburb of Peitou died suddenly of anthrax, but there was deemed to be no risk of the disease spreading.

The Anthrax bacterium lives in soil and is spread through food, skin abrasions or cuts and through the respiratory passage. If terrorists were to use the powder form of the bacterium and spread them through a building's ventilation system, the damage would be terrible, according to DOH officials.
The disease affects mainly cattle, horses and sheep, but can also pass to human beings, with the farming and livestock industries the most high-risk groups.
The United States is the only country in the world that has vaccine against anthrax, but it requires a total of six shots within 18 months to give enough protection.

If humans contract anthrax through the respiratory passage, the initial symptoms will resemble that of a cold. Patients develop serious breathing problems a few days later and can die within one or two days.

If the disease is contracted through the digestive system, the symptoms resemble those of acute enteritis, with a death rate of between 25 percent and 60 percent. The disease is treatable with antibiotics.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2 ARRESTED FOR POSSESSION OF ECSTASY

TEXT.P: Two people were arrested for ecstasy possession by Taipei police in an early Wednesday morning raid on a pub in downtown Taipei.

Chen Tien-ping, 42, from Australia and Tsai Chih-yuan, 36, from Singapore, were intercepted by police while entering a pub on Nanking East Road. Police discovered one MDMA pill, commonly known as ecstasy, on each of the pair and arrested them immediately.

Chen, who claimed to work for a Hong Kong newspaper, entered Taiwan last Friday and was slated to leave later Wednesday. He told police that a friend gave him the ecstasy pill in March in Australia and that it lay forgotten in his travel bag. He also claimed he did not know it is illegal to possess ecstasy in Taiwan.
Tsai, a flight attendant for a United States-based airline, claimed to have bought the drug in front of the pub from a stranger for NT$400.
Both men, who denied having taken ecstasy before, were transferred by police to the prosecution authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENTRY TO LEGISLATURE AIMED AT FORGING DIALOGUE MECHANISM: PFP CHAIR

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong said Wednesday that he will push for the establishment of an inter-party dialogue mechanism if he manages to get into the new legislature to be elected Dec. 1.
The PFP placed Soong's name at 11th place on its list of legislator-at-large candidates for the upcoming legislative elections.
Soong said the inclusion of his name in the list marks "new thinking."
"It signifies our party's determination to present a competent team in the new legislature to make a real contribution to our nation," he said.

For the upcoming elections, 41 legislator-at-large seats are available, which will be distributed among the various political parties in proportion to the number of ballots they collect in the elections for regional legislative seats.
Noting that Taiwan's Legislative Yuan has long been in a mess, Soong said he looks forward to entering the legislature to push for its overall reforms.

"If I can enter the parliament, I will invite the president or the premier to conduct extensive policy debates on the legislative floor so as to establish a viable dialogue mechanism between the ruling and opposition parties," he said.
Soong went on to say that although there is a majority party in the legislature at the moment, it lacks ideals, policy and direction to bring prosperity to the nation.
In his view, he said, no party will win more than half of seats in the new legislature. "Against this backdrop, we must use new thinking to cope with this new scenario," he noted.

He criticized the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for its inability to integrate domestic resources to boost national development. "Our ruling party is just good at election campaigning but has failed to come up with any policy initiatives to address the many thorny issues faced by our country," he lamented.
According to Soong, some of his friends have expressed doubt about his wisdom in seeking a legislative seat, as they do not think it will help his future political career.

"I have not made the decision based on my personal interests. My main purpose is to help forge a new legislative culture. Taiwan will have a new future only if it can establish a new legislature," Soong said.
Once he enters the parliament, Soong said, he will give his top priority to presenting innovative policy proposals to cope with major public issues.

He refrained from making any direct comment on President Chen Shui-bian's latest decision to name former Vice President Li Yuan-zu to represent him at the informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum to be held in Shanghai Oct. 20-21.

Instead, Soong outlined three principles for the future development of relations across the Taiwan Strait -- opposing secessionism; supporting the "one China" concept under the premise that the Republic of China's survival and its democratic political system and lifestyle will never be sacrificed; and recognizing the so-called "1992 consensus" that allows each side to have its own definition of "one China."
Soong said he is convinced that the lingering cross-strait limbo can be broken only when the DPP government agrees to these basic principles. Otherwise, he said, cross-strait ties will lead nowhere.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION LEAVES FOR FRUIT EXPO IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A delegation of agricultural officials, farm trade experts, bioscientists and farmer's association executives left for mainland China Wednesday to attend a fruit and vegetable trade fair.

Legislator Lin Feng-hsi of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, who is leading the delegation, said prior to his departure that the Oct. 11-14 trade fair in the southeastern mainland port city of Xiamen provides a forum for Taiwan to introduce its fine-quality fruits and vegetables to mainland and foreign consumers.

Lin said he is confident that many kinds of Taiwan fruits and vegetables will enjoy wide appeal at the trade show, which is being co-sponsored by the United Nations and the mainland Chinese authorities to boost agricultural development in the Asia-Pacific region.

More than 1,000 companies from 22 Asia-Pacific countries and various mainland Chinese provinces and municipalities are participating in the unprecedented fruit/vegetable exposition. The Taiwan delegation will man 50 vending booths displaying a variety of seasonal fruits and vegetables.

In addition to seeking long-term export orders, Lin said, the Taiwan delegation will also take advantage of the event to conduct substantive talks with representatives from nine southern mainland Chinese provinces on the entry of Taiwan fruits into the mainland market.

Lin said the talks will focus on trading terms, inspection and quarantine measures, refrigeration technology and transportation routes. Provincial-level mainland officials and agricultural and biotechnology experts, as well as farm trade executives from the nine mainland provinces, including Fujian and Guangdong, will take part in the negotiations.

In preparation for Taiwan and mainland China's imminent accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO), Lin said, Taiwan must step up efforts to tap mainland Chinese and other overseas markets to minimize the adverse impact of market opening required by WTO provisions.
With its advanced agricultural technology and bioscience expertise, Lin said, Taiwan should have a niche in the global high-end fruit market.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, MAINLAND CHINESE BASKETBALL HEADS MEET TO RESOLVE NAME ISSUE
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Oct. 10 (CNA) (By Kuo Fang-chih and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: The heads of Taiwan and mainland China's basketball associations met in Bangkok Wednesday in an attempt to hammer out an agreement over an acceptable new name for a previously Taiwan-based basketball team that recently relocated to the mainland.

Chinese Taipei Basketball Association President Wang Jen-cheng and China Basketball Management Center Director Xin Lancheng agreed that the Sina.com-financed team should be allowed to participate in Division A league basketball competitions in mainland China and that the mainland fully understands the related laws and regulations in Taiwan.

However, Wang said that both he and Xin would still have to consult with the relevant agencies of their respective governments before they can decide on an appropriate name for the team, which had originally proposed including either "Taiwan" or "Taipei" in its name but was forbidden from doing so.

Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council and National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports rejected the proposal on the grounds that it might boost Beijing's claims that Taiwan is a part of mainland Chinese territory.
The Sina.com team is composed of mainly Taiwanese players and is now based in the mainland Chinese city of Suzhou.
Xin said that there should not be any major problems on the mainland side but added that the final outcome would still have to depend on Taiwan's own decisions.
Wang said that the atmosphere during his discussions with Xin was good and that both were sincerely trying to resolve the problem.
Because the new season for Division A will not begin until Dec. 8, Wang added that there is still time for the two sides to continue their discussions.

Wang and Xin are in Bangkok to attend a meeting of the heads of various Asian basketball associations and to cheer for their own respective teams during the semifinal of the 19th Asian Women's Basketball Championships.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMCHAM CALLS FOR EARLY PASSAGE OF WTO-RELATED BILLS

TEXT.P: The American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei (AmCham) has urged the Republic of China's legislature to pass a number of bills related to Taiwan's imminent entry to the World Trade Organization (WTO).
AmCham, the largest foreign business group in Taiwan, made the appeal in a statement issued Tuesday in connection with the celebration of its 50 founding anniversary.

Noting that WTO accession is expected to bring about many new business opportunities for Taiwan, AmCham said in its statement that Taiwan's Legislative Yuan should accelerate screening of the 10-plus legislative bills concerning the ROC's WTO bid as the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body is expected to formally approve Taiwan's membership application at its ministerial meeting scheduled for November.
Meanwhile, AmCham said the ROC government should also take action on proposals made at the Aug. 24-26 Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC).
In its view, AmCham said the EDAC proposal that promotes free flow of foreign workers and services would help move the Taiwan economy forward.
AmCham said in its statement that failure to implement policy proposals such as these will seriously hinder Taiwan's ability to become a regional operation hub for multinational firms.

The statement cited Hong Kong, Singapore's and Shanghai as places with far few restrictions than Taiwan on certain personnel issues, pointing out that these are major competitors for regional offices.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MIRED IN `DOUBLE CRISIS': NEWSPAPER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy has slipped into a "double crisis" amid the global economic slump, due to the country's over-reliance on the U.S. market and on the information technology sector, according to a newspaper article published Wednesday.

Quoting a report by the Council for Economic Planning and Development, the article in the Liberty Times said Taiwan's trade dependence on the U.S. market, including its direct and indirect shipments to the United States, has reached 50 percent of its total exports. Coupled with Taiwan's overemphasis on the IT sector, the island is mired in a "double crisis" as a result of the global economic downturn.

As the second-quarter economic growth rate in the United States fell to 0.2 percent, the situation has had a serious impact on the economies of Southeast Asian countries, the report noted. At the same time, the high reliance of those countries on the U.S. IT sector has also deepened the impact of the investment bubble in the U.S. hi-tech industry.

In 1999, Taiwan hi-tech exports accounted for 37 percent of the country's total outbound shipments, while the percentages posted by the Philippines, Malaysia and Singapore were all over 50 percent, according to the report. It added that Taiwan's hi-tech exports were doomed to shrink markedly due to the U.S. economic sluggishness this year, seriously affecting Taiwan's economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATOR TO RUN FOR KINMEN MAGISTRATE

TEXT.P: A legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) began campaigning for the post of Kinmen County magistrate Wednesday, becoming the first DPP-nominated candidate to run for the post since the founding of the party.

Chen Chao-nan completed the registration procedure and inaugurated his campaign headquarters on the Taiwan-held frontline island opposite mainland China's Fujian province, witnessed by DPP Secretary-General Wu Nai-jen, Deputy Secretary-General Hsu Jen-tu and Legislator Chang Chun-hung.

Ever since the government ended the military-controlled administration system and implemented direct elections of Kinmen magistrate, the post has always been held by the KMT and the DPP has never nominated a candidate.
In a campaign speech, Wu said that now that the DPP is the ruling party, it considers the development of Kinmen County to be as important as that of any other county and city in the country.

In his own speech, Chen noted that the "mini three links" -- direct trade, transportation and postal service between Taiwan's Kinmen and Matsu islands and mainland China's Xiamen and Mawei -- were implemented by the DPP-led government at the beginning of the year, a breakthrough in relations across the Taiwan Strait.
He urged the people of Kinmen to vote for him in the year-end local elections that will take place simultaneously with the legislative elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROMOTING INDEPENDENCE WILL DRIVE TAIWAN TO ITS DEATH: KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan independence would be a disaster for the people of the island and would drive the country to its death, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Wednesday.

Refraining from referring to former President Lee Teng-hui by name, Lien accused "someone" of promoting Taiwan independence by making "ungrateful remarks" in public. He said that continuing to do so will only push Taiwan into a corner.
Although some people always say they love Taiwan, the KMT chairman said, "the nation we respect turns out to be a `foreign power' for them." He did not elaborate.

Lien made the remarks in Pingtung, southern Taiwan, to KMT supporters during a joint campaign rally for the party's candidates who will take part in December's elections for legislative seats and for local government chiefs.

Commenting on the performance of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) over the past more than one year, Lien said the coming elections will serve as an occasion for the Taiwan people to examine the deeds of the DPP.

As to recent criticism by Lee about his dreadful performance in the 2000 presidential election, the KMT chairman was reluctant to respond, but according to his secretarial staff, such verbal attacks on Lien are "unfair" and it is not his style to fight back, because Lien, a "respectful and broad-minded gentleman," feels it is a waste of time.

Lien, former vice president and the KMT's candidate in the 2000 presidential race, finished a distant third with just 2.9 million votes, far behind President Chen Shui-bian's 4.9 million votes and former Taiwan Governor James Soong's 4.6 million votes.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL RESULTS DECIDE KMT CANDIDATE RUNNING FOR KAOHSIUNG COUNTY CHIEF

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) announced Wednesday the results of two public opinion polls that decided which of two candidates will represent the party in the year-end election for Kaohsiung County chief.
Legislator Wu Kuang-hsun received an average of 2.3 percentage points higher in the polls than former Fengshan Mayor Huang Pa-yeh to become the official KMT-endorsed nominee.

Wu said that he still hopes to be able to work together with Huang in the future to help the KMT reclaim the county, which has been tightly held by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party for 16 years.

However, Huang said after congratulating Wu that he will look over the poll numbers again in detail and will not rule out insisting on running for county chief if he discovers for certain that the numbers were questionable.
Each of the two candidates appointed a company to conduct a poll that began 6 p.m. Tuesday and ended Wednesday noon.
Out of the 1,032 effective samples obtained by the company that Wu appointed, 37.4 percent of the respondents said that they support Wu, while 35.6 percent supported Huang.
Out of the 1,068 effective samples obtained by the company that Huang appointed, 36.6 percent said that they support Wu, while 33.8 percent supported Huang.
Averaging the results of the two polls, 37 percent supported Wu, and 34.7 percent supported Huang.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL DAY PARADE HELD IN YOKOHAMA
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 10 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: A Republic of China Double Ten National Day parade was held at Yokohama's Chinatown Wednesday, with more than 300 pro-Republic of China overseas Chinese residents and friendly Japanese people participating.
