Before the parade, a National Day rally was held at the Yokohama China School, presided over by Yokohama Overseas Chinese Association President Lei Chao-yuan.
Lei said that in spite of rain, the National Day parade was held as scheduled to demonstrate the Chinese community's spirit of solidarity, as well as its firm support for the ROC government.

ROC Representative to Japan Lo Fu-chuan praised the overseas Chinese for their unswerving and persevering spirit to attend the rally and the parade in the rain to show their loyalty to the ROC government.
Congratulatory cables to President Chen Shui-bian and the ROC armed forces from the Chinese community in Japan were read at the rally.
The National Day parade on the main streets of Chinatown was attended by teams of overseas Chinese and friendly Japanese citizens.
The event attracted thousands of spectators along the streets where many ROC flags were displayed to celebrate the 90th founding anniversary of the ROC.
In addition to the Yokohama parade, similar National Day celebrations were also held in Tokyo, Chiba, Osaka, Shizuoka, Kobe, Nagoya, Kyoto, Fukuoka and Hiroshima.
The Sankei Shimbun daily and the English-language Japan Times ran supplements to mark the Double Ten National Day.
The Chinese community in Japan also dispatched a 123-member mission to Taipei to attend National Day celebrations.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUINNESS RECORD HOLDER MAKES TAIWAN 27TH COUNTRY HE'S WALKED ACROSS

TEXT.P: The Guinness world record holder for the most number of countries traversed on foot completed his 27th conquest Wednesday when he arrived at the southern-most tip of Taiwan.

For his latest feat, Steven Newman, 47, received an official certificate from a representative of the Guinness Book of Records at the Oluanpi Lighthouse in Pingtung County, the final stop of his 534-kilometer trip that began Sept. 23 from the island's northern-most tip.
Newman, who hails from a small town in Ohio in the United States, said that he has witnessed the friendliness of the Taiwanese people on several occasions during the course of his journey.

He said that while he was walking along western Taiwan, many people along the way gave him water and "moon cakes," a traditional Chinese snack eaten on the Mid-Autumn Festival, which fell on Oct. 1 this year -- the 15th day of the eighth month on the lunar calender.
Newman is bringing home three gifts from Taiwan that he said he will treasure. One is a stone carving of a cicada given to him by a sculptor in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County.
Another is a box of betel nuts that he said he wants to bring home to his wife, who is a school teacher, so that she can let her students taste the so-called "Taiwanese bubblegum."
The third is a badge from a local McDonald's, because he said that he frequently ate at the fast food chain during the 18 days he spent in Taiwan.
He said that he will rest for a while before deciding whether to traverse Hong Kong, Vietnam or mainland China on foot next year.

Newman made his world record of traversing 24 countries on foot in 1987 after three years of traveling. He spent three-and-a-half months last year walking from the northern-most tip of Japan to its southern-most tip and completed a similar trip across South Korea in June this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, MAINLAND CHINESE OIL COMPANIES MAY JOINTLY EXPLORE IN STRAIT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) and mainland Chinese China National Offshore Oil Corp. (CNOOC) will probably form a joint venture in Hong Kong or Singapore to explore for oil in the Taiwan Strait, CPC sources said Wednesday.
The sources said that the CPC board of directors will discuss and finalize the project Friday and then forward it for approval to the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Mainland Affairs Council.

The CPC, using the name "Overseas Petroleum and Investment Corp.," signed an agreement with the CNOOC in 1998 to engage in the preliminary exploration for oil under the waters west of the Tainan Basin, southern Taiwan, and east of mainland Chinese Chaozhou and Shantou areas.
After preliminary explorations, both sides estimated that there are oil reserves of about 1,334.6 billion cubic meters in the area.

CPC ranking officials said that as they are restricted by Taiwan's current "no haste, be patient" policy toward mainland China, the CPC and the CNOOC suggest that both sides set up a joint venture in a third country, thereby allowing further oil exploration in the area.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMAN URGES BEIJING TO INVITE ROC PRESIDENT TO APEC SUMMIT

TEXT.P: U.S. Representative Tom DeLay on Tuesday urged Beijing to invite Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian to attend the upcoming informal leadership summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Shanghai.

The Texas Republican said during a speech he delivered at the U.S. House of Representatives that mainland China can lower Taipei-Beijing tensions and start constructive bilateral exchanges through this act of good will.

DeLay, who is the Republican whip, said that the people of the world will be able to determine from the APEC summit to be held Oct. 20-21 whether Beijing allows all APEC members to fully participate in jointly promoting trade and intra-regional economic development.
He said that Beijing still has the opportunity to show the world that it is sincerely willing to resolve its differences with Taiwan by inviting Chen to the meeting.
DeLay said that the key to resolving the tension across the Taiwan Strait is by engaging in wide-ranging and open dialogue on affairs of mutual importance.
Last month, 30 members of the U.S. House of Representatives endorsed a resolution supporting Chen's full participation in the APEC summit meeting.
The resolution, introduced on July 24, was referred to the U.S. House Committee on International Relations for further action.

The non-binding resolution says that the U.S. Congress supports the initiatives proposed for direct dialogue without precondition between leaders from both sides of the Taiwan Strait, and "specifically endorses the proposal for full participation" in the APEC forum by President Chen Shui-bian.
Chen has appointed former Vice President Li Yuan-zu to represent him at the upcoming meeting.
APEC, a regional forum dedicated to promoting free trade and investment, is one of the few international organizations that has as its members both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
However, because of mainland China's opposition, the ROC president has been barred from attending the annual APEC summits in person and has had to name a proxy to attend in his stead.
Although Chen has repeatedly expressed his desire to attend the Shanghai summit, Beijing has declined to make any exceptions regarding its position on the issue.
Yielding to international realities, Chen finally came to a decision Tuesday to name Li as his proxy.

APEC members are Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, mainland China, South Korea, the United States, the Philippines, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, Russia, Singapore, Thailand, Taiwan and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: LI TO ATTEND APEC SUMMIT IN CAPACITY AS SENIOR ADVISOR TO PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao said Wednesday that former Vice President Li Yuan-zu will represent President Chen Shui-bian at the leadership conference of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to be held in Shanghai Oct. 20-21.
He confirmed the appointment while speaking to media.
Tien said that the 78-year-old scholar-turned politician is "a very good choice" in terms of reputation and career achievements.

Li, who acquired his doctorate in law from Bonn University, has served as president of National Cheng Chi University, justice minister and education minister before serving as vice president between 1990-96.
Tien said that his ministry already informed the Beijing side of Li's appointment Tuesday through a formal channel but added that he has not yet received a response from Beijing.
He expressed his hope that Beijing will give a "goodwill response."
When asked why the Taipei side made public the appointment of Li before obtaining Beijing's consent, Li said that "the news was not released by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs."

In the past, the ROC president was represented at the APEC leadership conference by an official with an economic background, including former Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairmen Vincent Siew and P.K. Chiang, Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu and Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL DAY RECEPTION DRAWS 2,500 DIGNITARIES

TEXT.P: A Double Ten National Day reception was held at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall Wednesday evening, with some 2,500 Chinese and foreign dignitaries participating.
ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao, host of the reception, said that many unexpected disasters occurred in both foreign countries and Taiwan in the past few months.

He noted that the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on New York and Washington brought a great shock to the civilized world, while Taiwan was stricken by a series of natural disasters and financial difficulties.
Under such an adverse environment, Tien stated that the government and the people should cooperate to conquer the pressing difficulties.
The minister said that in the past few years, the ROC has found a space for survival in the economic, political and diplomatic fields, relying on the "Formosan spirit."
He pointed out that the ROC government will use diplomacy based on democracy and human rights in the coming years as it has become the mainstream value of the international community.
ROC President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Chang Chun-hsiung were among the government leaders invited to the National Day reception.
In the past, the National Day reception was held at the Taipei Guest House. This year, it was shifted to the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall because the Taipei Guest House is being renovated.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1,759 OVERSEAS CHINESE RETURN TO CELEBRATE ROC NATIONAL DAY

TEXT.P: The effects of two typhoons in a row caused a sharp decrease in the number of overseas Chinese returning to celebrating this year's Republic of China National Day.

According to statistics released Wednesday by the reception unit of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC), as of Wednesday, 1,759 overseas Chinese have returned to the ROC to attend the National Day festivities.
Of the 1,759 overseas Chinese, 898 were from Asia, 87 were from Oceania, 20 were from Africa, 58 were from Europe, 629 were from North America, and 56 were from South America.
OCAC Chairwoman Chang Fu-mei hosted a lunch Wednesday to entertain 250 leaders of overseas Chinese groups.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs held a reception in the afternoon at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
All the returning overseas Chinese attended a National Day party at night that featured various performances.

According to official statistics, there were 12,007 overseas Chinese returning to attend the ROC National Day in 1996, the year that the nation held its presidential election; 6,652 in 1997, the year Hong Kong's sovereignty reverted to Beijing; 7,135 in 1998; zero in 1999, the year that Taiwan was seriously hit by a strong earthquake; and 6,681 in 2000, the year the Kuomintang lost the presidency to the Democratic Progressive Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 11, or the 25th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1727: George II, King of Great Britain and Ireland and elector of Hanover, is crowned in London. His 1743 victory at the Battle of Dettingen was the last time that a British monarch led troops in the field.
1821: Sir George Williams, English social reformer who founded the Young Men's Christian Association (YMCA), one of the largest nonprofit voluntary organizations in the world, is born.
1834: Sir William Napier, Britain's Chief Superintendent of Trade in China, dies in Macao at the age of 48. He had recently returned from Canton after a disastrous attempt to persuade the imperial government of China to trade directly with Britain rather than through Hong Kong merchants.
1896: Dr. Sun Yat-sen is enticed into and placed in confinement at the Ching embassy in London. He was later rescued by his British friends.
1900: Winston Churchill, British politician and writer, is elected a member of the House of Commons, beginning his long political career. As prime minister, he led Great Britain during World War II. He published several works, including "The Second World War," and won the 1953 Nobel Prize for literature.
1939: U.S. scientists, including Albert Einstein, outline to President Franklin D. Roosevelt the possibility of developing an atomic bomb.
1945: A joint declaration by the government and the Chinese communists announces that an agreement between the two sides has been reached after six weeks of negotiations and that unsolved problems are to be settled by a political consultative conference.
1946: ROC government troops capture Kalgan (Changchiakow) in Inner Mongolia from the Chinese communists.
1957: The world's largest steerable radio-telescope goes into operation at the Jodrell Observatory of the British University of Manchester. The instrument has an 81-meter diameter parabolic bowl mounted on a trunnion 58 meters above ground level.
1968: Apollo 7, carrying U.S. astronauts Walter Schirra, Don Eiselle and Walter Cunningham, is launched.
1972: West Germany establishes diplomatic ties with Communist China.
1975: A two-day national conference on "Building a New Asia Through Moral Rearmament" opens in Taipei.
1976: Qiang Qing, the third wife and widow of Mao Tse-tung, is arrested with three associates. The so-called "Gang of Four" are charged with plotting a coup after Mao's death.
1978: The 1978 World Women's Football Invitational Tournament opens at the Taipei Municipal Stadium with 13 teams from Asia, Australia, Europe, the Americas and the Pacific competing.
1980: Soviet cosmonauts return to Earth after a record 185 days in space in the Salyut 6 spacecraft.
1986: A National Development Exhibition in celebration of the centennial of late President Chiang Kai-shek's birthday is opened at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei.
1986: U.S. President Ronald Reagan and Soviet Communist Party General Secretary Mikhail Gorbachev hold a summit meeting in Reykjavik, Iceland.
1986: A display of ROC military power in the "Kuo-kuang Maneuvers" is held at the Hukou Army Base in Hsinchu.
1990: The Ministry of the Interior reiterates that the Tiaoyutai island group belongs to the Republic of China. The chain of eight uninhabited islets, located in the East China Sea, is also claimed by Japan and Communist China.
1991: Direct air service between Australia and the Republic of China begins.
1992: President Lee Teng-hui and Panamanian President Guillermo Endara sign a joint communique on expanding bilateral cooperation.
1997: Leaders of some 40 nations end a rare Council of Europe summit with pledges regarding human rights and human cloning.
1999: Some 7,000 people gather at a stadium in Linkou on the outskirts of Taipei to mourn the death of 2,321 people in the devastating earthquake that rattled Taiwan on Sept. 21.
2000: Civil Aeronautics Administration Director-General Chang Yu-hern confirms that Spain, Denmark and the Czech Republic have agreed to exchange "temporary aviation rights" with the ROC to facilitate bilateral visits.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only he in this world who is possessed of absolute truth that can order and adjust the great relations of human society, fix the fundamental principles of morality, and understand the laws of creation of the Universe."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER INTERVIEWED BY LARGEST-CIRCULATION RUSSIAN DAILY
DOC.DATELINE: Moscow, Oct. 10 (CNA) (By Chang Hung-kuang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday in an interview by a Russian daily that there is ample room for Taiwan and Russia to further bolster cooperation and exchanges.

In the interview, carried in Russia's largest-circulation daily the Merchant, Chang said Russia and Taiwan complement each other as Russia has abundant natural resources and possesses high-tech talent and expertise, while Taiwan is rich in capital as well as in experience in small- and medium-size enterprise management and marketing strategies.

The fact that the mainstream Russian newspaper conducted the interview with the ROC premier and carried it in its Oct. 10 issue, the same day that the ROC celebrates its Double Ten National Day, is of special significance, said some local political observers.

Chang said that although it is true Taiwan is facing an unprecedented economic downturn amid sluggishness in the global economy, there is no reason to worry that a financial crisis will occur in Taiwan as the country possesses high levels of foreign exchange reserves while the government has implemented sweeping measures to reform and streamline Taiwan's financial system.
He said that the ROC government is aiming at seeking a balance between economic development and environment conservation in order to achieve sustained development.

Chang defended the Chen administration's decision to follow a new strategy of "active opening, effective management" toward Taiwan trade and investment in mainland China instead of the "no haste, be patient" tactics, saying that the new approach is aimed at increasing Taiwan's competitiveness in the global trade arena, rather than just in the area of the cross-Taiwan Strait trade.
According to Chang, bilateral trade between Taiwan and Russia has increased on a year-on-year basis, with the total amount of trade between the two sides reaching US$1.565 billion in 2000.

Computers, PC peripherals, and stereo and audio systems and equipment made up the bulk of Taiwan's exports to Russia last year, while metal raw materials were the major commodities that Russia exported to Taiwan.

Taiwan suffered a trade deficit of US$1.193 billion with Russia in 2000. Commenting on the trade imbalance, Chang said it should be addressed by increasing Taiwan exports to Russia, rather than by cutting imports from Russia.

In related news, Taiwan's chief representative in Moscow, Charles Shu-chi King, played host at a dinner party Wednesday evening marking the Republic of China's 90th birthday, with dignitaries from Russia's political and business circles as well as from the Chinese and Taiwan business communities participating.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 171 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Thursday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 171 points to close at 3,789.93.
Market turnover amounted to NT$50.82 billion (US$1.47 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TECHNOLOGY BARONS IN TAIWAN FACING SHRINKAGE IN WEALTH

TEXT.P: A recent survey by Business Weekly magazine showed that major shareholders of Taiwan's listed high-technology firms have suffered great losses in wealth over the past year due to the declining stock market.

The survey conducted in September showed that among the 100 most wealthy individuals in Taiwan's hi-tech sector, 87 reported that their wealth and assets shrank in the past 12 months, and the losses ranged between 20 percent and 80 percent.

Kuo Tai-ming, chairman of Hou Hai Precision Industry, remained the most wealthy hi-tech baron in Taiwan, although the market capitalization of his stocks amounted to only NT$50.9 billion at the end of September, down 48 percent from the level a year earlier.
Quanta Computer chairman Lin Pai-li, with wealth amounting to NT$49.1 billion, ranked second. As of the end of September, seven hi-tech executives in Taiwan were in the NT$10 billion wealth club.

While the newly listed hi-tech corporations have created several new wealthy individuals during the past several months, some stock market champs of previous years when the market was bullish were experiencing bitter setbacks. Some of them even failed to keep their places on the top-100 chart.

An analyst of China Securities Investment Trust Corp. said that in the 1990s, major shareholders of some electronics firms had pledged their stocks for bank loans to raise capital for reinvestments. While the booming prospect had served as a stimulus to share prices, market capitalization of these corporations continued to expand.

However, the adverse turn in the stock market's fortunes has put these shareholders in a dilemma, with most facing a depreciation in the value of their stocks and many having difficulties cashing out of their stocks on hand to repay the bank loans, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SLIM SUPPORT FOR SENDING ROC TROOPS TO FIGHT IN AFGHANISTAN: POLL

TEXT.P: Few Taiwan people support the proposal that the Republic of China send troops to assist the United States in its current war on global terrorism, according to the results of an opinion poll released Thursday.

The telephone poll of 1,124 randomly chosen adult residents, conducted by Open magazine from Oct. 8-10, found that only 1.17 percent support sending troops to join the U.S.-led military strikes on Afghanistan for its sheltering of Osama bin Laden, the suspected mastermind behind the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States.

About 52 percent of the respondents said they don't think that Taiwan should dispatch its service people to assist in the ongoing anti-terrorism war, while 31 percent said they think Taiwan can offer military logistic aid.

The same survey also found that 32.5 percent of those interviewed are willing to accept the Beijing-proposed "one country, two systems" unification scheme, but 61.06 percent said Beijing's unification formula is unacceptable.

As for the approval ratings of major domestic political parties, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) continues to take the lead, with a support rate of 21.93 percent; followed by the Kuomintang at 15.4 percent; the People First Party at 13.52 percent; the Taiwan Solidarity Union at 1.52 percent; and the New Party at 1.25 percent.

Asked about their self-identity, 46.54 percent said they perceive themselves as Taiwanese; 10.96 percent said they identify themselves as Chinese; 28.39 percent said they identify themselves as both Taiwanese and Chinese; 12.22 percent said they perceive themselves as both Chinese and Taiwanese; and 69.01 percent said they agree to be called ethnic Chinese.

Turning to the question about future relations between Taiwan and mainland China, 40.81 percent said they think that the status quo should be maintained forever; 15.95 percent said they prefer to see Taiwan gradually move toward independence after maintaining the status quo for some time; and 26.67 percent said they think that Taiwan should gradually reunite with the mainland after maintaining the status quo for some time.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 171 points to close at 3,789.93.

Encouraged by a rise in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 3,721.06 and continued to go up later due to heavy purchases made by investors. The index fluctuated between 3,810.84 and 3,716.19 during trading.

A total of 2.43 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$50.82 billion (US$1.47 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.74 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$36.12 billion (US$1.05 billion).

All the eight major stock categories gained ground, with electrical shares moving up the most at 5.9 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 4.6 percent, pulp and paper issues at 4 percent, foodstuff shares at 3.2 percent, textile issues and bank and insurance shares, both at 2.4 percent, construction stocks at 2.3 percent, and cement stocks at 1.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 564 to 30, with 41 stocks remaining unchanged.

TAIEX Index futures for November rose 223 points to finish at 3,838, with 812 contract transactions, while December futures gained 181 points to finish at 3,815, with six contracts traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPENING OF TELECOMMUNICATIONS MARKET TO EFFECT ON TAIWAN'S ECONOMY

TEXT.P: An opening of Taiwan's telecommunications market will affect the island's economic development and national security, according to a research report released Thursday by the Institute of Transportation of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.
The report indicates that Taiwan has gradually opened its telecommunications market to meet the requirements for World Trade Organization (WTO) membership.

While WTO membership will provide advantages for the local telecommunications sector to operate international businesses, the research report cautions about the risk of capital outflow. The high potential of the telecommunications service market in mainland China is seen as a strong magnet for foreign capital and a big attraction to Taiwan's investors, according to the report.
After joining the WTO, Taiwan's telecommunications market will be open to foreign investors and foreign workers, including those from mainland China.

The research report points out that Taiwan's telecommunications sector and communication networks may be at risk of being monitored by the authorities on mainland China, unless security measures are adopted before the liberalization of the market.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar appreciated NT$0.002 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Thursday, closing at NT$34.553.
The local currency opened Thursday at NT$34.570 and was traded between NT$34.546 and NT$34.570.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$178 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT MAY HELP BUSINESSES IN TROUBLE TO POSTPONE LOAN REPAYMENTS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance has submitted a proposal to the Executive Yuan suggesting that the government help companies with normal operations and good credit to postpone the repayment of bank loans, Wang Ling-lin, chairman of the General Chamber of Commerce of the ROC, said Thursday.

Officials of business and industrial associations met with economic and financial officials Thursday morning to study rescue measures for business firms who had suffered great losses from typhoons and floods.

Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Chinese Association of Industry and Commerce, said that a prolonged military conflict in Central Asia will delay the anticipated world economic recovery by three to six months, thus causing difficulties to the capital-rigid business and industrial circles in Taiwan.
He called on the government to help reschedule loan repayments for those businesses with normal operations and good credit.
The Ministry of Finance Wednesday afternoon convened a special meeting on the possible rescheduling of loan repayments and a proposal was made to the Cabinet for approval.

Koo said that he had discussed last week with Premier Chang Chung-hsiung and Wang Jin-pyng, president of the Legislative Yuan, the possibility of allowing private enterprises to postpone the repayments by one year. The authorities agreed to study the feasibility of the proposal.

The business leaders said that the government should adopt measures to help small and medium-sized businesses counter the difficulties triggered by the shrinkage of export markets. They also cautioned the authorities to prevent dumping of imported goods before Taiwan is admitted into the World Trade Organization.

Attending the Thursday discussions were Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang, Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi, Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan and Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development.

DOC.HEADLINE: SISY CHEN REGISTERS FOR LEGISLATIVE ELECTION AS INDEPENDENT

TEXT.P: Media celebrity Sisy Chen registered for the Dec. 1 legislative elections in metropolitan Taipei's southern precinct Thursday, the last day for candidacy registration for the pivotal polls.
Chen, who once served as spokeswoman for the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) when it was still an opposition party, registered her candidacy as an independent.
"Running for a legislative seat is one of the most difficult decisions to make in my life," Chen said, adding that she came to a final decision after much soul searching.

Accompanied by two friends, Chen arrived at the Taipei City Election Commission at 11:40 a.m. to register her candidacy, immediately causing a stir among media professionals at the commission's office.

Chen, known for her outspokenness and maverick thinking, said she intends to serve for only one legislative term. She further said that if she is elected to the Legislative Yuan, she would donate all of the salary to educational institutions that are dedicated to offering vocational training for unemployed blue-collar workers.

Chen reminded those who expect her to make promotional appearances if she is elected, such as private social functions and wedding ceremonies or funerals, should not vote for her. If elected, Chen said she would focus on policy debates and policy initiatives instead of wasting time on trivial publicity events.

Chen said she has no plans to distribute any campaign leaflets, not to mention offering any gifts to voters. A clean election would be the first step to establish a new legislative culture and political tradition in Taiwan, she noted.

Chen paid NT$200,000 in cash as a deposit for her candidacy. She was surprised when a registration office staffer told her that one NT$1,000 bill in the money she gave was counterfeit. "It's really disappointing. My mother directly transferred the money to me after she received the money from a bank teller this morning," she said.

Chen's participation in the race would add to fanfare in the Taipei south precinct competition as all major domestic political parties have already fielded a number of noted politicians, including many incumbents, to run for the 10 regional seats up for grabs.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER PUSHES FOR MANDATORY SUPPORT OF ELDERLY BY ADULT CHILDREN

TEXT.P: Legislator Lai Shyh-bao of the opposition New Party Thursday proposed legislation that would require adult children to provide care for their elderly parents.
Lai said he initiated the proposal after learning of a great number of cases where adult children abandoned their aged parents, often leaving them sick and helpless.

According to Lai, the 14-article "parents' support" draft bill precisely stipulates that attending or waiting on elderly parents is the responsibility of all children. It also stipulates the criteria for adult children to support their parents, particularly when they are old and ill, Lai noted.
He added that violators of the bill would face fines as high as NT$200,000 (US$5,797) or one year in prison.

According to Lai, the number of Taiwan citizens who are 65 years old or older stood at around 1.94 million at the end of June. The figure represented 8.43 percent of the island's total population, exceeding the benchmark 7 percent level, making Taiwan's society a "gray nation," he added.

Lai estimated that there are about 150,000 senior citizens in Taiwan who are poor, unattended or even displaced. He made the judgment based on government tallies showing that 8.97 percent of the people who are aged 65 or above, or about 174,000 senior citizens, are bracketed as people of low incomes who regularly need financial help.

Lai quoted government tallies as indicating that in Taiwan, an elderly person needs at least NT$16,000 (US$464) a month to survive, assuming that they are healthy. However, there are some 739,000 elderly citizens at present living on less than NT$6,000 every month, Lai said.
The tallies also showed that about 47 percent of the island's senior citizens are being taken care of in some way by their adult children.

Commenting on Lai's proposal, Tsai Huang-liang, Democratic Progressive Party whip at the Legislative Yuan, said that the draft bill was a worthy and respectable effort deserving the full support of all legislators.
Tsai said he hopes that the draft bill will be passed and promulgated this session.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIGNS ORGAN DONOR CARD

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung signed an organ donor card Thursday as part of an effort to raise the consciousness of the program in Taiwan.
The signing was part of activities launched by the Cabinet-level Department of Health aiming at allowing the concept of organ donation to take root in Taiwan over the next three years.
The Executive Yuan passed an amendment to the Organ Donation Act Thursday, paralleling the launch of a three-year nationwide organ donation campaign.
The health department is aiming at sponsoring 300 briefing workshops a year islandwide to promote organ donation in the country.
Chang said one person out of every three people in the United States has been shown to be willing to donate their organs, as compared with one out of every 60 people in Taiwan.

He added that last year, some 6,000 patients in Taiwan were waiting for donated organs for transplants to survive. Only 100 people obtained such transplants. Most of the waiting patients died because of a lack of donated organs.

Department of Health Director-General Lee Ming-liang joined Chang in the donor card signing drive. Lee said some prisoners on death row have agreed to donate their organs over the past several years, but the number of their donations are relatively few compared with the number of people who need an organ transplant.

Lee said thousands of people are killed in traffic accidents every year but most of them do not think about donating their organs while they are alive. Lee said that more people should consider signing a donor card while they are still healthy.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LEGISLATOR LIN CHIH-CHIA ENTERS YEAR-END ELECTION AS INDEPENDENT

TEXT.P: Legislator Lin Chih-chia of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) registered Thursday to run for re-election as an independent despite saying earlier that he was withdrawing from politics.

Lin, with tears in his eyes, said he had in fact intended to quit politics to pursue advanced studies, but said that he could not let down his die-hard supporters. Lin came forward on the last day of registration and decided to run as an independent since the KMT had not recommended that he run on its ticket.

Saying that he wanted to continue to work in the Legislative Yuan for the benefit of children and underprivileged groups, Lin said he was prepared to accept any recriminations that he may get from the KMT.

Lin was originally KMT candidate for Taipei County magistrate, but later agreed to abide by an opinion poll to decide whether he or Wang Chien-shien of the New Party, should represent the "pan-blue alliance" in the election to boost the chances of winning against incumbent Taipei County Magistrate Su Tseng-chang of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Lin, after losing by a statistically insignificant margin of 0.28 percent to Wang in the poll, agreed to take his hat out of the ring, and said that he would throw his full support behind Wang. He also said that he would withdraw from politics and would not run for magistrate or legislator.

The "pan-blue alliance" refers to the alliance between the KMT, currently the opposition party with the most seats in the Legislative Yuan, and its two splinter groups -- the People First Party and the New Party. The three parties share a roughly common pro-unification stance on relations with mainland China in contrast to the ruling DPP's pro-independence position.
Wang said he welcomed Lin's decision to enter the race for re-election, but some KMT legislators condemned the action.

Wang said that both he and Lin should do well in their respective campaigns, adding that since they will represent the "pan-blue alliance," their efforts to attract votes should be complementary. Wang said he had relatively less support in the second of the three election precincts in Taipei County, and Lin's registration in the second precinct will certainly strengthen Wang.

Several of the five KMT candidates running in the second precinct said that Lin's entering the race will affect their own election bids. Ten legislators will be elected in the second precinct of Taipei County.

KMT Legislator Chen Hung-chang -- one of the five KMT candidates -- said that if the KMT should decide to recommend Lin, it would compromise the party's credibility, and if Lin goes through with his bid as an independent, he would compromise his own credibility.

KMT Legislator Lee Sen-zong also said that democracy means that no one can interfere with the right to enter politics, but said he regretted that Lin had come out in support of him only last week but is now in the race himself.

Lee said that political figures should be models for society, indirectly criticizing Lin for changing horses in midstream by going back on his word to quit politics after withdrawing from the race for magistrate.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUANG PA-YEH REGISTERS FOR COUNTY CHIEF ELECTION AFTER POLLS

TEXT.P: Huang Pa-yeh, a member of the main opposition Kuomintang, registered Thursday as an independent candidate in the Dec. 1 election for Kaohsiung County magistrate.
The KMT announced Wednesday the results of two public opinion polls that decided which of two candidates would represent the party in the year-end election for Kaohsiung County chief.

Huang said that he had hoped the polls would help solve the stalemate between himself and Wu Kuang-hsun, a candidate endorsed by the KMT, but as the polls "were rigged and could not convince me," Huang said that he would not follow through with the agreements made before the polls.
Legislator Wu Kuang-hsun received an average of 2.3 percentage points higher in the polls than former Fengshan Mayor Huang to become the official KMT-endorsed nominee.

On questions that Huang's insistence to run in the election will compromise his credibility since he had agreed beforehand that he would respect the poll results, Huang said that the two public opinion poll companies used different samples, and the questions that were asked were "misleading," so that he could not accept the result of the polls.

Huang stressed that he had announced his withdrawal from the KMT Wednesday night and registered as an independent. Calling the opinion surveys nothing more than straw polls, Huang said that there was no more room to compromise with the KMT.

Huang was accompanied by legislator Chung Shao-ho of the People First Party to register. Both Huang and Chung earlier sought to represent the "pan-blue alliance" to run for Kaohsiung magistrate, and agreed to let a public poll decide who should run. Results showed that Huang led in the polls. Chung bowed out of the race and re-entered in the legislative race later.

As the KMT had not approved of the polls to decide the candidate, Wu didn't take part. Wednesday's public polls were a last-ditch attempt by the KMT to solve the stalemate between Wu and Huang. Both are adamant to run to the very end against Yang Chiu-hsing of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
Wu stressed that the process of the polls was simple and just, and he believes that justice has been done, adding that he would no longer consult with Huang.
Wu regretted that Huang had proposed the polls and reneged on his commitment after the results.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FINANCIAL SYSTEM UNDER PRESSURE: STANDARD & POOR'S

TEXT.P: The financial sector of 15 countries, including Taiwan, has come under increased pressure, a report made public Wednesday by Standard & Poor's shows.

It is the fifth such analysis released by Standard & Poor's since 1997. It surveyed 68 countries. In addition to Taiwan, Argentina, mainland China, Cyprus, Egypt, Germany, Iceland, Ireland, Japan, Lebanon, Holland, Portugal, Thailand, Turkey and the United States were named in the report by the international rating agency on the pressure facing the global financial sector in 2001.

Despite the fact that different countries are in different situations, Michael DeStefano, a Standard & Poor's manager, said he made the analysis based on the common factors existing in these countries while paying attention to some major indicators such as sovereign credit, private-sector debts, and surges in assets prices.
Other elements, such as the banking sector's failure to conduct reforms, inadequate government interference, a weak economic structure, and a lack of monitoring, were also involved, DeStefano said.

In the United States, a sharp rise in bank loans and an economic slowdown are indications that the prospects of the U.S. banking system are bleak, according to the report. In Japan, it warned that a move by the Japanese government to bail out banking systems with public money could hinder Japan's AA+ sovereign credit rating.
The report did not elaborate on the situation in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SUBMARINE RUNS AGROUND, MAKES REPAIRS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Navy Fleet Command announced Thursday that one of its submarines had run aground after executing an evasive maneuver during a military exercise last week, but the damaged sonar dome has been repaired.

According to the navy, the Hai Hu ("Sea Tiger") diesel-electric submarine was engaged in a live-confrontation drill Oct. 2 in waters off of southwestern Taiwan when it made a tactical roundabout deep-dive at a depth of 150 meters and scraped a protruding area of the sea floor.

Inspections back at the submarine's home port revealed that the starboard sonar dome was "slightly indented, scraped and cracked." Repairs on the Dutch-built Zwaardvis-class ("Swordfish") vessel were made at a dry dock.
The navy reported no injuries as a result of the accident.
Commissioned in 1988, the Hai Hu is one of only four submarines in the service of the ROC Navy and carries a complement of 67 crew members.
The 2,660-ton vessel has a sister ship called the Hai Lung ("Sea Dragon"). Both are based in southern Taiwan's Tsoying Port.
The other two ROC submarines belong to the venerable U.S.-made Guppy class.
Earlier this year, the U.S. administration agreed to provide Taiwan with eight diesel-electric patrol submarines through its foreign military sales program.
A delivery date is as yet unknown because U.S. shipyards no longer build diesel-electric submarines and would have to acquire blueprints from other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT DETERMINED TO CRACK DOWN ON CURRENCY FORGERY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung reiterated Thursday that the government is determined to crack down on forgery of currency and hand down heavy punishments on those convicted of the crime.
Speaking at a Cabinet meeting, Chang said that currency forgery has become a serious problem as it has disrupted the trust between individuals.
If a vender accepted a forged NT$1,000 bill, he said that the day's hard work of the vender would be in vain.
Therefore, the premier stated that the government has resolved to eradicate currency forgery.
He also urged the public to provide clues to law enforcement authorities and not circulate fake bills.
Chang said that the Ministry of Justice called a special meeting on the matter last week to work out related measures to counter currency counterfeiting.

He added that a task force has also be formed, comprising officials from the Central Bank of China, the Coast Guard, the National Police Administration, the Bureau of Monetary Affairs under the Ministry of Finance, the Public Prosecutors' Office of the Taiwan High Court and the Investigation Bureau.

On the upcoming year-end elections for legislators, county magistrates and city mayors, Chang asked the National Police Administration to ensure that no violent incidents occur during the campaign period.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER ACCUSED OF ASSAULT IN LEGISLATURE GIVES UP RE-ELECTION BID

TEXT.P: Independent legislator Lo Fu-chu, who is widely believed to be the "spiritual leader" of the Heavenly Way Alliance gang, announced Thursday that he would not seek re-election to the new Legislative Yuan to be elected Dec. 1.

Lo made the announcement in a written statement on the last day of candidacy registration for the pivotal polls, which will determine whether the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) can gain additional legislative seats to help it to govern more effectively.

Lo's announcement also came on the eve of the expiration of a six-month suspension of his legislative duties, which he self-imposed after his assault of a female colleague in March. Lo has an extensive history of using his fists rather than his intellect to conduct legislative business.

Lo, a two-term lawmaker, said in his statement that he is remorseful for his past thuggish behavior on the legislative floor. He further said he has come to understand that being a legislator is not the only way to make a real contribution to society and the nation.

"Therefore, I have decided not to take part in the upcoming legislative elections and I will devote the rest of my life to charity or things that would benefit the general public," Lo said, adding that his passion for serving the people and society will remain unchanged after ending his current legislative term.
Lo's announcement came as a surprise to many of his legislative colleagues.
DPP legislator Shen Fu-hsiung said he believes that Lo's withdrawal will help make the upcoming elections cleaner than ever and will also mark the beginning of legislative reforms.

Just last week, Shen vowed to join forces with the four DPP nominees to run in Taipei's southern precinct to block Lo's re-election bid. Lo moved his legal abode to the metropolitan Taipei precinct earlier this year from Taipei County in an attempt to run for another legislative term in the district.

Shen, a physician-turned-lawmaker, said he believes that Lo certainly must have made a prudent calculation of his chances before deciding to abandon his re-election bid. In his view, Shen said Lo's chances of winning a new term was "less-than-certain" as the campaign gimmicks he used in Taipei County would not necessarily be useful in metropolitan Taipei.

Some other lawmakers said Lo was deeply frustrated by the Taipei Prosecutor's Office decision earlier this week to indict him for his assault on People First Party Legislator Diane Lee in March and to ask police authorities to list him as a "hooligan" to be subject to reformatory education. "This might be a decisive factor in Lo's decision to quit politics," said a legislator who preferred anonymity.

Last Wednesday, Lo harangued and intimidated members of the legislature's finance committee for one hour simply because the DPP legislative caucus had questioned the validity of electing his son Lo Ming-tsai as convener of the committee. The junior Lo, also a legislator, was elected to the committee's convener seat early this month for a third consecutive term, breaking an internal rule of the chamber that forbids any lawmaker serving as a convener of any committee for three straight sessions. The senior Lo's invective halted the committee's plan to conduct a new run of convener elections on that day.
The controversy surrounding his son's convenership might also be a factor prompting Lo to decide to forsake his re-election bid, some lawmakers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN YOUNGSTERS MAY VIE WITH M'LAND COUNTERPARTS SOON

TEXT.P: Taiwan graduates may soon have to face fierce competition from their mainland Chinese counterparts and they had better be prepared for the coming changes, a magazine that provides information on job opportunities cautioned Friday.

Chang Sheng-yuan, editor-in-chief of the monthly Career, said that in such sought-after jobs in the fields of information, finance and business management, the average monthly pay for a mainland college graduate is 2,000 renminbi per month, or just over NT$8,000, but in Taiwan, a college graduate could get between NT$30,000 and NT35,000 a month.

The monthly reported that more than 60 percent of Taiwan students could pass college entrance examinations, while there are more than four million students in the mainland hoping to squeeze into colleges and universities in a much more fierce examination.

Nine Taiwan universities specializing in certain areas of research have received a subsidie of NT$720 million each this year, but only Beijing University and Tsinghua University have received subsidies amounting to 1.8 billion (NT$7.5 billion) renminbi over a three-year period, Chang said.

Taiwan universities have also not been rigorous in asking college students to improve their English, while in mainland China, college students have to pass an equivalent of a TOFEL test above 550 points to be able to graduate.

Chang said that if young men in Taiwan are willing to work on the mainland, they will have more chances in Taiw an businesses investing in the mainland, noting that this is because Taiwan businesses are not so famous on the mainland and their images are not too good, and elite students on the mainland are still unwilling to work in Taiwan businesses.

Chang also said that Taiwan students may not have to face direct competition from their mainland counterparts in the next two years, but in the future, in the greater Chinese economy, it may be inevitable that young men that share the same language and culture on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait may become rivals.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAKES LIMITED PROGRESS IN PROTECTION OF LABOR RIGHTS: REPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Oct. 10 (CNA) (By P.C. Tang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's government has adopted encouraging steps to further protect labor rights, however, the progress is not sufficient in the eyes of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions (ICFTU).

According to a recent ICFTU investigation report about violations against unions rights among a total of 140 countries, Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party has relaxed restrictions on forming unions, and has admitted three more nationwide labor organizations since it took power in May last year.

However, the report says, Taiwan's laws permits indirect intervention by the government on labor unions' interior issues, citing as an example the government's ability to dismiss any labor union whose activities disrupt social order.

Although a court ruling in 1995 said that the right to form a union by the people is guaranteed by the Constitution, until now Taiwan's public servants, teachers, officials related to the national defense industry are still not allowed to form unions, the report adds.
In Taiwan, there are still many restrictions on strikes that make even legal walkouts very difficult and harm the rights of collective negotiations, the report said.
Because of the lack of legislation, Taiwan still lacks sufficient protection against discrimination against labor unions, according to the report.

The report also accuses many Taiwan companies doing business abroad of violating laws and labor rights of the countries in which they invest, mainly in Central America, the Caribbean, South Africa and southeastern African countries. Because of these enterprises, Taiwan's reputation has been hampered among world labor-rights protection organizations.
The report also indicated that 209 labor union members were killed last year throughout the world, with Asia being the region that violated the most labor rights.
The Brussels-based ICFTU has 221 affiliates in 140 countries, with more than 156 million members around the world. Taiwan is one of its official members.
Aside from the close cooperation with the International Labor Organization, an affiliate of the United Nations, the ICFTU is also a consulting agency for many U.N. social and economic commissions.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY POLICE EXPECTED TO HELP PATROL RAPID TRANSIT SYSTEM SOON

TEXT.P: Military police are expected to join hands with police in patrolling the stations of the Taipei Rapid Transit System (TRTS) in the next few days, TRTS police said Thursday.

TRTS police said that they have asked military police stationed in Taipei City and Taipei County to help patrol TRTS stations in consideration of passengers' security after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States and a detergent assault on passengers occurred recently at a Washington subway station.

The military police have agreed to the request in principle and will further discuss the issue with TRTS police on the details of the patrolling mission, the TRTS police said, adding that military police are expected to join the mission in the next few days.

Besides maintaining military discipline of soldiers outside barracks, military police stationed in counties and cities in Taiwan are also responsible for securing social order with the cooperation of local police.

Having received violence-quelling, anti-terror and biochemical war training, the joining of the military police in the patrol at TRTS stations will strengthen the security for the TRTS and TRTS passengers.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINOR TAIWAN POLITICAL PARTIES PROTEST U.S. ATTACKS ON AFGHANISTAN

TEXT.P: Members of a number of minor political parties in Taiwan gathered in front of the de facto U.S. representative office on Thursday to protest the U.S-led attacks against the Taliban regime in Afghanistan.

Nearly 100 protesters from the Workers' Party, the Alliance for Labor Human Rights and the Alliance for the Unification of China burned U.S. and British flags in front of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) and demanded that the "U.S.-British hegemony" immediately stop its war.

The protesters called the attacks on Afghanistan "an action akin to terrorism" because the United States has failed to present any proof that Osama bin Laden was responsible for the terrorist attacks on America on Sept. 11.
The demonstration lasted about an hour, and nearly 300 policemen were called in to maintain order.
No AIT personnel came out to meet with the protesters.
The Republic of China government and all major political parties in Taiwan have expressed their support for the U.S. attacks.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN VOWS TO PROMOTE CULTURAL DIVERSITY, SOCIAL TOLERANCE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that his administration will continue to promote cultural diversity and social tolerance in order to maintain ethnic harmony.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with a group of overseas Tibetan and Mongolian representatives who came to Taipei to attend the Republic of China's Double Ten National Day celebrations.

Chen said the ROC government will continue to promote cultural, educational and religious exchanges with Mongolia and Tibet. Chen said he is convinced that cultural diversity can help cultivate mutual respect and social tolerance and thus contribute to ethnic harmony.

In the face of new challenges in the new century, Chen said the people of Taiwan need new thinking to overcome ethnic divisions and disputes over Taiwan's relations with mainland China -- independence or unification. "And I believe promoting cultural pluralism will be helpful to cope with the issue," he said. (By Sofia Wu) EMDITEM ZCZC CEP027 10-11-01 ROCKET AMMUNITION EXPLOSION KILLS SOLDIER IN TAINAN

Taipei, Oct. 11 (CNA) One soldier was killed and another seriously injured Thursday when a rocket exploded during live-fire training at a shooting range in southern Tainan County, military sources confirmed later the same day.

Tsao Chun-teh, 26, was killed and Hung Kuei-tsao, 22, was wounded after being ordered to handle five unexploded type 66 rockets, the sources said, adding that the two soldiers may have entered a restricted area and handled live rockets by mistake.
The two were rushed to a local hospital immediately. Hung died upon arrival, while Tsao remains in a critical situation, with his right arm and right leg blown off.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROCKET AMMUNITION EXPLOSION KILLS SOLDIER IN TAINAN

TEXT.P: One soldier was killed and another seriously injured Thursday when a rocket exploded during live-fire training at a shooting range in southern Tainan County, military sources confirmed later the same day.

Tsao Chun-teh, 26, was killed and Hung Kuei-tsao, 22, was wounded after being ordered to handle five unexploded type 66 rockets, the sources said, adding that the two soldiers may have entered a restricted area and handled live rockets by mistake.
The two were rushed to a local hospital immediately. Hung died upon arrival, while Tsao remains in a critical situation, with his right arm and right leg blown off.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA CHAIRMAN TO VISIT MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The chairman of the Taipei-based China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), is slated to head for mainland China on Nov. 15 to study the mainland Chinese market, CETRA officials announced Thursday.

Shea Jia-dong, accompanied by various CETRA board and supervisory members as well as a dozen officials of local trade associations, will travel to Beijing and Shanghai. He will also visit his mainland Chinese counterparts and hold investment seminars with Taiwan businessmen there.

In addition, a CETRA-organized trade-promotion delegation will depart for mainland China on NOV. 5. It will visit Beijing, Shanghai, Chengdu and Wuhan to gain an understanding of the development of local big chain stores and hypermarkets.

DOC.HEADLINE: DECOMMISSIONED DESTROYER TO SERVE AS FISH HABITAT

TEXT.P: A decommissioned destroyer belonging to the Republic of China Navy will be sunk Saturday off the coast of Hualien, eastern Taiwan, to serve as a fish habitat, a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Thursday.

The U.S.-made destroyer Yuehyang, which is 376.5 feet long and 41.75 feet wide, will be the third military ship to serve as a fish habitat. Two decommissioned transports -- the Wanan and the Lingyun -- were sunk last year off the coasts of Ilan and Penghu, respectively.
The Yueyang began its military service in the ROC Navy in 1970 and was decommissioned in 1999.
The official noted that the two ships sunk last year have helped improve the marine ecosystem and that artificial fish habitats can also be used to promote undersea tourism and fishing.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP MIGHT WIN OVER 80 SEATS IN LEGISLATIVE ELECTION: DPP LEADER

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Secretary-General Wu Nai-jen predicted Thursday that the DPP and the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) are likely to win over 80 seats each in the Dec. 1 legislative election.

Speaking to reporters at the close of the three-day registration period for the election of lawmakers, county magistrates and city mayors, he based his prediction on the results of a recent DPP-commissioned public opinion survey.

He added that the People First Party (PFP) could get 35 seats, five seats each could be won by the New Party and the newly established Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), with 10 seats going to independent candidates.
Of the seats for the DPP and the KMT, Wu said that 19 seats each will come from the seats allocated for the nationwide constituency and for overseas Chinese residents.

He added that the PFP is likely to acquire 11 seats in these areas, while the New Party and the TSU might have no seats from these portions because their ballots might fail to reach the required 5 percent of the total ballots.

Regarding the elections for county magistrates and city mayors, Wu said that the DPP might enjoy the lead in 10 counties -- Taipei, Ilan, Hsinchu, Taichung, Nantou, Changhua, Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung -- and the cities of Keelung and Tainan.
He said the DPP candidates in Taoyuan County, Hualien County, Hsinchu City and Taichung City are in a neck-and-neck struggle.
The year-end elections will be the first major elections in Taiwan since the DPP's Chen Shui-bian won the March 18, 2000 presidential election, ending the KMT's 55-year grip on power.
As it is almost certain that no single party will control a simple legislative majority after the election, Chen has said he will form a coalition government after the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ANALYST PREDICTS INFORMATION HARDWARE NEGATIVE GROWTH IN 2002

TEXT.P: A local analyst predicted Thursday that the annual growth in production value for the global information hardware industry next year will be between 1 percent and minus 10 percent.

Market Intelligence Center (MIC) Director Chan Wen-nan said that the most optimistic forecast for Taiwan's own information hardware industry is between 4 percent and 5 percent, while the most pessimistic number is between minus 2 percent to minus 3 percent.
He added that "next year will definitely be better than this year."

Chan said that the MIC, a division of the Institute for Information Industry, had originally estimated that the annual growth in production value for the local information hardware industry would be minus 8 percent this year.
However, he continued, after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on America, the MIC adjusted that figure down to between minus 11 percent and minus 12 percent.

The U.S.-led attacks on the Taliban regime in Afghanistan have further led the MIC to adjust the growth figure even further to minus 15 percent, he said, bringing the total estimated production value for 2001 down to US$33.4 billion -- approximately the same level as it was in 1999.

A number of hardware industries that were originally estimated to be capable of growing by 100 percent or more in production value have also been affected. The annual growth rate in the production value of digital cameras, liquid crystal displays and servers made in Taiwan have been downward adjusted to between 60 percent and 70 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAPARAZZI INDICTED FOR ENTERING PRESIDENTIAL RESIDENCE

TEXT.P: Four members of staff of Taiwan's Next Magazine who intruded into the presidential residence to cover the engagement ceremony of the president's daughter in July will face public trial, a Taipei prosecutor said Thursday.

Prosecutor Ke Yi-fen said the four people -- a reporter, two photographers and a driver -- tried to pass themselves off as members of the president's family in an attempt to cover the July 1 engagement ceremony of Chen Hsing-yu and her fiancee, Chao Chien-ming.

Ke said the four were charged with trespassing and dismissed their claim that they had become caught up in the cavalcade of vehicles entering the presidential grounds at the time and were unable to maneuver to get out of the grounds.
However, he also said that as they did not offer any resistance to the guards, they would not be charged with any offense against public officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: 458 HOPEFULS SIGN UP TO RUN FOR 176 LEGISLATIVE SEATS

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission announced Thursday that a total of 458 hopefuls have signed up to run for the 168 regional legislative seats and eight aboriginal legislative seats around the country in the Dec. 1 elections.

The commission added that another 90 hopefuls have signed up to run for the 23 available county chief and city mayor positions in the elections, meaning that only 25.55 percent of the candidates will emerge victorious.
Only 38.42 percent of the legislative candidates will be elected to the 225-seat Legislative Yuan.

The remaining seats will be partially filled by 41 legislators-at-large, to be determined according to a system of proportional representation among the various political parties. The more seats that a party wins in the regional legislative elections, the more legislator-at-large seats it gains.

In addition to the 41 legislators-at-large, eight other seats are reserved for overseas Chinese representatives who will be elected according to the same formula for proportional representation among political parties.

Twelve out of 97 registered political parties nominated a total of 325 candidates to run in the regional legislative elections and the aboriginal district legislative elections. Independent candidates and candidates who were running without their party's support accounted for another 133 sign-ups.

The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) nominated 98 candidates to run in the regional legislative elections, followed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) with 83 candidates, the opposition People First Party (PFP) with 61 candidates, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) with 39 candidates and the opposition New Party (NP) with 33 candidates.
The seven remaining parties have nominated fewer than three candidates each.
Five political parties nominated a total of 53 candidates in the running for county chiefs and city mayors, while another 37 candidates were running on their own without the backing of a party.

The KMT fielded 23 candidates to run for county chiefs and city mayors, the DPP chose 22 candidates, the PFP selected six candidates, the NP picked one candidate and the Green Party backed one candidate.
The KMT also nominated 39 legislator-at-large candidates and eight overseas legislator candidates, while the DPP nominated 23 legislator-at-large candidates and five overseas legislator candidates.
The KMT originally nominated 41 legislator-at-large candidates, but Chang Ming-chih, who ranked 28th on the list, and Lin Hui-kuan, who ranked 34th, decided not to accept their nominations.
Lin, who is president of the Chinese Federation of Labor, had accepted a nomination to rank fifth on the PFP list.
The list's arrangement of order indicates the party's order of preference and will therefore affect the candidates' chances of becoming legislators-at-large in the elections.

The PFP nominated 23 legislator-at-large candidates and five overseas legislator candidates, the TSU nominated 15 legislator-at-large candidates and one overseas legislator candidate, and the NP nominated eight legislator-at-large candidates and two overseas legislator candidates.

For the first time in the Republic of China's election history, two political party chairmen were included on the lists submitted to the Central Election Commission for legislator-at-large candidates.

PFP Chairman James Soong, who is a former Taiwan provincial governor, was entered on the PFP legislator-at-large candidates list in 11th spot, while TSU Chairman Huang Chu-wen, who is a former interior minister, was included on the TSU list in 15th place.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC EMBASSY IN PANAMA MARKS ROC NATIONAL DAY
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Oct. 11 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Embassy in Panama held a party Wednesday to celebrate the ROC's 90th national day at a local hotel, with more than 700 foreign dignitaries attending.

ROC Ambassador C.Y. Hu and his wife greeted the guests, who included ranking Panamanian officials, including First Vice President Alberto Vallarino, Second Vice President Dominador Bazan and Foreign Minister Jose Miguel Aleman.

Hu thanked Panama for its support of the ROC's efforts to join the United Nations and other international organizations and said that bilateral relations were further cemented after Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso visited Taiwan last year and ROC President Chen Shui-bian visited the Central American country earlier this year.

The ROC, now the world's 17th-largest trading nation, has transformed itself into a democratic and free country, Hu said. While the country's foreign reserves hit more than US$110 billion, per-capita income of the people of Taiwan reached US$14,216 in 2000, he added.
The ROC ambassador also praised the contributions made by ROC agricultural and technical missions to the upgrading of the living standards of the Panamanian people.
Vallarino, Bazan and Aleman toasted Hu and wished good health and prosperity upon the ROC president and people.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT COULD REMAIN BIGGEST PARTY AFTER ELECTION: KMT OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A ranking official of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Thursday that the KMT might remain the nation's biggest party after the Dec. 1 legislative election.

Chao Shou-po, chairman of the KMT Organizational Development Committee, said that 97 candidates will run for election in regional constituencies on the KMT ticket, 66 of whom are incumbent legislators, while 31 others are new faces.

Besides the candidates for the regional constituencies, the KMT also nominated 39 candidates for the 41 seats allocated for the nationwide constituency and named eight others to vie for the eight seats for overseas Chinese legislators.
Chao predicted that the KMT will win about 90 seats in the legislative election to retain its status at the largest party in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan.

However, ruling Democratic Progressive Party Secretary-General Wu Nai-jen said that the DPP and the KMT might win 80 seats each in the election, which will be the first major election since the DPP won the March 18, 2000 presidential election.

As it is unlikely that any single party will win a simple majority in the election, President Chen Shui-bian has stated that regardless of the results of the election, he will form a coalition government after the election.
Regarding the elections for county magistrates and city mayors, the KMT nominated 23 candidates and the DPP nominated 22 candidates during the three-day registration period that ended that day.
The KMT hopes to win in seven counties -- Taoyuan, Hsinchu, Taichung, Changhua, Yunlin, Chiayi and Tainan -- and in the cities of Hsinchu, Taichung and Chiayi.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WILL TAKE STEPS TO PREVENT TERRORIST MONEY LAUNDERING

TEXT.P: A spokeswoman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that the ROC government supports the U.S.-launched war against terrorism and has taken steps to prevent terrorists from laundering money in Taiwan.

Chang Siao-yueh said that the government has no plans to dispatch military personnel to join the U.S.-led military action in Afghanistan and added that the United States has not requested such action.

She stressed that the government's support for the United States will be mainly evident in two areas -- providing humanitarian assistance for the Afghan people and preventing terrorists from laundering money in Taiwan.
She said that relevant government units have tightened security measures at airports and harbors to prevent terrorists from infiltrating the country or carrying out acts of sabotage.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESULT OF 1ST STAGE OF NATIONAL ENGLISH EVALUATION EXAM UNVEILED

TEXT.P: The results of the first stage of a nationwide English evaluation examination for people with a junior high school education background were unveiled Thursday.
The tests are part of a government drive to urge people to improve their English-language ability levels in order to better compete in a rapidly globalizing economy

The Language Training and Testing Center (LTTC), which organized the examination, said the pass rate for the three-part test -- listening comprehension, reading and writing ability -- was 42 percent, with female examinees reaching an average pass rate of 43 percent and male examinees reaching an average of 40 percent.
The average scores were 83.31 out of a possible score of 120, 83.98 and 64.75, respectively, LTTC officials said.
A total of 31,014 people took the examination, of whom 12,932 passed.
The LTTC set 80 as a passing score for listening comprehension and reading comprehension parts of the examination and 70 as a passing mark for writing ability.
People from Taipei were better at listening comprehension, while Chiayi examinees were better at reading comprehension and writing ability, according to LTTC officials.
The youngest and the oldest people who passed the first stage of the examination were aged seven and 61, respectively.
Those who passed the first stage of the examination can register for the second stage -- spoken English -- before Oct. 26. The examination will take place Nov. 24 or Nov. 25, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 12, or the 26th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1492: After a month of experiencing mirages of land, explorer Christopher Columbus and his three ships sight "terra firma" at dawn.
1822: Brazil gains its independence from Portugal.
1901: Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th president of the United States, renames the Executive Mansion "The White House." He won the 1908 Nobel Peace Prize for his mediation in the Russo-Japanese War.
1920: Bertrand A. W. Russell, British philosopher, mathematician, social critic, and writer who won the 1950 Nobel Prize for literature, arrives in Shanghai as a visiting professor. He had a profound influence on the development of symbolic logic, logical positivism, and the set theory of mathematics.
1949: The Republic of China government moves its seat from Canton to Chungking.
1959: The United Nations General Assembly votes for a full-scale debate on Communist Chinese bloodshed in Tibet.
1960: Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev, angered during a debate on colonialism at the United Nations General Assembly, takes off his shoe and ponds his desk with it several times.
1964: The Republic of China and the Republic of Korea sign a friendship treaty in Taipei.
1968: The 19th Olympic Games opens in Mexico City, capital of Mexico.
1971: Dean Acheson, U.S. politician and secretary of state from 1949 to 1953, dies at the age of 78. He promoted the Marshall Plan and helped established NATO.
1974: Paul M. Popple, newly appointed deputy chief of the U.S. mission in the ROC, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1974: Juan Pao-shan, a Chinese student from Taiwan, is stabbed and killed in Los Angeles by leftists at a party in celebration of the Double Ten National Day of the Republic of China.
1976: Communist China's Prime Minister Hua Guofeng becomes chairman of the Chinese Communist Party.
1977: The Civil Aeronautics Administration of the Communications Ministry inaugurates radar control in Taiwan air-space.
1979: Fidel Castro, head of the Cuban government, delivers a speech at the United Nations General Assembly, requesting more U.N. aid for Third World countries.
1983: A Tokyo district court sentences former Japanese Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka to four years' imprisonment for his part in the Lockheed bribery scandal.
1984: In a move to further expand bilateral trade and economic relations, the ROC-Australia Trade Association and the Chinese-New Zealand Business Council are formally inaugurated in Taipei.
1987: South Korea adopts a new constitution allowing direct election of the president by the people rather than by the electoral college.
1989: The Republic of China and Belize announce the establishment of diplomatic relations.
1989: Direct telephone links between Taiwan and the offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu are completed.
1989: King Mswati III of Swaziland arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1992: A strong earthquake rocks Cairo, killing 552 people and injuring nearly 10,000 others.
1992: Premier Hau Pei-tsun receives Austrian Minister for Economic Affairs Wolfgang Schussel.
1999: The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics estimates that property losses in Taiwan resulting from the Sept. 21 earthquake total US$9.2 billion.
2000: A groundbreaking ceremony for the construction of Taiwan's first privately run hydraulic power plant is held at Wushantou Reservoir in Tainan County.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The life of the moral man is unobtrusive and yet it grows more and more in significance; whereas the life of the vulgar person is ostentatious, but it losses more and more in significance until it becomes nothingness."
