DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 11.57 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Friday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 11.57 points to close at 3,801.5.
Market turnover amounted to NT$72.31 billion (US$2.09 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CHANG EXTENDS GREETINGS TO BEDRIDDEN `YOUNG MARSHAL'

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung extended his greetings Friday via an ROC liaison office in the United States to the family of Chang Hsueh-liang, who is known for his role in the 1936 Xian Incident and who recently checked into a hospital in Hawaii for illness and senility.

Chang expressed his concern for the headline maker in the tumultuous period in modern Chinese history prior to the 1940s via the representative office, wishing the 101-year-old "Young Marshal" a speedy recovery and long life.

Refuting recent news reports that have said the "Young Marshal" was in critical condition and that his son had refused to consent to the use of life-support devices to keep the elder Chang alive, Chang Hsueh-liang's son publicized an open letter Thursday announcing that although his father is currently in the intensive care unit of a Honolulu hospital, his condition is rather stable and he does not require a respirator.

Premier Chang, who paid a visit to Chang Hsueh-liang at Chang's Honolulu residence in early September this year on his way back to Taiwan after a four-nation official tour to the Eastern Caribbean, recalled that the marshal was in good health then except for a hearing weakness.
The premier recalled that Chang, a devout Christian, was in high spirits during the visit and even composed a poem right on the spot as a gift to him.

Chang Hsueh-liang, son of northeastern mainland Chinese warlord Chang Tso-lin, played a key role in the kidnapping of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in 1936 in order to persuade Chiang to go all out against Japanese aggression, an incident known in contemporary Chinese history as the "Xian Incident."

Chang Hsueh-liang, who along with his father possessed prominent military and business influence in northern China at the time, became a flash point figure in Chinese politics on Dec. 29, 1928, when he pledged allegiance to the Nationalist government led by Chiang Kai-shek.

But a key incident in Chinese history took place on Dec. 12, 1936, when Generalissimo Chiang flew to Xian to order Chang and army general Yang Hu-cheng to attack the Chinese communists. However, Chang instead detained Chiang. It was not until two weeks later, with the nation clamoring for Chiang's release, that the generalissimo was freed.

Chang lived under virtual house arrest for nearly half a century after moving to Taiwan along with the ROC government in 1949. He regained his freedom only after President Lee Teng-hui democratized Taiwan.

Chang and his wife moved to Hawaii in 1993 and have since lived in seclusion. He and his wife, who died several years ago, went to church, listened to Chinese opera and played mahjong, but always stayed away from the media.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 11.57 points to close at 3,801.5.

The bourse opened at 3,898.36 but began to go down later due to a decline in financial share prices following heavy profit-taking selling. The index fluctuated between 3,898.36 and 3,769.89 during trading.

A total of 3.04 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$72.31 billion (US$2.09 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.74 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$50.82 billion (US$1.47 billion).
Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with electrical stocks moving up the most at 1.9 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 0.3 percent, and cement stocks at 0.1 percent.

The other major categories posted losses, with bank and insurance stocks moving down the most at 3.4 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 2.8 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.1 percent, textile issues 0.8 percent, and construction stocks at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 351 to 188, with 90 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were generally lower on Friday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for October moved down 20 points to close at 3,825, with 18,317 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for November lost 13 points to finish at 3,825, with 2,111 contract transactions, while December futures decreased 21 points to finish at 3,794, with 17 contracts traded.
Next March futures gained 40 points to finish at 3,950, with three contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 3,845 for October, 3,838 for November, 3,815 for December, 3,910 for next March, and 3,864 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
October TE futures moved up 2.9 points to close at 183.45, with 5,688 contract transactions, while November TE futures increased 2.1 points to finish at 182.5, with 604 contracts traded.
December TE futures gained 3.6 points to close at 181, with eight contracts traded, while next March TE futures rose 6.2 points to close at 184, with two contract transactions.
Next June TE futures moved up 1.45 points to finish at 180.5, with 24 contracts changing hands.
October TF futures fell 28.6 points to finish at 582, with 3,009 contract transactions, while November TF futures increased 29 points to close at 582, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOTH INBOUND AND OUTBOUND PASSENGERS REGISTER GROWTH

TEXT.P: Despite a lingering economic slowdown, both inbound and outbound passengers registered growth in the first half of this year, the Tourism Bureau reported Friday.
According to the bureau's tallies, the number of inbound visitors totaled more than 1.38 million between January and June this year, marking a 10.64 percent increase from the year-earlier level.
During the same six-month period, the number of outbound travelers reached 3.7 million, up 3.67 percent from the figure recorded for the like period of last year.
Meanwhile, Republic of China nationals made 54.38 million visits in the first half of the year, marking a 2.8 percent annual growth.
Tourist officials said the Tourism Bureau has been endeavoring to promote Taiwan as an "island of tourism" in the international travel market.
The bureau has commissioned multinational advertising companies to draw up comprehensive promotional packages to help attract foreign tourists, the officials said.
"We are crafting a new international image for Taiwan in order to realize our goal of posting a 10 percent gain in the number of tourist arrivals annually," said a bureau official.

According to the official, Japan remained the largest source of foreign tourists to Taiwan. As many Japanese youths like to travel abroad for short-term study, the official said the Tourism Bureau is encouraging local senior high schools and vocational schools to organize various study programs, including Chinese language and history courses, to lure young Japanese travelers.
The official said the bureau will also help local schools launch promotional programs in Japan in cooperation with local and Japanese travel agencies.

Moreover, the official said, the bureau is creating an Internet portal to provide comprehensive Taiwan-related tourist information and other relevant data to facilitate promotional operations and attract would-be visitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL UNIVERSITY TO OPEN EMBA CLASSES IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Yuan Ze University in Chungli, northern Taiwan, has jumped the gun by offering the first EMBA classes to Taiwan business people operating in mainland China, faculty sources at the school said Friday.

Yuan Ze University's management school began to receive registration reservations Friday for credits to be earned in the EMBA extension program. By doing so, it became the first Taiwan-based institute to begin offering extension programs outside the island since the Ministry of Education acquiesced to local universities' demands in August to be allowed to offer extension programs in Southeast Asia and mainland China.

Since the extension education program will not legitimately take effect until February, Lee Yung-hui, director of the Yuan Ze Institute of Management, said the school only began to receive reservations for the EMBA credit-granting program Friday, adding that the students to-be do not need to pay their tuition until the classes are formally opened.

The Yuan Ze management school is expected to initially open classes in three subjects in the credit-granting EMBA program, which will be available for Taiwan businesspeople at three schools in Guangzhou, Beijing and Shanghai, according to Lee.

Education Ministry officials said earlier this year that the extension classes to be opened in mainland China will cater only to Taiwan businesspeople until such time as the government grants credentials to mainland Chinese schools.
They said the Taiwan-initiated extension programs will be opened to mainland Chinese students only after the government has certified the academic excellence of mainland Chinese schools.

Although Education Minister Ovid Tzeng has said he hopes the policy of acknowledging academic credits granted by mainland Chinese schools will be confirmed by the end of the year, many local universities have jumped the gun by contracting mainland Chinese school authorities in the hopes of opening extension classes for Taiwan businesspeople there.
Under the ministry's plan, credits earned in the extension programs will be applicable toward a bachelor's or master's degree.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMUNICATIONS MINISTRY CONSIDERS LOW PRICE TAG FOR 3G LICENSES

TEXT.P: The vice minister of communications said Thursday that the Ministry of Transportation and Communications will issue five licenses to operate third-generation (3G) mobile phone services through auction, with a low price tag to encourage more bidding.
Tsai Duei noted that the ministry approved that day the regulatory provisions for 3G -- also known as UTMS (universal mobile telecommunications system) -- services.

At least seven telecommunications and wireless telecommunications service companies have shown interest in bidding -- Chunghwa Telecom, Teco Electric and Machinery, ET Group, First International Telecom Group, Far Eastone, Taiwan Cellular Corp. and KG Telecommunications.
Tsai said that the government will announce the price of the bids "soon."

He pointed out that some European telecommunications authorities have grossed billions of dollars from 3G mobile phone proceeds. However, as the economic climate is chilly, auctions in other countries have been disappointing.

UTMS offers broadband services, which allow high-speed data transmission and provide Internet and video links. Market experts have said that commercial 3G services might not be available until 2003 at the earliest and some European telecommunication firms are facing huge problems over the introduction of 3G technology.
The information technology consultant Gartner says in a recent report that building on the 3G networks will be expensive and a slow supply of terminals will delay the commercial services.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.003 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at 34.550.
The local currency opened Friday at 34.560 and was traded between 34.534 and 34.560.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$305 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT URGES TSU SUPPORT TO STABILIZE POLITICAL SITUATION

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui urged the public Friday to support Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) candidates in the year-end legislative elections to help stabilize the political situation.
Lee, the spiritual leader of the recently formed political group, made the appeal as he stumped for TSU legislative candidates Tsai Chung-chi, Chen Chien-ming and Chiu Kuo-chang in Taipei City.

Lee said that the instability of Taiwan's political scene is the fault of a chaotic legislature. Referring to KMT Chairman Lien Chan but refraining from mentioning him by name, he said that "someone" even tried to recall President Chen Shui-bian because he could not accept defeat in the presidential election.
Lee said that the president wants to push through many reforms, but the legislature will not lend its support, a stance which he said runs counter to the spirit of democracy.
Saying he has high expectation of the Taiwan people, Lee said that the public should help and support Chen during his four-year presidency.

He stressed that the year-end elections will be crucial to the stability of Taiwan in the coming century and urged people to vote for the candidates of a party that can help solidify the nation and work with the government.
The former president urged the public to help Chen realize the goals of stabilizing the political situation, solidifying democracy, stimulating the economy and strengthening Taiwan.
Lee said that although he is a octogenarian, he wanted to come forward to help stabilize the political situation because "the boat of Taiwan shall not sink."

On the rush of local businessmen deserting Taiwan in favor of mainland China, Lee said that economic prosperity in the mainland is limited to certain parts, which he claimed have been built up through the thousands of billions of dollars pouring in from Taiwan, a situation he likened to an unstable house that could collapse at any time. He further claimed that "80 percent of the Taiwan businessmen in the mainland lost money."
According to Lee, the per capita income in Taiwan is US$12,000, compared with US$800 in the mainland. Amid the economic sluggishness, he urged the public to work hard and vote in Dec. 1 election.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS FORM TASK FORCE TO MONITOR TERRORISM

TEXT.P: The legislative caucuses of the ruling and opposition parties decided Friday to form a task force to monitor the effect on Taiwan of the changing international situation in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on New York and Washington.
National Security Council officials and various Cabinet ministers will be invited to present reports to the task force on a regular basis.

Last Tuesday, President Chen Shui-bian invited the leaders of the opposition parties and Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng to hear a briefing from officials in charge of security affairs, after which, on Wang's suggestion, Chen instructed relevant government units to make a briefing to the Legislative Yuan.

The president and vice president of the Legislative Yuan will serve as convener and vice convener of the task force, which will have four members from the Kuomintang, three from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, two from the People First Party, one from the New Party and one from the non-partisan alliance.

The Republic of China government has stated its firm support for the U.S.-led military actions against terrorism and has taken steps to prevent terrorists from infiltrating the country or engaging in acts of sabotage.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES REBOUND CONSIDERABLY

TEXT.P: Local share prices rebounded considerably in the past week, stimulated by the upward trend of international stock markets, especially in the electronics sector, market analysts said Friday.

A report released by the Barits Securities Investment Trust Co. indicates that the weighted price index -- the market's key barometer -- dropped by 66 percent, from 10,202 points Feb. 27, 2000 to 3,446 points Oct. 3 this year.

Not only have the traditional manufacturing industries -- such as cement, construction, textiles, paper, rubber and plastics, food and nutrition -- suffered tremendous losses, the electronics sector was also hard hit in terms of stock prices, according to the report.
It adds that in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York and Washington, Taiwan's stock prices slid further, with the electronics and construction sectors suffering the most.

As the anticipation of war kept international stock markets in suspense, the Oct. 8 launching of military action against the Taliban regime in Afghanistan by the United States provided a release for markets around the world.

The weighted price index of the Taiwan Stock Exchange rebounded by nearly 10 percent between Oct. 3 and Oct. 11, with the monetary, automobile, electronics and steel sectors enjoying the best performances, according to the report.

The report points out that prices of electronic shares moved up an average 13 percent in the past week, partially reflecting the market atmosphere and also revealing the "irrational" downfall in the past month.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, MAINLAND CHINESE AVIATION REPS AGREE TO FLY WITHOUT FLAGS
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Oct. 12 (CNA) (By Liu Cheng-ching and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Representatives of Taiwanese and mainland Chinese aviation industries agreed at a seminar Friday that if direct bilateral flights are possible in the future, then all aircraft plying the routes will fly without their respective national flags.

Visiting Republic of China Legislator Elmer Fung of the opposition New Party, who was at the head of the Taiwan delegation, along with Civil Aviation Administration of China Deputy Director Bao Peide, made the announcement together after the seminar.

They announced that the two sides also came to the agreement that both Taiwan and mainland China have already taken immense losses in terms of time or money because direct bilateral air routes are still illegal.
They said that the survival and development of the aviation industries on both sides of the Taiwan Strait depends on the opening of direct flights.

The aviation representatives agreed that the technical and operational aspects of direct flights between Taiwan and the mainland are no longer problems because they can be resolved through negotiation.

The two sides said that they hope to rely on private sector aviation organizations to carry on with regularly or irregularly scheduled evaluations on related technical or operational issues while expanding the topics of discussion.

They also expressed the hope that the aviation industries on both sides of the Taiwan Strait can convene a cross-strait flight safety and aviation security seminar in response to the global repercussions of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on America.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MAKES AERIAL INSPECTION OF HIGH-SPEED RAILWAY PROJECT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian made an aerial inspection of the ongoing high-speed railway construction project Friday, starting from Taipei and ending at the Chingchuankang air base in the central Taiwan county of Taichung.

Chen told a news conference held at the air base that as the issue regarding the impact of the high-speed railway's vibration on the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park has been resolved, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC) Chairman Morris Chang had informed him that the company has decided to resume construction of its new production facilities in the park. TSMC is the world's largest microchip foundry service.

The president went on to say that he hopes the bullet train project can be completed by October 2005 as scheduled to provide fast, high-quality inter-city travel services along Taiwan's western corridor.

The high-speed railway, with a length of 345 km and trains running at a maximum speed of 300 km per hour, is expected to drastically shorten the terrestrial travel time between Taipei in the north and Kaohsiung in the south.

Noting that once the new railway is open to traffic, a trip from Taipei to Kaohsiung with a single stop at Taichung will take only about 90 minutes, Chen said the completion of the project will represent a transport revolution for the country.
At the moment, Chen said, he is not only concerned about the completion date of the new rail system but also about relevant planning work.

Chen said he has two expectations concerning the development of the high-speed railway project -- that the government should hammer out a comprehensive development plan integrating railway, highway, air and maritime transport services and that the central and local governments should join forces to craft new regional development projects in the vicinity of the 14 cities and counties and the 10 stations through which the railway will pass.

As construction of the new railway will certainly affect the everyday lives of those residing in areas near the construction sites, Chen said relevant government agencies and the Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) should streamline management and supervision of contractors and strengthen communications with local residents to seek their support and understanding.

Meanwhile, THSRC Chairwoman Nita Ing said construction on the high-speed railway, with a price tag of NT$407.6 billion (US$11.82 billion), has been proceeding smoothly and will gradually shift into high gear early next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PROPERTY MARKET OPENS TO FOREIGNERS

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan gave its final approval Friday to an amendment to the current law that allows foreigners to buy land in Taiwan for personal use or business purposes.

According to the amendment, foreigners will be permitted to buy landlots in Taiwan for own use or for investment and business purposes, as long as their applications are approved by central government business authorities.

It also stipulates that should foreign landowners fail to use the land in accordance with their application purpose within the approved time, they must sell off their property within three years of receiving notice from the local government.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE SEIZE 30,000 PIRATED CDS AND CDROMS

TEXT.P: Police arrested a couple and netted a haul of more than 30,000 pirated CDs and CDROMs Friday worth NT$3 million (US$86,455), when they raided a warehouse in Luchu Township, Taoyuan County.
Police said that they received a recent tip-off that large vehicles were taking delivery of goods from the warehouse in suspicious circumstances.
Police raided the warehouse and found the CDROMs, which included pirated music, pornography and computer software.
The arrested suspects, Chiu Hsien-chi, and his wife Chan Shu-feng, admitted that they were lured into the reproduction and selling of the pirated CDROMS because of the profits available.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPUTER INDUSTRY FACING MOUNTING INTERNATIONAL COMPETITION: MIC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's computer industry is facing mounting international competition and the production value of the hardware sector may register negative growth this year, according to a report by the Market Information Center (MIC) of the Institute for Information Industry.
MIC Director Chan Wen-nan said at a symposium Friday that the hardware manufacturing sector will face a severe challenge, especially from mainland China.

The MIC invited market experts from mainland China's information sector to speak on the prospects of mainland China's computer software and telecommunications industries at the symposium co-sponsored by the III and the Taipei Computer Association.

According to Chan, the Taiwan high technology industry's interest in the mainland China market is an "irreversible trend" and that the computer industry should study ways to coordinate the advantages of both sides of the Taiwan Strait for future development.
Production value of the computer hardware manufacturing industry grew by 34 percent in 1995, but the growth rate continued to drop in the subsequent years, according to Chan.

DOC.HEADLINE: BIRD SOCIETY BEGINS GENERAL SURVEY OF BLACK-FACED SPOONBILLS

TEXT.P: A Tainan-based bird conservation society said Friday that they are conducting a general survey of black-faced spoonbills and urged the public not to destroy the natural Taiwan habitat of the endangered species.

Thousands of migratory birds representing more than 30 species arrive in Taiwan each autumn, especially at the mouth of the Tsengwen Creek in Tainan County, southern Taiwan, to spend the winter, according to the Tainan County Black-faced Spoonbill Preservation Society.

The black-faced spoonbill, one of the world's rarest birds with only an estimated 600-700 remaining, attract the most attention. Generally about half of the world population of the birds migrate to Taiwan every winter, according to a society member.

The member noted that 33 black-faced spoonbills have arrived so far this year, attracting many bird watchers to the mouth of the Tsengwen Creek. He predicted that more of the birds will arrive, especially after November, and added that Tainan's environmental protection organizations will launch activities Sunday to welcome the arrival of the birds.

The member also said that although the society focuses mainly on the black-faced spoonbill, it will also increase its observation of other kinds of birds this year to better understand the interaction among the various species.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL CREDIT CARD SWINDLERS BROUGHT BACK TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Seven Republic of China nationals who had been given suspended jail terms by a South Korean court for credit card fraud returned to Taiwan Friday under police escort.
The seven men, including Cheng Cheng-shan, 53, were transferred to the Kaohsiung Prosecutor's Office on charges of document forgery shortly after their return, police authorities said.

According to police, Cheng and his accomplices used fake credit cards provided by a South Korean man of Chinese descent to purchase high-grade ginseng, priced at NT$70,000 (about US$2,029) per box, in South Korea from March this year.
The ring then sold the ginseng at a 15 percent discount, earning about NT$10 million by July, when they were arrested by South Korean police.
A South Korean court ordered the deportation of Cheng and six other ring members after giving them suspended prison terms early this month.
Police said at least five other members of the credit card fraud ring were still being detained in South Korea as their sentences were not suspended.

They also said that some other ring members are in hiding somewhere in Taiwan. A 26-year-old man, identified only by his family name Yang, was arrested at Kaohsiung International Airport in June for allegedly having used 40-plus fake credit cards to purchase goods in South Korea, Hong Kong and Southeast Asian countries.
The man might belong to Cheng's ring, an airport police officer said, adding that the Criminal Investigation Bureau is conducting an extensive probe into the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: SURVEY REVEALS MOST LOCAL MEN UNWORRIED ABOUT BALDNESS

TEXT.P: Taiwan males take a combined average of 13,000 pills each day to arrest baldness, although most men deny that they worry much about being bald, according to a survey conducted recently by a pharmaceutical company.
The sales of baldness remedies would be much greater in Taiwan if more people were to seek medical help for baldness, according to the survey results.
The survey found that only about 16 percent of men in Taiwan whose hairline began to recede at the age of 20 seek medical help, while most of them just accept their hair loss as a fact of life.

The random survey of 600 males aged between 18 and 49 in Taiwan's three major cities found that only 14 percent of them consider themselves bald. Of them, only 33 percent took concrete action, including using medicated shampoo, scalp care, seeking folk prescriptions to taking Western medicine, in that order.

Most respondents have not taken any action with regard to their baldness because they feel the issue is unimportant, because treatment is too troublesome or because they do not know where to find treatment, in that order, the survey found.

According to U.S.-based MSD, the pharmaceutical company which produces the renowned anti baldness treatment Propecia, the company has sold nine million pills since the medicine was allowed to be marketed in Taiwan 22 months ago, or an average of 13,000 per day. The active ingredient in the product is finasteride 1 mg.

According to Wu Min-chi, a dermatologist at Cathay General Hospital, while Propecia is so far one of the most effective treatments for androgenic alopecia -- male pattern baldness -- it is not recommended as treatment for all kinds of baldness.

Another MSD-developed medicine -- Poscar, which contains 5 mg finasteride and was originally developed for treatment of enlarged prostate, has also been used by Taiwan consumers as a baldness remedy. The medicine, however, is not recommended by dermatologists because of its high dose of finasteride.
Improper or excessive use of both Propecia and Poscar can cause side effects such as sexual dysfunction, Wu noted.
Women who suffer baldness, especially pregnant women, are generally not recommended to use Propecia as it can harm the male fetus, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN EXPORTS KAOLIANG TO MAINLAND CHINA VIA `MINI THREE LINKS'

TEXT.P: The Directorate General of Customs under the Ministry of Finance announced Friday that "kaoliang" liquor from the island of Kinmen was exported to mainland China through the "mini three links" mechanism for the first time in September.

According to the ministry's statistics, a total of 3,032 kilograms of the sorghum liquor valued at NT$392,050 (US$11,350) were shipped to mainland China directly from the island, which lies much closer to the mainland than it does to Taiwan.
In the past, such exports have always been routed via a third area like Hong Kong or Macau.

This marked the first time that Kinmen Kaoliang Liquor Inc. has taken advantage of Taiwan's new policy established in January to allow direct shipping, trade, and postal links between the islands of Kinmen and Matsu and their corresponding designated ports on the mainland.

According to government statistics, the Kinmen branch of the Kaohsiung Customs Bureau has recorded a total of 26 cases of imports to Kinmen from January to September, and four cases of exports from Kinmen during the same period.
The Matsu branch of the Keelung Customs Bureau recorded eight cases of imports to Matsu and no cases of exports from the frontline island from January to September.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMOSAN MACAQUES STEALING GOATS MILK: LOCAL FARMERS

TEXT.P: Farmers in southern Taiwan have reported that Formosan macaques, a protected primate species, are becoming so outrageous that they are now milking goats, a local evening newspaper reported Friday.
The United Evening News quoted Tsai Fu-ching, chief of Tsaishan Li (an administrative unit) in Kaohsiung City, who confirmed the reports.

Tsaishan residents said that they have often seen the monkeys milking goats in the past, adding that they tended to appear in the morning and would hang around with the goats in order to steal their food. Not satisfied with this petty larceny, they then grab the goats' teats and milk them.
Tsai said that the sheep do not resist and do not seem alarmed by the monkeys, possibly because they are so used to their presence.

The farmers claimed that the monkeys have become more and more bold recently, with one owner claiming that his daily take of around 20 liters of milk has dropped to no more than 10 liters in recent months.
One local expert said the monkeys might be stealing milk because Kaohsiung city authorities have prohibited people from feeding them and they are starving as a result.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMY WILL REGISTER NEGATIVE GROWTH THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: The effects of two destructive typhoons in a row and the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States will contribute to Taiwan's economy registering negative growth this year, a local economic research institute said Friday.
The Chung-Hua Institute for Economic Research (CIER) said that Taiwan's economic growth rate in the fourth quarter and the whole of this year will be in negative territory.
The CIER revised downward its original estimated figure for Taiwan's economic growth rate in 2001 to between minus 1 percent and minus 2 percent.
It said the recovery of the island's economy would not happen until next year.
The CIER predicted in the third quarter that Taiwan's economic growth rate for the fourth quarter would stand at 4.42 percent and that of the whole year at 2.2 percent.
It previously forecasted that Taiwan's economic growth rate in 2002 would be at 4.39 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: OLDEST CENTENARIANS IN TAIWAN TURN 116

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior announced Friday that it was able to register a total of 555 centenarians during its household census visits throughout Taiwan this year, with the oldest two being 116 years old.
According to the ministry, both 116-year-old centenarians are women and live in Taipei.
The oldest man is 108 years old and lives in eastern Taiwan's Hualien County.
Compared to last year, 59 more people crossed the centenarian threshold this year.

Among all the cities and counties, Taipei has the largest centenarian population, at 116. Another 74 reside in Taipei County, and 56 in Taoyuan County, making up the three regions with the highest number of centenarians.
The majority of centenarians, 91.35 percent, or 507 individuals, are between the ages of 100 and 104.
Forty-four centenarians are aged between 105 and 109, and only four centenarians are 110 years or older.
The male centenarian population gained 13 newcomers this year to reach 141, and the female centenarian population gained 46 newcomers to reach 414.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANY TAIWAN PEOPLE DO NOT THINK KMT IS 'FOREIGN POWER': POLL

TEXT.P: Many people in Taiwan do not agree with the remarks of former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui that the opposition Kuomintang is a "foreign power," according to results of a opinion poll released Friday.

The poll, commissioned by KMT Legislator Wu Ko-ching, who is also chairman of a public affairs and policy study association, was conducted between Oct. 5-10 based on telephone interviews. The survey, which received 1,071 valid respondents, had a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percent.
Lee, who is also former chairman of the KMT, has recently made numerous remarks hinting that the KMT is a "foreign power" and its leaders are fighting with Communist China against Taiwan.

The results of the poll found that 65 percent of respondents did not agree with Lee's intimation that the KMT is a "foreign power," while 62 percent did not think that the KMT is "cooperating" with mainland China against Taiwan.

The survey also found that 56 percent did not think that the KMT's plan to remove President Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressive Party from office last year was because it could not face the reality of its failure in the 2000 presidential election.
Sixty-eight percent think that Lee backs Taiwan independence, according to the poll.

As to how the KMT should respond to the verbal attacks from Lee, opinions were varied, with 31 percent maintaining that the KMT should react strongly; 26 percent said the KMT should keep a low-profile; and 25 percent said the KMT should just ignore the issue.
From the divided opinions, it seems that the KMT will find it hard to react properly to Lee's attacks, according to the survey.
Referring to approval ratings, the survey said that the KMT's support now stands at 25 percent, ahead of the People First Party and the DPP, each with about 20 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW POLITICAL GROUP, 'SHANMENG,' OUTLINES CAMPAIGN PLATFORM

TEXT.P: A newly founded political group, Shanmeng, said Friday it would not hesitate to support candidates for the Dec. 1 elections who share similar political ideals and concepts as its members.

Convener Hsu Hsin-liang of Shanmeng, or Mountain Alliance, made the remarks at a news conference where he also introduced four Shanmeng members who have registered their candidacy for the upcoming elections for legislators and local government chiefs.

Hsu, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) who quit the party to run in the 2000 presidential election, said he hopes to see more like-minded people enter the upcoming races.

Hsu outlined Shanmeng candidates' common campaign platform which includes promoting globalization, defending the political system prescribing in the Republic of China Constitution, fighting against the influence of moneyed interests in domestic politics and ending "national capitalism" by privatizing government-run companies.

Hsu said the constitutional system, national capitalism and globalization are the three core issues to be debated in the pivotal December legislative elections. "They are also the three key issues Taiwan must address after the elections," he added.

Hsu further said Shanmeng hopes that more like-minded people can enter the new Legislative Yuan to help promote its causes. "Our often unruly legislative body needs the participation of social elite to nurture a new political culture and instill better legislative ethics," he said.

The four Shanmeng members to run in the upcoming elections are Chu Li-lun, an incumbent opposition Kuomintang legislator who has been nominated by his party to run for Taoyuan County magistrate; Shih Ming-teh, a sitting lawmaker and former DPP chairman who has quit the party due to different political concepts; Chu Hui-liang, an incumbent legislator; and Sisy Chen, a former DPP spokeswoman. Shih, Chu and Chen will run for seats in the new Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'MINI THREE LINKS' GRADUALLY HEATING UP: MAC

TEXT.P: Ten months after implementation, the direct "mini three links" across the Taiwan Strait have gradually heated up with cooperation of mainland China, a senior official said Friday.
Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, made the remarks at a routine news conference.

In an effort to signify its sincerity to promote cross-strait rapprochement, the Republic of China government opened its two frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu for direct trade, mail and shipping links with mainland China's Xiamen and Mawei, commonly known as "mini three links," at the beginning of this year.
At first, mainland China cold-shouldered the program and imposed strict restrictions on mainland Chinese people and ships intending to make direct voyages to the ROC's two defense outposts.

In recent months, Lin said, mainland China has gradually eased such restrictions. "We recognize mainland China's goodwill in allowing more mainland people and boats to sail directly to Kinmen and Matsu," Lin said.
At present, mainland China still would not allow regular direct Kinmen-Xiamen and Matsu-Mawei shipping services and instead approves such applications on a case-by-case basis.
Lin said he hopes mainland China can adopt a more realistic and pragmatic manner in handling civilian, social and economic exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait for mutual benefits.

According to MAC tallies, ROC ships had made 96 direct voyages from Kinmen and Matsu to Xiamen and Mawei in the southeastern mainland province of Fujian as of the end of September, while mainland vessels made 27 direct Xiamen-Kinmen and Mawei-Matsu voyages during the same nine-month period.

Meanwhile, 8,703 ROC nationals had sailed directly to Xiamen and Mawei between January and September, and 524 mainland Chinese residents had made direct voyages to the ROC's two outlying islands during the same period. Both Kinmen and Matsu lie closer to the mainland than to Taiwan.

Lin also called on mainland China to resume regular cross-strait dialogue as early as possible so as to let the "mini three links" proceed even more smoothly and facilitate normalization of bilateral relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T LOOSENS RESTRICTIONS ON ENTRY OF MAINLAND CHINESE PROFESSIONALS

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has further simplified the procedures for economic, trade and technology professionals from mainland China to apply to enter Taiwan, a government spokesman said Friday.

Government Information Office Director General Su Tzen-ping said that mainland Chinese economic and trade professional working for multinational companies as well as technology professionals will now need to file their entry applications only five days in advance instead of two months.
He said that the Cabinet made the decision in response to the suggestions of the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei (AmCham) and the European Council of Commerce and Trade (ECCT).

Su went on to say that the Cabinet has also decided to follow their suggestion to allow the local organizations that invite the mainland professionals to pass on the official travel documents instead of delivering the papers in a roundabout manner via government-appointed agencies or organizations in Hong Kong or Macau.

Following the conclusions of the presidential Economic Development Advisory Conference held in August, the government has further extended the maximum duration of stay for mainland technology professionals who visit Taiwan to participate in technology research from three years to six years, he added.

Su said that in accordance with other conclusions at the conference and the suggestions of AmCham and the ECCT, the Cabinet has also simplified the document flow process to waive guarantee verifications for guarantors who work in multinational corporations or foreign-invested companies approved by the Ministry of Economic Affairs as long as the companies stamp their seals on the documents.
He added that the Cabinet has allowed mainland professionals to apply for travel document extensions for a period of one year to three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROWTH OF TAIWAN AIDS PATIENTS EXPECTED TO FALL IN 2 YEARS

TEXT.P: The number of AIDS patients in Taiwan is expected to decrease in two years, as more people become aware of how to protect themselves from the deadly disease, the head of a sexual disease prevention center said Friday.

Wu Shui-ying, head of the Taipei Municipal Sexual Disease Prevention Center, said control of the disease in Taiwan is in a similar situation to that in Japan and South Korea but added that a fall in the number of newly infected patients should occur in one or two years.

Wu, who took part in a recent Asia-Pacific conference on AIDS prevention in Melbourne, Australia, said only active prevention measures, such as education and practicing safe sex, can reduce the risks of infection and stem the outflow of financial resources that the government has to shoulder for AIDS patients.

In the first half of this year, there were 282 newly infected HIV patients in Taiwan, according to Wu. The number stood at 531 in 2000, 476 in 1999, 403 in 1998 and 353 in 1997. She said that it appeared that the number had peaked last year and said that it is expected to fall gradually in the coming years.

Judging from the infection rate among the young men preparing to start their military service, six to seven people out of every 100,000 test HIV positive, Wu said. Illegal prostitutes who have been required to undergo an HIV test have resulted in figures that indicate that one or two out of every 1,000 test positive.
Wu, noted, however, that the government is carrying a great financial burden for providing free treatment of the cocktail therapy in its national health program to people inflicted by HIV.

Citing estimates by the Cabinet-level Department of Health, Wu said that government spending on each AIDS patient can amount to NT$350,000 per year. Currently, there are more than 1,000 AIDS patients receiving the cocktail therapy provided by the government, she said.

Wu said that the actual number of HIV patients in Taiwan is around 15,000, much higher than the government estimate of 3,000, a situation which means that many of them are unaware that they are AIDS-virus carriers. She also warned that about 10 percent of the AIDS patients refuse treatment and go into hiding.
While calling for all-out efforts by the government to prevent the disease and trace missing patients, Wu said that education for Taiwan's populace on this front is a pressing issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC APPROVES OF PREMIER'S PERFORMANCE ON ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES: POLL

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission announced Friday that the results of a poll on the public's approval rating of Premier Chang Chun-hsiung is highest on environmental protection issues and lowest on economic issues.

The commission conducted the random telephone survey on Chang's administrative performance during his past year in office from Oct. 2-4 between 6:30 p.m. and 10 p.m. A total of 1,142 effective samples were acquired, with a sampling error of plus or minus 2.9 percent.
According to the poll, 65 percent of the respondents approved of Chang's performance on environmental protection issues, and 63 percent approved of his performance on national security issues.

The polls also show that 62 percent approved of his performance on cracking down on "black gold" -- or organized crime intervention in politics -- and 61 percent approved of his performance on upholding basic human rights.

Seventy-one percent said that they were not satisfied with Chang's performance on stabilizing economic development, and 49 percent said they disapproved of Chang's performance on handling natural disasters.

Forty-four percent said that they were not satisfied with the effort that Chang put in to carry out the reconstruction work for the damages caused by the Sept. 21, 1999 killer earthquake, and another 44 percent said that they were not satisfied with his performance in maintaining social order.

The commission also conducted another poll on the approval rating of President Chen Shui-bian, which stands at 51 percent, 4 percent higher than his rating in May. Only 33 percent of the respondents in that poll said that they disapprove of Chen's performance.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD TO LAUNCH LARGE EMPLOYMENT IMPROVEMENT PACKAGE

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Friday that it will launch a large package to help train talent for seven local sectors.

As Taiwan is facing mounting unemployment due to the country's economic structure and an increasing digital gap, the CEPD said joblessness among local elderly and middle-aged people is rising and it is urgent to take efficient measurers to create job opportunities and to bring down the unemployment rate.

The CEPD said it plans to help train as many as 1.4 million hi-tech professionals and grassroots technicians for the local semiconductor, aviation, optoelectronics, telecommunications and biotech industries.

According to CEPD estimates, Taiwan will have an average manpower vacancy of 315,000 for each sector in the coming four years. Some 52,000 vacancies will be in the white-collar sector, while there will be 287,000 vacancies for blue-collar workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO MAKE CLEAR STANCE ON ANTI-TERRORISM ACTION AT APEC FORUM

TEXT.P: Republic of China will make clear its anti-terrorism stance at the upcoming Shanghai meetings of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

MOFA officials said Friday that they are studying ways to support the multinational anti-terrorism action and will express the government's position at the informal APEC summit to be held in Shanghai, mainland China, on Oct. 20-21.
It is expected that the war against terrorism will be the main issue at this year's APEC summit, as United States President George W. Bush is scheduled to attend the event.
APEC leaders are expected to exchange opinions and issue a joint declaration against terrorism.

Mainland China, the organizer of this year's APEC summit, has suggested some steps to fight terrorism, which include cutting financial support to the terrorists; cooperation in security measures in aviation, airports and ports; and strengthening the integrated electronic net among member economies' customs.

In related news, Taiwan's Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi and Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Chen Poh-chih will leave for Shanghai Oct. 15 to attend APEC's annual ministerial meeting, which will be held a few days before the summit.
Lin, heading a 50-member delegation composed of high-ranking officials of various ministries, is expected to hold talks with his mainland counterpart to exchange views about issues related to APEC.

Lin will also hold talks with his counterparts from the United States, Canada, Mexico, Japan, Australia, New Zealand, Thailand and Vietnam. Their discussions will focus on ways to strengthen economic and trade cooperation among member economies.
A number of high-ranking officials from Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs will head for Shanghai Saturday to attend APEC's senior official meetings, which will begin on Oct. 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE GROUP OPPOSES PLAN TO MERGE OCAC WITH MOFA

TEXT.P: The Federation of Overseas Chinese Associations Friday issued a statement to oppose a proposal to merge the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

The statement, issued at a meeting of the federation's standing board of directors, criticized the Democratic Progressive Party administration for attempting to have the OCAC become a subordinate organ of MOFA.

It said the move would "cut off the long and deep connections between overseas Chinese residents and the Republic of China," and added that it will "hurt the interests of overseas Chinese residents protected by the Constitution."
The statement said that the federation will lead the way to oppose the government plan along with leaders of the overseas Chinese communities and overseas Chinese organizations.
Kwan Yuk-noan, a Kuomintang legislator elected from the United States, said that he is absolutely against the plan to merge the OCAC with MOFA.

He said that those who advocate the merger plan do not understand the real situation of the overseas Chinese communities. "At a time when mainland China is doing its utmost to woo overseas Chinese residents, how can we have the OCAC merged?" Kwan went on.
President Chen Shui-bian said recently that the government will form a "committee for government reorganization" in the near future to streamline governmental agencies.

In response to the overseas Chinese federation's statement, an official with the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) said Friday that it is still too early to talk about the OCAC merger plan because the direction of the reorganization plan has not been fixed yet.
He said that the "committee for government organization" will be operated by the Presidential Office, and added that the RDEC is only responsible for implementing the government's decisions.
In connection with the issue, OCAC Secretary-General Hsu Chen-jung said that no final decision has been made regarding whether to merge the OCAC with the foreign ministry.
He asserted that "if a decision has been made by the government, the public servants would have no other choice, but to accept the decision."
Nevertheless, Hsu said that "in a democratic society, the Federation of Overseas Chinese Associations, a social organization, has the right to express its opinions and ideas."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC GOVERNMENT URGES PEOPLE NOT TO VISIT PAKISTAN, AFGHANISTAN

TEXT.P: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs Friday urged the people not to visit Pakistan and Afghanistan for sightseeing or business purposes because the two countries have become high-risk areas following the U.S.-led military strikes against the Taliban regime.
The foreign ministry also advised citizens not to visit the following countries in the near future -- Tajikistan, Uzbekstan, Turkmenistan, Iran, Iraq, Saudi Arabia and Israel.
Citizens are also urged to heighten their vigilance when they visit Kazakhstan, Bahrain, Oman, United Arab Emirates, Egypt, Qatar, Kuwait and Turkey.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW BOOK RELEASED: 'STOP STIRRING UP TROUBLE, MR. LEE TENG-HUI'

TEXT.P: A new book written by two senior journalists which attempts to clarify events concerning former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui and 12 of his colleagues during his tenure as head of state was published Friday.

Written by Lu Keng and Ma Hsi-ping, the book titled, "Stop Stirring Up Trouble, Mr. Lee Teng-hui" was introduced to the public at a news conference attended by Lu, Ma, Wang Tso-jung, former head of the Control Yuan, government's highest watchdog organization, senior journalist Chang Fo-chien and other dignitaries.

Speaking at the news conference, Lu and Ma stressed that it was their belief that reporters should file balanced reports that compelled them to write the book to check the veracity of claims made in other books published recently.

In the other books on Lee, Lee slammed almost every one of his colleagues and wrote off their contributions during his 12-year tenure as head of state, including Lien Chan, current chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT). The KMT lost the presidency to the Democratic Progressive Party in the presidential election held in March, 2000.
Lu and Ma said that they interviewed 12 of Lee's past colleagues to give their accounts of the events attributed to Lee in past books.
The two senior journalists said the 12 told them the truth about what they had learned about events surrounding Lee.

The KMT revoked Lee's party membership Sept. 21 for his verbal attacks on the party and his stumping for rival Taiwan Solidarity Union's (TSU) candidates for the year-end legislative and local elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 13, or the 27th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
A.D. 54: Claudius I, 64, Roman emperor and historian, dies after supposedly consuming poisoned mushrooms dished up by his fourth wife, his niece Agrippina. Shortly before his death, Claudius had agreed to acknowledge Nero, Agrippina's son from a former marriage, as his heir instead of his natural son, Britannicus.
1792: U.S. President George Washington lays the foundation stone of the White House.
1812: British forces under Sir Isaac Brock defeat the Americans at the battle of Queenston Heights, helping to put an end to the U.S. attempt to invade Canada.
1884: Greenwich, England, is adopted as the universal meridian from which standard times throughout the world are calculated.
1913: Representatives from China, Britain and Tibet attend a meeting held in Simla, India, to discuss various problems concerning Tibet.
1923: Ankara becomes the capital of Turkey.
1925: Margaret Thatcher, British Conservative politician and prime minister from 1979 to 1990, is born. Her administration was marked by anti-inflationary measures, a brief war in the Falkland Islands (1982), and the passage of a poll tax.
1939: Adolf Hitler tries without success to persuade U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt to mediate peace between Germany, France and Britain.
1943: Italy declares war on Germany, its former Axis partner.
1949: Republic of China government troops evacuate Canton.
1960: The Institute of History and Philology of the Academia Sinica begins excavations at dwellings of the Yin people in Anyang County, Hunan Province, once the capital of the dynasty before 1200 B.C.
1964: Three Soviet cosmonauts operating Voshkod, the world's first multi-seat spacecraft, land safely after a 24-hour journey.
1968: Liu Shao-chi, state chairman of Communist China, is purged at the 12th Plenum of the 8th Chinese Communist Party Central Committee held in Beijing.
1970: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the severance of diplomatic relations with Canada.
1974: U.S. Senator Hiram Leong Fong of Hawaii arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1980: President Pieter W. Botha of South Africa is presented with the Key to the City of Taipei by Mayor Lee Teng-hui upon arrival for a state visit.
1981: Taipei Mayor Lee Teng-hui presents a Key to Taipei to Mayor Leon Amon of the Ivory Coast's Dimbokro City.
1988: The Shroud of Turin, for centuries regarded as the burial cloth of Jesus Christ, is shown by carbon-dating tests to date from between 1260 and 1390 in the Middle Ages, a period rife with forgeries.
1993: The United Nations Security Council decides to resume an oil-and-arms embargo against Haiti after Haitian military leaders fail to follow an agreement to allow President Jean-Bertrand Aristide to return to office and restore a democratic government.
1995: Joseph Rotblat, the nuclear physicist who devoted his life to trying to ban the bomb he helped create, wins the 1995 Nobel Peace Prize.
1995: France rejects appeals to abandon nuclear testing in the South Pacific.
1998: Daniel Chee Tsui, professor at Princeton University and a member of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research institute, becomes one of the three co-winners of the 1998 Nobel Prize for physics.
1999: A Jordanian Royal Air Force transport plane airlifts 14,600 kilograms of relief goods to Taipei to help surviving victims of the devastating earthquake that rocked Taiwan on Sept. 21.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian hails the decision to grant the 2000 Nobel Prize in literature to self-exiled mainland Chinese writer Gao Xingjian, saying that the honor marks Gao's greatest achievement.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The life of the moral man is plain, and yet not unattractive; it is simple, and yet full of grace; it is easy, and yet methodical."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY (Oct. 14 2001)
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 14, or the 28th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1066: Duke William of Normandy becomes the new ruler of England after defeating the English under King Harold in a hard-fought battle near Hastings.
1890: Dwight D. Eisenhower, U.S. military commander in Europe during World War II and two-term president of the United States after the war, is born.
1909: The Ching court sets up government counselor bureaus in each of its 22 provinces except Sinkiang, marking the beginning of a parliament in China.
1912: Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th president of the United States, is shot in an attempted assassination prior to his assuming the presidency. He won the 1906 Nobel Peace Prize for his mediation in the Russo-Japanese War.
1913: An explosion at Universal Colliery in South Wales kills 439 miners in Britain's worst mining disaster.
1915: The Interior Ministry of the National government orders a halt to the practice of binding the feet of women.
1920: Oxford University, the oldest university in Britain and one of the world's most famous institutions of higher learning, grants degrees to women for the first time.
1933: Nazi Germany walks out of the Geneva Disarmament Conference and withdraws from the League of Nations.
1939: The British Royal Navy battleship HMS Royal Osk is torpedoed and sunk at Scapa Flow, killing 810 people on board.
1944: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National government, summons 100,000 young intellectuals to join the army and organizes them into an expeditionary force of 10 divisions.
1944: Field Marshall Erwin Rommel, one of Nazi Germany's finest military leaders, known as "Desert Fox," dies at the age of 53. He commanded the Afrika Korps with distinction during the North African campaign from 1941-1943.
1947: The Bell X-1 becomes the first aircraft to fly faster than sound when the rocket-powered plane, piloted by U.S. Air Force Maj. Charles Yeager, is taken to a height of 9,700 meters under a B-29 Superfortress mother-plane. The test begins at 22,700 meters, and the maximum speed achieved is Mach 1.05, which is held for several seconds.
1958: Madagascar, known as the Malagasy Republic under the French, becomes a self-governing state in the French Community. It would gain independence in 1960.
1964: Martin Luther King Jr., American cleric who formed the foundation of the civil rights movement of the 1950's and 1960's, is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize. He would be assassinated in Memphis, Tennessee, four years later.
1973: Thanom Kittikachorn is forced to resign as prime minister of Thailand after violent clashes between troops and student protesters. He is succeeded by Sanya Thammasak.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives outgoing Jordanian Ambassador Fathi Yasin at the Presidential Office.
1977: The construction of the Shihkang Dam, capable of supplying 420,000 metric tons of water daily, is completed in central Taiwan.
1977: The much-loved entertainer Bing Crosby collapses and dies after completing a round of golf near Madrid. He was 73. One of his most successful films was "High Society," with Grace Kelly and Frank Sinatra.
1979: Dr. James Robinson, president of the University of West Florida, gives a reception at the Grand Hotel to mark the presentation of an honorary doctorate of law to President Chiang Ching-kuo.
1991: Aung San Suu Kyi, Burmese pro-democracy leader held under house arrest for more than two years by Burmese military rulers, wins the Nobel Peace Prize.
1992: Shin Kanemaru, Japanese political leader, resigns from Japan's parliament following criticism for his role in a scandal tying the Liberal Democratic Party to organized crime.
1993: The United Nations General Assembly ends a two-week general debate during which a total of 23 nations express their support for ROC membership in the world body.
1999: A delegation from the Republic of China takes part in the 26th International Small Business Congress held in Toronto, Canada.
2000: Mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji says in Tokyo that Beijing will take a cautious attitude to resolve the Taiwan issue peacefully, but he adds that this issue should not be prolonged indefinitely.
2000: The Noel Foundation of the United States gives the life award to Dharma Master Cheng Yen of Taiwan's Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Association for her "love without borders" activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The China Times:
The Cabinet is considering reclaiming assets improperly seized by the Kuomintang.
The United Daily News:
The Council of Labor Affairs completes initial draft statute allowing choice in retirement plans.
The Liberty Times:
Bush offers Taliban reprieve.
The Taiwan Daily:
U.S. warns attacks possible on states like Syria.
The Central Daily News:
U.N. shares Nobel Peace Prize with its leader, Kofi Annan.
The China Post:
The Legislature amends property laws for foreign investors.
The Taiwan News:
