The Taipei Times:
Ex-President Lee Teng-hui issues warning about risks of investing in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON `HAIYAN' POSING INCREASING THREAT TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A tropical storm originating in the Pacific which was upgraded to a typhoon early Saturday morning is expected to begin affecting Taiwan's weather Monday, Central Weather Bureau (CWB) sources reported.

Meteorologists at the weather bureau warned that Typhoon Haiyan (Ocean Swallow), an "autumn typhoon," could be disastrous as its outer rim will be accompanied by the northeast monsoon, with the combination being capable of triggering torrential rains.
The impact of autumn typhoons on the island doubles when they are "fueled" by northeast monsoons, which significantly affect Taiwan's weather during the fall and winter, the meteorologists said.
Typhoon Haiyan is expected to bring heavy rains to mountainous areas in the north and eastern parts of Taiwan as well as strong winds to coastal areas in eastern Taiwan in the following days.

Haiyan was located some 1,000 kilometers southeast of Taiwan as of Saturday noon and was moving in a northeasterly direction at a snail's pace, the CWB meteorologists said, adding that although it was moving slowly, it was gradually gaining strength.
Exactly when and if the weather bureau will issue sea and land warnings for Typhoon Haiyan will depend on further observations of the typhoon's speed and course, they added.

Weather across island on Saturday has generally been good, with temperatures of between 21 and 28 degrees Celsius in northern Taiwan, 21-29 degrees Celsius in central Taiwan, and 23-30 degrees Celsius in southern Taiwan, according to the weather bureau.

Two "autumn typhoons" battered Taiwan this August and September, respectively, with unprecedently high amount of precipitation, causing heavy human casualties as well as extensive property damage and losses in northern, eastern and central Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO FORMALLY BECOME WTO MEMBER FEB. 1: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Barring unexpected developments, the Republic of China will formally become a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO) Feb. 1, 2002, a senior official said Saturday.

Wu Wen-ya, director of the Board of Foreign Trade (MOFT), made the remarks before leaving for Shanghai to attend an informal meeting of senior officials of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
Despite the current U.S.-led war on terrorism, Wu said, the WTO has not given any hints that it might change the schedule of its ministerial meeting slated for Nov. 9-13 in Qatar.

Wu said the Geneva-based trade regulatory body is expected to formally approve Taiwan's and mainland China's WTO membership bids at its November ministerial meeting as relevant WTO working parties already endorsed their accession terms in September.

"Once the WTO ministerial meeting passes Taiwan's WTO membership application, our Legislative Yuan must approve all the promises we have made, including the passage of 19 related legislative bills," Wu said.

As the legislature will suspend operations in November to allow incumbent legislators to focus energy on preparations for the Dec. 1 elections, Wu said, screening of the WTO-related bills is not expected to be finalized until the end of this year.

According to the WTO regulations, Taiwan must then present all of the parliament-endorsed bills and other relevant documents to the WTO Secretariat before becoming a formal member 30 days after the presentation of all of these protocols.
"So if all goes well, we'll be able to enter the WTO as a full member Feb. 1 next year," Wu said.

He went on to say that as Taiwan has promised to cut import tariffs and further open its markets following its WTO entry, the domestic agricultural sector will sustain greater adverse impacts than the domestic industrial sector will.

Wu said sales of certain locally produced fruits, such as wax apples and mangoes, will be affected by the influx of foreign fruits. As for the industrial and service sectors, Wu said, the impact is expected to be relatively smaller.
Touching on the APEC informal senior officials meeting, Wu said it is basically a forum for member states to exchange views and forge friendships as its decisions are not binding.
Wu said the agenda will focus on promoting free trade and Asia-Pacific regional prosperity as well as on boosting e-commerce.

The APEC senior officials meeting will be followed by an annual ministerial meeting next week. Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi and Chairman Chen Po-chih of the Council for Economic Planning and Development will represent Taiwan at the conference.
Wu said the APEC ministerial meeting may add a new topic -- cooperation in the fight against global terrorism -- to its agenda this year.

Meanwhile, an APEC informal leadership meeting is scheduled to take place in Shanghai Dec. 20-21. ROC President Chen Shui-bian has appointed former Vice President Li Yuan-zu to attend the summit meeting on his behalf. But mainland China has yet to make any response concerning Li's presence at the meeting.

APEC groups 21 members -- Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, mainland China, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, the Philippines, Russia, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand, the United States and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT PROPOSES NEW RETIREMENT PENSION PLANS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) on Friday completed a preliminary draft statute governing a proposed set of new retirement pension plans including individual retirement accounts (IRAs) and annuity accounts.

The CLA finished the initial designs after a series of discussions with officials of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development and members of the employment panel of the presidential Economic Development Advisory Conference held in August.
The CLA is scheduled to ratify the draft within two weeks and submit it to the Cabinet for further discussions before the end of October.

According to the draft, three different pension plans will be available, and employees will have the option of switching between the different plans as many times as they wish within the first five years of the new pension system's adoption.
However, newcomers to the job market after the five year grace period will have to stick by their choices until retirement.

Except for companies with over 500 employees -- which are allowed to design their own corporate retirement plans, subject to CLA approval as well as to the consent of their labor unions or two-thirds of the employees -- all employers are required to give their employees the freedom to choose between the IRA and the annuity plans.

Under the proposed IRA plan, employers must contribute funds to an employee's IRA each month equal to 6 percent of that employee's insured monthly salary. That employee will be allowed to deposit an additional maximum 6 percent to the IRA without having to pay income tax on the deposited money until it is withdrawn.

When the employee retires at the age of 60, or if the employee becomes disabled, dies or loses his or her Republic of China citizenship permanently, a lump sum pension including interest earned will be handed out.
Employees will be allowed to choose their own accredited asset management companies to administer their IRAs.
During the transition to the IRA plan, employers will be required to deposit 2 percent to their employees' IRAs in the first year, 4 percent in the second year and a full 6 percent in the third year.

Under the proposed annuity option, employers must also contribute 6 percent of an employee's insured monthly salary to a retirement fund each month. That employee will be able to receive a retirement pension in monthly installments equivalent to an estimated 21 percent of his or her average insured salary in the last three years of employment.
The fund will be administered by one or two financial organizations appointed by a supervisory board made up of labor representatives, experts and government officials.

Investment strategies for that fund will be decided by the same supervisory board, but the employees will have to contribute additional money to a maximum of 6 percent of their insured monthly salaries to cover for inadequate funds as a result of any investment losses.
In the event that an employee dies, his or her family is guaranteed to receive the annuity for a total of 10 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC WEB SITE TEACHES PUBLIC HOW TO TELL REAL AND FAKE BILLS APART

TEXT.P: The rampancy of counterfeit bank notes in circulation in Taiwan has prompted the Central Bank of China (CBC) to strengthen efforts at educating the public on how to distinguish fake bills from real ones.

The CBC has added two items on its Web site's home page to teach the public the different ways to distinguish forged bank notes from real ones and to explain the law regarding printing and using counterfeit bills.
The CBC's Web site (www.cbc.gov.tw) has provided five basic methods to help the general public distinguish whether a bank note is fake or genuine.

Counterfeit bank notes of NT$100, NT$500 and NT$1,000 denomination, especially those of NT$1,000 denomination, have frequently been found in circulation recently. Even counterfeit coins of NT$50 denomination have been found in circulation.

According to Republic of China law, a person who is found guilty of counterfeiting or altering currently used Taiwan currency shall receive a minimum sentence of five-year imprisonment or a maximum sentence of death.

ROC law also stipulates that a person found guilty of putting counterfeit Taiwan currency into circulation or of collecting it from or delivering it to others with the intent of putting it into circulation shall receive a sentence of between three and ten years in prison.

A person who unknowingly receives counterfeit currency and then knowingly uses it or delivers to others with the intent of putting into circulation shall receive at most a fine of NT$15,000 if found guilty, according to ROC law.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT FLIGHTS WITHOUT GOVERNMENT AUTHORIZATION: CAA

TEXT.P: No Taiwan air carrier will be allowed to operate direct flights to mainland China without the authorization of the government, an official from the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications said Saturday.

Direct flights across the Taiwan Strait will only be possible after the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) makes it a national policy before conducting negotiations with mainland Chinese authorities on the plan and forging a formal agreement, CAA Deputy Director-General Chang Kuo-cheng said.
Chang urged authorities in Beijing to engage in "official bilateral negotiations" with Taiwan on direct cross-strait flights, saying the sooner this is done, the better.
He made the remarks in response to a report that the Taiwan and mainland Chinese aviation industries agreed Friday to offer flights with airlines from both sides not displaying national flags.

Representatives of the Taiwan and mainland Chinese aviation industries agreed at a seminar held in Beijing Friday that if direct bilateral flights become possible in the future, then all aircraft plying cross-strait routes will fly without their respective national flags.

Republic of China Legislator Elmer Fung from the opposition New Party, who headed a Taiwan delegation to Beijing, along with Bao Peide, deputy director of mainland China's Civil Aviation Administration, made the announcement together after the seminar.

They announced that the two sides came to an agreement on the fact that both Taiwan and mainland China have already suffered immense losses in terms of time and money due to the fact direct flight services between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are still illegal.
They said that the survival and development of the Taiwan and mainland Chinese aviation industries depend on the opening of direct cross-strait airlinks.

The two sides also agreed that they hope to rely on private sector aviation organizations to carry on with regularly or irregularly scheduled evaluations of related technical or operational issues while expanding the topics of discussion.

Commenting on the report, Chang said that because of the uniqueness of the cross-Taiwan Strait relationship, which has prevented Taiwan from applying international practices to solve cross-strait disputes, Taiwan airlines are not allowed to initiate direct flights to or from mainland China without governmental approval, even though the current statutes governing private exchanges across the strait have not specifically restricted Taiwan carriers from doing so.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT LOOKS INTO KMT ASSETS IN RESPONSE TO CONTROL YUAN DEMANDS

TEXT.P: Cabinet Secretary-General Chiou I-jen said Saturday that the government's move to assess whether the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has obtained public assets illegally in the past was taken in response to the Control Yuan's demands.

Chiou said that despite "natural" reactions questioning the move as politically motivated -- particularly with legislative elections coming up in December -- the Executive Yuan cannot evade the issue brought up by the government's highest supervisory body, which has recently completed an investigation into the KMT's allegedly illegal assets and urged the Executive Yuan to conduct its own thorough investigation on the matter.
Chiou went on to say that if the Executive Yuan did not act on the Control Yuan's demands, it would be criticized as administratively indolent or disrespectful toward the Control Yuan.
Therefore, he said that the administration will handle the case according to "normal procedures" and will not purposely speed up the process.

Chiou said that because a lot of ministries and government agencies are involved in the lengthy investigation process, the first phase is being handled by Minister-without-Portfolio Hsu Chih-hsiung, who is assembling a special task force to compile available information on the case.
Afterward, the government will look into ways of handling related legal issues, he added.

Chiou said even if the KMT assets are found to have been acquired following legal procedures, the Executive Yuan will continue to look into whether the process was "justified." If the acquisition was not justified, then the administration will study whether to resolve the issue by drafting a special bill to reclaim the assets or through other means, he added.

In response to the government's investigation, a KMT spokesman charged that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration is only trying to shift the public focus away from the DPP's "ineffective governance."

KMT Cultural and Communications Committee spokesman Chou Shou-shun said that the KMT has already been doing its own asset assessments for the past year in order to put them into trusts and make the party's assets transparent to the public.

In the event that the investigation discovers any illegally obtained public assets, Chou said that the KMT will act in accordance with the law and will not be greedy about such "illegally acquired wealth."

Meanwhile, opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong, who once served as KMT secretary-general, said that he supports the move to assess the KMT assets from a legal point of view if it is handled in a just and farsighted manner.

However, he said that because the KMT and the government relied on each other in the early years of the party's rule on Taiwan to provide political stability and economic prosperity to the island, it cannot be said that the KMT took complete advantage of the government because the party's assets have also done a lot for the country.
Soong added that because of the ongoing election campaign season, he hopes that all sides can handle the issue with a fair-minded attitude and without becoming emotional.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESSPEOPLE INVESTING IN INTERNET CAFE PLAZA IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: While the customers at the some 4,000 Internet cafes around the island are mostly teenagers, businesspeople in Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan are planning to develop an Internet cafe plaza aimed at the whole family.
The Internet cafe plaza under planning will have gardens, multimedia centers and restaurants. The investors plan to invest some NT$80 million in the project.

Internet cafes have become a new line of business with tremendous potential in Taiwan. However, authorities have found the business involving high technology and entertainment very difficult to regulate.
A survey conducted by the Shiang-yang Foundation earlier this year indicated that an estimated 120,000 high school and junior high school students indulge in visiting Internet cafes.

The survey of 9,935 students from 129 schools around the island showed that 51 percent of the respondents said that they have visited Internet cafes, while 45.5 percent said they are regular customers who visit an Internet cafe at least once a week.

The teenagers said they spend most of their time in Internet cafes playing computer games and visiting online chat rooms. Less than one out of ten said they access the Internet to visit adult entertainment or gambling Web sites.

Students' distraction from their studies and Internet access to pornography and gambling have raised concerns among many parents and education authorities. Internet cafes in Taiwan have been unable to help bearing a bad name, especially when the cafes are linked to reports such as gang fighting and the negatives effects of Internet cafes on health.
Many parents answering the survey questionnaire of the Shiang-yang Foundation said that they would try to keep their youngsters from visiting Internet cafes.
The Kaohsiung businesspeople investing in the planned Internet cafe plaza said they hope that the plaza will present a healthy image of Internet cafes to the public.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs in April of this year put the Internet cafe business under the category of "information-related recreational businesses." However, a supervision mechanism has yet to be established. Since the business involves Internet services, computer business, data processing, and food and beverage services, good coordination is needed among all the authorities concerned in order to regulate the mushrooming business.

A recently released research report by Capital Securities House estimated that the Internet cafe sector's total revenue might reach NT$13.6 billion next year. The booming sector is expected to help stimulate growth in the broadband communications market as well as in e-commerce.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMAN SHOT TO DEATH IN MANILA
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By Philip Liu and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan businessman was shot to death Thursday night in greater Manila's Quezon City, the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Manila said Saturday.

According to police, a gangster riding a motorcycle caught up with the pedicab that Meng and his girlfriend were riding in on their way to a shopping mall to eat dinner. The gangster pointed a gun at Meng and fired several shots before robbing him of a handbag containing cash, a cellular phone, a checkbook and some other personal belongings.
Meng died after being rushed to hospital by his girlfriend, the TECO said.

The TECO set up a task force to deal with the case shortly after receiving notification of the incident from the Philippine police. It has also assisted Meng's family members to rush to Manila as soon as possible and to arrange for his funeral.
It was learned that Meng's parents are expected to arrive in the Philippines on Saturday.
Investigations into the case are still under way.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTORS IN OVERSEAS FUNDS ADVISED TO PROTECT THEIR INTERESTS

TEXT.P: Investors in overseas funds should take the initiative in protecting their interests if a financial management firm causes them great losses due to miscalculations by the firm's researchers or intentional deception, according to the financial consultant firm MagniFinance L.L.C.

The consulting firm reported Saturday that several internationally renowned finance management firms were recently challenged by investors who had lost a great deal amid the crash in Internet stock prices.

A lawsuit filed against Merrill Lynch by investors of ML's Internet Infrastructure Holders has focused the attention of those in financial circles around the world on the issue, according to MagniFinance.

The outcome of the case may set a legal precedent for fund investors concerning securing their own interests. MagniFinance advised investors in Taiwan to familiarize themselves with the practices of finance management companies and with investors' rights and interests before making any such investments.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA HEAD SAYS HE HAS NOT PROMISED TO STUMP FOR CANDIDATES

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh said Saturday that he has not promised any candidates that he will stump for them during their campaigns for the Dec. 1 elections for legislators, county magistrates and city mayors.
The 1986 Nobel Prize winner for chemistry is regarded as a powerful campaign stumper because of his prestigious reputation.
During the presidential campaign in 2000, he openly threw his support behind the Democratic Progressive Party's Chen Shui-bian, helping Chen win the election by a slim margin.
When asked by the media whether he will stump for any candidates in the upcoming elections, Lee replied that "I have not promised to stump for any candidates."

As no single party is expected to win an outright majority in the next Legislature, the ruling DPP and the opposition Kuomintang have been struggling to become the party with the most seats in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan after the elections.

Academia Sinica, located in Nankang District, suffered heavy losses after Typhoon Nari swept northern Taiwan Sept. 16. Its premises were flooded, with its power supply and telephone services being disrupted for several days.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC GLOOM AFFECTS CAMPAIGN FUNDING (I)

TEXT.P: The lingering economic gloom has affected campaign funding for the upcoming elections for legislators and local government chiefs.

The pivotal Dec. 1 elections are just 49 days away, but campaign activities have yet to heat up partly because of funding shortages. In the past, major Taipei streets were dotted with campaign banners and posters of candidates from different political camps long before official campaign periods started.
This year, few campaign banners, billboards, leaflets or posters have so far been seen on streets or mailboxes of private homes as cash-strapped candidates have cut spending on campaign literature.

A candidate in a legislative race in metropolitan Taipei said campaign literature is expensive and its effectiveness is dubious. "At this time of economic hardship, I must adopt more effective strategies, including mass rallies and other innovative methods, to attract voters and promote my cause," he said.
The protracted economic slowdown and a string of typhoon disasters have made it extremely difficult for election hopefuls to raise campaign funds.

Apollo Chen, an incumbent opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker who is seeking re-election in the Taipei southern precinct, said he originally expected that the local stock market might stage a comeback in autumn to help make fund-raising easier.

"But the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States and the Typhoon Nari-triggered devastation have dampened any sort of stock market rally. Now, I don't dare approach any potential donor for contributions," he said.

Chen Chi-mai, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator who is seeking re-election in the Kaohsiung precinct, said in the past he used to draw up a campaign plan and then move to raise funds to finance the project.

"This year, I have to reverse my work schedule. I must first see how much money I can raise and then draft my campaign programs," Chen said, adding that the slumping stock and property markets as well as electronics industry woes have discouraged him from soliciting financial support from the business community.
Unlike the KMT, the DPP has few party assets. As a result, the party has traditionally relied on organizing luncheons or dinners to raise funds to finance various campaign activities.

The DPP's "Mainstream Alliance" faction is scheduled to hold a large-scale fund raiser Saturday evening. President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh have all been invited to attend. The alliance has prepared NT$50,000-per-person dinner tickets with a goal of raising NT$100 million (US$2.9 million) in cash to help finance its members' campaign programs.

"Sales of the dinner tickets have fallen far short of our expectations. Even the presence of our party heavyweights cannot help boost our fund-raising drive," said Cheng Pao-ching, a legislator who concurrently serves as the alliance's chief financier.

According to Cheng, the alliance has so far sold only about NT$30 million worth of dinner tickets. The alliance now has some 50 legislative members. It originally hoped that each member could distribute 100 tickets. But so far, few of its members have managed to sell their quota, with some of them even failing to sell a single ticket, alliance sources said.

KMT candidates face similar financial restraints. Although the KMT has been billed as the world's wealthiest party, its party assets have dwindled substantially over the past year amidst the domestic economic recession, party sources said.

Worse yet, the sources said, the loss of its position as the ruling party has seriously hindered the KMT's fund-raising efforts. In the past, major local business groups never hesitated to make generous political contributions to the party.

As the current DPP government has repeatedly vowed to eradicate the influence of moneyed interests and organized crime in domestic politics, KMT sources said, many private companies are now reluctant to donate funds to the party and its candidates.

Many KMT candidates have traditionally relied on the party for campaign funding. The party has so far twice distributed money to its standard-bearers for the upcoming elections, but the amount reportedly is only one-tenth that of the previous figure.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC GLOOM AFFECTS CAMPAIGN FUNDING (II)

TEXT.P: The three other opposition parties -- the People First Party (PFP), the New Party (NP) and the newly formed Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) -- have also had a hard time soliciting donations from business groups. Candidates of the three parties have all had to try to cash in on their respective party leader's personal charisma to boost their fund-raising drives.

PFP Legislator Chin Hui-chu, who is seeking re-election in the Taipei northern precinct, organized an auction last week to raise campaign funds. Initially, each item put up for auction could only fetch between NT$10,000 and NT$20,000. But after PFP Chairman James Soong arrived at the auction hall, items began fetching up to NT$100,000, and even as much as NT$300,000.

Encouraged by the marvelous results of the unprecedented campaign fund-raising method, Chin said she plans to invite Soong, one of the brightest stars in the local political arena, to attend another one of her fund-raisers to be held later this month.
In addition to stumping for PFP candidates, Soong has also been traveling around the island to attend dinners organized by party candidates to lend his support for their fund-raising drives.
In comparison, TSU candidates have relied solely on the party's spiritual leader -- former President Lee Teng-hui -- to help raise campaign funds and even to boost awareness of their party.

Lee's outspokenness and unique personal appeal have often attracted large crowds to TSU campaign rallies where the party has been selling a wide range of products, from lunch boxes and backpacks to T-shirts, bearing Lee's trademark smiling face.

Sales of these products has helped the new party raise NT$7.5 million so far, TSU sources said, adding that most of the buyers are elderly voters and that sales are far more brisk in southern Taiwan than in central and northern parts of the island. The trend fully reflects Lee's support base, a political observer said.

At campaign rallies, the TSU has also been selling books featuring Lee's 12-year stint as the Republic of China's head of state as well as his political views and life story. Among these books, "An Account of Lee Teng-hui's Years in Office" has reportedly been the best-seller.

As many New Party candidates are political novices from the academic community or from various professional fields, they have also been relying heavily on the party's convener, Legislator Hsieh Chi-ta, or several other party elders for financial support.

Fund-raising difficulties have made candidates of different political stripes become more budget-conscious. They have postponed the opening of their campaign offices or have scaled down their campaign headquarters. So far, many candidates have yet to open their campaign headquarters.

A number of candidates of the same party in the same precinct have adopted a joint campaigning formula to share campaign spending. They have shared campaign offices and have presented joint campaign literature and advertisements.

An advertising agency specializing in city bus advertising business said it has lowered ad fees substantially in order to attract candidates, but so far many city bus advertisement spaces for campaign posters remain available. In the past, a company executive said, city bus ad spaces were fully booked three months before the elections.

The grim domestic economic situation has also dampened local taxi drivers' interest in and passion for election campaigning. Unlike previous years, few taxi cabs have flown campaign banners or flags for any of the candidates this year.
Political observers said the effect of Taiwan's current economic decline and mounting unemployment rate on campaigning for the upcoming elections deserves further observation.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE:
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By Philip Liu and David Hsu)
DOC.TEXT:
The full name of Taiwan businessman in CEP0011 should be "Meng Ching-hsien." A corrected version follows. TAIWAN BUSINESSMAN SHOT TO DEATH IN MANILA
Manila, Oct. 13 (CNA) A Taiwan businessman was shot to death Thursday night in greater Manila's Quezon City, the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Manila said Saturday.
According to police, a gangster riding a motorcycle caught up with the pedicab that Meng Ching-hsien and his girlfriend were riding in on their way to a shopping mall to eat dinner. The gangster pointed a gun at Meng and fired several shots before robbing him of a handbag containing cash, a cellular phone, a checkbook and some other personal belongings.
Meng died after being rushed to hospital by his girlfriend, the TECO said.
The TECO set up a task force to deal with the case shortly after receiving notification of the incident from the Philippine police. It has also assisted Meng's family members to enable them to rush to Manila as soon as possible to deal with his funeral.
It was learned that Meng's parents are expected to arrive in the Philippines on Saturday.
Investigations into the case are still under way.

DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:

The United Daily News:

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE MEDICAL SECTOR IN U.S. URGED TO WORK FOR ROC'S WHO ENTRY
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The deputy representative of the Republic of China in the United States on Saturday urged Taiwanese medical associations in New York to push for the country's entry in the World Health Organization (WHO).

Lee Ying-yuan, the ROC deputy representative in the United States, spoke at the annual meeting of the North American Taiwanese Medical Association and urged members of various Taiwanese medical associations in the metropolitan New York area to exert their influence in the U.S. medical field and at universities to raise awareness of the ROC's efforts to be admitted into the WHO.
Lee also talked about U.S.-Taiwan relations and the current world situation. He said that the United States had thanked the ROC for its support following the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
ROC President Chen Shui-bian reacted positively and immediately to the call by the United States to contribute to the effort to rid the world of terrorism.

The ROC government donated US$500,000 for victims relief through the Red Cross Society of the ROC. It also promised to open its airspace to U.S. military aircraft if necessary and agreed that its Investigation Bureau and National Security Bureau would strengthen information exchanges with the FBI and CIA, according to Lee.
Lee said that he felt that the United States and Europe had developed closer ties since the attacks and he said that the United States and Asian countries would also deepen their existing bonds.

He stressed that the U.S. government has assured Taiwan that it will not make any deals to the detriment of Taiwan's interests when trying to obtain Beijing's cooperation for anti-terrorist actions, and that both countries' long-term stances based on the ideals of democracy and liberty will not change.

DOC.HEADLINE: F-16 JET FIGHTER PILOTS SAFE FOLLOWING TECHNICAL PROBLEM

TEXT.P: An F-16 jet fighter had to deploy its braking parachute while landing at an air base in Hualien after the plane's brakes apparently failed, a military official said Sunday.
The two pilots were not injured and there was no damage to the plane.

Captain Kung Hsiang-kai, head of the Political Warfare Department at the Hualien Air Force Base in eastern Taiwan, said the pilots triggered the braking parachute when they noticed a problem as they were landing.
Kung said maintenance staff at the base was in the process of conducting a thorough examination of the jet fighter. He dismissed speculation that a tire had burst on touchdown.
Kung stressed that the incident was only an isolated case and will not affect the combat readiness and training at the base.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING BALKS AT TAIWAN'S CHOICE FOR ENVOY TO APEC SUMMIT

TEXT.P: A Beijing official said Sunday that Taiwan's departure from the tradition of having an economic leader attend the Asia-Pacific Economic Corporation (APEC) forum gives Beijing "difficulties" in deciding whether to accept Taiwan's representative to the 2001 summit to be held in Shanghai on Oct. 20.

Beijing's Foreign Ministry spokesman Zhu Bangzao, who doubles as the news chief for the Shanghai APEC conference, made the comment in Shanghai in response to questions about Beijing's attitude toward Taiwan's proposal to have a former vice president, Li Yuan-zu, attend the summit on behalf of the Republic of China's president, Chen Shui-bian.

Zhu said Taiwan had previously sent an economic leader to the summit and said that Taiwan should follow its own protocol this time. Taiwan's attempt to "break the pattern" by sending a high-profile political leader has given Beijing pause before giving its approval for Li to attend the meeting, Zhu said.
He refused to say whether Beijing would reject Li, but said that, "Li himself should know."

The Liberty Times, a Taipei-based newspaper, said Sunday that Beijing has reportedly refused to allow Li to attend the summit because of his higher political status than that of the island's former representatives at the summit.

For the previous eight summits, Taiwan had sent an economic official, such as the chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, or a governor of the Central Bank of China to the gathering to avoid any political backlash from mainland China.
Li is a current senior adviser to the president and has served as education minister and justice minister before being elected vice president in 1990 and retiring in 1996.

Chiou I-jen, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, refused to comment on the Liberty Times' report Sunday morning, saying that the Executive Yuan would wait until Beijing's decision on the matter to make any response.
Chiou made the remarks in Hualien, while accompanying Premier Chang Chun-hsiung on an inspection tour in eastern Taiwan.
Meanwhile, Kuomintang specialist on mainland Chinese affairs Chang Jung-kung said if the Liberty Times' report is true, it indicates that Beijing's policy toward Taiwan has its shortcomings.
Chang told a symposium in Taipei on Taiwan's ties with mainland China that Beijing's snub of Li would expose its contempt for the feelings of the people on Taiwan.

Denying Li access to the summit because of China's fear that Taiwan is attempting to break free from past unfavorable practices would cost Beijing a valuable chance to court the friendship of the people of Taiwan, Chang said.

Although Taiwan is partly to blame for the current situation -- Taiwan did not seek counsel with mainland China on who it would send to the summit -- there is a possibility that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is deliberately trying to polarize local people against Beijing with the idea that this could be favorable for the DPP in the year-end elections, according to the KMT strategist.

A top DPP analyst of mainland Chinese affairs, Yen Chien-fa, said that Taiwan, as a member of APEC, should not give up its right to participate fully in all APEC activities because of the limitations imposed on it by Beijing.

Wu Jui-kuo, the People First Party's chief analyst for international affairs, said the situation was regrettable but not surprising given that Beijing maintains that the issue of Taiwan is a domestic one that does not figure on the international stage.

Although the issue of Taiwan's representative to the summit is still pending, Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi and Chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development Chen Po-chih will head for Shanghai Monday as scheduled for an APEC ministerial meeting between Oct. 17-18.

They will exchange views with their counterparts from mainland China and eight other member economies on trade issues and bilateral free trade agreements and study ways to promote regional trade liberalization as outlined in the 1994 Bogor Declaration which was named after the Indonesian city where the APEC leaders met in 1994.
The conclusions that emerge from the ministerial conference will be put in a document titled the "Shanghai Accord."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN LIEN CHAN CALLS FORMER PRESIDENT'S REMARKS 'OUTRAGEOUS'

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan responded Sunday to former President Lee Teng-hui's remarks calling the KMT an "alien regime" by saying that the statement was "outrageous."

Lien was responding to Lee's recent remarks that while he was president, he spent much of his time trying to remove the "alien regime" from power. Although he was now retired, Lee said that he was not about to allow the "alien regime" to regain power. Lee made the remarks while stumping for the newly formed political party the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).
Lee served concurrently as KMT chairman and ROC president between 1989 and 2000.
Lien, while stumping for Jason Hu, KMT candidate for Taichung City mayor, lashed out at the performance of the ruling Democratic Progressing Party and then turned his attention to Lee.

Lien, without mentioning Lee by name, said, "An old man who is retired has been going around every day making outrageous remarks." He said that although this old man stressed that he loves Taiwan, he criticizes the government created in accordance with the Constitution of the Republic of China and calls it an "alien regime."
Lien said that, "Anyone who recognizes the Republic of China and lives and develops under its system should not be differentiated in terms of foreign or local."
Lien stressed that the old man is pandering to the few, which he said was "splitting the country." He also said that the remarks were "heart-wrenching."
With the approach of the year-end elections, Lee's comments about the KMT and his successor as KMT leader have become more vitriolic, according to observers.

Lee told his supporters that the current political chaos is due to the hindrance of the opposition, and because "someone" still refuses to accept defeat in the 2000 presidential election. Lien finished a distant third with just 2.9 million votes, next to President Chen Shui-bian's 4.9 million votes and former Taiwan Governor James Soong's 4.6 million votes.

Lee has also criticized Lien without mentioning him by name by saying that a person holding a Ph.D. degree in political science should know better than to try to recall the president. Lee said that this showed a lack of political common sense.
The KMT, which originally refrained from commenting on Lee's remarks, expelled Lee from the party in September and has recently begun to refute his statements.
Meanwhile, a former KMT secretary-general said Sunday that Lee should feel sorry for calling the KMT an "alien regime."
John Chang made the remarks at the inauguration of his campaign headquarters in downtown Taipei for the year-end legislative election.

Chang noted that the late KMT Chairman Chiang Ching-kuo had long promoted the idea of "localization," which aimed at integrating the ethnic groups in Taiwan, but he said the "localization" promoted by some has sought to drive a wedge between the peoples, and would create differences between locals and mainlanders who came to Taiwan in 1949 with the Nationalist government after it was defeated by the Communists in the civil war.
Chang, without mentioning Lee by name, said that someone's idea of "localization" has twisted the true spirit of late President Chiang.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT ASSETS OPEN TO PUBLIC SCRUTINY: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang (KMT) is willing to compensate the country in compliance with the law should any of its assets be found to have been acquired illegally, a spokesman for the leading opposition party said Sunday.

Speaking at a news conference, Wang Chih-kang, head of the KMT's Cultural Communication Committee, stressed that the KMT has acquired all its assets in accordance with the law and that the party's property is open for public examination.

Wang called the news conference to explain the KMT's position after the government led by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) revealed its intention to reclaim KMT's assets which it said were seized through improper means.

Emphasizing that the government should pay heed to the country's economic problems by seeking political stability with the opposition, Wang described the move by the Cabinet as a "nothing but a campaign trick" for the December's elections for legislative seats and local government chiefs.
Wang said that the trick would not help Taiwan's economy or its political situation and would have a negative impact.

According to the KMT spokesman, the DPP is fully aware of the fact that the KMT has obtained all its property and assets through legal means. If the ruling party wants to reclaim the KMT's assets, it will need a legal base to do so, Wang noted, adding that it is impossible for the legislature to enact a law allowing the seizure of assets in a short time.
Lawmaker Lai Shyh-bao of the New Party also said that a special law could not be passed in the near-term.

Criticizing the DPP for injecting "political strife" at a sensitive time in the run-up to the year-end elections, Lai proposed that the government move swiftly to resolve the problems related to the vast government-owned land that is being illegally occupied or misused by private individuals or agencies.

According to Lai, a total of 74,831 hectares of government-owned land has been illegally occupied as of the end of last year. He stressed that the government should quickly act to handle the issue if it is serious about its vow to return national property to the people.

DPP lawmaker Shen Fu-hsiung contended that the attitude of the People First Party (PFP) will be critical following the ruling party's plan to reclaim the KMT's assets, as the DPP seats at the legislature for the time being are too few to pass the DPP's bills.

In other words, Shen explained, the government would tone down its voice should it decide to cooperate with the KMT to forge a planned coalition government following the December legislative elections. Otherwise, the government would remain unaffected and increase its claim if it chooses another party in the plan to cooperate with other parties.
Against such a backdrop, the PFP will play a critical role as to which extent it would support the KMT in the government's action to reclaim its assets, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE TENG-HUI CLAIMS TO BE SUCCESSOR OF CHIANG CHING-KUO IN THOUGHT

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui, who was expelled from the party he led for 12 years, claimed Sunday that his concept of "new Taiwanese" originated from the thoughts of late President and KMT chief Chiang Ching-kuo.

In a symposium in Taipei, the former KMT chairman said that his "new Taiwanese," which expands the definition of Taiwanese to anyone living on the island and intending to make the island their home, rather than those who immigrated from the mainland before 1949, was inspired by Chiang.
He recalled Chiang saying during his later years in the presidency that after living on the island for 40 years, "I have already become a Taiwanese."
Lee said: "That is the central idea of 'new Taiwanese.'"
After Chiang died on Jan. 13, 1988, Lee said he decided to harness the idea envisioned by Chiang to his own cause.
He regretted that Chiang's family members and children were oblivious to these thoughts of Chiang's.

A native of Taiwan and educated in agriculture, Lee was recruited by Chiang as a minister without portfolio in 1972, and then was assigned in sequence to head the Taipei City Government, the Taiwan Provincial Government and to be vice president.
He succeeded Chiang as president and KMT chairman after Chiang's death in 1988.

Lee said he had written down every conversation that he had had with Chiang since Chiang began grooming him as his successor by naming him as his running mate in the 1984 presidential election, but dared not publish the details of these meetings. Instead, Lee said the conversations between Chiang and himself would be published by his daughter after his death. He gave no reasons for wanting to release the conversations in this way.

Lee stepped down from the post of party chairman after his party lost the presidential election last year and has distanced himself from the party he led for 12 years for what he called the party's deviation from its political principles.
He recently began aggressively campaigning for candidates of the newly formed Taiwan Solidarity Union and lambasted the KMT as an "alien regime" colluding with Beijing to betray Taiwan.
His rhetoric against the KMT forced the party to revoke his party membership on Sept. 21.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO APPROVE LOCAL AIRLINES' USE OF CHINA'S AIRSPACE

TEXT.P: A Republic of China legislator urged the government Sunday to allow its civilian airlines to fly over mainland Chinese airspace on their way to European destinations to ensure the safety of passengers.

Legislator Elmer Fung from the opposition New Party made the call in a news conference, saying that he will press the government to consider the issue in his forthcoming interpellation in the legislature.

Fung just returned from a visit to mainland China, heading a delegation of executives from six of Taiwan's civilian airlines. After their talks with mainland Chinese aviation officials and industry representatives, a consensus was reached that Taiwan carriers could fly over mainland Chinese airspace for the security of passengers following the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States, as well as for saving time and money for the airlines.

He added that proposals by Taipei-based China Airlines and EVA Airways to fly their European routes over mainland airspace have been positively received by the mainland. Fung described mainland China's willingness to release its "first aviation right" as a good will gesture by Beijing authorities.
"If the government approves this proposal, the airlines as a whole can save approximately NT$500 million (US$14.5 million) per year, and each ticket could be reduced by NT$3,000," Fung noted.
Fung also urged the government to approve the proposal based on the consideration of the security of the public and not get mired in political ideologies.

The aviation industries in both Taiwan and mainland China have suffered immense losses in terms of time and money due to the fact that direct flight services between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are still banned.

Meanwhile, ROC's Minister of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) Yeh Chu-lan stressed Sunday that cross-Taiwan Strait aviation rights negotiations should be conducted based on the condition of equality and dignity, and any decision cannot be made unilaterally.
Yeh pointed out that the government generally does not oppose transport links with mainland China, however, these negotiations must be done through authorized agencies.
She added that the issues related to cross-strait relations are usually handled by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, while the MOTC takes care of the supporting and technical work.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANDARIN BECOMES THE SECOND-MOST FAVORED FOREIGN LANGUAGE IN JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 14 (CNA) (By Huang Ching-ching and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Mandarin Chinese has become the second foreign language that Japanese college students think they should learn, according to a survey released Saturday by Japan's Cabinet.
The survey, which was conducted in July, received 3,450 valid replies from 5,000 Japanese over 15 years of age about their opinions on university education.
The results indicated that Japanese students prefer to learn a language that is spoken widely and one that is used in a country close to Japan.

The survey found that 92.1 percent though that among foreign languages, university students should learn English first, followed by 59.6 percent for Chinese, 26.5 percent for French and 25.6 percent for Korean. German, which previously was the second-most favored foreign language for Japanese, was chosen by 19.3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA BEHIND APEC ENVOY CHOICE: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will decide who will lead the Republic of China delegation to the Oct. 20-21 summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Shanghai, Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi said Monday.

Lin noted that neither he nor Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman Chen Po-chi had participated in the selection of former Vice President Li Yuan-zu as the original proxy of President Chen Shui-bian at the coming summit. He added that although he had no options for a suitable candidate, MOFA is fully in charge of the issue.
Lin made the remarks following his arrival in Shanghai for an APEC ministerial meeting to be held Thursday.

Mainland Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Zhang Qiyueh said earlier the same day that she will negotiate with two ministers from Taiwan on Taipei's representative at the APEC summit, but added that Beijing insists that Taipei send an official with an economic background in accordance with past practice.
At the same time, MOFA spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue reiterated that Li is Taipei's "sole choice" and called on the Beijing authorities to respond favorably.

She said that S.C. Shen, head of MOFA's International Organizations Department who arrived in Shanghai Sunday for a senior officials' meeting, was negotiating with the mainland Chinese side over the issue.

P.K. Chang, a former CEPD chairman and now a chief at the opposition Kuomintang-sponsored Policy Research Foundation, said Taiwan's selection of its representative at the APEC summit should focus on the actual benefits the selection can bring rather than just achieving superficial publicity.
He said it would be best and would represent a breakthrough should Li be allowed to take part in the summit.

Commenting on Beijing's rejection of Li, Chang said it is obvious that there had not been good coordination between the host country and the Taiwanese side. From the point of view of precedence, he went on, Taiwan usually sends a government official with an economic background to the event.

However, he said that Li, a criminal law expert and a senior presidential advisor, would be an "adequate" candidate for the APEC summit, the theme of which will center on anti-terrorism efforts, according to Chang. However, he reminded relevant government authorities that Li would need to be provided with sufficient information on trade and economics to allow him to engage in bilateral talks with envoys from other member states.

Chang, who has taken part in several APEC summits on behalf of the ROC head of state, declined a proposal that he himself could represent the president at the coming APEC leaders' meeting, on the grounds that he is no longer a government official or an official policymaker.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EIGHTH-LARGEST TRADING PARTNER OF U.S.

TEXT.P: Taiwan's market share in the United States dropped in the first seven months of this year, making Taiwan the eighth-largest trading partner of the United States, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Monday.
DGBAS officials said that the decrease was due mainly to the sharp fall of U.S. demand for East Asian information products resulting from the slowdown of the U.S. economy.
According to DGBAS statistics, Taiwan's market share in the United States fell 0.38 percentage point to 2.95 percent in the first seven months of this year.
Canada and Mexico were the largest and second-largest trading partners, respectively, of the United States in the same period, according to the DGBAS figures.
The two countries' U.S. market shares were 19.41 percent and 11.31 percent, respectively, according to the statistics.
Japan was the third-largest trading partner of the United States during the period, with a market share of 11.17 percent, a year-on-year decline of 0.88 percentage points.
South Korea was the seventh-largest U.S. trade partner, with a market share of 3.04 percent, a decrease of 0.27 percentage points from the year-earlier figure.

DOC.HEADLINE: KIDNAPPER OF GENERALISSIMO DIES IN U.S.

TEXT.P: Gen. Chang Hsueh-liang, who briefly kidnapped Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in 1936 at the peak of the Chinese civil war, died Monday in Hawaii at the age of 101, according to his family.
He was admitted to the Straub Hospital in Honolulu Sept. 28 suffering from pneumonia and moved to the intensive care ward Oct. 9 after his condition worsened.
The hospital took him off a life-support system at the request of his family late last week.
Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Chang Chun-hsiung conveyed their condolences to Chang's family through Taiwan's representative office in Honolulu after learning of his death.

Born in 1901, Chang graduated from a military academy in northeastern China. In 1928, he succeeded his father, a warlord who dominated northeastern China after the Republic of China was founded in 1911, as leader of his father's militia, called the Northeastern Army.

In order to integrate the Northeastern Army into the forces of the Nationalist government, Chiang, who led the nationalists at the time, named Chang as the commander-in-chief of the army in northeastern China in 1929.

Chang and his followers were expelled from their stronghold when the Japanese Imperial Army invaded China in 1931 and occupied northeastern China. Chang, who was eager to drive the Japanese out of northeastern China and reclaim his former fiefdom, was at odds with Chiang, who wanted to use Chang's army to fight against the burgeoning Chinese communists.
The quarrel turned into a public brawl Dec. 12, 1936, when Chang took Chiang hostage in Sian in an attempt to force him to join with the communists to fight Japan.

Ironically, Chang was persuaded by Chiang to give up his attempt and submit himself to the Nanking-based Nationalist government for discipline. Chang escorted Chiang to Nanking Oct. 25 that year, ending the so-called Sian Incident.
Chang was put under house arrest thereafter, first in Zhejiang Province, then in Jiangxi Province and finally in Taiwan in 1946 after the nationalists fled from the communists.
Chiang died in 1975 in Taiwan, but Chang's ordeal was not over until 1988, when Chiang's son and successor, President Chiang Ching-kuo, also died.
Chang was granted relative freedom of movement within the island in 1988 by then-President Lee Teng-hui and was allowed to move to Honolulu in 1993, where he lived quietly.
He celebrated his 100th birthday May 28, 2000 in Honolulu with more than a hundred family members and friends from both Taiwan and mainland China.

Although he was blamed by the Nationalist government for giving the Chinese communists a much-needed reprieve when they were on the run from the nationalist forces, Chang has never returned to his northeastern China homeland, despite repeated entreaties from Beijing.
Chang married twice, divorcing his first wife Yu Feng-chih in 1964 and marrying his longtime female companion Chao Yi-ti while in captivity in Taiwan. Chao died in Honolulu June 23, 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: REVISED LAW TO FACILITATE TRANSPORT LINKS WITH MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Defying the government, lawmakers Monday passed at its first reading a revised law that would allow people from Taiwan proper to visit mainland China via the offshore islands of Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu.

Legislators at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Interior Committee approved an amendment to the "Statute Governing the Development of the Offshore Islands" that would lift a ban on people from Taiwan proper traveling to and from the mainland by allowing passage via either of the three Taiwan-controlled groups of islands lying opposite the mainland.

The government opened the "mini three direct links" -- trade, postal and transport exchanges -- between Kinmen and Matsu and the mainland port cities of Xiamen and Fuzhou at the beginning of this year as a litmus test for the possible opening of full-scale links between Taiwan and the mainland.
Under the existing measures, residents of the two islands or those who have listed their household registration on the island for more than six months can sail to and from the mainland directly.
The revised bill also includes Penghu along with Kinmen and Matsu as the embarkation points for people from Taiwan traveling between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Although there is still a long way to go before the amendment is signed to law by the president, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) -- which charts Taiwan's mainland policy -- expressed immediate reservations about the move. The bill has to pass second and third legislative readings before it can be sent to the Presidential Office for approval.

MAC Vice chairman Teng Chen-chung said that the revision, if adopted, would produce a total "door-opening" effect for the 23 million people of Taiwan and that his council will seek to have it adopted step by step in order to minimize the possible negative impact on the nation.

In stark contrast to the government stance, several business leaders hailed the amendment, saying it would greatly cut the cost and time for cross-strait travelers, especially Taiwanese investors on the mainland.

Tai Sheng-tung, chairman of the Association of the Small- and Medium-Sized Enterprises of the ROC, said that currently, a single trip via either Hong Kong or Macau takes about seven hours and costs NT$17,000 (US$480) in flights, while sailing through either Kinmen, Matsu or Penghu would take only three hours at the most and cost about NT$4,500.

Most important, the local travel and transport industries would also profit greatly from the new move by breaking Hong Kong's and Macau's grip as embarkation points for Taiwan people traveling in and out of the mainland. Hong Kong alone earns about NT$10 billion (US$289 million) by serving mainland-bound Taiwan visitors annually, Tai said.

Echoing Tai's view, Hsu Sheng-hsiung, chairman of the Electrical and Electronic Association, said that the new measures, if finalized, would benefit most of the nearly 10,000 Taiwan investors in the southern mainland province of Fujian.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLIGHT DETOURS OVER MAINLAND CHINA NEED DISCUSSION: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Any local airlines who wish to fly through mainland Chinese airspace must seek permission from the Taiwan authorities, Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan said Monday.

Yeh said current laws forbid Republic of China aircraft, vessels or other vehicles from flying, sailing, or passing through mainland Chinese airspace, territory, or waters without ROC permission and the mandate to waive these prohibitions rests not with the transport ministry but with the Mainland Affairs Council and the Executive Yuan, said Yeh.

Taiwan air carriers' requests to fly through mainland Chinese airspace on their way to Europe to save costs involve the Taiwan government's power to regulate aviation rights and cannot be granted by anyone other than the government.
The government, meanwhile, will not accede to such requests unless it can first consult with Beijing, Yeh said.

She made the remarks after a local newspaper reported Monday that the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) is set to recommend its members to fly from East Asia to Europe via mainland China rather than over India and Afghanistan in light of the U.S. strikes in Afghanistan.

The paper quoted sources at the International Air Transport Association as saying that one-third of the flights between Asia and Europe are routed via Southeast Asia, the Bay of Bengal, India, Afghanistan and the Middle East.
But business on this route was dealt a serious blow after the U.S. launched strikes on the Taliban regime in Afghanistan on Oct. 8.
As a result, the ICAO is mulling to divert the route to the four mainland Chinese flight information zones of Kunming, Chengdu, Lanzhou and Urumqi before flying over Siberia into Europe.
About 2,600 km of this route is in mainland Chinese airspace, over mainly highland, desert and mountain ranges.
Only flights by Hong Kong-based Cathay Pacific Airways take this route to Europe thus far, according to the ICAO.

Taiwan is not a member of the ICAO and is not expected to be informed of its recommendations for the detour. However, Beijing air traffic officials promised Oct. 12 to open the route to Taiwan carriers should they apply to use it.

Opposition New Party lawmaker Elmer Fung, who brokered the Oct. 12 meeting between Taiwan carriers and Beijing officials, estimated that the route over mainland China will save NT$500 million (US$14.5 million) per year for each of the two Taiwan air carriers that provide services between Taiwan and Europe, resulting in a one-way airfare reduction of NT$3,000.
Beijing's unilateral gesture, however, was denounced by the Taiwan authorities, who described the move as a political ploy to downgrade the island into a mainland province.
Officials in Taipei also blamed Beijing for trying to drive a wedge between the Taiwan authorities and Taiwan air carriers.
Beijing has boycotted any dialogue with the Taiwan authorities unless it admits Beijing's claims that there is only one China, a prerequisite Taipei will not accept.

DOC.HEADLINE: 70,000 POLICE BEGIN CRACKDOWN ON VOTE-BUYING, ELECTION VIOLENCE

TEXT.P: A 70,000-strong police task force began cracking down on vote-buying and election-related violence Monday, 46 days before the year-end legislative and local elections, according to sources from the National Police Administration (NPA).

Ninety people will compete for 23 county chiefs and mayoral seats, while 458 will vie for 176 of the 225 legislative seats at the year-end elections. Forty-nine seats for legislators-at-large will be allocated to political parties according to each party's ballots gained at the elections.

The NPA convened two meetings on anti- vote-buying and election-related violence measures in mid-August and mapped out a mechanism late that month that involves the laying out of information networks to improve the policing of elections, according to the NPA sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: CADMIUM-CONTAMINATED PADDY FOUND IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Four areas of rice paddy in southern Taiwan have been found to be contaminated by cadmium, with levels of the heavy metal exceeding the standard acceptable figure, Council of Agriculture (COA) officials said Monday.

The officials said that a total of three tonnes of rice grown on the affected land in Huwei, Yunlin County, were contaminated and that the COA will join hands with Yunlin county officials to buy and then destroy the contaminated rice.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 16, or the 30th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1758: Noah Webster, American lexicographer responsible for the first American dictionary, is born.
1793: The execution of Marie-Antoinette, 38, queen-consort of the late King Louis XVI, and the prospects of further executions by guillotine of both counter-revolutionaries and revolutionaries suggest that France is slipping even deeper into anarchy.
1846: American dentist William T. G. Morton successfully uses an anesthetic (diethyl ether) for the first time and removes a tumor from a young man's jaw at Massachusetts General Hospital.
1886: David Ben-Gurion, first prime minister of Israel, is born in Poland. He was a leading force in the creation of the Israeli state.
1906: British New Guinea becomes part of Australia.
1933: Republic of China government troops launch a fifth all-out offensive against communist rebels by adopting a fort-blockade policy of moving carefully and steadily in a step-by-step fashion.
1946: Ten leading Nazis found guilty some two weeks earlier of crimes against humanity by the International War Crimes Tribunal are hanged in the gymnasium of Nuremberg Prison.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek presents the Chinese communists with eight conditions for a nationwide cease-fire.
1949: The Kuomintang establishes the Revolutionary Practice Institute with party leader Chiang Kai-shek as its president.
1951: Liaquat Ali Khan, prime minister of Pakistan, is shot dead while addressing a public meeting in Rawalpindi.
1959: George C. Marshall, American soldier, diplomat and politician, dies at the age of 78. As U.S. secretary of state, he organized the European Recovery Program, often called the Marshall Plan, for which he received the 1953 Nobel Peace Prize.
1963: Ludwig Erhard succeeds Konrad Adenauer as chancellor of West Germany.
1964: Communist China explodes its first atom bomb at the Lop Nor test site in Sinkiang.
1972: President Dawda Kairbr Jawara of Gambia arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives a 30-member delegation of the American Association of State Colleges and Universities. The group is headed by Eastern Washington State College President Emerson C. Shuck.
1978: Polish Cardinal Karol Wojtyla is elected pope, the first non-Italian pope since 1542 and the youngest this century.
1979: Wei Jingsheng, noted human rights activist in mainland China, is sentenced to 15 years imprisonment by a "people's court" in Beijing for "anti-revolutionary" activities.
1981: Moshe Dayan, Israeli politician and minister of defense, dies of a heart attack at the age of 66. He directed the 1956 Sinai campaign and the 1967 Six-Day War.
1982: Wu Jung-ken, a 25-year-old mainland Chinese air force pilot, flies his MiG-19 to a U.S. military base outside Seoul in South Korea.
1982: Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, 1970 Nobel Prize winner for literature, arrives in Taiwan from Tokyo at the invitation of the Wu San-lien Literary Foundation of the Republic of China.
1984: Chiang Nan, pen name of Chinese writer Liu Yi-liang, is shot and killed by an assassin at his home in San Francisco.
1987: The worst storm to hit Britain in 300 years lashes southern Britain, demolishing buildings, blacking out London and killing 18 people.
1989: A committee of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, meeting in Lausane, Switzerland, votes 76-11 in favor of a ban on international trade in ivory.
1999: The ROC navy's destroyer "Kunyang" is formally decommissioned after 31 years of service.
2000: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh says that he feels no remorse for having thrown his weight behind President Chen Shui-bian in the later stages of the presidential campaign in March of the same year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man, even when he is not doing anything, is serious; and, even when he does not speak, is truthful."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 82.04 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Tuesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 82.04 points to close at 3,794.86.
Market turnover amounted to NT$31.47 billion (US$0.91 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON HAIYAN EXPECTED TO DEVIATE FURTHER AWAY FROM TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau announced Tuesday that although Typhoon Haiyan is expected to deviate further away from Taiwan, the public should still remain on guard against heavy rains and high tides brought on by the typhoon.
Meteorologists said that Haiyan has been slowing down and has continued to turn northward, which will cause it to narrowly miss the island.

As of 1:15 p.m., Haiyan was located approximately 280 kilometers east of northern Taiwan, with a storm radius of 250 kilometers. It was moving at 15 kilometers per hour in a north-northwesterly direction but was slowing down to nine kilometers per hour and turning toward a north-northeasterly course.
Haiyan has been packing winds of about 130 kilometers per hour near its center, with gusts of up to 165 kilometers per hour.

Meteorologists said that rain and winds are expected to intensify in northern and northeastern Taiwan toward Tuesday evening but that the island is expected to be free of the typhoon's influence by Wednesday night.

All flights and some railway services between Hualien in eastern Taiwan and the capital city of Taipei were canceled. Schools and businesses were closed for Monday in northeastern Taiwan's Ilan County.
In ports around Taiwan, 403 fishing vessels carrying a total of 3,167 mainland Chinese fishermen took up shelter from the typhoon.
The three-member crew of a Taiwan fishing vessel, the Hsinfusheng No. 1, was rescued by an Air Force helicopter Tuesday morning after having lost power in rough waters west of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA TO CONDUCT THOROUGH SOIL POLLUTION INVESTIGATION AROUND ISLAND

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration will conduct a thorough soil pollution investigation around the island following two recent cases of cadmium-contaminated rice paddies in southern Taiwan.

In a previous soil sample investigation, the administration found that a total of 1,024 hectares of land around the island were contaminated with one or more of eight kinds of heavy metals -- namely arsenic, mercury, copper, zinc, lead, nickel, cadmium and chromium. Arable land seriously polluted by heavy metals exceeded 300 hectares, according to the investigation.

In early September, 1,800 kilograms of cadmium-contaminated rice were found at warehouses of rice retailers in southern Taiwan. The Environmental Protection Administration and the Council of Agriculture traced the origins to a rice paddy in Huwei, Yunlin County.

Reports in recent days of a second cadmium-pollution case involving four areas of rice paddies aroused the concern of authorities. While tracing the cause of pollution, the Environmental Protection Administration has decided to conduct intensive studies on soil samples from polluted areas.

In the process of industrialization and urbanization, Taiwan's environment is losing ground to the growing population and to the mushrooming number of manufacturing plants. Toxic industrial waste has become the most damaging pollutant to arable land around the island.

Regarding the cadmium-contaminated rice paddy in Huwei region, nearby chemical plants have been suspected by environmental protection authorities of being responsible for polluting the area's ground water. Some dye producing factories have been under investigation, according to police.

The investigation is expected to be completed within six months, and the polluted areas will be placed under the strict control of the authorities, according to Cheng Hsien-jung, director of the Water Quality Protection Bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC STANDS FIRM ON CHOICE OF APEC SUMMIT ENVOY

TEXT.P: Former Vice President Li Yuan-zu remains the Republic of China government's sole choice as its representative to the annual informal leadership meeting to be held in Shanghai Oct. 20-21, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokeswoman said Tuesday.

"Li is our only choice. We do not have any replacement, and all relevant preparations are proceeding as scheduled," said Chang Siao-yue, director of the MOFA's Department of Information and Cultural Affairs.
Chang said the ROC government decided after careful deliberation to pick Li as President Chen Shui-bian's special envoy to the APEC summit meeting.

"We earnestly hope that mainland China can make a goodwill and positive response to our decision," Chang said, pointing out that the MOFA is continuing negotiations with mainland China through proper APEC channels. "We look forward to seeing a final result as soon as possible," he added.
In the meantime, Chang said, relevant government agencies are briefing Li on APEC-related affairs in preparation for his attendance at the Shanghai APEC summit.

Touching on Beijing's decision to exclude Taiwan and Hong Kong from an anti-terrorism meeting of foreign affairs ministers of APEC member states, Chang said the ROC is eager to play an active role in the current global campaign against terrorism.
Therefore, Chang said, the MOFA will spare no efforts in pushing for Taiwan's participation in the meeting.
Meanwhile, Presidential Office spokeswoman Kuo Yao-chi said officials of the National Security Council and various financial and economic agencies gave APEC-related briefings to Li Tuesday.

Kuo reaffirmed Chang's statement that Li remains the ROC's sole choice to attend the APEC summit. "Negotiations with mainland China over the issue have not made any significant progress, but we have not considered picking any replacement," she noted.

Kuo said the controversy surrounding Taiwan's representation at the APEC summit has attracted international media attention in recent days. "We hope that the international community can pay heed to the unfair treatment the ROC has endured in the forum," she added.

APEC is one of the few international organizations that admit both Taiwan and mainland China. But because of mainland China's opposition, the ROC head of state has been unable to attend the annual APEC summit in person and has had to name a proxy in his stead.

In the past, Beijing forced Taiwan to limit its representation at APEC summits to an economics minister or a business leader. Last year, Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan led the island's delegation to the APEC summit in Brunei.

As anti-terrorism is high on the agenda of the upcoming APEC summit, Kuo said, President Chen hopes that Li, a criminal law expert, can represent the ROC at the meeting to contribute his expertise in the relevant field.

Li, 78, has a doctoral degree in law from Bonn University in Germany. He had been minister of justice before serving as the ROC's vice president between 1990 and 1996. He is now a senior adviser to the President.

APEC groups Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, mainland China, South Korea, the United States, the Philippines, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, Russia, Singapore, Thailand, Taiwan and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES
