DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 82.04 points to close at 3,794.86.
The bourse opened at 3,715.09 and continued to go up later due to a strong rebound in electrical shares. The index fluctuated between 3,794.86 and 3,699.82 during trading.

A total of 1.45 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$31.47 billion (US$0.91 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.49 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$31.94 billion (US$0.93 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most at 1.5 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 0.5 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.1 percent.

The other major categories posted gains, with electrical shares moving up the most at 3 percent, followed by bank and insurance stocks at 1.3 percent, plastics and chemical shares and cement stocks, both at 0.9 percent, and textile issues at 0.7 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 370 to 147, with 113 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURAL OFFICIAL INSISTS ON BUFFER ZONE FOR ARABLE LAND

TEXT.P: As the government is relaxing restrictions to allow more agricultural land to be turned into industrial land or residential areas, an agricultural official said Tuesday that the regulations requiring a buffer zone between agricultural land and developed sites must not be changed.

Chen Hsi-huang, chairman of the Council of Agriculture, said that industrial pollution has been a serious threat to Taiwan's agriculture. He said that the government's regulations requiring the setting up a 10-meter to 30-meter "green belt" buffer zone are meant to protect agricultural areas from pollution.

In a proposal to revise the regulations on land for agricultural purposes, the Council for Economic Planning and Development and the Ministry of Economic Affairs have suggested a relaxing of the "buffer zone" regulations to allow the industry more flexibility in acquiring land.
Insisting that arable land and agriculture must not be further sacrificed in the process of industrialization, Chen said that the Council of Agriculture will not give in on its position.

Currently, some 880,000 hectares of land around the island is used for agricultural purposes, and 750,000 hectares of that land is privately owned, according to statistics compiled by the Council of Agriculture.
Approximately 4,000 hectares of arable land are turned into industrial land or residential areas every year with the approval of authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were generally higher on Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for October moved up 79 points to close at 3,810, with 4,642 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for November rose 75 points to finish at 3,800, with 11,023 contract transactions, while December futures increased 74 points to finish at 3,800, with seven contracts traded.
Next March futures fell 76 points to finish at 3,780, with six contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 3,731 for October, 3,725 for November, 3,726 for December, 3,856 for next March, and 3,761 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also generally higher.
October TE futures moved up 7.7 points to close at 185.2, with 1,381 contract transactions, while November TE futures increased 7.5 points to finish at 184.5, with 2,027 contracts traded.
December TE futures rose 9.95 points to finish at 185, with three contracts changing hands. No transactions were reported for other months.
October TF futures moved up 7 points to finish at 580, with 589 contract transactions, while November TF futures increased 7.8 points to close at 577.8, with 879 contracts traded.
December TF futures lost 9.8 points to finish at 560.2, with only one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR CLOSES UNCHANGED ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar closed unchanged at 34.549 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Tuesday.
The local currency opened Tuesday at 34.538 and was traded between 34.538 and 34.558.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$197 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S AIR DEFENSE MISSILES ATTAIN PRECISION GOAL: ARMY OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: An Army spokesman said Tuesday that each of the Army's various types of air defense missiles has achieved a degree of precision that is compliant with combat-readiness goals.

Maj. Gen. Wu Szu-huai said at a routine news conference at the Ministry of National Defense that the Army's Tien Kung, Hawk and Patriot missile batteries have all undergone a series of live-fire testings earlier this year.

Wu, who heads the combat operations department at the Army General Headquarters, said that the successful test-firing of the Patriot missile demonstrates that the Army now possesses a certain degree of anti-missile capability.
It was the first time that the Patriot was test-fired outside of the United States.

Meanwhile, Wu said that the Army has completed the formation of air cavalry brigades equipped with advanced attack helicopters that can hug close to the island's hilly terrain and achieve increased survivability in a combat environment.

He added that these units have allowed the Army's aviation arm to be reclassified from its previous logistics support and transport role to become the primary combat force in any beachhead operations requiring decisive victory.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN URGED TO HEED INVESTMENT RISK IN MAINLAND

TEXT.P: Investment by Taiwan businessmen in mainland China has continued to grow, totaling US$2.12 billion in the first nine months of this year, officials of the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Tuesday.
Officials said the figure represents an 18.95 percent increase from the same period last year.

They noted Taiwan investment in the mainland totaled US$365 million in September alone, up 177 percent from the previous month, which they attributed mainly to Formosa Plastic Group's investment project worth US$48 million in Ningbo, Zejiang province to produce ABS, a plastic product.

Though Taiwan investment in the mainland has increased rapidly, the officials urged businessmen not to overlook investment risk. They said the mainland relies heavily on exports, though its export growth is expected to slow down due to the sluggish world economy. They said Taiwan businessmen had better make risk assessments and not be overly optimistic.
The officials also said that since March this year, Taiwan's investment in the United States has continued to show negative growth except in July.
Investment in the United States in September totaled US$39 million, down 64 percent from the previous month.
A noteworthy phenomenon is the dramatic increase of investment in Canada, totaling US$243 million in the first nine months of this year, up 63-fold from the same period last year.
The top five destinations for Taiwan investment are the British Virgin Islands and the Cayman Islands, the United States, Latin America, Canada and Singapore.
Overall, outbound investment other than to mainland China totaled US$3.28 billion in the first nine months of this year, up 6.94 percent from the same period last year.
The officials also reported that overseas and foreign investments in Taiwan totaled US$4.06 billion in the first nine months this year, down 28.3 percent from the same period last year.
The officials said that affected by the global economic recession and terrorist attacks in the United States, major investor countries have dramatically cut back on overseas investment.
The officials said that after the terrorist attacks, world investors have been investing more conservatively, a trend they said will delay economic recovery.
Overseas Chinese and foreign investment in September totaled US$214.5 million, down 27 percent from the same month last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO COUNTER DPP'S EFFORTS TO TRACK SOURCES OF KMT ASSETS

TEXT.P: The largest opposition party, the Kuomintang, will launch a "return the money to the people" campaign to counter the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's recent campaign to uncover possible illegally acquired KMT assets, a spokesman of the KMT said Tuesday.
Chou Shou-shun noted that since the DPP took office in May 2000, the national wealth has shrunken by NT$20.28 trillion, or an average drop of NT$810,000 (US$23,340) per person.
Chou pointed out that the DPP used the term "return the money to the people" as its campaign theme last year, but during the past 18 months, it has in fact been "looting money from the people."
He said the KMT will campaign on the theme through its local branches, mobilizing the jobless to appeal for "the right to work," and for the public to "forsake the incompetent government."

Chou said that during the one-and-half-year DPP reign, the national economy has worsened because the government lacks a goal and a clear sense of direction. Statistics by its think tank showed that the loss of national wealth in the real estate market, stock market and foreign exchange market alone reached NT$20.28 trillion, or roughly the total amount of central government budgets over 15 years.
Chou said that the these losses have not counted the huge losses resulting from the suspension of the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant or the intervention in the local stock market by the government funds.

The KMT's campaign is seen as a counterattack against the DPP's campaign on investigating the sources of KMT assets. The KMT has responded by saying that this is another "campaign trick" by the DPP in the run-up to the year-end elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. TO ORGANIZE BRAINSTORMING SESSION FOR SUBMARINE DEAL WITH ROC
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 15 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. military is scheduled to discuss in Washington its decision to sell Taiwan eight diesel-powered submarines with U.S. defense contractors, specialists from outside the United States and a small group of Republic of China military personnel, U.S. defense industry sources said Monday.

It is unclear how many defense industry representatives will take part in the meeting, slated for Tuesday. Several staff members of the ROC military procurement mission stationed in the United States are expected to attend the session.

This will be the first time that the U.S. military has invited defense contractors to discuss the plan since the Bush administration agreed to a robust arms sale package to Taiwan in April, which included the sale of eight diesel-powered submarines to help upgrade Taiwan's naval defense capabilities in the face of mainland China's mounting military threat.
U.S. sources said the brainstorming session is mainly designed to provide a forum for exchanges of views between U.S. military personnel and defense contractors.

During the session, U.S. military staff will brief defense industry executives from the United States and other countries on the ROC's naval defense needs and ask them to offer initiatives to help Taiwan acquire diesel-powered submarines.
As the United States itself has stopped producing diesel submarines, it must seek the help of other countries in delivering the ROC's submarine order.

U.S. sources said although mainland China has been pressuring countries capable of building older-style submarines not to cooperate with the United States, the U.S. military is confident that it can realize its plan by pooling its resources with foreign defense contractors.

Commenting on a Taiwan newspaper report that Taiwan would be able to take delivery of the first diesel submarine from the United States in 2010 at the earliest, U.S. sources said it is only a tentative schedule jointly worked out by the two sides. The exact date will depend on the manufacturing capability of the selected contractor, Taiwan's budget plans and other relevant factors.

In Taipei, a spokesman for the ROC's Navy General Headquarters (NGH) has confirmed that a U.S. team familiar with submarine technology visited Taiwan in late September to look into its naval defense needs.

"The two sides have reached a consensus on some procedural issues," NGH spokesman Maj. Gen. Wang Chueh said, adding that the U.S. military has posted a notice on its official Web site saying it will host a presentation for qualified shipbuilders from around the world Tuesday to introduce key points of its submarine deal with Taiwan. Taiwan's state-owned China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) has also received an invitation.

Wang said the United States will decide which shipbuilding group will be contracted to build the submarines for Taiwan in six months. If all goes well, he said, construction on the first submarine will get under way in 2005 and the ship will be ready for delivery around 2011.

Meanwhile, CSBC executives have on many occasions expressed their company's interest in landing the order to build the submarines for the ROC Navy. CSBC officials said the company has experience in building warships and repairing submarines. "If we can obtain a blueprint and certain technology, we'll be able to build the eight diesel submarines," said a CSBC executive.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATOR'S ABSENCE CAUSES PLENARY MEETING ABORTED

TEXT.P: Forty-six days before the election of the fifth legislature and two weeks before the election recess of the Legislative Yuan, a plenary meeting was aborted Tuesday morning because too many legislators were absent.
Wang Jin-pyng, president of the Legislative Yuan, said that the legislature might not be able to finish the interpellations by the end of this month.
As to the screening of bills, Wang said that he will convene a caucus meeting Thursday, hoping all political parties can reach consensus to accelerate the screening work.
Wang said that bills related to the resolutions of the Economic Development Advisory Conference and Taiwan's participation in the World Trade Organization should be attended to as soon as possible.
Before the election recess, there will be two plenary meetings and the legislators will have five working days to screen the bills, according to Wang.
Many incumbents are running for a new term at the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TURNOVER OF TAIWAN COMPANIES DOWN 14 PERCENT IN SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: Turnover of Taiwan companies listed on the stock market decreased by an average of 14.61 percent in September over the same period last year, according to statistics compiled by the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TSE).

The statistics of the TSE show that turnover of the 576 listed companies totaled NT$470.5 billion (US$13.6 billion) in September, and only 159 companies registered growth during the same month, mainly in transportation and petrochemical industries.

Among the companies, the petrochemical industry registered the highest growth in its turnover in September with 6.07 percent, while traditional enterprises posted the highest drop -- 40 percent. The turnover in the electronics industry saw a decrease of 23 percent over the same month from last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA TO CONDUCT EXERCISE AGAINST TOXIC GAS ATTACKS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration announced Tuesday that it is slated to test the preparedness Oct. 26 of emergency personnel and resources in a mock toxic gas attack on the Taipei Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) system.
The exercise will see if the city's response is sufficient to handle an actual attack by terrorists using toxic gas or other biological agents on the city's transit system.

It will be Taiwan's first exercise aiming at preparing for biological and chemical attacks carried out by terrorists, the administration said, adding that more than 1,000 personnel will be mobilized for the exercise from the military, police and fire departments, as well as health, transportation and environmental protection agencies.
The exercise is to be held at an MRT station in downtown Taipei.
The mock emergency will cover such areas as clearing the underground system of passengers, treating the injured and preventing the public from panicking, the administration said.

There will be two exercises Oct. 19 and Oct. 25 before the main test on Oct. 26, and MRT services and street traffic between Chungking South Road and Poai Road will be restricted during the main exercise.

Although no toxic gas attacks have ever occurred in Taiwan, the administration said it will print manuals to serve as a reference to prepare relevant government authorities and the public for any contingency.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEATHER BUREAU LIFTS LAND WARNING FOR TYPHOON HAIYAN

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau lifted its land warning for Typhoon Haiyan Tuesday evening, saying the storm will be moving rapidly away from Taiwan after changing direction the same day.
As of 5:30 p.m. Tuesday, Haiyan was located approximately 320 kilometers northeast of Taiwan and is moving at 19 kilometers per hour on a northeasterly course, meteorologists said.

The weathermen lifted the land warning a half day earlier than expected, as Typhoon Haiyan changed direction and was regarded as less of a threat to Taiwan because of the easing of the high pressure area in the Pacific Ocean.
It is expected that the weather bureau will remove its sea warning for the typhoon later Tuesday night.

However, the meteorologists warned that because of the influence from the rim of the typhoon and the effect of the winter monsoon, northeastern and northern parts of Taiwan should prepare for continued rainfall Tuesday night.
They suggested that people not go fishing and stay away from the coast during the night.
As for Wednesday, a meteorologist said the weather around Taiwan, except for the north and northeast parts, will turn better as the high pressure from the north will bring drier air to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI DELEGATION HEADS TO ASIA PACIFIC FILM FESTIVAL IN JAKARTA

TEXT.P: A Taipei delegation left for Indonesia Tuesday to attend the 46th Asia Pacific Film Festival slated for Oct. 17-20 in Jakarta, local motion picture industry sources said.

The Taipei delegation, headed by Chiu Shun-ching, president of the Central Motion Picture Co., was comprised of anthropologist-turned-director Hu Tai-li, actors Yin Chao-te, Tai Li-jen and Chu Chung-heng and actress Hsiao Shu-shen.

According to film festival authorities in Jakarta, the opening and the Asia Pacific Film Festival board of directors meeting is scheduled for Wednesday, followed by an academic seminar and a "Seoul Night" gala on Thursday.

Delegates of all the Asian-Pacific nations and areas that are participating in the film festival are scheduled to call on Indonesian President Megawati Sukarnoputri Friday and get together for an "Asia Pacific Night" gala in the evening.
The most high-profile awards presentation ceremony is scheduled to be held Saturday evening, followed by a farewell cocktail party, according to the Jakarta film authorities.

Taiwan films that have entered the festival include features "What Time Is It There?" by director Tsai Ming-liang, "The Cabbie" by directors Chen Yi-wen and Chang Hua-kun, and "Fleeing by Night" by director Hsu Li-kong.

Two other short films that represent Taiwan are "Grandma's Hairpin," a documentary about aging retired servicemen who came to Taiwan from mainland China 50 years ago, by director Hsiao Chu-chen and "Sounds of Love and Sorrow," a documentary about the lives of Taiwan's aboriginal Paiwanese, produced and directed by Hu Tai-li.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LIKELY TO EXCHANGE TRADE OFFICES WITH MONGOLIA: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that the Republic of China is likely to exchange commercial offices with Mongolia to facilitate exchanges and cooperation.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with a group of young Mongolian politicians who are attending a month-long administrative training class in Taipei.

Chen said the ROC will also study the feasibility of opening its job market to Mongolian blue-collar workers. Taiwan has allowed imports of laborers from several Southeast Asian countries, including Thailand, the Philippines, Indonesia and Vietnam.
Because of a combination of complicated reasons, Chen said, the people of Taiwan have many incorrect and unrealistic perceptions of Mongolia.
"After a visit to Mongolia in October 1999, I have come to understand its true face and picture," Chen said.

Noting that he has long been eager to forge closer ties with Mongolia, Chen said he took the initiative to form a sisterly relationship with Mongolia's capital, Ulan Bator, during his stint as mayor of Taipei between 1994 and 1998.

The sister-city ties have helped boost bilateral friendship and eventually prompted the Mongolian government to grant landing visas to ROC tourists and business people, Chen said. "Now would-be Taiwan visitors to Mongolia no longer need to travel to Japan to apply for visas with the Mongolian Embassy there," he added.
Chen further said he feels that the current administrative training workshop provides a good example for Taiwan-Mongolian exchanges.

"You are the first group of Mongolian youths to receive professional training in Taiwan," Chen told his guests, adding that the program marks the start of bilateral cooperation and that the ROC will continue to sponsor such programs for Mongolian public functionaries in the future.
With a view to boosting bilateral trade and economic cooperation, Chen said his administration is considering exchanging representative offices or trade liaison offices with Mongolia.

All of the participants to the first Mongolian administrator training workshop, organized by the ROC's Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission, are secretaries-general of Mongolia's provincial councils. Fourteen of the 18 Mongolian provinces have sent the top day-to-day affairs managers of their legislative councils to attend the training workshop.
According to the ROC's existing statute on civilian exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, Mongolians are deemed as mainland Chinese people.

Against this background, officials of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said if the government wants to allow imports of Mongolian workers, the proposal must receive the consent of the Legislative Yuan.
CLA officials further said the expansion of import sources of foreign laborers is one of the conclusions reached at the Aug. 24-26 Economic Development Advisory Conference.
In addition to Mongolia, the officials said, North Korea and Myanmar may also be added to the list of countries whose people can be allowed to work in Taiwan legally.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ELECTRONICS CO. BUILDS R&D RELATIONS WITH SCOTTISH FIRMS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Picvue Electronics, Ltd. has invested US$12 million to engage in research and development of crystal display plates with two Scottish manufacturers, visiting Scottish First Minister Henry McLeish said at a news conference Tuesday.
McLeish, at the head of a Scottish trade promotion delegation, arrived in Taiwan Sunday for a three-day visit.

Stressing that the main purpose of this trip in Taiwan is to promote bilateral trade between Scotland and Taiwan and to talk with Taiwan's science and technology enterprises on the establishment of closer cooperative relations.
Dubbed the "European Silicon Valley," Scotland is one of Taiwan's major investment destinations in Europe.

At present, there are 15 Taiwan manufacturers establishing strongholds in Scotland, including Hon Hai Precision Industry Co., Ltd., Lite-On Technology Corp., and Chunghwa Picture Tubes, Ltd., McLeish said, adding that the two-way trade between the two countries in the past year reached US$144 million.
In the past five years, 13 Taiwan manufacturers have invested US$576 million in Scotland.

McLeish said that given the current global economic slowdown and the aftereffects of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States, the time is ripe now for the two countries to cooperate in developing knowledge-based economic industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PILGRIMS SAIL DIRECTLY TO MAINLAND CHINA VIA KINMEN

TEXT.P: A group of pilgrims sailed directly from the southwestern Taiwan port of Putai to the mainland Chinese city of Xiamen via the Republic of China's frontline island of Kinmen Tuesday for a four-day religious tour.

It was the third religious group to be allowed to make a direct voyage to mainland China for religious purposes since the ROC government opened its offshore defense outposts of Kinmen and Matsu to direct trade, mail and shipping links with Xiamen and Mawei in the southeastern mainland province of Fujian -- commonly known as the "mini three links" -- at the beginning of this year.

The group, composed of more than 300 pilgrims from the southern Taiwan county of Chiayi, was jointly organized by three Taoist temples in the county -- Peitien Temple, Paoan Temple and Huangluan Temple.

The group took with it more than 20 icons of folk deities to their home temples. Most of the icons were taken to Taiwan from Fujian more than 100 years ago and had been kept in the three Chiayi temples ever since.

Tsai Wu-chang, the leader of the group, said he welcomes the Legislative Yuan Interior Affairs Committee's endorsement in its first reading a day earlier of a draft revision bill to the existing statute on the development of Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu, another ROC-controlled island group in the Taiwan Strait.

According to the draft revisions, Taiwan residents would be allowed to make direct voyages to mainland China via the three outlying islands. Under the current "mini three links" regulations, only Kinmen and Matsu residents can do so, while Taiwan residents must apply for government approval on a case-by-case basis.

Tsai said he hopes the draft revisions can finally pass the legislative floor to help would-be Taiwan visitors to the mainland save time and money, as well as boosting the economic development of the three outlying islands.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2001 `TAIWAN E-COMMERCE WEEK' OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 2001 "Taiwan E-Commerce Week" opened at a Taipei hotel Tuesday with about 1,000 experts and representatives of the information-technology industry participating.

ROC President Chen Shui-bian delivered a speech at the opening ceremony in which he called the 21st century a "century of information" and stressed the importance of the Internet to economic development.
As Taiwan's economy relies heavily on exports, Chen said, the global trend of E-commerce cannot be neglected.
He said the E-commerce week will demonstrate the results of an ROC government project to promote E-commerce and help local enterprises expand their IT know-how with foreign experts.
The week's activities are being jointly organized by the Institute for Information Industry (III), the Ministry of Economic Affairs and RosettaNet.
III Secretary-General Lin Feng-ching said that application of E-commerce is a major step that is being taken by all countries to improve their competitiveness.

Although the development of E-commerce in Taiwan has been affected by the dotcom crash since the second half of 2000 and the slowdown of the U.S. economy, he noted that the role of the Internet to economic development remains important.

E-commerce week includes "E-Partners" from Oct. 17-18, "E-Manufacturing" from Oct. 19-23, and "E-Commerce" from Oct. 24-25. The activities will feature symposiums that will be attended by experts from home and abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN OPTIMISTIC ABOUT TIES WITH MONGOLIA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian might see one of his dreams come true soon, as there is a good possibility that the Republic of China and Mongolia will exchange trade offices in the near future.

Chen said he is very happy about a recent breakthrough in bilateral relations and attributed the new development to his profound friendship with former Mongolian Prime Minister Janlaviin Narantsatsralt.
Chen, who served as Taipei mayor from 1994-1998, visited Mongolia in October 1999 for the first time, while Narantsatsralt paid a visit to Taiwan a year later.

Chen, who was elected the ROC's 10th president in March 2000, recounted that he assured Narantsatsralt during a state banquet in Taipei that the existing Taiwan-Mongolia and Mongolia-Taiwan associations could serve as a starting point for the exchange of trade and representative offices between the two countries.
Claiming that he is not superstitious, the president revealed nevertheless that everything went smoothly for him after he rode a "horse of heaven" in Mongolia.

The president made the remarks during a meeting at the Presidential Office with 15 Mongolian youths who are taking part in an administrative personnel workshop sponsored by the Cabinet-level Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission.
Chen also told them that the ROC government will study the possibility of importing Mongolian workers to Taiwan to further bilateral exchanges and cooperation.

Lamenting that Taiwan's understanding of Mongolia is limited and superficial, Chen voiced the hope that there will be a breakthrough in two-way ties with the establishment of trade offices on either side.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT CALLS FOR CREATIVITY IN HANDLING `ONE CHINA' ISSUE
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By James Kuo and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said recently that the leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait should treat the "one China" concept in a creative manner.
Chen made the remarks in an interview with Urs Schoettli, a correspondent in Tokyo for the Swiss daily Neue Zurcher Zeitung.
Chen said the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, split since the late 1940s, must start with economic and cultural integration in order to achieve eventual political integration.

"And this process must be based on three principles -- democracy, parity and peace," Chen stressed, adding that every possible solution to cross-strait disputes must take into account the free will of the people of Taiwan and that no party can resort to the use of force.
Chen said that Taiwan has become a mature democracy, with its people freely electing their head of state and political parties vying for popular support by serving the general public.
All these things remain unimaginable in mainland China, Chen said, adding that Taiwan can serve as the vanguard of mainland China's democratization.

Chen lauded the mainland for its economic achievements through market opening and trade reform under the leadership of its patriarch, the late Deng Xiaoping, and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.
Chen further said he is convinced that mainland China's economic success will be followed by social and political reforms after its accession to the World Trade Organization in the near future.
"I firmly believe that mainland China will pursue freedom and democracy in the long run," Chen said optimistically.

The Swiss daily ran an article, titled "Will Taiwan Become the Vanguard of Mainland China's Democratization?" on the front page of its Oct. 13-14 weekend issue, and published the full text of Schoettli's interview with Chen on its international news page.

In the interview, Chen also mentioned that he has been awarded Liberal International's 2001 Prize for Freedom, but complained that Denmark bowed to pressure from the mainland China and refused to grant him a visa, dashing his hopes of traveling to Denmark next month to receive the award in person.
"They awarded me the Prize for Freedom, but they took away my freedom to travel," he said.

The Liberal International, an alliance of more than 80 liberal political parties from more than 60 countries, commended Chen for his "solid record as a human rights activist" and his contributions to democracy on the island.

Chen, a former human rights lawyer, defended an opposition leader who narrowly escaped the death penalty at a sedition trial in 1980 for organizing a demonstration in defiance of a now-scrapped ban on street protests.
Chen went on to become a member of the Legislative Yuan and the mayor of Taipei. He swept to power in presidential elections in March 2000, ending more than five decades of one-party rule.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR TAIWAN AUTOMAKERS TO SET UP R&D CENTERS

TEXT.P: Four Taiwan automobile manufacturers have decided to invest a total of NT$38.6 billion to establish research and development centers under the guidance of the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) of the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
An IDB official said that the plans will greatly improve the island's international auto manufacturing competitiveness.

Despite the fact that the number of vehicle transactions in Taiwan this year is not expected to exceed 350,000, the official said the IDB has helped Yulon Motor, China Motor, Kuozui Motors and Ford Lio Ho Motor to establish R&D centers that will go into operation in 2002 and 2003.
The total investments by the four automakers will amount to NT$38.6 billion -- with Kuozui Motors putting up the highest amount of NT$14 billion.

Ford Motor Co. of the United States will provide an efficient compact production system to Ford Lio Ho and dispatch specialists to train local staff with the aim of developing Taiwan as its Asian R&D center.

Yulon Motor will match this with a plan drawn up by the Asian Technological Center to develop an R&D center that will serve as Nissan Motor's Asia-Pacific design center, while cooperating with nine yet to be selected satellite plants.
China Motor will introduce a comprehensive productivity management system from Japan and Kuozui will adopt Toyota Motor's management system to set up their R&D centers.
With the establishment of these centers, the IDB official noted, Taiwan is likely to become a major automobile R&D center in Asia in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL AUTO, MOTORCYCLE SALES VOLUME TO DECREASE SHARPLY IN 2001

TEXT.P: The sales volume of automobiles and motorcycles in Taiwan this year will decrease sharply due to the sluggish economy, officials of the Industry Development Bureau (IDB) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Tuesday.

The officials estimated that the sales volume of automobiles will decrease to 350,000 from the 420,000 recorded last year, while the volume of motorcycle sales will drop to 610,000 from last year's 700,000.
The IDB also predicted that the impact of Taiwan's admission into the World Trade Organization (WTO) on its automobile and motorcycle industry will be minor.
Local sales of automobiles and motorcycles reached a high in 1996, with automobile sales hitting 560,000, and motorcycle sales standing at 1.17 million.

According to an evaluation by the automobile industry, domestic demand for automobiles should reach an annual average of 500,000. The figure of 350,000 estimated for this year will probably be the lowest, according to automobile industry sources, who added that the volume will bottom out and rally next year.

Because Taiwan will only cut tariffs on imported cars by 1 percent after it enters the WTO, such imports will not account for a bigger market share in Taiwan in the future, according to the IDB officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOSE CARRERAS TO PERFORM IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: World renowned operatic tenor Jose Carreras arrived Monday for his sixth concert tour of Taiwan, starting his performances in Taiwan's southern port city of Kaohsiung, tour organizers said Tuesday.
Carreras is scheduled to give a solo concert at Kaohsiung's Cultural Center Wednesday evening in a performance that will also be televised simultaneously for an outdoor audience.

At a press conference held on the eve of his performance, Carreras said he hopes that the Kaohsiung concert will be received as favorably as when he performed "The Bohemians" with famed conductor Herbert von Karajan in Vienna several years ago and received 74 curtain calls.
"I was starving after that final curtain fell," said a broadly smiling Carreras.

Carreras noted that the weather in Kaohsiung was similar to that of his Spanish hometown, which made him feel at home. He added that he has chosen the Plegaria (the Prayer) as an encore as a tribute for the victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on America.
Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh attended the press conference, during which he offered Carreras an illustrated volume of poetry about Kaohsiung City as a souvenir.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DRONE PLANE NETS WORLD METEOROLOGICAL FIRST

TEXT.P: Taiwan atmospheric scientists Tuesday successfully obtained vital typhoon data by flying two remote-control aircraft close to the depression's eyewall, a world first for any flying object collecting meteorological information.

The first remote-control aircraft, or "aerosonb I" in atmospheric science jargon, was launched at 7 a.m. Tuesday to a location only about 150 kilometers away from the eyewall of Typhoon Haiyan, which was about 200 kilometers from Ilan, eastern Taiwan. The plane successfully transmitted meteorological information about the typhoon to its designers and controllers on the ground.
After staying aloft for a record 108 kilometers, the drone crashed at 11:25 a.m. after transmitting the information, the meteorologists said.

The second drone -- "aerosonb II" -- was launched at around 2 p.m. Tuesday on a similar mission. It landed safely at 4:30 p.m. after having also successfully collected vital information about Typhoon Haiyan, which left the island in the late afternoon.
The flights also marked a milestone in Taiwan's typhoon information collection, the scientists said.

The aerosonb project was jointly sponsored by the National Science Council, the Central Weather Bureau, the military Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology and National Taiwan University's Department of Atmospheric Sciences.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADE WAR EXPECTED BETWEEN DOMESTIC OIL COMPANIES

TEXT.P: A fuel oil trade war is expected to break out at the end of the year between Taiwan's two oil companies, as two major airlines' fuel contracts with the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) will expire at that time, oil industry sources said Tuesday.
Although the local aviation fuel market was liberalized two years ago, sales are so far still dominated by CPC.

With the expiration of the contracts between CPC and the nation's two largest airlines -- China Airlines and EVA Airways -- CPC's biggest rival -- Formosa Group -- is getting ready to gain a foothold in the aviation fuel market, with an estimated worth of NT$22 billion (US$638 million).
The Formosa Group has gone so far as to lay an oil pipeline from Taipei Port in northern Taiwan to Chiang Kai-shek International Airport. The pipeline is expected to be completed soon.

A CPC executive said that although the Formosa Group has been preparing for a long time to seek a slice of the huge aviation fuel market, the CPC will not wait for the Formosa Group to take the initiative in the trade war.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT CONGRATULATES NOBEL PEACE PRIZE WINNERS

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian has sent a congratulatory letter to the United Nations and its secretary-general, Kofi Annan, for their winning of this year's Nobel Peace Prize, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said Tuesday.
The officials added that Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao have also sent congratulatory letters.
The Nobel committee in Oslo announced Oct. 12 that the U.N. and Annan would share the Nobel Peace Prize for "their work toward a better organized and more peaceful world."

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTERS FROM BEIJING, TAIPEI HOLD TALKS IN SHANGHAI
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By Peng Sze-chou & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi exchanged views Tuesday in Shanghai with his mainland Chinese counterpart, Shi Guangsheng, on issues connected with World Trade Organization (WTO) accession.
Lin told reporters after the meeting that if everything goes smoothly, both Taiwan and mainland China will be able to become members of the global trade regulatory body early next year.
"It will bring a huge and deep effect on the WTO itself, as well as on cross-Taiwan Strait trade relations," he said.
The day's talks focused on the establishment of a consultation channel to resolve cross-strait trade problems under the WTO framework.

Asked how Taiwan will react to Beijing's claim that if Taiwan fails to recognize the "one China" principle, it will have difficulty discussing direct trade, postal and transport links and other issues under the WTO framework, Lin replied only that "it is normal to use the mediation mechanism within the WTO framework to resolve disputes."
During the talks, Lin said he expressed his thanks for the courteous treatment accorded his visit to Shanghai for the ministerial meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
He added that he also asked Shi to support a proposal submitted by Taiwan to the APEC meeting.
Besides his meeting with Shi, Lin also held bilateral talks that day with his counterparts from Brunei, New Zealand, Singapore and Thailand.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AUTO PARTS, COMPONENT EXPORTS EXPECTED TO GROW BY 10% IN 2001

TEXT.P: Affected by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States and the flooding in Taiwan after two consecutive typhoons, Taiwan's auto parts and components exports are expected to increase by 10 percent this year, Industry Development Bureau (IDB) officials said Tuesday.

According to the officials, the attacks on the United States have led to a boom in the U.S. auto parts and components market. Sources with the auto parts and components industry forecast that the slowdown of the U.S. economy will also lead to fewer new car sales, creating a promising future for the parts and components market and estimated sales of NT$90 billion in 2001 compared with NT$81 the previous year.
The flooding resulting from two consecutive typhoons have also augmented domestic demand for auto parts and components, leading to sales growth for local suppliers, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO INCREASE SOURCES OF FOREIGN WORKERS: CLA

TEXT.P: Taiwan is set to increase its sources of foreign laborers, Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Chairwoman Chen Chu said Tuesday.
About 300,000 foreign laborers, mostly from the Philippines, Thailand, Indonesia and Vietnam, are employed in Taiwan at present.
Chen said that CLA has contacted the authorities in Myanmar, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Cambodia, North Korea and Mongolia to discuss the possible import of laborers from those countries.

Among those countries, Chen said, Myanmar and Cambodia are likely to be chosen as additional sources of foreign labor simply because of the advantage of direct flights between Taiwan and these two countries.
She said that Taiwan is also likely to list Mongolia as a source of labor as a result of the warming relations between the two countries.

Chen went to on say that the CLA is considering setting a quota system for the number of workers from each foreign country, depending on what extent those foreign governments cooperate with Taiwan with regards to the island's foreign labor policy.

The CLA recently adopted a new wage system for foreign workers by docking the workers of their accommodation and meal fees from their monthly minimum salary of NT$15,840 set by the government in the Basic Labor Law.
Chen said that the quota for Vietnamese workers may increase in the future as the new wage system has been well received by the Vietnamese government.
CAL is scheduled to publish the list of the additional counties that can supply workers to Taiwan at the end of this month, along with the revised foreign labor policy, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 17, or the first day of the ninth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1662: Charles II, King of England, sells Dunkirk to the French.
1849: Frederic Chopin, Polish-born French composer and virtuoso pianist of the romantic era, dies of tuberculosis in Paris at the age of 39. His music, written chiefly for the piano, is noted for its expressiveness.
1855: Englishman Henry Bessemer patents his process for making steel.
1912: The first Balkan War breaks out when Bulgaria, Serbia and Greece declare war on Turkey.
1919: Zhao Ziyang, former Chinese Communist Party chief, is born. As prime minister in the 1980s, he pioneered bold economic reforms. He was swept from power in the political crisis sparked by the 1989 pro-democracy demonstrations centered in Tiananmen Square in Beijing.
1920: Hsieh Wen-ta, Taiwan's first aviator, flies his aircraft over Taichung in central Taiwan.
1945: The first batch of ROC government troops aboard some 40 U.S. Navy ships arrives at Keelung in Taiwan, which reverts back to Chinese rule after 50 years of Japanese occupation.
1956: Calder Hall, Britain's first nuclear power station, is opened by Queen Elizabeth II.
1963: The Hong Kong government sets up the Chinese University of Hong Kong.
1964: Construction of a cross-harbor bridge on Penghu (the Pescadores) is started.
1966: Lesotho and Botswana are admitted into the United Nations.
1967: Henry Puyi, formerly Hsuan Tung, the last Ching ruler, dies in Beijing at the age of 61.
1972: President Park Chung Hee declares martial law in South Korea.
1973: The Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center is inaugurated in Shanhua in southern Taiwan.
1973: The ten Arab members of OPEC announce an enormous 70 percent hike in oil prices and a cutback in production in response to America's support for Israel in the Yom Kippur War.
1974: The Asian Christian Federation opens its first conference on Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei with 200 delegates from 15 Asian countries attending.
1977: Akira Nishiyama, former Japanese ambassador to South Korea, arrives in Taiwan to assume his duties as director of the Japan Interchange Association's Taipei office.
1979: Mother Teresa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for caring for the world's "unwanted and unloved."
1981: A group of more than 100 former officers of the U.S. Air Force's 14th squadron, better known as the Flying Tigers, arrives in Taipei to visit Chinese friends.
1989: An earthquake rocks northern California, killing more than 60 people.
1994: Israel and Jordan initial a historic peace treaty, ending their 46-year state of war.
1995: The Republic of China and Macau establish a five-year renewable air pact allowing Eva Airways, TransAsia Airways and Air Macau to fly routes between Taiwan and Macau.
1996: Russian President Boris Yeltsin sacks security chief Alexander Lebed one day after Lebed is accused of building his own army in an attempt to seize power.
1999: Vice President Lien Chan calls on Cardinal Paul Shan to express gratitude for the 921 earthquake relief assistance provided by the Catholic community in Taiwan.
2000: The Republic of China's Central News Agency enters into an agreement with France's Agency France-Press at a ceremony that ROC Vice President Annette Lu says signifies Taiwan's future leadership role in global Chinese news networks.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man, without the inducement of rewards, is able to make the people good; and without a show of anger, to awe them into fear more than if he had used the most dreadful instruments of punishment."

Market turnover amounted to NT$61.45 billion (US$1.78 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN P.M. TO TRY TO SHORE UP APEC'S ANTI-TERRORISM STANCE

TEXT.P: Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien will meet with the Malaysian and Indonesian heads of state in Shanghai this coming weekend to try to shore up the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum's anti-terrorism stance, Canadian officials said Tuesday.

The APEC leaders plan to issue a strong statement denouncing the terrorist attacks in the United States at this weekend's informal APEC leadership summit where the topic of terrorism is expected to overshadow almost everything else.
The APEC summit in Shanghai will be the first overseas meeting for both Chretien and U.S. President George W. Bush since the Sept. 11 attacks.

The APEC leaders will also discuss the slumping economies of many member countries, but much of the discussion is expected to be about shoring up support for Bush's international coalition against terrorism, according to the officials.
"This has to be on the agenda, even if it is informal," said one Canadian official during a background briefing.

Chretien will do his part, the officials said, by meeting with representatives of several member countries Sunday to talk about the coalition. Most notably, he plans to meet with leaders from Indonesia and Malaysia, both predominantly Muslim countries where there has been unrest over the U.S.-led bombing of Afghanistan.
Chretien also plans to meet one-on-one with Bush, Russian President Vladimir Putin, Mexican President Vicente Fox and others, they noted.

One senior Canadian official said that the APEC leaders are expected to be unanimous regarding the declaration, adding that the drafting process has been smooth, despite reservations from some countries about the U.S. approach to handling the terrorism crisis.

Mainland China has insisted it will not allow the issue of terrorism to dominate this week's meeting, and discussions will go ahead on the economy and the future of the APEC organization. A declaration is expected in favor of a new round of negotiations on multilateral trade liberalization.
