DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN TO CONFER PRESIDENTIAL AWARDS ON FOUR SOCIAL GURUS

TEXT.P: Three individuals and one aboriginal group have each been selected as recipients of the Presidential Cultural Award in recognition of their exceptional contributions to Taiwan society, awards organizers said Wednesday.

President Chen Shui-bian is scheduled to confer the Presidential Cultural Award in mid-December at a ceremony to be held at the Presidential Office on Buddhist philanthropist Master Cheng Yen, Taiwanese linguist Wu Shou-li, physician-turned-sociologist Lin Tsung-yi and the Shan Mei Community Development Association, said officials from the National Cultural Association (NCA).

The prestigious Presidential Cultural Award, the first of its kind, is a manifestation of one of the commitments Chen made to the Taiwan public after he took office last year to help reinvigorate cultural development and raise moral standards in Taiwan.

The four Presidential Cultural Award recipients will serve as role models for the Taiwan public by allowing their spirit of contribution to society and the light of their wisdom to inspire members of Taiwan society, particularly those of the younger generation, NCA officials said.

Master Cheng Yen, founder of the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, is a Buddhist nun-turned-philanthropist whose compassionate and charitable operations reach every corner of the globe.

Cheng Yen and her followers started their philanthropic activities in 1966 with only a tiny amount of funds saved from handicraft work. In 1973, the Tsu Chi Charity Clinic was established, offering free medical care to the poor and needy. The clinic became a general hospital six years later. Tzu Chi volunteer workers were one of the major factors helping Taiwan stand up again after the devastating magnitude 7.3 earthquake struck in September 1999.

Wu Shou-li, 92, is the most senior recipient of the first President Cultural Award. A Taiwanese scholar who received a Japanese education in his early life when Taiwan was under the colonial rule of Japan, Wu taught in National Taiwan University's Department of Literature for decades while doing research on the southern mainland Chinese dialect of Fujianese, from which the Taiwanese dialect is derived.

Despite his advanced age, Wu managed to publish his double-volume Madarin-Taiwanese Dictionary last year after decades of painstaking work. The dictionary is considered an important cornerstone in dialect studies in Taiwan.

Dr. Lin Tsung-yi, 81, was the first Taiwanese person to receive a doctorate in philosophy from a university in the United States. Lin had been an adviser to the World Health Organization for years before committing himself to working as a sociologist in Taiwan after the tragic Feb. 28 Incident, in which his father, formerly the director of the NTU Department of Literature, was killed.
From that time, Lin became the leader of Taiwan's sociological activities, particularly in efforts at seeking justice for the families and offspring of victims of the Feb. 28 Incident.

The Shan Mei Community, a village of the aboriginal Tsou tribe located south of Mount Ali in central Taiwan, was also chosen to be a recipient of the award for its strenuous and painstaking efforts at saving the Taiwan Ku fish -- an endangered species endemic only to Taiwan's mountainous regions and a distant relative of the carp.

The Tsou villagers have spent years working to save the species by keeping the fish's habitat intact and continuing to promote the concept of conservation among other groups of people around the island, according to the award organizers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high and closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 22.27 points to close at 3,817.13.

Encouraged by a rise in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 3,829.61 and continued to go up before profit-taking selling pressure drove prices down. The index fluctuated between 3,872.81 and 3,800.2 during trading.

A total of 2.66 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$61.45 billion (US$1.78 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.45 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$31.47 billion (US$0.91 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most at 0.9 percent, followed by textile issues at 0.5 percent, and bank and insurance shares at 0.4 percent. Cement stocks remained unchanged.

The other major categories posted gains, with electrical shares moving up the most at 1 percent, followed by foodstuff stocks at 0.6 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.5 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 267 to 234, with 130 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MIXED ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported mixed results on Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for October moved up 10 points to close at 3,820, with 3,523 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for November lost 15 points to finish at 3,785, with 18,198 contract transactions, while December futures decreased 8 points to finish at 3,792, with 11 contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 3,810 for October, 3,800 for November, 3,800 for December, 3,780 for next March, and 3,840 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, also reported mixed results.
October TE futures edged up 0.3 points to close at 185.5, with 1,099 contract transactions, while November TE futures decreased 1.5 points to finish at 183, with 4,482 contracts traded.
December TE futures rose 0.3 points to finish at 185.3, with 0 contracts changing hands. No transactions were reported for other months.
October TF futures moved down 2.2 points to finish at 577.8, with 617 contract transactions, while November TF futures decreased 6 points to close at 571.8, with 1,564 contracts traded.
December TF futures rose 9.8 points to finish at 570, with three contract transactions, while next March TF futures fell 2.2 points to close at 574, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOURISM GROWS AMID ECONOMIC SLUMP

TEXT.P: Despite the economic sluggishness in the local and world markets, the local tourism industry still posted growth in the first half of this year, according to statistics released Wednesday by the Tourism Bureau.

Tourist arrivals and departures, as well as domestic travel, all registered increases during the first six months of the year compared with the levels posted during the same period of a year ago, according to the bureau.

During the January-June period, the people of Taiwan made a total of 3.7 million visits abroad, while tourist arrivals in Taiwan totaled 1.38 million, up 3.67 percent and 10.64 percent, respectively, year-on-year, bureau tallies show. In addition, Taiwan people made 54.4 million trips at home around the island during the same time, up 2.8 percent from the year-earlier level.

Some 80 percent of Taiwan's first-time outbound tourists paid visits to destinations in Asia. Hong Kong was the most popular choice in Asia for tourists from Taiwan, absorbing 31.6 percent of Taiwan's total outbound travel, according to the statistics. Asian visitors also accounted for the bulk of foreign inbound travel for Taiwan, with Japanese tourists accounting for 37.5 percent of the total.

Tourism Bureau officials also said the bureau will launch a major publicity campaign to create a new image for Taiwan in a bid to draw a greater number of Japanese tourists. The officials said they hope to meet the target of 10-percent growth in foreign inbound travel for the whole of 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUSPECTED VOTE-BUYING UNDER INVESTIGATION: JUSTICE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan said Wednesday that while selling tickets for admission to election-oriented fundraising banquets is not illegal, the practice of buying a great number of tickets or of receiving such tickets may constitute vote-buying.

Chen declined to speculate on whether Vice President Annette Lu was involved in such a suspected vote-buying fund-raiser, but said after people filed a complaint with the Taipei District Prosecutors' Office that similar cases are currently under investigation.
Chen made the remarks after opposition Kuomintang Legislator Chen Chien-chih asked him during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan whether Lu is involved in vote buying.

In the complaint to the Taipei prosecutors, Lu was accused of putting up NT$1.8 million (US$52,173) for three tables at a fund-raising banquet sponsored by the "Mainstream Alliance" faction, a sub-group of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party. Each ticket was priced at NT$50,000.
Chen has strenuously promoted a "clean election" in the approach to elections for legislators, city mayors and county chiefs slated for Dec. 1.

He defended his justification for a NT$30 maximum standard for vote-buying violations earlier this month, saying that the decision will not be altered despite widespread criticism from the candidates.

Chen said the decision to prosecute candidates caught spending more than NT$30 on any individual for vote-buying was made by the State Public Prosecutor General's Office after a consensus was reached with prosecutors general and leading prosecutors at all levels.
He reiterated that the government is determined to ensure that the year-end elections are not sullied by gifts of money or goods in exchange for votes -- standard practice in Taiwan politics.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN 3G LICENSES TO BE AUCTIONED AT YEAR-END

TEXT.P: Ministry of Transportation and Communications officials announced Tuesday that the five licenses to operate third-generation (3G) mobile phone services will be auctioned at the end of this year, with the price tag set between NT$4.2 billion and NT$7.6 billion.

The officials said the ministry will begin to accept applications Friday, with a Dec. 18 deadline. At least seven local telecommunications and wireless telecommunications service companies are known to be interested in bidding -- Chunghwa Telecom, Teco Electric and Machinery, ET Group, First International Telecom Group, Far Eastone, Taiwan Cellular Corp. and KG Telecommunications.
Before the auction, a special committee will conduct preliminary qualification screening, a ministry spokesman said.

The communications ministry has set the price tag of two licenses for 35MHz spectrum at NT$7.6 billion each, with another 35MHz license priced at NT$6.7 billion due to possible interference. The bidding price for the 40 MHz license is NT$ 7.5 billion, and for the 25MHz license, NT$4.2 billion.
By auctioning the five licenses, the national treasury is expecting to fetch NT$33.6 billion.

In setting the bidding prices, the ministry has taken into consideration long-term telecommunication developments in Taiwan and the utility rate, in addition to the current international economic climate, according to Teng Tien-lai, director of the ministry's Posts and Telecommunications Department.
Teng said that the bidding prices of Taiwan's licenses were comparatively lower than those in other countries in the Asia Pacific region.

The 3G services -- also known as UTMS (universal mobile telecommunications system) services -- offer instant wireless network services for multi-media communications. With 7.2 million Internet users and a high proportion of 2G mobile phone users, Taiwan is seen as potentially rich market for 3G mobile telecommunications services.

A research report conducted by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications and the Council for Economic Planning and Development forecast that the production value of the telecommunications sector by the year 2010 will have reached NT$322.2 billion.
The 3G mobile telecommunication services will facilitate the development of e-commerce and related Internet services, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.001 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Wednesday, closing at 34.548.
The local currency opened Wednesday at 34.560 and was traded between 34.515 and 34.565.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$244 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: 45.2% BELIEVE U.S. WILL COME TO ROC'S AID IF BEIJING ATTACKS: POLL

TEXT.P: The majority of local people do not think that mainland China will take advantage of the current U.S.-led counter-terrorism campaign to invade Taiwan, according to the results of an opinion poll released Wednesday.
The telephone poll of 1,077 randomly selected adult residents was conducted by Yok Mu-ming, an opposition New Party candidate in the Dec. 1 legislative elections.

The survey results show that 64 percent of those interviewed do not think that mainland China will attack Taiwan amid the ongoing U.S.-led strikes against the Taliban in Afghanistan in retaliation for the Islamic country's sheltering of Osama bin Laden, the suspected mastermind of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States.
But if mainland China really were to launch an attack on Taiwan, 45.2 percent said they think that the United States would send troops to assist Taiwan in repulsing an invasion by communist troops.
Nevertheless, 36.5 percent said they do not think that the United States would be likely to come to Taiwan's aid.
More than 70 percent said they support the current U.S. military action in Afghanistan, according to the survey.

The poll also found that 50.3 percent approve of President Chen Shui-bian's response in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks that toppled New York City's World Trade Center and damaged the Pentagon, the U.S. military's nerve center.
Meanwhile, 45.3 percent said they are generally satisfied with the ROC government's overall performance in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks.

According to the same poll, 63.9 percent said they do not think that Taiwan will fall victim to terrorist attacks. Asked what would happen if Taiwan were to be attacked by international terrorists, 54.6 percent said they think that the government may not be capable of handling the situation and 64.9 percent said they do not think that the government has the ability to fight against biowarfare.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFORM GROUP CALLS ON POLITICAL PARTIES TO SOLICIT SUPPORT

TEXT.P: A non-profit group trying to monitor the assets of political parties called on the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and other parties Wednesday to solicit support for its cause.
Officials of the National Reform Alliance to Monitor Assets of Political Parties made the call during a meeting with DPP Deputy Secretary-General Hsu Yang-ming.

The alliance seeks to persuade the country's political parties to support its appeals to "return the money to the people." It also says that political parties should refrain from holding stocks or real estate and that their assets should be in the form of cash deposited in banks.
Hsu signed the agreement on behalf of the DPP, stressing that even if the DPP is the subject of such monitoring, it is "positive" about the appeal for transparency.

Hsu also said that opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan stressed before the presidential election in March 2000 that all political parties must stop profit-seeking activities, starting with the KMT.
But Hsu noted that the KMT has refused to work with the Executive Yuan's decision to investigate questionable KMT assets, which Hsu said has "completely reneged on Lien's promise."

Hsu said that because of the incomplete legal basis for such monitoring, there will be some hurdles to be crossed. He said that all political parties will have to support the enactment of a "political party law" and a "political fund management law," as well as formulating special relevant laws in the interest of the people.
The DPP was the second political party to receive a visit from the alliance. The Taiwan Solidarity Union, a political group formed in August, was visited earlier this month.
The alliance, comprised of professors, lawyers and accountants and inaugurated last year, later called on the New Party and the People First Party to solicit their support.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY'S MISERY INDEX CREEPS UP A NOTCH

TEXT.P: Taipei's misery index was gauged at 4.53 percent in the first eight months of this year, the Taipei city government's Department of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DBAS) reported Wednesday.
The figure was higher than Kaohsiung City's 3.89 percent and Taiwan Area's average of 4.52 percent recorded in the same period, according to DBAS officials.
It was also 0.44 percentage points higher than the figure posted for the same period of last year, the city officials added.
The misery index is a composite of the unemployment rate and inflation rate. High unemployment and inflation during the period pushed the index up, the officials noted.

The average jobless rate during the eight-month period stood at 3.68 percent, lower than Kaohsiung City's 4.73 percent and Taiwan Area's average of 4.22 percent, they said. However, the officials pointed out that the city's consumer prices rose by 0.85 percent while Kaohsiung City and Taiwan Area's consumer prices declined by 0.84 percent and 0.30 percent, respectively.
Taipei City's misery index was recorded as 5.58 percent in the month of August, with inflation growing by 1.03 percent and unemployment rising to 4.55 percent, the DBAS officials said.
Taiwan, along with Japan and Singapore, have the lowest misery ratings in the world, according to the officials.
A high misery index cuts national income and is considered a "hidden worry" for the government, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S OVERDUE LOAN RATIO TOO HIGH: ANALYSIS

TEXT.P: The overdue loan ratio of Taiwan banks was high at 15.7 percent at the end of last year due to serious bad debt problems, according to an analysis released Wednesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

The analysis noted that the number of locally operated financial institutions has fallen considerably in past years, from 1,952 at the end of 1996 to 1,778 last year. These institutions include credit cooperatives of counties or provincial cities and credit departments of farmer's or fishermen's cooperatives.
With the liberalization of the financial market, many of these institutions have sought to upgrade their operations through mergers or through transforming into commercial banks.
They have faced increasing competition from newly established commercial banks and business shrinkage has forced quite a few out of the market, according to the analysis.

At the end of last year, deposits at these banking institutions accounted for 13.9 percent of the total deposits of Taiwan banks, while the loans extended by them represented only 8.7 percent of total bank lending in Taiwan.

Non-performing loans have caused serious problems for the locally operated banking institutions. At the end of last year, the amount of overdue loans held by these institutions totaled NT$204.2 billion, with the overdue loan ratio rising from 8.6 percent to 15.7 percent in four years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MARKET SHARE IN U.S., JAPAN DROPPING

TEXT.P: Hit by the recessions in the United States and Japan, market shares of Taiwan-made products in the two countries have dropped in the first seven months of this year, according to government statistics.

Tallies published recently by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show that the market shares of locally made products in the United States and Japan fell by 0.38 percentage points and 0.32 percentage points, respectively, during the January-July period, compared with the year-earlier levels.

During the same seven-month period, the market share of Japanese goods in the U.S. market fell from 12.05 percent to 11.17 percent, while South Korea and Singapore also saw shrinkages of 0.27 percentage points and 0.24 percentage points, respectively, according to the tallies. Taiwan enjoyed only a 2.95 percent market share in the United States, down by 0.38 percentage points from a year ago.

In the Japanese market, U.S.-made products grabbed the largest stake of 15.48 percent, ahead of mainland China, which was in second place during the same seven-month period. Taiwan seized fourth place with a 4.37 percent market share in Japan, down from 4.69 percent a year ago.

According to DGBAS officials, the economic slump in the United States since the fourth quarter of last year has noticeably slashed the country's demand for hi-tech products. East Asian economies, including Taiwan, all rely heavily on hi-tech exports to the United States, they noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER VOWS `ZERO TOLERANCE' CAMPAIGN AGAINST VOTE-BUYING

TEXT.P: Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan pledged a "zero tolerance" campaign against vote-buying Wednesday, with the aim of eradicating the influence of moneyed interests and organized crime in politics, more commonly known as "black gold" politics.
Chen made the vow in a report on the ongoing anti-black gold campaign at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Judicial Affairs Committee.

Noting that vote-buying is the root cause of black gold politics, Chen said law-enforcement authorities will not compromise on the vote-buying crackdown in the run-up to the pivotal Dec. 1 elections for legislators, city mayors and county magistrates.

"We are determined to wage a sustained war on vote-buying as a first step toward wiping out black gold politics," Chen said, adding that the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) will not intervene in the investigation of any vote-buying charges.
With Taiwan entering a red-hot election campaign season, Chen said the MOJ has drawn up a comprehensive work plan to eradicate vote-buying.

Chen said the action pack includes revisions of the existing regulations to increase the reward money for those who provide information regarding suspected vote-buying cases and for law enforcers who contribute to the cracking of vote-buying cases.
In addition, Chen said, the ministry has launched an all-out anti-vote-buying publicity campaign and has deployed personnel for information gathering.
Meanwhile, he went on, the MOJ has endeavored to forge a consensus among prosecution, police and investigation agencies on vote-buying probes.

Chen further explained that although the MOJ has the power to oversee the administration of prosecutors' offices around the country, it is not authorized to exercise administrative supervision of any specific vote-buying case under investigation.

"As the MOJ strictly abides by the regulations that permit the offering of general operational directives to prosecutors' offices as well as oversight of their operations after the closure of a specific criminal case, political interference in vote-buying probes are unlikely to take place," Chen assured lawmakers.

Pointing out that black gold politics have had a profound and far-reaching adverse impact on social justice and have even undermined national strength, Chen said the MOJ will not cease in its anti-vote-buying crusade.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT $ 4.7 BILLION PAID IN UNEMPLOYMENT BENEFITS: CLA

TEXT.P: Amid a rising unemployment rate, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) reported Wednesday that it has paid a total of NT$4.7 billion in labor unemployment benefit in the first nine months of this year.

According to the Cabinet-level agency, the figure was nearly three times the level paid for the whole of 2000. The 76,089 subsidy receivers represented a number that was also more than three times that of last year after the government eased payout restrictions this year. The figures rose from NT$1.66 billion and 24,018 people, respectively, in 2000.

The council predicted that it might have to pay NT$7 billion in unemployment benefit for the whole of 2001 and that the figure is likely to climb to NT$12.3 billion for 2002. It said that it paid NT$516 million for just 11,341 unemployed workers in 1999, the first year in which the government subsidy was approved.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES EXTENSION OF INSURANCE GUARANTEE FOR AIRLINES

TEXT.P: The Cabinet approved a proposal Wednesday for a two-month extension of the current government guarantees for the island's airlines on insurance claims for accidents caused by hijacking or war.
The Cabinet approved the proposal, which was presented by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) at its weekly meeting.
According to the proposal, the government's war-risk insurance coverage guarantees for local carriers will remain valid until midnight of Dec. 25 this year.
The proposal will soon be referred to the Legislative Yuan for endorsement, Cabinet sources said.
MOTC officials said the ministry came up with the proposal mainly because of the ongoing U.S.-led war on terrorism in retaliation for the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York and Washington.

With the escalation of the U.S. strikes on the Taliban in Afghanistan in retaliation for the regime's sheltering of Osama bin Laden -- the suspected mastermind behind the Sept. 11 attacks -- MOTC officials said the commercial aviation insurance market is not expected to return to normal for the time being.

Against this backdrop, the officials went on, the government's war-risk insurance coverage guarantees for local airlines must be extended for another two months to help domestic carriers weather the difficulties.

In the wake of the terrorist attacks on America, international underwriters have raised aviation insurance premiums across the board and have slashed the maximum third-party liability compensation to US$50 million.

The government's financial guarantee will give the nation's airlines temporary coverage above that amount in the event of any claims resulting from hijackings or war, while giving the companies time to negotiate new contracts with insurance companies.

The U.S. government and a number of other governments around the world have already pledged to help their aviation industries through their difficult times by providing similar financial aid packages.
The Republic of China government first offered a 30-day war-risk insurance coverage guarantee to domestic carriers on Sept. 26, which will end Oct. 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROVERSIAL LAWMAKER ELECTED LEGISLATIVE FINANCE COMMITTEE CONVENER

TEXT.P: Independent lawmaker Lo Fu-chu was elected Wednesday as one of the three conveners of the Legislative Yuan's finance committee, after weeks of procedural disputes centered around the frequently controversial lawmaker.

Only two days after an attempt to elect the conveners -- which ended in arguments over the validity of certain ballots -- the committee's members were finally able to complete the voting process Wednesday.
Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker Lin Wen-lang received five votes to ensure his election to one of the three seats.

Although the vote counting was initially stalled by arguments over another ballot validity issue, Lin -- who served as the temporary chairman -- cited relevant laws and ruled that a disputed ballot for opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislator Gary L.L. Wang was valid, ensuring that Wang also received five votes to become the second committee convener.
After a ballot for Lo was ruled to be invalid, he was forced to enter a tie-breaker with KMT lawmaker Lee Shang-ren, who, like Lo, received four valid votes.
Lee drew the first lot but lost, thereby handing the last convener seat to Lo.

After the results were announced, Lee held a news conference in which KMT caucus whip Lee Cheng-chong said that the caucus was sorry that the failure of two other KMT lawmakers to show up at the voting led to only one KMT legislator being voted convener.

Because Lo received one decisive vote from a KMT lawmaker to ensure his victory, the KMT whip added that the caucus will look into the matter and report the lawmaker who did not support the caucus-appointed candidate for disciplinary measures if the lawmaker is found to have violated party rules.

Meanwhile, DPP legislative caucus convener Lin Feng-hsi said at a news conference after the voting that his caucus is "regretful" that Lo was elected despite his party's attempt to prevent Lo's victory.
Lin said that the DPP had even backed the failed KMT candidate with three votes, yet another KMT lawmaker helped Lo become elected.
He added that the KMT should discipline the lawmaker who did not vote for his caucus-appointed candidate.

On Oct. 3, Lo had harangued and intimidated members of the finance committee because the DPP legislative caucus had questioned the validity of electing his son, Lo Ming-tsai, as a convener of the committee.

The junior Lo, also a legislator, had been elected to the committee's convener seat earlier this month for a third consecutive term, breaking an internal rule of the chamber that forbids any lawmaker serving as a convener of any committee for three straight sessions.
The senior Lo's invective halted the committee's plan to conduct a new run of convener elections on that day.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER AGAINST PLAN TO EXPAND 'MINI THREE LINKS'

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday that the recent preliminary legislative move approving an amendment allowing people from Taiwan to visit mainland China via Kinmen and Matsu is "inappropriate."

He told a Cabinet meeting that the government's policy of promoting "mini three links" between the two islands and mainland Chinese ports has been implemented since early this year in consideration of the need and convenience of Kinmen and Matsu residents.
Chang said that if everyone in Taiwan were allowed to visit mainland China via Kinmen and Matsu, it could adversely affect the security of the two islands.
Therefore, the premier asked the leaders of relevant government organizations to step up communications with the Legislative Yuan to prevent the amendment from being enacted.
An amendment allowing the authorities of the offshore islands to approve the operations of tourist hotels and casinos was also approved in the preliminary legislative move.
Regarding this, Chang said that the government has not yet decided whether to legalize gambling on Taiwan's islands. He also asked related officials to continue communicating with the legislators.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOSCOW TO JOIN ASIA PACIFIC FILM FESTIVAL
DOC.DATELINE: Jakarta, Oct. 17 (CNA) (By Wu Su-jo and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Delegates of the countries that are participating in the ongoing 46th Asia Pacific Film Festival agreed at a board of directors meeting Wednesday to welcome Moscow to join the 17-member film festival organization.
The delegates also agreed to Taipei's suggestion that documentaries should have their own category instead of being included in the short film category.
Starting from the 47th Asia Pacific Film Festival, which will be held in Seoul, entries will compete in four categories -- drama, documentaries, short films and animation.
The four-day festival opened Wednesday.

The Taipei delegation, headed by Chiu Shun-ching, president of the Central Motion Picture Co., is comprised of anthropologist-turned-director Hu Tai-li, actors Yin Chao-te, Tai Li-jen and Chu Chung-heng and actress Hsiao Shu-shen.
Delegates of all the Asia Pacific nations and areas that are participating in the film festival are scheduled to call on Indonesian President Megawati Sukarnoputri Friday.

Taiwan films that have entered in the festival include features "What Time Is It There?" by director Tsai Ming-liang, "The Cabbie" by directors Chen Yi-wen and Chang Hua-kun, and "Fleeing by Night" by director Hsu Li-kong.

Two other short films that represent Taiwan are "Grandma's Hairpin," a documentary about aging retired servicemen who came to Taiwan from mainland China 50 years ago, by director Hsiao Chu-chen and "Sounds of Love and Sorrow," a documentary about the lives of Taiwan's aboriginal Paiwanese, produced and directed by Hu Tai-li.

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC MINISTERIAL-LEVEL MEETING BEGINS IN SHANGHAI
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Oct. 17 (CNA) (By Peng Ssu-chou and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The two-day ministerial-level meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum began Wednesday in Shanghai with foreign ministers, trade ministers and representatives from the 21 member economies participating.

Participants will discuss issues concerning trade and anti-terrorism at the two-day meeting presided over by mainland Chinese Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan and Minister of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Shi Guangsheng.
The ministerial-level meeting will be followed by a weekend summit by leaders of the 21 member economies.

Taipei has proposed that former Vice President Li Yuan-zu represent President Chen Shui-bian at the APEC summit, but Beijing has refused the proposal, saying that Li does not possess a background of serving as an economic or financial official.

Zhang Qiyue, spokesperson for the mainland Chinese Foreign Ministry and Shanghai's APEC secretariat, said that Beijing is still waiting for Taipei's response to the summit representative issue, adding that Beijing does not want to see a situation that Taipei is absent at the summit.
U.S. President George W. Bush is expected to arrive in Shanghai Thursday to attend the APEC summit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL ELECTRONICS PRODUCTS EXHIBITION OPENS

TEXT.P: The 2001 Taipei International Electronics Products Exhibition opened Wednesday with 806 domestic and foreign manufacturers participating.
Products displayed at the exhibition include satellite communication materials, information home appliances and computer information products.
The exhibition was jointly organized by the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) and the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers' Association (TEEMA).
TEEMA Chairman Hsu Sheng-hsiung and Examination Yuan President Hsu Shui-teh jointly presided over the opening ceremony for the exhibition.
CETRA estimated the number of visitors to the five-day exhibition will exceed 40,000.
The exhibition will conclude Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-VICE PRESIDENT REMAINS TAIPEI SOLE OPTION FOR APEC SUMMIT: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taipei is negotiating with Beijing on Taiwan's representative to the upcoming summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Shanghai and a final decision may come Thursday, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Wednesday.

But MOFA spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue reiterated that former Vice President Li Yuan-zu remains Taipei's sole option for the coming APEC summit this weekend and urged Beijing to respond to the offer favorably.

According to Chang, Taipei is negotiating with the mainland Chinese side on the issue in the hope of following the so-called "Koo Chen-fu model." She added that other details are flexible, such as Li's title.

Koo, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), participated in APEC summit various times as the ROC top representative. The SEF is a semiofficial organization authorized by Taipei to deal with Beijing in the absence of official contacts.

Beijing has rejected Taipei's offer to send Li as Chen's representative at the Oct. 20-21 APEC summit on the grounds that Taiwan's envoy must be an official with an economic background as stated in the 1991 APEC memorandum of understanding and according to past practice.
Responding to Beijing, Chang said the 1991 agreement should not be applied to APEC economic summits, which started only in 1993.

As the issue is still being discussed between the two sides, MOFA officials are reluctant to speculate on possible other candidates to attend the meeting. Regarding the much-talked about "Koo model," the officials said there is still much to consider and the model needs further definition.
Koo was able to attend the APEC summit in the past as the proxy of ROC president after being given the additional title of "senior commissioner of the Council for Economic Planning and Development."

MOFA officials said there are four options for Taiwan at present -- push to allow Li to attend the meeting, select another representative, appoint Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman Chen Po-chih or Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi, who are already in Shanghai as the envoy, or skip the summit.
The ROC government should choose wisely who it ultimately sends to the summit because to miss the meeting would be too high a price to pay, P. K. Chiang, a former CEPD chairman, said.

Chiang, who took part in APEC summits in the past on behalf of ROC presidents, called on the government to act prudently because Taiwan's insistence on its selection for representative may shut the door for Taiwan's participation this year.
Chiang said the government should carefully weight the issue as there is not much time left. "Actually there are many options worth considering by the government," he noted.

Mainland Chinese Vice Foreign Minister Wang Guangya said earlier the same day that Taiwan can take part in this year's APEC summit as long as it dispatches an envoy in agreement with the 1991 memorandum of understanding and past practice.
Wang also said the example set by Koo, cannot be viewed as a precedence.
Meanwhile, the CEPD said the Executive Yuan may assign Li as its "senior commissioner" to help push for his representation as Chen's proxy at the summit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO-WAY TRADE AT HSINCHU SCIENCE-BASED PARK DOWN 59% IN SEPTEMBER
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, Oct. 17 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Imports and exports by manufacturers at the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in September totaled NT$33.48 billion, down 58.6 percent from the same month last year.

An official with the industrial park administration attributed the sharp decline mainly to the adverse effects of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on New York and Washington, Typhoon Nari , which wreaked havoc in Taiwan Sept. 16-17 and the protracted global economic sluggishness.
The official listed the park's exports for September at NT$19.33 billion, down 54.3 percent from September of 2000, and imports at NT$14.15 billion, down 65.4 percent.
It was the seventh consecutive month for the park to register a negative growth in exports since last March.
Statistics show that the accumulated trade surplus of the park in the January-September period was NT$42.2 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REITERATES ANTI-TERRORISM STANCE
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Oct. 17 (CNA) (By Peng Ssu-chou and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has conveyed its willingness to the United States to fight terrorism and its intention of playing a supporting role in U.S.-led anti-terrorism actions, an ROC official said Wednesday in Shanghai.

ROC Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long, made the remarks at a news conference held after the bilateral ministerial-level meeting between him and U.S. Deputy Secretary of Commerce Samuel W. Bodman.

Chen said that the United States has accepted the ROC's message and expressed its intention to support the ROC at the ministerial-level meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum which opened Wednesday in Shanghai.
Beijing did not invite ROC representatives to the APEC ministerial-level meeting to attend a Thursday anti-terrorism breakfast to be presided over by mainland Chinese Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan.

Ho Mei-yueh, vice chairman of the ROC's Council for Economic Planning and Development, said at the news conference that the ROC has enacted a law governing the prevention of money laundering which it can provide to other countries for reference to stop terrorists from obtaining funds.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPERT SAYS LARGE-ENOUGH WAR WILL HELP ECONOMIC REVIVAL

TEXT.P: An expert said Wednesday that if the scope of the U.S.-led military strikes against Afghanistan is large enough, the global economy would have an opportunity for revival.

Wei Duan, former government director-general of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, said in an interview that mankind currently lacks the experience and ability to resolve the problem of another great depression through peaceful means.
From a historical point of view, he said, a huge economic bubble emerged in the 10 years before the Great Depression that hit the United States in 1929, when U.S. stocks crashed by 90 percent.
It was only after seven years of depression that the onset of World War II finally single-handedly shortened the gap between production and sales that grew over the years, he added.
Wei said that the current situation is very similar, with Japan's stock index losing three-quarters of its value after starting the previous wave of global economic bubbles.
When the U.S. economy was likewise slipping, the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks came, becoming what Wei said could be called "the straw that broke the back of the world economy."

Prior to 1960, he continued, the world economy would switch from bull to bear every three to five years. However, he said that between 1960 and 2000, the world economy has been in a continuous upswing because when the Japanese economic bubble burst, the U.S. dot-com bubble immediately took over.
Therefore, he said that the global economy looked good generally, and that people were barely aware of the misery that usually comes when the economy hits rock bottom.

Wei went on to say that although many U.S. financial and economic experts have predicted that the U.S. economy will see a very quick V-shaped rebound, others believe that the prospects for the U.S. economy can only be optimistic if the American consumers have not lost confidence.

He said that the U.S. consumer confidence index has already dropped from the previous high of 140 points to below 100, which is considered rare in recent years. This is mainly because with the onset of war, people cut down on spending and started to save.
Wei predicted that American consumer expenditures could continue to shrink, which would be very unfavorable to a U.S. economic recovery.

For Taiwan, he said, the public should be ready for a protracted economic slump because the four major sources of domestic income -- salaries, rent, interest and investments -- will continue to drop, and the economic growth rate will continue to be adjusted downward.
Wei said that many companies in Taiwan are cutting their employees' salaries or even downsizing. The unemployment rate continues to grow and salaries continue to shrink, he added.
Because the central bank has adjusted downward its interest rates several times, We said, the interest rates for certificates of deposit have dropped below 3 percent, affecting interest income.
With the continued slump in the property market, he went on, rent has gone down instead of up.
Meanwhile, he added, businesses have been seeing their profits drop, affecting investment income as well.
Wei said that Taiwan's exports rely heavily on the electronics industry, but Taiwan's electronic information products have been unable to find buyers with the current U.S. economic slump.
He added that new investments in Taiwan so far this year registered 30 percent less than the same period last year, demonstrating a key factor leading to the negative economic growth rate this year.
He said that it will be difficult to achieve the government's estimated 4.16 percent annual economic growth for 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVOY TO POSTPONE DEPARTURE FOR SHANGHAI APEC SUMMIT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Wednesday evening that the nation's envoy for the informal summit meeting of this year's Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum will not leave for Shanghai as scheduled on Thursday.

The ministry said in a news release that as Taipei has yet to receive a formal invitation from Beijing, the sponsor of the summit, the envoy, Senior Presidential Adviser and former Vice President Li Yuan-zu, and his entourage will postpone their departure.
Beijing has objected to Taiwan's offer of Li as its top envoy at the summit, scheduled to open at the weekend, on the grounds that Li lacks an economic or financial background.
Due to Beijing's past threats of boycott, Taiwan has been represented at past APEC summits by senior economics officials, rather than its presidents.
The ministry said that it is still negotiating with Beijing regarding the nation's envoy at the summit.
Meanwhile, a CNA dispatch from Shanghai quoted Taiwan officials attending the APEC-related meetings as saying that the Taiwan envoy and the entourage will arrive in Shanghai Friday afternoon.
However, the officials did not elaborate whether Li will remain as the top Taipei envoy, or if there will be someone else in his place.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 18, or the second day of the ninth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1405: Pope Pius II, originally named Enea Silivio Piccolomini, is born. He was noted for his unsuccessful attempt to lead a crusade against the Turks.
1860: Invading British troops burn the Yuanmingyuan, the imperial summer palace in Beijing, to the ground.
1867: The United States purchases Alaska from Russia for US$7.2 million.
1873: Delegates from Columbia, Princeton, Rutgers, and Yale universities meet and formulate the rules for American football.
1898: The United States takes possession of Puerto Rico from Spain.
1907: The first plans are announced for an International Court of Justice to be set up in The Hague.
1922: Tsai Yuan-pei, a scholar and the president of Peking University, resigns in the wake of student protests against an extra levy on professor's handouts.
1926: The will of Vladimir Ilich Lenin, Russian founder of the Bolshevik party, leader of the Russian Revolution and first head of the USSR, is made public to the world in the New York Times.
1931: Thomas Alva Edison, America's most prolific inventor, dies at the age of 84. His inventions include the phonograph, the microphone and the kinescope.
1941: General Hideki Tojo becomes prime minister of Japan and begins planning for war against the United States.
1944: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt cables Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National government and supreme commander of the China theater of war, regarding his decision to appoint Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer as chief of staff of the China theater of war to succeed Gen. Joseph Stilwell.
1946: The Chinese communists reject the government's latest peace offer presented by Chiang Kai-shek on Oct. 16.
1967: Venera 4, a Soviet spacecraft, enters the atmosphere of Venus and transmits data back to earth.
1970: Vice President Yen Chia-kan, who concurrently holds the post of premier, leaves Taipei for New York to attend the 25th anniversary of the founding of the United Nations.
1974: Acting for President Chiang Kai-shek, Vice President Yen Chia-kan accepts the credentials of Maj. Gen. Ismael D. Lapus as the Philippines ambassador to the Republic of China.
1974: The ROC national taekwondo team returns from Seoul after taking second place in the First Asian Taekwondo championships.
1976: Chinese-American scientist Samuel Chao Chung Ting and his colleague Burton Richter share the 1976 Nobel Prize for physics for their discovery of an elementary nuclear particle called the "psi," or "J particle."
1987: The United States attacks an Iranian oil rig in revenge for strikes against its shipping operations by gunboats.
1989: Erich Honecker, 77, East Germany's hardline ruler who failed to respond to the desire among East Germans for change, is ousted from the post he held for the previous 18 years.
1989: People trample each other as a crowd tries to squeeze through the gates of a stadium to watch a World Cup qualifying soccer match in Guatemala. Eighty-three people are killed and nearly 200 others are injured.
1990: The Mainland Affairs Council is established under the Executive Yuan to formulate and implement mainland policy, with Vice Premier Shih Chi-yang serving as its chairman.
1998: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the ROC's Straits Exchange Foundation, crowns a six-day visit to mainland China by meeting with President Jiang Zemin, marking the highest-level contact between the two sides since 1949.
1999: Two more Knox-class frigates leased from the United States are commissioned in order to help beef up the Republic of China's naval defense capabilities.
2000: A seminar on trade and economic cooperation among the three Chinese communities -- Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong -- opens in Beijing.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man, by living a life of simple truth and earnestness, alone can help to bring peace and order in the world."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 5.93 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Thursday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 5.93 points to close at 3,811.2.
Market turnover amounted to NT$35.6 billion (US$1.03 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: LUNGKENG ECOLOGICAL PRESERVE SET TO REOPEN 9 MONTHS AFTER OIL SPILL

TEXT.P: After nine months of clean-up work following an oil spill near the Lungkeng Ecological Preserve in southern Taiwan's Kenting National Park, the preserve will be reopened to tourists starting Oct. 20, although only 200 visitors will be allowed to enter per day.
Back on Jan. 14, the Greek-registered bulk carrier Amorgos ran aground off the coast near Kenting National Park, spilling roughly 1,150 tons of fuel oil into the water.

Three kilometers of coastline, from the Lungkeng Ecological Preserve to the rocky cliffs at Oulanbi, was seriously polluted. The ensuing clean-up work among the coral reefs was extremely difficult to carry out.
In addition to residents in the neighboring area, 1,600 soldiers were mobilized to help in the clean-up effort.
A spokesman of the Kenting National Park administration said Thursday that although marine life in the area has been showing signs of revival, it would take time for a total rehabilitation.
Located on Hengchuen Peninsula at Taiwan's southernmost tip, Kenting National Park, with its coral reefs and coastal tropical rainforests, is renown for its natural beauty.

The 60-hectare Lungkeng nature preserve was set aside for the purpose of academic research and environmental education activities, and only a limited number of visitors are allowed to enter the area each day.
Those who wish to apply for permission to enter the nature preserve for environmental education activities must submit an official application at least two weeks in advance.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened low but closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 5.93 points to close at 3,811.2.
The bourse opened at 3,761.1 but began to go up later due to a rebound in certain electrical shares. The index fluctuated between 3,811.2 and 3,758.58 during trading.

A total of 1.73 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$35.6 billion (US$1.03 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.66 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$61.45 billion (US$1.78 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with pulp and paper issues moving up 1.5 percent.

The other major categories posted losses, with foodstuff shares and textile issues moving down the most, both at 1.2 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 1 percent, cement stocks at 0.9 percent, construction shares at 0.6 percent, and bank and insurance shares and electrical stocks, both at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 323 to 190, with 117 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower on Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for November moved down 15 points to close at 3,770, with 12,810 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for December lost 16 points to finish at 3,776, with 23 contract transactions, while next March futures decreased 35 points to finish at 3,755, with only one contract traded.
Next June futures fell 110 points to close at 3,740, also with one contract traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 3,785 for November, 3,792 for December, 3,790 for next March, 3,850 for next June, and 3,830 for next September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
November TE futures edged down 0.5 points to close at 182.5, with 3,619 contract transactions, while December TE futures decreased 3.7 points to finish at 181.6, with four contracts traded.
Next March TE futures lost 3.2 points to finish at 182.3, with 10 contracts changing hands. No transactions were reported for other months.
November TF futures moved up 3.6 points to finish at 575.4, with 1,542 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S BREACH OF APEC PROTOCOL REGRETTABLE: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that mainland China's gross breach of the well-established protocol of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum is extremely regrettable.
Chen made the remarks in telephone conversations with Chinese-American Congressman David Wu (D-Ore.)

The president said mainland China has so far not sent any special envoy to Taipei to forward him an invitation to this year's APEC informal leadership meeting, scheduled to be held in Shanghai Oct. 20-21.
Worse yet, Chen said, mainland China has not even sent any formal invitation to him. "Its breaking of the established APEC protocol is very regrettable," Chen told Wu.

Because of Beijing's complete disregard of the APEC protocol, Chen said, the Republic of China delegation to the annual gathering of the top leaders of the 21 APEC member states has had to postpone its departure for Shanghai.
Chen recalled that last year's APEC summit host, Brunei, twice sent its special envoy to Taipei to present him with an invitation letter.

The president placed phone calls at his office Thursday morning to three Democratic members of the U.S. House of Representatives -- Nancy Pelosi, who was recently elected the Democratic Party whip in the House, as well as Rep. Howard Berman and Rep. Wu.

During the conversations, Chen reiterated the ROC government and people's condemnation of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks that brought down the twin towers of New York City's World Trade Center and partially damaged the Pentagon in Washington, D.C.
Chen also reaffirmed the ROC's adamant support for the current U.S.-led anti-terrorism campaign.
He congratulated Pelosi for her election as the House minority leader and invited her to visit Taiwan again to help boost bilateral exchanges.

For his part, Rep. Wu told Chen that he had originally planned to go to Shanghai together with U.S. President George W. Bush to attend the annual APEC events. "But I had to give up the plan as the Bush delegation didn't include any members of Congress," he said.
President Chen told Wu that he also hoped to attend the annual APEC summit in person. But Chen said he had to shelve the plan simply because of political reasons.

Both Taiwan and mainland China joined APEC in 1991, and mainland China has used its larger political muscles to block the ROC president from attending the group's annual summit meeting. As a result, the ROC president has traditionally had to designate a stand-in, usually an economics official, to represent him at the occasion.

This year, Chen picked former ROC Vice President Li Yuan-zu to attend the APEC summit on his behalf. Chen said he believes that Li, a criminal law expert, would best be able to contribute to the meeting because counter-terrorism will be a main topic of discussion in APEC summit in Shanghai.

Although mainland China has not publicly described its specific objections to Li's attendance, it appears that his background in politics is the main problem. If Li attends the APEC summit, it will set a precedent of Taiwan sending a representative who has held a high-ranking political position.
Taiwan hopes to solve the problem by saying that Li will represent Taiwan as a consultant to the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development.

The ROC used this title before when tycoon and elder statesman Koo Chen-fu attended three APEC summits from 1995-97 on behalf of then-President Lee Teng-hui, and Taipei is asking Beijing to agree to the "Koo Chen-fu model" again.

The octogenarian Koo is also the chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, a quasi-official body that handles relations with mainland China in the absence of official ties. But Koo did not use this title when he attended APEC.
The two sides were still discussing the issue Thursday morning, and it was not immediately known whether mainland China would accept Li's new title.
Since ending his six-year stint as vice president in 1996, Li, 78, has stayed out of the public eye, and during his career, he was known for keeping a low profile.
