DOC.HEADLINE: III BRINGS SENIOR CITIZENS CLOSE TO COMPUTERS

TEXT.P: The Institute for Information Industry (III) will present awards to 19 senior citizens for their impressive works in a computer application contest for those aged over 65.

The III together with the Ministry of Education and the National Science Council are sponsoring the "Evergreen Information Month" activities for the fifth year. The activities begin Friday with the award presentation ceremony and the opening of the exhibition featuring the prize-winning entries.

In view of the increasing number of senior citizens on the island and the apparent computer knowledge gap between senior citizens and the average population, the government has been seeking to bring the senior citizens closer to computers.
Supported by educational establishments as well as social welfare organizations, the "Evergreen Information Week" activities were first held in 1997.
Targeted at the 1.94 million senior citizens in Taiwan, the activities feature computer applications in health monitoring and computer and Internet application courses.
The 19 winners of the computer application contest are between 65 and 85 years old. Their experience in computer applications ranges between one to 10 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUVENILE CONSULTING GROUP HOLDS MEETING FOR SCHOOL DROPOUTS

TEXT.P: Educational personnel and social workers in Taipei met Thursday to find ways to help the increasing numbers of youngsters who drop out of school.

Sponsored by the Chungshan Juvenile Consulting Group, the discussions concentrated on the difficulties that some youngsters have fitting into the social environment at school and ways to deal with delinquent dropouts.

A spokesman for the consulting group said that quite a few dropouts were either facing problems at home or discrimination at school. Disappointed teachers sometimes also tended to give up on these youngsters.

A study conducted by the Ministry of Education showed tat more than one-fourth of the dropouts were from single-parent families. Students from aboriginal families in remote regions also had higher dropout rates than those in urban regions.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.003 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Thursday, closing at 34.545.
The local currency opened Thursday at 34.542 and was traded between 34.508 and 34.549.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$294 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC BELIEVES U.S WILL NOT COMPROMISE TAIWAN FOR CHINA'S SUPPORT: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government believes in the U.S. commitment to separating its anti-terrorism campaign from the Taiwan Strait issue, a senior Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Thursday.

Stanley Kao, director of MOFA's North American Affairs Department, made the remarks amid mounting concerns about the possibility that the United States could compromise Taiwan's interests in exchange for mainland China's cooperation in the current U.S.-led war on global terrorism.

Kao said U.S. President George W. Bush's trip to Shanghai is mainly to attend the annual informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to seek expansion of the anti-terrorism coalition.

Prior to his departure for Shanghai, Bush said during his meeting with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, he will reaffirm to Jiang the U.S. support for the "one China" policy as well as its desire to see a peaceful solution to all disputes between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Kao said several senior Bush administration officials, including Secretary of State Colin Powell, has also made reassurances that the United States would not seek mainland China's support for the anti-terrorism campaign at the expense of Taiwan.

"We believe in the sincerity of the United States in promising not to mix up its counter-terrorism drive with the Taiwan Strait issue," Kao said, adding that relevant U.S. officials have on many occasions reaffirmed similar commitments to the ROC.

Commenting on a Washington Post report that the Bush administration was considering waiving sanctions that bar sales of military-related equipment to mainland China, Kao said MOFA is trying to obtain more information about the report.

In his view, Kao said the cross-strait balance of military power is critical to the ROC's national security. Noting that the United States has consistently attached great importance to Asia-Pacific regional stability and security, Kao said the robust U.S. arms sales package to Taiwan struck in April this year signifies that the United States is serious about security in the region.
Against this backdrop, Kao said, the ROC government is optimistic about defense cooperation with the United States.

Meanwhile, a foreign wire service report from Shanghai quoted a senior U.S. Department of State official as saying Wednesday that the Bush administration has no plans to ease sanctions against mainland China.

The U.S. official told reporters traveling with Powell en route to Shanghai for an APEC meeting that he unequivocally denied the Washington Post report that said the Bush administration was considering such a move, specifically to allow sales of spare parts for mainland Chinese-owned helicopters as another weapon in the U.S. war on terrorism.
"There's no such sale or waiver contemplated," he said.

The Post quoted U.S. officials as saying the White House was considering a waiver of sanctions imposed after the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown in Beijing to allow the sale of parts for Black Hawks that Washington sold to mainland China in the 1980s.

It said the helicopters were designed for high altitudes typical of much of mainland China, including its Afghan border. Afghanistan is now under U.S. bombardment for refusing to hand over the chief suspect in the Sept. 11 attacks on New York and Washington, Saudi-born dissident Osama bin Laden.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI LASHES OUT AT BEIJING FOR FAILING TO ACT AS PROPER APEC HOST

TEXT.P: Mainland China has not acted in line with the obligations of a host country of the informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, a spokeswoman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Thursday.
Chang Siao-yue said that as Beijing has reservations about the government's choice of former Vice President Li Yuan-zu to head the delegation, it has yet to send a formal invitation.

The ROC delegation, which was scheduled to leave for Shanghai for the Oct. 20-21 meeting Thursday, will have to delay their departure, Chang said, adding that the government is now consulting with mainland authorities on the matter, but so far no headway has been made.

She stressed that Li was chosen after careful consideration, and that his background as a criminal law expert would contribute to discussions on anti-terrorism, which will be on the agenda at the summit meeting. The government is still hoping that Li will represent President Chen Shui-bian at the meeting, she added.

On Beijing's insistence that Taiwan must act in accordance with past practices and a memorandum of understanding in 1991 to send officials with economic or financial backgrounds to the regional meeting, Chang said that the informal leadership meetings were not convened until 1993, and the memo of understanding in 1991 should not govern in this situation.

Both Taiwan and mainland China joined APEC in 1991, but Beijing has used its political clout to block ROC presidents from attending the group's annual summit meeting. As a result, ROC presidents have traditionally had to designate a stand-in, usually an economic official, to represent the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTPUT OF TAINAN INDUSTRIAL PARK THIS YEAR TO REACH NT$48 BILLION

TEXT.P: This year's production at the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park is expected to reach NT$48 billion, showing a 100 percent increase over that of last year, an official with the park said Thursday.

As the plants of some major manufacturers, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. and United Microelectronics Corp., have been completed, the official noted that the industrial park's output next year may rise to NT$80 billion.
If the global economic recovery comes earlier than expected, he went on, the 2002 output might even reach NT$100 billion.

The Tainan industrial park is the largest such facility in Taiwan, covering 1,600 hectares. Construction projects for the first phase started in July 1996 and will be completed in 2005, or five years ahead of the original schedule.
The projects for the second phase will be completed in 2011 and the projects for the Luchu development will be completed in 2010.

At present 62 plants have been established at the Tainan industrial park -- 20 of them being the expanded plants of the semiconductor manufacturing companies located at the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park.

Of the 62 plants, 25 have started full operations. Their revenues in the first eight months of this year were NT$28.6 billion, up 195 percent over the same period last year. The output for the whole of 2001 is estimated at NT$48 billion.
The official said the effects of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on New York and Washington on the Tainan industrial park were not so severe as those on the Hsinchu industrial park.
He estimated that the revenues of the Tainan industrial park in the September-October period alone would amount to NT$10 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA SHIPBUILDING HOPES TO GET ORDERS TO BUILD SUBMARINE PARTS
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Oct. 18 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) hopes to secure orders from the United States to build components used in the eight diesel-powered submarines the United States has agreed to sell to Taiwan, CSBC sources said Thursday.
The United States will detail the specifications for building the submarines and will invite international tenders to jointly construct the submarines.

The CSBC has sent two representatives involved with the manufacture of submarine parts to the United States to hear the explanation, CSBC sources said, adding that the two will bring back related data to ranking CSBC officials for their reference to bid for contracts.

DOC.HEADLINE: 66.5 PERCENT OF 12-YEAR-OLDS HAVE TOOTH DECAY OR MISSING TEETH

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) announced Thursday that 66.5 percent of the 12-year-olds examined in a DOH-sponsored study on teenager oral hygiene last year have tooth decay or missing teeth, an improvement over 20 years ago.
Of the 5,700 elementary and middle school students examined, the average number of decayed or missing teeth among 12-year-olds is 3.31, with 54.3 percent of those teeth already treated.

According to the DOH, 85.1 percent of 12-year-olds in 1981 had tooth decay or missing teeth. The average number of tooth decay or missing teeth was 3.76, with only 10.4 percent of those teeth treated.
The World Health Organization standard goal for oral hygiene is achieving a nationwide average figure of less than three decayed or missing teeth.
According to the study, 81.78 percent of the 15-to-18-year-olds examined have gum disease and require treatment.

Tsai Yin-ling, the dentist in charge of overseeing the study, said that this reflects the likelihood that middle and high school students often neglect their oral hygiene because they are busy with schoolwork.

DOC.HEADLINE: BONE MARROW DONORS, M'LAND RECIPIENTS SHARE INTERESTING COINCIDENCES

TEXT.P: An eastern Taiwan hospital extracted bone marrow from two donors Thursday and found a number of interesting coincidences among the donors and the recipients on the mainland.

Hualien Tzu Chi Hospital completed the 316th and 317th bone marrow surgeries Thursday. The first bone marrow donor was a 21-year-old male college student, and his recipient will be a 39-year-old male in the mainland with leukemia. The second donor was a 28-year-old female, and her recipient a 27-year-old female in the mainland.
Tzu Chi said that both donors were born on Oct. 28, while the two recipients both sought donors on March 28 this year. They also had other interesting similarities.
Both donors traveled to Hualien Tzu Chi on August 14 to have physical examinations, and they took the same flight to the hospital again Wednesday afternoon They both underwent surgery Thursday.
The extracted bone marrow will be sent to a university hospital in Zhejiang. The same doctor is treating the two patients on the mainland.
All these coincidences have led Tzu Chi hospital to believe that the donors and recipients have what Chinese call an "unknown yuanfeng" (destiny) between them.
Tzu Chi celebrated the birthdays of the two donors in advance Thursday and also expressed the hope that the two recipients will have speedy recoveries.
The male donor reported that he has developed a strong body through learning Chinese martial arts. After donating blood to celebrate his 18th birthday, he has since regularly donated blood.
The female donor was the only one in Tzu Chi's bone marrow data bank that matched the recipient in the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL SAYS PUBLIC STILL SEES LINK BETWEEN ORGANIZED CRIME AND POLITICS

TEXT.P: The majority of local people are pessimistic about the prospects for a government campaign to eradicate the influence of organized crime in domestic politics, according to the results of a public opinion poll released Thursday.

The telephone poll of 1,012 adult residents randomly chosen from throughout the island, conducted by Open magazine from Oct. 8-11, found that 85 percent of the respondents said they do not think that organized crime's influence in local politics could be completely rooted out.

Although President Chen Shui-bian campaigned on a policy platform against the influence of moneyed interests and organized crime in politics, commonly known as "black gold," survey results showed that 58 percent said they had not seen any improvement in containing organized crime's influence in domestic politics.
Only 38.77 percent said they had seen some progress in preventing organized crime from interfering with local political affairs since President Chen assumed office in May 2000.

Meanwhile, 38.08 percent said they think that organized crime's influence is most serious in the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), while 8.82 percent said they think that such a phenomenon is most serious in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

About 50 percent said they think that many candidates for the Dec. 1 legislative elections have close ties to organized crime, and 49.31 percent said they believe that candidates with backgrounds in organized crime would win in the upcoming polls.
Analyzing the poll results, DPP legislator Lin Chung-mo said many local people remain suspicious of the government's determination to wipe out "black gold" politics.
Against this background, Lin said, law enforcement authorities should redouble their efforts to eliminate "black gold."

DOC.HEADLINE: INBOUND, OUTBOUND TRAVELERS DECLINE SHARPLY AFTER TERRORIST ATTACKS

TEXT.P: Both inbound and outbound tourists have declined significantly since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States, the Tourism Bureau reported Thursday.
According to bureau tallies, the number of tourist arrivals between July 12 and Sept. 30 fell 19.4 percent from the same period of last year.

In September alone, the total number of inbound passengers dropped 12.8 percent from the year-earlier level. By areas, the number of tourists from the United States registered a 26.9 percent annual decrease in September; the number of Japanese tourists slid 9.4 percent; and the number of Hong Kong visitors also fell 8 percent in September.
The total tourist arrivals for the first nine months of this year posted a moderate 5.8 percent gain as compared with the same period of last year, tourist officials said.
The Tourism Bureau originally projected this year's growth in inbound tourists at 10 percent. But now the bureau said it has to adjust downward the growth target to a marginal 0.15 percent.

Although tourist arrivals did increase slightly more than 10 percent in the first half of this year, the trend reversed itself since July. In the first 10 days of October, the number of inbound visitors recorded a 17.5 percent decline from the like period of 2000.

Meanwhile, the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York and Washington have also dampened local people's interest in making overseas pleasure trips as outbound travelers plunged 18.34 percent in September from the year-earlier level.

In the first nine months of this year, outbound passengers dwindled 3.67 percent as compared with the like period of last year. Tourist officials said the total number of outbound travelers would registered a 5 percent negative growth this year.
With the decline in tourist arrivals, major local tourist hotels have seen their room occupancy rates drop by more than 20 percent, travel sources said.

Tourist officials said they will step up promotional efforts to attract tourists from Japan, Hong Kong, Macau, New Zealand, Australia and European countries. On the other hand, the bureau will suspend promotional programs in North America in consideration of the current U.S.-led war on global terrorism.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, MAINLAND CHINA TO BECOME CLOSER UNDER WTO FRAMEWORK

TEXT.P: Trade and economic ties between Taiwan and mainland China will become closer after both sides join the World Trade Organization (WTO) and bilateral trade disputes can be settled under the WTO framework, an economic affairs official said Thursday.

Speaking at a seminar sponsored by the National Policy Foundation on the impact of WTO membership, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu said mutual benefits will far exceed competition following the two sides' entry into the world trade regulatory body.
According to Lin, increased trade and economic exchanges will bring the two sides closer, but mainland-based export-oriented small Taiwan businesses will be hit hard.

In terms of industries, Lin pointed out that Taiwan's agricultural industry will be much more affected by its WTO membership than the service and industrial sectors due to the expected lowering of high import duties on agricultural imports. The service and industrial sectors will be less affected in turn as a result of their wider opening to foreign competition.

Kao Koong-lian, former vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council and now a panel director of the foundation, urged the government to pay attention to future inflows of foreign imports and investment from mainland China.

Lin Chu-chia, a professor of economic science at National Chengchi University, said current cross-strait activities are already complementary in nature and that is the reason why two-way trade and economic exchanges are increasingly growing.

WTO membership will create an international stage and a good communication channel for both Taiwan and mainland China, he said. Lin called on the governments on both sides of the Strait to forswear their ideological struggle and devote their energy to economic issues of mutual concern.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD IPO PURCHASES IN TAIWAN TOTAL US$3.5 BILLION FOR 2001

TEXT.P: Purchase by the world's top 20 international procurement offices (IPOs) of information technology products in Taiwan is estimated to total US$3.5 billion for 2001, a government agency announced Thursday.

The figure represents an 8.4 percent growth over the 2000 level, according to officials of the Committee for Information Industry Development under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, who added that the figure might increase by more than 10 percent next year.
The officials disclosed the information amid speculation the world's leading 20 IPOs in Taiwan will reduce their purchases here and that some of them will move their headquarters out of Taiwan.

Citing statistics compiled by the Institute for Information Industry, the committee reported that purchases by the 20 IPOs all registered double-digit growth for each of the past five years. The growth rates were 41.7 percent and 47.7 percent, respectively, for 2000 and 1999, while they stood at 38 percent and 27 percent, respectively, for 1998 and 1997. In 1996, the rate was 33.7 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE LAUNCHES ONLINE WEEKLY PAPER

TEXT.P: An online newspaper published by the Presidential Office was formally launched Thursday, according to officials of the Department of Public Affairs under the Presidential Office.

The officials said "President A-bian's Electronic Paper" seeks to use an informal approach to explain the president's administrative ideals and ways to implement them, as well as a more delicate approach to depict the inner world of President Chen Shui-bian, nicknamed A-bian.

Officials said they hope the paper will build a channel of "direct communication between the president and the people" so that they can share the president's thoughts and some of the titbits of his daily life.

Officials said the inaugural publication includes a column on Chen's recent observations in which the president lauds the Taiwan people's "great ability to adapt to their environment" and says that this spirit should be upheld to overcome difficulties and "create miracles."

The inaugural edition also includes video excerpts of the president's appeal to the nation made on the Double Ten National Day rally, in which he exhorted the people to stand up to challenges and realize their dreams.

There is also an "information zone" that reveals for the first time that the president will publish a new book at the end of the month. The book will describe how the president has faced problems, met challenges and thought about the future since assuming the presidency May 20, 2000.

There is also a readers' hotline column in which the first article is a letter to the president from a couple that have devoted themselves to post-Sept. 21 earthquake reconstruction work, together with the president's response.
The paper also carries previously unpublished pictures of the president.

Officials said that since the paper began to accept subscriptions Oct. 8., the response has been so enthusiastic that the number of subscribers had surpassed 20,000 by Wednesday. The subscribers will receive the paper via e-mail.
Officials said that those who are interested in the paper can click on http://www.president.gov.tw for more information.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH THINK TANK REPORTS TAIWAN'S ARMS PROCUREMENT REDUCED IN 2000
DOC.DATELINE: London, Oct. 18 (CNA) (By Mark Ou and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's arms procurement spending in 2000 fell to US$1.2 billion, while mainland China took deliveries worth US$1.6 billion, according to a report released Thursday by the International Institute for Strategic Studies (IISS).

The IISS "Military Balance 2001-2002" report notes that the value of Taiwan's arms deliveries in 2000 reached its lowest point since 1995 even as the value of mainland China's arms deliveries shot up from 1999's US$510 million.
The London-based IISS pointed out that the international arms trade fell significantly, with the total value of deliveries falling from US$37.2 billion in 1999 to US$29.3 billion in 2000.

The Middle East continued to spend more on arms imports than any other region, accounting for at least 40 percent of the world market. Saudi Arabia, the largest Middle Eastern customer, took deliveries worth US$7.3 billion, a slight increase over 1999.

The United States once again accounted for nearly 50 percent of global arms deliveries, while the United Kingdom remained the second-largest exporter, with 17.4 percent of deliveries, the IISS report notes.

The IISS predicts that delivery of eight diesel-electric submarines that the U.S. administration has agreed to sell Taiwan will be delayed even under the best of circumstances, because the United States no longer produces diesel submarines and other countries that can still manufacture the vessels have already expressed their unwillingness to cooperate.

The report also notes that Taiwan's impending acquisition of four U.S. Kidd-class destroyers should serve as an effective counter-balance to a number of destroyers that mainland China has acquired from Russia.
Taiwan's acquisition of more advanced Patriot missiles will also improve its ability to counter short-range ballistic missiles and cruise missiles, the IISS report adds.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTHRAX FEAR ON RISE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The fear of anthrax is increasing in Taiwan, with people eager to obtain antibiotics against anthracis bacillus, sources with the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health said Thursday.

CDC officials said the center has received 44 phone calls from around the island in the past few days inquiring where they can buy Ciprofloxacin -- the antibiotic used to treat anthrax -- and what they can do if they receive mail containing an unknown white powder.
Some of those making the phone calls said they have felt worried after receiving mail with an unknown return address, with some even suspecting that they had contracted anthrax.

CDC Deputy Director Chiang Ying-lung noted that no human anthrax cases have been reported in Taiwan since 1969 and added that presently there are eight local hospitals that have Ciprofloxacin supplies.
He asked doctors to heighten their alert regarding the disease and urged the public to see a doctor if they suspect that they have contracted the disease.
He said that because Ciprofloxacin has strong side effects, the public should not buy the antibiotic over the counter.
The CDC urged the public not to open mail of unknown origin but to seal it in plastic bags and let the police and the CDC deal with it.
Chiang also advised anyone receiving mail containing an unknown white powder to wash their hands and avoid touching their face, because anthrax spores are easily killed with soap and water.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WORLD'S 7TH MOST COMPETITIVE NATION: WEF REPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Oct. 18 (CNA) (By Tang Ping-chun & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The Geneva-based World Economic Forum (WEF) writes in its 2001 global competitiveness report released Thursday that Taiwan has become the world's seventh most competitive nation, advancing from last year's eleventh place.
Mainland China, which is expected to enter the World Trade Organization together with Taiwan early next year, ranked 39th place from the preceding year's 40th place.

The annual report consists of two index rankings. The growth competitiveness index ranking measures prospects for growth over the coming five years, while the current competitiveness index ranking measures an economy's current productive potential.
Finland emerged as the most competitive nation in both categories.

The report, prepared by the WEF and Harvard University professors Jeffrey D. Saches and Michael E. Porter, contains economic data of 75 countries together with the results of a survey of 4,600 business executives worldwide.

The 2001 rankings of growth competitiveness index, with last year's rankings in parentheses, include: 1. Finland (6) 2. United States (1) 3. Canada (7) 4. Singapore (2) 5. Australia (12) 6. Norway (16) 7. Taiwan (11) 8. Netherlands (4) 9. Sweden (13) 10. New Zealand (20) 11. Ireland (5) 12. Britain (9) 13. Hong Kong (8) 14. Denmark (14) 15. Switzerland (10) 16. Iceland (24) 17. Germany (15) 18. Austria (18) 19. Belgium (17) 20. France (22) 21. Japan (21) 22. Spain (27) 23. South Korea (29) 24. Israel (19) 25. Portugal (23).

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT RECEIVES NATIONAL ASUNCION UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian reiterated Thursday the long-standing relations between the Republic of China and Paraguay when he received visiting National Asuncion University President Paul Battilana.
The president noted the close exchanges between the two countries, saying Paraguay is the only ally of the ROC in South America and an important gateway to the South American market.

The president said that he attaches great importance to relations between the two countries and that the ROC government looks forward to a visit to Taiwan from Paraguayan President Luis Angel Gonzalez Macchi in the first half of next year.

The president, who received an honorary doctoral degree from the National Asuncion University when he visited Paraguay in May this year, said that he welcomes Battilana on his first visit to the ROC, both as ROC president and an alumni.

The president said that the bestowing of the honorary degree on him was not just his personal honor but also a recognition of the political and economic achievements realized by the ROC and the 23 million people of Taiwan.
The president said that he cherished his first honorary doctoral degree from a Spanish-language country.

The president noted that Asuncion University, created in 1887, is a prestigious university with 12 colleges and 55 departments and graduate schools. If it can forge sisterhood relations with Taiwan universities and increase exchanges, this would further enhance the understanding between the two peoples, he went on.

Battilana for his part expressed the hope that the ROC Ministry of Education will send more Chinese language teachers to Paraguay, whereupon Chen promised to provide assistance so that Asuncion University can establish a department and graduate school of Chinese language soon.

Battilana also said that it was a great honor of his university to bestow the honorary doctorate on Chen and expressed the hope to have more exchanges and cooperation between his university and its Taiwan counterparts to help develop Paraguay's technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO MEDICAL TEAMS FROM TAIWAN READY TO HELP AFGHAN REFUGEES

TEXT.P: Two medical teams from Taiwan are ready to provide medical services to Afghan refugees, Department of Health Deputy Director-General Huang Fu-yuan said Thursday.

Huang noted that the members of the teams will come from National Taiwan University Hospital, Shin Kong Wu Ho Su Memorial Hospital, National Chengkung University Hospital and Pingtung Christian Hospital.

He said that the two teams will work alongside U.N. non-government organizations to provide humanitarian assistance to the refugees, but added that there is no concrete timetable for dispatching the medical teams.

Meanwhile, an official of the Taiwan-based Buddhist Tzu Chi Compassionate Relief Association said the association has provided food and medicine for the Afghan refugees through Knightbridge International, a U.S.-based charity group.
If everything has gone smoothly, she went on, the first batch of Tzu Chi relief materials should have reached the Afghan border Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-VICE PRESIDENT REMAINS TAIPEI'S CHOICE OF APEC ENVOY: ROC OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Oct. 18 (CNA) (By Peng Szu-chou and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's economics minister said Thursday that former Vice President Li Yuan-zu remains Taipei's sole choice to represent the ROC president at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum's informal leadership meeting slated for Oct. 20-21.

Lin Hsin-yi said at a news conference in Shanghai following an APEC ministerial level meeting that he hopes Beijing will "demonstrate its wisdom," because Taipei will insist on its choice "to the last moment."

Beijing has insisted that Taiwan must act in accordance with past practice by sending officials with economic or financial backgrounds to the regional meeting, but Taipei has been adamant in its wish to send Li, justifying the decision by saying that his background as a criminal law expert would be better suited to contributing to discussions on anti-terrorism, which will be on the agenda at the summit meeting.

At another news conference held immediately after Thursday's ministerial meeting, mainland Chinese Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan insinuated that there might be "some kind of obscure political scheme" behind Taipei's choice of Li.
When Lin rose to his feet and raised his hand to request the floor to hear Taipei's explanation, Tang cut him off, saying that it was unnecessary to "waste further time" on explanations.
Tang also referred to the Taipei delegation as "China Taipei" instead of the APEC-designated "Chinese Taipei."
Responding to Tang's accusation, Taipei's visiting Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Chen Po-chih said that it is "a kind of misunderstanding."
Chen added that on the basis of promoting benign bilateral interaction, Taipei hopes Beijing will not dwell on such misunderstandings.

With Beijing's acceptance of Li still up in the air, National Chengchi University foreign relations professor Lin Bih-jaw said in Taipei that out of consideration of the national interest, the ROC government should not speak of boycotting the APEC summit in protest, as some observers have conjectured it might.
Lin suggested that if Beijing really cannot accept Li as envoy, Taipei should try to find another candidate in the limited time available and try not to absent itself from the summit.

Both Taiwan and mainland China joined APEC in 1991, but Beijing has used its political clout to block ROC presidents from attending the group's annual summit meeting. As a result, ROC presidents have traditionally had to designate a stand-in, usually an economics official, to represent the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STRONG ON INVENTION AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT: REPORT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's strong invention capability will have the country enjoy the world's seventh most competitive economy for the next five years, according to a report published Thursday by the Geneva-based World Economic Forum (WEF).

The forum reported in its Global Competitiveness Report 2001 that Taiwan will have the world's seventh-most promising economic growth prospects over the next five years due to its technical progress, especially in the field of invention. Taiwan has the world's fourth-highest number of patents and that is a sound foundation for its economic development, the report said.

According to the report, Taiwan leads 75 other countries in the field of invention, lagging behind only Canada. However, according to the results of a survey of 1,000 international businesses around the world, Taiwan ranks only in a relatively low 18th place in the same category.
Statistics compiled by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) indicate that the number of patents grew noticeably last year in Taiwan.

In 2000, a total of 61,000 new patents applied for government registration, up 17.9 percent from the 1999 level. Some 42,241 of them were approved by the government, up 44.9 percent from a year ago. About 17,503 of the approved new patents were new inventions, up 55.2 percent over the year-earlier level.

In terms of the number of new inventions approved by the U.S. government, 5,806 cases raised by Taiwan were recognized by the U.S. authorities, behind only patents from the United States, Japan and Germany.
In addition, a total of 9,203 articles of scientific research and study were published in major local scientific publications, an increase of 259 over 1999, according to the DGBAS tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGES BEIJING TO SEND APEC SUMMIT INVITE

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao Thursday urged Beijing to invite Taipei to attend the Oct. 20-21 informal leadership conference of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.

President Chen Shui-bian has appointed former Vice President Li Yuan-zu as his representative at the Shanghai leadership conference, but because of Beijing's opposition, Li has been unable to leave for Shanghai.
The foreign ministry held a meeting to discuss the issue Thursday and stressed the need to safeguard the nation's sovereignty and dignity.
Tien said at a press conference that Beijing should commit the obligations of a host country and send an invitation to Taipei as soon as possible.

He criticized Beijing for failing to follow the past APEC practice of dispatching an official to deliver the invitation in person, and expressed Taipei's serious protest over the "unreasonable treatment" accorded Taipei by mainland China.

Earlier that day, ROC Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi said in Shanghai that Li "remains the sole choice of Taipei for the APEC summit." Lin headed the Taiwan mission to the APEC ministerial meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRACTITIONERS PROTEST BEIJING'S SUPPRESSION OF FALUN GONG
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Oct. 18 (CNA) (By Tang Ping-chun and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Several hundred Falun Gong practitioners from Taiwan, Europe and the United States gathered in front of the mainland Chinese embassy in Belgium Thursday to protest Beijing's suppression of the movement.

Huang Chun-mei, a Falun Gong practitioner from Taiwan, said that 120 Taiwan Falun Gong practitioners joined hands with practitioners from Europe and the United States to stage the protest in a bid to bring European Union officials' attention to Beijing's persecution of Falun Gong practitioners and help rescue practitioners persecuted in mainland China.
Fifteen EU heads of state were scheduled to meet Friday in nearby Ghent, Belgium, for an unofficial summit.
Nicolas Schols, a spokesman for Belgian Falun Gong practitioners, said they staged the protest in a bid for support from around the world for their protest.
They also sent a letter to Beijing, urging the authorities there to release Falun Gong practitioner Zhao Ming, presently incarcerated in a labor camp in mainland China.

According to the spokesman, European Parliament members Olivier Durpuis and Lennart Sacredios, as well as Marcel Colla, chairman of the Belgian Parliament's Foreign Relations Committee and Ferredy Willems, a Belgian parliamentarian, will give speeches to express their support to Falun Gong.
The protesters were also scheduled to travel to Ghent Friday to practice Falun Gong in front of the summit venue as part of their protest.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 20, or the fourth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1818: Britain and the United States establish a border along the 49th parallel west of the Great Lakes.
1827: The Battle of Navarino in Greece comes to an end as British, French and Russian fleets annihilate the Turkish and Egyptian fleets.
1890: Sir Richard Burton, British explorer, soldier, diplomat and scholar, dies of a heart attack in Trieste at the age of 69. He discovered Lake Tanganyika and translated the 16-volume "Arabian Nights".
1891: Sir James Chadwick, English physicist, is born. He won the 1935 Nobel Prize in physics for the discovery of the neutron.
1935: Mao Tse-tung and his communist forces end their so-called "Long March" in Yenan in Shensi Province. On Oct. 10, 1934, the main forces of the Chinese communists fled their bases in Kiangsi Province to the northwest, launching the "Long March."
1935: Arthur Henderson, British politician and founder of the Labor Party, dies at the age of 72. He won the 1934 Nobel Peace Prize for his contributions as president of the World Disarmament Conference.
1943: The Republic of China signs a new Sino-Belgium Treaty and a new Sino-Luxembourg Treaty in Chungking.
1943: The United Nations War Crimes Commission is formed.
1944: U.S. Gen. Douglas MacArthur returns to the Philippines with 250,000 troops to fulfill his promise of returning that he made at the time when his forces were forced to retreat in the face of advancing Japanese forces.
1949: Britain recognizes the People's Republic of China under Mao Tse-tung.
1950: The ruling Kuomintang sets up the Taiwan Province Reform Commission with Nieh Wen-ya serving as its chairman.
1951: Governor Wu Kuo-chen of Taiwan presides over a ceremony marking the completion of the Akungtien Reservoir in Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan.
1955: President Chiang Kai-shek permits self-renewal for General Sun Li-jen, former commander-in-chief of the ROC Army, without taking disciplinary action against him after an investigation commission submitted a report on a sedition case.
1957: President Chiang Kai-shek is reelected Tsungtsai (director general) of the Kuomintang.
1962 Some 20,000 Chinese troops launch an offensive on Indian military posts along the Himalayan border.
1964: Herbert C. Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, dies at the age of 90. After the stock market crash of 1929, he was unwilling to finance employment through federal intervention and lost the presidency to Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1932.
1968: Jackie Kennedy, widow of late U.S. President John F. Kennedy, marries multi-millionaire Aristotle Onassis.
1971: Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts at improving relations between communist and non-communist nations.
1973: Queen Elizabeth II officially opens the Sydney Opera House in Australia.
1973: Yang Liang-kung, new president of the Examination Yuan, assumes office, while Liu Chi-hung takes office as vice president.
1975: The Fourth Pan-Pacific Conference on Regional Science opens in Taipei with more than 100 experts from Japan, the United States, Singapore and the ROC attending.
1982: People trample each other as a crowd tries to squeeze through the gates of a stadium to watch a soccer match in Moscow. A total of 340 people are killed.
1999: The ROC government extends its congratulations to Indonesian President-elect Abdurrahman Wahid for his election victory.
2000: Tseng Chu-wei, a professor of finance at National Chengchi University, urges the Democratic Progressive Party government to stop presenting any new policy initiatives in order to revive public confidence and maintain domestic stability.
2000: The U.S. Senate passes by a unanimous vote a House concurrent resolution in support of Taiwan's participation in the United Nations.
Confucius lesson of the day: "Among the means for the regeneration of mankind, those made with noise and show are of the least importance."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY (Oct. 21, 2001)
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 21, or the fifth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1520: Ferdinand Magellan, Portuguese navigator, and his expedition team are blown by storms into a strait that separates South America from Tierra del Fuego and other islands south of the continent and that also connects the southern Atlantic and Pacific oceans. The strait now bears his name.
1727: The Ching court and Russia sign a new border treaty at the trading town of Kiakhta in Outer Mongolia.
1833: Alfred Nobel, Swedish industrialist and chemist who invented dynamite, is born. He founded the Nobel Prize to award to the world's leading scientists, artists and peacemakers.
1879: Thomas Alva Edison, U.S. inventor, successfully tests an electric incandescent lamp with a carbonized filament at his New Jersey laboratory.
1934: Government troops capture Juichin, the Chinese communist's capital in Kiangsi. The main force of rebels is wiped out and the remaining ones flee to the northwest.
1938: Japanese troops finally capture the Chinese city of Canton after months of bombing.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National government, and Madame Chiang arrive in Taiwan for the first time for an inspection tour.
1950: Communist Chinese forces begin their occupation of Tibet.
1952: The first worldwide Overseas Chinese Conference opens in Taipei.
1953: The first Overseas Chinese Day is celebrated in Taipei.
1954: The United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France agree to end the Allied occupation of Germany.
1958: John Foster Dulles, U.S. secretary of state, arrives in Taipei for a visit. He pursued a policy of opposing the USSR largely through economic and military aid to U.S. allies.
1960: Queen Elizabeth II launches the HMS Dreadnought, Britain's first nuclear submarine.
1960: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Mali.
1964: Yang Chuan-kuang, the ROC decathlon champion who won the ROC's first Olympic silver medal in 1960, announces his retirement after winning fifth place at the Tokyo Olympics.
1973: The fifth general meeting of the Federation of Overseas Chinese Associations opens in Taipei with more than 400 delegates from 50 countries and areas participating.
1975: The second naphtha cracking plant of the Chinese Petroleum Corporation begins production.
1976: Ding Mou-shih, director general of the Government Information Office, returns from a week's visit to the Republic of Korea.
1979: Israeli Prime Minister Moshe Dayan resigns over the government's refusal to negotiate with Palestinians.
1979: Willy Brandt is elected chancellor of West Germany.
1987: Ho Ying-chin, a Chinese general who received the formal surrender of Japanese forces in China from Gen. Okamura in Nanking on Sept. 9, 1945, dies at the age of 97.
1994: The United States and North Korea sign a landmark deal under which Pyongyang is to freeze and then dismantle its nuclear program.
1999: Far East Transport Corp. begins flight services between Taipei and Kota Kinabala in Malaysia.
2000: Chinese Taipei's Chiang Chih-chung breaks the world record in men's Class 12 javelin with a throw of 57.228 meters to capture Taiwan's first gold medal at the Sydney Paralympics.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In another place in the Book of Song it is said, `His virtue is light as hair.' Still a hair is something material. `The workings of Almighty God have neither sound nor smell.' There is nothing higher than that."
