DOC.HEADLINE: OCAC TO HOLD INVESTMENT SEMINAR IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: The Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) is to hold an investment seminar for overseas high-tech entrepreneurs of Chinese descent in mid-November, OCAC sources said Saturday.

The seminar is part of a bid to introduce Taiwan's investment environment to overseas Chinese entrepreneurs and encourage them to invest in Taiwan or establish strategic partnerships with domestic enterprises, according to the officials.
Twenty-seven overseas Chinese high-tech entrepreneurs in the fields of biotechnology, medical technology, venture capital and semiconductors are expected to come to Taiwan to attend the seminar.

The seminar, jointly organized by OCAC, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Ministry of Finance and the Cabinet-level National Science Council, is scheduled to be held Nov. 13-14 at the Taipei International Conference Center.
Local and overseas Chinese entrepreneurs attending the seminar will exchange views on business operations at a roundtable forum presided over by Vice President Annette Lu.
After the forum, they are expected to call on President Chen Shui-bian.

OCAC will also arrange for the entrepreneurs to visit the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park and the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. to give them a better understanding of Taiwan's investment climate, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET VOICES SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN'S APEC MINISTERIAL DELEGATION

TEXT.P: The Cabinet announced Saturday that it has extended the government's regards to Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi for his delegation's hard work in the just-concluded Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum ministerial meetings.

Lin's delegation, which includes Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Chen Po-chih and other Republic of China economic officials, was slated to return from Shanghai to Taipei Saturday.

On behalf of Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Cabinet Secretary-General Chiou I-jen had cabled Lin's delegation the previous day to express the government's moral support, despite some outside criticism of the delegation's performance in the face of Beijing's repeated attempts to put down Taiwan.

Although Taiwan was unable to participate in the ongoing APEC informal leadership summit because of Beijing's refusal to accept a former ROC vice president who had been selected to attend in place of ROC President Chen Shui-bian, Lin's delegation managed to contribute in various ways to the APEC mechanism before leaving Shanghai, an official said.
The official added that the delegation has lodged a letter of protest to Beijing -- the host of this year's APEC summit -- while copies were delivered to the other 19 APEC members.

Lin has conveyed to the United States Taiwan's willingness to cooperate with America's anti-terrorist operations despite being barred from attending a breakfast meeting Thursday for APEC members to discuss the subject.

He has also suggested to his mainland Chinese counterpart that a bilateral economic and trade advisory channel can be established under the World Trade Organization (WTO) framework in order to resolve bilateral economic and trade issues.

Meanwhile, his delegation has helped promote the process of further liberalization of trade and investment in the Asia Pacific region and has voiced support for starting a new round of negotiations at the fourth ministerial meeting of the WTO.
It has also shared Taiwan's successful experience in developing small- and medium-sized businesses with other APEC members, including Brunei, New Zealand, Singapore and Thailand.

APEC comprises Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, mainland China, South Korea, the United States, the Philippines, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, Russia, Singapore, Thailand, Taiwan and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF MAINLAND CHINESE VISITING TAIWAN ON THE RISE

TEXT.P: The number of mainland Chinese citizens visiting or departing Taiwan has increased remarkably this year, while the number of Taiwan residents traveling abroad has declined, sources from the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) reported Saturday.

Mainland Chinese citizens made 105,405 visits to Taiwan in the first nine months of this year, up 16.53 percent from the same period of last year, according to tallies compiled by the National Police Administration (NPA) under the MOI.

During the first nine months, 89,782 mainland citizens departed Taiwan, marking a whopping increase of 28.03 percent over the corresponding period of the previous year, according to the NPA statistics.

Meanwhile, residents from Taiwan proper and the offshore Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu areas made 5.554 million entries during the nine-month period, while making 5.626 million exits, down 0.98 percent and 1.31 percent, respectively, the NPA tallies show.
During the same period, foreign nationals made 1.771 million visits to Taiwan, up 5.43 percent, while 1.774 million exited Taiwan, up 8.87 percent.

According to the chart showing entries to Taiwan in the Jan.-Sept. period this year, about 70 percent were Taiwan citizens, roughly 23 percent were foreign nationals and 1.37 percent were mainland Chinese.
A similar chart showing departures from Taiwan in the Jan.-Sept. period indicates that 72.62 were Taiwan citizens, 22.90 percent were foreign nationals and 1.16 percent were mainland Chinese.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY EXERCISE `CHEN TUNG 90' TO BE LAUNCHED LATE OCTOBER

TEXT.P: An annual military exercise coded "Chen Tung 90" will be launched Oct. 22-26 in the eastern Taiwan counties of Hualien and Taitung, sources with the Hualien-Taitung Defense Command said Saturday.
The purpose of the exercise is to strengthen the command ability of officers at all levels, promote the quality of staff officers and fortify soldiers' combat capability, according to the sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO COMPROMISE ON CROSS-STRAIT TRADE POLICY: ROC PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that no incidents will be allowed to compromise Taiwan's business and trade policy toward mainland China, which was reshaped during the Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) held late August.

Chen reassured the nation that all the conclusions reached at the EDAC, including business and trade policy toward mainland China, will be carried out one after another without interruption by any incident across the Taiwan Strait, such as Taiwan's forced absence from the Oct. 20-21 Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) leadership summit meeting in Shanghai.
The president made the remarks during a speech to a gala marking the 45th founding anniversary of TECO Electric and Machinery Co. in Taipei.

Chen said the government is currently preparing for Taiwan's accession into the World Trade Organization (WTO) in the hope that accession will help bolster the country's strength while expanding its arena of international activities.

Meanwhile, Chen stressed, the administration will also strive to carry out the EDAC conclusions and implement a new list of economic development guidelines to accelerate the upgrading of Taiwan's industrial structure, improve the investment climate and sharpen the domestic business and industrial sector's international competitiveness.
Chen also gave a thumbs-up to TECO's performance during its long-term presence in Taiwan's electrical and machinery manufacturing development.

With its persistence and entrepreneurship, TECO has become a household name in Taiwan over the past several decades, Chen said, adding that because the electrical motors produced by TECO are so commendable, the word "TECO" is now tantamount in Taiwan to "motor."
Chen also exhorted TECO's management and workforce to "plow deeper in Taiwan while seeding globally" and turn the company into Taiwan's "motor" of economic progress.

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC BOYCOTT `INEVITABLE:' DPP CHAIR

TEXT.P: Given mainland China's recalcitrant and bullying mentality, Taiwan's absence from this year's informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum was "inevitable," a ruling party heavyweight said Saturday.

Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh was commenting on the Republic of China government's announcement Friday that in protest over Beijing's refusal to send an official invitation to Taiwan, the country would not be represented in the Oct. 20-21 APEC summit meeting in Shanghai.

"It was a forced choice to protect our national dignity," Hsieh said, adding he is convinced that no matter which domestic political party was in power, its administration would certainly make a similar choice.
Hsieh said that although it is important for Taiwan to join in international activities, national dignity and sovereignty should not be disparaged.

In the first place, Hsieh said, Beijing broke the established APEC protocol of sending a special envoy to Taipei to deliver a formal invitation to President Chen Shui-bian to the Shanghai summit meeting. Instead, it simply faxed an unsigned notice without specifying the name of the recipient.
Even after Chen designated former Vice President Li Yuan-zu to attend the annual APEC summit in his stead, Beijing still declined to issue an official invitation.
"Against this backdrop, could we send a delegation to the Shanghai meeting at the expense of our national dignity?" Hsieh asked.
He reminded mainland Chinese leaders that if they opt to "completely swallow" Taiwan, such a strategy will lead nowhere.

Hsieh, who concurrently serves as mayor of Kaohsiung, Taiwan's second-largest city after Taipei, further urged the mainland leaders to forsake their "zero-sum" game strategy and treat Taiwan with respect so as to create a win-win scenario for both sides.
Hsieh also warned that Beijing's sabotage of Taiwan's participation in the 2001 APEC summit will only increase the feelings of resentment and result in a negative impact on cross-strait relations.
Meanwhile, Hsieh called on the people of Taiwan to stand united behind the government in support of its decision to safeguard national dignity.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DHARMA MASTER: U.S. WAGING `MERCIFUL WAR'
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 19 (CNA) (By David Wang, Eric C.Y. Tseng and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's visiting Dharma Master Hsing Yun claimed Friday that the United States is waging a "merciful war" targeting terrorists, not Muslims, because the war is being carried out even as relief supplies are being airdropped over Afghanistan.

Hsing Yun, who heads the renowned Fokuangshan monastery in Taiwan, made the remarks at a news conference before leading 30 of his followers in a blessing and cleansing ritual at the site of the former World Trade Center.
At the conference, he expressed his opinion that the U.S.-led war is "not a war of hatred." The United States, he said, is using "mercy" and "wisdom" to subjugate the enemy.
He also said that while he does not agree with war, the current conflict is a "necessary" conflict "for peace."
Hsing Yun also urged the American public not to panic in the face of reported cases of anthrax attacks, adding that he is confident in the survival of mankind.

On another occasion in midtown Manhattan later in the evening, Hsing Yun urged the various religions, economies and nations of the world to respect and accept each other and to seek out other ways of resolving differences other than through war.
He said that wealth cannot be measured merely in material or monetary terms. Security, health and wisdom are other kinds of wealth, he added.
During his visit, Hsing Yun donated US$200,000 to the American Red Cross on behalf of Fokuangshan for distribution to the families of the victims in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on America.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ATTENDS 45TH FOUNDING ANNIVERSARY OF LOCAL ELECTRICAL FIRM

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung attended a celebration Saturday of the 45th founding anniversary of the Teco Electric and Machinery Co., Ltd.
In a speech on the occasion, Chang said that unceasing renovation, together with research and development, are the momentum behind the operation of any enterprise.

He lauded the Teco management and workers for their efforts to make the company grow, from its early days as a home appliance supplier to its present position as an electronics and information products manufacturer.

Faced with the economic slowdown and rising unemployment, Chang encouraged Teco employees to keep in mind continuing renovation and R&D in mind to raise the added value of products and achieve the goal of "everlasting business operation."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REAFFIRMS `NO CHANGE' IN CROSS-STRAIT TRADE POLICY

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Saturday that although Taiwan is dismayed by Beijing's rudeness in barring its envoy at the current Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit, it will not change its cross-Taiwan Strait trade policy.

Chang made the remarks while attending a ceremony to mark the 45th founding anniversary of TECO Electric and Machinery Co., one of Taiwan's largest electric appliances and electronics manufacturing groups.

Chang said he feels regret over mainland China's failure to abide by the APEC protocol of sending a special envoy to deliver an official invitation to President Chen Shui-bian to the regional economic forum's Oct. 20-21 informal leadership meeting in Shanghai.

In order to safeguard the Republic of China's national dignity and status, Chang said the ROC government was forced to call off its plan to send a delegation to the meeting in protest over Beijing's discrimination.

Nevertheless, Chang said the incident will not dampen the government's preparations for easing restrictions on mainland China-bound investment, expanding the functions of the offshore cross-strait transshipping center or the opening of direct cross-strait trade, mail and transportation links.

Noting that "active opening, effective management" is the government's basic policy toward commercial and civilian exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, Chang said the government will not back off from this stance simply because of any single incident.
Speaking on the same occasion, TECO Chairman Huang Mao-hsiung said mainland China's suppression of Taiwan's participation in APEC activities is very regrettable.

"Perhaps cross-strait economic exchanges will be affected by the latest APEC disputes. In the long run, I think cross-strait trade ties will continue to move ahead and will not suffer any serious setback," Huang said optimistically, adding that he hopes the two sides will continue to strengthen dialogue and communication.

In his view, Huang said, cross-strait political disputes should not overly hinder bilateral commercial exchanges for the sake of mutual benefits. Like many other Taiwan companies, he went on, TECO has set up production facilities on the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS MOST BONE FRACTURES IN ASIA: OSTEOPOROSIS EXPERT

TEXT.P: Bone fractures are more prevalent in Taiwan than anywhere else in Asia because of local people's aversion to exercise and the sun, according to the president of the Republic of China Osteoporosis Association.

Yang Tsai-hsing said Saturday at a seminar on osteoporosis on World Osteoporosis Day that according to a study conducted by National Taiwan University, as many as one out of every 200 people in Taiwan has had a bone fracture.

Most of the victims are senior citizens, with only a small percentage being younger people who sustain fractures through accidents, he said, adding that the death rate among senior citizens a year after bone fracture is as high as 15 percent.

Yang said that drinking milk and taking calcium supplements can be helpful in making bones stronger for young people, and that people older than 35 or women after menopause should also take an appropriate amount of calcium supplement if they are unable to achieve a balanced diet.
However, he continued, bone tissue that is lost in old age cannot be replaced through calcium pills or milk. Only prescription drugs can truly control the loss of bone tissue, he added.
Osteoporosis, a hormonal condition also known as brittle bone disease, is most common among post-menopausal women.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSSEXUAL ALLOWED TO BECOME ADOPTIVE PARENT

TEXT.P: After five months of waiting and struggling, a local transsexual woman was allowed Friday by the Chiayi District Court to become an adoptive parent to a six-month-old baby boy, marking a precedent in Taiwan legal history.

Gorgeous Chang Chia-ling, also known as "Chung Ling," was allowed to adopt the baby, whose parents have been unable to look after him since birth, on the grounds that she has sufficient family support to raise the child, according to sources from the Chiayi District Court.

Chang filed a request with the Chiayi District Court in May to adopt the baby, but the court did not respond favorably for the first several months, as court officials doubted her ability to take care of a child as she is a "show girl" with what the officials thought is an "odd" sexual history.
Chang makes her living as a drag show actress in southern Taiwan.
At an Aug. 24 hearing, the judges said they would make a final decision only after Chang could provide more background information on her adoption agreement.

After reviewing all relevant papers and carrying out fact-finding visits to the child's biological mother's home, as well as to Chang's home, the judges gave the green light Friday to Chang's adoption petition.
In addition, the judges said, there is no mention in the Republic of China's Civil Codes whether or not a transsexual can become an adoptive parent.

The child's birth mother is currently serving a jail sentence for drug abuse, while the father has been declared "unknown." The child had been looked after by his grandfather since the mother went to prison.

Chang is the neighbor of the child's grandfather and she developed a special fondness for the child as soon as she saw him. She then asked to take care of the child and the child's grandfather happily agreed.
Chang was thrilled by the judges final approval for the adoption.
"Now I'm the baby's mother and I am going to name him Chang Tah-wen," she said shortly after hearing of the court's decision.
She noted that ever since she was a child, she believed herself to be a female in a male's body and had always liked to wear his mother's dresses and play with dolls.
At the age of 24 after completing military conscription, Chang went to Thailand to receive a sex change operation at a cost of NT$240,000.
Since than, she has lived happily, gaining local fame in the drag show business and a better-than-average living.
"A child like this will make my life fuller and more complete," she noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORT NAMES NO. 1 SECURITY SOFTWARE PROVIDER

TEXT.P: An International Data Corporation (IDC) research report ranks Computer Associates International, Inc. (CA) as the world's leading provider of authentication, authorization and administration (3A) security software, with a 15.5 percent market share worldwide.
This percentage makes CA the number one worldwide 3A security vendor by a wide margin.

This reaffirms CA's continued leadership in the security marketplace, CA said in a press release Friday. Earlier this year, another IDC report, titled Worldwide Internet Security Software Market Forecast and Analysis, 2001-2005, ranked CA as the world's leading provider of Internet security software for the second year in a row.

This latest report, titled Worldside Security 3As Software Market Forecast and Analysis, 2001-2005, indicates that the 3A market remains a fast-growing market, with an expected growth of 27 percent over the next five years. It is expected to reach $9.4 billion by 2005.

According to IDC, security 3A software is made up of administration, authorization and authentication, which is used to administer security on computer systems or in an enterprise and includes the processes of defining, creating, changing, deleting and auditing users. CA provides superior 3A solutions within its eTrust product family, including: eTrust PKI, eTrust SSO, eTrust CA-ACF2, eTrust CA-Top Secret, eTrust Admin, eTrust Access Control, and eTrust Intrusion Detection.
IDC is recognized as one of the marker leaders in providing research and analysis to eBusiness executives, IT professionals, IT suppliers, and services suppliers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LASHES OUT AT MAINLAND CHINA FROM ABROAD

TEXT.P: Taiwanese officials in Canada kicked off a letter-to-the-editors campaign Friday after host China violated APEC protocol by neglecting to send an envoy to deliver Taiwan's invitation to the forum's informal leaders' meeting.

"In calculating to obstruct Taiwan's participation in the meeting, the People's Republic of China has shown its true face to the world and has neglected its responsibility as APEC's host country," said a letter from the Taiwan representative office in Canada to the Ottawa Citizen newspaper.

The letter was signed by Kuan Ching-cheng, director of the Information Division of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office, Canada. It also accused Beijing of rejecting a Taiwanese presidential representative nominated to attend the APEC meeting in Shanghai.

"The PRC acts have made it impossible for Taiwan to attend the meeting," Kuan claimed. He stressed that Taiwan, as an equal member of APEC, has every right to participate and be accorded the same respect and dignity as any other contributing nation.

"The exclusion of Taiwan by mainland China shows its disregard for Taiwan's efforts and concerns for peace and security in the Asia Pacific region, of which Canada is an important member," he pointed out.
In Shanghai, as the main topic for discussion is "cooperation against terrorism," it is important for all nations to make their contributions, Kuan said.

Taiwan will not be discouraged from its role in APEC, he said, adding that Taiwan will support any measures adopted at the meeting, in the knowledge that only cooperation will see the end to terrorism and any unprovoked use or threat of use of force.
In the interests of peace, cooperation and economic prosperity, Kuan urged mainland China to put aside its efforts to isolate Taiwan and obstruct its participation in international activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. LAMENTS TAIWAN'S ABSENCE FROM APEC LEADER'S SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Praising Taiwan for the role it has played in the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, the United States said Friday that Taiwan's absence from the group's leaders' meeting this year "will be a loss for all participants."

The State Department expressed disappointment that Taiwan was unable to attend the leaders' meeting, which opens Saturday in Shanghai, but said that Washington does not see this "as a precedent for future APEC meetings."
It also said that the United States "expects Taiwan will attend next year's leaders' meeting," which will be held in Mexico.
The statement came after Beijing failed to respond to Taiwan's proposal to send former Vice President Li Yuan-zu as its representative to the informal gathering of heads of state or government.
Since the first leaders' meeting was held in 1993, Taiwan has been the only member of the now 21-member organization not represented by its political leader, thanks to objections from Beijing.

In the statement read to reporters, the State Department also expressed Washington's gratitude for the way ROC President Chen Shui-bian has handled the incident and for his support of the U.S.-led campaign against terrorism.

"We appreciate President Chen's statement of support of the global counter-terrorism program and his affirmation of Taiwan's willingness to implement the decisions that APEC leaders will reach October 21," said the State Department.
It said that the United States has supported Taiwan's "membership and valued participation in APEC" since the island joined the organization in 1992.

Without commenting specifically on Taiwan's choice or its rejection by Beijing, the State Department said that the United States has "supported, as in the past, Taiwan's participation in APEC meetings at appropriately senior levels."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE CARS TO BE ALLOWED ACCESS TO L.A. INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Oct. 19 (CNA) (By Lawrence Chu and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Private cars can pick up or unload airline passengers at Los Angeles International Airport terminals as from Saturday, the Airport Authority said Friday. "Starting 5 a.m. tomorrow," an Airport Authority spokesman said, "private cars will be allowed to stop near terminal entrances to pick up or unload passengers."
The multifloor car parks near the terminals are also open to private cars, the spokesman said.

The Airport Authority has banned all private cars from driving near the terminal entrances since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center in New York and the Pentagon to prevent car bomb assaults. Two temporary parking lots set up miles away from the airport terminals have accommodated private cars, whose riders are ferried to and back from the terminals through free shuttle bus service.
Car drivers are not allowed to park on the shoulders of the driveway to load or unload baggage, the spokesman said. Nor can they pick up or unload passengers there.
Police will continue spot-checking vehicles in and out of the airport to prevent terrorist sabotage, the sokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI NOT TO BACKPEDAL ON PLANNED CROSS-STRAIT TRADE OPENING

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi said Saturday that Taiwan will not backpedal on its planned trade liberalization with mainland China despite what happened at Shanghai.

Lin told a news conference in Taipei after his return from Shanghai that Taiwan would continue liberalizing trade with mainland China "according to schedule." He attended this year's ministerial meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum as Taiwan's chief delegate.

Taipei's decision to boycott the informal APEC leadership meeting will not curtail its plan to ease restrictions under the existing "no haste, be patient" policy on investment in mainland China, Lin said.

Noting that the decision to ease such investment restrictions was one of the conclusions reached at the high-profile Economic Development Advisory Conference (ADEC) in late August, Lin said the demarche is on course in spite of Taiwan's boycott of the Oct. 20-21 APEC summit in protest against Beijing's breach of the forum's well-established protocol.

"We must conduct cross-strait relations with vision and should not be daunted by any setback in carrying out our basic economic development policy of 'developing Taiwan with global perspective,'" Lin said.
Lin arrived in Shanghai Oct. 15 at the head of the Republic of China delegation to the Oct. 17-18 APEC ministerial meeting.

During a news conference Thursday, mainland Chinese Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan rudely brushed aside Lin's complaint that Chinese Taipei, the ROC's official designation in APEC, had not received the formal invitation from the host country to attend the leadership meeting in Shanghai.
Tang's rudeness, Lin said, "manifestly exposed the true nature of Beijing's policy" toward Taiwan.

As Taipei and Beijing were still negotiating Taiwan's "representation" issue, Lin said, he had to refrain from making any "strong" protest lest it should abort the negotiations. He did not file any verbal protest with Tang at the press meeting.

"We were determined not to give up hopes until the last minute as we believed that former Vice President Li Yuan-zu was the best stand-in to represent President Chen Shui-bian at the APEC summit," Lin pointed out.

Taipei announced its decision not to attend the Shanghai summit Friday morning. "As soon as we had learned of the decision," Lin said, "we lodged a strong protest with the mainland Chinese authorities over their failure to observe the APEC convention to extend Li an official invitation. We have also circulated our letter of protest among the 19 other APEC members."

Later on Friday, Lin said, he followed his prearranged schedule to visit Taiwan companies in Suzhou and Kushan, both near Shanghai. Taiwan investors there, he added, are generally well aware of cultural and political differences between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The cross-strait wrangling over Taiwan's representation at the APEC summit did not hamper the Taipei delegation's dialogue with all other APEC member states to improve bilatera and multilateral trade and economic cooperation, Lin added.
Moreover, Lin said, he has received assurances of their support for Taiwan's early accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO), a Geneva-based world trade regulatory body.
"A joint statement issued at the end of the ministerial meeting also reaffirmed the forum's full support for Taiwan's and mainland China's WTO accession," Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC LEADERS URGED TO JOINTLY CONDEMN BEIJING'S RUDENESS
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Oct. 20 (CNA) (By Peng Si-chou and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian Saturday urged the member economies of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to jointly condemn China's discrimination against Taiwan at the ongoing APEC meeting.

In a letter to the other APEC leaders, Chen expressed his "profound disappointment and great rage of not being invited by the People's Republic of China, the host economy, to attend this very important meeting."

Citing a 1991 APEC memorandum of understanding on Taiwan's accession to the organization and past practices, China had rejected Taiwan's proposal to have it represented by Li Yuan-zu, former vice president, at the informal leadership meeting of the 21-member trade bloc on the grounds that Li has no economic background. The summit began in Shanghai on Saturday.
Taiwan announced its withdrawal from the summit on Friday and put its blame on China for its "irrational" obstruction of Taiwan's participation in the gathering and other international events.
Taiwan, which joined APEC in 1992, had since 1993 sent top economic affairs officials, in stead of its president, to attend the annual gathering of heads of state or government of APEC members.

Chen said that as a member of APEC, Taiwan has in the past 10 years fully supported and taken part in the APEC-sponsored programs, including the liberalization of trade and investment as well as economic and technical cooperation.

He added that Taiwan had been looking forward to cooperating closely with all other members at the Shanghai meeting to fight terrorism and work out ways for a speedy recovery of the sluggish global economy.
However, Chen said, Taiwan was unable to attend this year's gathering due to China's violation of the APEC practices by not sending an envoy to Taipei to deliver the invitation to the meeting.

"China's intentional discrimination against Taiwan's participation in APEC has severely hurt APEC's spirit of cooperation," Chen said in the letter circulated by Taipei's delegates before they departed for home.

Taiwan's Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi and Council of Economic Planning and Development Chairman Chen Po-chih, who attended the pre-summit ministerial meeting, returned to Taipei earlier in the day, leaving Taiwan unrepresented at the summit for the first time.
"I therefore call on the member economies to jointly condemn China's behavior and prevent such an occurrence from happening again," Chen said.

In spite of its absence in the summit this year, Chen said, Taiwan is more than willing to throw its full support behind the U.S.-led anti-terrorism campaign and, within the APEC framework, increase cooperation with all other members in the prevention of money laundry and tax evasion.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEC. 1 ELECTIONS CRITICAL TO POLITICAL REFORM: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that the upcoming parliamentary elections are the most critical part of Taiwan's political reform.
The elections are scheduled for December 1. Top administrative officials of Taiwan's 21 counties and cities will be elected on the same day.

Chen spoke on what he called the second phase political reform in Taiwan at a national congress of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) here. "The elections," he pointed out, "are vitally important to our ongoing political reform."

Lee Teng-hui completed Taiwan's first phase political reform by getting himself popularly elected president. The political reform is now in its second stage following Chen's election as president on March 18 last year.
Since his inauguration on May 20, Chen said he has spared no efforts to minimize the "transitional syndrome" or the impact of the end of the Kuomintang's 55-year one-party rule.
"Thanks to our concerted efforts, there has been no upheaval or panic in society over the past one and half years," Chen said.

As the DPP controls barely one-third of the seats of the Legislative Yuan, Chen said, his administration has met boycott after boycott in the opposition-dominated legislature nearly every time it presented bills on reform or policy initiatives.
As a result, Chen said, his administration has so far failed to live up to Taiwan's "public expectations."
To facilitate the administration's sweeping reform programs, Chen said, he hopes that the DPP can emerge as the largest party in the new legislature.

"If the DPP wins the largest number of legislative seats, it will be able to form a majority ruling alliance and a stable coalition government to carry out various reform programs and rev up our sluggish economy," Chen pointed out.
The DPP success or failure in the year-end legislative elections is crucial to Taiwan's continuing political reform, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP DISCARDS 'NO HASTE, BE PATIENT' POLICY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Saturday that the "no haste, be patient" policy on investment in the mainland is outdated and vowed to replace it with a more aggressive approach.

In a resolution passed at its national congress held in the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung, the DPP vowed to adopt an "active opening and efficient management" strategy with regard to Taiwan's economic development in the face of the new century.
The "no haste, be patient" policy, adopted by the previous Kuomintang-led administration, bans any single Taiwan investment case worth more than NT$50 million (about US$1.44 million) on the mainland.
The party said in the resolution that now is a turning point for Taiwan to readjust its economic structure since a new world economic order is in the making.
"Taiwan must accelerate its economic reforms in the face of the formation of new economic blocs and its imminent entry to the World Trade Organization (WTO)," it said.
Taiwan, which applied to join the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), the predecessor of the WTO, in 1991, is expected to become a full WTO member at the beginning of next year.
The resolution puts its emphases on knowledge-based economy, economic liberation, principle of social justice and improved government efficiency.
With the principle of "Taiwan first" and national security ensured, the DPP said it hopes that the new approach will give a shot in the arm of Taiwan, enabling it to create another economic miracle.
Delegates to the congress also resolved to upgrade the status of any resolution approved by party congress to "an equivalent of policy guidelines."

DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh, while responding to questions raised by the press after the congress, denied that the move to heighten the status of resolutions is a veil attempt to allow the "Resolution on the Future of Taiwan" adopted in May, 1999 to take precedence of its "Policy Guideline on the Independence of Taiwan" of 1991 which has since caused controversy among the general public.
Hsieh said that 1999 resolution aims to give a new interpretation to the 1991 guidelines and that the DPP's stance on safeguarding the sovereignty of Taiwan will not change.

On which one of the two important documents DPP members should follow, Hsieh, a lawyer-turned politician, said that "it's natural for the new law (the 1999 resolution) to overtake the old one (the 1991 policy guidelines)."

The 1991 Policy Guidelines on the Independence of Taiwan declares clearly that the DPP aims to establish a Taiwan republic with an independent sovereignty, while the 1999 "Resolution on the Future of Taiwan" advocates that Taiwan is an independent state and that any change in its status quo should be made possible only by means of a referendum of all the people of the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The China Times:
DPP congress votes to soft party's stickiness to Taiwan independence.
The United Daily News:
US: Taiwan's absence from the APEC summit is a "loss for all participants."
The Liberty Times:
US: Taiwan's absence from APEC summit should not be a precedent.
The Taiwan Daily:
President Chen urges APEC members to condemn Beijing's snub to Taipei by denying it invitation to summit.
The Central Daily News:
US special forces launch ground attacks in Afghanistan.
The China Post:
U.S. ground troops strike, chopper crash claims two.
The Taiwan News:
China twisted Taiwan's rights, says Lin.
The Taipei Times:
Chen urges APEC to condemn China.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH IS FIRM ON COMMITMENT TO TAIWAN: US SPECIALIST
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Oct. 20 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Although U.S. President George W. Bush didn't dwell on the issue of Taiwan in his talks with Chinese leader Jiang Zemin Thursday in Shanghai, he and his administration is firm on the U.S. commitment to Taiwan's security, according to a U.S specialist on Chinese affairs.

Douglas Paal, president of the Asia Pacific Policy Center in Washington D.C., told a local television station that Bush didn't discuss the issue of Taiwan at length with Jiang because the Shanghai summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum is not the appropriate place or time to discuss the matter, but Bush's concern for Taiwan's security is strong none the less.

Paal, who is reported to be a candidate considered by President Bush to head the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan, said that Bush has tried to coerce Beijing to mend its way by getting tough with it since he took office eight months ago, and the policy has thus far worked.

Taiwan was afraid that the United States might back away from its commitment to Taiwan's security during discussions with the Chinese leadership while the United States tried to drum up support for its anti-terrorist campaign.
Bush said earlier this year that his administration will "do whatever it takes" to defend Taiwan against possible attacks from Beijing.

In a joint news conference after their talks in Shanghai, Bush said his government wanted to develop constructive ties with Beijing, while Jiang urged Washington to abide by the three communiques between the two sides in shaping its policy toward Beijing, and handle its tie with Taiwan appropriately.
Paal said mainland China has operated many intelligence gathering stations along its border with Afghan and may possess information valuable to Washington's campaign against terrorism in Afghanistan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL SECRETARY-GENERAL SAYS CHEN WILL LEAD THE NATION AHEAD

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will bring the country to a new level during his four-year term, so long as the people rally behind the government, Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said Sunday.
Yu made the remarks while attending the inauguration of the campaign headquarters of Perng Shaw-jin of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for Taoyuan magistrate in the year-end election.

Yu said that after President Chen assumed the presidency in May 2000, he has actively promoted improving the conscience of politics and was instrumental in withdrawing political influence from the military, made headway against "black gold," and introduced financial reforms -- all of which will strengthen the political and economic fundamentals of the nation.

He, who served as Ilan county magistrate for two terms, also cited his own experience in Ilan County as an example, saying that the eastern county, under the helm of the DPP for the past two decades, has won recognition from all sides, adding that it is too soon to see the full fruits of Chen's work as the president has only been in office 17 months.

Saying the government can accept criticism from the opposition with humility, Yu also pointed out that the world economic slowdown is a factor that must be considered when judging the performance of the president.

In addition, the president also inherited some of the deficiencies from the previous administration, such as overdue loans of more than NT$900 billion from financial institutions, and the fact that the legislature has not undergone the same reshuffle as the political changeover of the new government, he said, so that the new government has faced an uphill battle in implementing many of his policies.

Yu also recommended Perng, saying that with his background as a prosecutor and legislator, he has the vision, ideals as well as rich experience, which he said would contribute to the building of Taoyuan County.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WINS FOUR PRIZES AT ASIA PACIFIC FILM FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan won four awards at the 46th Asia Pacific Film Festival which concluded in Jakarta Saturday night.

"What Time is It There?" a feature film by Taiwan director Tsai Ming-liang, won the honors of best picture and best director, and Lu Yi-ching, an actress in the film, was awarded the prize for best supporting actress.
Meanwhile, another Taiwan feature film, "Fleeing by Night," was awarded the prize for best music.

Taiwan, which had entered three features and two documentaries in the contest, is one of three countries which took away four awards at the festival. The other two countries are Indonesia and South Korea.

The five-day festival opened under the shadow of protests by Muslims against the U.S. strikes against Afghanistan. Many delegations withdrew from the festival at the last minute out of security concerns.
The Taiwan delegation will leave Jakarta for Taipei Sunday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-DPP CHAIRMAN URGES SUPPORT FOR GOVERNMENT AFTER APEC SUMMIT ROW

TEXT.P: People in Taiwan should rally behind the government following Taiwan's absence from the weekend summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Shanghai, a senior political figure said Sunday.

Shih Ming-teh, former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party who has already quit the party, called on the people to side with the government and President Chen Shui-bian following the incident.
Stressing that "foreign and national defensive affairs are different from civic domestic affairs," Shih said all the people should support the government's handling of issues on these two fronts.

The Taiwan delegation for the APEC ministerial meetings, led by Council for Economic Planing and Development Chairman Chen Po-chih and Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi returned to Taipei Saturday night after Beijing rejected Taipei's proposal to send former Vice President Li Yuan-zu as Chen's representative at the APEC summit meeting Saturday and Sunday.

President Chen and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs may have misjudged the situation and made an improper decision, Shih said, but added that local political figures should only criticize after all the facts are presented.
Shih made the remarks during a campaign rally for a candidate of the People First Party in the December 1 legislative election.

The former DPP chairman said that he has criticized the performance of President Chen, but he emphasized that citizens of the Republic of China should have a clear concept about the APEC summit row, which in fact is a foreign policy issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S MATSU BELIEVERS TO ATTEND MATSU CULTURAL FESTIVAL IN MACAU
DOC.DATELINE: Macau, Oct. 21 (CNA) (By Jen Chung-hung and Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: More than 700 Taiwan followers of Matsu, the goddess of the sea, will attend the first Matsu Cultural Festival in Macau Oct. 24-26.

A nine-member group from Chenlan Temple in Tachia in central Taiwan led by Tung Chen-hsiung, executive director of the Board of Trustees of the temple, arrived in Macau Saturday to make preparations for the festival to be sponsored by Macau authorities.
In addition to Tachia's Chenlan Temple, followers from the Taiwan Matsu Association will also send a large delegation to the festival.
Taiwan Matsu believers will attend the festival's opening ceremony and participate in a ritual ceremony to demonstrate traditional Matsu worship in Taiwan.
This Matsu cultural activity will undoubtedly strengthen cultural exchanges between the people of Taiwan and the former-Portuguese colony of Macau, Tung said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN LION AIR TO OPEN TAIPEI-SEOUL, TAIPEI-BALI SERVICE

TEXT.P: Jakarta-based Lion Air is scheduled to open Taipei-Seoul and Taipei-Bali non-stop air services beginning Nov. 6, it was reported Sunday.
Taipei-based Far East Air Transport Corp. will serve as a general agent for Lion Air in Taiwan.
A Far East official said that Lion Air will use Airbus 310s to operate the Taipei-Seoul and the Taipei-Bali route on Tuesdays, Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays weekly.
The official also said that Far East will offer a variety of tourist packages to lure local travelers.
Lion Air was formally inaugurated a year ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT MUST BE OPEN TO MAINLAND MARKETS INVESTMENT: OPPOSITION

TEXT.P: If the government wants to stimulate the sluggish economy, it should not exclude mainland markets from its global perspective, officials from the opposition New Party said Sunday.

Legislator Lai Shyi-bao, Taipei City Councilman Fei Hung-tai and Pacific Broadband CEO Joanna Lei made the remarks at a seminar to discuss Taiwan's investment environment in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States.

Lai noted that Taiwan's annual increase of industrial production was negative 7.1 percent in the first eight months this year; annual increase in the manufacturing industry was a negative 7.9 percent during the period, showing Taiwan's domestic industry is in bad shape. In addition, both private investment and export orders showed negative growth.

Lai suggested that the government vigorously implement the consensus reached in the Economic Development Advisory Conference in August, saying that among the 322 agreements reached during the conference, the government has put less than 10 percent of them into place.

In addition, Lai said Taiwan and the mainland should complement each other and establish a mechanism of division of labor. Taiwan should not exclude mainland China markets from its global perspective, Lai said.

Lei, who will represent the New Party in the year-end legislative election, said the government should not stop businesses from going to the mainland, but should bail out infrastructure and industries that employ a large number of workers. It should also keep the root of such industries as personal computer industry in Taiwan.

Taipei City Councilman Fei noted that President Chen Shui-bian had said that only with a stable cross-strait relationship and a solid political and economic situation could it is possible to engage in domestic reforms and develop the economy, adding that the president should maintain good cross-strait relations and not continue to strain the relationship.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHIEF CRITICIZES DPP FOR DEMEANING VOTERS BY SMEARING KMT

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan criticized the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Sunday for looking down on voters by mimicking Chinese Communist tricks in smearing the opposition parties.

While stumping for party candidates in Chiayi City, KMT Lien said the DPP is belittling the public if it thinks that lambasting the opposition with communist jargon will win over the public in the year-end elections.

Lien was referring to DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh's criticism of the KMT the previous day when he said that the opposition is the country's "anti-reaction forces and public enemy," a term commonly used by the Chinese Communists in the Cultural Revolution between 1966 and 1969.

Noting that the DPP's attempts to use the communists' gambit in Taiwan's elections is doomed to fail, Lien said, the ruling party has betrayed its contempt for the voters by thinking naively that they will buy its claims.
Given the DPP's twisted perception of democracy, the KMT chief said, if the DPP controls the legislature, it will be a disaster for the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ABSENCE FROM APEC SUMMIT WILL NOT BE PRECEDENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's absence from the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) leadership meeting has set no precedent for its future participation, Vice Foreign Minister Wu Tzu-dan said Sunday.
In an interview with the United Evening News, Wu said Taiwan will continue to take part in next year's APEC summit in Mexico City.
"What transpired (in Shanghai) this time," Wu pointed out, "should not be considered a precedent for the future APEC meetings."

Taipei withdrew from this year's APEC summit at Shanghai Friday over a dispute about who should represent Taiwan. Beijing vetoed Former Vice President Li Yuan-zu, President Chen Shui-bian's proxy at the meeting, which closed Sunday.
In choosing Chen's personal representative to the Mexico City summit, Wu said, Taipei will "take into account the international situation and our ties with mainland China."

Wu welcomed a statement from Washington on Saturday that Taiwan's absence from the meeting is a loss to all participants. The U.S. Department of State also said in the statement that the absence should not be a precedent for the future APEC meetings.
"We fully shared Washington's views," Wu said. "And we will consider our choice for the next summit carefully," he added.

The informal leadership meeting, initiated by U.S.President Bill Clinton in 1993, was designed as a forum for leaders of the APEC member economies, but Taiwan's chief of state has been excluded from the gathering because of Beijing's opposition. Taipei used to send an senior economic official to the meeting in place of its president.
Li, an erstwhile political heavyweight, was appointed President Chen's representative at Shanghai. Beijing,however, extended no formal invitation to Li.
His absence left Taiwan unrepresented at the APEC summit meeting for the first time since 1993.

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC LEADERS VOW TO PREVENT 'ALL FORMS OF TERRORIST ACTS'
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Oct. 21 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Asia-Pacific leaders Sunday pledged to prevent "all forms of terrorist acts" and to strengthen cooperation to catch those who carry out such crimes in a joint statement after ending a two-day informal leadership summit here.

They unequivocally condemned "in the strongest terms" the terrorist attacks in the United States on Sept. 11 and are determined to enhance counter-terrorism cooperation in line with "specific circumstances in their respective economies."

In the anti-terrorism statement, the leaders at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit pointed out they consider the murderous deeds as well as other terrorist acts in all forms and manifestations, committed wherever, whenever and by whomsoever as a "profound threat to the peace, prosperity, and security of all people, of all faiths, of all nations."

"Leaders commit to prevent and suppress all forms of terrorist acts in the future in accordance with the Charter of the United Nations and other international law, pledge to implement the U.N. Security Council Resolutions 1368 and 1373 faithfully and immediately, strongly support all efforts to strengthen the international anti-terrorism regime, call for increased cooperation to bring perpetrators to justice, and also call for early signing and ratification of all basic universal anti-terrorist conventions, including the International Convention for the Suppression for the Financing of Terrorism," the statement said.
Terrorism is also a direct challenge to APEC's vision of free, open and prosperous economies, and to the fundamental values that its members hold, the statement said.

The APEC leaders, the statement continued, " reaffirm that it is more important than ever for every economy to forge ahead in its commitment in achieving Bogor's goal of free, open trade and investment."

It is deemed imperative to strengthen international cooperation at all levels in combating terrorism in a comprehensive manner and affirm that the United Nations should play a major role in this regard, the statement added.

The leaders also pledged to fully cooperate to ensure that international terrorism does not disrupt economies and markets, through close communication and cooperation among economic policy and financial authorities.

The APEC groups Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, mainland China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, the Philippines, Russia, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand, the United States, and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SOFTENS STANCE ON TAIWAN'S INDEPENDENCE

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) no longer insists on the hasty founding of an independent republic of Taiwan, its chairman Frank Hsieh said Sunday.
Hsieh said the DPP virtually gave up its 1991 platform, which calls for the establishment of a republic of Taiwan and enforce a new constitution.

He sponsored a motion, which was adopted at a DPP national congress in this southern port city Saturday, to let the 1999 "Resolution on Taiwan's Future" take precedence over the party platform. The resolution stipulates that any change in Taiwan's status-quo must be determined by the 23 million people on this island through a referendum.

"As a new law supersedes an old one," Hsieh said, "the Resolution on Taiwan's Future (instead of the party platform) now serves as the basis for the DPP's fundamental policy vis-a-vis cross-Taiwan Strait issues."
With the change in policy, the DPP stops short of openly calling for Taiwan's independence, for the resolution affirms that the island as it is now is a de facto independent state.
"The change," Hsieh pointed out, "reflects Taiwan's public opinion and is in line with political realities. We are more flexible."
Tsai Huang-lang, DPP whip at the Legislative Yuan, went along with Hsieh halfway. He said that the ruling party was "pragmatic" in upgrading the resolution.

The party stalwart, however, insisted that the DPP has not deviated from its Taiwan independence course. "There is no such problem as to whether the DPP was attempting to play down its independence platform," he said.
"We have just adopted a pragmatic, or more flexible attitude on the issue," Tsai added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SUPPORTS APEC'S ANTI-TERRORISM DECLARATION: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will support the anti-terrorism declaration made in the Asian-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum Sunday in Shanghai despite its absence from the meeting, Katherine S. Y. Chang, spokesperson for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said Sunday evening.

Taipei withdrew from this year's APEC summit at Shanghai Friday over a dispute about who should represent Taiwan at the meeting. Beijing vetoed Former Vice President Li Yuan-zu as President Chen Shui-bian's proxy at the meeting, and did not send Li an invitation to to the meeting, which closed Sunday.

Chang said that Taipei attaches great importance to all APEC meetings and that its absence from the Shanghai summit is not a precedent for its future participation. In fact, Taiwan is making preparations for the 2002 APEC summit to be held in Mexico, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 22, or the sixth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1721: Peter I, known as "Peter the Great," is proclaimed Emperor of all of Russia. He extended his territory around the Baltic and Caspian shores and reformed the administration of the state.
1835: Sam Houston, U.S. politician and general who fought in the Texan struggle for independence from Mexico, is sworn in as president of the Republic of Texas.
1873: The emperors of Russia, Germany and Austro-Hungary form an alliance.
1906: Paul Cezanne, French painter and leading post-impressionist figure, dies at the age of 67. His most famous paintings include "Mont Sainte-Victoire" and "The Card Players."
1909: Elise de Laroche, French aviator better known as Baronne de Laroche, becomes the first woman to fly solo.
1944: The Military Committee of the National government begins drafting young intellectuals for military service after Chairman Chiang Kai-shek on Sept. 14 urged 100,000 young men to enter the army.
1947: Pakistan and India begin a war over Kashmir.
1947: Japanese spy Yoshiko Kawajima is sentenced to death by a Chinese military court.
1950: Popular elections of magistrates are held in Taiwan Province, with Yang Chung-ching being elected chief of Hualien County and Chen Chen-chung being elected chief of Taitung County.
1951: A strong earthquake rocks Hualien, killing 43 people and destroying many houses.
1953: Laos gains independence from France.
1962: U.S. President John F. Kennedy makes his first major move in the showdown with the USSR over the building of ballistic missile sites in Cuba by announcing that Cuba will be placed under a naval "quarantine" -- a blockade -- until the Soviets remove the missiles.
1964: Jean-Paul Sartre, French writer, rejects the Nobel Prize for literature by saying it would reduce the impact of his writing.
1966: KGB master spy George Blake, who had spied for the Russians for 12 years and in 1962 had been sentenced to 42 years in prison, escapes from the maximum security wing of Wormwood Scrubs prison in west London.
1975: Arnold Toynbee, British historian and philosopher, dies at the age of 86. His "Study of History" explores patterns of growth and the decay of civilization.
1976: The 34,000-ton tanker Tsaineng (Talent) calls at Taichung port, becoming the first vessel to enter Taiwan's fourth international seaport.
1977: The first generator of the first nuclear power plant in Taiwan becomes operational.
1978: The Republic of China and the Republic of Korea agree to exchange information on the development and preservation of energy resources at their 13th annual ministerial economic conference.
1986: Yeh Chien-ying, one of the senior leaders of Communist China, dies in Beijing at the age of 89. With the support of Yeh, who commanded a wide following in the army and among senior cadres in 1976, Hua Kuo-feng was able to purge the "Gang of Four" and become Mao Zedong successor.
1992: Belgian Foreign Trade Minister Robert Urbain visits Taipei to relay a message of welcome to Taiwan business leaders intending to invest in Belgium. He also pledges support for the ROC's bid to join GATT.
1993: Boris N. Yeltsin, president of Russia, signs a decree governing private farms, paving the way for the breaking up of state-controlled farms and the move toward a free market economy.
1995: Independent presidential candidate Chen Li-an names Wang Ching-feng, a Control Yuan member, as his running mate.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew rushes to Chiayi immediately after a magnitude 6.4 earthquake struck the southern city at 10:19 a.m. and injured more than 320 people.
2000: Industrial sources say that Taiwan's exports in personal and notebook computers have increased by more than 40 percent over last year, with local notebooks accounting for 60 percent of the global market.
Confucius lesson of the day: "A ruler needs only to be earnest in his personal conduct and to behave in a manner worthy of his position."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 55 points to close at 3,900.62.

Encouraged by a rise in U.S. share prices over the weekend, the bourse opened at 3,866.7 and continued to go up later due to a rebound in blue chip stocks. The index fluctuated between 3,924.3 and 3,861.71 during trading.

A total of 2.34 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$51.15 billion (US$1.48 billion), compared with the previous trading session which saw 2.29 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$51.85 billion (US$1.5 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile issues moving up the most at 2.8 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 2.7 percent, bank and insurance shares at 2.5 percent, construction stocks and plastics and chemical shares, both at 2.2 percent, pulp and paper issues at 2 percent, and cement stocks and electrical shares, both at 1.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 453 to 103, with 75 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPORTS PLUMMET IN WAKE OF TYPHOONS, TERRORIST ATTACKS

TEXT.P: The total value of Taiwan's September export orders received plummeted by an unprecedented scale as a result of a spate of typhoons and the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Monday.

Export orders received by Taiwan exporters and manufacturers in September totaled US$10.48 billion, down 26.81 percent from the level for the previous September, marking the largest year-on-year monthly drop in this category and the first time in Taiwan's foreign trade history that such a decline exceeded 20 percent, MOEA officials said.

Meanwhile, the annual growth of Taiwan's industrial production index showed a decline of 7.85 percent in the January-September period, also marking the largest drop ever in any nine-month period in this category, the officials noted.
Electronics and related high-technology industries were the hardest hit by the prominent downturn, according to MOEA statistics.

Export orders received by Taiwan electronics companies totaled US$2.11 billion in September, down an alarming 40.19 percent over the previous September's level, while export orders for other information technology and telecommunications products and equipment amounted to US$1.74 billion, down a staggering 36.35 percent.

Chang Yao-tsung, director general of the MOEA Statistics Department, said the fallout from the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks has knocked at least US$1.5-2 billion off Taiwan exporters and manufacturers' export orders.

Typhoon Nari, which caused heavy human casualties as well as extensive property damage when it battered Taiwan in mid-September with record levels of precipitation, was another major factor in the unprecedented decline in September export orders, Chang noted.

Nari and Lekima, another "autumn typhoon," forced an industrial zone in northern Taiwan and the headquarters of several important export-oriented enterprises to shut down their operations for at least one week in September, indirectly contributing to a 15-percent year-on-year decline in overall manufacturing output for September, Chang continued.

According to the MOEA tallies, Taiwan's industrial production index stood at 112.87 in September, down 7.30 percent from the level for August and down 14.11 percent from the level for the previous September.
On economic prospects in the remaining months of this year, Chang said the United States' retaliatory actions against terrorists has added more elements of uncertainty to the global economic outlook.

Taiwan, with export trade as the backbone of its economic growth, is expected to continue to be affected by the ongoing U.S.-led military actions, he said, adding that it will be difficult for export orders growth to pick up in the fourth quarter and that industrial production will also remain at a low ebb.

A recent Department of Statistics survey found that 22.99 percent of domestic manufacturing companies think export orders will turn for the better in October, while 40.19 percent think they will remain unchanged and 36.82 percent believe export orders will decline in October.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WON'T BACKTRACK ON CROSS-STRAIT POLICY: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan will not backtrack on its fundamental policy toward mainland China simply because of the recent bilateral fracas over the island's representation at an Asia-Pacific leadership meeting, an official said Monday.

The official with the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, said although Beijing's refusal to issue an official invitation to Taipei's representative to this year's informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum was very regrettable, the Republic of China government will not backpedal on its long-term policy of promoting constructive cross-strait engagements.
Basically, the official said, the MAC hopes that Taiwan's forced absence from this year's APEC summit in Shanghai can be regarded as an isolated case.

Nevertheless, the official admitted that it's still premature to predict at this moment whether the dispute over the issue of Taiwan's APEC summit "representation" will affect the future development in cross-strait relations.

Noting that Taiwan cannot alone dictate cross-strait interaction, the official said the MAC will keep tabs on the development in cross-strait interchanges in the wake of the Shanghai APEC summit over the weekend.
In reality, the official said, the development in cross-strait relations hinges on many major factors, including mainland China's attitude and the general opinions of the people of Taiwan.
In his view, the official said, future cross-strait detente will hinge on goodwill shown by Beijing.

Meanwhile, Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi, who represented Taiwan at the pre-summit APEC ministerial meeting, reiterated Monday that Taiwan's absence from the just-concluded APEC summit will not be a precedent regarding its future participation.

"Nor will the incident affect Taiwan's imminent entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) as a full member," Lin pointed out, adding that a joint declaration issued at the end of the APEC summit Sunday reaffirmed the 21-member regional forum's support for Taipei's and Beijing's WTO accession.

Both Taipei and Beijing have received official clearance regarding the terms of their WTO accessions, and the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body is expected to formally endorse their memberships at its ministerial meeting scheduled for November in Qatar.

Asked whether the APEC fracas will prompt the government to backtrack on its planned relaxation of restrictions on mainland China-bound investment, Lin quoted President Chen Shui-bian as having assured the domestic business community that his administration will continue preparatory work for carrying out the conclusions reached at the Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) held in late August.

Noting that easing cross-strait investment restrictions under the "no haste, be patient" policy adopted by the previous Kuomintang government was one of the major EDAC conclusions, Lin said the government will not backpedal on its planned trade liberalization with mainland China.

Taipei withdrew from this year's APEC summit in Shanghai Friday over a dispute about who should represent Taiwan. Beijing breached APEC protocol by not sending a special envoy to deliver an official invitation to President Chen, and then it refused to accept former Vice President Li Yuan-zu, Chen's hand-picked proxy, as the ROC president's representative to the informal leadership summit, which closed Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS AND MEDICAL SPECIALISTS FORM HEALTH REFORM FOUNDATION

TEXT.P: After years of preparations, a group of scholars, social workers and medical specialists have formed the "Taiwan Health Reform Foundation" Sunday to monitor the operations of the nation's medical system.

Liu Mei-chun, executive officer of the foundation, said that the quality of medical services in Taiwan is very often questioned. Most of the unsatisfied patients complained that doctors and hospitals failed to provide sufficient information about their health conditions.

According to results of an Internet survey conducted by the foundation recently, the public is interested in knowing about individual medical histories. They also expect that hospitals will make public such information as the cost of various medical treatments, irregularities by hospitals or medical personnel, the financial status of private hospitals and evaluation reports of hospitals.
Liu said that many patients and their families found themselves left in the dark when te doctors wouldn't even bother to explain the health issues of the patients, except writing quick prescriptions.

In an earlier survey on the quality of medical services, nearly half of those responding complained that doctors usually write a prescription after having spoken to the patient for only five minutes. Sixty percent said that they had no more than three minutes to explain their problems to the doctors.
Many of those polled expressed discontent with the large expenditures of the National Health Insurance Program.
The foundation hopes to play an active role in promoting health reform by coordinating efforts of those in the health field and social welfare organizations.
In view of the numerous disputes between patients or their family members and medical personnel and hospitals, the foundation hopes to develop a settlement mechanism with a legal basis.

Liu said that the foundation would conduct surveys on the quality of medical services every quarter. Every two to three months, the foundation, together with the media, will sponsor discussions on health reform.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN URGES VOLUNTEER SERVICE

TEXT.P: Lien Chan, chairman of the largest opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT), urged the public on Monday to put their love of Taiwan into action by joining volunteer services.
Lien made the remarks during a video shoot for an ad announcing a program to publicize the awareness of volunteer service called, "volunteer a day for society."
Lien and a score of KMT volunteers, armed with brooms, swept an area of Hsimenting in downtown Taipei Monday. Lien said that individuals should be lifelong volunteers in the service of society.
Saying that the original script for the TV ad was somewhat stilted, Lien improvised some of the lines to make the commercial sound more natural.

Lien said that keeping in steps with global efforts in volunteerism this year, the KMT will set up volunteer teams around Taiwan, setting disaster relief as their number one goal, with environmental protection as a priority. The groups will also working closely to improve society and the environment in general.

Lien and Hsieh Chi-ta, convener of the New Party, completed filming the ad Monday for the volunteer society, which has also arranged for Frank Hsieh, chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, and James Soong, chairman of the People First Party, to appear in the ad.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IT PRODUCTION ABROAD TOPS DOMESTIC OUTPUT: III

TEXT.P: The production value of the Taiwan-based information technology sector abroad was US$24.8 billion in 2000, surpassing for the first time its domestic output value of US$23.2 billion, according to the Institute for Information Industry (III).

During the 1994-2000 period, the overseas output of Taiwan-based IT firms rose from US$3 billion to US$24.8 billion, while the sector's domestic production value increased from US$11.5 billion to US$23.2 billion, III tallies showed. The growth rate of domestic output between 1994 and 1996 averaged 20 percent, but the percentage posted noticeable falls over the past four years.

Officials of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said that the increased overseas IT production is a reflection of the local sector's failure to upgrade its industrial level. They warned that a continued exodus by local IT firms will deteriorate the local unemployment situation and lead to a hollowing-out of the industry.

According to the CEPD officials, mainland China is the major production base abroad for Taiwan-based IT companies, which pulled out 38.6 percent of the total value worth of their orders in the mainland last year.

At present, the production value of Taiwan's IT industry was the world's fourth-largest, lagging behind mainland China in third place, the CEPD officials said, pointing out that 72 percent of mainland China's IT output was contributed to by Taiwan-funded companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE OEM SUPPLIERS MOVING PRODUCTION LINES TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: More OEM (other equipment manufacturer) electronic parts suppliers in Taiwan are moving their production lines to mainland China to lower production costs, though they have kept their operational centers in Taiwan, according to industrial sources.

Hsiao Chih-hsien, marketing manager for the northern Asia region of the high technology company Seagate, said Monday that mainland China has become the fastest growing market in the area. In order to have more convenient access to the market, many OEM suppliers have moved their production lines, or even research and development centers to mainland China.
Seagate, for instant, still puts its order to suppliers in Taiwan, and most of these suppliers were making deliveries from their manufacturing plants in mainland China, he said.

The marketing specialist said that he believes Taiwan is able to maintain its competitiveness even when most of the OEM suppliers keep only their administrative departments in Taiwan. Innovation and streamlined logistics are key, he added.

The local currency opened Monday at NT$34.537 and was traded between NT$34.537 and NT$34.548.
