DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD HEAD DEFENDS IMPLEMENTATION PROGRESS OF EDAC CONCLUSIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top economic planner Monday defended the implementation progress of the 322 conclusions reached by consensus at the Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) held in August that was designed to help invigorate the island's floundering economy.

Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, discounted local media reports that have said that only 11.8 percent of the EDAC conclusions have been carried out since the conference was concluded.
The actual figure, Chen said at a news conference, is 91 percent.
Chen said he had to listen to his conscience and called the news conference "to right the wrongs" that were produced by "distorted reports" by some media.

President Chen Shui-bian initiated the EDAC to chart a path for the island through the present economic slump. More than 100 economic and trade officials, scholars and specialists, and business leaders took part in the three-day conference. Participants agreed by consensus on 322 recommendations to tackle pressing national issues including the rising unemployment rate, Taiwan's worsening investment environment, the amelioration of cross-Taiwan Strait economic and trade relations, the declining competition of local industries and the increasing seriousness of the local financial situation.
Chen said most of the EDAC conclusions have been taken care of in accordance with the special demands of each.

For example, he noted, 34 conclusions have been written as draft bills and forwarded to the Legislative Yuan for screening in hopes that they will be promulgated during the current legislative session.

Eighty others have technically been turned into administrative orders for implementation, he said, adding that it was agreed by EDAC participants that consensuses reached in the cross-strait affairs group would not be restricted to a fixed timetable for implementation.

Instead, according to Chen, the participants decided to keep the cross-strait business and trade policies flexible and readjust them in accordance with the timing of both sides' accession into the World Trade Organization and actual interactions between the two sides' business and trade sectors.

Meanwhile, former premier and chairman of the Cross-Strait Common Market Foundation, Vincent Siew said the 322 conclusions are critical to Taiwan's economic development and their implementation should not be put off because of political factors, such as the year-end elections of legislators, city mayors and county chiefs.
Chi Schive, president of the Taiwan Academy of Banking and Finance, said the 322 EDAC conclusions are actually a hodgepodge of ideas involving too many areas.
He said that not all of the conclusions are applicable and the government should screen those conclusions before putting them on a timetable for implementation.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK MANUFACTURERS VYING IN MAINLAND MARKET

TEXT.P: The merger between Compaq and Hewlett Packard has reshaped the market for notebooks and Taiwan suppliers to the two international computer giants are modifying their marketing strategies with more emphasis on the market in mainland China, a source familiar with the situation said Monday.

Inventec Corp. and Arima Computer used to be contracted OEM (other equipment manufacturer) suppliers to Compaq. Both manufacturers felt the merger impact on their third-quarter sales, with deliveries dropping by 20 percent to 30 percent from the previous year's level, according to industry sources.
Taiwan's notebook manufacturers in the past few years had enjoyed good business with large OEM orders from leading international firms such as IBM, Compaq, Apple, Dell and Hewlett Packard.

In years when sales were brisk, Taiwan's OEM suppliers were able to achieve high growth -- up to 30 percent. However, since the world economic climate took a downturn early this year, the notebook sector began to have to deal with large inventories and fewer orders from international companies.
The industrial source said that notebook manufacturers are making moves into mainland China, in addition to their efforts to lure orders from Japanese brands such as Toshiba and NEC.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROSTER OF GOVERNMENT RESTRUCTURING COMMITTEE RELEASED

TEXT.P: The roster of a long-planned government restructuring committee was unveiled Monday, with President Chen Shui-bian serving as its chairman.
Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general to the president, said President Chen has also appointed Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and Examination Yuan President Hsu Shui-teh as vice chairmen of the new body.
Yu himself has been named the chief executive of the committee, while Vice Premier Lai Ing-jaw will be the deputy chief executive.
"President Chen has also approved a list of 23 other members of the committee," Yu said, adding that the president hand-picked the members from government, academic and business circles.
Yu chaired a preparatory meeting earlier in the day to set the agenda for the committee's first conference to be held Thursday as well as its ultimate goals.

Participants to the preparatory meeting, mainly senior staff members of relevant government agencies, also discussed the committee's organic rules which are expected to be formalized at the body's inaugural meeting, Yu said.

According to the organic rules, the committee's primary missions are drafting a comprehensive blueprint for government restructuring, division of labor and resources between central and local governments as well as relevant personnel system reform.

The committee will be authorized to set up seven divisions to conduct project research and administrative affairs, including planning and research, secretariat, conference affairs, general affairs, news releases, personnel and accounting divisions.

The new committee comprises 10 government officials, 11 academics and four senior industry and business executives. The government officials in the committee include Yu, Vice Premier Lai, Cabinet Secretary-General Chiou I-jen, Examination Yuan Secretary-General Hsu Ching-fu and Lin Chuan, director-general of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.

The four members from the business community are Nita Ing, chairwoman of the Taiwan High-Speed Railway Corp.; Acer Group Chairman Stan Shih; Chi-Mei Group Chairman Hsu Wen-lung; and Wei Chi-lin, chairman of Land Bank of Taiwan.

Noting that the formation of a government restructuring committee is one of the major conclusions reached at the high-profile Economic Development Advisory Conference in late August, Yu said the committee's first meeting scheduled for Thursday will mark the beginning of the Republic of China government's largest-ever downsizing plan since the implementation of the Organization Law of the Executive Yuan (or Cabinet) in March 1947.

The Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission came up with a draft executive branch restructuring plan earlier this year. Under the plan, the number of the Executive Yuan's current 36 ministries and commissions will be trimmed to 25.

The draft package will be submitted to the newly formed restructuring committee for discussion and a final version is scheduled to be referred to the Legislative Yuan for deliberation and approval next February.

"We hope that the new legislature to be elected Dec. 1 can pass all proposed revisions to the existing Executive Yuan Organization Law by next April to pave the way for a sweeping overhaul of the executive branch," Yu said.

Then President Chen hopes to carry out structural reforms of the Judicial Yuan, the Examination Yuan and the Control Yuan, Yu said, adding that the overall government restructuring plan in scheduled to be completed in two years.

Political analysts said Taiwan has lagged far behind the United States, Japan, many European countries and even mainland China in government restructuring. In their view, political factors have been the biggest obstacles to the long-talked-about and much-needed government downsizing.
Government sources said Presdient Chen has done his utmost to exclude political considerations in selecting members of the restructuring committee to ensure the success of the ambitious reform plan.

"The committee roster is composed of members with expertise or backgrounds in constitutional affairs, public administration, organizational management, self-government, sociology and business management," said a government official who preferred anonymity.

DOC.HEADLINE: 15,000 WORKERS HIRED UNDER GOVERNMENT'S EMERGENCY EMPLOYMENT PLAN

TEXT.P: Nearly 15,000 workers have been hired as temporary workers under a government emergency employment plan aimed at reconstructing areas damaged by recent typhoons, sources with the Employment and Vocational Training Administration (EVTA) said Monday.

The EVTA, which is responsible for carrying out the plan, said that as of Oct. 19, more than 19,000 people were recommended by all local employment service centers and 14,979 were employed and have begun working since the EVTA publicized the plan Oct. 1, the sources said.

A task force for promoting domestic employment under the Executive Yuan originally earmarked NT$400 million (about US$11.59 million) for the plan with the number of workers employed set at 10,000, EVTA sources said.

However, the employment promoting task force decided later to raise the fund to NT$600 million because the number of workers recommended by all local employment service centers far exceeded that set by the task force.
The more-than-expected number of workers applying for one-month temporary jobs indicates that times are indeed tough, the sources said.

The workers hired under the emergency employment plan are to be engaged mainly in the clearing up of street drains and repairs in towns hit by the typhoons. They will end their work at the end of this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR CLOSES UNCHANGED ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar closed unchanged at 34.543 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday.
The local currency opened Monday at 34.537 and was traded between 34.537 and 34.548.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$150 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECOND SKILL KEY TO COUNTERING ECONOMIC RECESSION: SURVEY

TEXT.P: A vast majority of Taiwan's white-collar workers agreed that cultivating a second skill is the best way to counter an economic recession, a recent survey has found.

According to the results of the survey released Monday by a local Web site -- www.104.com.tw -- 93.8 percent of the people polled believed that having a second skill is the best way to tackle economic sluggishness in the workplace.
The survey also discovered that 97.8 percent of senior workers with at least 10 years of annuity agreed to the concept out of the fear of being eliminated in the workplace by younger workers.

However, the survey also pointed out that only 29.9 percent of Taiwan's white-collar workers are cultivating a second skill, with those aged between 20 and 29 being the most active in doing so -- mainly learning a computer language.
At the same time, 43.3 percent of the respondents said that they have plans to take part in professional skill examinations within one year to gain a certificate.
The survey, which was conducted Aug. 9-14, covered 1,976 valid questionnaires during a software exhibition fair in Taipei. No margin of error was given.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR UPGRADING OF PUBLIC AWARENESS OF ANTHRAX

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged relevant government agencies to heighten alert on all possible forms of terrorist biowarfare and take effective steps to help enhance public awareness of anthrax risk.
Chen gave the directives after presiding over the fourth high-level national security meeting regarding the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States.

Noting that the current U.S.-led war on global terrorism is an unprecedented new type of warfare, Chen said international terrorist organizations have not only threatened the U.S. domestic security but has also posed great threat to global stability and values.

A U.S.-proposed anti-terrorism statement issued at the end of this year's informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Shanghai Sunday indicates that counter-terrorism has become a prevailing international stance, Chen said.

"Although Taiwan was forced to absent itself from the Shanghai APEC summit in protest against Beijing's rude discrimination," Chen pointed out, "the government has pledged its adamant support for the ongoing global anti-terrorism campaign."
Against this backdrop, Chen said, all relevant government agencies should remember this promise and come up with concrete work plans in follow-up APEC working meetings.
"We should actively take part in various action plans in intelligence and information exchanges, security inspections, anti-money laundering and strengthening of energy security," Chen explained.

He further said although the Republic of China is not a U.N. member, the executive and legislative branches should work together to substantiate the various U.N.-initiated anti-terrorism conventions and resolutions in domestic laws and statutes.

"As the ROC-U.S. judicial assistance agreement, initialed by the two sides earlier this year, forms an integral part of bilateral cooperation in crackdown on cross-border organized crime and acts of terror," Chen said, "I hope the executive branch can lobby the legislature to ratify the accord during its current session."

In view of gradual spread of anthrax infections, Chen said, relevant government agencies should step up precautions. In addition to staging anti-anthrax drills and intensifying publicity campaign, he said, the government should start evaluation and planning of vaccine purchases and supply sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT REBUTS FORMER PARTY CHAIRMAN'S CRITICISM

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) issued a statement Monday to rebut former party chairman Lee Teng-hui's criticism of the party and the party's leaders.

Lee stepped down from the KMT chairmanship following the party's defeat in the March 18, 2000 presidential election. His party membership was revoked in September mainly because he decided to stump for candidates of the newly formed Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).
Over the past few weeks, Lee has openly criticized the KMT, accusing it of "joining hands with communist China to oppose Taiwan." He has also described KMT leaders as "bad people."

With the approach of elections for legislators, county magistrates and city mayors Dec. 1, and Lee's continued criticism of the KMT while stumping for TSU candidates, the KMT issued a statement to clarify the party's position.
The statement claimed that as the "spiritual leader" of the TSU, Lee has distorted facts to hurt the KMT.

It noted that the KMT took steps to revoke Lee's party membership in line with past practice adopted to revoke the party memberships of former Premier Hau Pei-tsun and former Judicial Yuan President Lin Yang-kang at a time when Lee was serving as KMT chairman and ROC president.
Lee has described the KMT administration as a "foreign administration" and noted that he worked with the "KMT bad fellows" for many long years.
The statement asked: "Why did the KMT administration -- which Lee once headed -- become a foreign administration and why did the KMT leaders become bad follows soon after Lee quit?"

It also stressed that the KMT's policy toward mainland China is against the communist system, not against the mainland people, and added that the party is against Taiwan independence because it might cause a military showdown across the Taiwan Strait.
The statement said that the KMT's mainland policy, adopted when Lee was party chairman, remains unchanged, and added that "the one who has changed is Lee, not the party."
"The KMT is striving to protect Taiwan and oppose the communists," it pointed out, denying Lee's claim that the KMT was "uniting with communist China to oppose Taiwan."

Regarding Lee's criticism that the KMT was "dragging at the legs" of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government because the KMT could not endure losing power to the DPP, the statement said that if Lee's remarks were true, the KMT would not have presented advice on economic development to the new government and would not have participated in the Economic Development Advisory Conference.
The statement said that although Lee has quit the KMT, the KMT has not denied Lee's contributions to the party and the country.
It said that the party has learned from its defeat in last year's presidential election and is striving to promote democratization with a hope of regaining voter confidence in the year-end elections.
As no single party is expected to win a simple majority in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan in the elections, the KMT and the DPP are struggling to become the biggest party.
President Chen Shui-bian has stated that he will form a coalition government after the elections, regardless of the results of the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE AUTO WORKER'S STRIKE ENTERS 4TH WEEK
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Oct. 22 (CNA) (By Philip Liu and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: A strike staged by workers of Nissan Motor Co., the Philippines, entered its fourth week Monday, company sources said Monday.

Taiwan's Yulon Motor Co. -- the major shareholder in the company -- threatened in turn to withdraw its capital in the company if the Philippine government cannot solve the dispute between the company management and the labor union.

Chao Ling-kai, a senior Nissan, Philippines executive, said that the management had sent a record of the negotiations between the management and the labor union to the Philippine Labor Department for arbitration, but he added that a ruling is not expected until November.
The union is demanding a 50 percent pay raise and several-fold increases in benefits, which the management cannot accept, said Chao.

He also claimed that union members had begun threatening the security of company personnel and company property, adding that the management had asked for extra guards to protect company personnel and property.
This is the first time Nissan Motor Co., the Philippines occurs the strike since last year when Yulon Motor invested 1.2 billion pesos in the Philippine company.
Yulon, with 1.2 billion pesos invested in the company, owns a 37 percent stake of Nissan Philippines, followed by Japan's Marubeni Co.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM TIEN TO ATTEND CHANG HSUEH-LIANG'S MEMORIAL SERVICE IN U.S.

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian has asked Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao to attend the Nov. 23 memorial service in Hawaii for Chang Hsueh-liang, who kidnapped Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in 1936 in the so-called Xian Incident.
Tien, who left for Hawaii Monday, said President Chen asked him to attend Chang's memorial service and bestow Chang a citation in order to convey his deepest condolence.

Cecilia Yen, wife of Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Strait Exchange Foundation, will represent Madame Chiang to convey her condolence to Chang's family in the service. She said she thinks Chang was a great Chinese and one of the most influential figures in modern Chinese history, who changed the history of China.
Chang, born in 1901, succeeded his father, a warlord who dominated northeastern China after the ROC was founded in 1911, as leader of his father's militia, called the Northeastern Army.

In order to integrate the Northeastern Army into the forces of the Nationalist government, Chiang, who led the nationalists at the time, named Chang as the commander-in-chief of the army in northeastern China in 1926.

However, Chang and his followers were expelled from their stronghold when the Japanese Imperial Army invaded China in 1931 and occupied northeastern China. Chang, who was eager to drive the Japanese out of northeastern China, was at odds with Chiang, who wanted to use Chang's army to fight against the burgeoning Chinese Communists.
Chang took Chiang hostage in Xian Dec. 12, 1936 in an attempt to force him to join with the communists to fight the Japanese.

Chang was persuaded by Chiang to give up his attempt and submit himself to the Nanking-based Nationalist government for discipline. Chang escorted Chiang to Nanking two weeks later, ending the so-called Xian Incident.
Chang was then put under house arrest for nearly half a century after moving to Taiwan along with the ROC government in 1949.
Chang was granted relative freedom of movement on the island in 1988 by then-President Lee Teng-hui and was allowed to move to Honolulu in 1993.

The citation bestowed by President Chen hails Chang as a patriotic figure, who pledged allegiance to the Central Government despite the Japanese threat and contributed significantly to the unification of the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER HOPES TO CONVENE EXTRAORDINARY LEGISLATIVE SESSION

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung Monday expressed hope that the Legislative Yuan will convene an extraordinary session in mid-November to approve documents required for Taiwan's accession into the World Trade Organization (WTO).

The WTO ministerial meeting will be held in Qatar Nov. 9-13, and if everything goes smoothly, the documents for Taiwan's entry into the global trade regulatory body will be formally recognized at the meeting.

As the Legislative Yuan will go into a one-month recess Nov. 1 in preparation for the Dec. 1 elections for legislators, county magistrates and city mayors, Chang said he hopes the extraordinary session will be called after the Qatar meeting so as to approve the relevant WTO documents.

Once approved by the Legislative Yuan, the documents will be submitted by the Executive Yuan to the Presidential Office and to the WTO secretariat. One month later, Taiwan will become a formal WTO member.

Chang also said that he and President Chen Shui-bian had exchanged views with Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng on the WTO issue and that the Legislative Yuan should be able to enact all bills required for Taiwan's WTO membership in the coming days.

In this connection, Democratic Progressive Party legislative caucus leader Tsai Huang-lang said Monday that the legislative caucuses from the ruling and opposition parties had agreed to call a plenary session Oct. 31 to handle WTO-related bills.

Because of the lack of time, he said, the legislative caucuses are considering steps to speed up the enactment of bills connected with WTO membership and with implementation of the resolutions of the Economic Development Advisory Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S WORDS ON '1992 CONSENSUS' MAY AFFECT STABILITY: KMT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's denial of the "1992 consensus" will have a serious impact on cross-strait stability, said the former chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affair Council (MAC) under the Kuomintang-led administration Monday.

Su Chi, convener of the national security section under the National Policy Foundation, a think tank for the KMT, said he was worried about the remarks that Chen made at a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) election campaign rally for Hualien magistrate candidate Yu Ying-lung Sunday.

Chen said that opposition parties have forced him to accept "one country, two systems," the 1992 consensus, and the "one China" principle. Their purpose, he said, is to eliminate the Republic of China and sell out Taiwan.

Su further pointed out that if President Chen and former President Lee Teng-hui form an alliance after the year-end elections, the cross-strait situation will undoubtedly further deteriorate. The KMT will keep a close eye on developments, Su said.
Noting that Taiwan independence and a ban on nuclear power are two of the basic tenets of the DPP, Su said he wondered what could be next from the ruling party.

Su said that the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant was the foundation of the island's economic development and that the "1992 consensus" was the bedrock on which cross-strait stabilization rested, adding that he thinks President Chen's expression was purely to attract votes.

The former KMT-led administration developed cross-strait relations based on the principle of "one China with different interpretations" and the "1992 consensus," Su said. Former President Lee, Chairman of the Strait Exchange Foundation Koo Chen-fu and former Premier Vincent Siew used these terms during their terms in office and no one claimed that by using them, the KMT was selling out Taiwan, Su said.

Su also believed that Chen's remarks on the "1992 consensus" was going "far beyond the course" and said that President Chen could not put "one country, two systems" and the "one China with different interpretations" on an equal footing.

Meanwhile, Chairman of the People First Party (PFP) James Soong criticized President Chen's remarks on the "1992 consensus" saying that his comments ran encounter to the majority opinions of the ruling and opposition parties.

PFP spokesman Hsieh Kung-ping said that even DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh has said that only by returning to the "one China" principle under the Republic of China Constitution framework could the cross-strait dispute be resolved. This was advocated by both the ruling and opposition parties, Hsieh quoted Soong as saying.
The PFP strongly opposes "one country, two systems, " or "one country, three systems" since they will downgrade Taiwan's status and could be construed to eliminate the ROC, Hsieh said.

Referring to the "1992 consensus," Hsieh said that the issue was under discussion by the ruling and opposition parties but President Chen came out and said that was to sell out Taiwan. President Chen was intentionally trying to provoke reaction from both sides of the independence/renunciation issue, Hsieh quoted Soong as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE DENIES PLAYING `ELECTION TRICKS' WITH APEC

TEXT.P: A Presidential Office spokesman denied accusations by lawmakers Monday that the government had "played a trick" by skipping this year's Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum summit in an attempt to solicit public support for the coming elections.

Kuo Yao-chi, director-general of the Presidential Office, was reponding to accusations by main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislators Kwan Yuk-noan, Fan Yang-sheng and Yang Tzou-chow, who claimed that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-led government made up its mind not to attend the APEC summit last weekend as a means of winning votes for the ruling party in the year-end legislative and county chief elections.

According to the lawmakers, the government acted in the hope that Beijing's snub to Taiwan would create an anti-mainland China backlash at home, which could translate into extra votes for the pro-independence DPP.

The three KMT lawmakers were members of the Taiwan delegation at the APEC ministerial-level meetings, which was led by Council for Economic Planing and Development Chairman Chen Po-chih and Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi.

Saying it is a pity that Taiwan did not take part in the gathering and thereby lost the chance to boost its international presence, they said that the government's insistence on sending former Vice President Li Yuan-zu as President Chen Shui-bian's sole proxy at the summit had prevented Taipei officials from negotiating with flexibility on the issue.
They also criticized Lin's performance, blaming the minister for having been "too scared" to speak out for Taiwan on public occasions.

Calling the KMT lawmakers' speculation "totally incorrect," Kuo said the government had done its best to prepare for the APEC summit from the very beginning. She added that the government was forced to make the withdrawal announcement at the last minute because it had not received a formal invitation from host mainland China.

Kuo noted that the APEC summit is an important international event for Taiwan and stressed that the government would never have thought of seeking to court public backing for elections by choosing to skip the gathering.

DOC.HEADLINE: POSTPONED WTO MEETING WILL NOT AFFECT TAIWAN'S ENTRY: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi said Monday that any change to the date or venue of a World Trade Organization (WTO) minister's meeting is not expected to affect Taiwan's entry into the organization.
Lin made the remarks in the fourth high-level national security meeting, presided over by President Chen Shui-bian, following the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States.

Due to the security concerns following the attacks and the U.S. military retaliation against the Taliban regime in Afghanistan, there have been suggestions that the WTO should change the venue of a WTO ministerial meeting scheduled for November in Qatar.
The meeting is expected to approve the admission of both Taiwan and mainland China to the world trade regulatory body.

Asked whether Taiwan -- which withdrew from the just-concluded informal summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum -- would have its WTO admission affected, Lin said he sees no such implication.
According to Lin, a statement from the APEC informal summit reaffirmed its support for WTO entry for both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Lin also presented a report regarding ROC economic strategy following the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

According to the report, the Ministry of Economic Affairs will keep a close eye on the situation in Afghanistan, help local enterprises to explore markets that are less affected by the U.S. military action, such as Japan, South Korea, Southeast Asia and mainland China, and assist them to take advantage of trade opportunities related to survival equipment, computers and telecommunications.
However, Lin refused to comment on the 26.81 percent drop in Taiwan's exports in September -- a record monthly drop.

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC INCIDENT WILL NOT AFFECT TAIWAN'S WTO ENTRY: CEPD CHIEF

TEXT.P: A Taipei official said Monday that Taiwan's absence from the 2001 informal leadership conference of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Shanghai will not affect Taiwan's bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman Chen Po-chih, who led the Taiwan mission to the APEC ministerial meeting, told reporters that the incident will also not affect the government's policy of "cultivating Taiwan with a global perspective."

Because Beijing's failure to follow the APEC protocol of sending an official to Taipei to deliver an invitation to the leadership conference, Taiwan was forced to withdraw from the gathering at the last minute.

Chen said that the APEC incident and WTO accession are two independent cases and added that the United States has stated that Taiwan's APEC participation and WTO activities in the future will not be affected by the incident.
A WTO ministerial meeting in Qatar next month is expected to admit the entry bids from both mainland China and Taiwan.
Regarding the future development of cross-Taiwan Strait economic and trade relations, the CEPD chief said that the direction will change to "cultivating Taiwan with a mainland perspective."
In the past, he said, Taiwan worked to open its market to foreign investment, whereas the new direction is to place more emphasis on expanding to foreign lands.

Chen said that the government's policy toward mainland China will become more positive than before and added that the mainland will be included as one of the bases for "cultivating Taiwan with a global perspective."

Chen admitted that the mainland is the best place for investment for many industries, but added that it is not the only possible base for Taiwan's development and that its importance should not be exaggerated.

The recent Economic Development Advisory Conference proposed that the government replace its "go slow, be patient" policy with "active opening, effective management" in dealing with investment relations with the mainland, a proposal that the government decided to accept.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF FOREIGN LABORERS IN TAIWAN FALLS TO 319,000

TEXT.P: The number of foreign laborers in Taiwan fell to 319,240 in September, a decrease of 1,587 from the previous month, according to statistics released Monday by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA).
It was the third consecutive monthly drop in the number of foreign laborers in Taiwan, the CLA said. The September figure was nearly 10,000 less than that of the peak month, it added.

Meanwhile, the number of foreign household caregivers in September totaled 105,873, an increase of 362 from the August figure. Foreign household caregivers still comprised the majority of foreign laborers in September, according to the CLA statistics.

The number of foreign household caregivers in August had registered a negative growth from the previous month and CLA officials attributed the September increase to revisions of regulations governing the hiring of foreign household caretakers.

When the government opened its doors to foreign laborers in the early 1990's, only the families of patients with a level of 60 or lower on Barthel's score -- a measurement used to evaluate the physical and mental condition of patients -- were allowed to hire foreign caregivers.
In July 2000, the CLA revised its regulations to require a Barthel's score of less than 20, a much more stringent requirement.

A Barthel's level of 20 or lower means that a physically disabled or mentally ill patient is "totally dependent," while a level of 40 or below on the score means that the patient is "heavily dependent."
The CLA amended the regulation again in July 2001 to loosen the standard to a Barthel's score of 40 or lower.
The same CLA statistics show that the number of foreign housemaids in September amounted to 9,112, a month-on-month growth of 104.

The number of foreign laborers working in the low-tech manufacturing sector in September stood at 10,002, an increase of 161 over the previous month, while the number of foreign laborers working in the high-tech manufacturing sector totaled 245, a growth of eight, according to the statistics.
The number of foreign laborers working in the government's major construction projects in September reached 32,621, a month-on-month increase of 544, according to the statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT APPROVES FUND FOR GENE RESEARCH

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC) approved Monday the appropriation of NT$4 billion for gene research.

NSC Vice Chairman Huang Wen-hsiung said that the 2002 budget for the island's development of biotechnology will top NT$17.1 billion, and added that NT$4 billion of the sum is to be used for gene research.
Huang said that construction of gene research facilities at Academia Sinica will start in January and be completed by August 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PLAN TO OPEN EVENING TRADING FOR TAIEX: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Securities and Futures Commission Chairman Chu Shou-chuan Monday denied that his commission is considering opening the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) for evening trading.
He said that the commission is just asking the TAIEX to formulate a plan for after-hours trading and that the commission hopes the plan can be completed by the end of this year.
Chu made the remarks in response to a news report saying that the TAIEX is considering opening for evening trading and other measures to keep in step with global markets.
Chu stressed that the SEC has no preset stance regarding the plan for after-hours trading nor it has any position regarding the time and approach of its implementation.

The Economic Daily News on its front page Monday quoted commission officials as saying that they were considering opening the stock market for evening trading from 6 p.m. to 11 p.m. to be more in tune with the trading hours of major bourses around the world.
The officials noted that at a time when global financial markets are quickly changing and competing fiercely with each other, extending the TAIEX's trading hours is inevitable.

However the officials stressed that a public hearing will be held regarding these measures before any final decisions are made, adding that the measures will be put into practice in two years at the earliest.
The Taiwan stock market this year extended its daily trading time from three hours starting from 9 a.m. to four-and-half hours to end at 1:30 p.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG CALLS FOR CONTINUED KMT DOMINANCE IN LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Vice Chairman Wang Jin-pyng said Monday Taiwan can only be assured a bright future if the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) continues to be the majority party in the legislature.
Wang, who is also president of he Legislative Yuan, made the remarks while stumping for KMT legislative candidates in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, in the year-end elections.
Wang said that during the time when the DPP was the opposition, the legislature passed 200 bills a year, but while the KMT was the opposition party, the legislature passed nearly 400 bills a year.

Wang said that the DPP has used boycotts, scuffles and heated arguments in the legislature in the past, becoming a laughing stock, but after it became the ruling party it has not allowed any criticism, instead pointing fingers at the opposition camp as an "obstable to reform" and "a public enemy."
Wang reiterated that it is only natural for the opposition parties to keep the ruling party in check and that the DPP is in fact the source of chaos in the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 23, or the seventh day of the ninth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1812: An anti-Napoleonic faction in Paris headed by Gen. Claude Francois de Malet tries to mount a coup d'etat, believing Napoleon to be dead in Russia.
1924: During China's warlord era, Feng Yu-hsiang, Hu Ching-yi and Sun Yueh form an allied force to launch a military coup that results in the resignation of Tsao Kun who was elected president of the Beijing government Oct. 5, 1923.
1926: Leon Trotsky is expelled from the Soviet Communist Party.
1928: The Republic of China government formally establishes the Ministry of Education.
1948: Changchun, a city in Kirin Province, northeastern China, falls to communist troops.
1952: Ukrainian-born microbiologist Selman A. Waksman wins the Nobel Prize for physiology or medicine for discovering the antibiotic streptomycin, an agent effective in the treatment of tuberculosis.
1955: Ngo Dinh Diem is elected president of South Vietnam.
1956: Hungarian students and workers demonstrate in Budapest against the Soviet occupation.
1957: ROC Vice President Chen Cheng is elected deputy director general of the Kuomintang.
1958: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek and U.S. Secretary of State John Foster Dulles issue a joint communique reaffirming solidarity between the two countries and stating that the islands of Kinmen and Matsu are "closely related" to the defense of Taiwan and Penghu under present conditions.
1966: The Ministry of the Interior proclaims today (the ninth day of the ninth lunar month) as Double Nine Festival, also known as the Chung Yang Festival, to honor senior citizens.
1968: Nigerian President Hamani Diori arrives in the ROC for an official visit.
1969: The United States starts pulling its troops out of Vietnam.
1973: The ROC suspends diplomatic relations with Upper Volta following Ouagadougou's recognition of Beijing.
1974: Brig. Gen. Abboud Salem Hassan, commander in chief of the Royal Jordanian air force, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1976: The first Chung Cheng Cup Martial Arts Tournament opens at the Taipei Athletic College with Wang Sun-teh, president of the Taipei Martial Arts Association, presiding.
1980: An economic cooperation agreement is signed in Taipei between La Chambre de Commerce of D'Industrie de Marseilles of France and the Far East Trade Service of the ROC.
1982: Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, winner of the 1970 Nobel Prize in literature, delivers a speech entitled "To Free China" at Taipei City Hall.
1983: Muslim suicide bombers blow up the U.S. and French headquarters in Beirut, killing more than 200 U.S. marines and French paratroopers.
1992: Emperor Akihito of Japan arrives in Beijing for a six-day visit.
1997: Hong Kong's stock market falls victim to Southeast Asia's economic turmoil, with the Hang Seng index falling more than 10 percent in its biggest crash in history.
1998: A Tokyo court hands down the first death sentence to a member of the Japanese doomsday cult that carried out the 1995 Tokyo subway gas attack.
1999: Taiwan finishes second with 15 medals at the 1999 Pan Pacific Master Swimming Championship held in Perth, Australia.
2000: The 15th Belgium-Republic of China Economic Cooperation Conference opens in Brussels to discuss ways of bolstering economic cooperation between the two countries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be conscientious and sincere in what you say; be earnest and serious in what you do: in that way, although you might be in barbarous countries, you will get along well with men."

DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Tuesday are as follows:

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER ATTENDS CHIANG KAI-SHEK KIDNAPPER'S MEMORIAL SERVICE
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Oct. 22 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's foreign minister arrived in Hawaii Monday to attend the memorial service for Chang Hsueh-liang, a key figure in ROC history who kidnapped Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in 1936 in the so-called Xian Incident.

Arriving a day before his scheduled attendance at the service on behalf of ROC President Chen Shui-bian, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao met with Chang's family to convey Chen's condolences and to bestow a posthumous citation on Chang for his contributions to the Republic of China.
Cecilia Yen, wife of Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation, will represent Madame Chiang at the service to convey Chiang's condolences.

Chang was born in 1901 and succeeded his father -- a warlord who dominated northeastern China after the Republic of China was founded in 1911 -- as leader of his father's militia, called the Northeastern Army.

In order to integrate the Northeastern Army into the forces of the Nationalist government, Chiang, who led the Nationalists at the time, named Chang as the commander in chief of the Nationalist army in northeastern China in 1926.

However, Chang and his followers were expelled from their stronghold when Japanese Imperial forces invaded China in 1931 and occupied northeastern China. Chang, who was eager to drive the Japanese out of the region, was at odds with Chiang, who wanted to use Chang's army to fight against the burgeoning Chinese Communists.
Chang took Chiang hostage in Xian Dec. 12, 1936 in an attempt to force him to join forces with the Communists to fight the Japanese.

Chang was persuaded by Chiang to give up his attempt and submit himself to the Nanking-based Nationalist government for discipline. Chang escorted Chiang to Nanking two weeks later, ending the so-called Xian Incident.
Chang was then put under house arrest for nearly half a century after moving to Taiwan along with the ROC government in 1949.
He was granted relative freedom of movement on the island in 1988 by then-President Lee Teng-hui and was allowed to move to Honolulu in 1993.

The citation bestowed by President Chen hails Chang as a patriotic figure who pledged allegiance to the Nationalist government despite the Japanese threat and contributed significantly to the unification of the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN FOREIGN MINISTER WELCOMES DEMOCRATIC REFORMS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Canada welcomes the democratic reforms and transformations in Taiwan, Canadian Foreign Affairs Minister John Manley said in a letter to the Taiwanese-Canadian Association dated Oct. 16.

In the letter, Manley said the positive changes brought about by Taiwan's "young and dynamic democracy" will continue to create greater opportunities for the development and expansion of contacts between the people of Taiwan and Canada.

The letter was addressed to Ms. Mireille Lin, the association's president, who presented a petition to the Canadian government Sept. 5 on behalf of association members across Canada calling on Canada and other major democracies to welcome Taiwan to become a member of the United Nations and other international organizations.

"As you noted in your letter, Canada recognizes the People's Republic of China as the sole legitimate government of China. Canada does not have diplomatic relations with Taiwan, but encourages economic, cultural and people-to-people contacts," the minister said.

Without mentioning Taiwan's official name -- the Republic of China -- Manley said that "Canada will continue to work constructively with Chinese Taipei within the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum."
The Republic of China on Taiwan is a member of APEC, the International Olympic Committee and other international bodies under the designation "Chinese Taipei."
Manley added that Canada looks forward to a similarly constructive and mutually beneficial relationship with Taiwan within the World Trade Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 26.2 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Tuesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 26.2 points to close at 3,874.42.
Market turnover amounted to NT$47.92 billion (US$1.39 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY TO TAKE PART IN MOCK BIOCHEMICAL ATTACK ON TAIPEI MRT SYSTEM

TEXT.P: A senior Republic of China Army official said Tuesday that the military will participate in an upcoming cross-ministerial drill to demonstrate its preparedness for a biochemical terrorist attack.

Maj. Gen. Chang Chin-teh, who heads the chemical warfare department at the ROC Army General Headquarters, said at a routine news conference at the Ministry of National Defense (MND) that the chemical warfare group of the Sixth Field Army will take part in the exercise scheduled for Saturday.
Chang said that the Army has teams in northern, central, southern and eastern Taiwan that can quickly identify and neutralize chemical agents on the spot.
He added that the military has a comprehensive protective mechanism in place against chemical attacks and conducts frequent drills to rehearse related procedures.
The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) is in charge of organizing the upcoming exercise, which will simulate a biochemical attack on a crowded Taipei Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) station.

The MND, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the Department of Health, the National Police Administration, the National Fire Administration and the Coast Patrol Administration are jointly participating in the event.

The same government agencies staged a similar drill last Friday at the same location. In that exercise, a mock terrorist released noxious gases in the MRT's Hsiaonanmen Station, and the government mobilized police, medical, EPA and chemical warfare personnel to handle the ensuing crisis.

President Chen Shui-bian on Monday urged relevant government agencies to heighten their alert against all possible forms of terrorist biowarfare and to take effective steps to help enhance public awareness of the anthrax threat.
Chen gave the directives after presiding over the fourth high-level national security meeting regarding the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States.
In addition to staging anti-anthrax drills and intensifying the campaign to inform the public, he said, the government should start evaluating and planning vaccine purchases and supply sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI INTRODUCING GERMAN EXPERIENCE IN PHYTOMEDICINAL RESEARCH

TEXT.P: The Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) will sponsor a seminar at the Grand Hotel in Taipei Wednesday, introducing German experience in research and development in herbal medicine and international marketing of phytomedicines.

A spokesman of the research institute said Tuesday that experts from the renown German drug manufacturer Dr. Willmar Schwabe Pharmaceuticals as well as university professors have been invited to speak at the seminar.

Dr. Willmar Schwabe Pharmaceuticals specializes in the field of plant-derived pharmaceuticals. One of the company's most renown products is ensaculin, a neuronal activator for the treatment of Alzheimer's disease. Derived from naturally occurring coumarins, ensaculin has been proven in clinical trials to be able to stimulate interaction with several transmitter/receptor systems, which are known to be diminished by Alzheimer's disease.

The spokesman said that the Chinese have used herbs in medical treatment for thousands of years, adding that the government has instructed the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the ITRI to advance the herbal medicine research and development as well as its commercialization.
He also pointed out that in terms of clinical studies, regulatory status and international marketing, the Chinese have much to learn from the West.

The spokesman said that the institute has arranged five speeches to be delivered at the seminar, including one titled "Industrial Research and Clinical Studies," by Dr. Karl-Heinz Stumpf, managing director and head of the Research and Development Division of Dr. Willmar Schwabe GmbH, Pharmaceuticals, as well as "Prospects of Phytomedicinal Research and Market Demands," by Prof. Theodor Dingermann of the Institute for Pharmaceutical Biology, Goethe University in Frankfurt.

Speeches titled "Pharmaceutical Quality of Herbal Medicines as a Basis of Clinical Efficacy," by Dr. Gerhard Franz of the Department of Pharmaceutical Sciences of the University of Regensburg, and "The Latest Regulatory Status and Entry Requirements for Herbal Products in European Countries, by Christine Mayer Nicolai, manager of the Regulatory Affairs and Herbal Medicinal Products/Homeopathics, Federal Federation of Pharmaceutical Industry, Germany, will also be delivered.
In addition, Melville Eaves, director of the division of International Marketing of Dr. Willmar Schwabe GmbH, will deliver a speech titled "International Sales and Marketing of Photomedicines."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 26.2 points to close at 3,874.42.
The bourse opened at 3,959.14 but began to go down due to profit-taking pressure. The index fluctuated between 3,959.14 and 3,868.92 during trading.

A total of 2.31 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$47.92 billion (US$1.39 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.34 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$51.15 billion (US$1.48 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile issues moving up the most at 0.6 percent, followed by construction stocks at 0.5 percent.

The other major categories posted losses, with foodstuff shares moving down the most at 2 percent, followed by electrical shares at 0.9 percent, pulp and paper issues and bank and insurance shares, both at 0.8 percent, cement stocks at 0.4 percent, and plastics and chemical shares at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 322 to 198, with 113 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower on Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for November moved down 56 points to close at 3,850, with 15,964 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for December lost 49 points to finish at 3,846, with 25 contract transactions, while next June futures decreased 19 points to finish at 3,871, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 3,906 for November, 3,895 for December, 3,890 for next March, 3,890 for next June, and 3,951 for next September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were generally lower.
November TE futures moved down 2.7 points to close at 184.3, with 3,710 contract transactions, while December TE futures decreased 4 points to finish at 184, with 10 contracts traded.
Next March TE futures lost 3.15 points to finish at 184, with 10 contracts changing hands, while next September TE futures fell 9.35 points to close at 185.1, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.
November TF futures moved down 6 points to finish at 600.8, with 2,354 contract transactions, while December TF futures rose 9 points to close at 606, with five contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CAN BECOME WTO MEMBER DEC. 10 AT EARLIEST

TEXT.P: Taiwan will become a full member of the World Trade Organization (WTO) 30 days after Nov. 10 if the Legislative Yuan convenes a special session to give its stamp of approval, a Ministry of Economic Affairs official said Tuesday.
Quoting WTO Director-General Mike Moore, the official said the fourth WTO ministerial meeting will be held in the Gulf state of Qatar from Nov. 9-13 as originally scheduled.

Earlier this month, the Hong Kong-based South China Morning Post reported that the WTO is expected to formally endorse mainalnd China's accession terms Nov. 10 and that mainland China's National People's Congress will convene an extraordinary session on the same day to ratify the mainland entry protocol for immediate delivery to the WTO Secretariat.
Under current WTO regulations, an applicant's membership bid will take effect 30 days after its accession protocol is sent to the Secretariat of the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body.

The WTO has agreed in principle to simultaneously approve the accession protocols of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. Taiwan's legislature, however, will be in recess when the WTO passes the island's accession protocol Nov. 10.

"We hope the legislature can convene a special session that day to ratify the protocol lest Taiwan lag behind mainland China," the official said, adding that if mainland China enters the WTO before Taiwan, it may try to bar Taiwan's accession using the excuse of Taiwan's restrictions on direct cross-strait trade and transportation links.

Against this backdrop, the official said, the executive and legislative branches of the government should work hand in hand to complete all formalities in time to ensure simultaneous WTO entry with mainland China.
Meanwhile, the Legislative Yuan approved a proposal earlier in the day to screen all WTO-related bills Oct. 30-31, the chamber's last two working days before the Dec. 1 legislative elections.

In view of the legislature's hectic work schedule in the run-up to the upcoming elections, legislative caucuses of ruling and opposition parties also agreed Tuesday that the 20-plus WTO-related bills can be put up for second readings directly.
