DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT DEFENDS `SPECIAL STATE-TO-STATE' THEORY

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui said Tuesday that the "special state-to-state" model he proposed in 1999 to characterize Taipei-Beijing relations has already become the "bottom line" in bilateral negotiations.

Lee said at the opening of an Academia Historica seminar on 20th century Taiwanese history and notable figures that there is no longer a question of the so-called "1992 consensus" or the "one China" principle in cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
His concept was the result of two years' study based on the works of domestic and foreign legal experts, he added.

Lee said that at the time in July 1999 when he first brought up the concept in an interview with a German reporter, Beijing had been preparing to announce to the world on its national day in October that its top cross-strait envoy was scheduled to visit Taiwan to discuss its "one country, two systems" formula.
That was the reason that Wan Daohan, the head of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, had been forced by Beijing to delay his scheduled visit, Lee said.

Lee went on to say that he believed the situation was very serious because the world would have been given the message that "the Republic of China has been destroyed" if Beijing had been able to make its announcement.
He said that "one country, two systems" is obviously not a good system because Hong Kong has only been governed under that formula for less than four years, yet "things have already become this bad."
Lee stressed that Taiwan must maintain its sovereignty in order to ensure its national security and dignity.

After Lee presented his "two states" model -- which was seen to be a departure from the ROC government's previous stance that characterized cross-strait relations as "one China, with each side free to interpret that term individually" -- tension in the Taiwan Strait increased noticeably and Beijing froze all dialogue and negotiations with Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S JOBLESS RATE HITS RECORD HIGH OF 5.26 PERCENT IN SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's jobless rate hit a record high of 5.26 percent in September and is expected to continue to rise in the next three months, the Directorate General of the Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Tuesday.

DGBAS officials said the number of people who lost their job due to plant closures or scaledowns in September stood at a new high of 245,000, or an increase of 14,000 from the previous month. Most of the jobless are middle-aged or a little older -- people who are traditionally the family breadwinners.
The officials, therefore, estimated as many as 1.18 million individuals may be affected by the jobless situation.

The officials noted that the jobless rate this September had not decreased as in the past, indicating that the job market is still sluggish, although first-time job seekers decreased by 4,000 from the previous month.
The number employed in September stood at 9.35 million, down 28,000 from the previous month.

The officials said that due to the terrorist attacks in the United States and the sluggish world economy, the jobless rate in the next three months is expected to stay high, with the average rate hovering around 5 percent in the fourth quarter and the year's average estimated to be above 4.5 percent.

The officials said that sluggish demand in the high-tech industry was responsible for the jobless rate in Hsinchu, the home of hundreds of hi-tech companies, to rise dramatically. The jobless problem has spread from the central and southern parts of the island to the north.

The officials said that the jobless rate gap between southern and northern Taiwan shrank dramatically in September. Sixteen out of 23 counties and cities reported a jobless rate of over 5 percent and only the offshore island of Penghu reported a jobless rate of under 4 percent.

Meanwhile, a labor union in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, appealed to Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, asking him to make good on a promise to create 10,000 new jobs after the mass rapid transit system starts construction.
The 60 laborers, representing those out of work and those who are worried about losing their jobs, shouted, "We want work, and give us 10,000 jobs."

Labor representative Yeh Kao-ping said that during the past 17 months of the current government, the political situation has been unstable, the economy has been sluggish, and the jobless rate has continued to rise, adding that the jobless rate in Kaohsiung City reached 5.56 percent in August, or the second-highest in Taiwan, which he said was not because the opposition was not cooperating with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) as the DPP has claimed.
Yeh asked Hsieh, who serves concurrently as DPP chairman, to make good of his promise to create jobs, and that the employment of Kaohsiung laborers will be given preference.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T MONETARY REFORM MEASURES ANTAGONIZE FARMERS' ASSOCIATIONS

TEXT.P: Officials of the Council of Agriculture Tuesday admitted that relations between the authorities and farmers' associations have turned sour since the Ministry of Finance launched a monetary reform campaign aimed at local financial institutions in mid-August.

The Bureau of Monetary Affairs under the finance ministry and the Central Deposits Corp. on Aug. 10 put under supervision 36 local financial institutions, of which 27 were credit departments of farmers' associations.

In early September, the finance ministry announced that 35 local financial institutions, mostly credit departments of farmers' associations, would be taken over by public banks in mid-September. Employees of these associations, being laid off without proper compensation, took to the street to protest against the indifference of the authorities.

Agricultural officials said that the tension between the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration and the local farmers' associations was obvious, and the forthcoming elections of legislators as well as mayors and county magistrates have complicated the confrontation.

Farmers' associations were traditionally strongholds of political parties in terms of votes. Well aware of the associations' role in the December elections, Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang and Chairman Chen Hsi-huang of the Council of Agriculture in the past weeks have visited executives of several farmers' associations in Pingtung, Kaohsiung, and Tainan, hoping to resolve the differences and to smooth over simmering resentment.

The opposition parties, on the other hand, have sought to secure votes through their old connections. Former agricultural officials of the Kuomintang (KMT)-ruling era also increased contacts with their old acquaintances at the farmers' associations.

Wang Chih-wen, director of the Training Department of the Republic of China Agricultural Training Association, said that the farmers' associations would not make public their political inclinations so that they will not offend the Council of Agriculture. But they have shown strong resentment towards the finance ministry.
Lin Cheng-huei, secretary-general of the Hsiulin Farmers' Association in Changhwa County, said that they were most humiliated when the authorities treated the farmers' associations as "thieves."

Only a few weeks before the elections, the Council of Agriculture is trying hard to win favor from the farmers' associations. Chairman Chen has given his personal guarantee that the authorities will not make another round of clean-up reforms on credit departments of the farmers' association as had been rumored.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar was down NT$0.007 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Tuesday, closing at 34.550.
The local currency opened Tuesday at 34.550 and was traded between 34.538 and 34.559.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$258 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHITE POWDER IN CAL PLANE PROVES TO BE FALSE ALARM

TEXT.P: The suspicious white powder found on a China Airlines plane flying from Taipei to Hong Kong appears to have been nothing more than spilled coffee creamer, CAL officials in Hong Kong reported Tuesday.

The plane, flight No.605 carrying 359 passengers, took off from Taipei for Hong Kong at 10 a.m. Flight attendants noticed the white powder on the carpeting of the floor of business class and alerted Hong Kong police.

Police boarded on the plane after it landed in Hong Kong and checked every passenger. Experts were sent to check the suspicious white powder to see if it was related to the anthrax which has caused three deaths in the United States so far.
Hong Kong authorities have initially determined that the powder may be creamer for coffee, but will need further tests to confirm this.
CAL officials said that the airline will not be dissuaded by a false alarm from keeping up their vigilance against terrorism in any form.
The plane later returned to Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF PASSENGERS TRANSITING LOS ANGELES TO DECREASE SHARPLY
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Oct. 22 (CNA) (By Lawrence Chu and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Affected by the fear of the recurrence of terrorist attacks, the number of air passengers making transit stops in Los Angeles is expected to decrease sharply over the next year, the authorities of the Los Angeles International Airport said Monday.
The airport authorities made the remark in its latest operations forecast report.
It estimated that in the next year, the number of transit passengers will decrease 35 percent, or 25 million, from the 70 million yearly level.
The airport authorities said in the report that part of the 25 million are passengers from Asia who fly to and from the west coast of the United States.

Since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States, nearly all major Asian airlines, including the All Nippon Airways (Japan), Singapore Airlines, Malaysian Airlines, China Airlines (Taiwan) and EVA Airways (Taiwan) have slashed their numbers of flights to the United States.
The airlines' move has resulted in large operating losses for the Los Angeles International Airport, the biggest civil international airport in the western United States.
The authorities of the Los Angeles International Airport said in the report that in the next fiscal year, the airport's operational loss will continue expanding.
It estimated that revenue from car parks will decrease US$108 million in the next fiscal year.
The airport authorities said that it will try to cope with the situation by seeking new sources of revenue and stemming unnecessary expenditures, as well as compiling a new budget plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: BANK IN KAOHSIUNG RECEIVES LETTER WITH SUSPICIOUS ANTHRAX POWDER

TEXT.P: A letter with suspicious anthrax white powder on the outside which was received by the Kaohsiung branch of the Taishin International Bank was sent Monday to the Department of Health for further examination, said an official of the Kaohsiung City Health Department.

The health official said that a female clerk discovered a letter from Hsinchu without a return name or address when handling letters addressed to the bank Monday afternoon. She also found that the outside of the envelope was sprinkled with white powder. She immediately notified her supervisor and the bank reported the incident to the police.
The official said that the clerk who touched the suspected letter was rushed to hospital for a check-up.

Police and city health department officials rushed to the scene and placed the suspected letter in a plastic bag and delivered it to the Center for Disease Control under the Department of Health for analysis.
The health authorities have yet to determine the nature of the white powder.
This was the fourth case of suspicious letters found in Taiwan, however, none of those analyized have been found to contain anthrax or any other dangerous substance.
An official from the Directorate of Southern Taiwan Postal Region said that postal workers are keenly aware of the situation and are on the lookout for any suspicious letters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STUDENT WINS INTERNATIONAL SENIOR HIGH SCHOOL ART AWARD
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 23 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A senior high school student from Taiwan won the first award in an international senior high school art competition held in Japan Monday.

Tu Chun-chie, a third-grade student at Fuhsin Trade and Arts School in Taipei County, earned the highest award with his oil and watercolor paintings. The competition was organized jointly by Japan's Daily Yomiuri Shimbun and Takazaki Junior College of Arts.

The international competition, the only one that targets senior high school students, is divided into music and paintings. A total of 1,901 art works from 25 countries were entered in the competition.

DOC.HEADLINE: DHL TO CONTINUE INVESTMENT PROJECTS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: DHL Taiwan Corporation will continue its US$30 million investment projects in Taiwan this year despite the sluggish economy.
Marc Duale, who is in charge of DHL's Asia-Pacific operations, said that Taiwan will play an important role in DHL's air cargo business.
By the end of this year, he said that DHL will move its Taiwan cargo transshipment center into the air cargo terminal of Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.
DHL's fourth large-scale service center in Taiwan, located in Shihlin, will go into operation in the near future, he said. The new service center covers a floor space of 6,000 square feet.

The three existing service centers, located in Neihu, Chungho and Taichung, are capable of handling more than 7,000 parcels each per day. They have been built with investment surpassing NT$100 million each.
Duale met the media after signing a contract with a company affiliated with the Evergreen group on the operation of its Taiwan cargo transshipment center.
He said that DHL Worldwide Express' other investment projects in Asia include investing US$82 million in Hong Kong, US$125 million in Japan and US$35 million in Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT PREPARED TO HELP BOOST DOMESTIC AIR TRAFFIC

TEXT.P: The government is willing to do its best to help local carriers tackle their current operational difficulties, Fair Trade Commission Vice Chairman Cheng Yu said Tuesday.

Cheng said the government is willing to help local carriers operating domestic flights cope with their operational difficulties by whatever means possible in cooperation with the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA).

Cheng said that the consensus was reached during a coordination meeting called by the CAA Monday, which was attended by officials from relevant government agencies and representatives of Far East Air Transport Corp., UNI Airlines, China Airlines, and TransAsia Airways.

According to Cheng, all parties concerned reached a tentative agreement during the meeting to either forge a joint venture or launch a joint promotion campaign for domestic routes, which have been affected since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States.

As long as the four carriers file a formal application for a joint venture or a joint promotion campaign with the commission in advance, Cheng said the commission would approve the application after normal procedures.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE ENDORSES EXTENSION OF INSURANCE GUARANTEE FOR AIRLINES

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan endorsed a Cabinet proposal Tuesday to extend for two months the current government guarantees for the island's airlines on insurance claims for accidents caused by hijacking or war.

According to the proposal, initiated by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC), the government's war-risk insurance coverage guarantees for domestic carriers will remain valid until midnight of Dec. 25 this year.
MOTC officials said the ministry came up with the proposal mainly because of the ongoing U.S.-led war on terrorism in retaliation for the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York and Washington.

With the escalation of the U.S. strikes on the Taliban in the Central Asian state of Afghanistan -- MOTC officials said the commercial aviation insurance market is not expected to return to normal in the short term.

Against this backdrop, the officials went on, the government's war-risk insurance coverage guarantees for local airlines must be extended for another two months to help domestic carriers weather the difficulties.

In the wake of the terrorist attacks on America, international underwriters have raised aviation insurance premiums across the board and have slashed the maximum third-party liability compensation to US$50 million.

The government's financial guarantee will give the nation's airlines temporary coverage above that amount in the event of any claims resulting from hijackings or war, while giving the companies time to negotiate new contracts with insurance companies.

The U.S. government and a number of other governments around the world have already pledged to help their aviation industries through their difficult times by providing similar financial aid packages.
The Republic of China government first offered a 30-day war-risk insurance coverage guarantee to domestic carriers on Sept. 26, which will end Oct. 25.

In addition to approving the two-month insurance guarantee extension, the legislature also passed a proposal demanding that the government allow airlines, particularly those which operate flight services to European destinations, to apply to use mainland China's airspace to avoid the Middle East war zone and save time and fuel costs.

The proposal was initiated by opposition New Party legislator Elmer Feng, who headed a delegation of senior executives of six Taiwan carriers to meet with mainland Chinese civil aviation officials and industry executives earlier this month to explore the possibility of Taiwan carriers flying over mainland airspace for safety and cost-saving purposes amid the current U.S. strikes on Afghanistan. According to Feng, mainland authorities would approve if Taiwan carriers file applications.

Officials with the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said flying over a country's airspace does not need negotiations. With the host country's consent, a foreign commercial aircraft can fly over its airspace.
Nevertheless, the ROC's existing regulations governing civilian exchanges across the Taiwan Strait bans domestic carriers from flying to mainland China.

CAA officials said it's up to the Mainland Affairs Council, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, to decide whether Taiwan's commercial aircraft would be allowed to fly over mainland China en route to Europe.

Under pressure from the legislature, MOTC Minister Yeh Chu-lan said domestic carriers can file applications for flying over mainland airspace. "The Cabinet will decide the fate of those applications," she noted.
Legislator Feng also admitted that although the legislature has passed his proposal, he is not sure whether the proposal can be implemented smoothly in the future.

Both China Airlines (CAL) and EVA Airways, the two Taiwan carriers that operate flight services to major European cities, said even though they hope to fly to Europe via mainland China to save time and fuel, they would not do so without the government's approval.

Since the U.S.-led forces began strikes on Afghanistan, CAL and EVA have made detours to southern India, Saudi Arabia and the Red Sea on the way to Europe. As a result, flights from Taipei to Europe will take an additional 30 minutes, while the detour will cause a one-hour increase in flight time on their way back.

DOC.HEADLINE: `THUG' LEGISLATOR DEPARTS FOR HONG KONG AMID FRESH ALLEGATIONS

TEXT.P: Independent Legislator Lo Fu-chu took a flight to Hong Kong Tuesday on a one-way ticket purchased at the airport shortly before departure, according to sources at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.

Lo's unexpected departure caused widespread allegations and speculation in the Taipei political arena as the Taipei City Police Headquarters was making a final decision on whether Lo should be listed as a hooligan as had been requested by the Taipei Prosecutors' Office earlier this month.
Staff at Lo's office said his departure had nothing to do with the police meeting, that Lo was going for a private business meeting and that he would return to Taiwan in a couple of days.

The Taipei Prosecutors' Office indicted Lo Oct. 8 for physically assaulting Diane Lee, a legislator of the opposition People First Party (PFP). The prosecutors also requested that Taipei City Police Headquarters list Lo as a gangster, based on 14 charges.

The Taipei City Police Headquarters convened a meeting last week in which it excluded three of the 14 charges and resolved that an eight-member ad hoc meeting would make a final decision on whether Lo -- widely recognized as a thug because of his frequent assaults on his colleagues at the Legislative Yuan -- should be listed as a hooligan.

Lo, who buckled under the pressure of public censure after the Lee assault in March and gave himself a six-month suspension from legislative activities, stirred up a new storm at the Legislative Yuan in early October when he ranted and raved at members of the Legislative Yuan Finance Committee who were discussing the rule banning any lawmaker from chairing any committee for three sessions in a row.

The rule prevented Lo's son, Kuomintang Legislator Lo Ming-tsai, from chairing the committee, as it would have been his third consecutive session as convenor -- even though he was elected to the position.
Lo Ming-tsai filed for a constitutional interpretation Oct. 9 on the justification of the Taipei Prosecutors' Office requesting his father's listing as a hooligan.

The junior Lo lambasted the prosecutors for "violating the Republic of China Constitution." He called the move an act of "judiciary white terror" and claimed the judicial system was illegally intervening in the legislative system.

DOC.HEADLINE: 15 MAINLAND CHINA-BOUND INVESTMENT PROJECTS APPROVED BY MOEA

TEXT.P: A total of 15 indirect mainland China-bound investment plans worth US$191 million were given the green light Tuesday by the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

Executive secretary of the commission Tsai Lien-sheng said the 15 projects had been submitted to the commission before the spat between Taiwan and mainland China over Taipei's selection of President Chen Shui-bian's proxy at the summit meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Shanghai over the previous weekend.

Tsai said that the commission approved the applications in accordance with normal procedure, despite the APEC summit row. Two capital increment plans worth US$19 million and US$13 million, respectively, by Yulon Motor Co., Ltd., together with an US$8 million investment plan by Yuen Foong Yu Paper Manufacturing. Co., Ltd. were among the 15 applications.

Two investment projects by the Formosa Plastics Group -- Taiwan's petrochemical giant -- to build a phenylethylene plant and a power plant in the mainland were not on the agenda of the commission's screening meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEAN COUNTRIES URGED TO EASE VISA RESTRICTIONS ON ROC LEADERS

TEXT.P: European countries should ease "unreasonable" visa restrictions on high-ranking Republic of China officials, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday.

MOFA spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue made the remark after Denmark and France declined to issue visas to President Chen Shui-bian that would have allowed him to receive in person a human rights award from the Liberal International (LI).

"European countries should drop all `unreasonable' constraints on visa applications by our senior officials in line with the principles of humanitarianism and justice," Chang said, adding that the ROC deserves fair treatment in the international community.
Chang said the MOFA is still endeavoring to pave the way for Chen to somehow travel to Europe to receive the LI's 2001 Prize for Freedom in person.
"We hope that European countries will refrain from self-imposed restrictions on senior ROC officials simply for fear of offending mainland China," Chang said.
She further said MOFA has no plans at the moment to send an envoy to Europe to collect the award on Chen's behalf.
In a recent interview with a Swiss newspaper, Chen complained that Denmark had bowed to pressure from mainland China by refusing to grant him a visa.
"They awarded me the Prize for Freedom, but they took away my freedom to travel," he said.

Foreign wire service reports quoted LI Secretary-General Jan Weijers as having said that the organization's attempts to arrange another venue for Chen to receive the award had been thwarted by what he claimed is a European Union policy under which Taiwan's top five leaders are denied visas -- even for private visits.

However, Chang pointed out that former Hong Kong Governor Chris Patten, who is now a member of the European Commission, the executive arm of the 15-member European Union, said in May this year that there is no official EU policy of denying entry permits to senior Taiwan officials.
"That a democratically elected president cannot travel to Europe to receive a human rights award -- our view is that this is totally cynical," Weijers said from LI's headquarters in London.

LI, an alliance of more than 80 liberal political parties from more than 60 countries, commended Chen for his "solid record as a human rights activist" and his contributions to democracy on the island.

Chen, a former human rights lawyer, defended an opposition leader who narrowly escaped the death penalty at a sedition trial in 1980 for organizing a demonstration in defiance of a now-scrapped ban on street protests.
Chen went on to become a member of the Legislative Yuan and the mayor of Taipei. He swept to power in presidential elections in March 2000, ending more than five decades of one-party rule.
Previous winners of the LI's Prize for Freedom include Burmese opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi, Algerian women's rights campaigner Khalida Messaoudi and Czech President Vaclev Havel.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET OPPOSES PROPOSED DIRECT TRAVEL TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Government officials expressed concern Tuesday about a proposal to allow direct travel from Taiwan proper to mainland China via the offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu, saying it would strain the defense and social order of the offshore islands.

They were responding to questions raised by opposition legislators Chao Erh-chung and Lin Ping-kun during a general interpellation session in the Legislative Yuan. Both asked the officials to express their views on the revised bills governing construction on the offshore islands, which recently passed its first reading.
The revised bill also makes provisions for the establishment of casinos on the offshore island of Penghu and tax exemptions for the offshore islands to help stimulate the economy and aid development.

Chao, who hails from Kinmen and Lin, who is from Penghu are both opposition Kuomintang lawmakers and have promoted the revision of the bills in the belief that the opening of direct trade, postal and transport links between Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China should be wider.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said the Cabinet hopes the opening of links between the two sides of the Taiwan strait will be conducted in a "safe, orderly and gradual way," but if Beijing is unwilling to consult with Taipei on related matters, it will be hard to expect "orderly and massive cross-strait exchanges."
Chang said that if Taiwan people were to be allowed to travel to mainland China directly through Kinmen and Matsu, it would put a strain on defense and social order on the islands.
Mainland Affairs Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen also said that if Taiwan people could travel to the mainland freely through Kinmen and Matsu, it would have a tremendous impact on national security.

As Beijing would not consult with Taipei on related matters, and as wharf facilities are lacking in Kinmen and Matsu, Tsai said she was opposed to such an opening, adding that Kinmen and Matsu also have no capacity to check on the inflow and outflow of visitors.
Tsai also said that the MAC will review a further opening of the "three mini links" -- which were started on a trial basis this year -- by the end of the year.

The MAC will review whether to let Taiwan businessmen and executives based in the mainland's Fujian Province travel to Taiwan via Kinmen and Matsu, according to legislator Lin Chung-cheng, who first made the proposal.
Ministry of Justice Chen Ding-nan also stated categorically that the ministry is opposed to the establishment of casinos on the offshore islands.

Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, echoed Chen's words, saying that one has to consider the negative effect of casinos, claiming that there are cases in other countries where the opening of casinos has turned the casino areas into drug trafficking centers.

On the subject of tax breaks, Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang said that he has reservations about proposed duty-free and tax exemption measures for the offshore islands, while Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi also said that if the offshore islands are allowed to import goods duty free and the goods are brought back to Taiwan proper, it will affect Taiwan's industrial development.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA TO HELP LOCAL FIRMS EXPLORE MAINLAND MARKET

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) will launch a campaign to help local companies grab a slice of mainland China's market for high-end products, a CETRA official said Tuesday.

CETRA Secretary-General Huang Chih-peng said the council will first organize an exhibition of high-quality products in mainland China and help local companies to participate in mainland Chinese product shows, which will include a renovation and high-technology exhibition scheduled to take place in Beijing in May next year.

Considering mainland China's imminent entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), which will force the mainland to further open its market, CETRA is making maximum effort to help local enterprises develop a mainland market share, evidence of which could be seen in a recent four-page ad in Time magazine.
In a computer show held in Shanghai in August, CETRA published joint advertisements with prominent Taiwan computer companies, Huang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC GOVERNMENT TO HOST GAMES GALA FOR FOREIGN DIPLOMATIC CORPS

TEXT.P: A carnival-style athletic gala is scheduled to be held Saturday in Taipei to entertain members and dependents of the foreign diplomatic corps in the Republic of China, government sources reported Tuesday.

The 2001 Games for Foreign Diplomatic Corps in the ROC will be held at the campus of National Taiwan University Saturday under the auspices of the Cabinet-level National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports (NCPFS), council officials said.

The officials said the games will not just be an athletic gathering, but a carnival featuring a garden party with various folk delicacies and exhibitions of diverse cultures throughout the day, as well as a program of different cultural performances at night.

Some 280 officials, staff and dependent of 28 foreign embassies, consulates and liaison offices stationed in Taiwan are expected to take part in the one-day gala, which will open in the morning with games including a paint ball war, a street basketball competition and a street football game, according to NCPFS officials.

Meanwhile, more than 200 ROC officials and staff members from Cabinet-level agencies which maintain operations related to foreign relations and foreign affairs are also expected to join the carnival to add to the fanfare and the festive mood, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA, CETRA JOINTLY PROMOTING TAIWAN PRODUCTS OVERSEAS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), in cooperation with the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), is currently sponsoring a Taiwan product fair in the Nicaraguan capital of Managua.

A total of 19 Taiwan-based firms are taking part in the exhibition of Taiwan-made products, which range from hi-tech computer parts and peripherals to house-cleaning goods. The trade fair kicked off last Saturday and will run through next Monday.

Meanwhile, some 17 Taiwan-based companies, mainly producers of everyday products, will participate in the 16th International Trade Fair slated for Tuesday through Sunday in Guatemala City. The largest exhibition in Guatemala takes place every two years and provides a good opportunity for Taiwan businesses to explore the markets in Central America.

In addition, 14 Taiwan firms dealing in construction materials and home decoration participated in a household products fair in Lithuania and Latvia recently. MOFA officials said the participation of Taiwan companies in these annual events will help local businesses explore the northern European and Baltic markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMOSAN MACAQUES POSE THREAT TO CROPS

TEXT.P: Formosan macaques have caused heavy agricultural damage in five Taiwan counties, Council of Agriculture (COA) officials said Tuesday at a news conference.

The officials said that 33 crop varieties in Miaoli, Taichung, Nantou, Changhua and Yunlin counties are frequently attacked by the foraging primates, usually on hillside areas up to a height of around 500 meters.
The monkeys are particularly fond of bamboo shoots and longans, according to the officials and farmers have tried various methods to discourage the attacks, all of which have failed.

However, the officials also admitted that the worst-affected areas are in fact those that have been earmarked for reforestation but are being illegally cultivated by farmers looking for quick profits. The Formosan macaque is an endangered species.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER MAC CHIEF DEFENDS SO-CALLED `1992 CROSS-STRAIT CONSENSUS'

TEXT.P: Former Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Su Chi said Tuesday that the so-called "1992 consensus" said by some to have been reached by Taiwan and mainland China has formed an "important political basis" for the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations in the past decade.

Without the consensus, he claimed, there would have been no cross-strait reconciliation between 1992-1995, including the 1993 Singapore talks between Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu and Chairman Wang Daohan of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.

Su, who was in charge of Taiwan's relations with mainland China under former President Lee Teng-hui, said that the consensus prevented direct collision between Taipei and Beijing and brought a win-win result for both sides.
Regarding remarks by Lee that day that there never was any "1992 consensus," Su said that today's Lee is different from the Lee of the past.
According to Su, the existence of the "1992 consensus" and the "one China with respective interpretations" are "facts" which have been admitted by Koo, former Premier Vincent Siew and Lee himself.

Su speculated that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the newly formed Taiwan Solidarity Union, which regards Lee as its spiritual leader, dislike "one China with respective interpretations" because they think "one China" implies that Taiwan is part of China.

Chen and the DPP have recently described "one country, two systems," "one China with respective interpretations" and the "one China principle" as schemes designed to "destroy the Republic of China and sell out Taiwan."

Su said that such a view destroys the basis for the development of cross-strait relations and further hinders the resumption of bilateral dialogue which has been stalled since the second half of 1999.
He said that he hopes the remarks were only "election campaign language" or an unintentional slip of the tongue on Chen's part and that Chen will not insist on such a view after the Dec. 1 elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PLANS TO IMPORT INDIAN SOFTWARE TALENT, TRAINING MECHANISM

TEXT.P: Taiwan plans to open its door to computer software programmers from India to help ease a manpower shortage in the local information-technology (IT) industry, a senior official said Tuesday.

Minister-without-Portfolio Tsai Ching-yen, also a joint convener of the Science and Technology Advisory Group (STAG) under the Executive Yuan, said Taiwan should also consider importing software educational and training mechanism from India to help boost the domestic software industry development.

Tsai said the STAG invited software industry representatives, senior executives of IT industry associations and scholars to discuss feasible measures to resolve the software manpower shortage problem.
"All the participants reached a consensus that we should introduce software talent and training system from India," Tsai said.

Noting that India is known for its software technology, Tsai said the South Asian country accounts for 20 percent of the world's software OED (original equipment designing) market. Indian software firms offer services to 200 of the world's top 1,000 corporations, according to Tsai.

"Among the world's 23 software companies which receive the top-grade certification in terms of the U.S.-developed Level Software Engineer Institute Capability Maturity Model," Tsai said, "15 are Indian firms."
As India can cultivate 75,000 outstanding software engineers, Tsai said, many countries around the world have actively recruited talent from that countries.

"The United States and Germany have even revised their domestic laws to facilitate imports of Indian software talent," Tsai said, adding that Japan, Belgium, Singapore and Ireland have also adopted various measures to recruit qualified Indian software engineers or programmers.

Noting that India is also known for its software educational and training mechanism, Tsai said Japan and mainland China have forged cooperative ties with India's largest software training institution.
In comparison, Tsai said, Taiwan has lagged behind in introducing India software talent and training system.

"The STAG will invite officials of relevant government agencies in the near future to discuss a comprehensive plan to introduce Indian software engineers and training mechanism into Taiwan," Tsai added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA TELECOM OPTICAL FIBER CABLE RESTORED

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Chunghwa Telecom Co. said Tuesday that it had repaired an optical fiber cable cut by mistake by Taiwan Power Co. workers earlier that day and apologized to its customers for the inconvenience.

The workers damaged the cable in Miaoli while laying underground wires. The damage caused heavy logjams on international telephone calls, long distance calls, mobile phone calls and Internet networks throughout Taiwan.

A Chunghwa Telecom official said that only around 30 percent of calls to United States went through prior to 11 a.m., in comparison with the normal figure of 70 percent, while approximately 10 percent of calls to mainland China went through.

DOC.HEADLINE: 19TH TAIWAN-JAPAN SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY MEETING TO OPEN WEDNESDAY

TEXT.P: The 19th Joint Meeting of Taiwan's Asian-Pacific Science and Technology Association and Japan's East Asian Science and Technology Coordination Association will open in Taipei Wednesday.

Hiromi Ozawa, chairman of Japan's Science and Technology Coordination Association, will head a Japanese delegation to discuss 132 science and technology cooperation projects with their local counterparts during the two-day meeting.

The two associations have implemented 1,654 technology exchange programs since the two countries suspended diplomatic relations in 1972. More than 7,000 scientists have participated in the exchange programs.
The annual meeting is held alternately in Taipei and Tokyo.

Panel discussions on science and technology strategy, energy, information technology, publications, the machinery, chemical and electronic industries, science and technology education, electronic communications, agricultural technology, biotechnology and environmental protection will also take place during the meeting.
More than 100 scholars and entrepreneurs from both countries will also take part in a seminar on the administration of information technology resources and their applications.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARAGUAY VICE FOREIGN MINISTER VISITS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Paraguayan Vice Foreign Minister Rigoberto Gauto Vielman arrived in Taipei Tuesday at the start of a five-day visit to the Republic of China.

During his stay, Gauto will meet high-ranking officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of National Defense and the Mainland Affairs Council to exchange views on ways to strengthen substantive ties between the two countries.
Paraguay is the only diplomatic ally of the ROC in South America.
Gauto is scheduled to leave Taipei Oct. 28.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN GROUP HOPING TO INCREASE TRADE EXCHANGES WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A German trade delegation called on Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou Tuesday to discuss increased exchanges between Taipei and German cities.

The delegation, headed by German Federal Commissioner of Foreign Investments Martens Jeebe, was in Taipei to attend a seminar on the Euro -- which is scheduled to begin circulating in Europe next January -- and trade opportunities for high-tech products.
Ma visited Germany several times during his term as vice secretary-general of the Kuomintang and vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, as well as in recent years.

Ma recommended Nankang Software Industrial Park in Taipei and Neihu Light Industrial Park to the delegation. He also expressed the hope of seeing more technological cooperation with Germany, adding that Taiwan cities could learn a lot from Germany.

He also said that he hopes to increase trade and cultural exchanges with Germany and added that the Taipei city government could study ways to set up a German trade promotion unit similar to an existing Canadian trade promotion unit in city hall, to increase bilateral trade cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LEGISLATURE OK'S TAIWAN FLIGHT DETOURS OVER MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China legislature resolved Tuesday to allow Taiwan air carriers to fly through mainland Chinese airspace rather than over India and Afghanistan on their way to Europe, in light of the U.S. military action in Afghanistan.

The Legislative Yuan passed a non-binding resolution requesting the Cabinet to permit Taiwan airlines to negotiate with mainland Chinese authorities over the possibility of Taiwan aircraft flying to Europe via mainland China rather than over India and Afghanistan.

However, Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan said local carriers will remain prohibited from using mainland Chinese airspace unless Beijing agrees to discuss the issue with ROC government officials.

Officials from the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said the council will give all possible and pragmatic routes considerations on the premise that the ROC's national interests are fully secured.

In a written statement, the MAC said the agency will pay close attention to the development of related situations and would like to assess different possible routes for the domestic airlines to choose from under the consideration of national interests.

Yeh said current ROC laws forbid Taiwan aircraft, vessels or other vehicles from flying, sailing, or passing through mainland Chinese airspace, territory, or waters without ROC permission and the mandate to waive these prohibitions rests not with his ministry but with the MAC and the Executive Yuan.

Taiwan air carriers' requests to fly through mainland Chinese airspace on their way to Europe to save costs involve the Taiwan government's power to regulate aviation rights and cannot be granted by anyone other than the government, Yen added.

She also continued that the government will not accede to such requests unless it can first consult with Beijing. Beijing has consistently refused to consult with the Democratic Progressive Party-led government.

The Legislative Yuan made the non-binding resolution as the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) was set to recommend to its members that they fly from East Asia to Europe via mainland China rather than over India and Afghanistan in light of the U.S. military actions against the Taliban in Afghanistan.
ICAO authorities were quoted as saying last week that one-third of the flights between Asia and Europe are routed via Southeast Asia, the Bay of Bengal, India, Afghanistan and the Middle East.
But business on this route was dealt a serious blow after the United States launched strikes on the Taliban regime Oct. 8.
As a result, the ICAO began mulling whether to divert the route to the four mainland Chinese flight information zones of Kunming, Chengdu, Lanzhou and Urumqi before flying over Siberia into Europe.
About 2,600 km of this route is in mainland Chinese airspace, over mainly highland, desert and mountain ranges.
Only flights by Hong Kong-based Cathay Pacific Airways take this route to Europe thus far, according to the ICAO.

Taiwan is not a member of the ICAO and was not informed of its recommendations for the detour plan. However, Beijing air traffic authorities promised Oct. 12 to open the route to Taiwan carriers should they apply to use it.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISA CARDS MOST POPULAR PLASTIC IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Trade through Visa cards totaled NT$52.70 billion (about US$1.05 billion) in Taiwan in August, accounting for 74 percent of the total amount of credit card trade that month, according to Ministry of Finance figures quoted Tuesday by Visa International officials.
Chen Chun-jen, general manager of Visa International, Taiwan, attributed the performance to seasonal factors, pointing out that August is traditionally a high-consumption month.

Chen said that Visa transactions in August 1999 and 2000 both hit second-highest records in those two years, while the amount in August 2001 was the highest single-month figure for a single brand of credit card so far this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER AGREES TO CALL MAINLAND CHINA `PRC'

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung agreed Tuesday to call mainland China "the People's Republic of China (PRC)" rather than "communist China."
At a news conference at the recently concluded Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum in Shanghai, a Taiwan television reporter repeatedly referred to the mainland as "communist China."
Mainland Chinese Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan was unhappy with the term, saying that the term has not been used for a long time.

At that day's legislative session, opposition Legislator Wu Ke-ching (Kuomintang-Taoyuan County) said that the Executive Yuan should decide upon an official name to use when referring to the mainland.
In reply, Chang said that since Tang was reluctant to accept the use of the term "communist China" Taiwan should "respect their opinion and call them `the People's Republic of China.'"

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJORITY SUPPORT CHANGE OF `GO SLOW, BE PATIENT' POLICY: SURVEY

TEXT.P: The results of a recent survey show that 77 percent of the respondents support the government's decision to relax the "go slow, be patient" policy in dealing trade and investment relations with mainland China.

The survey was conducted by the Taipei Computer Association though e-mail and on-line questionnaires between Oct. 16-21 over the contents of the Democratic Progressive Party's Oct. 20 resolution calling for the creation of a new economic situation for Taiwan.
Some 7,000 people viewed the questionnaires and 1,284 of them responded.
The results indicate that 79 percent support the idea of building Taiwan into a global data center, while 78 percent agree with the government's plans on basic wages for laborers.
Seventy-seven support the decision to change the "go slow, be patient" policy with "active opening, effective management."
Sixty-four percent believe that Taiwan is still competitive enough to attract foreign investment.
Only 30 percent said they have confidence in the ruling party's ability and resolve to implement the plans mentioned in the resolution, while 65 percent say they have no confidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN REPRESENTATIVE BIDS FAREWELL TO TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: The outgoing Australian representative to Taiwan bid farewell to Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, in a conversation that mostly focused on koalas given to Taiwan by Australia.
Sam Gerovich, representative of the Australian Commerce and Industry Office in Taipei, will leave for Shanghai in November to assume his post as consul-general of Australia in Shanghai.
Gerovich, who was born in Shanghai and lived there until he was nine years old, can speak fluent Chinese.

Ma told Gerovich that Taipei and Hong Kong will hold a joint forum next year and added that he would also welcome Shanghai's participation. He expressed hope that Gerovich can help promote exchanges between Taipei and Shanghai.
Ma also hailed Gerovich for his contributions to the trade, environmental protection, educational and cultural exchanges between Taipei and Australia.
He went on to say that as well as the frequent human exchanges between the two sides, animal exchanges are also very close, referring to the koala gift.
The talk about the furry marsupials seemed to make Ma and Gerovich quite excited. with Ma joking that koalas born in Taiwan should be considered "new Taiwanese."

DOC.HEADLINE: WITHDRAWAL FROM APEC SUMMIT UNFAVORABLE FOR TAIWAN: SCHOLARS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, northern Taiwan, Oct. 23 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Scholars at a symposium Tuesday that Taiwan's withdrawal from the informal summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum over the weekend is unfavorable for the island.
The symposium was sponsored by the International Research Institute of Tamkang University to o analyze the post-APEC forum summit U.S.-Taiwan relations and cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

The participants agreed that Taiwan's absence from the APEC informal leadership summit meant that Taiwan walked off the international and economic stage and will only have an advantage for those politicians who place their personal gain above public interest, while representing a disadvantage for Taiwan's future.

The symposium was jointly presided over by Wei Eh, dean of the International Research Institute and Yu Chuan-tao, ex-president of the Central Police University, and more than 30 local scholars participated.

According to Wei, the relationship between Washington and Beijing has become closer since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on Washington and New York, while Washington-Taipei ties are shrinking daily. Taiwan, he claimed, has "lost important bargaining chips" and this situation is very unfavorable for the island.

Prof. Lee Peng-ching of Tamkang University claimed that many people in Taiwan have failed to identify themselves as Chinese and that "indigenization" is on the rise in Taiwan. Under such circumstances, he went on, dialogue may not be able to resolve the cross-strait problem and Beijing may eventually resort to force to resolve the Taiwan issue.
Prof. Lin Yao-fu offered the opinion that Taiwan's absence from the APEC informal leadership summit has shut down the door on Taiwan's participation in anti-terrorist activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 24, or the eighth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1632: Antonie van Leeuwenhoek, the Dutch microscopist who was the first man to see bacteria, is born.
1648: France and the Holy Roman Empire sign the Treaty of Westphalia, ending the Thirty Years' War.
1861: The chief justice of California sends the first U.S. transcontinental telegram from San Francisco to President Abraham Lincoln in Washington.
1901: Ann Edison Taylor, 43, a teacher, is unhurt after going over Niagara Falls in a padded barrel to raise money to help pay her mortgage.
1908: Taiwan's West Coast Railway Trunk Line from Keelung to Kaohsiung is opened to traffic. An inauguration ceremony is held at the Taichung Park.
1922: The Irish parliament adopts a constitution for an Irish Free State.
1929: Share prices collapse as nearly 13 million shares change hands in panic selling on the New York Stock Exchange in what became known as "Black Thursday."
1931: Notorious Chicago gangster Al Capone, who has dominated organized crime for the past six years, receives an 11-year sentence and an US$80,000 fine for tax evasion.
1931: The Council of the League of Nations adopts a resolution urging Japan to withdraw its troops from Northeast China by Nov. 16.
1937: New Zealand aviator Jean Batten breaks the record by flying from Australia to England in just five days, 18 hours, and 18 minutes.
1944: The Japanese battleship "Musashi," one of the largest ever built, is sunk by U.S. planes during the Battle of Leyte Gulf.
1945: The United Nations Charter, adopted by the San Francisco Conference in June 1945 and ratified by 26 nations, formally comes into force.
1945: Vidkun Quisling, former head of the puppet government established in Norway by the Nazis in 1940, is executed at Akershus Fortress in Oslo.
1957: French fashion designer Christian Dior dies at the age of 52. He was noted for his "New Look" of 1947 that emphasized narrow shoulders, tight waists, and long, full skirts.
1960: Communist China and Mali establish diplomatic ties.
1964: Northern Rhodesia becomes independent from Britain as the Republic of Zambia, with Kenneth Kaunda as president.
1976: Mainland China's Chiang Ching, who was dragged from her bed by armed guards Oct. 6 and charged with treason, finds the going rough now that her late husband Mao Tse-tung is no longer around to protect her.
1986: Cheng Tsai-tien, 26, a communist Chinese pilot, lands his MiG-19 jet fighter in South Korea after flying it from mainland China's Shantung peninsula to seek asylum in the Republic of China.
1989: American television preacher Jim Bakker is sentenced to 45 years in jail and fined US$500,000 for swindling his followers out of millions of dollars.
1990: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes a partial revision of the Corporate Law.
1999: Gerardo Rocha, rector of the University of Santo Tomas in Chile, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
2000: The Asian Wheelchair Sports Federation is formally established, with Lai Fu-huan, deputy chairman of the ROC's National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, elected as its chairman.
2000: Former ROC Premier Hau Pei-tsun issues a statement expressing regret that three of his former colleagues in the ROC Navy have been impeached by the Control Yuan for their connection with an arms purchase scandal 10 years ago.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman of spirit or a man of moral character will never try to save his life at the expense of his moral character. He would prefer to sacrifice his life in order to save his moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Wednesday are as follows:
The China Times: Independent Legislator Lo Fu-chu was designated by Taipei police as a gangster under Anti-Hoodlum law. @The United Daily News: After second round of review of evidence, Taipei police decide unanimously to put independent Legislator Lo Fu-chu on the list of hooligans to be detained at anytime. @The Liberty Times: Taiwan jobless rate hits all-time record of 5.26 percent in September, with unemployment rate in northern city of Hsinchu -- home to most big technology companies in Taiwan -- being 5.69 percent. @The Taiwan Daily: 'Thug' Legislator Lo Fu-chu likely to be listed as a gangster. @The Central Daily News: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan calls for all-out mobilization of party members for the year-end elections of legislators, city mayors and county chiefs. @The China Post: Jobless rate hits another record high. @The Taiwan News: Hundreds of refugees drown in boat disaster. @The Taipei Times: Gangster Lo Fu-chu skips town.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGENDARY GENERAL CHANG HSUEH-LIANG LAID TO REST
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Oct. 23 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Chang Hsueh-liang, a legendary former warlord who played a historic role in the turbulent China of the 1930s, was laid to rest Tuesday in Hawaii.

A Christian memorial service was held at a funeral parlor in Honolulu early in the morning, with the participation of Republic of China Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao as well as Chang's family and friends.

Tien attended the ceremony on behalf of the ROC government and President Chen Shui-bian who also asked Tien to bestow a posthumous citation on Chang in recognition of his contributions to the country.

Chen and many other senior ROC officials and prominent political figures, including Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and former Premier Hau Pei-tsun, sent wreaths to express their respect for Chang.

Former ROC first lady Madame Chiang Kai-shek, who has led a reclusive life in New York since her husband died in 1975, named Cecilia Yen, secretary-general of the National Women's League of the ROC, to represent her at Chang's funeral. Moreover, Madame Chiang sent a cross of flowers to express her condolences.

Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and a number of other elder mainland politicians also sent flower baskets to pay tribute to Chang. He Yafei, minister of the mainland Chinese embassy in the United States, made a brief appearance at the funeral parlor to pay his respects to Chang, but he left before the memorial service began.
The presence of representatives and the messages of condolence from both sides of the Taiwan Strait indicated Chang's special status in modern Chinese history.
Chang, also known as "young marshal," died Oct. 15 at a hospital in Honolulu at the age of 101.

The "young marshal" succeeded his father -- a warlord who dominated northeastern China after the Republic of China was founded in 1911 -- as leader of his father's militia, called the Northeastern army, in his early 20s.

In order to integrate the Northeastern army into the forces of the Nationalist government, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, who led the Nationalists at the time, named Chang as the commander in chief of the Nationalist army in northeastern China in 1926.

However, Chang and his followers were expelled from their stronghold when Japanese Imperial forces invaded China in 1931 and occupied northeastern China. Chang, who was eager to drive the Japanese out of the region, was at odds with Chiang, who wanted to use Chang's army to fight against the burgeoning Chinese Communists.
Chang took Chiang hostage in Xian Dec. 12, 1936 in an attempt to force him to join forces with the Communists to fight the Japanese.

Chang was persuaded by Chiang to give up his attempt and submit himself to the Nanking-based Nationalist government for discipline. Chang escorted Chiang to Nanking two weeks later, ending the so-called Xian Incident.
Chang was then put under house arrest for nearly half a century after moving to Taiwan along with the ROC government in 1949.
He was granted relative freedom of movement on the island in 1988 by then-President Lee Teng-hui and was allowed to move to Honolulu in 1993.

The citation bestowed by President Chen hails Chang as a patriotic figure who pledged allegiance to the Nationalist government despite the Japanese threat and contributed significantly to the unification of the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO LOWER TARIFFS ON OVER 3,400 INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: With its impending accession to the World Trade Organization (TWO), Taiwan decided to slash tariffs on industrial products to the trade-weighted average of 5.78 percent in the first year of accession, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Wednesday.

Officials from the MOEA's Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) said industrial tariffs, affecting 3,470 categories of products, will be lowered from the current 6.03 percent to 5.78 percent in the first year of Taiwan's WTO membership and eventually down to 4.15 percent in 2004 when the tariff-cut move is completed.
Over the three-year period, tariffs on Taiwan's industrial products are expected to be slashed by 31.18 percent on a year-on-year basis, IDB officials noted.

The officials said the cross-the-board industrial tariff cut is not expected to have a major impact on most areas of Taiwan's industrial sector, except for on those relying heavily on the domestic market to survive, including the household electrical appliance manufacturing, automobile and tire manufacturing, heavy electrical machinery manufacturing and paper making industry.

Meanwhile, the officials said, the Republic of China government has been soliciting support from various WTO member countries for Taiwan's proposal to allow for the continued imposition of quota restrictions after Taiwan enters the WTO in order to protect the island's fragile compact car manufacturing sector.

Compact car imports which meet the quota will have a tariff rate of 30 percent in the first year, with the rate being gradually lowered to 17.5 percent by the ninth year of Taiwan's WTO membership, the officials continued.
Taiwan will become a full member of the WTO 30 days after Nov. 10 if the Legislative Yuan convenes a special session to give its stamp of approval, a ranking MOEA official said Tuesday.

Quoting WTO Director-General Mike Moore, the official said the fourth WTO ministerial meeting will be held in the Gulf state of Qatar from Nov. 9-13 as originally scheduled, during which the WTO is expected to formally endorse mainland China and Taiwan's accession terms.

Mainland China's accession terms are expected to be endorsed Nov. 10, and Beijing's National People's Congress will convene an extraordinary session on the same day to ratify the mainland entry protocol for immediate delivery to the WTO secretariat.
Under current WTO regulations, an applicant's membership bid will take effect 30 days after its accession protocol is sent to the Secretariat of the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body.

The WTO has agreed in principle to simultaneously approve the accession protocols of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. The ROC's Legislature, however, will be in recess when the WTO passes the island's accession protocol Nov. 10.

"We hope the Legislative Yuan can convene a special session that day to ratify the protocol lest Taiwan lag behind mainland China," the official said, adding that if mainland China enters the WTO before Taiwan, it may try to bar Taiwan's accession using the excuse of Taiwan's restrictions on direct cross-strait trade and transportation links.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAUNCHES NEW MAGAZINE ON INTERNATIONAL AFFAIRS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) launched a new magazine Wednesday to signify its concern about international affairs and implementation of the island's diplomatic policy.

DPP Secretary-General Wu Nai-jen told a news conference that the new International Affairs Quarterly will focus on policy research, particularly on subjects closely related to Taiwan's foreign policy.

"General international relations, the global economy, the current international situation and strategic security will be the major topics to be addressed," Wu explained, adding that the new magazine is expected to offer feasible initiatives for the formation and implementation of Taiwan's foreign policy.
In the face of mainland China's perennial squeeze on Taiwan's presence in the international arena, Wu said Taiwan cannot afford to make any mistakes in its diplomatic work.

"Our policymakers must keep abreast of the latest international situation and prudently evaluate every possible impact of various policy proposals before formulating a strategy to cope with major diplomatic events and defend Taiwan's interests," Wu said.

He added that the government must make an overall review of two recent incidents -- Beijing's refusal of Taiwan's representative to attend this year's informal leadership summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum in Shanghai over the weekend, and President Chen Shui-bian's inability to obtain visas to travel to Europe to receive the 2001 Prize for Freedom awarded by the Liberal International, a London-based alliance of more than 80 liberal political parties in 60 countries around the world.

Noting that the wave of globalization has diminished national boundaries, Wu said the DPP has made active, pragmatic adjustments of its policy platform to enable Taiwan to better adapt itself to the new international climate characterized by emphasis on democracy, human rights and freedom.

Wu was referring to a decision made at the DPP's party congress Saturday that elevates a 1999 resolution on Taiwan's future to the same level as the "Taiwan independence clause" of the DPP's charter. It was an important step in the DPP's history and a new interpretation of the party's pro-independence platform. From now on, whenever the two come into conflict, the 1999 resolution, which recognizes the existence of the Republic of China, will take precedence over the party charter's independence clause.
Nevertheless, Wu pointed out that all the adjustments will not weaken the DPP's insistence on its basic value -- "Taiwan first," or "Taiwan's national interests take precedence over anything else."
"In the new century," Wu said, "Taiwan should play the role of an active participant in international affairs to defend the mainstream values of the global society."

Meanwhile, DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh said in the inaugural issue of the International Affairs Quarterly that the new publication pools resources of the academic community, think tanks, political parties, news media and government agencies to provide a forum for foreign policy discussion and encourage research in international affairs for government reference.

In view of increasing commercial and civilian exchanges acros the Taiwan Strait, Hsieh said Taiwan must cash in on the opportunities provided by imminent simultaneous entry of Taipei and Beijing to the World Trade Orgnization (WTO) to integrate resources of both sides and develop itself into a major base for multinational companies to tap the vast mainland Chinese market.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN URGES TAIWAN INDUSTRIES TO EVOLVE TO SURVIVE NEW CHALLENGES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Wednesday exhorted Taiwan industries to evolve and change qualitatively in order to survive the challenges posed by an increasingly competitive world market.

Chen said that the question of how Taiwan will succeed in the transitional struggle in the 21st century depends on how well the country will face the new international situation, adding that the industrial sector, the backbone of Taiwan's economic growth, should strive to readjust itself to meet the new challenges.

Addressing a ceremony marking the ground-breaking of a second-generation export processing zone (EPZ) in Taiwan's southernmost county of Pingtung, Chen said Taiwan is presently facing at least three major challenges with the beginning of the era of the globalized economy.
First, he said, Taiwan is facing a challenge posed by mainland China, which is undertaking an unprecedented transition from an economic backwater to a key player in global economic development.

The president noted that Taiwan must find its direction soon in this turbulent current of transition, as well as utilize its geographical, cultural, and technological advantages in seeking further and sustainable development.

Second, Chen said, with Taiwan's and mainland China's impending WTO accession, Taiwan faces the challenge of how to adjust its economy in order to allow itself to be placed in an advantageous position for competition in the global economy.
Third, Taiwan faces the challenge of how to make biotech-led high technology development the basis of its economic development in the following decade, he continued.

Meanwhile, Chen highly credited the contributions of EPZs to Taiwan's economic progress over the past decades, pointing out that the new-generation EPZs, like the one which is going to be developed in Pingtung County, will be new global operations centers for the industrial and business sectors, and not simply manufacturing complexes for exports.

The planned Pingtung Export Processing Zone, which will include the high-added-value electronics and information technology, biotech, aeronautics, agricultural machinery and automobile industries, is expected to attract some NT$60 billion (US$1.74 billion) worth of investment to the area, Chen said.

In addition, he noted, the Pingtung Export Processing Zone will be a multipurpose operational center combining manufacturing as well as sea, land and air transport operations, and providing swift and convenient services to domestic and international manufacturers and dealers.

The 124-hectare export processing zone is expected to create some 45,000 job opportunities when it is completed, making Pingtung County a new industrial and business hub in southern Taiwan, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: POST-QUAKE RECONSTRUCTION WORK TO BE COMPLETED IN 2 YEARS: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Reconstruction work in the wake of the killer temblor of Sept. 21, 1999, will be completed in two years, Huang Jung-chun, director of the 921 Earthquake Post-Disaster Recovery Commission, said Wednesday.
Huang made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan during a joint meeting of the domestic and budget committees to review the budget for reconstruction.

Legislator Yeh Yi-jin of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party asked about the slow pace of house reconstruction since the magnitude 7.3 quake struck Taiwan over two years ago, causing more than 2,400 deaths and heavy property losses.
Yeh asked the commission to complete all reconstruction work for the people in the affected areas within five years so that their lives can return to normal.

Huang noted that overall, the reconstruction of houses damaged or destroyed in the affected areas is half completed, and he predicted that there will be great progress in the reconstruction of housing complexes in the middle of next year.
