DOC.HEADLINE: GROUP OF ABORIGINAL ELDERS QUESTIONED OVER VOTE-BUYING SUSPICIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, central Taiwan, Oct. 24 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A group of elderly aboriginal tourists aboard a bus home after taking a leisure trip to Japan's Okinawa Prefecture were taken to a Nantou County investigation station Tuesday night for questioning, local sources reported Wednesday.

The members of the group, all from the aboriginal village of Chunyang in Nantou County's Jenai Township, were "intercepted" by an army of prosecutors and police officers near Tsaotun Township around 12 p.m. Tuesday during their trip home.

The group, including 33 tribal elders and their travel leader Lin Hsiao-ying, were brought to the station for questioning, mainly on suspicions of their being "treated" by legislative candidates in the Dec. 1 island-wide elections.
The elderly men and women were not allowed to go home until 5 a.m. Wednesday after each of them had been questioned about the alleged vote-buying and bribery.

Nantou prosecutors said they made the move to take the group in for questioning after they were tipped off that the elders may have been involved in a suspected vote-buying deal by joining the tour group to Okinawa several days ago.
The seniors were provided with interpreters and a medical doctor during the questioning session, the prosecutors said.
All 33 elders were let go after 5 a.m. without any conditions, while the group leader Lin Hsiao-ying was released on NT$10,000 bail.

While the elders denied receiving any gifts from any election candidates, the presiding Nantou prosecutor, Hsu Sung-kuei, argued that the prosecutors possess some evidence that indicates vote-buying laws were violated which will necessitate further investigation before any alleged violators are indicted.

Both Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan have vowed to eradicate vote-buying from the year-end elections for legislators, county chiefs and city mayors, thereby directly accelerating the sweeping actions of law enforcement authorities at all levels islandwide as the day of the elections approaches.
Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan earlier this month defended the NT$30 (US$0.87) standard for vote-buying violations, saying that the decision will not be altered despite widespread criticism.

Chen stressed that the decision, which has been ridiculed by some politicians and elected representatives as unrealistic, will not be changed as the government is determined to stamp out in this year's elections that which has become commonplace in Taiwan politics -- gifts of money or goods in exchange for votes.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T WORKING TO MAKE TAIWAN FREE OF FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE BY 2007

TEXT.P: A legislator of the opposition New Party said Wednesday that the government hopes to make Taiwan free from the threat of foot and mouth disease (FMD) by 2007.

Legislator Chang Shih-liang said that the Executive Yuan has set up a task force to eradicate FMD in three stages, with the implementation of nationwide vaccinations by the end of 2005 occurring during the first stage.
During the second stage, the government will be on high alert in order to prevent even a single case of FMD from occurring in 2006.
In the third stage, the government will declare Taiwan an FMD-free zone and ask international authorities to confirm the results.
Chang noted that in recent years, domestic hog, cattle and sheep farmers and their meat exporters have lost billions of NT dollars every year due to FMD.

He said that although the Executive Yuan plans to achieve the goal of an FMD-free Taiwan by 2007, the goal can be achieved two years earlier if the Executive Yuan can rigorously implement the vaccination and prevention measures and if farmers cooperate with the government.

The FMD epidemic, which ravaged hog farms islandwide in March 1997, caused losses estimated at NT$43.9 billion (1.26 billion) for Taiwan's hog-raising industry. After the FMD outbreak among hogs, cases of cattle being infected with FMD were also reported.
The annual production value of Taiwan's hog-raising industry dropped from NT$88.6 billion in 1996 to NT$44.7 billion in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAIL SUSPECTED OF CONTAINING ANTHRAX TESTS NEGATIVE

TEXT.P: As of Tuesday, 24 pieces of mail received by people in Taiwan which were suspected of containing anthrax have been tested and have been shown to not contain the substance, the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health said Wednesday.
Nine of the 24 pieces of mail were found to contain powder, but the results of chemical testing of the powder for the presence of anthrax were negative, the CDC said.
The CDC added that among the contents of the 24 pieces of mail were ordinary letters, photographs, commercial letters, quotations, garments and gloves.
Meanwhile, several people who suspected that they had contracted anthrax and several commercial invoices that their holders suspected contained anthrax all tested negative.
CDC Deputy Director Chiang Ying-lung said that many of the letters that look as if they may contain anthrax may be practical jokes.

DOC.HEADLINE: BLOCKING OF TAIWAN'S PRESENCE AT APEC SUMMIT HARMFUL: ROC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice Foreign Minister Wu Tzu-dan said in a report Wednesday that Beijing's "blocking" of Taiwan's participation in the leadership conference of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum was harmful to the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
In the report presented to the Legislative Yuan, Wu said that because of the incident, cross-strait tensions will not be relaxed in the short term.

He continued: "It will not only worsen the situation across the Taiwan Strait, but has also hurt the feelings of the Taiwan people and has affected any possibility of a resumption of cross-strait dialogue."
Commenting on the summit talks between U.S. President George Bush and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, Wu said that their talks have not caused any negative effects on Taiwan's interests.

He noted that Bush only reiterated that the U.S. government would continue to observe the "one China" policy, would like to see a peaceful solution to the Taiwan Strait issue, would honor the Taiwan Relations Act and the three joint statements signed between the United States and mainland China.

Therefore, Wu went on, mainland China made no gains in terms of the Taiwan Strait issue during the talks and he added that it also reflected a U.S. promise made to Taipei before the talks that Taiwan interests would not be sacrificed.

Meanwhile, Wu told legislators that mainland Chinese Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan's actions were "incredible" when he stopped a Taiwan reporter from using the term "Chung Kung" (communist China) to refer to mainland China at a recent APEC news conference in Shanghai.
According to Tang, the term has not been used for a long time, but Wu pointed out that "Chung Kung" is a common abbreviated term for "the Chinese Communist Party" or "the People's Republic of China."
On Taiwan's absence from the APEC informal leadership conference this year, Wu said that "it was a special case, not a precedent."

Taiwan was forced to abstain from attending the leadership meeting because Beijing rejected ROC President Chen Shui-bian's appointment of former Vice President Li Yuan-zu to represent him at the conference.
Taipei also criticized Beijing for failing to follow APEC protocol by refusing to send an official to Taipei to deliver the invitation for the leadership conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO HELP INCREASE TAIWAN EXPORTS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 24 (CNA) (By Victor Lai) (By Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taipei, Oct. 24 (CAN) In light of sharp falls in Taiwan's exports and imports this year, the Economic Affairs Ministry (MOEA) will take measures to help boost exports to various key markets less affected by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States.

In cooperation with the Board of Foreign Trade and the semi-official China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), the MOEA has set its sights on Japan, Southeast Asia, South Korea and Europe, as well as Central and South America, for Taiwan's outbound shipments to offset the decline in demand from the U.S. market in the wake of the terror attack.

A CETRA official said that from November, a total of 156 delegations will take part in trade fairs or will sponsor investment seminars in countries in the targeted regions, while CETRA will also dispatch 34 trade-promotion missions to the United States -- Taiwan's largest export outlet -- within the next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEGOTIATIONS NEEDED FOR TAIWAN FLIGHTS OVER MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Taipei needs to negotiate with Beijing on the issue about flights by Taiwan-based aviation companies through the airspace of mainland China, Transportation and Communications Minister Yeh Chu-lan was quoted as saying Wednesday.

Government Information Office Director-General Su Tzen-ping quoted Yeh as saying at a news conference following a Cabinet meeting that the issue needs to be discussed by the governments or official authorities on the two sides, as Taiwan has not inked any aviation agreement with mainland China.

The legislature approved a non-binding resolution a day earlier demanding that the government permit applications by Taiwan-based carriers to fly over the airspace of mainland China en route to Europe in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks against the United States.

Following the attacks last month, the International Civil Aviation Organization proposed that aviation companies use the "L888" route through the airspace of mainalnd China for their flights to Europe, rather than the usual route that overflys South Asia.
Vice Transportation and Communications Minister Chang Chia-chu said national carriers can apply for the L888 route if they think it is necessary.

But he pointed out that his ministry will be able to handle relevant matters only after the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) agrees that such flights will not violate the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.

According to the law, airplanes of Taiwan-based aviation companies are not allowed to fly over the mainland, Chang said, adding, however, that it is up to the MAC to decide whether such flights are illegal under the current circumstances.

Chang noted that his ministry will help local carriers resolve technical problems regarding the issue after the MAC -- the top government agency in charge of charting Taiwan's policy toward mainland China -- gives the nod and clarifies whether negotiations with Beijing are mandatory.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO CHAIR AD HOC TASK FORCE ON GOVERNMENT RESTRUCTURING

TEXT.P: The chairman of the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) said Wednesday that an ad hoc task force on government reform to be headed by the president will focus initially on the slimming down of government agencies.

Lin Chia-cheng said while reporting to the Legislative Yuan's Organic Laws Committee that the RDEC has already established the goal of cutting one-third of the existing government ministries and agencies so that only 21 will remain after the first phase of the massive government streamlining project is completed.

Lin said that four other special organs, including the Central Bank of China and the National Palace Museum, will remain intact, but he added that it is too early to tell how many government employees will be downsized in the restructuring.

A draft amendment to the Organic Law of the Executive Yuan will be completed by the RDEC in March, with a Cabinet-approved version to be delivered to the Legislative Yuan for deliberation and ratification by the end of April 2002, he added.

Lin said that the provisional Government Restructuring Committee will be formally established Wednesday with President Chen Shui-bian at its head because "only the president has the authority to coordinate the five yuans."
Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, who heads the Executive Yuan, and Examination Yuan President Hsu Shui-teh will serve on the committee as vice chairmen.
Presidential Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun will serve as convener of the committee staff, while Lin will be the staff's executive secretary.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSTRUCTION BEGINS ON KAOHSIUNG MASS RAPID TRANSIT SYSTEM

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government held a ground-breaking ceremony attended by President Chen Shui-bian Wednesday for the southern Taiwan city's first mass rapid transit (MRT) system.

Kaohsiung City Mayor Frank Hsieh noted at the ceremony that while the MRT system for Kaohsiung has been in the planning stages since 1990, construction has never been started, which has negatively affected the development and employment rates of Kaohsiung and southern Taiwan.

Fortunately, he added, the Kaohsiung City Council passed the budget for the MRT system two years ago, so that together with the big support provided by the central government, Kaohsiung City finally will have its own MRT system.
Also speaking at the ceremony, Chen said that the Kaohsiung MRT system should be attributed to Hsieh's efforts and Kaohsiung city council's passing of the budget.
He added that he envisages a bright future for Kaohsiung after the completion of the MRT system.
The system is designed to integrate high-speed and regular railway and city bus systems, providing a comprehensive mass transportation network, according to Hsieh.
Wednesday's ceremony was to mark the start of construction of the system's red and orange lines, which are estimated to cost NT$170 billion (US$5 billion), while other lines are also being planned.
Construction of the red and orange lines, to be conducted by a Taiwanese engineering company and a Japanese engineering company, is expected to be completed in three years and four months.
The red line will span a length of 28.3 kilometers with 23 stations, while the orange line will have a length of 14.4 kilometers with 14 stations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 25, or the ninth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1825: The Erie Canal, which connects the Great Lakes with New York City via the Hudson River, is opened, assuring the future prosperity of the upper Midwest region of the United States.
1825: Austrian composer Johann Strauss the Younger is born. He is best known for his waltzes, such as the ever-popular "The Blue Danube," and for operettas such as "Die Fledermaus."
1881: Pablo Picasso, Spanish painter, sculptor, graphic artist, ceramist, and designer, is born. He became one of the greatest and most versatile 20th-century artists.
1909: Prince Ito Hirobumi, former Japanese premier and resident-general in Korea, is assassinated by a Korean nationalist.
1914: Dr. Sun Yat-sen, founding father of the Republic of China, marries Soong Ching-ling in Tokyo, Japan.
1928: The Republic of China Nationalist government begins to implement the five-yuan system -- Executive Yuan (the Cabinet), Legislative Yuan, Judicial Yuan, Examination Yuan, and Control Yuan.
1936: Leaders from Germany and Italy meet to form the Berlin-Rome Axis, providing mutual assistance and opposition to communism.
1938: Chinese troops evacuate Wuchang and Hankow during the War of Resistance against Japan.
1938: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini formally declares Libya a part of Italy after years of slowly colonizing the country.
1945: Taiwan is formally retroceded to China after 50 years of Japanese occupation. Chen Yi receives the formal surrender of Japanese rulers at a ceremony held at the Chung Shan Hall. The Nationalist government declares Oct. 25 as Taiwan Retrocession Day.
1945: In order to obstruct ROC troops from entering Manchuria, the Soviet Union "voluntarily" pulls out its garrison troops from Yingkow, and allows Chinese communist troops to occupy the city in southern Liaoning Province.
1949: ROC government troops win a victory at Kinmen against a communist Chinese attack.
1950: Beijing launches a movement to resist U.S. aggression and to aid North Korea and Chinese communist "volunteer-troops" formally entering North Korea to join the Korean War.
1951: The Korean conflict truce talks, which began July 10 at Kaesong after Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, acting on instructions from Washington, suggested a meeting between Allied and communist military officers to discuss a truce, are moved to Panmunjom.
1952: The United States blocks communist China's entry into the United Nations for the third year in a row.
1966: The first open school in Taiwan is inaugurated at the Provincial Taipei College of Business.
1976: An eight-member ROC delegation leaves for the United States to attend the first World Conference on Agricultural Education for Youth and Adult Leaders.
1979: Military personnel and civilians on Kinmen celebrate the 30th anniversary of the Kuningtou victory.
1985: The Taiwan Provincial Government decides to implement health insurance for farmers.
1986: Madame Chiang Kai-shek returns from the United States for a celebration to mark the centennial anniversary of the birth of the late president.
1988: A comprehensive farmer health insurance plan is initiated in Taiwan.
1996: Israel begins redeployment of its West Bank troops to further a peace deal with the Palestine Liberation Organization.
1999: Former U.S. Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger says in Taipei that Taiwan should make its own decisions and the United States has the obligation to help Taiwan with its defense capabilities.
2000: National Science Council Chairman Weng Cheng-i says that the ROC will gradually open its doors wider to mainland Chinese science-technology professionals.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "A great man is one who has not lost the child's heart."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR INTER-PARTY COOPERATION AT RETROCESSION DAY RALLY

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung on Thursday urged all the major domestic political parties to promote inter-party cooperation instead of confrontation in order to upgrade Taiwan's national competitiveness.
Chang made the appeal at a rally in Chunghsing Village in the central Taiwan county of Nantou in celebration of the 56th anniversary of the island's Retrocession Day.

"Today marks the first Taiwan Retrocession Day in the 21st century," Chang said, adding that he hopes major domestic political parties refrain from partisan wrangling and work together to sustain Taiwan's economic growth.

Chang said although Taiwan has made admirable achievements in economic development and political democratization in the past half century, it has yet to forge a viable or mature mechanism for constructive inter-party engagements due to more than five decades of one-party rule.

Noting that the island's first-ever transition of power between different political parties in May 2000 ushered in a new era in Taiwan's political history, Chang said political parties can compete for taking the helm of the nation.

"Nevertheless, all parties should cooperate in addressing issues related to economic development, foreign relations and other subjects that concern overall national interests," Chang said, adding that all domestic parties should "feather nests" instead of "erect walls" among them in order to enhance communication and mutual trust.

Chang went on to say that Taiwan used to be known as "Ilha Formosa," or a "beautiful island," but over exploitation of land and water resources over the past five decades has damaged its ecological system and natural environment.

"A spate of disasters caused by landslides or mudslides signal a `protest' by Mother Nature," Chang said, adding that "we must do some soul searching while working on various post-disaster rehabilitation programs, and we should devote more energy to reforestation work."

On the economic front, Chang admitted that Taiwan's economy is not in good shape. "Amid a lingering global economic slowdown," the premier said, "our economy has taken a serious downturn and the unemployment rate has continued to rise."

In this time of economic hardship, Chang said, the people of Taiwan should not lose confidence in the government's determination to rev up the sluggish economy. "The government will continue to increase public investment to create new job openings and make every possible effort to improve the investment climate," he pledged.
Touching on the upcoming elections for legislators, city mayors and county magistrates, Chang said the Dec. 1 elections are critical to Taiwan's political reform.

"Law enforcement authorities will step up their crackdown on vote-buying and organized crime in the run-up to the elections," Chang said, adding that the government will spare no efforts in ensuring that the first elections following last year's transfer of power from the Kuomintang to the Democratic Progressive Party are clean, fair, just and violence-free.
Retrocession Day marks the restoration of Taiwan to Chinese rule on Oct. 25, 1945, after half a century of Japanese occupation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher on Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for November moved up 32 points to close at 3,988, with 17,294 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for December rose 4 points to finish at 3,968, with 27 contract transactions, while next June futures increased 45 points to finish at 4,025, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 3,956 for November, 3,964 for December, 3,979 for next March, 3,980 for next June, and 4,001 for next September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
November TE futures edged up 0.6 points to close at 193.3, with 3,410 contract transactions, while December TE futures increased 0.7 points to finish at 192.7, with 10 contracts traded.
Next September TE futures lost 3.2 points to finish at 191.8, with 27 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.
November TF futures moved down 6 points to finish at 610, with 2,199 contract transactions, while December TF futures rose 6.4 points to close at 616.4, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR CLOSES UNCHANGED ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar closed unchanged at 34.545 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Thursday.
The local currency opened Thursday at 34.533 and was traded between 34.517 and 34.550.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$273 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: "HONG KONG'S DREAM IS DYING" SAYS ASIAWEEK

TEXT.P: The Hong Kong dream is dying, Asiaweek executive editor Richard Hornik and correspondent Crystyl Mo wrote in the latest issue of the weekly magazine.

In an article on the latest woes that Hong Kong is facing, Hornik and Mo said the negative equity scandal in the city is currently eating away at the heart of its middle class, adding that the scandal serves as yet another example of the constant parade of mini-crises to hit Hong Kong since its reunification with mainland China in 1997.

As many as 200,000 Hong Kong families now owe more on their properties than they are presently worth, they wrote, adding that the problem is more pervasive than a lousy real estate market. It also involves a continuing perception that the government thinks that what's good for Hong Kong's business tycoons is good for the city.

"While this paradigm worked during the time of the British and even up to the last decade, economic shifts favoring cheaper South China cities in Guangdong Province are changing all the rules," they wrote.

However, they added, economists point to the city's proximity to southern China as Hong Kong's number one asset, along with its sophisticated mass of human capital. Moreover, the city remains Asia's financial capital and maintains the leading container port. If one adds the city's generally independent legal system, then Hong Kong is poised to reinvent itself as mainland China enters the WTO era, they wrote.

"The final wrinkle, however, may be one of identity", they pointed out, adding that a recent opinion poll found that less than 20 percent of high school students think of themselves as Chinese, leading Hong Kong observers to question how well the city can integrate itself with the mainland.
"But as one Hong Kong expert explains, Hong Kong's salvation may be its unsentimental willingness to change," they concluded. (Stanley Cheung)

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJORITY OF PEOPLE SUPPORT PROBE INTO SOURCES OF KMT ASSETS: POLL

TEXT.P: The majority of respondents to a recent poll support a Cabinet proposal to pass a special law that would allow a probe into the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) huge party assets, according to the results of the poll released Thursday.

The telephone survey of 1,065 randomly chosen adult residents was conducted by the weekly magazine Open from Oct. 15-17 with the aim of exploring public opinion on the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-led government's recent decision to draft a special bill to pave the way for a probe into the sources of the KMT's wealth.
The poll results show that 61.5 percent of the respondents gave a thumbs-up to the Cabinet proposal.

Moreover, 68.86 percent said they believe that at least some of the KMT assets were acquired by illegal means, while 44.68 percent of those interviewed said they think that more than half of the KMT's fortune was snatched illegally.

In addition, 41.58 percent said they believe that investigating the sources of the party's assets would benefit all of the people of Taiwan, although 29.63 percent said they think that such a move would most benefit the ruling DPP.

Nevertheless, 60.66 percent also agreed with the view that the Cabinet's plan to look into sources of the KMT's assets is mainly a campaign strategy in the run-up to the Dec. 1 elections for legislators, city mayors and county magistrates.
Meanwhile, 47.93 percent of the survey respondents said they do not think any of the country's political parties are especially clean or non-corrupt.

In comparison, 58.24 percent said they think that the KMT, which ruled Taiwan for 55 years until May 2000, is most corrupt; followed by the DPP (16.95 percent), the People First Party (4.6 percent), the newly formed Taiwan Solidarity Union (1.82 percent) and the New Party (0.77 percent).
The KMT is considered to be the world's wealthiest political party, with assets estimated at anything between US$6.7 billion and US$16 billion.
Analyzing the survey results, DPP Legislative Whip Tsai Huang-lang urged the KMT to respond to public opinion and voluntarily return its "illegally" acquired party assets to the national coffers.

Tsai said that as the KMT still controls the majority of the seats in the legislature, it will not be an easy task to pass a special law to provide a legal framework for a probe into the KMT's assets.

Quoting the survey results, Wang Tan-ping, chief executive of the KMT's policy research department, pointed out that more than 60 percent of the survey respondents regard the proposal to probe the KMT's assets as "yet another of the DPP's campaign tricks."

In response, DPP legislators Parris Chang and Yeh Yi-chin said that is irrelevant and that "most important point is that the majority of the people back the proposal to probe the legality of the KMT assets."

DOC.HEADLINE: VISITING INDIAN TRADE MISSION HOLDS TRADE TALKS WITH LOCAL DEALERS

TEXT.P: A visiting Indian trade mission made up of 40-plus members met with Taiwan trade officials and traders Thursday for business talks at the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) building.
The Indian trade mission arrived in Taipei Wednesday for trade talks under the co-sponsorship of the CETRA Office in Bombay and the India-Taipei Association in Taipei.

S.K. Verma, director of the India-Taipei Association (ITA) in Taipei, and Chang Shih-chang, director of the CETRA Office in Bombay, attended the talks. More than 100 local traders also took part in the meeting.

Chang said that the Indian traders in the mission mostly come from Bombay's Maharashtra district, the financial center of the city, adding that they are interested in purchasing machine tools, agricultural machines, semi-manufactured chemicals and electronics.

Chang pointed out that the there is potential for Taiwan manufacturers and business firms to increase their sales in the Indian market, noting that India's gross domestic product growth for this year is expected to hit 6 percent despite the global economic slowdown.

Taiwan exported US$474 million worth of goods to India and imported US$382 million of goods in the first nine months of this year, representing a 14.3 percent drop in exports but a 0.9 percent increase in imports over the same period in the previous year. S.K. Verma said that although two-way trade between Taiwan and India has decreased slightly, it has remained stable compared with trade with other regions.
The Indian official also called on local traders to grab the opportunity to tap the Indian market in the wake of the United States lifting its trade sanctions imposed on India and Pakistan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMY COULD REBOUND IN 2ND QUARTER NEXT YEAR: THINK TANK

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy could start to rebound in the second quarter of next year and see an obvious recovery in the second half of next year, the head of a local think tank said Thursday.

Wu Rong-i, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER), said that in the wake of the terrorist attacks in the United States, there are uncertain factors in the world economy and added that the length of the military campaign in Afghanistan will be crucial to the global economic recovery.
Wu predicted that the war will not last too long and that it will not expand further. He also pointed out that the key to Taiwan's recovery hinges on when the U.S. economy will rebound.

Wu also said that as the military campaign against terrorism continues, the U.S. dollar could soften and he did not rule out the possibility that the Taiwan dollar will appreciate against the greenback, although such a rise would be modest. However, he added that the local currency could depreciate in the short term.

On interest rates, Wu also said that although short term interest rates have dropped to a historic low, the domestic economy is still poor and he predicted that Taiwan's interest rate will continue to be low.
He said that with the sluggish economy and high unemployment, the government can only expand public expenditure to help stimulate private investment.
Wu also said that as people tend to deal with pay cuts by not spending, the government should distribute "purchasing coupons" to the public to increase consumption.

He said that after the Economic Development Advisory Conference, the nation reached a consensus on domestic economic issues and confidence in the nation returned. However, he expressed regret that the terrorist attacks on the United States have had a negative impact on good economic prospects.

TIER officials also unveiled the results of a survey on domestic manufacturers, which show that the number of respondents who predicted that the economy will improve in the next six months decreased to 14.9 percent from 18.7 percent in the previous month, while those who think the economy will worsen increased to 38 percent from 22.9 percent in the previous month.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CONDUCTS DEFENSIVE EXERCISE AGAINST CHEMICAL ATTACKS

TEXT.P: Government agencies mobilized over 1,000 military, medical, police and environmental protection personnel Thursday in their second joint exercise staged at a Taipei subway station to simulate possible responses against a chemical attack.
Hau Lung-bin, who heads the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA), oversaw the 90-minute drill.

He said that the primary objective was to familiarize the public with the necessary measures to take, while government agencies were given the opportunity to rehearse their coordination with each other in the event of such an emergency.
The exercise began when a mock terrorist released an unknown toxic gas in the passenger compartment of a subway train at the Hsiaonanmen Station of the Taipei Mass Rapid Transit system.
When mock commuters began suffering from signs of gas poisoning, police and medical personnel were called in to conduct first-aid and carry out an evacuation.

Meanwhile, emergency teams from the EPA, the Department of Health and the chemical warfare branch of the military determined the type of gas used in the attack, raced to neutralize the threat and sanitized the station.
A similar exercise was conducted last Friday, but on a smaller scale. About 500 people took part in that drill.

President Chen Shui-bian urged relevant government agencies Monday to heighten their level of alertness to all possible forms of terrorist biochemical warfare and to take effective steps to help enhance public awareness of the anthrax threat.
Chen gave the directives after presiding over a fourth high-level national security meeting regarding the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States.
In addition to staging drills and intensifying the campaign to inform the public, he said, the government should start evaluating and planning vaccine purchases and supply sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE OVERSEAS CHINESE STUDENTS APPLYING TO STUDY IN TAIWAN: OCAC

TEXT.P: An official of the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) said Thursday that the number of overseas Chinese students applying to study in Taiwan is increasing year by year.

Statistics compiled by OCAC show that 9,357 overseas Chinese students came to Taiwan to receive higher education in the 1998 academic year. The number increased to 10,566 in the 1999 academic year and again to 11,033 in 2000.

The official attributed the increase to the fact that local universities and colleges are offering more vacancies for overseas Chinese students, coupled with the efforts by the Education Ministry and OCAC to promote Taiwan education.

Meanwhile, in order to promote international academic exchanges and strengthen student exchanges between Taiwan and foreign countries, OCAC has helped local universities enter cooperation agreements with universities in foreign countries. Under this program, foreign students can apply to study in Taiwan universities from third year and can obtain a bachelor's degree after finishing a four-year course.

At present, Ming Chuan University, Shih Hsin University, National Chi Nan University and Chao Yang University of Science and Technology are engaged in cooperation programs with universities in Malaysia.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN HAILS TSMC NEW INVESTMENT PLANS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday he is very pleased to learn that Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC) has decided to launch new investment plans at two of the island's high-tech industrial parks.
Chen made the remarks during a visit to the TSMC's newest manufacturing facility in the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park in southern Taiwan.
"The TSMC's new investment plans manifest its support for the government's ambitious bid to develop Taiwan into a regional operation hub," Chen said.

Noting that Taiwan still enjoys competitive edges in the high-tech industry development, Chen said local businesses and individual people should remain confident in the island's developmental potential, despite current domestic woes.
Chen said his administration will make every possible effort to improve the domestic investment climate and drop all unnecessary restrictions and improper interferences in economic activities.
"By so doing," Chen said, "we hope to create an environment where all enterprises can exercise their vitality and creativity freely and fully to enhance their competitiveness in the global market."
Based on Taiwan's current high-tech basis, Chen said, the government intends to nurture even more creative and productive new enterprises.

Touching on the government's policy toward trade and economic ties with mainland China, Chen said his administration has replaced the "no haste, be patient" policy with a more positive approach -- "active opening and effective management."

"The policy adjustment was based on the principles of 'Taiwan first,' 'economy first' and the demand of domestic enterprises," Chen explained, adding that mainland China would be part of Taiwan's global development plan.

Chen also lauded the TSMC for its completion of a professional study which confirms that, through engineering technology, the effects of vibrations from a high-speed railway project near the Tainan science park on microchip fabrication can be eliminated.
TSMC is the world's leading microchip foundry service. Chen said he hopes that the TSMC's study would help lure investors back to the southern Taiwan high-tech industrial stronghold.
Several local semiconductor manufacturing firms have shelved their investment plans in the Tainan industrial park over concerns regarding possible vibrations from the high-speed railway project.

TSMC was among the first group of local enterprises to build production facilities in the Tainan park. Its first chip factory in the park began volume production in January 1999. Construction of its second plant in the Tainan park for 8-inch wafer fabrication was suspended earlier this year over vibration concerns.
TSMC Chairman Morris Chang announced in a speech welcoming Chen's visit that construction on the new plant has resumed after the study confirmed the viability of its investment plan in the park.

In the past, Chang said, TSMC focused its investments in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in northern Taiwan. As the park has reached its capacity, he said, the company has decided to make the Tainan park its most important site for its future semiconductor production in Taiwan.

Chang further said Taiwan has proven itself to be a suitable location for semiconductor manufacturing. "As long as corporate enterprises and the government continue to work together, Taiwan will maintain its competitive edge in the world market."

Speaking on the same occasion, TSMC Deputy Chief Executive Officer F. C. Tseng said TAMC will invest up to NT$700 billion (US$20.29 billion) over the next 10 to 15 years in building five 12-inch wafer plants in the Tainan parks and a new 12-inch wafer factory in the Hsinchu park.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CATHOLICS HOPE TO SERVE AS BRIDGE BETWEEN VATICAN, BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: Vatican City, Oct. 24 (CNA) (By Tony Feng & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Republic of China envoy to the Vatican Raymond Tai said Wednesday that the government hopes that the Roman Catholic Church in Taiwan can serve as a bridge between the Vatican and Beijing to jointly help Catholics in mainland China regain religious freedom.

Tai was in Vatican City to take part in a congress to commemorate the fourth centenary of the arrival in Beijing of Jesuit missionary Matteo Ricci. The congress was sponsored by the Italian-Sino Association.
Tai made the remarks after Pope John Paul II asked Beijing in a historic statement to forgive "errors" committed by the Roman Catholic Church.

The pontiff's statement continued: "The failings of the church may have given the impression of a lack of respect and esteem for the Chinese people on the part of the catholic church, making them feel that the church was motivated by feelings of hostility toward China."

Tai expressed his gratitude to the pontiff for his sincerity in attempting to resolve the historic and cultural conflicts existing between the Roman Catholic Church and the Chinese people and expressed hope that Chinese around the world will regard the pontiff's statement as an act of goodwill.
He added that the ROC government and people would be happy to see the Vatican and Beijing resume dialogue, as it would help to promote religious freedom in the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: FPG TO ADOPT SPENDING-CUT PLAN TO REDUCE COSTS

TEXT.P: Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) -- Taiwan's largest petrochemical company -- said Thursday that a spending-cut plan drawn up in an effort to slash costs will help it save NT$5 billion to NT$7 billion each year.

FPG management said the plan will mainly focus on high-ranking staff, whose special annual bonus payments, usually distributed in July and representing about 40 percent of their annual salaries, will be cut by 20 percent from next year. Meanwhile, a cost-controlling measure has been implemented with the aim of reducing overtime payments by encouraging workers to take turns on duty.
A high-ranking FPG official said that the current recession is the most severe in Taiwan's history and added that it is difficult to predict when business conditions will improve.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRANCE URGED TO ISSUE VISA TO ROC PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Oct. 24 (CNA) (By James Kuo and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Germany's Free Democratic Party (FDP) caucus issued a press release Wednesday urging France to issue a visa to Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian so that he can visit Strasbourg to receive a human rights award.

The French government declined to grant Chen a visa that would have allowed him to travel to Strasbourg to receive an award from Liberal International (LI), which has aroused the attention of some European democratic parties.

Ulrich Irmer, speaker of the FDP caucus on foreign policy in Bundestag, issued the press release via its website, in which he said Taiwan, after a tremendous change in political and social aspects during the last 18 months, can serve as a model for dictatorships in some developing countries.

He noted that Chen, who assumed his post in May last year, has been active in promoting human rights and striving to ease the tension between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, which is why he won the LI Prize for Freedom.

Taiwan has transformed from a one-party authoritarian political system to a pluralistic and democratic society; the evidence was seen in its elections, which allowed Taiwan to achieve political democratization and saw opposition leader Chen Shui-bian elected president, Irmer said.
He urged all democratic countries to recognize Taiwan's democracy and support Chen's continued promotion of democratic reforms.

Referring to the French government's reported refusal to grant Chen a visa, Irmer also urged France, which he described as a European vanguard in liberty, human rights and democracy, to show a cooperative attitude.
LI, based in London, is an alliance of more than 80 liberal political parties from more than 60 countries.
Previous winners of the LI Prize for Freedom include Burmese opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi, Algerian women's rights campaigner Khalida Messaoudi and Czech President Vaclav Havel.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION ALLIANCE AIMS TO TAKE TAIPEI COUNTY IN ELECTIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei County, northern Taiwan, Oct. 25 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Several opposition heavyweights stumped Thursday for Wang Chien-shien, the candidate for the "pan-blue alliance" running for the post of Taipei county magistrate in the year-end elections.

The "pan-blue alliance" refers to a cooperative strategy among the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), the New Party (NP), and the People First Party (PFP) to select joint candidates for the Dec. 1 local and legislative elections.

Wang's campaign headquarters were inaugurated Thursday in Panchiao City, Taipei County, in a ceremony attended by KMT Vice Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, PFP Secretary-General Chung Jung-chi and eight other candidates nominated by the KMT, the PFP and the NP.
The Democratic Progressive Party has been the ruling power in Taipei County for the last 12 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT WILLING TO SEEK NORMALIZATION OF TAIPEI-BEIJING TIES

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said in an interview published Thursday in the London-based Financial Times that he is willing to jointly seek the normalization of Taipei-Beijing ties with his mainland Chinese counterpart.

According to an ROC Government Information Office news release, in his interview in the Taiwan Survey -- one of approximately 240 surveys published by the Financial Times annually -- Chen said that any move toward normalization would have to be made under the principles of democracy, fairness and peace and carried out with wisdom and creativity under "existing foundations."
Chen added that he also hopes to jointly find a mutually acceptable definition for the so-called "one China" issue.
The freedom of choice of the 23 million people in Taiwan must be respected and both sides should be accorded equal status and must not threaten the other through force or violence, he went on.

Chen said that an improvement in bilateral ties must start with the establishment of stable cross-Taiwan Strait relations. In the short term, he continued, there might not be a breakthrough. However, he added that stabilizing the current relationship so that it does not continue to deteriorate would be a "good beginning."

He said that Taiwan's accomplishments, such as its democratization and the first peaceful transfer of political power to an opposition party, will "undoubtedly" become a beacon that will guide mainland China toward democratization and modernization.

In regard to bilateral trade, Chen said that the mainland Chinese market must be viewed as a part of the global market. Therefore, he said, the "no haste, be patient" regulatory policy for Taiwanese investment in the mainland must be replaced by an "active opening, effective management" policy based on the principles of "Taiwan first, global perspective, common interests and crisis management."
This year's Taiwan Survey was the fifth consecutive annual survey on Taiwan published by the newspaper.

DOC.HEADLINE: BROADCAST FEES FOR WORLD CUP BASEBALL TOTAL US $ 1.27 MILLION

TEXT.P: An official of the Chinese Taipei Baseball Association announced Thursday that domestic and overseas broadcasting rights for the 34th Baseball World Cup will cost a total of more than US$1.27 million.

Lin Chung-cheng, secretary-general of the Chinese Taipei Baseball Association, said that domestic broadcasting fees are lower, at NT$9.5 million (US$273,775) and will be shared by three local TV stations -- Chinese Television System, Videoland Inc. and TVBS.
Dentsu Inc. of Japan won the US$1 million overseas broadcasting rights and TV stations in Cuba, Panama, Japan and South Korea have contacted Dentsu for broadcasting rights.

Sixteen countries -- the United States, France, Canada, Italy, the Netherlands, South Africa, Russia, Japan, South Korea, the Philippines, Australia, Panama, Nicaragua, Dominica, Cuba and host Taiwan will take part in the 34th Baseball World Cup, which will take place in stadiums in Taipei, Chiayi and Kaohsiung Dec. 6-18.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOCIAL WELFARE SPENDING ON TAIWAN WOMEN LESS THAN NT$100 EACH

TEXT.P: Each of Taiwan's adult women received only an average NT$94.2 in social welfare benefits in cities and counties across the island in 2000, according to a report released Thursday.

According to the report compiled by the Civil Social Welfare Promotion Task Force, which was formed by various social welfare organizations, Taoyuan County allocated the highest amount of NT$127 million for women's welfare spending last year, accounting for 3.87 percent of the county's total social welfare spending.
Hsinchu County ranked second with an allocation of NT$85.7 million, which represents in turn the highest ratio of 13.65 percent as a percentage to the county's total social welfare expenditure.

Calculating at the standard 5 percent set by the central government, Hsinchu County is the only local government to have surpassed the lowest level, the report said, adding that 10 other counties and cities failed to reach even 1 percent.
Changhua County sat at the bottom, having earmarked only NT$9.8 -- or 0.14 percent of the total -- for each of its female adult citizens, ahead of Taichung City's NT$13.4, according to the report.

The report said the rating was made to demonstrate that Taiwan women's welfare rights are seriously ignored by the authorities and it urged the government to improve the situation by increasing professional personnel and budgets in line with the growth rate of the female population.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE TO MOSCOW MEETS TREKKERS FROM TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Moscow, Oct. 24 (CNA) (By Chang Hung-kuang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Representative to Moscow Charles King met Wednesday with three trekkers from Taiwan who had just completed a 1,300-km trip across Russia on foot.
King praised Lai Hsin-hung, Chen Chung-jen and Chou Yen-ni for their perseverance in completing the trip despite encountering hardships.

The trio left Moscow at the end of September by train for the border of Russia and Georgia. From there, they walked to the Russian-Ukraine border, tracing the route of the western expedition by Mongolian conqueror Genghis Khan (1167-1227).
They reached Moscow after completing the 1,300-km trip on the night of Oct. 23.
At one point during the trip, the trio said that local policemen mistook them for spies and Chen was detained at a police office. He was released after his identity was confirmed.
After a few days of rest in Moscow, the expedition will depart again for Ukraine to continue tracing the route of Genghis Khan's expedition.
The event is being sponsored by the ROC Mountain and River Expedition Association.
The expedition in Ukraine will be completed Nov. 21 and a group of supporters from Taiwan will fly there in November to join the trio during the last stage of the trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO FOREIGN ORGANIZATIONS HAVE RECEIVED SUSPECT MAIL in ROC: MOFA

TEXT.P: No foreign organizations in Taiwan have received letters or packages containing substances bearing any resemblance to anthrax spores, a spokeswoman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.

Chang Siao-yue said at a regular weekly news conference that her ministry had checked with foreign organizations reported by local press to have taken delivery of questionable letters or packages and was told that no suspicious substances were discovered.

Nevertheless, she went on, the Foreign Ministry, which has kept close contact with foreign organizations in Taiwan since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York and Washington, has been working with police to step up security at local foreign organizations.
She made the comments to dismiss local media reports that the trade offices of South Korea, India and German had received letters containing questionable substances.
Meanwhile, a police officer in Taipei said a suspicious package sent to the German trade office in Taipei the day before yesterday had proved to be a hoax.
The package, bearing a Canadian postmark, raised the suspicions of the staff at the German trade office because it had no return address and they called in police to investigate.
The officer, who asked not to be named, refused to reveal the contents of the package, but admitted that a police explosives team was sent to the trade office.
Since the package came from overseas, the police said they could do nothing but ask the related foreign authorities for help in tracing its source.
The local media reported earlier in the day that questionable white powder had been found in at least nine letters sent to the South Korean and Indian trade offices in Taipei, respectively.
The two countries' trade offices are located in the Taipei World Trade Center and two of the suspicious letters were sent from Pintung, southern Taiwan, to the presidents of each country.

All the letters were sent to local health agencies for testing and health officials said it takes 24 hours to ascertain whether the white substance is the feared anthrax spores, according to the reports.
Local press reports also said that a package delivered to the Israeli trade office in Taipei, which is also in the trade center, was sent to police that same day for investigation.
The reports quoted Chou Jung-kuang, manager of the Taipei World Trade Center, as saying that the package contained unidentified pieces of metal.

DOC.HEADLINE: CATHOLIC OFFICIAL URGES NO `POLITICIZATION' OF PONTIFF'S STATEMENT

TEXT.P: A Catholic official on Thursday urged the public to be open-minded and not to politicize a recent statement by Pope John Paul II at a symposium in Rome.

John B. Wu, secretary-general of the Chinese Regional Bishops' Conference, said that the pontiff's statement Wednesday in which he "asked forgiveness" for past "errors" in mainland China should not be construed as the possible impending establishment of diplomatic relations between the Vatican and Beijing.

The pope's statement was read at the Oct. 24-25 symposium, which was sponsored by Italian-Chinese Institute to commemorate the fourth centenary of the arrival in Beijing of Jesuit missionary Matteo Ricci.

The pontiff said that he feels "deep sadness for the errors of the past" and regrets that "in many people, this feeling may have given the impression of lack of respect and esteem for Chinese people on the part of the Roman Catholic Church, making them feel that the church was motivated by feelings of hostility toward Chinese."
"For all of this, I ask the forgiveness and understanding of those who may have felt hurt in some way by such actions" on the part of Christians, the pontiff said in his statement.
Local media immediately asked if the pontiff's statement will have nay impact on the Republic of China's relations with the Vatican, the ROC's only ally in Europe.

Wu said that as there are millions of Catholics in the mainland, the pontiff's statement was aimed only at expressing goodwill toward the Beijing authorities for the welfare and rights of Catholics in the mainland.

He noted that it was the first time that the pope had spoken openly of errors and had asked for forgiveness as the leader of the Catholic Church, adding that his "wise approach," despite the lack of communication and dialogue channels between the Vatican and Beijing, should win kudos from the world.
Addressing concerns as to whether the Vatican and Beijing will establish diplomatic relations, Wu also said the key lies not in the Vatican, but in Beijing.
He said that communism is already bankrupt and that if Beijing continues to maintain a tough attitude, the pontiff's goodwill or sincerity will not do any good.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH COURT ACQUITS BROTHER-IN-LAW OF FORMER MOST-WANTED FUGITIVE

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court Thursday acquitted the brother-in-law of former most-wanted fugitive Chen Chin-hsing of charges that he served as Chen's accomplice in the 1997 murder of the 17-year-old daughter of TV celebrity Pai Ping-ping.

In what was the second retrial for Chang's case, the court overturned a previous life imprisonment sentence that was handed down in the Taiwan High Court's second trial in September 1998 and upheld in the subsequent first retrial.

On Thursday, the court returned to the original ruling of not guilty handed down by the Taipei District Court, saying that police evidence and Chang's confessions -- which he said were extracted under torture by investigators -- did not corroborate with each other.

Chang, who has been detained for over three years, was released immediately after his acquittal but forbidden to relocate his residence. He thanked the judge for "carefully investigating" his case and said that he will go home to help his mother run her business.
Prosecutors have the right to file another appeal against the latest ruling.
In April 1997, Pai Hsiao-yen was kidnapped and killed after days of torture by Chen and accomplices Lin Chun-sheng and Kao Tien-min.
Chang was accused of guarding and torturing the teen and assisting in disposing of her body after Chen had murdered her.
Chen was executed in October 1999, while both Lin and Kao killed themselves during separate shootouts with police in late 1997.
Chen's wife Chang Su-chen was sentenced to nine months imprisonment for hiding her husband when he was on the run.

Chen had also been responsible for the kidnapping of a Taipei county councilor in June 1997, the abduction of a businessman in August that same year, the murder of a plastic surgeon, his wife and a nurse at the surgeon's clinic in October, and the hostage-taking of the family of South African military attache Col. McGill Alexander in November, when he finally surrendered after a 24-hour standoff with the police.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER U.S. VICE PRESIDENT GORE SAID TO VISIT TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) was probing foreign wire service reports Thursday that said former U.S. Vice President Al Gore will visit Taipei in early November.
However, MOFA spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue said that MOFA was unable to confirm the report.

According to a foreign wire service, Gore will visit the Republic of China Nov. 9 at the invitation of a religious group in Taiwan. He is expected to deliver a keynote speech at a seminar on how to safeguard the holy sites of the world's religions.
The report also mentioned that Gore attended an illegal fund-raiser sponsored by a Taiwan religious group during last year's U.S. election campaign, which caused heated debate among the U.S. media.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMICS CALL FOR BAN ON ELECTION CANDIDATES AS TV HOSTS

TEXT.P: A group of academics called Thursday for politicians who have entered the race for the year-end elections to stop serving as television talk show hosts or hostesses.

The academics, who described themselves as an independent watchdog of the local mass media, are mainly members of the Formosa Professor's Association, which is a group friendly to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

They unveiled a list of local politicians who are either frequent guests or who actually host television talk shows, blaming them for what they called "skewing television broadcasts in their own favor."

National Taiwan University Professor Lee Yung-chih said those politicians have turned their TV appearances into free TV campaign advertisements by pitching their "twisted" political views or canvassing votes for themselves.
Under their manipulation, Lee said, the local media has been debased into the political mouthpieces of a cluster of politicians rather than an independent "fourth estate."
This, Lee said, is unfair for other candidates who have little access to television or broadcasting and represents abuse of the mass media.

Besides appealing to media owners to shut these biased politicians out of their studios, Lee said his group is calling for the enactment of bills requiring television program hosts or hostesses to quit their jobs once they register as candidates for public office.
Lee said his group also urged the national security agencies to determine whether Beijing is pulling the strings behind Taiwan's media.
Politicians who were accused by the group of airing their political prejudices on TV are chiefly candidates from opposition parties, with the exception of two DPP candidates.

The group also warned the public to exercise great caution when tuning in to programs hosted by Li Ao and Sisy Chen in particular, claiming that their programs are "extremely biased." According to the group, these presenters are "known" for "excoriating the government" or "pouring political satire on the DPP leaders" in their programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: INT'L MEDIA EXPRESS CONCERN OVER TAIWAN'S ABSENCE FROM APEC SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Many foreign newspapers have expressed concern over Beijing's mistreatment of the Republic of China at the just-concluded informal summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, the Government Information Office (GIO) said Thursday.

Taiwan withdrew from this year's APEC summit in Shanghai Oct. 20-21 over a dispute on who should represent ROC President Chen Shui-bian at the gathering. Host Beijing vetoed the proposal of Taiwan to send former ROC Vice President Li Yuan-zu on the grounds that he lacked an economic or financial background.
The Taiwan authorities also protested that Beijing did not respect APEC protocol of sending an envoy to deliver a formal invitation to the annual summit.

The GIO, which asked ROC overseas representative offices to explain to the world community the reason why Taiwan was absent from the summit, said Thursday that many international media had reacted to the incident.
GIO officials noted that some newspapers, including the New York Times, published Taiwan's explanation, while other dailies expressed their support for Taiwan.

A Boston Globe editorial said that Beijing should stop bullying Taiwan, while an editorial in Japan's Mainichi Shimbun noted that Beijing displayed narrow-mindedness in treating Taiwan the way it did.
The French daily Le Monde said: "This is the most serious situation to have happened since APEC was founded."

A Belgian paper noted that Beijing's efforts to create a good image for Shanghai were overshadowed by the row, while an Italian daily said Taiwan's absence at the summit affected the mood of the gathering.

Some European media said that Taiwan has lost its world stage after the United States readjusted its international affairs priorities following the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, while others said that the gap between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will widen further after the dispute.
Britain's Financial Times pointed out that the issue will affect Taiwan's year-end legislative elections and increase Chen's reputation.
In Latin America, Panama's daily La Prensa published the whole process of Taiwan's withdrawal from the summit under the title "China Humiliates Taiwan."

Panamanian diplomats also mentioned Beijing's lashing out at a motion presented earlier this year by Panama to the United Nations in support of the ROC's U.N. bid, stressing that Beijing's behavior in blocking Taiwan's international stage is hegemonic.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHOPPING MALLS TO IGNITE COMPETITION IN LOCAL RETAIL MARKET

TEXT.P: A state-of-the-art multi-function shopping mall -- Breeze Center -- will open Friday, which is expected to stir up a new wave of competition between traditional supermarkets and large shopping malls in Taipei.
The Breeze Center, a facility designed to create a high-end shopping mall particularly for women, has set an annual business target of NT$50 billion.

By providing customers with a shopping center, recreational facilities, restaurants, an art gallery and a large-scale retail market in the complex, center officials said they hope to build a new consumption pattern for Taipei citizens.

Dismissing speculation that the center has chosen to join the battlefield at a time when a severe economic slump has swept all businesses in Taiwan following the Sept. 11 terror attacks in the United States, a center executive said he is optimistic about the purchasing capabilities of Taipei citizens.
As the mall is located in Taipei's affluent "East District," he said, he strongly believes that it will gain ground, particularly among women aged between 25 and 39, despite the current sluggishness.
"You can eat, drink, play and enjoy yourself within our facilities," said C.C. Wu, manager of Core Pacific City, a new shopping mall which is slated to be inaugurated in November.

Pointing out that shopping malls are set to prevail in the future retail market, Wu said the emergence of such comprehensive establishments will create a consumer revolution and help stimulate the market.

Sogo Pacific Department Store, which has long enjoyed a leadership role in Taipei's retail market and is located near the Breeze Center, said it will be a big task for new-style shopping malls to change the decades-old consumption habits of Taipei residents.

According to a Sogo executive, high-quality products and services are always the key elements in the face of the fierce competition from new multi-function facilities. "As long as the department stores know where their customers are and provide distinctive products, they will stand firm forever," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AFFIRMS POPE'S STATEMENT ON PAST CATHOLIC `ERRORS' IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) Spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue affirmed Thursday Pope John Paul II's statement regarding past Catholic "errors" in China.

In his statement addressed to a congress held Wednesday, the pontiff asked China to forgive "errors" committed by the Roman Catholic Church in the past, in the hope of normalizing the Holy See's relations with mainland China.
Commenting on the statement, Chang said: "The ROC government affirms and admires the frankness of the Holy See for its willingness to face history and ask the Chinese people for forgiveness."
However, she went on, the government wants to remind the Holy See that mainland China "remains at present an autocratic government which neglects religious freedom and democracy."
Chang said that the ROC and the Holy See have maintained cordial relations since the normalization of bilateral relations in 1942.
She noted that the Holy See, based on humanitarian considerations, has been deeply concerned about the religious freedom of some 10 million Catholics on the mainland.
In this regard, Chang said, the ROC government "is willing to cooperate with and help the Holy See to promote religious freedom in mainland China."
However, she pointed out that the Beijing government continues to deny religious freedom and added that Beijing's stand "is totally contrary to the Holy See's concept of promoting religious freedom."
The 81-year-old pope said in his statement that it is no secret that the Vatican hopes for the opening of some form of dialogue with Beijing.
"Once the misunderstandings of the past have been overcome," he said, "such a dialogue would make it possible for us to work together for the good of the Chinese people and for peace in the world."

DOC.HEADLINE: NFA TO SET UP SPECIAL SQUAD, TRAINING CENTER

TEXT.P: National Fire Administration (NFA) officials said Thursday that it will establish a special rescue squad and training center after the passing of a revised bill on NFA organization.

Under the revised bill, the NPA will set up the special rescue squad, which will receive helicopters from the Ministry of National Defense next year and will work closely with an airborne firefighting squad that will also be established next year.
The officials said the rescue team will comprise a total of 79 people divided into squads stationed in central, northern and southern Taiwan.

In addition, the NPA will also set up a training center, which will be responsible for training firefighters, volunteer firefighters and private rescue groups, as well as conducting exchanges with international rescue training groups to upgrade the professional skills of local firefighters.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONTREAL TO HOST 2006 GAY GAMES

TEXT.P: Montreal, Canada's second-largest and most multicultural city, will host the 2006 Gay Games, beating out Los Angeles, Chicago and Atlanta.
The Federation of Gay Games made the announcement Thursday in the South African city of Johannesburg.
The federation estimated that more than 24,000 athletes and 200,000 other visitors will pump millions of dollars into the Montreal economy during the week-long summer event.
The bid was Montreal's second attempt to host the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT VOWS TO CONTINUE WITH REFORMS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian vowed Thursday to continue with his government reforms by first of all cutting the number of agencies under the Executive Yuan by one-third over a two-year period.

Presiding over the first meeting of the government reform committee, Chen said in the same breath that the incumbent government employee's interests will be fully protected under the government's streamlining program.

At the same time, the government will revamp regulations on recruiting new staff to ensure that the administration will get first-class talent into the government in order to offer the public first class service.

However, the president went on, government reform cannot succeed without amending the country's Constitution, which lays down the mandates of the president and the administration led by the premier, as well as the powers and liabilities of the Executive Yuan and the legislature.

Noting that the vague ties between the popular president and the legislature under the existing Constitution underlies many disputes between the Democratic Progressive Party-led government and the opposition-controlled legislature, Chen said a revision of the Constitution is necessary to rid the country of its political unrest.
A clear division of political powers and financial resources between the central government and the local governments is also vital to ensure the success of the government reforms.
He urged the committee to build a public consensus on these issues as a first step toward ensuring that the proposed government reforms, if not the last, are the most successful.

The government reform committee was formed in line with the conclusions drawn by the National Economic Development Conference, which call for the streamlining of the government structure to promote government efficiency.

DOC.HEADLINE: OCTOBER CONSUMER CONFIDENCE INDICES RISING

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer confidence indices in October posted an increase of 59.01 points, or a slight increase of 0.92 percent as compared with the previous month, according to survey results released Thursday by the Taiwan Research Institute (TRI).

The survey covered the next six months' commodity price index, employment opportunities, economic prospects, the timing for stock investment and consumer durables, which form the consumer confidence indices.
The results also show that consumers who beleive that the first half of 2002 will be the best time to purchase durables increase by 6.05 points as compared with the previous month's level.

The same survey shows that 75.3 percent of the respondents believe the first half of 2002 will be not a good time to buy stocks. Only 14.1 percent of the respondents said that they would purchase stocks in this period.
The results also show that 83.7 percent of the respondents are pessimistic on the economic prospects in the coming six months with only 4.5 percent of the respondents expressing optimism.
They also show that 77.9 percent of the respondents were pessimistic on employment in the six-month period, while 6.2 percent expressed optimism in this regard.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 26, or the 10th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1879: Leon Trotsky, Russian communist leader who, along with Lenin, organized the October Revolution, is born. He was forced into exile by Stalin, sentenced to death in a Soviet court, and murdered in Mexico, where he had found asylum.
1919: Francois Mitterand, French president from 1981, and founder of the French Socialist Party, is born.
1931: Japan turns down a proposal of the Council of the League of Nations which adopted a resolution on Oct. 24 urging Japan to withdraw its troops from Northeast China by Nov. 16.
1937: Chinese troops begin a withdrawal from Shanghai to the northern Soochow River after Japanese troops capture Tachang. Shanghai would be captured by the Japanese Nov. 11.
1942: The aircraft carrier USS Hornet is sunk after being attacked by Japanese aircraft in the Solomon Islands Battle.
1944: After three days, the Battle of Leyte Gulf in the Philippines ends with victory for the United States. Over 30 ships are sunk in the great sea battle, most of them Japanese, including the Japanese navy's last four aircraft carriers.
1954: Britain and the United States end their occupation of Trieste and return control of the area to Italy.
1951: Winston Churchill is appointed British prime minister for a second time.
1955: The Republic of South Vietnam is proclaimed under Ngo Dinh Diem.
1961: Outer Mongolia is admitted into the United Nations.
1964: The Republic of China opens a consulate in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.
1964: The Republic of China and Panama sign a trade agreement in Panama City.
1971: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Belgium as the latter establishes ties with mainland China.
1971: The Republic of China withdraws from the United Nations.
1973: President Richard Nixon prepares for the possible launching of World War III after hearing that the Russians are sending arms to the Middle East as war rages there.
1973: David M. Kennedy, the U.S. ambassador-at-large, arrives in Taipei for a three-day private visit.
1975: The First Taiwan Area Games opens in Kaohsiung with 4,980 athletes participating.
1979: Park Chung Hee, president of South Korea, is slain by Kim Jae Kyu, the head of the Korean intelligence agency.
1989: A China Airlines passenger plane crashes near Taiwan's Siulin Village in Hualien County on its way from Hualien to Taipei, killing 54 people on board.
1993: The ROC and Mexico sign a pact to promote bilateral investment and technology transfers.
1994: Israel and Jordan sign a peace treaty in a ceremony at their mutual border attended by U.S. President Bill Clinton, ending 46 years of hostilities.
1995: Russian President Boris Yeltsin is hospitalized in Moscow after an apparent heart attack, his second in four months.
1999: Nankang Software Park, the largest software manufacturing park in Asia, is opened by President Lee Teng-hui in suburban Taipei.
2000: Former Commander in Chief of the ROC Navy Adm. Yeh Chang-tung claims that he has been falsely accused in an impeachment brought against him by the Control Yuan.
2000: Morris Chang, chairman and chief executive officer of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., urges the government to open up to the mainland Chinese market or face the stifling of Taiwan's industry.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "The sages are of the same species as ourselves."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Friday are as follows:
The China Times:
Military command and administration to be unified under jurisdiction of the Ministry of National Defense.
The United Daily News:
Civil servants will have freer hand in performing official duties under the newly revised law.
The Liberty Times:
TSMC announces expansion program of NT$700 billion in support of the call for keeping business roots in Taiwan.
The Taiwan Daily:
TSMC's Tainan fab still on track.
The Central Daily News:
KMT Chairman Lien Chan blasts President Chen over alleged mishandling of the APEC summit representation issue.
The China Post:
Legislature ratifies revisions ahead of WTO entry.
The Taiwan News:
TSMC to raise local investment up to NT$700 billion.
The Taipei Times:
Pope pushes for new ties with Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 31.37 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Friday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 31.37 points to close at 4,043.57.
Market turnover amounted to NT$79.09 billion (US$2.29 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 31.37 points to close at 4,043.57.

Encouraged by a rise in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 4,042.47 and continued to go up before profit-taking pressure drove prices down. The index fluctuated between 4,104.21 and 4,031.05 during trading.

A total of 3.16 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$79.09 billion (US$2.29 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 2.24 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$54.86 billion (US$1.59 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile issues edging down 0.1 percent.

The other major categories posted gains, with bank and insurance shares moving up the most at 1.3 percent, followed by plastics and chemical stocks at 1 percent, pulp and paper issues at 0.8 percent, electrical shares and cement stocks, both at 0.7 percent, foodstuff shares at 0.5 percent, and construction stocks at 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 344 to 173, with 113 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ORDERS MND TO REVIEW ALLEGED NORTH-SOUTH DEFENSE IMBALANCE

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Friday he will direct the Ministry of National Defense (MND) to study whether a defense imbalance truly exists between the northern and southern parts of Taiwan.

Chang made the promise during a Legislative Yuan question-and-answer session in response to opposition Kuomintang Legislator Chiang Chi-wen's criticism that the military has failed to place equal emphasis on defense measures in northern and southern Taiwan.
The lawmaker from the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung claimed that the MND has traditionally given more emphasis on defense buildup in the densely populated northern part of the island.

As a result, Chiang said, many of the country's major economic establishments and military installations in southern Taiwan, including Chinese Petroleum Corp., Linyuan Oil Refinery, China Shipbuilding Corp., Kaohsiung Harbor, and Tsoying naval base, have been exposed to rival mainland China's missile threat.

Noting that mainland China has deployed more than 300 M-class missiles in its southeastern province of Fujian, which lies opposite Taiwan, Chiang said she couldn't understand why the military has deployed all of the three sets of the "Patriot PAC-2 plus" anti-missile defense system, purchased from the United States, in northern Taiwan.
Chiang said she hopes that the MND can come up with a comprehensive plan to improve the imbalance in defense buildup in northern and southern Taiwan.

In response, Premier Chang said he would ask the MND to conduct an overall review of defense measures and installations around the island and craft a feasible package to fortify defense buildup in southern Taiwan.
