DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MIXED ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported mixed results on Friday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for November remained unchanged at 3,988, with 17,898 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for December rose 32 points to finish at 4,000, with 31 contract transactions, while next March futures decreased 50 points to finish at 3,961, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 3,988 for November, 3,968 for December, 4,011 for next March, 4,025 for next June, and 4,033 for next September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, also reported mixed results.
November TE futures edged up 0.7 points to close at 194, with 4,002 contract transactions, while December TE futures increased 0.7 points to finish at 193.4, with 8 contracts traded.
Next September TE futures lost 0.8 points to finish at 191, with 9 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.
November TF futures moved up 2.6 points to finish at 612.6, with 2,585 contract transactions, while December TF futures lost 0.8 points to close at 615.6, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAGAZINE ASSOCIATION TO SPONSOR INTERNATIONAL CONFAB IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: The Magazine Business Association of Taipei (MBAT) will sponsor the 2001 International Magazine Conference of Taipei Nov. 13-14 at the National Central Library in Taipei.

In addition to local publishers and media members, the association has invited experts from the magazine business in the United States, France, Japan, Singapore, Hong Kong and South Korea to be keynote speakers at the two-day conference.

James Jin, chairman of the association, said Friday that Taiwan's magazine business has been affected by the economic slump. It is expected that through the exchange of opinions among publishers from different markets, local publishers can learn from the experiences of their counterparts.

This will be the second international magazine conference sponsored by the association. The first International Magazine Conference of Taipei was held April 12-14, 1999. Executives of leading international publishing houses and advertising companies were invited to the conference.

Topics to be discussed at the conference will include launching a new magazine, advertising sales, strategies against economic depression, Asia-Pacific media development and trends, and online strategies.
The Magazine Business Association of Taipei was established in December 1996, with about 200 members running over 400 magazines.

At the end of 1998, there were over 5,700 magazines registered with the authorities. Most of the magazines were internal company periodicals, association or corporate newsletters, religious publications or academic research journals. Only some 500 magazines were licensed to be marketed, Jin said.

As the coming of the Internet era has had a great impact upon the local magazine industry, the association has tried to work out editorial as well as marketing strategies to meet the challenge. In January 1998, the association organized 108 magazine publishing houses to present a web magazine exhibition which enabled better interaction among publishers and their readers.
Jin said that the association is planning to construct a website, which will have a payment mechanism for the subscription of magazine articles.

In recent years, many Taiwan magazines have sought to expand their business to mainland China, a market with tremendous potential for Chinese-language publications. Jin said that the discussions at the conference will provide some ideas to local publishers in mapping out their marketing strategies in Chinese communities outside Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN PASSENGER SHIP MAKES BREAKTHROUGH IN `MINI THREE LINKS'

TEXT.P: A passenger ship sailed from a harbor other than Liaolo directly to mainland China Friday, making a breakthrough in the "mini three links" implemented by the Republic of China government at the start of this year on a trial basis.

The ship, carrying 151 passengers, sailed for Xiamen from Shueitou Wharf at 9:20 a.m. The passengers had earlier checked in at the passenger center at Liaolo Harbor, east of Kinmen, and then took four buses to Shueitou Wharf, located west of Kinmen.

When the government opened direct trade, postal and transportation links between Taiwan's two offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China on Jan.1, 2001, which are commonly referred to as "the three mini links," it designated Liaolo Harbor as the departure point in Kinmen for Xiamen, and Fuao Harbor in Matsu as the departure point for Mawei Port in Fuzhou. The passenger ship therefore broke the "one place, one harbor" limitation by sailing from Shueitou Wharf.

The distance between Liaolo Harbor and Heping Wharf in Xiamen is about 24 nautical miles, and the sailing time is about two-and-a-half hours, with the route passing through the turbulent stretch of sea off Kukang. In comparison, the distance from Shueitou Wharf is only 16 nautical miles, and the sailing time is about an hour less.

The Kinmen county government and private sector have long been suggesting that the government turn Shueitou Wharf into a departure point for the mainland, and the central government finally gave the green light recently.

Travel agencies applied to the Ministry of Transportation and Communications one week ago under the name of the Kinmen County Association for the Welfare of the Disabled and then obtained approval to depart from Shueitou Wharf.
Lee Hsi-shun, head of the association, said that taking the shorter route will save a lot of time and trouble for passengers, adding that such measures are very convenient for the people.

Lee Chu-feng of the opposition New Party and Wu Cheng-tien, deputy director of the Cross-Strait Association in Kinmen and Matsu were also on hand for the event. Both of them said that the sailing from Shueitou Wharf was a breakthrough, expressing the hope that such travel will become more common in the future and that approval will not need to be applied for on a case-by-case basis.
The 151 passengers included a 55-member group from the Kinmen County Association for the Welfare of the Disabled as well as 96 tourists taking part in five-day tours and exchanges in Xiamen.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DELEGATION TO WOO OVERSEAS HIGH-TECH TALENT
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Oct. 25 (CNA) (By Neil Lu, Chang Hui-yen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A Republic of China delegation will visit the United States in mid-November to help Taiwan high-tech companies find the skilled workers they need.

The delegation, jointly formed by the ROC Ministry of Economic Affairs and the National Science Council, will hold presentations in several major U.S. cities to invite overseas professionals to work in Taiwan to help in the upgrading and transformation of domestic industries.

The delegation will visit San Francisco, New York, Dallas and Los Angles. It will hold a presentation in the Bay Area, San Francisco Nov. 10. Taiwan manufacturers will also conduct interviews with qualified candidates during the presentations.

Twenty-five Taiwan companies, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, Macronix International, and Silicon Integrated Systems Corp., are seeking 260 skilled workers to fill positions in the semiconductor, electronics, information, communications, biotechnology, environmental protection, industrial safety and pharmaceutical fields.

It is known that the delegation will not only target ROC nationals now residing in the United States, but also mainland Chinese now living there. Working experience requirements for the potential candidates will also be relaxed to a minimum of two years for those who hold doctoral degrees, four years for those who hold master's degrees and six years for those who hold bachelor's degrees.
The delegation will leave Taiwan for the United States Nov.9 and return to Taiwan Nov. 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE'S LOVE FOR TRAVEL NOT DAMPENED BY ECONOMIC SLUMP

TEXT.P: Taiwan people's love for travel has not been affected by the slumping economy, statistics released Friday by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications showed.

Statistics on the transportation, communications and travel expenses of Taiwan families in 2000 showed that average spending in these areas by each family in Taiwan in 2000 grew by 1.1 percent over the previous year.

Officials said that although the growth rate was the lowest in five years, spending in these areas still registered an increase, showing that families are still willing to dish out money for transport, communications and travel.
Statistics showed that family income averaged NT$1.09 million (US$31,412) in 2000, up 0.2 percent from the previous year, also representing the lowest growth rate in the past five years.

The figures also showed that of a Taiwan family's total consumer spending in 2000, 11.4 percent went toward transportation and communications, or NT$75,000 (US$2,161), representing a 0.3 percent increase over the previous year.

A regional breakdown of spending on transportation and communications by Taiwan families in 2000 showed that Taipei families topped the list, spending an average NT$90,000 (US$2,594), followed by Kaohsiung families at NT$75,000 (US$2,161). Taiwan families, excluding those in Taipei and Kaohsiung, spent an average NT$73,000 (US$2,104) on transportation and communications.
In terms of travel spending, Taiwan families in 2000 dished out an average NT$24,000, up 9 percent from the previous year and representing the highest growth in the past five years.

Travel spending by Taipei families averaged NT$52,000, up 18.6 percent from the previous year, while Kaohsiung families spent an average NT$21,000, up 0.1 percent. Travel spending by families in other cities and counties averaged NT$19,000, up 7.7 percent, showing that Taiwan people attach great importance to leisure and travel activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESEARCHERS IN TAIWAN IDENTIFY TUMOR SUPPRESSER GENE

TEXT.P: A research group consisting of staff from National Taiwan University, Academia Sinica and the Institute of Biochemical Science has identified a tumor suppresser gene, Collapsin Response Mediator Protein-1 (CRMP-1), which can be applied in cancer diagnosis and therapy.
Yang Pan-chi, medical director of National Taiwan University Hospital, said Friday that the unveiling of the gene map secret has advanced medical research in cancer therapy.
After nearly five years of research work, the biomedical group found that activation of CRMP-1 can suppress the proliferation of malignant cells in lung cancer patients.

Yang said that the fatality ratio of female lung cancer patients in Taiwan is pretty high, while cancer cell proliferation was found among 80 percent of the patients within two years after surgery. Less than 15 percent of the patients diagnosed with lung cancer managed to survive for more than five years.

He said that with the new discovery, medical institutes can develop a biochip with the cancer suppresser gene to trace the proliferation of cancer cells, and the new technology may provide better chances of survival for lung cancer patients.

DOC.HEADLINE: APLFD TO HOLD MEETING IN AUCKLAND
DOC.DATELINE: Auckland, Oct. 26 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The 47th general meeting of the Asian Pacific League for Freedom and Democracy (APLFD) will open in Auckland Saturday with the participation of some 60 delegates from 15 countries.

Major topics to be discussed at the two-day meeting will include issues related to the pursuit of freedom, democracy and human rights and a message from Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian will be read at the opening ceremony.
The Executive Council of the league called a meeting Thursday, in which Peng Ming-min, secretary-general of the league and a senior advisor to Chen, reported on its operations.
Several New Zealand officials and lawmakers have been invited to attend the opening of the general meeting, while some local scholars will also make special reports at an academic symposium.
The delegates to the meeting are from Taiwan, Japan, South Korea, Australia, Indonesia, India, the Philippines, Thailand, New Zealand, Singapore, Laos, Burma, Vietnam, Turkey and Fiji.
Lin Chung, representative of the Taiwan Economic and Cultural Representative Office in New Zealand, honored the delegates at a dinner Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REBUTS VP'S STATEMENT ON APEC SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chung-hsiung Friday rebutted Vice President Annette Lu's statement on the government's misjudgment in the recently concluded Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum informal leadership summit.
Chang made the remarks while answering a question raised by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Liao Wan-ju at a Legislative Yuan interpellation session.

According to Liao, the government's decision to withdraw from the informal leadership summit was a misjudgment and only Lu had told the truth. The government's misjudgment of the situation will possibly lead to Taiwan losing its place on the international stage, Liao claimed.

Chang replied that the Chen Shui-bian administration decided to withdraw from the summit for the sake of upholding the nation's dignity. Therefore, Chang said, Lu's statement did not correspond to the facts.

Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi backed Chang, saying that the Ministry of Economic Affairs had prepared for the best and the worst possible scenarios, the best being that Presidential Senior Adviser Li Yuan-zu could attend the summit and the worst being that the government would send an alternate candidate or miss the meeting.

Liao then asked who had been chosen as an alternate candidate, at which point Chang appeared to suddenly change his story, replying that in fact, President Chen was originally scheduled to attend the meeting and the alternate candidate was actually Li. Liao ridiculed this policy decision as a "mission impossible."

DOC.HEADLINE: N.T. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.006 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at 34.539.
The local currency opened Friday at 34.532 and was traded between 34.522 and 34.547.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$273 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LEGISLATIVE CAUCUS TO PROPOSE 10% PAY CUT FOR LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the opposition People First Party (PFP) said Friday that it will come up with a proposal demanding a 10 percent pay cut for all lawmakers amid the current domestic woes and rising unemployment rate.
"We hope that the initiative will inspire highly paid senior government officials to follow suit," PFP parliamentary whip Chou Hsi-wei told a news conference.
In the draft bill, Chou said, the PFP will propose that all legislators be subject to a 10 percent pay cut, but that their aides be exempt from any salary reduction.
Chou said many people have complained that lawmakers are paid excessively.
"In view of the nation's financial straits and lingering economic gloom," Chou said, "legislators should take the initiative to voluntarily lower their pay to set a model for society."
Chou added his hope that senior-grade officials (grades 10-14) will also be subject to the proposed salary reduction.
The legislative caucuses of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and two other opposition parties -- the Kuomintang (KMT) and the New Party -- all threw their support behind the pay cut proposal.

DPP legislative whip Tsai Hung-lang said he feels that the current NT$530,000 (US$15,362.32) monthly pay for lawmakers, particularly those who devote their full energy to legislative work and public service, is "reasonable."
Nevertheless, he went on, the DPP caucus is willing to support the pay cut bill in consideration of the government's financial difficulties.

As for a proposed pay cut for high-ranking officials, Tsai said, the DPP caucus could not make any response at the moment. "There has been an established pay scale and system for all civil servants," Tsai said, adding that any adjustment of the system needs a comprehensive review.

In contrast, New Party legislative whip Ying Chih-hung said that his party caucus supports the 10 percent pay cut for all lawmakers and hopes that the move can inspire an appropriate salary reduction for high-ranking civil servants.

KMT caucus whip Lee Cheng-chung said he basically agrees with the pay cut proposal. "Nevertheless," he continued, "as lawmakers' salaries are based on the general pay scale for all civil servants, any adjustment should be preceded with a systematic review lest it damage the whole system."
As the KMT, which ruled Taiwan for 55 years until May 2000, still controls a majority in the legislature, any pay cut proposal needs its support to pass to the legislative floor.

During a parliamentary question-and-answer session held earlier in the day, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung did not make any direct reply to a question as to whether he would agree to a proposal to halve his "special expense account."

Chang instead said the Cabinet has launched an austerity campaign demanding that all government agencies and public educational and research institutes trim their expenditure by at least 7 percent during the rest of the current fiscal year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY ALTERNATIVE DRAFTEES ON DIPLOMATIC SERVICE TO BEGIN DUTIES

TEXT.P: The first group of the Republic of China's military draftees on alternative diplomatic service will soon depart on duty for Taipei's allies in Latin America, the Caribbean and Africa.

After a three-month training period, scores of ROC conscripts who will serve their military service providing diplomatic services to the ROC's diplomatic partners attended a passing out ceremony Friday at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
Foreign Affairs Vice Minister C.M. Lan presided over the event and encouraged the young diplomatic conscripts to behave themselves while fulfilling their obligations overseas.
The draftees will serve for a period of 20 months.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC OFFICIAL RESERVED ABOUT MEDIA REPORT ON CHINESE MEDICINE

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Cheng Ming-tung was reserved Friday about a media report that mainland China will permit people from Taiwan to take part in its annual national examination of Chinese medicine doctors from next year.

Responding to a reporter's question on whether the move will have an impact on cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges and on the government's attitude toward the mainland, Cheng said that the government's information on the issue was limited and that he would comment on the issue only after gaining a more comprehensive understanding of the facts.

The local press has reported that from next year, the mainland authorities will allow people from Taiwan, Hong Kong, Macao and other countries to take part in three categories of its national examination of Chinese medicine doctors -- clinical, Chinese herbal medicine and oral. Those who pass the exam will be able to apply for registration to practice in mainland China, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FINANCE MINISTER TO MEET WITH HEADS OF FOREIGN BANKS

TEXT.P: Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang is scheduled to meet next Monday with the branch heads of the 39 foreign banks in Taiwan to explain the island's financial market prospects after its expected entry to the World Trade Organization in November.
Yen is also slated to meet with the commercial representatives of countries including the United States, Japan, France, Australia and Singapore.

According to the ministry, he will explain the results of Taiwan's financial reforms, with particular emphasis on the Financial Holding Company Law that will go into effect Nov. 1 and is expected to facilitate foreign investment.
The minister will also explain the mechanism and process involved in setting up new assets management companies in Taiwan.
The Legislative Yuan passed the Financial Holding Company Law and five other major financial reform bills in an extraordinary session June 26-27.

The law allows a company with controlling interest in a bank, insurance company or brokerage firm to establish a holding company and is expected to help consolidate the financial sector by facilitating mergers and acquisitions.

Also passing the legislature was a statute for the establishment and management of a NT$140 billion (US$4.05 billion) financial rehabilitation fund similar to the U.S. Resolution Trust Company of the 1980s to clean up bad loans, particularly at local farmers' cooperatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FLASHES BLUE RECESSION LIGHT FOR 10TH CONSECUTIVE MONTH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy in September again flashed a blue light, representing a recession in the country's official rating system, the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) announced Friday.
It was the 10th consecutive month that the island's economy had flashed a blue light, the rating system's worst situation.
In the past two decades, the longest period during which Taiwan has flashed a blue recession light was from September 1981 to March 1983 -- 19 consecutive months.
Between March 1995 and November 1995, the same condition lasted nine straight months.

The CEPD predicted that the speed of Taiwan's economic recovery will depend on such factors as the progress of U.S. actions against terrorism and whether the ruling and opposition parties can work together to boost the economy.

In the CEPD-devised five-color system, a red light signifies an overheated economy; yellow-red indicates that the economy is heating up; green reflects steady growth; yellow-blue signals economic sluggishness; and blue represents recession.
In applying the system, the CEPD measures nine major areas of economic activity, including exports, industrial production, stock indices and orders placed in the manufacturing field.
According to the CEPD, all nine areas registered blue lights in September, indicating that the prospects of an early economic recovery remain bleak.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's index of leading economic indicators for September -- a key barometer of economic trends over the next three to six months -- arrested its upswing momentum that had held for the past three months and instead moderately dropped 0.9 percent from the preceding month to end at 93.1 points.

The index of coincident indicators, which looks at the economy's current condition, plunged 3.4 percent to end at 95.8 points, registering the sharpest drop since March 1974, when an energy crisis was to blame.

According to the CEPD, its most recent survey of local manufacturers' confidence levels indicates that only 10 percent of the respondents believe that the economy will take a turn for the better in the next three months.
Another 57 percent said that the economy will remain at the same level, while the remaining 33 percent said that the economy will deteriorate.

The 10th cyclical slowdown in Taiwan's economic history began last November, when the economy was given a yellow-blue light for economic sluggishness. The blue recession light was officially registered in December 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE WOMEN WITH DEFECTIVE GENES MORE PRONE TO LUNG CANCER: STUDY

TEXT.P: An increasing number of women in Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore are getting lung cancer, with some researchers believing that genetic problems are the root of the problem, according to recent research.

Yang Pan-chih, director of the internal medicine department of National Taiwan University Hospital, who has conducted long-term research into female lung cancer, said Friday that the latest results show that Chinese women have between four and 50 defective genes.
The genes in question are those that neutralize poison or metabolize medicine, according to Yang.
If more than three of these gene types are defective in an individual, the lung cancer rate of these people will be 20 times that of normal people, he claimed.

He added that while exposure to kitchen smoke or second-hand cigarette smoke can act as a catalyst, those who do not smoke or are not exposed to kitchen smoke still have high a possibility of getting lung cancer if they have defective genes.
Department of Health statistics show that there are 6,000 new cases of female lung cancer in Taiwan per year, with the fatality rate exceeding that of liver cancer, a major killer in Chinese society.

The statistics also show that in Taiwan, death from lung cancer in women has become the biggest cancer killer among women in the last 10 years and that its occurrence rate is still increasing gradually.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SEEN MORE POLITICALLY THAN ECONOMICALLY ORIENTED: KMT POLL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is generally perceived as more politically than economically oriented, according to the results of an opinion poll released Friday by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

The telephone survey of 1,067 randomly chosen adult residents, conducted by the KMT legislative caucus from Oct. 17-18, found that 51.27 percent of the respondents feel that Chen is working mainly for political purposes -- more specifically, for the sake of his Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) victory in the critical Dec. 1 elections for legislators and local administrative chiefs.
Only 23.24 percent said they feel that Chen is really working to rejuvenate the slumping domestic economy, despite his promises to the contrary.
The poll results also show that 56.7 percent are dissatisfied with Chen's performance over the past 18 months, while 34.4 percent approve of his overall performance.

Meanwhile, 48.55 percent said they think that Chen's attribution of his administration's lackluster achievements to opposition party scheming is "unreasonable," but 34.02 percent said they agree with his view.

According to the poll, 47.14 percent think that Chen's attendance at a fund-raiser organized by the DPP's largest Mainstream Faction earlier this month was "inappropriate," while 35.52 percent gave a thumbs-up to the move.
About 46 percent said they think this kind of fund-raiser can spur speculation about the possible influence of moneyed interests in domestic politics, but 22.21 percent disagreed.
Commenting on the survey findings, DPP legislative whip Tsai Huang-lang said the KMT poll was politically motivated to smear Chen's image.

As a matter of fact, Tsai said, the survey was yet another of the KMT's mud-slinging campaign tricks. "For one thing," he said, "the questionnaire was biased, with the aim of demonizing Chen and discrediting the government.

"The truth is that President Chen convened a high-profile economic development advisory conference in late August to underscore his determination to rev up the sluggish domestic economy," Tsai claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: VATICAN-TAIPEI TIES WILL REMAIN UNCHANGED: VICE FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: the Republic of China's diplomatic ties with the Vatican will remain unchanged as long as Beijing's dictatorship remains unchanged, Vice Foreign Minister Chiou Jong-nan predicted Friday.

Answering questions from legislators about indications that the Vatican is reaching out to Beijing, Chiou said at the Legislative Yuan that the sticking point hindering the Vatican's ties with Beijing is Beijing's reluctance to grant its people religious freedom.

The differences cannot be ironed out unless Beijing relaxes its dictatorial rule and loosens its grip on its people's religious activities, he said, adding that therefore, the chances of the Vatican abandoning Taipei in favor of mainland China are slim.
The Vatican's gesture toward Beijing is aimed at resuming dialogue with Beijing, which will not be in any way prejudicial to the ROC, said Chiou.

His answer is similar to remarks made by a Foreign Ministry spokeswoman a day earlier, when wire services reported that Pope John Paul II had begged Chinese forgiveness for "past errors" committed by the Catholic church in their country.
The 81-year-old pontiff also said that the Vatican hopes to open some form of dialogue with mainland China.

A spokesman for Beijing's Foreign Ministry responded that his government is ready to improve ties with the Vatican as long as the Holy See severs its diplomatic ties with the ROC and promises not to interfere with mainland China's internal affairs. He was referring to the Holy See's right to choose bishops and cardinals, a right disputed by Beijing.

Meanwhile former Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti, who is widely believed to be an unofficial adviser to the Holy See, said in Rome Thursday that the "Taiwan issue" could be easily resolved if Beijing were to offer the prospect of diplomatic ties.

However, Taipei seemed to take the diplomatic flirtation between the Vatican and Beijing in its stride. ROC Ambassador to the Holy See Raymond Tai said Thursday in Rome that he had been informed in advance of the Vatican's overture toward Beijing and that he would be happy to see the resumption of dialogue between the Vatican and Beijing, which might promote religious freedom in mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MAY BLOCK TAIWAN'S WTO ENTRY: ROC ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi said Friday that Beijing will convene a national people's congress shortly after the World Trade Organization (WTO) Ministerial Meeting next month in Qatar approves Beijing's entry.

Lin also said that Beijing and its allies might possibly interfere with Taiwan's WTO entry, which is why the Executive Yuan has asked the Legislative Yuan to convene an extraordinary session Nov. 16 to approve related documents so as to reduce any possible changes.
He made the remarks while answering question raised by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Liao Wan-ju at a Legislative Yuan's interpellation session.
According to Liao, Beijing's rude treatment of Taiwan in the recent Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation forum means that Beijing may also interfere with Taiwan's WTO entry.

Lin replied that the WTO has 142 contracting members and that the WTO situation is quite different from the APEC issue. But he admitted that there is the possibility that Beijing might use its allies to interfere with Taiwan's WTO entry.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN BOASTS WORLD'S GREATEST LONGEVITY

TEXT.P: Japan has the world's longest-lived people, with an average life expectancy of 81, according to a list of the average longevity rates of 100 countries released Friday by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI).
Following Japan are Switzerland, San Marino, Hong Kong, Sweden, Iceland, Australia, Martinique, France and Spain, according to the MOI list.

With an average life span of 84, Japanese women are also longer-living than women in any other country or region on the list, while average Japanese male longevity is 77, tying with Switzerland, Hong Kong, Sweden and Iceland.
The United States was placed 30th on the list, with an average life span of 77 -- 79 for women and 74 for men.
Hong Kong ranked 36th on the list, with an average life expectancy of 79. The average longevity of Hong Kong's women is 82, while that of its men is 77.
Singapore ranked 37th, with an average longevity of 78. The average life span of Singaporean women is 80, while that of its men is 76.
Taiwan ranked 38th on the list, with an average life span of 75 for its people. The average longevity of Taiwan's women is 78, while that of Taiwan's men is 73.
South Korea was placed 44th on the list, with an average longevity of 74. The average life span of South Korean women is 78, while that of its men is 71.
Mainland China was placed 88th, with an average longevity of 71 -- 73 for the women and 69 for the men.
North Korea was 95th on the list, with an average life span of 70. The average longevity of North Korean women is 73, while that of its men is 67.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE: RESUBMITTING TO CORRECT ITEM CEP0018: `CHINESE

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tung was reserved Friday about a media report that mainland China will permit people from Taiwan to take part in its annual national examination of medical doctors from next year.

Responding to a reporter's question on whether the move will have an impact on cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges and on the government's attitude toward the mainland, Chen said that the government's information on the issue was limited and that he would comment on the issue only after gaining a more comprehensive understanding of the facts.

The local press has reported that from next year, the mainland authorities will allow people from Taiwan, Hong Kong, Macao and other countries to take part in three categories of mainland China's national examination of medical doctors -- clinical, Chinese herbal medicine and stomatology. Those who pass the exam will be able to apply for registration to practice in mainland China, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO CONSIDER LETTING MORE PROFESSIONALS WORK IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Director of Legal Affairs Liu Teh-shun said Friday that the government will consider lifting restrictions to allow sports and medical professionals from Taiwan to work in mainland China in the future.

Liu made the remarks in response to reports that the mainland is to permit people from Taiwan, Hong Kong, Macau and other countries to take part in its annual national examination for medical professionals in the clinical, stomatological and traditional Chinese medicine fields starting next year.

However, he reminded the public that current domestic regulations still prohibit Taiwan people from practicing medicine in the mainland, and that violators could be fined NT$100,000-NT$500,000 (US$2,900-US$14,500).

Citing Article 33 of the Statute Governing Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, Liu said that people or organizations from Taiwan, with the exception of accountants and arbitrators, are not allowed to work for any organization in mainland China without government approval.
Earlier this month, a previously Taiwan-based basketball team ignored government warnings and relocated to the mainland to play in its Division A league basketball tournaments.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU CHI MEDICAL CENTER SETS UP RESEARCH CENTER FOR LIVER DISEASE

TEXT.P: The Tzu Chi Medical Center and Buddhist Tzu Chi University in Hualien, eastern Taiwan, have recently established a joint research center for the study of liver disease, Taiwan's leading cause of death.

Lin Hsien-hung, leader of the research center, said Friday that the researchers will try to find relationships between environment exposure and hepatitis and cirrhosis in order to find ways to help prevent the disease.

The center will integrate three blood data banks belonging to the Buddhist Tzu Chi University -- which include blood data on two of the main aboriginal tribes in Taiwan -- and information about liver disease compiled by the Tzu Chi Medical Center and other smaller medical centers in the region.

Lin added that after they expand the scale of their blood databank, the research will focus on the study of hepatitis, including epidemiology, the history of hepatitis and the effect of alcohol on the liver.
According to research statistics compiled over the last few years, chronic hepatitis has become a major cause of death among Taiwan people.
Lin went on to say that hepatitis B and hepatitis C are factors that predispose toward chronic hepatitis, although not all the hepatitis B and hepatitis C patients will develop chronic hepatitis.
Therefore, he said, there must be other factors that should be studied, especially the effects of cigarettes, alcohol and betel-nut on Taiwan people.
According to Department of Health statistics about the top 10 killers in Taiwan last year, chronic hepatitis and hepatitis were the No. 6 and No. 8 killers, respectively.

Meanwhile, the liver disease rate in the Hualien area, which is home to many of the island's aborigines, is the highest in Taiwan, a situation that has also puzzled medical researchers and needs to be further studied, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FEWER GOAT'S MILK PRODUCTS FOUND WITH FALSE LABELING

TEXT.P: Various domestic goat's milk products blended with cow's milk have been found bearing false labeling, although the figure was roughly 50 percent lower than the previous year, the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) said Friday.

Samples of 74 products which did not state on the label that the product also contained cow's milk were tested by health bureaus around the island and 12 samples, or 16.2 percent, were found to contain cow's milk, considerably less than the 30 percent of mislabeled products found during similar checks last year.
Chen Shu-kong, director of the DOH's Bureau of Food Sanitation, said that suppliers of mislabeled goat's milk products are subject to fines of between NT$30,000 and NT$150,000.
Goat's milk powder, goat's milk wafers, flavored goat's milk and fresh goat's milk are all sold in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC BACKS INCREASED CROSS-STRAIT NEWS MEDIA EXCHANGES: MAC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Republic of China would like to see increased exchanges among news media on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and is willing to ease restrictions on such exchanges, a mainland affairs official said Friday.

Chen Ming-tong, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, made the remarks during a seminar on cross-strait relations from a media perspective.

Chen said that ever since Taiwan opened its doors to mainland Chinese news media by allowing mainland journalists to visit Taipei for up to one month on each visit, mainland media reports on Taiwan have become more lively and realistic.

"Even though mainland reporters have given more coverage to negative than to positive events," Chen said, "the open-door measure has at least helped prompt them to shed some stereotyped descriptions of Taiwan and to adopt a more realistic approach in their reporting."
To his knowledge, Chen said, mainland reporters have come to a better understanding of the different media cultures and work environments on the two sides since working here.

Chen said he is convinced that increasingly realistic reports and "reference information" dispatched by mainland journalists from Taipei will also help prevent senior mainland officials from misjudging Taiwan's situation and cross-strait events.
"Through talks with mainland reporters stationed here," Chen said, "I feel that many of them are impressed by Taiwan's press freedom and its media's aggressiveness in criticizing the government."
Touching on a report that Beijing will allow Taiwan news organizations to open permanent offices on the mainland, Chen said the report would need to be confirmed.
He further said that the MAC is more than willing to promote cross-strait journalist exchanges on the principles of parity and reciprocity.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LEADER PLEADS FOR CAMPAIGN THAT DOES NOT SPLIT COUNTRY

TEXT.P: People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong pleaded with local politicians Friday not to try to divide the people while soliciting votes for the year-end elections.
Stumping in Taipei for a PFP legislative candidate, the former Taiwan provincial governor urged politicians of whatever political parties to avoid using Taiwan's ethnic divide for political purposes.

"Native Taiwanese" usually refers to people who moved to the island from the southeastern coast of mainland China before 1949 and now account for 85 percent of the island's population, while "aliens" allude to those who fled to the island after 1949 when the Nationalist Government relocated to Taiwan.

Soong, himself a so-called "alien," urged candidates to refrain from seeking support by labeling their rivals "aliens" and thereby free the public from the "spiritual prison" -- a term he borrowed from Vice President Annette Lu, who has portrayed her 500-odd days in office as "confinement in a spiritual prison" because, she claims, she can no long express her opinions as she pleases.
Soong also urged the Kuomintang -- the PFP's partner in the opposition alliance at the Legislative Yuan -- to be more tolerant toward KMT members who are sympathetic toward the PFP.
Soong noted that the KMT expelled a well-known labor leader after he was named by the PFP as a candidate for non-elected legislators.
Instead of dismissing the labor leader, Soong said, the KMT should have been glad that its member was tapped by its political ally as a candidate.

The former KMT secretary-general, who was expelled from the KMT for running against the party's candidate in last presidential election, said at the campaign rally that his party is not competing to be the biggest party in the legislature but is rather struggling to accomplish KMT founder Sun Yat-sen's political goal of "a country belonging to the public, with the people as its supreme master."

DOC.HEADLINE: MATSU DEFENSE COMMAND CONDUCTS MILITARY EXERCISE

TEXT.P: The Matsu Defense Command (MDC) confirmed Friday that an anti-aircraft exercise dubbed "Wanping" had been carried out the previous night.

The purpose of exercise was to test the results of training and the capability of the anti-air defenses of Matsu, a front-line island stronghold of the Republic of China lying close to the coast of mainland China, according to an MDC spokesman.
The exercise covered Nankan, Beikan and Chukuang islands, all of which are part of the Matsu group of islands.
The exercise, which included both anti-aircraft fire and surface shooting, was inspected by Matsu Defense Commander Gen. Lu Hua-ning, who praised the performance of the troops involved.

Lu added that the exercise was routine and had nothing to do with the cross-Taiwan Strait situation or a military exercise carried out recently by People's Liberation Army forces in the South China Sea.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN, NANAN SET GOOD EXAMPLE FOR CROSS-STRAIT COOPERATION

TEXT.P: A 44-member delegation from Nanan City in mainland China's Fujian Province left Kinmen Friday for home after concluding a five-day trade-promotion visit to the Taiwan-held frontline island.

The delegation's leader, Nanan Mayor Chen Qingchung, said before the departure that Kinmen and Nanan have set up a good cooperation model and that he expects private-sector exchanges between the two sides to further grow, laying a solid foundation for developing mutually beneficial ties.

The Nanan delegation inked 28 cooperation accords with the Kinmen business community during their visit. Importers of stone, gravel and construction materials from Kinmen, Matsu and Taiwan placed orders for more than 3 million metric tons -- worth NT$2 billion -- with the delegation.

According to Chen, cross-strait exchanges are set to bloom due to the imminent entry of Taiwan and mainland China into the World Trade Organization. As Kinmen and Nanan share the same language, blood links and folk customs, Chen said he believes that two-way contacts will become more diversified and increasingly frequent.
The Nanan delegation left for their hometown aboard a ferry operated by Kinmen County from Liaolo Port.

Earlier the same day, a privately owned ferry carrying 151 Kinmen passengers departed from Shuitou Port for Xiamen City in Fujian Province, marking the first time that a boat from either Kinmen or Matsu has embarked from Shuitou to the mainland Chinese side since the establishment of the "mini three links" at the beginning of this year.

The local travel agency in charge of the trip applied to leave from Shuitou on the grounds that some of the passengers were disabled and the Ministry of Transport and Communications approved the application.

Liaolo Port, a trial embarkation point for the "mini three links" between the two sides, is some 24 nautical miles away from Xiamen's Hoping Port, while Shuitou Port is only 16 nautical miles away, a difference of an hour's travel time.

Local public opinion leaders, including New Party lawmaker Lee Chu-feng and cross-strait trade promoters who witnessed the departure in Shuitou, agreed unanimously that Shuitou is a good starting point for direct shipping, trade and transport links between the two offshore islands and Fujian Province.
The Kinmen county government stressed that it strongly believes that future approval of Liaolo Port as a departure point for the "mini three links" will help strengthen bilateral shipping ties.

Since the implementation of the "mini three links," ferries have made a total of 96 trips between the two sides, carrying 8,130 people from the Taiwan side to the mainland side and 520 mainland people to Taiwan-controlled territory.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT REITERATES RESOLVE TO PROMOTE CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that his determination to promote cross-Taiwan Strait relations will not be affected by any factors.

In an interview with Associated Press Television News, Chen said that as president, he has "the duty and obligation to bring peace to the Taiwan Strait as well as promote and complete the normalization of cross-strait relations."

Chen said that the ROC government fully supported the incorporation of anti-terrorism into the agenda of the informal leadership conference of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Shanghai, but he expressed deep regret that owing to Beijing's political interference, Taiwan was unable to participate in the Oct. 20-21 summit.

He stated that he affirms and admires U.S. President George Bush's remarks in Shanghai to remind the Beijing authorities that they should not take advantage of the global anti-terror campaign to oppress the minority peoples in mainland China.

He also noted that U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell and National Security Adviser Condoleezza Rice have repeatedly stressed that the United States will not sacrifice Taiwan's interests in the process of cooperating with Beijing to fight international terrorism.
Chen criticized mainland China for failing to follow APEC protocol by refusing to send an official to deliver a formal invitation to Taiwan's delegate to the APEC leadership conference.

Initially, Chen said, he had intended to attend the informal summit himself, but about 10 days before the opening of the summit, he appointed former Vice President Li Yuan-zu to represent him. Beijing refused to accept Li's appointment and Taiwan was forced to abstain from the informal summit for the first time.

Asked what he would like to discuss with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin if were allowed to visit Beijing, Chen said he would hope to "exchange with him on the experiences and views over the universal values of democracy, freedom and human rights."
He noted that "we hope to negotiate and engage in dialogue with them to promote cross-strait relations on the principles of democracy, equality and peace."
The president also said that the problems that have stalled the development of bilateral relations are "not on the Taiwan side."

He said that under Jiang's leadership, the Beijing government has harbored "many misunderstandings" about Taiwan and does not understand him and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in many areas.
Nevertheless, Chen reiterated his determination to improve cross-strait relations with "sincerity and goodwill."

For instance, he said, that despite the APEC incident, the ROC government's policy to implement the 322 resolutions reached by the recent Economic Development Advisory Conference, including relaxing control on Taiwan's trade and investment ties with the mainland, will continue.
Regarding the Dec. 1 local elections, Chen said that DPP candidates might be able to win in 13-14 counties and cities of the 23 county magistrate and city mayor posts up for grabs.

He went on to say that the ruling party might also be able to replace the opposition Kuomintang as the biggest party in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan after simultaneous year-end legislative elections, although no single party is expected to win a simple majority.
Therefore, he said, he is optimistic of forming a coalition government under the control of the DPP after the elections.
Chen also said that both Taiwan and mainland China are expected to be admitted into the World Trade Organization at the WTO ministerial meeting to be held in Qatar next month.
He expressed hope that both sides will in future engage in constructive interaction on the international economic and trade stages under the framework of the global trade regulatory body.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSFER OF POWER 'LIKE BOAT SAILING IN ROUGH SEA': PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian describes in a new book to be published next week the scenario of Taiwan's first-ever transition of power between different political parties in May 2000 as "a boat sailing in rough sea."

According to excerpts of the new book released by the Presidential Office Friday, Chen said he feels that the historic transfer of power 18 months ago marked only a "symbolic" transfer of power, rather than a total change of administration.

Chen recalled that the National Security Council failed to transfer its full archives and files and that the Presidential Office staff and other administrative agencies were not very cooperative in the transitional process.

"At that monumental moment, I felt that I was like walking on a tight rope and could afford any misstep," Chen said in the book which recounts how he faced problems, met challenges and thought about the future since taking the presidency.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LEADER DISMISSES DPP ADMINISTRATION AS `INCOMPETENT'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's perception of a coalition proves the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration's "incompetence," "arrogance" and "ignorance of the public well-being," opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng said Friday.

He made the comment after Chen told the Associated Press earlier in the day that his DPP party will not give up the leadership of the coalition government he has promised to form after the Dec. 1 elections.
The president said that his party will "share power with the people" and consult with other parties in assembling the administration, but the coalition will still be controlled by the DPP.

Noting that while political sleight of hand might work in elections, it will not work in running the government, the KMT leader said the problem with the DPP is its lack of administrators, and that it cannot run the government without talent from other parties.

But a coalition cannot be formed between parties without mutual trust and Chen's interview, according to Lin, has exposed the president's oblivion to the root problems within his current government. Chen is condemned to repeating his errors in his next administration, whether it is a coalition or not, Lin claimed.

In light of his administration being blocked at every turn in the opposition-controlled legislature, and because much of his agenda is mired in political wangling between the ruling and opposition parties, Chen has promised to change tack after the election by putting together a coalition.

The opposition, especially the KMT, which is the leading party in the current legislature, has demanded that the president ask whichever party controls the most seats in the legislature after the election to form a coalition.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SUPPORT RATE UP AFTER EXPULSION OF EX-CHAIRMAN: KMT LEADER

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng said Friday that the party's support rate has increased following the recent move to revoke the party membership of former Chairman Lee Teng-hui.
Lin told reporters that Lee is "obviously" inclined toward supporting Taiwan independence, a stance totally contrary to that of the KMT.

Therefore, he said, after his expulsion from the party, some former party members have returned to the party. He added that the results of various public opinion surveys also indicate that the party's support rate is on the rise.
Lee was expelled mainly because he stumped for the candidates of the newly formed Taiwan Solidarity Union and criticized the KMT.

Regarding the Dec. 1 legislative and county chief elections, Lin said that the KMT has "absolute confidence" in its ability to continue to be the biggest party in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan after the elections.
He said that the party's target is to win 90 seats, with a possibility of reaching 100 seats.
In the elections for the 23 county magistrates and city mayors, he said the KMT might have a chance of winning in eight to 12 counties and cities.
The KMT leader expressed the hope that the "pan-blue alliance" -- referring to the KMT, the People First Party and the New Party -- will cooperate in the elections.
"Our country will have a bright hope only when the pan-blue alliance cooperates to win in the elections and it will be a disaster for the country if the DPP makes a gain," Lin claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDAC CONSENSUS CAN HELP NORMALIZE CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: The consensus reached in an August economic conference in Taiwan will bring positive effect in normalizing relations between Taiwan and mainland China, Republic of China government spokesman Su Tzen-ping said Friday.

In an interview by Asiamedia, which belongs to the University of California in Los Angeles, Su said that in the Economic Development Advisory Conference (EDAC) held in August and initiated by President Chen Shui-bian to boost Taiwan's flagging economy, a consensus was made to adopt an "active opening, effective management" strategy toward local investment in mainland China, instead of the present "no haste, be patient" policy.

Su said economic integration between Taiwan and mainland China will "inevitably" turn into political integration, which is in accordance with Chen's idea of "seeking a permanent peace between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait starting with economic, trade, and cultural integration between both sides."

Su also noted that to prevent the frequent economic exchanges between the two sides from affecting Taiwan's security and to further protect Taiwan investment in mainland China, the ROC government will establish a "national security net" to stabilize the mechanism of the free market, allow for political democratization and advance the national defenses.

Referring to the imminent entry of both Taiwan and mainland China into the World Trade Organization, Su said local industry will benefit in production and trade, although he admitted that certain sectors, such as agriculture and low-tech industry, will bear the brunt of the impact.
However, Su added, Taiwan's industries have been readjusting toward WTO regulations for a long time, and he predicted that they will be able to withstand the impact.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC AIRLINES CAN 'APPLY' TO FLY OVER MAINLAND CHINA: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Domestic airlines can "apply" to the Cabinet to fly through mainland Chinese airspace on flights that originally crossed Afghanistan, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Friday.

Chang made the remark at the Legislative Yuan while fielding questions by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lee Hsien-jung as to why the government was still refusing to allow local carriers to take advantage of an offer by Beijing to allow mainland overflights in order to avoid the dangerous skies over Afghanistan.

The Legislative Yuan recently passed a resolution asking the government to allow domestic airlines to use mainland airspace after Beijing offered to allow local carriers into its territory, but the Cabinet has refused to comply, saying such a move would have to be discussed by government officials of both sides.
Lee blasted the two government departments concerned -- the Mainland Affairs Council and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications -- for their failure to decide on the issue.

Chang said only that airlines can "apply" to fly over the mainland airspace according to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area promulgated in September 1992.
He added that Taiwan and mainland China have not signed any air flight agreements and the government will have to negotiate with mainland China on flight accords.
However, Beijing has refused to negotiate with the administration of Chen Shui-bian.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 27, or the 11th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1728: Captain James Cook, English navigator, is born. His voyages on the ship Endeavour led to the European discovery of Australia, New Zealand and the Hawaiian Islands.
1858: Theodore Roosevelt, U.S. statesman and president, is born. He won the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts in ending the Russo-Japanese War in 1905.
1921: Yen Fu, a noted Chinese translator who introduced Western culture to China, dies in his hometown of Minhou in Fukien Province at the age of 67.
1922: The Italian government resigns under increasing pressure from the fascist movement under Benito Mussolini.
1927: Mao Zedong leads his followers and reaches Chingkang Mountain in Kianghsi Province to establish a stronghold for the Chinese Communist Party.
1930: The Wuhsheh Incident occurs when Taiwan's aboriginal inhabitants in the Wuhsheh area of Taichung County launch their resistance campaign against Japanese rule and kill 134 Japanese.
1931: Representatives from Nanking and Canton meet in Shanghai for peace negotiations.
1942: Madame Chiang Kai-shek leaves for the United States to address a joint session of the U.S. Senate and House of Representatives.
1947: The Ministry of the Interior announces that the "Democracy Alliance" is an illegal organization subject to being cracked down on in accordance with current laws.
1947: The Sino-American Relief Treaty is signed in Nanking under which US$30 million worth of relief goods are to be shipped to Taiwan.
1955: Taiwan's first sex-change operation is successfully carried out at the Army First Hospital.
1961: The 16th United Nations General Assembly votes in favor of the admission of Outer Mongolia. The Republic of China abstains from the vote.
1964: The Republic of China and the Republic of Korea sign a treaty of amity in Seoul.
1974: Teizo Horikoshi, president of the Interchange Association of Japan, and Sadan Iguchi, the association's director, arrive in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1978: President Anwar Sadat of Egypt shares the Nobel Peace Prize with Premier Menachem Begin of Israel.
1979: President Chiang Ching-kuo calls on Korean Ambassador Ock Man Ho to express his condolences over the death of President Park Chung Hee.
1983: U.S. President Ronald Reagan defends his decision to send a 2,000-strong force of Marines and Army Rangers to the Caribbean island of Grenada.
1986: An international conference on "Chiang Kai-shek and Modern China" opens in Taipei, with more than two hundred Chinese and foreign scholars attending the four-day meeting.
1987: A referendum in the Republic of Korea approves constitutional reforms, including the establishment of direct presidential elections.
1990: Moscow City Mayor Gavriil H. Popov arrives for a formal visit to the ROC to discuss the strengthening of ROC-Soviet trade relations.
1994: The Legislative Yuan passes revisions to the "Wildlife Conservation Law," greatly toughening penalties against violators and stipulating that the breeding of endangered animals in captivity must cease within three years.
1997: The Dow Jones index drops 554.26 points, its largest one-day decline in terms of points.
1999: The International Relations Committee of the U.S. House of Representatives amends and passes the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, aiming at extending U.S.-Taiwan security ties.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian and Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan hold their first meeting since Chen's election in March, in which Lien urges Chen to convene a National Unification Council meeting.
2000: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung announces a decision to halt construction of Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant, saying the move is the only choice for building a nuclear-free homeland.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "The sense of mercy is in all men; the sense of shame is in all men; the sense of courtesy and respect is in all men; the sense of right and wrong is in all men."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY ( Oct. 28, 2001)
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 28, or the 12th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1492: Christopher Columbus discovers Cuba on his first voyage to the New World and claims it in the name of Spain.
1636: Harvard College is founded at Cambridge by the General Court of Massachusetts on the comparatively modest sum of US$740, part of US$1,440 bequeathed to the university by Mr. John Harvard, assistant pastor of the First Church of Charleston.
1746: An earthquake completely destroys Lima and Callao in Peru, killing more than 18,000 people.
1794: Robert Liston, the Scottish doctor who performed the first operation in Britain on an anesthetized patient, is born.
1886: A statue called Liberty Enlightening the World, the largest present ever sent to the American people from the French, is inaugurated on Liberty Island in the Upper Bay of New York Harbor by President Grover Cleveland.
1891: A strong earthquake rocks the Niphon Islands in Japan, killing 10,000 people and leaving more than 300,000 others homeless.
1901: Taiwan's first Shinto shrine is inaugurated on Yuanshan in Taipei during Japanese colonial rule of Taiwan.
1912: Sir Richard Doll, the British cancer researcher who proved the link between cigarette smoking and lung cancer, is born.
1914: Jonas Salk, the American microbiologist who developed a polio vaccine, is born.
1950: Finland establishes diplomatic relations with Communist China.
1953: A launch ceremony for the first batch of U.S.-provided fishing boats to Taiwan is held in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
1962: Soviet leader Nikita Krushchev informs U.S. President John F. Kennedy that work on missile sites under construction in Cuba will be halted and that missiles already delivered will be shipped back to the USSR.
1966: Wu Chen-nan, former leader of the "Taiwan Independence Revolutionary Council" in Japan, returns to Taiwan.
1972: Two pandas, a gift from Communist China to Japan, arrive at the Ueno Zoo in Tokyo.
1973: Former Japanese Prime Minister Nobusuke Kishi and two other Japanese leaders arrives in Taipei to extend birthday congratulations to President Chiang Kai-shek.
1977: Taiwan's first experimental geothermal power plant goes into operation in Ilan.
1979: Movie star James Mason arrives in Taipei to attend the Golden Horse Awards presentation ceremony at the invitation of the Movie and Drama Association of the ROC.
1980: Asaad Abdul Aziz Al-Zuhair, the first resident Saudi Arabian ambassador to the Republic of China, arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
1982: Felipe Gonzales, 40, becomes Spain's first Socialist prime minister in a landslide victory.
1992: Australian Tourism and Resources Minister Alan Griffiths visits Taipei to promote closer bilateral trade relations. He is the first Australian minister to visit Taipei since 1972.
1993: An explosion occurs at Taiwan Power Company's Hsintienlun power plant in central Taiwan, killing six people and injuring 26 others.
1993: Communist China resumes trade relations with South Africa, cut off since July 1960.
1999: Renowned Japanese writer Ayako Sono arrives in Taipei, bringing with her a cash donation of 300 million yen (US$2.88 million) and immeasurable compassion for Taiwan's earthquake victims.
2000: Former Finance Minister Paul Chiu is ordered to post NT$600,000 bail after he was formally questioned by a Taipei district prosecutor about his alleged wrongdoings during his tenure as finance minister.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "He who attends to his smaller self becomes a small man, and he who attends to his greater self becomes a great man."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The China Times:
Lawmakers willing to take pay cut to help economy.
The United Daily News:
President Chen says he will not 'surrender' power to form a new Cabinet after Dec. 1 polls.
The Liberty Times:
President Chen says Taiwan fears that Beijing may take advantage of anti-terrorism campaign to further suppress Taiwan's presence in the world arena.
The Taiwan Daily:
President Chen writes of peril in the nation's first transfer of power.
The Central Daily News:
South Korean ruling party suffers a serious defeat in parliamentary by-elections due to economic gloom.
The China Post:
President Chen pledges to form coalition Cabinet.
The Taiwan News:
British to send in ground troops.
The Taipei Times:
U.S. Congress backs Taipei in APEC row.

DOC.HEADLINE: NON-PERFORMING LOANS RESOLUTION MECHANISM SEMINAR TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: An international seminar on the non-performing loans (NPLs) resolution mechanism is scheduled to be held in Taipei Oct. 30-Nov. 1, organizers said Saturday.

Taiwan's Central Bank of China (CBC) and the Malaysia-based South-East Asian Central Banks (SEACEN) Research and Training Center have jointly organized the Seminar on the NPLs Resolution Mechanism and Its Impact on the Financial System.

The seminar will be held at the CBC headquarters with Chen Shih-meng, CBC Deputy Director, and Subarjo Joyosumarto, executive director of the SEACEN Research and Training Center, giving speeches at the opening ceremony.

Participants to the three-day seminar will discuss the causes behind NPLs, the credit deflation of Southeast Asian banks after the 1997 Asian financial turmoil, the role of the Assets Management Companies (AMCs) in the NPLs resolution mechanism, as well as the impact of the mechanism on the realty market and the financial system.
Representatives from the 11 member central banks and monetary authorities, and several central bankers from non-member Japan, Iran and Pakistan will participate in the seminar.

The SEACEN Research and Training Center groups the Bank of Indonesia, the Bank of Korea, the Bank of Negara Malaysia, the Bank of Mongolia, the Central Bank of Myanmar, the Nepal Rastra Bank, the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, the Monetary Authority of Singapore, the Central Bank of Sri Lanka, the Central Bank of China (Taiwan) and the Bank of Thailand.
