DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT DECRIES BEIJING'S REJECTION OF TAIWAN'S APEC PROXY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday night that Beijing's refusal to welcome his appointed proxy to attend last weekend's Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) leadership summit in Shanghai was tantamount to "a rejection of the people of Taiwan."

While in northern Taiwan's Miaoli County to stump for ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidates in the Dec. 1 legislative, county chief and city mayor elections, Chen said that Taiwan's choice of a presidential representative to the annual APEC summit "is not a decision for the Communist Chinese to make."

He said that it was also not a decision that mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin could make on behalf of Taiwan and that refusing to let former Republic of China Vice President Li Yuan-zu participate in the regional forum was the same as brushing aside a decision made by the 23 million people of Taiwan.

Meanwhile, to expound on the president's comments Friday in an interview with Associated Press Television News that his determination to promote Taipei-Beijing relations will not be affected by any factors, Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tong said Saturday that the government's policy toward mainland China is flexible, dynamic and in pace with the times.

Chen said in a speech to the public that although some people criticize the DPP administration for not having clear mainland policy guidelines like the previous administration's Guidelines for National Unification, the government in fact follows the practice of having the president deliver policy speeches or of having a representative group reach consensus on relevant issues at various important junctures.
He reiterated that Taiwan has the sincerity and good will to communicate with mainland China but that Beijing must first accept the existence of the Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: RETIRED AGENT ANALYZES DECLINE IN INTELLIGENCE FROM MAINLAND

TEXT.P: A retired Taiwan intelligence agent said Saturday that the issue of ideology is one of the major reasons behind a decline in intelligence from mainland China.

The former official with the Military Intelligence Bureau (MIB), who preferred to remain anonymous, was commenting on remarks by President Chen Shui-bian in his soon-to-be-published book that intelligence from mainland China has decreased significantly since he assumed office in the Republic of China's first-ever transition of power between different political parties in May 2000.

In the past, the former MIB agent said, the most effective way to recruit mainland Chinese people to work for the bureau was to persuade them to "provide intelligence and information for the sake of eventual reunification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait."

"As Chen's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) used to espouse Taiwan independence," he said, "some mainland intelligence agents have become reluctant to risk their lives to work for Taiwan after the inauguration of the DPP government."

The ex-official, who was in charge of mainland intelligence during his 30-plus years of service with the MIB before his retirement last year, recalled that some senior MIB agents also applied for retirement after the DPP took the helm of the nation.

"They intended to leave the MIB because they were unused to working for a non-Kuomintang government made up of what had been an outlawed group -- the pro-independence DPP," he said. To his knowledge, he added, high-ranking MIB officials had made strenuous efforts to convince them to remain in their posts.

The ex-military agent said President Chen's complaint about the dwindling amount of mainland intelligence is really an alarm. According to him, it has truly become more difficult to develop an intelligence network in mainland China since Chen assumed the ROC presidency.

The former MIB official further said another reason for the decline in mainland intelligence is that mainland China has stepped up its anti-espionage campaign and has refrained from publishing or circulating sensitive documents in order to better protect their military secrets.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ABSENCE FROM APEC SUMMIT REGRETTABLE: U.S. OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The United States will continue to be supportive of Taiwan's representation in Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) meetings in accordance with past practices, a U.S. State Department official said Friday.

C. Lawrence Greenwood, a senior official for APEC, said at a morning briefing hosted by the Asia Society that Taiwan's absence at this year's APEC informal leadership summit in Shanghai was "regrettable".
He termed it regrettable because Taiwan in the past has played "a very valuable and positive role" at APEC summits, adding that he believes Taiwan will continue to play such a role in the future.

Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian announced Oct. 19 that because of the mainland Chinese government's failure to follow the established APEC protocol of sending a special envoy to present an invitation to the ROC president to attend the informal leadership summit, Taiwan would not attend the summit in Shanghai.
In response to a question concerning the issue of Taiwan representation at APEC summits in the future, Greenwood said that "we look forward to working very closely with all APEC members."
He pointed out that the United States has always been very supportive of Taiwan's representation in accordance with past practices, adding that "we will continue to be supportive in this way."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. ANNOUNCES PROPOSED SALE OF ANTI-TANK MISSILES TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The U.S. Department of Defense announced Friday the proposed sale of 40 JAVELIN anti-tank missile systems to Taiwan at an estimated cost of $51 million.
If the U.S. Congress approves the sale as expected, this will represent the first addition of JAVELIN missiles to the Republic of China's anti-armor arsenal.

In a press release, the Defense Security Cooperation Agency said the sale would consist of 40 JAVELIN command launch units, 360 missile rounds, as well as simulators, and support equipment and services.

The agency said the systems would enhance Taiwan's medium-range anti-tank capability, adding that the transfer would also provide Taiwan with "a strong anti-landing capability and would increase inter-operability with U.S. forces".
With a range of approximately 2,500 meters, JAVELIN is equipped with an imaging infrared system and a fire-and-forget guided missile.
The prime contractor if the sale is approved will be JAVELIN Joint Venture (Raytheon and Lockheed Martin) of Orlando, Florida.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STAGES DEFENSIVE EXERCISE AGAINST BIOCHEMICAL ATTACKS

TEXT.P: The government demonstrated its full preparedness for a biochemical terrorist attack by staging an exercise at a Taipei subway station Saturday, mobilizing over 1,000 military, police, medical and environmental protection personnel.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said after overseeing the 90-minute drill that the primary objectives were to test the government's emergency response capability, to sensitize the public to biochemical terrorist threats and to familiarize them with the necessary measures to take in the event of such an emergency in order to minimize injuries.
He instructed all government agencies that took part in the exercise to immediately evaluate any problems that arose during the drill in order to rectify such oversights in the future.
Saturday's drill was the culmination of two previous rehearsals held Thursday and last Friday that were designed to work out the kinks in advance of the official exercise.
All three exercises began with a mock terrorist releasing an unknown toxic gas in the passenger compartment of a subway train at the Hsiaonanmen Station of the Taipei Mass Rapid Transit system.

In charge of organizing the exercise, Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) head Hau Lung-bin said that the government selected the location out of concern that terrorists might choose to carry out biochemical attacks in transportation hubs and public places with high concentrations of people.
During the exercise, while mock commuters frothing at the mouth dropped to the ground and noxious gases continued to spread, alarmed station personnel called in the cavalry.
Immediately, police arrived and cordoned off the area, and EPA personnel sealed the air ducts to the subway.
An evacuation was carried out, and medical personnel promptly began attending to the victims.

Emergency teams from the Department of Health and soldiers from the chemical warfare branch of the military's Sixth Field Army also rushed to the scene and began identifying and neutralizing chemical agents, sterilizing the entire station and the subway train.

On Monday, President Chen Shui-bian had urged relevant government agencies to heighten their level of alertness against all possible forms of terrorist biochemical warfare and to take effective steps to help enhance public awareness of the anthrax threat.
Chen gave the directives after presiding over a fourth high-level national security meeting regarding the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States.
In addition to staging drills and intensifying the campaign to inform the public, he said, the government should start evaluating and planning vaccine purchases and supply sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH SCHOOL GRADS TO HAVE MULTIPLE CHANNELS TO ENTER UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: Starting in the 2002 academic year, high school students in Taiwan will have more channels to enter the university or college department of their own choice as the Education Ministry puts into force a reform multiple university entrance program.

A spokesman of the Education Ministry announced Friday that in the 2002 academic year, 12 percent of freshmen will be selected from high schools' recommendation lists, 13 percent will be chosen from among individual applications, and 75 percent will be selected from among those choosing the conventional method of attending the university joint entrance examination.

The spokesman said that while all departments of the 143 universities and colleges will select their students mainly from the joint entrance examination, 347 departments will accept school recommendations as well as individual applicants, seven will only accept individual applicants, and five only school recommendations.

The multiple-channel approach has been in practice on a trial basis for the past few years, with the participating departments usually accepting only a limited number of students from recommendation lists or individual applications. In addition to the qualification requirements, these departments have conducted separate tests or interviews, with applicants having to prove their special qualities, language abilities or unique academic working plans in order to be accepted by the departments.

Those who plan to enter a university for the academic year beginning in 2002 via the school recommendation list or individual application channels are required to take a high school graduate examination in February, with their performance on the exam to be an important reference for the screening committees.

As most university departments will use the conventional method to select the majority of their new students, most high school graduates are expected to attend the university joint entrance examination next July.

The multiple-channel program is considered by those in education circles to be a great breakthrough in terms of Taiwan's education reform, with universities and colleges being able to attract students interested in specific subjects that they offer on the one hand, and high school graduates being offered more opportunities and choices on the other, the spokesman said.
The new mechanism will also provide advantages to students with special talents or qualifications, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEMICONDUCTOR WON'T HASTEN ITS DEPLOYMENT IN M'LAND: CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The chairman of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC) said Friday that it is still too early for TSMC to set up production lines in mainland China, adding that the company will invest NT$700 billion to build six 12-inch fabs in Taiwan over the next 10 years.

Morris Chang said at the company's third quarter investor conference that TSMC has made ready its deployment in mainland China, taking into consideration mainland's rapidly growing market and the advantages of its lower production costs.
He said, however, the market scale would remain comparatively small over the next two to three years and that it would not be easy to make money with some premature investments.

At the investor conference, Chang said that TSMC's net sales for the third quarter of 2001 reached NT$26.9 billion, down 43.3 percent from the same period the previous year, while the company's third-quarter net income totaled NT$1.2 billion, down 93.8 percent.

Chang said that the prospects for the semiconductor sector will remain gloomy next year, while the adverse impacts of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States will delay the recovery of the electronics industry as a whole.
Nevertheless, Chang said that he believes that TSMC will have a better performance in terms of revenues in the first quarter of next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND OVERFLIGHTS ISSUE STILL A `HOT POTATO' FOR GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: The issue of Taiwan jetliners flying through mainland Chinese airspace is still a "hot potato" for the government, despite Premier Chang Chung-hsiung expressing Friday that domestic carriers can apply to the Cabinet for mainland overflights.

Chang said Friday at the Legislative Yuan that domestic airlines can apply to the Executive Yuan for permission to fly through mainland airspace on their routes that had passed through Afghan airspace.

He made the remark while fielding a question by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lee Hsien-jung as to why the government is still refusing to allow domestic carriers to take advantage of an offer by Beijing to allow mainland overflights in order to avoid the dangerous skies over Afghanistan.

The Legislative Yuan recently passed a resolution asking the government to allow domestic airlines to use mainland Chinese airspace after Beijing offered to allow Taiwan carriers to do so, but the Cabinet has refused to comply, saying that such a move would have to be discussed by government officials from both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Deng Chen-chung, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said Saturday that Beijing has until now only verbally consented to allowing Taiwan carriers to fly through its airspace without further expression of an intent to negotiate with Taipei on the issue.
He said now that both Beijing and Taipei claim that "the ball is in the other's court," it is impossible for domestic carriers to fly through mainland Chinese airspace at present.

However, Deng said the MAC is highly flexible regarding the feasibility of Taiwan carriers' using mainland airspace, adding that Taipei still hopes that the implementation of the measure through negotiations with Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. THINK TANK FORESEES POSSIBILITY OF WAR IN TAIWAN STRAIT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 26 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Mainland China is likely to attack Taiwan in the next five to 10 years because it is worried about the "de-Sinonization" trend in Taiwan in recent years, according to a report released by a U.S. think tank Friday.

The report, issued by the National Bureau of Asian Research, said mainland China's fretting over Taiwan-U.S. relations, Japan-U.S. relations and new U.S. defense strategy would also enhance the possibility of mainland China using force against Taiwan.

Noting that the issue regarding reunification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is critical to the Communist Chinese regime's survival, the report said this reality has made it even more difficult to deter mainland China from invading Taiwan.
For the Chinese Communists, the report said, their regime's survival is far more important than national economic prosperity.
The report also pointed out that two other factors have made mainland China more likely to resort to the use of force against Taiwan.

First, the report said, mainland China's goal is mainly to intimidate Taiwan not to move toward de jure independence rather than to control the island. As a result, the report said, it would be relatively easier for mainland China to achieve its military aims.

Second, the report said if Beijing were to think that political and military developments in Taiwan, the United States and in other U.S. allies in the Asia-Pacific region were making the so-called Taiwan issue more difficult to resolve, mainland China would be more likely to resort to military intimidation.

The report further said three factors would enhance the possibility of mainland China using force against Taiwan -- namely Beijing underestimating Taiwan's and the United States' determination to defend the island; Beijing believing that if the United States were involved in a conflict in another part of the world, it would be less likely to involve itself in a Taiwan Strait conflict; and Beijing believing it could use military and diplomatic means to alienate the United States from its regional allies.

Meanwhile, the report said Beijing would like to see incumbent Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian from the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lose his re-election bid in 2004. If Chen wins his re-election bid and the DPP manages to increase its seats in the legislature, the report said, Beijing would become very jittery.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T OFFICIAL ADVOCATES INTELLIGENT TRANSPORTATION SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Taiwan's traffic-related problems such as congestion, accidents and air pollution can be alleviated only through the adoption of an intelligent transportation system (ITS), a Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) researcher said Saturday.

Chen Yi-chang, combined technology planner at the Transportation Research Institute, said at an ITS development seminar that the new system makes better use of technological advances in information gathering, telecommunication networks, traffic control and vehicle design to maximize the efficiency of the existing resources.

It is not feasible to try to solve traffic problems by building more roads, Chen said. The number of vehicles vying for space on the island's saturated roads has grown by 60 percent in the past nine years to a whopping 16.99 million against 51 percent for the total surface area available for automotive transportation, he added. Taiwan's surface area totals 36,000 square kilometers.

Those figures work out to about 472 vehicles per square kilometer. "And that number is rising," Chen said, "and all this contributes to excessive fuel waste and the mounting problem of air pollution."
Traffic accident casualties including deaths and injuries number more than 6,000 persons a year, according to police statistics. The top cause of the mishaps was "improper driving."

Through a systematic collection and analysis of traffic data, Chen said, useful and timely information can be provided for motorists as well as the operators and supervisors of public transportation systems.

The system would give operators an up-to-date picture of traffic conditions so that they could effectively adjust the scheduling and route assignment of their fleet of vehicles, while regulating the use of roads by encouraging drivers to avoid congested sections and traffic hours, Chen pointed out.

Chen said that his institute is working together with the MOTC Technology Advisory Department to develop a national ITS that is expected to reach demonstration stage in 2002. The ITS is scheduled for completion by 2005, he added.
The Transportation Research Insititute is in charge of developing the following ITS systems:
- Advanced transportation management.
- Electronic toll collection system for the freeways.
- Advanced travel information.
- Emergency response.
- Advanced mass transportation.
- Commercial vehicle operations.
- Advanced vehicle control and safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES PUBLIC FUNCTIONARIES TO REMAIN 'NEUTRAL'

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung Saturday cautioned government employees against getting involved in any form of election campaigning.
Chang told a "National Development Seminar" in Taipei the public functionaries should remain "neutral," while candidates are stumping across Taiwan in the run-up to the year-end elections.
Legislators, county magistrates and city mayors will be elected on the first day of December.

"All 600,000 public servants," Chang said, "should refrain from compromising their strictly neutral stance vis-a-vis the elections." Only by doing do so, he added, can they serve as a "clean stabilizing force of the nation."
The premier said the government employees sometimes have to "go out of" their way to help victims of natural disasters. "Don't stick to red tape all the time," he warned.

He compared the red tape-induced official lethargy with the whole-hearted assistance the military and charity organizations, the Buddhist Tzu Chi Compassionate Relief Association in particular, gave the victims of such natural disasters as the Great Earthquake of September 21, 1999.
"The public has been greatly impressed by the good work they did," he said.

Compared with the good reputation enjoyed by the military and Tzu Chi, Chang said, the public servants are considered "cold and conservative." "The people expect their officials to do just as well," he pointed out.

Chang said the public functionaries have made "efforts" to live up to that expectation. However, he added, whatever progress has been made is still not enough. He stressed the public servants must act to change the image that the government is incompetent. (Victor Lai)

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSFER OF POWER TO DPP PROCEEDED SMOOTHLY: LIN

TEXT.P: The transition of power from the Kuomintang to the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) proceeded smoothly, a top aide to former President Lee Teng-hui said Saturday.
Lin Pi-chao, deputy secretary-general to the Kuomintang President, denied that the power transition in May last year was "turbulent."

President Chen Shui-bian describes the historic shift of power as "turbulent" in his new book, which will come off the press next week. Excerpts of the book were made available Friday in a Presidential Office release. "I was surprised by Chen's characterization," said Lin, a key member of the Kuomintang government's transition team. "As a matter of fact," he pointed out, "it proceeded very smoothly."
Lee Teng-hui wanted a smooth transition, Lin said.
"Lee ordered Ding Mou-shih, then secretary-general of the National Security Council, to organize a special team to ensure a smooth transfer of power," Lin said.
"In preparation for the monumental shift of power," Lin recalled, "Ding held many rounds of talks with Chang Chun-hsiung, head of Chen's transition team, on relevant work and arrangements."
Chang, the incumbent premier, did not express any dissatisfaction over the conduct of the transition, Lin said. "To the best of my understanding," he pointed out, "Chang was not dissatisfied."
The Chen book is titled: "The First Voyage of the Century."
According to the book, the transition of power was fraught with danger. It is compared to a voyage in "turbulent seas."
In particular, President Chen accuses the National Security Council (NSC) of failing to hand over its dossier. He claims he is in total darkness about the NSC's work and problems.
Worse still, Chen charges in the book, his inherited staff was not cooperative in the early days of his Presidency. Cabiet agencies have faced the same problem, he adds.
The President recalls he was convinced that the transition would be full of uncertainty. He doubted if the power would be turned over peacefully and if he could be sworn in at all.
Neither the DPP nor the Kuomintang had any experience in power transfer, Chen writes.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS BEIJING'S RUDENESS AT APEC WILL AFFECT CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: Many local people think that mainland China's rudeness toward Taiwan at a recent regional meeting would adversely affect relations across the Taiwan Strait, according to the results of an opinion poll released Saturday.
The telephone survey of 1,120 randomly chosen adult residents was conducted from Oct. 24-26 by Gallup public opinion research center at the request Sanlih Entertainment Television.

Nearly 70 percent of survey respondents said they thought that mainland Chinese Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan's rudeness toward the Republic of China representative at a news conference held after a ministerial meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum would have a negative impact on future cross-strait relations. But 17 percent thought otherwise.
Poll results also showed that 48 percent of those interviewed were dissatisfied with the ROC government's handling of the APEC event, while 30 percent approved of the government's performance.

Despite Beijing's refusal to allow President Chen Shui-bian's proxy, former Vice President Li Yuan-zu, to attend this year's APEC summit in Shanghai, 45.8 percent of the respondents still said they support the proposal to ease restrictions on mainland China-bound investment. In contrast, 30 percent said they oppose the proposal.
Asked about future cross-strait relations, 28 percent said they agree to the Beijing-proposed "one country, two systems" unification scheme, but 35 percent gave a thumbs-down to the overture.
According to survey findings, the APEC fiasco is not expected to have a significant impact on the Dec. 1 elections for legislators, city mayors and county magistrates.
Only 25.4 percent said they think that Beijing's bullying of Taiwan at the APEC meeting would help the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) draw "sympathy votes" in the upcoming polls.
In comparison, 26.5 percent said they think that the APEC incident would help benefit the main opposition Kuomintang in the year-end polls.

Meanwhile, 17 percent said they believe that the opposition People First Party would also benefit from the DPP government's APEC fiasco. And 12.9 percent said they don't think that any political party would benefit from the APEC incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'SPORTS DAY' OUTING FOR FOREIGN MISSION STAFF

TEXT.P: Some of them played soccer. Others shot baskets. All of them laughed and had fun.

They did so with a unity of purpose at a Sports Day 2001 outing at National Taiwan University here Saturday to defy the threat of international terrorism heightened by the suicidal jetliner attacks on New York and Washington on Sept. 11.
All of them -- there were over 200 of them -- work at 29 foreign missions in Taipei or their wives, sons and daughters.
Vice President Annette Lu opened the meeting. Burkina Faso Ambassador Jacques Y. Sawadogo thanked all for participation in Sports Day 2001 to show support for the global anti-terrorism effort.
Highlights of the outing, aside from unconventional sports competition like a three-a-side soccer match, included a food fair and a special handicraft show.
Visitors swarmed to booths set up by the missions from Paraguay, India, Thailand, Belize, Great Britain, the Philippines, Argentina and Malaysia to taste delicacies not easily available in Taiwan.
Sports 2001 Night followed the outing. A fashion show was presented as a special attraction. An aborigine dance, "Return of the Innocent," drew a large audience.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP IS TO BLAME FOR TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC SLUMP

TEXT.P: Former Vice President Lien Chan said Saturday the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is to blame for Taiwan's economic slump.

Lien, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), told an election campaign rally here the current economic downturn started with the suspension of a nuclear power station project in October last year. The stock market turned bearish at the same time, he added.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung announced the suspension a year ago today, Lien said. The former vice president appeared at the rally to stump for Chu Lih-lun, who is running for magistrate of Taoyuan County, and KMT Parliamentary nominees.
Legislators, county magistrates and city mayors will be elected on December 1.

"October 27," Lien said, "should be designated as Day of Suffering for the Taiwan Economy." The people had to pay for a NT$3.1 billion loss caused by the suspension of the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant project, he charged, adding that investors have lost NT$6 trillion in the past 12 months.
"For all this the DPP is to blame," Lien pointed out.

He blasted the DPP for failure to make the economy grow by more than five percent a year as it had promised at the beginning of President Chen Shui-bian's administration. "The economy is expected to register a negative growth this year," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIVE TAIWANESE ACTIVISTS BARRED FROM ENTERING HONG KONG
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 27 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Five Taiwanese labor activists, who were barred from entering Hong Kong to take part anti-poverty protests, left Hong Kong for Taipei Saturday after being detained at the Hong Kong airport for one night.

The five were among some 20 foreign protesters who have been invited to participate in a march to be held on the eve of the World Economic Forum's East Asia economic summit which will open next Monday.

Organizers of the event told CNA that the five Taiwanese were barred from entering Hong Kong after they arrived at the Hong Kong airport Friday. The reason cited by immigration officials was "for security consideration."

They said that after the overnight detention, the five were forced to fly back to Taipei Saturday noon. Other protesters from the Philippines, New Zealand, Bangladesh, Thailand, Japan and South Korea have entered Hong Kong.
The five Taiwanese are Tsai Chih-chieh, Sun Chuang-li, Yang Wei, Hung Chia-ning and Liu Hui-min.

DOC.HEADLINE: APLFD CONGRESS OPENS IN AUCKLAND
DOC.DATELINE: Auckland, Oct. 27 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The 47th congress of the Asia Pacific League for Freedom and Democracy (APLFD) opened at a Auckland hotel Saturday with the participation of some 60 delegates from 15 countries.
Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's message to the congress was read at the opening by ROC Representative to New Zealand Lin Chung.
Chen told the gathering that freedom, democracy and human rights are the most valuable assets being pursued by the humankind.
In the past decade, he noted that the ROC has achieved full democracy and has made significant progress regarding human rights.

Chen said that in order to step up protection of human rights in Taiwan, the ROC government is considering to establish a "human rights committee" under either the Presidential Office or the Executive Yuan (Cabinet).
Several New Zealand officials and politicians are among the dignitaries invited to speak at the opening ceremony.
The main theme of the two-day congress is "Democracy and Human Rights in Asia and Pacific During the New Century."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The China Times:
President: vice president is stand-in, not semi-president.
The United Daily News:
President Chen: Annette Lu acts as semi-president.
The Liberty Times:
Politicians joined in chorus for reforms of both government and legislature.
The Taiwan Daily:
Lee Yuan-tseh insinuates that KMT chief Lien Chan is bragging about himself and smearing rivals.
The Central Daily News:
Lien Chan: people is suffering because President Chen ruined economy.
The China Post:
Chen supports plan to halve size of Legislature.
The Taiwan News:
U.S. launches heaviest strikes since war began.
The Taipei Times:
Military will get anti-tank kit form US.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT SEA-AIR TRANSSHIPMENT RESULTS LOWER THAN EXPECTED: AIRLINES

TEXT.P: More than two months after direct sea and air transshipment services across the Taiwan Strait were formally implemented, two major Taiwan airlines reported that increases in their cargo delivery volumes have been lower than expected.

EVA Airways had originally expected that its volume of cargo deliveries would increase by 1,000 tons per month in the short term following the start of direct cross-strait sea and air transshipment services before reaching as high as 4,000 tons per month in the middle- to long-term.

EVA didn't give the exact figure but admitted that the volume of cargo deliveries has been lower than expected, especially after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States. It is understood that the figure for the two-month-plus period is around 200 tons.

Meanwhile, China Airlines reported that the volume of its cargo deliveries via cross-strait sea and air transshipment services totaled only around 70 tons for the same period. The maximum carrying capacity of a single Boeing 747-400 cargo plane is 120 tons.

The Ministry of Transportation and Communications had said, based on airline operator estimates, that the implementation of direct cross-strait transshipment services could create around NT$12 billion (US$345.82 million) in business opportunities.
Although the airline operators said that results have been less than ideal so far, they expressed enthusiasm for the government's policy.

The Republic of China decided to expand the functions of its Kaohsiung offshore cross-strait transshipment center to cover airborne transshipment services, thereby dramatically cutting the time for cargo deliveries from the mainland.

The first shipment of cargo directly from mainland China to be transshipped via Taiwan came from Xiamen, Fujian Province, on board a Taiwan-based vessel of Uniglory Marine Corp. on Aug. 15 before being transported by air to Europe from Kaohsiung's offshore transshipment center.
Both Uniglory Marine and EVA Airways are affiliates of Taiwan's Evergreen Group, which operates the world's largest container shipping fleet.

Under the direct cross-strait air and sea transshipment services mechanism, cargo arriving at Kaohsiung from Fuzhou or Xiamen in mainland China is transported to Kaohsiung Airport or CKS International Airport in northern Taiwan to be transported by air to a third country.
Currently, mainland Chinese goods to be transshipped to a third country via Kaohsiung can neither clear customs nor enter Taiwan proper.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE AIRLINES BEGINS TAIPEI-MANILA-SHANGHAI FLIGHT SERVICES

TEXT.P: Amid increased exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Philippine Airlines began operating flights on the Taipei-Manila-Shanghai route Sunday.

A Philippine Airlines jet airliner, with 160 passengers on board, departed from Chiang Kai-shek International Airport Sunday morning, making Philippine Airlines the first foreign carrier to ply indirect flights between Taiwan and mainland China.

A Philippine Airlines Taiwan executive said her company decided to launch flight services on the route to better service Taiwan travelers heading for the mainland in the absence of direct cross-strait air traffic.

The flight on the Taipei-Manila-Shanghai route, offered five times per week, takes six hours and 50 minutes. Passengers departing from Taipei only have to wait for about one hour at the Manila airport and do not have to transfer airplanes.
In addition, Philippine Airlines now also offers four weekly flights between Taipei and Xiamen via Manila.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW SPAT ERUPTS BETWEEN PRESIDENT AND VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The smoldering differences between President Chen Shui-bien and Vice President Annette Lu again came into the open this weekend with Chen insinuating that Lu had overstepped her role as his lieutenant and Lu denying the charge.

In an advanced copy of the new book about Chen's first 500 days in office, President Chen says that according to the ROC Constitution, the vice president, instead of sharing the powers of the head of state, has a different and separate job from that of the president. Chen was quoted by anonymous academics as having said that Lu has acted more like a "semi-president" rather than as a vice president.

In the new book, scheduled to hit newsstands Wednesday, Chen supported his view by quoting former President Lee Teng-hui as warning him against letting his vice president in on offical memorandumns, calling the practice "governmental protocol."

Furthermore, Chen said he had consulted former Vice President Li Yuan-zu about the proper role of vice president and was told by Li that "a vice president is nothing more than a vice president" and that this view was the secret for his amicable ties with then President Lee Teng-hui during Li's six-year stint as vice president.
Li was billed as "a person with no voice" in Taipei political circles because of his refraining from airing personal views in public and therefore staying clear of controversy.

Military leaders expressed their displeasure with President Chen when he let Lu join him in overseeing military exercises and in inspecting military units, saying that "there is a commander in chief of armed forces but no deputy commander in chief" under the constitution, according to Chen.
Chen said that he believes that Lu will gradually come to know what her role is under the Constitution and play it accordingly in the future.

The president said he has expressed his views in support of both men and women running the state, adding that he chose Lu as his running mate in the 2000 presidential election on the strong recommendation of his wife Wu Shu-chen despite warnings by others that Lu is an abrasive person and hard to get along with.
Hours after the contents of Chen's book were made public, Lu issued a statement through her office late Saturday arguing that she had never overstepped her authority.

The vice president, who studied law at National Taiwan University and Harvard University, said she has "a considerable grasp of the constitution" and is confident that she has never acted beyond her authority and has always given Chen her utmost respect.

If she has ever appeared to have upstaged the president in public, she said, it has been for a good and proper reason, pointing to the example of her inspection of disaster areas in the wake of the recent typhoons that ravaged the island and the necessity of coming to the aid of victims who have suffered from repeated natural disasters.

Noting that the year-end elections are drawing near, Lu said she prefers to reserve her opinions about the new book's other controversial parts concerning her lest a public spat between herself and Chen jeopardize the election chances of the Democratic Progressive Party candidates.
Lu in her statement praised Chen's ideas concerning both men and women running the country but seemed to disagree with Chen's views about the role of the vice president.

Sunday's China Times quoted the Republic of China's first female vice president as saying that Li Yuan-zu was branded a voiceless man by Lee Teng-hui when Lee explained to the country his choice of Li as his running mate.

Lu told the paper that Li never called himself a voiceless man except for once in public, although he did do many things for the country while in office, not to mention Li's successor who doubled as premier for two years.

The outspoken vice president is often at odds with Chen, with the Latest example being Lu's criticism of Chen's choice of envoy to represent him at the recent Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation informal leadership summit in Shanghai.

Lu said in an interview with a local magazine Wednesday that Chen's misunderstandings of the international situation led to Beijing's rejection of Li Yuan-zu as Chen's personal envoy to the summit, an allegation immediately denied by Chen's office.

Calling Lu's remarks "misleading and regrettable," the President's Office said in a statement that the APEC informal leadership summit fiasco was caused by Beijing's attempts to undermine the island's status in the international arena rather than by miscalculations by the ROC government.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN HALF OF VOTERS STILL UNDECIDED: POLL

TEXT.P: More than half of Taiwan voters still have not decided for whom they will vote in the Dec. 1 legislative elections, according to the results of a public opinion poll released Sunday.

On the question of who they would vote for if the elections were held tomorrow, the poll, conducted by the Republic of China Public Opinion Research Association between Oct. 23-25, found that 51 percent of those surveyed said they are still undecided.

Meanwhile, on the same question, 14 percent of the respondents said they would vote for a Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate, 10 percent said they would cast their ballot for a Kuomintang (KMT) candidate, and 7.9 percent said they would vote for a People First Party (PFP) candidate.

On the question of which political party is most capable of leading the people through Taiwan's current economic hardships, 19.1 percent said the KMT, 11.6 percent said the DPP, and 5 percent mentioned the PFP.
Some 26.4 percent of those surveyed said they have confidence in none of the political parties in this regard, while 33.8 percent said they have no opinion on the question.

Meanwhile, 21.8 percent of those polled said they think that the KMT is the political party that will give the people the most confidence if it takes power, 17.3 percent mentioned the DPP, and 9 percent said the PFP. Those who said they have confidence in none of the parties in this regard was 18.8 percent, while those with no ideas on this question was 29.2 percent.

On the question of which political party they support the most, 13.3 percent of those surveyed said they favor the DPP, 8.2 percent mentioned the KMT, 7.7 percent said the PFP, while 35.3 percent said they support none of the parties, and 22.8 percent said they have no idea.
The poll, carried out by telephone interview on 1,177 adults around the island, has a margin of error of plus or minus 2.9 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATIVE CAUCUS WHIP HOPES WTO BILLS PASSED BEFORE NOV.1

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party's Legislative caucus whip Tsai Huang-liang expressed the hope that the Legislative Yuan will be able to pass all the bills related to Taiwan's WTO entry before its goes into a one-month recess beginning Nov. 1.

The Legislature will go into recess because of the scheduled Dec. 1 elections for legislators, county magistrates and city mayors. However, it will hold a special one-day session Nov. 16 to deliberate the bills related to Taiwan's WTO accession before the next session commences Dec. 2.
Tsai said he hopes that despite the time pressures, the 14 WTO-related bills, 9 of which still have to undergo deliberation by the legislature, will be passed before the end of this month.

The legislative caucuses of the ruling DPP and the opposition parties will meet again Tuesday, with discussion centered on WTO-related bills as well as the fiscal year 2002 national budget and the Legislative Yuan reform bill.

The nine bills which the Legislature still has not completed deliberations on include the civil aeronautics law amendment bill, the seaport law amendment bill, the lawyer law amendment draft bill, the construction law draft bill, the examination law amendment draft bill for foreigners on special profession and technicians, the cinema law amendment draft bill, the compact disc statute draft bill, the certified accountant law bill, and the customs house import tariff and duties amendment bill.

Lee Cheng-Tsung, the KMT's legislative caucus whip, and Levi Ying, the New Party's legislative caucus whip, said that they could not assure that all the bills would be passed as the New Party has opinions regarding the lawyer law amendment bill.
Chou Hsi-wei, the People First Party's legislative caucus whip, said that the construction bill has nothing to do with Taiwan's WTO entry and should be excluded from the list. (Edward Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER HALF OF TAIPEI RESIDENTS APPROVE OF RECRUITING SYSTEM: POLL

TEXT.P: Slightly over half of Taipei residents approve a military recruiting system, although most think the system may result in insufficient numbers of military personnel, according to the results of a survey released Sunday.
The results of the poll, conducted between Oct. 17-19 on Taipei residents over the age of 18, were announced by Yok Mu-ming, a New Party (NP) candidate in the Dec. 1 legislative elections.
The survey showed that 50.1 percent of respondents said they approve of the recruitment system, while 42.1 said they are against it.

Those who said they favor the idea of military personnel streamlining in order to reduce national defense expenditures and put the resulting savings toward economic construction and social welfare was 58.3 percent, while those who said they are against the idea was 31.9 percent.
The survey also showed that 51.3 percent of those polled said the cross-strait military situation is "normal," while 17.1 percent said it is "tense," and 20.6 percent said it is "not tense."
Meanwhile, 51.5 percent of those polled said they do not worry about a cross-strait military clash breaking out, while 43.3 percent said they do worry about this.

Regarding the argument that implementing the recruiting system will help enhance cross-strait trust and contribute to cross-strait peace while not leading to an arms race with the mainland, 58 percent of respondents said they agree, while 27.2 percent said they disagree.
Taiwan currently has a system of conscription, and draftees can choose to engage in military services or in alternative social work or diplomatic work.
A total of 1,070 valid samples were collected for the survey, with the poll having a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TOUTS TAIWAN'S ADVANTAGE OVER MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Mainland China is no match for Taiwan in both democracy and economic competitiveness, President Chen Shui-bian said in Kaohsiung Friday.
In an attempt to stem the exodus of Taiwan's enterprises to mainland China, President Chen urged his countrymen not to buy claims that mainland China is better than Taiwan in terms of doing business.

Quoting a Financial Times survey, Chen said mainland China lagged far behind Taiwan in overall competitiveness, personnel quality, the number of skilled workers and resources, not to mention the island's sound democracy which has seen the first peaceful power transition in the country's history.

Chen cited another survey, "Global Competitiveness Report 2000-2001," as ranking Taiwan fifth on the list of the world's best areas in terms of economic prospects and competitiveness, ahead of Hong Kong, South Korea, Japan and the United Kingdom. In the survey by the Geneva-based World Economic Forum, the People's Republic of China came in 39th place and was expected to remain on the spot in the next five years.
In respect of scientific development, Taiwan ranked fourth against 52nd for mainland China, Chen told an annual conference of the Tainan Association.
"All these surveys debunk widespread claims that mainland China is a place better than Taiwan for doing business," Chen pointed out.
Although there is always room for improvement in Taiwan's investment climate, Chen said, "our people should never lose faith in our own country."
President Chen said he told the Associated Press in an interview Friday he would ask President Jiang Zemin of the People's Republic of China two questions, if and when they ever meet.

One of the questions, Chen said, was why followers of the Falun Gong spiritual movement can preach their belief freely in Taiwan but are forbidden to do so on the Chinese mainland. The other question was: Will China follow in Taiwan's footsteps in democracy, allowing different political parties to govern in turn?
Chen said he posed the latter question to stress that Taiwan is a full-fledged democracy. Democracy is Taiwan's proudest achievement, he told the Associated Press.
"In democracy as well as economic potentiality," Chen pointed out, "China isn't our match at all."
He repeated his call for a higher government efficiency by halving the seats of the Legislative Yuan. The Executive Yuan (Cabinet) agencies should be reduced by a third, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 29, or the 13th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1618: Sir Walter Raleigh, English courtier, navigator, colonizer and writer, is beheaded in the Tower of London for treason against King James I at the age of 54. His literary works include poetry, memoirs, and a world history.
1863: Henri Dunant, Swiss philanthropist, founds the International Red Cross. He was a joint recipient of the 1901 Nobel Peace Prize.
1881: The first national political party is founded in Japan.
1911: Joseph Pulitzer, Hungarian-born American journalist and newspaper publisher, dies at the age of 64. He owned papers in St. Louis and New York City as well as established the Pulitzer Prize.
1923: The Republic of Turkey is proclaimed, with nationalist leader Kemal Ataturk as its first president.
1927: Russian archaeologist Peter Kozlov discovers the tomb of Genghis Khan in the Gobi Desert.
1929: "Black Tuesday" follows "Black Thursday" on Wall Street as the crisis of confidence hits the New York stock market, leading to the Great Depression of the 1930s.
1932: The Normandie, one of the three most luxurious ships ever built, is launched in France. The 300 meter-long vessel crossed the Atlantic Ocean in just over four days. A fire destroyed the ship while it was berthed in New York Harbor in 1942.
1942: Nazis massacre 16,000 Jews in Pinsk, Russia.
1944: In his capacity as supreme commander of the China Theater of War, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek appoints U.S. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer as chief of staff of the China Theater of War. Meanwhile, U.S. Gen. Daniel L. Sultan is appointed commander in chief of the U.S. Expeditionary Forces in India.
1945: Anna Rosenberg is given the first U.S. Medal of Freedom ever awarded to a woman.
1953: The North American F-100 Super Sabre jet fighter sets a record by reaching a speed of 1,215 kilometers per hour, becoming the first jet capable of being operated at supersonic speeds.
1962: The Republic of China Foreign Ministry issues a statement refusing to recognize India's position of using the "McMahon Line" as the border line between India and China.
1964: Tanganyika unites with Zanzibar, forming Tanzania.
1974: A five-member Korean parliamentary mission headed by the chairman of the Korean Democratic Republican Party, Rhee Hyo Sang, and 130 members of the Japanese Diet, arrive in Taipei to take part in celebrations marking President Chiang Kai-shek's 87th birthday.
1977: Taiwan's first IC (integrated circuit) plant, under the Industrial Technology Research Institute, is inaugurated in Chutung in Hsinchu County.
1980: A declaration by Deng Xiaoping, vice chairman of the Chinese Communist Party, that Mao Zedong made serious political mistakes during his rule, is made public.
1981: The Chinese National Federation of Industries and the Chamber of Industry of Guatemala sign a cooperation agreement to promote economic, trade and cultural relations.
1984: The Chinese team from Taiwan wins second place in the World Amateur Baseball Championship in Cuba.
1985: The first prototype of "Ching Kuo," the first ROC-developed and manufactured indigenous defense fighter, bursts its nose-wheel during a test flight at Chingchuenkang Air Force Base in Taichung.
1986: The Ministry of Economic Affairs announces that ROC-U.S. trade talks on wine and tobacco imports are in a stalemate. Washington charged that Taipei failed to keep promises of providing greater market access for U.S. beer, wine and tobacco, and said the United States would draft retaliatory measures against the ROC under Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974.
1998: John Glenn, U.S. astronaut, blasts off aboard the space shuttle Discovery at the age of 77, 36 years after his first space mission.
1999: Carleton S. Fiorina, chief executive of Hewlett-Packard Co., the world's No. 2 computer maker, arrives in Taipei for a two-day whirlwind visit.
2000: Taiwan's China Airlines inaugurates a new flight route between Taipei, Penang in Malaysia, and Medan in Indonesia.
2000: A poll unveiled by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party shows that only 33.2 percent of the Taiwan public supports the Cabinet's decision to halt construction on the island's fourth nuclear power plant, while 47.5 percent oppose the decision.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "When a ruler regards his ministers as his hands and feet, they regard him as their belly and heart; when he regards them as dogs and horses, they regard him as a common citizen; when he regards them as dirt and grass.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERT WARNS OF INCREASED COMPETITION, DISPUTES FOLLOWING WTO ENTRY

TEXT.P: Although both Taiwan and mainland China hope for new trade and investment links following their imminent World Trade Organization (WTO) accession, a local expert warned Sunday of fiercer competition and increased trade friction between the two sides.

Tien Chun-mei, head of the Mainland Chinese Economic Affairs Department under the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, told CNA that two-way relations will be "cooperative and competitive" in the future and that Taiwan must take measures to tackle the challenge amid a brand-new trade and commerce relationship between the two sides.

As the government decided to adopt the "active opening, efficient management" policy to replace the "no haste, be patient" policy governing mainland-bound investment by Taiwan business after the Economic Development Advisory Conference in August, Tien said Taiwan is set to further open up its market while its WTO accession approaches.

According to Tien, Taiwan will face stronger pressure from mainland China's agricultural imports, an influx of mainland Chinese capital and growing Taiwan investment in mainland China after the island joins the WTO.

In view of the delicate situation between the two sides, Tien urged the government to take precautions especially against the expected inflows of investment from mainland China as he said it is very possible Beijing will use its investment in Taiwan as a tool to manipulate the island's economy and financial market.

To effectively regulate the movements of mainland Chinese capital in the Taiwan market, Tien said the government must start with reforming the local financial system and improving its monitoring mechanisms.

At a time when political hostilities still exist between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Tien proposed that the government prohibit mainland capital from being invested in Taiwan's infrastructure, media, hi-tech and financial sectors.
Tien said that the government must have the ability to react swiftly to market developments and that an official mechanism to monitor capital movements should be set up immediately.

At the same time, trade friction between Taiwan and mainland China will also increase after the two sides enter the WTO, the economist warned. He said he was also skeptical about whether bilateral trade disputes can be resolved through normal procedures set by the WTO.

From Taiwan's point of view, future cross-strait trade, commerce and investment disputes should be settled through WTO channels, Tien said. But he pointed out that mainland China may not be willing to do so out of fear that a "country-to-country relationship" would be established between Taiwan and the mainland under the WTO framework.

Meanwhile, some Taiwan companies may be forced to move out of Taiwan in search of lower production costs, fueling a fresh wave of exodus by local businesses to mainland China and creating a "clustering phenomenon of Taiwan investors" there, he said.

According to Tien, Taiwan must efficiently upgrade its industrial levels with an international outlook to fend off the "economic magnetism" of mainland China, which he said is sparing no efforts to lure greater Taiwan investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NOT YET DECIDED ON USING WTO EXCLUSION PRINCIPLE AGAINST M'LAND

TEXT.P: Taiwan has not yet decided whether to employ the "exclusion provision" against mainland China after its impending accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO), sources from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Monday.
According to WTO regulations, a member is allowed to exclude another member from open market treatment under special conditions.
Since both mainland China and Taiwan have not yet been formally admitted to the WTO, the MOEA said it sees no rush in declaring Taiwan's stance on the matter at the moment, ministry officials said.

Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi said Taiwan will wait until the last minute to make known its decision on the "exclusion provision" issue on the grounds that there is the possibility that Beijing might use its political clout to interfere with Taiwan's WTO entry.

Vice Economic Affairs Minister Chen Ruey-long noted that the issue of whether Taiwan would employ the WTO's "exclusion provision" to deal with its post-WTO accession trade and economic ties with mainland China is currently under intensive assessment by high-level officials, adding that the government will make a decision based on the best interests of the nation at the most "appropriate time."

According to WTO regulations, Chen said, if Taiwan decides to employ the "exclusion provision" against mainland China, it must put forth the proposal to the WTO Secretariat before the fourth WTO ministerial meeting is held in Qatar Nov. 9-13, during which mainland China's and Taiwan's WTO accession will be the centerpiece of discussions.
Chen added that Taipei will make the final decision on the "exclusion provision" issue before Nov. 9.

Meanwhile, in response to a local daily newspaper report Monday that Taiwan will not employ the "exclusion provision" against mainland China after the island is admitted into the WTO, officials from the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said related government agencies have not yet made any decision on the matter.

MAC officials said the Republic of China government is more than willing to engage in any form of goodwill interactions with mainland China under the WTO framework and attaches great expectations to the conducting of bilateral economic and trade exchanges based on the principles of reciprocity and equality.
Taiwan should have no need to use the "exclusion provision" against mainland China if the two sides can engage in benign interactions, MAC officials added.
Meanwhile, Wu Rong-I, president of the private think-tank Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, called for the government Monday to handle carefully strategies related to Taiwan's WTO accession.

Wu said if Taiwan refrains from employing the "exclusion provision" against mainland China, the island should open its entire market to all mainland China-originating agricultural products, adding that it is a big question mark whether Taiwan's agricultural sector could stand the impact.

Meanwhile, Wu pointed out, mainland China promised to endorse a "defending provision" when it began to conduct WTO bilateral talks, indicating that within the first 12 years of its formal WTO membership, mainland China would agree to the employing of the "defending provision" by any member of the WTO if that member country found that imports of mainland Chinese products had exerted too great an impact on its domestic industries and consequently caused great losses to its people.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 21.53 points to close at 4,065.1.
The bourse opened at 4,081.94 and continued to go up due to a rise in electrical share prices. The index fluctuated between 4,084.89 and 4,033.98 during trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPAT ERUPTS OVER ISSUE OF CABINET-FORMING RIGHT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and Frank Hsieh, chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, on Sunday and Monday, respectively, stressed that it is the president's right to form the Cabinet after the year-end legislative elections.

Both were responding to Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou's remark Sunday in Tainan, southern Taiwan, that if the opposition camp wins over half of the legislative seats in the Dec. 1 elections, the president should hand over the right to form the Cabinet. The popular mayor made the comment while stumping for candidates of the Kuomintang (KMT), the opposition party with the most seats in the present Legislature.

President Chen said that the fact that the right to form the Cabinet is the president's "is a matter of common sense," adding that "you don't have to have a doctoral degree to understand this," in an apparent indirect reference to Ma, who holds a doctoral degree in law from Harvard University.

The president pointed out that just as the Taipei mayor appoints major officials and just as the U.S. president forms his cabinet instead of the majority party in Congress forming it, he "certainly will form the Cabinet" after the elections.

Chen pointed out that if one were to act according to the rhetoric of the opposition camp, then this would mean that they would end up ruling the country regardless of whether they had won the presidency, asking rhetorically what the point of holding a presidential election would be.
DPP Chairman Hsieh on Monday also criticized Ma's remark, saying it will not win the support of the people.

On the opposition camp's demand that the ruling party turn over the right to form a Cabinet or else chaos in the political situation will result, Hsieh said that this is tantamount to "political blackmail."
He stressed that the people are most concerned about whether there will be growth in the economy and stability in politics and that they are less concerned about who holds political power.

Hsieh said that in the past, the Republic of China constitution had stipulated that the president's choice for the post of premier had to gain the approval of the Legislative Yuan, but that under the revised constitution, the Legislative Yuan no longer has this right of approval and the forming of the Cabinet is a presidential power.

Ma for his part said Monday that he would not speak again on the issue of the right to form a Cabinet, mentioning only that he would elaborate on his view in due time following the elections if it became necessary.

While in Tainan on Sunday, the popular mayor urged voters to rally behind the "pan-blue alliance" before making his comment that if the alliance wins more than half the seats in the Legislature, the president should hand over the right to form the Cabinet to the alliance so as to facilitate the operations between the executive and legislative branches of government.

Ma said that Taiwan could not afford more political chaos and that the people could not wait any longer, adding that the president should respect the will of the public as manifest in the results of the elections. Chen's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) currently controls less than one third of the seats in the Legislative Yuan and is hoping to increase this number in the elections.

The "pan-blue alliance" refers to an alliance between the KMT and its two splinter groups -- the New Party and the People First Party. The three parties share a roughly common pro-unification stance on relations with mainland China in contrast with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's pro-independence position.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADE WITH MAINLAND AS PROPORTION OF ROC'S TOTAL TRADE INCREASES

TEXT.P: While Taiwan's foreign trade has continued to decline due to the global and domestic economic sluggishness, the island's two-way trade with mainland China as a proportion of its total trade has surged to a new high, the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) reported Monday.

Taiwan's exports to mainland China as a proportion of its total exports soared to 21.5 percent in August, while the island's imports from mainland China as a proportion of its total imports increased to 6.2 percent, both representing record highs, BOFT officials noted.

Taiwan exported US$2.029 billion worth of products to mainland China in August, down 12.2 percent from the same month in the previous year, while it imported US$475 million worth of products from the mainland, down 2.9 percent, according to BOFT tallies.

Taiwan's exports to and imports from mainland China began to decline from the beginning of the second quarter of this year as part of the consequences of the island's floundering economy. The scale of this decline, however, has been much smaller than the decline in the island's exports to and imports from other parts of the globe, BOFT officials said.

Taiwan's two-way trade with mainland China amounted to US$19.29 billion for the first eight months of this year, marking a year-on-year decline of 8.9 percent. The figure, meanwhile, represented 12.4 percent of the island's entire foreign trade in the period, up from the 11.1 percent for the same period in the previous year, the officials quoted BOFT statistics as indicating.

Electric machinery, machine tools, plastics, iron and steel, synthetic fibers, and industrial textiles made up the bulk of Taiwan's exports to mainland China in the January-August period, with electric machinery and related equipment constituting 50 percent of the island's total exports to the mainland, the officials said.

In comparison, the top five categories of products that Taiwan imported from mainland China during the eight-month period were electric machinery and related equipment, machine tools, mineral fuel and related products, iron and steel, and toys and sporting goods, in that order.
