DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER DEFENDS PRESIDENT CHEN'S COMPLAINT ABOUT DOSSIER TRANSFER

TEXT.P: The controversy stirred up by President Chen Shui-bian's allegation in his new book that last year's transfer of power was completed through a "verbal transition" without dossier handover continued to rage in the political community Monday.
Several candidates running for legislative seats in the Dec. 1 elections as well as a civic group filed charges against former President Lee Teng-hui over dossier law violations.

In an effort to diffuse the controversy, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung told the local press that President Chen's mentioning of certain "facts" in his soon-to-be-published book was mainly aimed at pushing for the establishment of a sound system regarding the transition of power between different political parties, and not at blaming any individual persons or government agencies.

In his book, titled "The First Voyage of the Century," President Chen particularly accused the National Security Council (NSC) of failing to hand over its files. He claimed that he was in total darkness about the NSC's work and problems. Excerpts of the book, which will come off the press Wednesday, were made available over the weekend in a Presidential Office release.

Premier Chang, who was head of Chen's transition team, said he is convinced that Chen mentioned the issue mainly because the president intends to set up a system to govern transitions of power. Last year's peaceful transition of power from the Kuomintang (KMT) to the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) was the first ever in the Republic of China's history.

Chang cited two events -- the ROC's representation at the annual summit meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum and the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States -- to underscore the importance of the establishment of a wholesome system.

In his view, Chang said, relevant government agencies should leave detailed records on how the Presidential Office had decided on the choice of a proxy to represent the president at the APEC summits and how the Cabinet had responded to the Sept. 11 incident. "Such records could be useful reference materials in the government's future decision-making procedures," he noted.

In reaction to Chen's allegation, several key members of a pro-unification association filed a charge with the Taipei Prosecutor's Office against former President Lee accusing him of failing to hand over the NSC dossier to his successor. The association has been critical of Lee over his alleged pro-independence stance.

Several candidates for the upcoming legislative elections, including Ko Su-hai, Taipei City Councilor Wei Yi-lung and opposition People First Party Legislator Lee Ching-hua, also filed similar charges against the former president separately.

Legislator Lee said the former president had handled many major national incidents and issues -- including the 1996 Taiwan Strait crisis and the choosing of Taiwan's representatives to the annual APEC summits -- through the NSC during his 12-year stint as the head of state.

"If no official records concerning those events were left in the Presidential Office, the former president might have offended our country's dossier law and might even have committed such crimes as damaging official documents and concealing national secrets," Lee alleged.

In response to Chen's allegation, former NSC Secretary-General Yin Chung-wen issued a statement Sunday stressing that he had personally handed over the complete NSC dossier to his successor Chuang Ming-yao when the DPP administration was inaugurated May 20, 2000.

Meanwhile, the KMT's Legislative Yuan caucus issued a statement Monday demanding that the Presidential Office look into whether any officials should be held accountable for failing to handling over the NSC dossier during last year's transition of power.
The statement said if the dossier had been properly transferred as former NSC Secretary-General Yin claimed, President Chen should issue a public apology for his "slip of the tongue."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER RECEIVES OUTGOING CHADIAN AMBASSADOR

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung on Monday expressed his appreciation to outgoing Chadian Ambassador to the Republic of China Salim Abderaman Taha for his contributions toward enhancing relations between the two countries during his four-year term.

Premier Chang noted that since the resumption of diplomatic ties between the ROC and Chad four years ago, there has been much cooperation between the two nations, adding that Taha played a crucial role in the upgrading of bilateral relations and in the promotion of bilateral exchanges.

Taha noted that since the resumption of formal diplomatic ties, bilateral cooperation has covered many major areas, citing as an example the fact that the ROC has helped in the building of hospitals, roads and bridges in Chad.

He said that in the area of drinking-water improvements alone, statistics show that infectious diseases in some parts of the African nation have been eradicated, adding that the people of Chad are appreciative of the ROC's assistance.
Taha also expressed his heartfelt thanks for the assistance rendered to him during his four-year term, stressing that bilateral relations will be further cemented in the future.

He added that after his return to Chad, there will be two ROC ambassadors in his country, including the actual one and he himself. Considering himself as a Taiwan person already, he said he will dedicate his efforts toward promoting friendly cooperation between the two nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC FUNDAMENTALS GOOD: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that Taiwan's economic fundamentals are good and expressed the hope that the public will continue to have confidence in the country.
President Chen made the remarks while receiving the winners of awards in the stocks and futures field of business at the presidential office.

The president cited the Geneva-based World Economic Forum's recently released "Global Competitiveness Report 2000-2001" which rated Taiwan as the seventh most competitive economy over the next five years, up from 11th place last year.
Chen said that the report shows that Taiwan's economic fundamentals are sound and that the island's potential cannot be underestimated, adding the people of Taiwan should have faith in themselves.
On the fluctuations in the domestic stock market, the president attributed them mainly to the effects of the global economic slump and to several domestic factors.

The president also pointed to Taiwan's fourth-place ranking in terms of scientific development in the World Economic Forum's report, saying this high ranking is the result of the Taiwan people's strong abilities in terms of innovation and invention.
The president said that all these points indicate that Taiwan has sound economic fundamentals and good prospects.

He also pointed to a report by the Financial Times that noted Taiwan faces serious challenges in the global economy but that its economy will not continue to be sluggish as the island enjoys certain advantages, saying that the public should rally behind the government.

On the "go slow, be patient" policy toward investment in mainland China, the president stressed that the policy had made significant contributions in the past, but he added that with the changing times, the government will now follow a policy of "active opening, effective management."

He urged domestic businesses to maintain their roots in Taiwan by keeping their headquarters as well as research and development departments in Taiwan, saying that mainland China will only be a part of Taiwan's economic policy with a "global perspective."

DOC.HEADLINE: ARSON ON THE RISE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The number of arson cases in Taiwan has continued to rise over the last three years, reaching a record high of 1,004 in 2000, sources from the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) reported Monday.

The number of reported arson cases in 1999 climbed to 792 from 670 in 1998 before jumping to 1,004 in 2000, officials from the MOI's National Fire Administration quoted ministry tallies as indicating.

National Fire Administration officials noted that while the number of arson cases has been on the rise over the past several years, the number of accidental fires has continued to decline, from 18,254 in 1999 to 15,560 in 2000.

The officials warned of the ever-increasing increasing seriousness of the implications of the rising number of arson cases, particularly when the number of accidental fires declined by 2,694 over the last two years while the number of arson cases increased by 212.
In the first eight months of this year, according to the tallies, the number of accidental fires was 9,106, compared with 797 reported cases of arson.

Similar records disclosed in August by the National Fire Administration showed that the number of arson cases in the first six months of this year increased by 33.9 percent over the figure for the same period the previous year.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIERCE COMPETITION EXPECTED IN TAIWAN'S FINANCIAL SERVICES MARKET

TEXT.P: At least 13 combinations of banking, insurance, and securities operations have been formed and will apply for licenses to become financial holding companies, presaging unprecedented fierce competition in Taiwan's financial services market.

An analysis by President Securities Corp. indicated that several domestic financial groups have readied themselves to provide full-fledged services when the government puts the Financial Holding Company Law into force Nov. 1.

In addition to Fubon Group and Lin Yuan Group, China Development Industrial Bank, United World Chinese Commercial Bank and the International Commercial Bank of China have expressed interest in the corporate structure which will allow banks, insurers and brokerages to operate in a cluster.

The analysis said that the financial holding companies will have the advantages of attracting more customers with their full-fledged services. For fear of being edged out of the market by the leading financial conglomerates, some banks, insurance companies and securities houses are seeking to maintain their competitiveness through mergers.

The analysis pointed out that mergers are not necessarily the answer for improving competitiveness and that the mushrooming number of financial holding companies engaged with one another in price wars will only damage the financial services market.

The Financial Holding Company Law was passed by the Legislature in early July as part of the government's financial reform programs. With the opening of Taiwan's financial sector to international competition when the island is admitted into the World Trade Organization, Taiwan is embracing opportunities as well as challenges, the analysis said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-U.S. JOINT-VENTURE TO MARKET NEW SMALL UTILITY PLANES
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Oct. 28 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A small utility plane developed by a Taiwan-U.S. joint-venture aircraft manufacturing firm, will take off at a grand ceremony to be held in West Virginia in November, industry sources said over the weekend.

Lo Cheng-kuo, vice chairman of the joint-venture firm -- Tiger Aircraft Co. -- said that prominent politicians and senior business executives from the Republic of China and the United States, including U.S. senators John D. Rockefeller and Robert C. Byrd, as well as ROC Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Yin Chi-ming, will attend the ceremony.

"After more than two years of strenuous efforts, Tiger will be able to receive certification from the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration in the next few days for volume production of our new AG5B small utility airplane," said Lo, who was in the San Francisco area to promote the new plane.
The four-seater, single-engine AG5B can fly for up to 500 miles without refueling and will sell for only US$219,500, Lo continued.
He noted that the United States now has 6,000 similar small aircraft. "Tiger has received orders for 48 AG5Bs," Lo went on, adding that eight of them will be delivered before the end of this year.

Lo said the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York and Washington have sent the U.S. civil aviation industry into a tailspin. "Nevertheless, the terrorist assaults have brought new business opportunities to small plane manufacturers, as many globe-trotting lawyers, doctors, engineers and business executives now prefer to purchase or lease small aircraft for short- and medium-range travel," he noted.

Tiger's plant in West Virginia can produce 180 to 200 AG5Bs per year, Lo said, adding that the company plans to increase the number of its marketing centers in the United States from the current four to 15 over the next few years. Tiger will also construct a maintenance and repair workshop in mid-2002 to enhance its after-sale service.
The company has paid-in capital of US$30 million, with U.S. investors contributing 30 percent and the remaining stakes held by several Taiwan venture capital firms.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXCESSIVE EXPANSION CAUSES LOSSES FOR TAIWAN TFT-LCD MANUFACTURERS

TEXT.P: Excessive expansion of their production capacities had caused heavy losses for Taiwan's TFT-LCD (thin film transistors -- liquid crystal display) manufacturers due to drastic price drops, according to a report published Monday.

The Industrial Technology Information Services (ITIS) forecast that the production value of Taiwan's TFT-LCD manufacturers will reach NT$89.9 billion in 2001, up 77 percent from the previous year's level.
The rapid expansion has enabled Taiwan's TFT-LCD manufacturers to increase their international market share from last year's 11.6 percent to 22.9 percent.

However, as the supply has far exceeded demand in the past few months, TFT-LCD prices have dropped by 50 percent to 60 percent since early this year. Sources in the local opto-electronics sector said that heavy inventories and price drop might cause the four leading TFT-LCD manufacturers to suffer losses as high as NT$25 billion this year.

The four leading manufacturers -- Au Optronics, Chi Mei Optoelectronics Corp., Chunghwa Picture Tubes, and HannStar Display Corp. -- are all planning to cut production costs by moving their low-end assembly lines to mainland China.

An ITIS report suggests that Taiwan's TFT-LCD manufacturers can also lower their production costs by sourcing more components and parts supplies domestically. At present, manufacturers rely heavily on imports of key components.

Although Monday's report predicts that TFT-LCD prices will remain low and that no rebound is foreseen before the end of next year, many Taiwan manufacturers are more optimistic about the prospects for next year.
A spokesman for Au Optronics said he expects that a gradual recovery of the international demand for PCs in the second half of next year will stimulate demand for TFT-LCDs.

Au Optronics, a merger of Unipac Optoelectronics and Acer Display Technologies, is the third-largest TFT-LCD manufacturer in the world, next only to Samsung and LG Philips of South Korea. In the first half of this year, Au Optronics's supplies accounted for 8 percent of the world demand for TFT-LCDs.

According to the ITIS report, Taiwan may catch up with South Korea and Japan to become the world's No. 1 TFT-LCD supplier within the next few years. In addition to Au Optronics, Chi Mei Optoelectronics has been playing a dominating role in the international market. The company took over DTI -- a joint venture of IBM Japan and Toshiba -- in July and boosted its TFT-LCD production capacity considerably.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS OPPOSE MERGER OF BUDGET OFFICE AND FINANCE MINISTRY

TEXT.P: Three scholars have voiced opposition to a government proposal to incorporate the Finance Ministry and the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS), part of the government's reform package.

Su Tsai-chu, a political science professor at the National Taiwan University said last week that the merger of the two agencies -- whose functions do not overlap -- would neither achieve the reform's goals of cutting down the number of employees nor improve government efficiency.

The Finance Ministry is charged with finding means for the government, while the DGBAS is tasked with preventing the government from wasting funds. According to Su, the two jobs cannot be mixed and therefore the incorporation of the two agencies will not serve the purpose of the government reform.
Meanwhile, Chu Che-min professor of finance at National Cheng Chi University warned that the merger of the two agencies could damage the independence of the budget planners and accountants.

Staff responsible for the distribution of government financial resources are more tools for elected government chiefs to carry out their political agenda than ordinary government employees and should be granted special protection to ensure that they "remain detached" when performing their jobs.
But, Chu said, their incorporation into the Finance Ministry will compromise their independence and hamper the government's ability to implement policy.

Wei Duan, a former DGBAS chief and presently a researcher at Taiwan Research Institute, a local think tank, said the merger will rob government accountants of their ability to blow the whistle on financial irregularities in various government agencies.

The current system under which budget planners and government accountants are appointed and supervised by the DGBAS rather than chiefs of the government agencies for which they work will be scrapped after the merger, and budget planners as well as government accountants will lose their independence once they are appointed and controlled by the heads of the government units in which they work.

Wei credited the current system, which has operated for more than 70 years, with "eliminating" the once-prevailing corruption of book-tampering and payroll-padding. According to Wei, it has also minimized other financial irregularities.
Unless a better system of checks and balances is put in place, Wei said, the current system of an independent DGBAS should remain.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP OFFICIAL WARNS TAIWAN AGAINST BEIJING'S MOVES AFTER WTO ENTRY
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 28 (CNA) (By Jennifer J. Huang and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Beijing will be able to absorb even more economic resources from Taiwan as a result of the expected removal of bilateral trade barriers after both sides enter the World Trade Organization (WTO), an official of Taiwan's ruling party said Sunday.

Yan Jiann-fa, director of the Democratic Progressive Party's China Affairs Department, warned at the 43rd annual conference of the American Association for Chinese Studies (AACS) held in Chicago that Taiwan's WTO entry will compromise its economic sovereignty because Beijing will step up its efforts to use Taiwan businessmen to apply pressure on their own government.

Yan said in his speech to nearly 100 members of AACS -- the only academic society in America devoted exclusively to the general area of Chinese studies -- that although cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges are unavoidable, they should be conducted at a gradual pace in keeping with "reality."
Taiwan faces the challenge of trying to strike a balance between maintaining national dignity and acquiring realistic advantages, he added.

During the process of globalization, he continued, Taiwan can be a springboard for foreign companies venturing into mainland China because of the island's geographic and cultural advantages as well as its abundant international trading experience.
Meanwhile, he warned that Taiwan must not accept Beijing's "one China" principle because it would allow Beijing to rule over and destroy the Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: APLFD CONGRESS CONDEMNS WORLD TERRORISM
DOC.DATELINE: Auckland, Oct. 28 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Participants at the 42nd Congress of the Asian Pacific League for Freedom and Democracy (APLFD) unanimously approved a resolution Sunday to condemn terrorism and called on all nations to stand united against terrorist organizations.

At the three-day congress that closed that day in Auckland, the participants also expressed sympathy for the families of the victims killed in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York and Washington and voiced concern over the innocent Afghan people presently suffering under the U.S.-led bombardment of the country.
The participants also voiced deep concern over the Chinese Taipei delegate's rejection by Beijing at the recent Asian-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum informal leadership summit in Shanghai.

Some 60 delegates from 15 nations took part in the congress. It was also the first time that Presidential Senior Adviser Peng Ming-min had officiated at the meeting since he assumed the post of the APLFD secretary-general early this year.
The congress also adopted a resolution to admit Vietnam as the organization's 20th member nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES AUSTRALIA TO EASE VISA RESTRICTIONS ON ROC OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung urged Australia Monday to ease visa restrictions on Republic of China officials with a view to facilitating bilateral exchanges and cooperation.
Chang made the appeal during a farewell meeting with outgoing Australian Representative to the ROC Sam Gerovich, who has been assigned to a new post in Shanghai.

"I felt regret over the Australian government's recent denial of a visa to the ROC's Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) Chairwoman Chang Fu-mei," Chang said, adding that he hopes similar events would never happen again.

Noting that Australia's move has hindered the OCAC chief's plan to visit ROC expatriates in Australia, Premier Chang said he looks forward to seeing a breakthrough in high-level ROC-Australian exchanges in the future.
Chang went on to express his appreciation of Gerovich's efforts to promote substantive relations between the two countries during Gerovich's four-year services in Taipei.

For his part, Gerovich said he was grateful for the ROC government's support and assistance for his work during his stint in Taipei. "I take great pleasure in seeing remarkable progress in trade, immigration, travel and student exchanges between our two countries over the past four years," he added.
Gerovich said he will study the feasibility of promoting commercial and civilian exchanges among Taiwan, mainland China and Australia after assuming his new post in Shanghai.
For instance, Gerovich said he will look into whether there is room for Taiwan and Australian firms to cooperate in investing in Shanghai and other mainland areas.

In response, Chang said he admires Gerovich's ambition. Nevertheless, he said, further development of trade and economic ties across the Taiwan Strait relies on peace in the Taiwan Strait. "We hope that the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue can resume as early as possible to ensure a peaceful environment for bilateral exchanges," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 30, or the 14th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1735: John Adams, the second president of the United States, is born. He was one of the signatories to the Declaration of Independence, and he negotiated the end to the War of American Independence.
1910: Swiss philanthropist Henri Dunant dies at the age of 82. He founded the International Red Cross and shared the first Nobel Peace Prize with Frederic Passy of France in 1901.
1911: On the advice of the regent Prince Chun, Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Ching dynasty, grants a constitution to combat growing support for the revolutionary forces of Dr. Sun Yat-sen.
1927: The Chinese Communist Party launches armed rebellions in Haifeng and Lufeng in Kwangtung Province.
1937: The National government decides to move the capital from Nanking to Chungking.
1952: The Federation of Overseas Chinese Associations is set up in Taipei following the first worldwide Overseas Chinese Conference, which opened in Taipei on Oct. 22.
1953: Wu Ching-heng, former chairman of the Presidium of the Constituent Assembly, dies in Taipei at the age of 88.
1973: Tsengwen Dam and Reservoir, the largest in Taiwan, is completed and dedicated as a birthday present to President Chiang Kai-shek.
1973: Economic Minister Y. S. Sun leaves for Saigon to take part in the eighth Sino-Vietnamese Ministerial Conference on economic cooperation.
1974: Nobusuke Kishi, former Japanese prime minister, and Mitsujiro Ishii, former speaker of the House of Representatives, arrive in Taipei to join in birthday celebrations for President Chiang Kai-shek.
1974: The first F-5E Freedom jetfighter made in the Republic of China rolls off the assembly line.
1975: Ground for the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, named after the late president, is broken by Adm. Ni Yue-si, president of the ROC Amateur Athletic Federation, and Wang Yung-ching, the donor.
1975: Li Teng-hui, the ROC minister of state, leaves for Nakualofa at the head of an envoy to attend the 100th anniversary of the Constitution of the Kingdom of Tonga.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves the establishment of National Chiang Kai-shek University in central Taiwan.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves the code on gold trading and importation, to go into effect Nov. 1.
1986: The ROC-made "Sky Bow" and "Sky Sword" missiles are officially renamed the "Chung Cheng (Chiang Kai-shek) 100" series in a renaming ceremony presided over by Premier Yu Kuo-hwa.
1988: Rev. Sun Myung Moon, head of the Unification Church, presides over one of the biggest mass wedding ceremonies in history, held in Yongin, South Korea, where 6,516 couples tie the knot.
1990: Communist China announces the results of a nationwide census which shows its population totals 1.13 billion people.
1990: The Republic of China establishes trade and consular ties with Bolivia.
1995: Voters in the province of Quebec vote in favor of remaining part of Canada in a referendum.
1995 Fire breaks out on a subway train below the streets of Baku, capital of the Republic of Azerbaijan, killing 337 people and injuring at least 270 others.
1997: Mary McAleese, a Belfast lawyer, is elected President of Ireland.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui reiterates that the Republic of China has never forsaken its goal of promoting eventual unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
2000: The ROC's opposition parties declare Premier Chang Chun-hsiung "persona non grata" for his announcement of a major policy turnabout that they say was not only "illegal," but also "sacrificed the public interest."
2000: Republic of China Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen signs a memorandum on military cooperation with his Macedonian counterpart Ljuben Paunoski in Taipei.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "There never was a man trained to benevolence who neglected his parents. There never was a man trained to righteousness who made his ruler an after-consideration."

DOC.HEADLINE: DEPRESSED STOCK MARKET MAY BE AN OPPORTUNITY: ENTREPRENEUR

TEXT.P: The sluggishness of Taiwan's stock market may be an opportunity, in the eyes of a leading entrepreneur, for the Taiwan business sector to reduce its zealousness for the securities market and to refocus on economic fundamentals.

Day Sheng-tong, president of the National Association of Small- and Medium-Size Enterprises, ROC, said Tuesday that Taiwan's stock market experienced its heyday early last year when the dot-com myth drove the stocks of related companies to unrealistic highs.

The entrepreneur said that at that time, the electronics manufacturing sector, which created no more than 20 percent of the job opportunities around island, was able to attract 80 percent of all the capital invested in the stock market.
Many businesspeople lost track and began neglecting their own trade when they started focusing on making easy money on the stock market, according to Day.
The collapse of the "bubble economy" and the ensuing drastic decline in share prices since late last year have seriously shaken the public's confidence in Taiwan's economy.

Day said that a depressed stock market, negative economic growth and a decline in foreign trade have worsened the confidence crisis. However, he pointed out that Taiwan's economic prospects are not as bad as they seem judging by the sound fundamentals of the manufacturing industry.

When businesses dedicate their efforts and invest money in upgrading their operations and improving their products, more job opportunities can be created, he said, adding that laying off employees or moving businesses overseas might not be the best solution to meet the new challenges.

Companies that have built sound operational structures will be able to weather the storm, and Taiwan industry will be healthier when companies that don't make the grade are weeded out of the market, according to Day.

Remaining optimistic about Taiwan's economic prospects in the coming year, Day however said that politicians should avoid engaging in further verbal squabbling as this may cause an exodus of disillusioned businesspeople.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 149.49 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Tuesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 149.49 points to close at 3,915.61.
Market turnover amounted to NT$48.79 billion (US$1.41 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: MICROSOFT LAUNCHES WINDOWS XP IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Microsoft Taiwan formally launched the new Microsoft Windows XP operating system at the Taipei International Convention Center Tuesday, with thousands registered to try out the system.

Michael Rawding, president of Microsoft Asia, and chief executives of the Taiwan offices of Acer, Compaq, and Intel attended the kick-off ceremony. Leading hardware manufacturers are collaborating with Microsoft, using the Windows XP system in PC computing.
Microsoft held Windows XP launch events in 50 countries Oct. 25. An estimated 480,000 users have tried the new system in the launch events around the globe.
With separate editions for home users and professionals, the new system will be introduced to the public in Taichung Nov. 6 and in Kaohsiung Nov. 8.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION NEW PARTY LAWMAKERS SAY MEDIA SUPERVISION COMES WITH POWER

TEXT.P: Opposition New Party lawmakers said Tuesday in response to President Chen Shui-bian's call for the media to report more good news that the obligation of being supervised by the media comes with being in power.
Legislator Lai Shyh-bao reminded the president that his election to the nation's highest office can also be said to have been aided by the media which reported both good and bad news.
Chen said in his soon-to-be-published book titled "The First Voyage of the Century" that the media should be "magpies" that bring good tidings in addition to being "crows" that report on the "pains."

In the book, which goes on sale Wednesday to mark his first 500 days in office, the president also called on the media to be impartial and self-disciplined and to keep national security matters in mind when reporting on sensitive issues.
However, New Party lawmaker Elmer Fung said that "only dictators would suppress journalistic freedom by using the pretext of national security."

Meanwhile, ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislator Tsai Ming-shian said that the media should defend freedom of the press, but he added that he hopes it can report in a balanced and responsible manner.
Tsai urged members of the media to firmly maintain their role as the fourth estate and avoid becoming the propaganda tools of any of the political parties or candidates in the year-end elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 149.49 points to close at 3,915.61.

Affected by a plunge in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 3,961.56 and continued to go down due to a sharp decline in semiconductor share prices. The index fluctuated between 3,976.22 and 3,906.7 during trading.

A total of 2.05 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$48.79 billion (US$1.41 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.12 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$52.25 billion (US$1.52 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with electrical shares moving down the most at 4.6 percent, followed by bank and insurance stocks at 2.9 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 2.4 percent, pulp and paper issues at 2.1 percent, textile issues at 1.9 percent, construction stocks at 1.8 percent, foodstuff shares at 1.1 percent, and cement stocks at 0.9 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 474 to 82, with 62 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERTS WARN ABOUT TAIWAN'S GROWING TRADE DEPENDENCE ON M'LAND MARKET

TEXT.P: Following the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States, mainland China has emerged as a relatively stable market that looks even more attractive to Taiwan business, but experts warn about the risks of Taiwan's growing trade reliance on the mainland Chinese market.

Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) tallies show that in 2000, the United States and Japan absorbed 20.8 percent and 19.1 percent, respectively, of Taiwan's total exports worth US$148.32 billion, while Europe took in 14.8 percent, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations 13.3 percent, and Hong Kong 11.6 percent of the total.

However, it is worth noting that the same statistics show that mainland China and Hong Kong together absorbed 22.8 percent of Taiwan's overall outbound shipments last year, surpassing the United States as Taiwan's largest export outlet.

Taiwan's exports to the mainland Chinese market as a ratio of its overall exports rose from 11.1 percent in 1999 to 11.2 percent in 2000, and the percentage climbed to 12.1 percent for the first seven months of this year, according to the MOEA statistics.

The figures show that Taiwan's export sector has become increasingly dependent on the mainland Chinese market, experts said, warning that under such circumstances, any drastic changes in the mainland Chinese market will have a serious impact on Taiwan's foreign trade businesses.

Since the beginning of this year, the global political and economic situation has undergone dramatic changes. The Sept. 11 terrorist attacks against the United States have cast a cloud of uncertainty and anxiety over the world's economic situation.

With mainland China's imminent entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) and its successful bid to host the 2008 Olympic Games, mainland China has in turn become a more stable market, further attracting Taiwan businesspeople to invest there.

As Taiwan is also to join the WTO in the near future, it is expected that trade across the Taiwan Strait will grow even faster, a situation which experts say may stir up another wave of "landing by Taiwan businesspeople on the mainland."

According to assessments by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), Taiwan outbound shipments have primly focused on the mainland Chinese market, while 50 percent of Taiwan investment overseas is directed to mainland China.
C. S. Chou, director of the MAC's Department of Economic Affairs, questioned what the point is in promoting cross-strait trade if this will eventually hurt Taiwan's economy and its independence.

Chou said that as the private sector is eager to edge into the mainland Chinese market, the government's trade and financial authorities should provide Taiwan businesses with sufficient and accurate information about the mainland market.

He contended that relevant government authorities should hammer out a detailed program on exploring the mainland Chinese market and set up a risk-monitoring system amid growing economic exchanges between the two sides.

The MAC official warned government trade policy makers not to dance to the tune of Taiwan businesspeople, adding that it is extremely important for the policy makers to gain a deeper understanding of the dangers hidden in the mainland market.

Taipei Import-Export Association Chairman Lee Tung-liang said external trade is Taiwan's sole weapon for maintaining its economic development, but he called attention to the fact that mainland China is not the only outlet in the world for Taiwan businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE PASSES NEW BILLS TO UPGRADE LEGISLATIVE EFFICIENCY

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed two bills amending parts of its existing Organic Law as well as its Operational Statutes Tuesday with a view to upgrading parliamentary efficiency.
Under the new rules, the minimum number of legislators needed to form a caucus in the Legislature will be raised from five to eight.
The revision is mainly aimed at restricting the number of legislative caucuses in order to facilitate the formation of parliamentary consensus on major policy issues, legislative sources said.

Under the Legislature's revised Organic Law, any political party which manages to garner at least 5 percent of the vote in the legislative elections will be qualified to form a caucus, and legislators should join party caucuses based on their party affiliation.

Independent legislators and those whose party fails to win 5 percent of the vote in the legislative elections can either join other party caucuses or associate with a minimum of seven other colleagues to form a new caucus.
According to the Organic Law, a caucus can propose a legislative bill for deliberation.

Also passed Tuesday was an amendment to the Legislative Yuan's Operational Statues that frees a new Legislature from screening bills left over by the previous Legislature, except for budget bills and petitions filed by ordinary citizens.

Under the present statutes, the Legislature is required to screen bills that had been approved by the preceding chamber's standing committees. Many lawmakers have complained that the requirement has prevented them from working on new bills to reflect the latest public opinion. The new rule will ease lawmakers' workload and allow them to have more time to deliberate newer bills to meet the demands of the public, parliamentary sources said.

The newly amended laws are effective as of the inaugural day of the new Legislature to be elected Dec. 1. According to the Republic of China constitution, the new Legislative Yuan will open Feb. 1, 2002.
