DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY SAYS ROC DOES NOT PRODUCE, POSSESS OR DEPLOY NBC WEAPONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan does not produce, possess nor deploy nuclear, biological or chemical weapons, a military spokesman said Tuesday.

Col. Chu Chih-hung, deputy director of the National Defense Medical Bureau's medical and health-care department, said at a routine news conference at the Ministry of National Defense that the military has no choice but to prepare against possible biological attacks and that it will grow germ cultures if necessary.

However, Chu stressed that producing germ cultures is different from producing biological warfare agents. All hospitals are able to grow germ cultures from patients, but the military does not conduct research on how to apply them to war, he added.
As to mainland China's capabilities in developing biological warfare agents, Chu said that the information is too sensitive to divulge.

Meanwhile, military spokesman Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng said at the same news conference that the military has been working with the Department of Health to strengthen the nation's capabilities in terms of countering diseases and has established emergency response teams with the power to rapidly and accurately determine biological warfare agents.
Huang said that the military has completed the compilation of a soldier's handbook on defending against biological warfare.
The handbook, which will be distributed to all echelons of the armed forces, lists basic measures of protection that can be taken in the event of encountering biological warfare agents, Huang added.
Chu said that such attacks are most likely to be carried out in cities, industrial zones and transportation hubs with higher population densities.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD BLASTS PRESIDENT CHEN'S NEW BOOK
DOC.DATELINE: Taitung County, eastern Taiwan, Oct. 30 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan charged Tuesday that President Chen Shui-bian's new book has been causing damage to different people "one chapter at a time."

Lien said that he did not "play (Chen) for a fool" by first agreeing to scrap an 84-hour bi-weekly labor work hour bill and then writing a letter ordering KMT legislators to support the bill as Chen said in the latest excerpt from the book, which will go on sale later this week to mark the president's first 500 days in office.

Lien urged Chen to give up his election promise of cutting down labor working hours to 40 hours per week -- a move that opponents have said could lead to serious industry-wide repercussions resulting from lost productivity.

Lien went on to say that when he met with Chen on Oct. 27 last year, he had recommended that the president actively serve as a coordinator between the management and labor forces that had been arguing over the bill.
He even recommended to the president at the time that the implementation of the new working hour scheme be delayed, Lien added.

Lien criticized Chen's soon-to-be-published book titled "The First Voyage of the Century" for attacking former President Lee Teng-hui in the first excerpt that was released, Vice President Annette Lu in the second excerpt, members of the media in the third and Lien himself in the fourth.
The KMT chairman said a more appropriate title for the book would be "The Lost Voyage of the Century."

Lien's criticisms coincided with those of opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong, who called the series of excerpts "soap opera episodes" meant to affect the outcome of the Dec. 1 elections.

In the first book excerpt, Chen charged that the National Security Council of the former Lee administration had failed to hand over certain dossiers when the new administration came to power last May.

In the second excerpt, Chen said that although the vice president has always been only a nominal head, he has allowed her to participate in many activities. However, he said that the post of the vice president is not the same as being "half a president," pointing to controversial moves such as Lu's organizing and hosting of an international event that is usually the job of the president.

In the third excerpt, the president said that the media should be "magpies" that bring good tidings in addition to being "crows" that report on the "pains," should strive for more balanced reporting and should keep national security matters in mind when handling sensitive issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA PLANNING TO OFFER HUMANITARIAN AID TO AFGHAN REFUGEES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government has drafted a package of measures to extend humanitarian aid to Afghan refugees amid continued U.S. strikes on Afghanistan in retaliation for its sheltering of terrorists, an official said Tuesday.
Francis T. N. Chang, director of the West Asian Affairs Department under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), made the remarks at a routine news conference.
Chang said the ministry has called several rounds of meetings of relevant government agencies and civic groups to discuss measures for assisting Afghans displaced by the ongoing U.S. attacks.

"We have come up with an initial plan," Chang said, adding that the MOFA has asked the ROC's embassies and representative offices abroad to seek appropriate channels for delivering cash and relief goods donated by individual ROC nationals and organizations to needy Afghan refugees.

U.S. forces began to attack the Taliban regime in Afghanistan early this month after the Islamic regime declined to hand over Osama bin Laden, the key suspect of the Sept. 11 terrorist assaults that toppled New York City's World Trade Center and partially damaged the Pentagon in Washington.

Meanwhile, Chang said the MOFA will offer necessary assistance to foreign celebrities who are scheduled to visit Taiwan in early November to attend the inauguration of a museum of religions in Taipei County.

"The ministry will grant courtesy treatment and technical assistance to prominent international figures who will come to Taipei for the inauguration of the Museum of World Religions Nov. 8," Chang said.

Former U.S. Vice President Al Gore and world-renowned religious leaders and religion experts from Russia, Saudi Arabia, Israel, Jordan and many other countries will take part in the museum's opening ceremony and a seminar on preservation of religious relics. Gore is expected to deliver a keynote speech at the seminar.

The museum, the brainchild of a local Buddhist master, will be dedicated to promoting reconciliation among different religions. After more than a decade of construction and preparations, the museum's founders have managed to collect numerous religious scriptures, artifacts, instruments, objets d'art, more than 7,000 books various religions as well as 2,000-plus video and audio recordings on religious subjects.
Its founders said they want to make the museum, the first of its kind in Taiwan, "a temple without boundaries" and "a retreat for everyone from the unrest in the world."

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION UPSET OVER CEC'S DECISION ON LISTING OF PARTY AFFILIATION

TEXT.P: Legislators from the "pan-blue alliance" voiced strong discontent Tuesday over the Central Election Commission's decision to disallow Wang Chien-shien from listing a recommendation for him by three parties under the party affiliation column in an election bulletin.

The "pan-blue alliance" refers to an alliance between the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and two of its splinter groups -- the New Party (NP) and the People First Party (PFP). The three parties share a roughly common stance of pro-unification regarding relations with mainland China in contrast to the more pro-independence position of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Legislators Ting Shou-chung and Hung Hsiu-chu of the KMT, which has the most seats in the Legislature, as well as the NP's Cheng Long-shui and the PFP's Lin Yu-fang called a press conference at the Legislative Yuan to strongly protest the CEC's decision that Wang can only list one party under the party affiliation column, saying the CEC is trying to "interfere with the integration of political parties."

They pointed out that the CEC's decision seriously violates the spirit of the Election and Recall Law and is an attempt to splinter the alliance, adding that they will ask the Council of Grand Justices for an interpretation of the decision.

Wang, a former finance minister known for his integrity, will run for Taipei county magistrate in the Dec. 1 elections. He is the only candidate so far who has been endorsed by the "pan-blue alliance" in its integration efforts aimed at winning the elections.

Ting also said the DPP's spreading of news that cooperation between the PFP and DPP after the election would cost it the least was an attempt by the party to drive a wedge between the "pan-blue alliance."
Legislator Hung stressed that President Chen, whether in the Taipei mayoral race or in the presidential race, has been successful by playing rivals off against each other.

Realizing that cooperation among the three parties of the "pan-blue alliance" will seriously undermine the election prospects of incumbent Taipei County Magistrate Su Tseng-chang of the DPP, Hung said the DPP has resorted to the tactic of trying to cause rifts in the alliance.

Referring to the CEC decision, Hung said that there are many cases in other democratic countries of a candidate listing recommendations by more than one political party, adding that the CEC should use these cases as a reference.

PFP Legislator Lin also said because Wang has an excellent chance of winning the Taipei County magistrate election, the DPP has used its resources to interfere with his chances. He suggested that Wang, who is of the New Party, not fill in the party affiliation column to indicate that he represents a party outside the DPP.
NP Legislator Cheng also suggested that he incorporate the colors of the three "pan-blue alliance" parties into his campaign logo and that he run as an independent candidate as a last resort.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP AIMING TO COMPLETE PARLIAMENTARY REFORMS IN NEXT LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is aiming at completing its planned reforms to the Legislative Yuan in the next Legislature, Wu Nan-jen, secretary-general of the ruling party, said Tuesday.

Wu said that the reforms will include halving the number of seats in the Legislature and implementing a single-seat, two-votes system -- referring to one vote for a candidate and one vote for a party.

Wu noted that the public can no longer put up with the chaos at the legislative branch and that carrying out the reforms will be the most important political task of the DPP, adding that all political parties have their own views on reform but that they lack substantial plans.

Wu said that the DPP has completed the paper work on the reforms and that the plan will be turned over to its Central Standing Committee for approval over the next few days before the party seeks the consensus of the other political parties.
On the question of whether to lengthen the term of legislators to four years to coincide with that of the president, he said this will require consultations with the other political parties.

Noting that passing amendments to the constitution requires the attendance of at least three-fourths of all legislators and the consent of three-fourths of those present, Wu said that the DPP will have to gain the consent of all the major political parties in order to successfully pass its parliamentary reforms.

He pointed out that the DPP will complete work on the amendment of the organization law of the National Assembly by next May and will finish work on the constitutional amendment and the amendment to the Election And Recall Law by next June.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA STEEL CORP. BUYS TAIWAN MACHINERY MANUFACTURING CORP.

TEXT.P: China Steel Corp. (CSC) and Taiwan Machinery Manufacturing Corp. (TMMC) inked an accord Tuesday in which CSC agreed to buy land belonging to TMMC at a cost of NT$3.26 billion (US$93.2 million).

Under the terms of the pact, CSC will purchase a landlot occupied by TMMC's Linhai plant, while one of its newly established affiliates will buy the plant building, machinery facilities, vehicles, stock and materials for an additional NT$241 million.
At the same time, CSC also promised to take over 170 TMMC employees and transfer them and their operations to its affiliates.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN WORRIED ABOUT POLITICAL CHAOS IN WAKE OF DEC. 1 POLLS

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong expressed worry Tuesday about possible domestic political chaos in the wake of the Dec. 1 elections for legislators and local government chiefs.

Soong told a group of local reporters on his way to the northeastern county of Ilan to stump for PFP candidates for the upcoming legislative elections that the period between the end of the critical polls and the inauguration of the fifth Legislative Yuan Feb. 1, 2002 could be a "turbulent period" in Taiwan's political development.

"If the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) fail to restrict their incumbent legislators who lose their re-election bids in the upcoming polls from exercising their legislative power between the election and their ouster from the legislature," Soong said, "I cannot imagine what kinds of bills or actions they might engineer."
Should that be the case, Soong said, the domestic political arena will be "rough and turbulent."

In his view, Soong said, the present domestic political problems do not lie in "chaos in the parliament" as the ruling party claims, but rather in the DPP's incompetence, inexperience and frequent policy flip-flops.
Worse still, Soong claimed, the DPP leadership's "disrespect for the Republic of China's constitutional system" has aggravated the current domestic political plight.

Touching on DPP Secretary-General Wu Nai-jen's idea that the cost of a DPP-PFP tie-up after the December polls would be minimal, Soong said it is premature to talk about how a coalition government will be formed.

"We must respect public opinion and the legislative electoral outcome," Soong noted, adding that the ongoing DPP-KMT spat over which party should lead the formation of a new Cabinet in the wake of the elections indicates their disrespect for public opinion.
In addition, Soong went on, the DPP-KMT squabble is aimed at containing and squeezing the PFP's chances of victory in the year-end polls. He did not elaborate.

Soong also questioned the propriety of President Chen Shui-bian's decision to publish memoirs on his first 500 days in office. "Few heads of state in the world have ever published their memoirs while still in office," he said.

Chen's new book, titled the First Voyage of the Century, will come off the presses this week. Excerpts of the book have been made available in the past few days, stirring up heated discussions on Chen's allegations about the lack of dossier transfer in last year's transition of power from the KMT to the DPP, as well as on his views about Vice President Annette Lu and the role of domestic news media.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2001 WORLD CUP BASEBALL TAIPEI COMMEMORATION STAMP ISSUED

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung presided Tuesday over a ceremony to mark the issue of the 2001 World Cup Baseball Taipei Commemoration stamp series issued by the Directorate General of Post (DGP).
Minister of Transportation and Communications Yeh Chu-lan also witnessed the ceremony.

The 34th World Cup Baseball Championships will open simultaneously at the Tienmu Diamond, the Hsinchuang Stadium, the Chiayi Stadium and the Chengching Stadium in Kaohsiung County on Nov. 6. A total of 16 national teams from five continents will vie for the champion during the 12-day competition.

The DGP issued the set of four stamps featuring a pitcher, a batter, a catcher and a batter sliding into a base as backgrounds and one stamp featuring the Republic of China team to commemorate the first time the world cup has been held in Taipei.
In related news, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou called on Taipei citizens to attend the Chinese Taipei-Italy game at the Tienmu Diamond Nov. 6 following the opening ceremony.
Ma made the remarks after inspecting the preparation of the Tienmu Diamond and accepting a large outdoor TFT-LCD Television set donated by Japan Matsushita Co., Ltd.
He also presided over a lighting ceremony after inspecting the bilingual audio sound equipment at the diamond.
Ma said that the Tienmu Diamond, with a capacity of more than 10,000 seats, is a world-class baseball field.

Also that day, the Netherlands team, champion of the European Cup baseball tourney, practiced at the Chiayi Stadium and was scheduled to hold friendly matches with the Chunghsin Sharks in Tainan on Wednesday and Thursday. On Friday, the Netherlands nine will take on South Africa in a friendly in Tainan.
Charles Van der Meijs, captain of the Netherlands team, who visited Kaohsiung two years ago, had high praise for the good conditions at the Chiayi Stadium.

He said that this will be the second time that the world baseball tournament will be held in Asia. The powerful Cuban nine has dominated the competitions in past years and as of 1998, Cuba had captured 22 championship cups since 1939, the first year in which the world series was held.
Cuba is vying for its seventh consecutive championship in the upcoming tournament, although the Netherlands defeated Cuba in last year's Olympics.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA TO SET UP OFFICE IN MONGOLIA

TEXT.P: The semi-official China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) has decided to set up a trade office in Mongolia to further strengthen Taiwan-Mongolia bilateral trade relations, a CETRA official said Tuesday.

The official said that CETRA is expected to dispatch officials to Mongolia to prepare for setting up a trade office shortly after the CETRA Board of Trustees approves the project next January or February.
Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian has disclosed while receiving visitors from Mongolia recently that Taiwan and Mongolia will set up trade offices in each other's capital cities.
Mongolia has been sending technicians and public functionaries to Taiwan to receive intensive training ever since Taipei established sisterhood ties with Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital.
At present, several Taiwanese companies have invested in Mongolia and economic ties between the two countries are escalating, according to CETRA Chairman Shea Jia-dong.
CETRA marketing surveyors have visited Mongolia several times in the past few years and the time is now ripe for CETRA to set up a spearhead office in Mongolia, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. RESPECTS TAIWAN'S NON-NUCLEAR POLICY: U.S. OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A United States official responsible for nuclear affairs said Tuesday that the U.S. government respects Taiwan's non-nuclear policy, although it still considers nuclear power as a safe energy source.

Alex Burkart, deputy director of the Office of Nuclear Energy Affairs under the State Department's Nonproliferation Bureau, made the remarks in Hualien, eastern Taiwan, during a nuclear energy cooperation conference between the two countries.
More than 90 experts in nuclear energy affairs from both countries attended the two-day conference, which was scheduled to conclude Wednesday.

Ouyang Min-shen, vice chairman of Taiwan's Atomic Energy Council under the Executive Yuan, expressed his shock at the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States and stressed that Taiwan has strengthened security measures at its nuclear power plants since the incidents.
However, he added, the government's energy policy is to make Taiwan a country free of nuclear power.

Burkart, who led a 20-member delegation made up of U.S. officials responsible for nuclear affairs, environmental protection and laboratory heads, made no comment on Taiwan's non-nuclear policy, but stressed that nuclear power still accounts for the most important part of the U.S. energy policy.

He cited statistics to emphasize the safety and low cost of nuclear energy and added that his country will continue to pour billions of dollars into funding new technologies in nuclear power generation and nuclear waste disposal.

The participants will discuss issues such as the safety of nuclear energy, protection against radiation, nuclear power for consumers and nuclear waste disposal, and will review existing cooperation projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHILDREN OF FOREIGN BRIDES PRONE TO SLOW DEVELOPMENT, DOCTOR CLAIMS

TEXT.P: Children of mothers who are foreign brides in Taiwan are prone to slowness or retardation in their mental and linguistic development due to their mothers' difficulties in adapting to new environments, a local medical source claimed Tuesday.

Foreign nationals who settle in Taiwan after marrying Republic of China citizens are often found to have trouble learning local languages and adapting to their new lives, as well as "insufficient relationship support," which eventually affects their children's physical and psychological development, according to a pediatrician at Kaohsiung Chang Kung Memorial Hospital.

In a three-month survey of 13 mother-child groups, Dr. Chou Wen-chun found that 63 percent of the children whose mothers are foreign brides suffer certain levels of development retardation, with slowness in language development topping the list of problems, followed by "mixed development retardation."

From clinical observation, Chou said, mental and psychological factors exert great impact on the learning ability of the children of foreign brides, while the mothers themselves encounter difficulties raising their children.

In the survey, Chou claimed, mothers from mainland China have greater self-confidence than those from Southeast Asian countries, probably because most of the mainland wives come from big cities and have higher levels of education.
By comparison, wives from Southeast Asian countries are relatively quieter and "evidently" have more adaptation problems, according to Chou.

However, Chou admitted that her results need longer periods of observation and that individual cases need to be followed to examine how the "psychological problems" of foreign brides affect their children's mental and physical development.
Chou added that foreign bride mothers need greater assistance and support than their local counterparts to allow them to live and raise normal and healthy children in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA UNVEILS NEW WHITE PAPER ON FOREIGN LABOR POLICY

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) unveiled a new version Tuesday of its White Paper on the Republic of China's policy on foreign labor imports and management.
"The new measures outlined in the White Paper will take effect Nov. 9," said Kuo Fang-yu, director-general of the CLA's Employment and Vocational Training Administration.

Under the new policy, meal and accommodation fees, with a maximum of NT$4,000 (US$115.94) per month, will be deducted from the wages of foreign laborers. All alien workers, including housemaids and caretakers, as well as those working in the manufacturing and construction industries, will be subject to the new regulation.

The new wage calculating formula will help local employers save an estimated NT$10 billion per year in salaries for foreign laborers amid the current domestic economic downturn, according to industry sources.

To help offset the decrease in wages for foreign laborers, local manpower agencies will be prohibited from collecting brokerage fees -- NT$30,000 per person at present -- from legal foreign workers after the new package becomes effective.
Additionally, brokerage fees for overseas manpower agencies -- NT$26,000 per head -- will be lowered to the level of the present NT$15,840 minimum monthly wage for foreign laborers.

Nevertheless, foreign laborers will have to pay NT$1,500 to NT$1,800 in "monthly service charges" to local manpower brokerage houses under the new rules, up from the current amount of NT$1,000. The measure was designed to defuse a backlash from local manpower agents over the cancellation of their brokerage fees.
In line with the new policy, local employers will still have to pay brokerage fees to local agents if they want to employ foreign laborers.
To ensure smooth implementation of the new package, Kuo said, the CLA has conducted extensive negotiations with major labor supply countries. "All of them have agreed to our new policy," he noted.
Under the new policy, Kuo said, the ROC will diversify its foreign manpower sources, with Myanmar topping the list of possible new sources. Mongolia and Sri Lanka might also be included on the list.
At present, Thailand, the Philippines, Indonesia and Vietnam are the main sources of legal foreign workers in Taiwan.
Kuo said the CLA has compiled an "alarming index" on the total number of foreign laborers based on the domestic unemployment rate, the labor shortage rate and the present number of foreign workers.

In terms of this index, Kuo said, the government must continue to implement its current retrenchment policy, at least in the foreseeable future, as the total number of foreign workers in Taiwan during the first nine months of this year has reached an alarming level.
Meanwhile, Kuo went on, the CLA will adjust its policy on employment of foreign housemaids and caregivers.

As the number of foreign housemaids and caregivers reached 9,112 at the end of September and the number has shown signs of a steady rise, Kuo said the CLA will tighten restrictions on local families intending to hire foreign family helpers from Nov. 9.

On the other hand, he continued, restrictions on hiring foreign housemaids by foreign expatriates in Taiwan will be largely eased in order to attract foreign investors, high-tech engineers and senior managerial executives.
All foreign expatriates who have obtained legal residency in Taiwan and have an annual income of NT$3 million or over can apply to employ foreign family helpers and housemaids.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GROUP DONATES US$200,000 FOR VICTIMS OF SEPT. 11 ATTACKS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 29 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan-based Buddhist Fo Kuang Shan Temple donated US$200,000 Monday for the victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on New York and Washington.

The donation was presented by Shih Yi Heng, master of Fo Kuang Shan's New York branch, and was accepted by officials from the International Red Cross in the presence of several local leaders of the International Fo Kuang Shan Association.

The money was contributed by Fo Kuang Shan's followers in Taiwan, Hong Kong and other countries, and included the revenues from recent concerts performed by a Fo Kuang Shan Buddhist musical troupe in the United States and Canada.
On Oct. 19, Master Hsing Yun, founder of the Fo Kuang Shan Temple, visited the ruins of the New York World Trade Center to pray for the victims killed in the terrorist attacks.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2 EX-EDUCATION MINISTRY OFFICIALS CHARGED IN GRAFT SCANDAL

TEXT.P: Two former Ministry of Education officials were among 33 people charged with serious offenses Tuesday after the Taipei District Prosecutors' Office announced the close of the notorious Jin Wen scandal following an 11-month investigation.

Prosecutors said they were seeking a 15-year sentence for former Education Minister Yung Chaur-shin and a life sentence for former Vice Education Minister Lin Chao-hsien, on charges ranging from graft, fraud, taking bribes and document forgery to embezzlement for helping the Jin Wen Group illegally expand its business operations.
Yung was accused of illegal influence peddling to allow the Jin Wen Group buy land, while Lin was charged with illegally approving the group to set up a junior high school.

The prosecutors were also seeking a 12-year term for Chang Yu-huei, a former minister without portfolio who was in charge of illegally granting a bank loan of NT$1 billion, while he was chairman of the state-run Central Trust of China.
Both Yung, Lin and Chang pleaded not guilty and denied that they had taken bribes from the Jin Wen Group to buy villas built by the group at prices much lower than normal market prices.
The prosecutors also asked for a 12-year term for Chang Wan-li, chairman of the Jin Wen Group who has remained at large overseas after the case was uncovered earlier this year.

Meanwhile, Minister of Education Ovid Tzeng said he was unable to comment on the indictments, but he lamented that some ministry officials and former ministry officials were allegedly involved in the scandal, the worst case of its kind in Taiwan's education spectrum.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTGOING AUSTRALIAN COMMERCE & INDUSTRY OFFICE REPRESENTATIVE CITED

TEXT.P: Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu conferred a second-grade economic medal Tuesday on Sam Gerovich, outgoing representative of the Australian Commerce and Industry Office in Taipei, for his contributions to bilateral economic ties.
Gerovich arrived in Taipei in August 1997 to assume his duties as representative of the Australian Commerce and Industry Office in Taipei.
During his tenure, Gerovich dedicated himself to implementing economic and technology cooperation between Taiwan and Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS OUTGOING CHADIAN AMBASSADOR

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian lauded outgoing Chadian Ambassador to the Republic of China Salim Abderaman Taha Tuesday for his contributions toward cementing bilateral relations between the tow countries.

Chen praised Taha's extraordinary performance during his four-year ambassadorship in Taiwan, describing Taha's work as the best model for the development of relations between the governments of the ROC and all African countries.
Chen congratulated Taha for his promotion to the head of Chad's General Bureau of Protocol and exhorted him to continue to play the role as a bridge between the peoples of Taiwan and Chad.
The ROC president also expressed his appreciation to Taha for his assistance to the ROC entourage during Chen's visit to Africa in August 2000.
Chen asked Taha to convey his greetings to Chadian President Idriss Deby and expressed hope that Deby will visit Taiwan again.
Chen offered his appreciation to Deby for being a popular head of state in Chad after winning the first popular presidential election in the African country in 1996 with an overwhelming mandate.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC INVESTMENT IN OVERSEAS OILFIELDS BEARS FRUIT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-run oil company Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) has begun to benefit from investment in overseas oil fields, a CPC official said Tuesday.

The official noted that CPC obtained 1,000 barrels of crude and 3 billion cubic meters of natural gas from these oilfields last year, representing annual net revenue of NT$1.8 billion (US$52 million).

CPC has invested in five foreign oilfields, with future exploitation quantity reaching the equivalent of 290 million barrels of oil valued at US$568 million after deducting exploitation and operation costs, according to the official.
CPC's oilfields are scattered throughout Ecuador, Indonesia, Venezuela and the United Arab Emirates.

DOC.HEADLINE: `ANY PARTY' COULD BE PARTNER IN COALITION GOVERNMENT: DPP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that his party would not rule out the possibility of cooperating with any other political party to form a coalition government after the Dec. 1 legislative and local elections.
He made the remarks to quell controversy caused by DPP Secretary-Secretary Wu Nai-jen's statement a day earlier that "cooperating with the People First Party (PFP) would be the least costly."
Wu's statement was rejected immediately by PFP officials who said that the PFP does not want to cooperate with the DPP.
Hsieh told reporters at the Kaohsiung City Council that the DPP will form a coalition government after the year-end elections, but added that any other party could be a coalition partner.

He said that the DPP has already evaluated the advantages and disadvantages of cooperating with the various parties and added that his party will not announce its conclusions before the elections, as it might affect the results.
As no party is expected to win a simple majority in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan, President Chen Shui-bian has said that he will form a coalition government after the elections.

In this connection, the spokesman for the PFP legislative caucus, Liu Wen-hsiung, said that the DPP's claim to want to cooperate with the PFP is apparently designed to scare voters away from the PFP at a time when PFP support is on the rise.
He labeled the Chen administration "incompetent" and went on to say that if the DPP government wants to form a coalition government, it should outline a clear direction with goodwill and sincerity.

The PFP was formed by former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong soon after he lost his presidential bid to Chen with a small margin in March 2000. Soong collected 36 percent of the vote, compared with Chen's 39 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER U.S. SECRETARY OF DEFENSE VISITS ROC

TEXT.P: Former U.S. Secretary of Defense William Cohen arrived in Taipei Tuesday for a three-day visit, according to Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) sources.

Cohen, who supported the U.S. policy of engagement with Beijing but felt that the improvement of U.S. relations with mainland China should not be implemented at the expense of Republic of China security, was met at the airport by Linghu Jung-tah, deputy director of MOFA's Department of North American Affairs.

During his stay, Cohen and his two-member entourage are expected to meet with President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao and National Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen, MOFA officials said.
Cohen is also expected to meet with Commander-in-Chief of the Navy Lee Chieh, primarily for talks about Taiwan's supposed purchase of submarines from the United States, according to MOFA officials.
The MOFA sources noted that Cohen, who visited Taiwan four times when he was a senator and a member of the House of Representatives, was very friendly toward the ROC when he was a congressman.
Cohen is scheduled to leave Thursday for Japan to continue his Asian tour, which will also take him to South Korea and Singapore, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN PASSES CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed a customs import tariff amendment bill at a third-reading Tuesday at a plenary session.

In line with Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), Taiwan must lower its tariffs, affecting more than 5,000 tariffs. It has been estimated that Taiwan will lose more than NT$5.1 billion in reduced duties in the first year of the country's WTO membership.

Import duty on liquor such as whisky will be reduced to zero in the first year of Taiwan's WTO entry, and duty on passenger cars will be reduced from the current 30 percent to 17.5 percent gradually, while the existing quota system for foreign imports will be canceled by 2011.
Tariffs on agricultural products will be reduced from the current 20.02 percent to 14.01 percent in the first year and will be further reduced to 12.86 percent.
Tariffs on industrial products will be reduced from the current 6.03 percent to 5.78 percent in the first year and will be further reduced to 4.15 percent.

Tariffs on tobacco products will be reduced from the current 20 percent-32.5 percent to 13 percent or 15 percent within six years, while tariffs on beer will be reduced from the current 5 percent to zero in 2005.
Taiwan and mainland China are expected to be admitted into WTO next January.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILLEGAL COMMISSIONS SUSPECTED IN FRENCH JET FIGHTER SALES TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 29 (CNA) (By Tzou ming-jhie & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Part of the huge sum found in bank accounts of an arms broker at the center of a multinational scandal might be illegal commissions from the French sale of 60 Mirage-2000 jet fighters to Taiwan in 1992, according to Monday newspaper report.

Le Monde said French investigators suspect the 250 million Swiss francs (about 5 billion French francs) in two Swiss bank accounts owned by Andrew Wang may come from not only the French sale of six Lafayette-class frigates in 1991, but also from the Mirage sale.

The funds were frozen in April by the Swiss authorities and a Paris court has assigned two magistrates -- Renaud Van Vuymbeke and Dominique de Talance -- to look into Wang's role in the Lafayette sale.
Meanwhile, Swiss magistrate Paul Perraudin was charged by Bern authorities with investigating Wang's bank accounts in that country to see if illegal gains were stashed there.

Le Monde quoted sources familiar with the case as saying that the last cash deposits in Wang's Swiss bank accounts were in 1999, coincident with Taiwan's payment for the Mirages rather than for the Lafayettes.

Taiwan's armed forces paid for the frigates and the jet fighters according to deliveries made by the French builders -- Thomson-CSF for the frigates and Dassault Aviation Concern for the jets. The whole payment for the frigates was completed in 1999 but the payment for the Mirages is not yet finished, although Taiwan took delivery of the 60 planes in 1997.
Le Monde said Wang got a commission of 3 billion French francs from the sale of the Lafayettes and 2.4 billion francs from the sale of the Mirages and missiles they carry.

Former French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas, who was charged in Paris by prosecutors with taking bribes in approving the sale of the six frigates to Taiwan in 1991, claimed in a June 18 interview with Le Figaro daily that 70 percent of Wang's commission went into the coffers of French political parties or was used to line the pockets of politicians in France and other countries.
Dumas, however, failed to support his allegations and van Ruymbeke and de Talance had thus far to find any evidence to verify Dumas' claims.

Wang's Swiss funds came to light in April when he tried to transfer 1.7 billion French francs from his accounts to accounts opened in another Swiss bank in the names of his son and wife. The authorities, alerted by the unusual movement of huge funds, ordered the accounts blocked pending its owner's explanation.
It was at that time the Swiss authorities found that Wang is a arms broker wanted in Taiwan for his role in the sale of French arms to Taiwan.

Wang, who served as Thomson's agent in Taiwan, fled the island in 1993 before the Taiwan authorities could question him in connection with the death of a navy captain in 1993. The captain was in charge of the navy's weapons acquirement programs.

Wang lives in Oakland, California and has never been investigated, despite the fact that there is a warrant for his arrest on murder charges in Taiwan, partly because of the lack of an extradition accord between the United States and Taiwan.

The disclosure of Wang's Swiss bank accounts prompted the Republic of China Navy to ask Thomson Aug. 22 for 4.39 billion French francs in compensation -- the alleged commission in the sale of the frigates.
Naval authorities claim that Thomson promised in its contract that the 16 billion French franc price tag for the frigates did not include any commission. The case is still pending in Paris.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROL YUAN MAY INVESTIGATE ALLEGED SCANDAL INVOLVING MIRAGE DEAL

TEXT.P: Officials of the Control Yuan, the highest watchdog body of the Republic of China, said Tuesday that they may take steps to investigate an alleged payoff scandal involving Taiwan's purchase of 60 French-made Mirage jet fighters.
According to a report a day earlier in the French daily Le Monde, part of a huge sum deposited in Swiss banks by Taiwan arms broker Andrew Wang might be illegal commissions on the Mirage deal.

The Control Yuan's task force on a similar scandal involving the French sale to Taiwan of six Lafayette-class frigates in 1991 held a meeting Tuesday to review the progress of its investigation into under-the-table kickbacks originating from the sale of the frigates.
Two members of the task force visited Switzerland and other European countries recently to collect data related to the scandal.
Wang, who is wanted in Taiwan, is a key person in the scandal. Some 250 million Swiss francs in two Swiss bank accounts belonging to him have been frozen by the Swiss authorities since last April.
The Le Monde report implies that Wang's money at the two banks might have come from commissions not only from the frigate sale, but also from the Mirage deal.

Under the contracts signed by Taiwan and the dealers, no commissions were allowed to be paid in the two deals and should commissions have been paid, Taiwan would be entitled to seek compensation from the dealers.
The task force plans to publish the conclusions of its investigation on the Lafayette payoff scandal, probably before the Dec. 1 legislative and local elections.
A member of the task force said that he is also planning to get involved in the investigation into the alleged Mirage scandal.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTER URGES PEOPLE TO HAVE FAITH IN LOCAL ECONOMY

TEXT.P: In an attempt to persuade local people to have faith in Taiwan's economy, Minister of Interior Chang Po-ya said Tuesday that local economic situation now is no worse than the poverty and deprivation experienced by Taiwan after World War II.
Chang, who made the remarks at a ceremony to mark Merchandiser's Day, told commercial representatives from around the island that she admired their efforts to make Taiwan's trade prosper.

Turning to Taiwan's current economic downturn, Chang quoted a survivor of the devastating earthquake that hit Taiwan in 1999 as saying: "I experienced the hardship brought by World War II, and conquered and recovered from those difficulty, what else can harm me?"
She also noted that Taiwan today is better than mainland China during the Cultural Revolution or the 1989 massacre in Tiananmen Square.
Chang called on local businessmen to take more steps to boost the local economy rather than scaring themselves with the current situation.
Chuang Lung-chang, chairman of the Taiwan Chamber of Commerce, said in the ceremony that although Taiwan will register negative economic growth this year, the crisis may be the turning point.
He said that out of every economic turmoil emerges a new industry or a new group of leaders. Chuang urged the people to have a positive attitude toward the current economic slump.
Chang also bestowed awards to traders and to people dedicated to environmental protection and charity work.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT INSTRUCTS GOVERNMENT TO TAKE MEASURES ON WTO IMPACT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian instructed the government Tuesday to work out counter-measures to reduce the shock of World Trade Organization (WTO) entry on the country's agricultural sector.

Chen issued his instructions after hearing reports by officials from the Presidential Office, the Executive Yuan and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) at the nine-member policy-making task force at its regular weekly meeting.
Members of the task force believed that Taiwan's agricultural sector will receive a great shock after Taiwan is admitted into the WTO next January.
However, officials said that according to the latest estimate by National Taipei University and National Tsinghua University, the agricultural labor force will lose 22,500 people in 2002.
After hearing the reports, Chen instructed the Executive Yuan to work out counter-measures to deal with the situation and especially measures to stabilize the price of agricultural products.

Chen stressed that the Executive Yuan should carry out the established measures to stabilize the agricultural sector's labor force and should also remind those agencies under its control to monitor the situation.

Chiou I-jen, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan and spokesman for the nine-member policy-making task force, later related Chen's instructions at a press conference held at the Government Information Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER SECURITY HEAD DENIES WITHHOLDING FILES DURING POWER SHIFT

TEXT.P: The former chief of the National Security Council denied Tuesday that the council or any other units under the Presidential Office withheld secret files from the new administration during Taiwan's 2000 power transition.

Ding Mou-shih, who served as secretary-general of the National Security Council between 1994 and 1999 under then-President Lee Teng-hui and in 2000 as secretary-general of the Presidential Office, also under Lee, issued a statement Tuesday claiming that all files of the two agencies were handed over to the administration of President Chen Shui-bian, who succeeded Lee.

Ding said in the statement that he left his job at the National Security Council in 1999 after -- handing over all files, memos and official seals to his successor -- to take his new job at the Presidential Office when President Lee was still chairman of the council.

When Chen swept to power in the 2000 elections, Ding said he had already been named the staff chief of Lee's office, and had listed and transferred all office items to the transition team of Chen after his inauguration on May 20 that year. He said he also asked the National Security Council, as well as the Executive Yuan -- both of which are under the Presidential Office to follow suit.
He said that all the transfers were done smoothly.

As for Chen's claims that files concerning Lee's decision to float his controversial claims for Taiwan's statehood against mainland China are missing from the council's archives, Ding said Lee aired the so-called "speical state-to-state claim" in July, 1999, six months after Ding started his new job at the Presidential Office.

Ding said his secret contacts with U.S. officials on behalf of the island were carried out on the orders of Lee and that he was joined by officials from other government agencies on these missions. Ding said he reported back to Lee after each of these contacts.

Ding's statement was a response to Chen's claims Sunday in his new book that when he took the helm of the National Security Council on May 20 last year, he was surprised to find that the council did not even have any complete minutes of its previous meetings.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung reinforced the president's suggestion that the previous Kuomintang administration withheld secret security files from the new government by complaining to the legislature Monday that the National Security Council did not have any record of the impact of Lee's "special state-to- state claim" on the country.

Although he did not dispute Chen's claims head-on, Ding's statement was seen as a veiled denial of his claims, similar to a response made by Yin Tsung-wen, who succeeded Ding as secretary-general of the National Security Council.
Refusing to answer questions from journalists, Yin said a day earlier only that "the answer is evident so long as you bother to retrieve the files according to the rules."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 31, or the 15th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1517: Martin Luther nails his 95 theses against papal corruption in Rome to the church door in Wittenberg.
1887: Chiang Kai-shek, the late president of the Republic of China, is born at Hsikou in Fenghua County, Chekiang Province.
1916: Gen. Huang Hsin, leader of the revolution that overthrew the Ching dynasty, dies in Shanghai at the age of 43.
1947: The United Nations sets aside Oct. 24 as "United Nations Day."
1952: The China Youth Corps is organized with Chiang Ching-kuo serving as director.
1957: Tsung Dao Lee and Chen Ning Yang share the Nobel Prize for physics for work disproving the law of conservation of parity.
1958: Nobel Prize winning author Boris Pasternak is expelled from the Soviet Writers' Union and faces possible exile for his "Dr. Zhivago."
1966: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Lesotho.
1971: China Television Service, the third commercial TV network in the Republic of China, begins regular programming.
1972: The Southern Cross-Island Highway, which took four-and-a-half years to build at a cost of nearly NT$500 million, is opened to traffic.
1974: People throughout the Republic of China celebrate the 87th birthday of President Chiang Kai-shek.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan addresses leaders gathered to pay tribute to President Chiang Kai-shek on the late leader's 90th birthday, then breaks ground for the Chung Cheng Memorial Hall to honor President Chiang.
1976: Taichung port in west central Taiwan is formally opened.
1978: The Taiwan Area Freeway, with a total length of 377 km, is fully opened to traffic on the 92nd anniversary of the birth of the late President Chiang Kai-shek.
1978: The Sino-Saudi Arabian Bridge over the Choshui River in central Taiwan, which was built with low-interest loans from Saudi Arabia, opens to traffic as a part of the newly completed North-South Freeway.
1979: Representatives of retired servicemen meet at the Taipei City Auditorium to mark the first Veterans Day, also marking the 25th anniversary of the Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen.
1981: Premier Sun Yun-suan receives J.A. Guevara Moran, the minister of agriculture and pasture of the Republic of El Salvador.
1982: Wu Jung-ken, a 25-year-old MiG-19 pilot in the Communist Chinese air force who flew to a U.S. military base outside Seoul on Oct. 16, arrives in Taipei.
1983: Taipei's Kuantu Bridge, the first multi-arch steel bridge in East Asia, opens to traffic. The construction of the bridge, 809 meters long, took three years and cost NT$700 million to complete.
1984: Mrs. Indira Gandhi, Indian prime minister, is shot dead while walking in the garden of her home in New Delhi. She was 67.
1986: Madame Chiang Kai-shek presides over and addresses a mass rally at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei to mark the 100th anniversary of the birth of the late President Chiang.
1996: Former Polish President Lech Walesa visits the Republic of China.
1999: A delegation from the Taiwan Roots Medical Organization leaves for a visit to four African countries to evaluate the possibility of providing medical care to one of them.
2000: Legislator Ting Shou-chung of the opposition Kuomintang says that he is continuing to solicit more support for his proposal to recall President Chen Shui-bian.
2000: A Los Angeles-bound Singapore Airlines Boeing 747-400 jumbo jet crashes while taking off from Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, killing 81 of the 179 aboard, leaving 44 injured and 54 others unhurt.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "If you will practice a benevolent government, then the people will love all above them and will die for their officers."

DOC.HEADLINE: INNOVATION CAN HELP TAIWAN APPAREL INDUSTRY REVITALIZE ITSELF: CHEN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's traditional textile and garment industry is recasting itself as a high technology manufacturing industry, which requires innovation to allow it to create a "second spring" of development, President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday.
The president made the remarks while addressing the opening ceremony of the annual conference of the International Apparel Federation (IAF) held in Taipei.

Chen said the textile and apparel industry has traditionally been Taiwan's "golden-egg-laying hen," which has not only created a commendable number of job opportunities, but has also been a driving force behind Taiwan's go-go economic development over the last two decades.
Nowadays, Chen noted, Taiwan's textile and apparel industry has begun to take off its "traditional overcoat" and put on a new "outfit of high technology."

Chen said there is no so-called "sunset industry" in Taiwan, although there are "sunset products" and "sunset management concepts," adding that all traditional industries that seem to be out-dated can create a new era of prosperity for themselves so long as they embrace the spirit of innovation, speed and endeavor.

The president noted that all Asian countries' textile and garment industries are facing transition challenges and the task of repositioning themselves on the world stage. He said that although their counterparts in Europe and North America are leading the trends, the Asian manufacturers, from a continent with richly diverse cultures and styles, still have great potential for further development and bright business prospects.

The IAF is holding its three-day annual conference in Taipei under the auspices of the Taiwan Textile Federation with the participation of representatives from 25 member countries, most of which are from Europe and America.
This represents the second time that the IAF has held its annual meeting in Taiwan since 1991.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S 1ST CIVILIAN FLIGHT TRAINING CENTER TO BEGIN TRAINING IN APRIL

TEXT.P: Despite the fact that the civil aviation industry has since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States been facing its biggest challenges in recent history, a non-profit group has continued to push for a plan to nurture domestic pilots.

China Aviation Development Foundation (CADF) said Taiwan's first civilian flight training center, which was inaugurated Sept. 1, will start to recruit trainees next January and will begin its training courses April 1.

After receiving 18 months of intensive training, the trainees will be helped by the CADF to find work with domestic airlines, and it is expected that more than 100 pilots will be added to domestic airlines every year, according to the CADF.

Statistics compiled by the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) show that there are currently 1,511 domestic pilots and 526 foreign pilots working for domestic airlines. To cut over-reliance on foreign pilots, the CAA has in recent years been cooperating with a foundation at National Taiwan University on a project nurturing local pilots.
This year, the CADF has decided to start its own training program, hoping to diminish reliance on foreign pilots in a shorter period of time.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROL YUAN HEAD TO PRESENT TAIWAN DONATION TO NEW YORK CITY
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 30 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien is scheduled to arrive in New York City Saturday with a cash donation of nearly US$1 million that Taiwan is offering to the Big Apple in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

Chien, a veteran diplomat and ROC representative in the United States before becoming head of the Control Yuan, Taiwan's top watchdog agency, is expected to present the donation on behalf of the ROC government to New York Mayor Rudolph Giuliani in person on Sunday.

The cash donation represents the concerns and sympathy of the ROC government toward the people of New York City who suffered the trauma of the terrorist attacks, in which nearly 6,000 people were killed and the city's landmark twin towers of the World Trade Center were brought down.

Chien, who was the ROC's foreign affairs minister between 1990 and 1996, will be accompanied by staff members of the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chin Foundation, Taiwan's largest charity organization, and World Vision Taiwan, another influential charity group on the island, during the trip.

In addition to presenting the Taiwan donation to the New York City mayor, Chien is also expected to meet with representatives from New York's Chinatown, conveying the ROC government's concerns and greetings to members of the Chinese and Taiwan communities there.
Chien is the latest in a string of high-level ROC officials to recently visit New York City, with visits made by President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Chang Chun-hsiung within the past year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND PLAYS DOWN LATEST PLANNED U.S. ARMS SALES TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) on Wednesday played down the planned U.S. sales of spare parts to Taiwan for various types of military aircraft, saying that the deal is mainly for logistics supply purposes.
The ministry has traditionally refrained from making any comments on arms dealings with the United States.

An MND official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, explained that the items in the sales package unveiled by American authorities Tuesday are all spare parts for U.S.-made military aircraft now in service in the Republic of China's Air Force.
"This is a normal `cooperative logistics supply support arrangement' and does not have any sensitive significance," the official noted.

According to the official, the United States will provide spare parts for various types of military aircraft, including the F-5E/F and F-16 A/B jet fighters, and the C-130H transport planes, as well as for the U.S. systems and subsystems installed on the Taiwan-developed Indigenous Defense Fighter (IDF).

The U.S. Defense Security Cooperation Agency said Tuesday it had notified Congress of a possible agreement to provide Taiwan with spare parts and logistical support for the F-5E/F and F-16 fighter jets, the C-130H transport plane, and for the U.S. systems of the IDF aircraft.

The agency under the U.S. Department of Defense said the sale would not affect the basic military balance in the Taiwan Strait area, adding that it would also not have an adverse impact on U.S. defense readiness.
"These spare parts are required to assure that aircraft and aircraft systems previously procured from the United States are maintained in a mission ready status," the agency said in a news release.
The price tag for the new sales package is estimated at US$288 million.
Last Friday, the U.S. defense cooperation agency also announced a proposed sale of 40 JAVELIN anti-tank missile systems to Taiwan at an estimated cost of US$51 million.
If the U.S. Congress approves the sale as expected, this will represent the first addition of JAVELIN missiles to the ROC's anti-armor arsenal.

Military sources said the systems would enhance Taiwan's medium-range anti-tank capability, provide Taiwan with a strong anti-landing capability and increase its inter-operability with U.S. forces. With a range of approximately 2,500 meters, JAVELIN is equipped with an imaging infrared system and a fire-and-forget guided missile.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF PRIMARY, JUNIOR HIGH SCHOOL DROPOUTS IN TAIWAN TOPS 8,600

TEXT.P: A total of 8,666 students in Taiwan dropped out of elementary or junior high school last year, representing a dropout rate of 0.3 percent, according to recently released Ministry of Education statistics.

The statistics showed that the figure was up by 328 from the 1999 level, and the ministry estimated that some 3,000 of the dropouts might have gone missing based on an the average missing rate of 35.6 percent registered among dropouts during the 1996-1998 period.
The so-called dropouts refer to those primary and junior high school students who stop attending school and receiving their compulsory education for a long period of time.

Investigations showed that dropouts are three times to five times more likely to commit crimes than youths who remain in school and that they are likely to create many problems for society should they be unable to go back to school.
Experts and specialists have therefore called on the Ministry of Education and school authorities to take effective measures to help dropouts return to school.

In addition, the drug addiction rate among dropouts is 10 times that of youths who remain in school, experts said, adding that as many as 60 percent to 70 percent of the juvenile delinquents and young female prostitutes are dropouts.
They warned that the large pool of dropouts may have become the main source for illegal criminal rings in recruiting new blood.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASSETS MANAGEMENT COMPANIES MAY FURTHER DEPRESS REAL ESTATE MARKET

TEXT.P: Central Bank of China Deputy Governor Chen Shih-meng said Tuesday that Taiwan's sluggish real estate market might be further depressed if assets management companies (AMCs) suppress the purchasing prices too much.

Chen made the comments while addressing the opening ceremony of the seminar in Taipei Oct. 30-Nov. 1 on non-performing loans (NPLs) resolution mechanisms and their impact on the financial systems, sponsored by the Southeast Asian Central Banks Research and Training Center (SEACEN).
AMCs have functioned effectively in many countries in resuming lending and in recovering fair value of distressed assets, especially when the financial systems were in trouble.

Chen said that the establishment of AMCs is one of the mechanisms that has been applied by Taiwan's financial authorities to help solve the problem of the existence of a large number of ailing financial institutions.

The Bankers Association of the ROC set up the first AMC in Taiwan, namely the Taiwan Asset Management Co., early this year after the government gave the green light at the end of last year. Several domestic banks and international financial institutions also plan to apply for licenses.

At the SEACEN seminar, representatives from SEACEN member states are examining the causes of NPLs and their effects on banking systems. Since the Asian financial crisis, many Southeast Asian countries have adopted mechanisms to resolve the problem of NPLs and to reduce their devastating impacts on the real economy.

Since the mechanisms may have brought certain side effects, the bank executives are using the opportunity of the three-day seminar in Taiwan to review the effectiveness of the mechanisms and to share their experiences.

SEACEN was set up in 1982 with eight member central banks (Bank Indonesia, Bank Negara Malaysia, the Central Bank of Myanmar, Nepal Rastra Bank, Bangko Sentral ng Philipinas, the Monetary Authority of Singapore, the Central Bank of Sri Lanka, and the Bank of Thailand. With the addition of the Bank of Korea in 1990, the Central Bank of China, Taipei, in 1992, and the Bank of Mongolia in 1999, the regional organization has now 11 members.

The organization has conducted research studies on financial, banking and economic developments in member countries and in the region as a whole, in addition to sponsoring training programs and seminars.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, U.S. AGREE ON EXCHANGES ON ENHANCING NUKE POWER PLANT SAFETY

TEXT.P: Participants in a civil nuclear cooperation meeting between the Republic of China and the United States agreed on Wednesday to increase exchanges on nuclear power plant safety and to establish formal communication channels regarding the matter.

The participants, including more than 90 experts in nuclear energy affairs from both countries, pointed out during the two-day meeting in Hualien, eastern Taiwan, that after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States, nuclear power plant safety has become a major concern. The meeting opened Tuesday.

They discussed issues related to measures to strengthen nuclear power plant safety to deter terrorist attacks and decided to cooperate in the areas of nuclear power plant safety, examination and research on nuclear reactor control rod cracks, and emergency response plans outside nuclear power plants.

Shen Li, director of the Department of Nuclear Regulation under the Atomic Energy Council (AEC), said that since the Sept. 11 attacks, the United States has reviewed its nuclear power safety plan, adding that the AEC has also instructed the state-owned Taiwan Power Co. to step up related safety measures at the island's existing nuclear power plants.

Shen said that if Taiwan can obtain the U.S. plan, it will benefit Taiwan's safety measures regarding nuclear power plants. But he also said that the plan has to be kept secret so as not to allow terrorists to use it as a reference in planning attacks on nuclear power plants.
Both sides decided that they would not go into details regarding substantive security measures and that they would act cautiously by leaving the matter for future face-to-face meetings.

As there have been several incidents of control rod cracks at Taiwan's nuclear power plants, both sides also agreed to cooperate on research into the causes of nuclear rod cracks as well as repair and maintenance work.

On emergency responses outside nuclear power plants, both sides agreed that the AIC and the Federal Emergency Management Agency of the United States will conduct exchanges on drills, mobilization and response measures.

In response to Taiwan's "nuclear-free homeland" policy, the participants also agreed to cooperate on the decommissioning of nuclear power plants, with Taipower and the U.S. Energy Department to establish bilateral communication channels.
The AIC's Fuel Cycle and Materials Administration will also send officials to the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission to receive six-month training on the disposal of highly radioactive waste.

Alex Burkart, deputy director of the Office of Nuclear Energy Affairs under the State Department's Nonproliferation Bureau, led a 20-member delegation made up of U.S. officials responsible for nuclear affairs, environmental protection and laboratory heads to the meeting in Hualien.

During the meeting, participants also discussed the issues of nuclear energy safety, protection against radiation, nuclear power for consumers and nuclear waste disposal, as well as reviewed existing cooperation projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOLK SNACK INGREDIENT PROMISING TO BECOME IMPORTANT CASH CROP

TEXT.P: A creeper herb which can be processed into a black jelly dessert traditionally called the "Divine Grass" in Taiwan, is promising to become one of the island's most lucrative cash crops, sources from the Council of Agriculture (COA) reported Wednesday.

The "Divine Grass," whose botanical name is mesona, has recently been designated by the Cabinet-level COA as a "star" cash crop to be aggressively promoted in northern Taiwan after COA researchers found that mesona has an average cost efficiency of NT$280,000 (US$8,116) per hectare of plantation, compared with NT$80,000 (US$2,319) per hectare of paddy for rice.

Mesona, a creeper herbaceous plant, has been casually planted by farmers islandwide at the foot of orchard plants or beside vegetable fields and has until now been considered only an insignificant by-product of farming.

After conducting research for 10 years, the COA Agricultural Improvement Station in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, successfully developed a new, revised species of Taiwanese mesona, naming it the "Taoyuan No. 1."

According to the COA researchers, "Taoyuan No. 1" is best suited for cultivation in the northern Taiwan counties of Taoyuan, Hsinchu and Miaoli, and the herb's unique properties make it suitable for processing into a high-added-value instant nutritious dessert food which can be mass-produced for commercial sale.

"Taoyuan No. 1" mesona is scientifically-proven to contain a high percentage of ursolic acid and oleanolic acid -- good anti-oxidant agents which are also effective at combating tumors and lowering blood sugar levels, the researchers said.

"Taoyuan No. 1" mesona requires a much smaller amount of starch when it is processed into "Divine Grass Jelly" as it has much stronger gelatin-forming characteristics than do other dried mesona varieties which used to be imported from mainland China and Indonesia to be sold to Taiwan snack dealers at lower prices, the researchers pointed out.

Recently, Japanese researchers confirmed that mesona indeed has certain properties that have medical value and are planning to use the herb to produce a bottled anti-cancer "functional drink," according to the Taoyuan researchers.
Since mesona has never been planted in Japan, the "Taoyuan No. 1" mesona is commercially promising in terms of becoming a lucrative export to Japan for the production of the health drink, they noted.

Meanwhile, COA officials in Taoyuan are planning to promote "Taoyuan No. 1" mesona, aiming to make the herb into instant mesona packs for quiche desserts, mesona tea bags, and mesona pudding and ready-to-serve mesona dishes for sale in supermarkets.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. NOT SUPPORTIVE OF TAIWAN USING WTO `EXCLUSION PROVISION'
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 30 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. government does not support either side of the Taiwan Strait employing the "exclusion provision" against the other after the two are admitted to the World Trade Organization (WTO), a senior U.S. trade official said Tuesday.

In a speech delivered at the Foreign Press Club, U.S. Assistant Trade Representative Jeffrey Bader said there is so far no sign showing that either Taiwan or mainland China will employ the "exclusion provision" against the other after their WTO accession.
According to WTO regulations, a member is allowed to exclude another member from open market treatment under certain conditions.
Bader said he would be surprised if the two sides of the Taiwan Strait employ the "exclusion provision" against each other under the WTO framework.
In his view, Bader said, such a practice is not in the interests of either side.
It was the first time that a senior U.S. official has explicitly expressed the U.S. government's stance on this politically sensitive issue.

Sources said U.S. officials have often inquired in private whether Taiwan would employ the "exclusion provision" against mainland China after WTO entry. But this was the first time that U.S. authorities have publicly expressed their attitude of not supporting the idea of Taiwan employing that provision against the mainland.

Bader, a China hand who once served as the State Department's China desk chief under the Clinton administration, said if Taiwan and mainland China employ the "exclusion provision" against each other, their benefits from WTO accession would be restricted.

Should that be the case, he said, they would be unable to use the WTO's arbitration mechanism to resolve their bilateral trade disputes. They would also face difficulties enjoying normal trade treatment or status, he added.

Meanwhile, U.S. Trade Representative Robert Zoellick said Tuesday that the WTO would formally admit Taiwan and mainland China as its full members at its ministerial meeting scheduled for Nov. 9-13 in Qatar.
Zoellick said he doesn't think that mainland China has any tricks up its sleeve to block Taiwan's WTO entry at the upcoming meeting.
In Taipei, senior officials have on many occasions said the Republic of China government has yet to make a final decision on whether to employ the "exclusive provision" against mainland China.

Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi said Monday Taiwan will wait until the last minute to make known its decision on the "exclusion provision" issue on the grounds that there is the possibility that Beijing might use its political clout to interfere with Taiwan's WTO entry.
According to Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long, the issue regarding whether Taiwan will employ the "exclusion provision" is still under intensive assessment.
"The ROC government will make a decision based on the best interests of the nation at the most `opportune time,'" Chen said.

Under WTO regulations, if Taiwan finally decides to employ the "exclusion provision" against mainland China, it must put forth the proposal to the WTO Secretariat before the world trade regulatory body approves its membership bid.
