DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER U.S. DEFENSE SECRETARY COHEN CALLS ON ROC OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Former U.S. Secretary of Defense William Cohen on Wednesday called on Republic of China Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao and other high ranking officials.
Cohen, accompanied by a two-member entourage, arrived in Taipei Tuesday for a three-day visit.
On Wednesday morning, Cohen called on Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), and then met with Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao in the afternoon.

Cohen was originally scheduled to call on the commander-in-chief of the ROC Navy, Adm. Lee Chieh, on Wednesday afternoon. However, Adm. Lee left for Tzoying Naval Port in southern Taiwan early Wednesday morning.
Unconfirmed reports said that Cohen visited Taiwan's naval fleet in Tsoying and was briefed by Adm. Lee there earlier in the morning.

Although Cohen has stepped down from the post of defense secretary, he has comprehensive knowledge of the Asian-Pacific situation. It is generally believed that Cohen's current trip to Asia is aimed at winning the right for the company he now represents to help the ROC Navy acquire the submarines it is looking to add to its fleet.

Cohen was very friendly toward Taiwan when he was a member of the Senate and of the House of Representatives in the past. He supported the U.S. policy of engagement with Beijing but felt that an improvement in U.S.-mainland Chinese relations should not come at the expense of Taiwan's security.
During his stay in Taipei, Cohen will be received by ROC President Chen Shui-bian and call on Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen.
Cohen is expected to leave Thursday for Japan to continue his Asian trip, which will also take him to South Korea and Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STUDENTS SAID TO BE AFFECTED BY U.S. TIGHTENING OF VISA POLICY
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Oct. 30 (CNA) (By Neil Lun and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan students planning on studying in the United States will be at least indirectly affected by U.S. President George W. Bush's move to tighten restrictions regarding foreign student visas, a Republic of China official in San Francisco said Tuesday.

Huang Mei-chu, cultural section chief of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in San Francisco, said that the U.S. move targets mainly those countries that are related to terrorist activities, but he added that Taiwan students will inevitably face more restrictions, such as more rigorous screening, when they apply for student visas.

Huang said the American Institute in Taiwan, which represents U.S. interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, will also rigorously require those students applying to study in the United States to actually attend school when they issue the visas.

President Bush said Monday that the United States will tighten its visa policy, adding that the United States' generous policy in this area has been taken advantage of in the past. One of the 19 hijackers who crashed one of the planes in the Sept. 11 attacks entered the United States legally with the kind of visas routinely granted each year to foreign students, according to the U.S. Department of Justice.

But Huang also said that the real factors affecting Taiwan students' willingness to study in the United States may be on the Taiwan side, with many students choosing not to go to the United States out of safety concerns in the wake of the terrorist attacks.

In fact, even before the terrorist attacks, she said that the number of Taiwan students studying in the United States had recently been decreasing each year. The number of Taiwan students studying in America last year totaled 29,234, ranking the island as the fifth largest source of foreign students in the United States as compared with its first-place ranking in the past.

Huang noted that rising tuition fees at U.S. colleges and universities as well as Australia's and New Zealand's active solicitation of Taiwan students by promoting their lower school fees have contributed to the decline in the number of Taiwan students studying in America.

DOC.HEADLINE: UMC EXPECTS BUSINESS REVENUE TO INCREASE IN FOURTH QUARTER

TEXT.P: United Microelectronics Corp.'s business revenue might bottom out in the fourth quarter as prospects for the wireless market are improving and customers are sending in new orders, according to UMC Vice Chairman John Hsuan.
Hsuan said at an investors conference Tuesday that the company's third-quarter revenue amounted to NT$11.9 billion, down 20.3 percent from the second quarter level.
In the July-September period, UMC suffered after-tax losses amounting to NT$4 billion, as the production facility utility rate was lower than 40 percent.

The sluggish wireless market has had a great effect upon UMC, as the chip manufacturer targets mainly the market for communication products. Hsuan said that better prospects can be expected for the coming months as the wireless market is showing signs of recovery and many customers have succeeded in reducing their heavy inventories.
Although the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States may have cast uncertainty on the market, UMC is confident that business revenue will go up next year, according to Hsuan.

The market climate has affected UMC's imminent capital investment plans. Company Vice Chairman Peter Chang said that UMC reduced its capital investment from the projected NT$1.5 billion to NT$1.1 billion for the year. Judging from this year's business environment, the company may also reduce the amount of its capital investment set for next year, he added.

Most of UMC's capital investment was used to build a 12-inch wafer foundry at the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park this year and Chang emphasized that 12-inch wafers will definitely become a trend.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN ASKED TO REVISE BUDGET PROPOSAL FOR FISCAL 2002

TEXT.P: The legislative caucuses of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and New Party (NP) warned Wednesday that if the Executive Yuan fails to revise the budget proposal for fiscal 2002, they will boycott budget deliberations.
The opposition parties had complained that the current budget proposal does not reflect the actual situation and is not in line with a resolution adopted by the Legislative Yuan.
As a result, the Legislative Yuan resolved a day earlier that the Cabinet must revise the budget proposal by the end of November.

Responding to the demand, Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics chief Lin Chuan said that it is very hard to accept the demand as it would be a time-consuming task which cannot be finished in just one or two months.

The leaders of the KMT and NP legislative caucuses criticized Lin's attitude and warned that if he fails to present a revised version of the budget proposal to the Legislative Yuan by the stipulated time, the two parties will refuse to deliberate the budget.
The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) described the move as "going too far."
A DPP leader said that there is "no need" to make such a "trouble-causing" demand because the content of the budget proposal can be altered during the legislative deliberation.
The Legislative Yuan will go into a one-month recess Thursday to allow lawmakers to campaign for re-election in the Dec. 1 elections.
The KMT now controls a slim majority in the Legislative Yuan, but no single party is expected to win a simple majority in the upcoming elections.
President Chen Shui-bian has stated that he will form a coalition government after the elections, regardless the election results.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HEAD VOWS TO PROMOTE CUTTING LEGISLATIVE SEATS BY HALF

TEXT.P: Frank Hsieh, chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said Wednesday that he will do his best to promote the aim of cutting the number of legislative seats by half.

Promising that he will demand that DPP candidates in the Dec. 1 legislative elections issue a joint declaration on the matter and make it a plank in their campaign platforms, Hsieh said that he will also ask candidates from other political parties to sign a pledge in an effort to jointly promote the aim of reforming the Legislative Yuan through constitutional amendments.

Hsieh told the local press that all candidates taking part in the coming legislative race should publicly express their support for the pledge and jointly work out a timetable for the reduction by half of the 225-seat parliament.
"Only by doing so can a national consensus be forged which will be essential to launch constitutional amendments to achieve this goal," he stressed.

After the transition of power in May last year, many forms of corruption and defects have gradually emerged, Hsieh pointed out, adding that the DPP-led government is determined to probe all these cases, despite a backlash from vested interest groups.

Commenting on a question raised by Kaohsiung city councilors that the annual salaries of Kaohsiung municipal hospital presidents are too high and that their pay should be adjusted to reduce the financial burden on the city government, Hsieh said that it is unfair to compare their salaries with his own and that high pay for such experts is "necessary to protect the benefits of all citizens."

According to an income list made public by a Kaohsiung city councilor, a vice president of a Kaohsiung municipal hospital can earn NT$7.58 million per year, including an annual salary and all fringe benefits, far ahead of Hsieh's annual income of NT$2 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TRADE TIES SEE BREAKTHROUGH

TEXT.P: Trade and economic relations across the Taiwan Strait will see a breakthrough with the Cabinet approval Wednesday of a package of guidelines for expanding the scope and functions of the "offshore transshipping center."
The Cabinet approved the package at its weekly meeting, which was chaired by Premier Chang Chun-hsiung.

Chang said the passage of the package signifies the government's determination to improve cross-strait relations and to substantiate consensus reached at the Economic Development Advisory Conference held in August.
To ensure the smooth implementation of the new "open door" trade policy, Chang said the Cabinet will expand the scope and functions of the "offshore transshipping center" in a gradual manner.
In the initial stage, he said, mainland China-originating goods will be allowed to enter Taiwan for processing for export to third destinations.

"We hope mainland China can reciprocate our goodwill measures by opening more mainland ports for direct offshore cross-strait transshipping services and lifting restrictions on cross-strait cargo transportation," Chang said, adding that the two sides should resume dialogue as soon as possible to further boost bilateral trade and economic exchanges.

Government spokesman Su Tzeng-ping said that once the new package is put into force, raw materials from mainland China can be processed into semi-finished or finished products for delivery to other countries or areas.
"This will mark a big step forward in cross-strait commercial exchanges and will also help upgrade Taiwan's competitiveness in becoming a major global transshipment center," Su explained.
The package of guidelines was jointly thrashed out by the Mainland Affairs Council, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Ministry of Finance and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.
The package will be formally implemented after all those relevant government agencies have drawn up various enforcement rules, Su said.

According to the package, Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan will remain the only domestic port allowed to operate offshore cross-strait transshipping services, although its scope and functions will be expanded.
At present, mainland China-originating goods cannot enter Taiwan through the transshipping center.

Under the new package, raw materials and semi-finished mainland goods can be processed at Taiwan's export processing zones, bonded factories, science-based industrial parks and bonded warehouses for eventual delivery to other countries and areas.
Moreover, the government will no longer impose a cap on the ratio of added value after processing in Taiwan.
In addition to the existing maritime and sea-air cross-strait transshipping services, the new package will also allow the opening of cross-strait air-sea transshipping services in the future.
